HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Lots of Gore, Tantrums, Leather And Bleach

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
"Playing God" is so fond of showing bloody hands digging into bullet-punctured bodies that after its third or fourth close-up of an emergency surgical procedure, you might as well be watching a children's finger-painting class for all the impact it has. Those dripping red hands belong to Eugene Sands (David Duchovny), a down-and-out Los Angeles surgeon who becomes the pet miracle worker of a big-time counterfeiter and smuggler named Raymond Blossom (Timothy Hutton).
Eugene, a synthetic-heroin addict who lost his medical license after being caught operating while high, is "discovered" by Raymond one night in a Los Angeles drug lair where he improvises a lifesaving breathing mechanism for a gunshot victim after a shootout. The next day Raymond has Eugene kidnapped and brought to the Malibu dream house he shares with his sulky, puffy-lipped girlfriend, Claire (Angelina Jolie). Raymond magisterially appoints the unemployed surgeon to be his own private Mr. Fixit, charged with saving the lives of his bullet-riddled henchmen without their having to go to the hospital. It isn't long before the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which has been tracking Raymond, pressures Eugene into betraying his new employer. 
 "Playing God," directed by Andy Wilson from a screenplay by Mark Haskell Smith, wants so desperately to be stylishly hard-boiled that it runs wildly amok. In addition to a ridiculously high blood count, the movie heaves and strains with overripe dialogue and acting that veers between somnambulism and hysteria with nothing in between.
Mr. Duchovny's Eugene is a flat imitation of a typical Richard Gere louse, minus Mr. Gere's glinting sarcasm and facetiously cynical grins. His performance is utterly lifeless and without charm. Mr. Hutton plays Raymond, who affects bleached hair and long leather jackets, as a kind of Jack Nicholson parody, alternately growling inscrutably, then going ballistic in freakouts that even Mr. Nicholson would probably be embarrassed to see on the screen.
Raymond, unfortunately, is only one of several characters to fly into uncontrolled fits of fury. Whenever anyone, even the F.B.I. contact, gets angry, he invariably throws a full-scale tantrum. For a film that wants so badly to be cool and hip, "Playing God" is the movie equivalent of a rageaholic. Once it raises its voice, it can't stop screaming.
"Playing God" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It is extremely violent and gory, with sexual situations and abundant profanity.

PLAYING GOD
 
Directed by Andy Wilson; written by Mark Haskell Smith; director of photography, Anthony B. Richmond; edited by Louise Rubacky; music by Richard Hartley; production designer, Naomi Shohan; produced by Marc Abraham and Laura Bickford; released by Touchstone Pictures. HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Owning and Leasing;
Daewoo's British Trick: Making Dealers Vanish

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
CD-ROM no-dicker stickers to mega-car marts to digital deals on the Internet, car sellers are experimenting with techniques that may hold promise for a future where only one thing seems certain: the traditional dealership will be forced to make big changes. An approach that has proved successful in Britain may soon be adapted for the United States as the Daewoo Motor Company sets up shop.
Daewoo Motor America, the United States marketing unit of the South Korean auto maker, recently acquired property in Fairfield, Conn., for its first American dealership. Daewoo will operate the former Traynor Porsche-Audi dealership as one of its first factory-owned showrooms. In addition, Daewoo (pronounced DAY-woo) has acquired other sites for sales operations and plans to buy more. The company says it will start start selling cars in the spring. 
 Daewoo intends to operate company-owned stores where state franchise laws allow it. (New Jersey and Maryland are among the states that prohibit factory-owned dealers.) Most of the nation's car dealerships are independently owned and operated. While they do exist, factory-owned dealerships are rare and have had limited success.
In Britain, Daewoo established its beachhead with a simple plan: by running its own sales operations it would cut out the middle man. The money saved was channeled into an aggressive advertising campaign that quickly generated a high rate of brand awareness.
In addition, Daewoo created customer-friendly sales and service operations and it established a set-price, no-haggling policy, much like the one used in the United States by the Saturn unit of the General Motors Corporation. Another program that was successful in Britain, and that may be extended to the United States, according to a company representative, involves weeklong test drives. And, as the company tries to become established, it may offer a few customers extended, six-month test drives.
British consumers seem to like Daewoo's approach, and the company says sales have exceeded expectations. From April 1995 through the end of 1996, Daewoo sold more than 33,000 cars in Britain and is on track to capture 1 percent of the market. Analysts project that expansion of the company's British sales network could yield sales of 40,000 to 50,000 units a year for a market share of more than 2 percent by 2001.
And Daewoo seems to be pleasing its customers. In its most recent survey on quality and customer satisfaction, J. D. Power & Associates ranked the company fourth in Britain, ahead of established and respected auto makers like Toyota and Mazda.
Daewoo's retail outlets in Britain are often in unlikely locations, including grocery stores, to make car-buying more convenient. The company has a sales center within the nation's largest supermarket, Savacentre, in London.
Daewoo has three levels of retail outlets. Large superstores called Motor Shows sell high volumes of new cars and some used cars, and have service operations. Car Centres have smaller showrooms and focus more on service. Support Centres emphasize service and the sale of accessories.
In Britain, Daewoo advertisements portray dealers as sharks and they have disclosed a typical dealer's profit on a car sale. These methods have infuriated many conventional dealers.
Such on-the-edge advertising is unlikely in the United States. "Our ads must communicate the different car-buying and ownership experience to American consumers in compelling ways," a company spokesman said in a written response to submitted questions. Daewoo declined to make an executive available for an interview.
Certainly Daewoo is not selling a glamorous product. The cars it has been offering in Britain are aging designs based on Opel models from General Motors. But in the United States, Daewoo will sell three new models: the subcompact Lanos, the compact Nubira and the midsize Leganza.
In the United States, where Daewoo is following two other Korean auto makers, Hyundai and Kia, the company is planning full-service dealerships and scaled-down satellite stores. The satellites will be in places convenient for consumers "to experience our cars," a spokesman said, without saying specifically whether they would be sold at places like supermarkets or discount stores. Every store will feature a finger-touch computer kiosk where consumers can obtain product information.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Daewoo advertisement in Britain, left, boasted, "We delivered over 15,000 cars in our first year by removing one spare part: the dealer." Above, the Daewoo Leganza.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE REVIEW;
An Ambitious Symbol Of Newark's Pride

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
As the diva protested to the camera-toting tourist, "We are not a building!" Darn right. And neither is the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. Don't let those sturdy walls of brick and glass fool you. Newark's new center is much more than a work of architecture. It is an uproar. A commotion. A melee of civic hope.
Designed by the Los Angeles architect Barton Myers, the performing arts center is an immensely ambitious example of what has become a familiar urban genre: the recruitment of art to salvage a declining downtown. But Newark is not just any downtown. It is a city that came to symbolize urban decline after it was ripped apart by riots in the 1960's. And this $180 million project is no minor gesture in the direction of urban renewal. 
 Under the direction of its president, Lawrence P. Goldman, the performing arts center, which opens on Oct. 18 with a gala, has taken shape as a potent counter-symbol, an art riot, so to speak, or at least a cultural rally. In the years ahead, the life of this place will unfold not just inside the center but also in the streets around it.
Following a master plan developed in 1988 by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill and James Stewart Polshek & Partners, the center occupies a superb site across the street from the historic Military Park, just a block from the Passaic River. The building's relationship to the city is inspired. Start with the simple decision to forego a tunnel connecting the building to the underground parking lot beneath Military Park. Concert and theatergoers will have to take to the streets. One can appreciate this building, in fact, as a nightly transfusion of people into a city's once deserted streets.
A riverside park is in the works. Eventually, concert and theatergoers commuting from New York City will be able to take a pleasant 10-minute stroll from Newark's newly refurbished Penn Station through that park. These plans are light years from the days when developers believed no one would venture into Newark unless new office towers came equipped with skywalks. Skyscrapers are wonderful. Skywalks are a contradiction in terms.
The center's exterior is contextual. Its red brick walls, relieved by contrasting masonry bands and columns of stone, employ an industrial vocabulary, with clear roots in the handsome factory buildings that still grace the city's periphery. A steel canopy, suspended over the entrance, reinforces the industrial look with a metallic nod in the direction of the blackened superstructure of a nearby bridge. On the main facade, expanses of glass frame sparkling views of the lobby. Visitors can also enter through a small templelike rotunda, tucked into the facade's western corner. The rotunda's curving edge reads from afar as the hinge of a door thrown open in welcome.
The center's high spots are its two theaters. Prudential Hall, the largest of these, seats 2,750. It is breathtakingly glamorous. If you don't say "ooh" when you walk through the door, you will at least say "aah." Otherwise, please rent a video, make some popcorn and stay home.
The hall is classical in form and spirit: four-tiered and horseshoe-shaped, glittering with light. The color scheme varies slightly from the traditional red and gold. There's red galore, but in place of gilded plaster, the tiers are faced with panels of beautiful golden wood. These are studded with wooden medallions, an acoustical device and a visual delight, picked out with twinkling lamps.
Red fabric panels can be lowered over the auditorium's red plaster walls to change the hall's acoustics. Movable wooden "towers," each 40 feet tall, can be shifted to alter the stage configuration. An acoustical reflector overhead can project beyond the proscenium frame. Its dimensions and angle will vary according to the kind of performance -- orchestral, dance or pop music.
A ceiling dome of molded white plaster billows overhead, its circumference ringed with lights. The dome awaits the installation of a chandelier. A pity some local muralist has not been commissioned to represent a Newark heaven. Even so, stage and auditorium have been combined into one warm, embracing room. The region has not seen as fabulous a new hall since Philip Johnson's New York State Theater opened its doors three decades ago.
The 514-seat Victoria Theater is a gem of more modest size and cut, a smoky amethyst of a room, with walls of gray and rose brick and seating upholstered in an iridescent fabric that shifts in tone from green to plum. Intended for more experimental productions and children's theater, it's a spare, serious space that may hold the key to the center's future as a place where art is produced as well as consumed. Though the auditorium is small, the stage is vast and equipped to handle sophisticated productions. Why adopt an industrial esthetic unless you intend to produce?
The center's vast lobby areas are much less successful. There is simply too much going on. Structural steel rods poking out of the ceiling. Miles of patterned carpet. Balconies faced here with glass, there with curved panels of wood. Floors inlaid with colored stones. Copper elevator doors. Copper handrails. An exterior promenade paved with glass block. One could go on. Do I have to come right out and say it? Please promise not to tell anyone. The lobby is a mess.
Still, it's a mess worth pausing over, because it raises an issue of general concern: How to create visual richness without going out of control? This design also compels one to ask why some messes are better than others. After all, many architects today celebrate heterogeneity as an ideal esthetic for these culturally fractured times. Isn't heterogeneity just a $10 word for mess? Why isn't Barton Myers's mess as appealing as the messes designed by Frank Gehry, Eric Owen Moss, or Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown?
The answer is that they deal with mess from a philosophical point of view. When Mr. Venturi and Ms. Scott Brown make different visual vocabularies collide, the collision is exaggerated and deliberate. Mr. Moss's architectural collages are held together by intuition, not by repeated materials and forms. Mr. Gehry's fragmented buildings gradually unfold into unified spatial patterns.
Pattern, in two and three dimensions, is the issue here. It turns out that modern architects were more successful than post-modernists have been at enriching buildings with pattern. Thomas Beebe, the architect, once observed that modernists excelled at pattern-making because it was integral to the Beaux Arts training many of them received. But the manipulation of abstract, two-dimensional pattern was also the first thing students were taught in a Bauhaus-style education.
The idea that modern architecture was visually destitute was usually based on poor examples, like the Avenue of the Americas in midtown Manhattan. But other modern cityscapes -- like the condominium towers on Collins Avenue north of the Art Deco District in Miami Beach or the high-rise social housing on the outskirts of Barcelona -- present a different picture. Buildings in these areas offer patterns of remarkable variety through the simple manipulation of windows, mullions, spandrels, balconies and the random patterns of reflections, curtains and interior lighting. A street full of googie buildings can add up to a remarkably rich environment. A few contemporary architects, like Rem Koolhaas and Architectonica, have clearly picked up on this idea.
Though Mr. Myers tries to stay within an architectonic framework, he's embroidered the structure with more elements than he manages to control, visually or spatially. The eye keeps taking refuge in details, because the space never comes into focus. Churlish as it may be to rain on Newark's parade, the fact must be stated clearly: Architecture, too, is a performing art. The center's management would not dream of presenting less than top-flight work on its stages. There's no reason to relax standards when it comes to architecture, an art form that goes on playing year after year.
Enough. The center's shortcomings will fade into the background when the lobby is full of people, especially at night, when the glazed, brightly lit spaces will project an animated social spectacle into the recovering city outside. And the building's heart is in the right place around the clock.

Parking is available at a garage under Military Park and in two street-level parking lots across the street from the center; daily parking fees are $7 and $10, with limited valet service available for $15. Getting There
 
BY CAR: From Manhattan, take the Lincoln Tunnel to the New Jersey Turnpike to Exit 15W (Newark/the Oranges); pick up route 280 west and continue to Exit 15A, which leads to Route 21 south; take Route 21 south, which is also McCarter Highway, and continue to Center Street; turn right onto Center Street and continue to the performing arts center.
BY TRAIN: Take New Jersey Transit from Penn Station in Manhattan to Penn Station in Newark (one-way fare, $2.50; free for children 11 and younger on weekends). There are also PATH trains to Penn Station in Newark leaving from the World Trade Center, Tower 1, in lower Manhattan; one-way fare, $1. A loop bus operates daily from Penn Station in Newark to the performing arts center, with stops in -between; fare, $1 one-way. New Jersey Transit information: (201) 762-5100. PATH information: (800) 234-7284.

SECTION: Section A; Page 34; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 213 words

HEADLINE: Working Less in France

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "French Premier Proposes Cutting Workweek to Create Jobs" (news article, Oct. 11): You translate the French theory behind the shorter workweek as a scheme to take a given economic pie and "divide it into smaller slices." If the aim of the shorter workweek is austerity, why is it so vehemently opposed by the French employer federation? As you report, the French Socialists have been forced by the unions to embrace the shorter workweek, with no loss in pay. Where is the austere discipline in this demand?
You also suggest that "other European countries have rejected such an approach." In fact, in recent weeks, the demand for shorter workweeks has been embraced by Spain's opposition Socialists and resuscitated by Germany's Social Democrats and labor leaders. 
 In Italy, the Communists temporarily brought down the center-left government when the prime minister rejected proposals for a shorter workweek. European Union countries will soon introduce maximum work time regulations as part of the "social chapter" of the Maastricht treaty. It is probably the relative isolation of the American labor movement that has kept labor leaders from embracing the popular program. Still, we can hope.
 
JONATHAN CUTLER
New York, Oct. 15, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

SECTION: Section A; Page 35; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 673 words

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
Grounds for Hope

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina

 BODY:
"The situation is better," President Alia Izetbegovic said. "There is hope for the future in Bosnia."
Coming from Mr. Izetbegovic, who has often taken a somber view of his country's prospects, the comment was notable. And it was echoed by many others I met here -- editors, politicians, international experts. 
 Why the optimism? President Izetbegovic and others gave several reasons.
First they mentioned progress in dealing with indicted war criminals. President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia has just sent to the International War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague 10 accused Croats who he said had "voluntarily" turned themselves in. It was a powerful signal of international commitment to the Dayton agreement. For Mr. Tudjman acted, after long delay, under heavy American pressure. That is a second fundamental reason for the optimism: the more decisive, vigorous U.S. policy since Secretary of State Albright visited here in May.
The most important indicted figure still at large is Radovan Karadzic, who led the Serbs in their genocidal war. But his influence in the Serbian half of Bosnia, the Republika Srpska, has been greatly reduced by his conflict with its President, Biljana Plavsic.
Another reason is the recent seizure by the international force here, SFOR, of four transmission towers used by Serbian television in Pale. SFOR acted at the request of the international civilian High Representative, Carlos Westendorp, who made the decision because Pale television broadcast ethnic hate and called the SFOR troops Nazis.
The clampdown on Pale television, Dr. Karadzic's mouthpiece, is seen by many as a crucial step because of the way television was used by Serbian leaders to rouse the ultranationalism that led to the war. Broadcasts depicted Muslims and Croats as killers of Serbs. Haris Silajdzic, the Bosnian Prime Minister, said there was "a collective paranoia created by the media."
The four seized towers now transmit broadcasts from Banja Luka, Mrs. Plavsic's headquarters. They are far less hateful, though news programs ignore the other half of Bosnia or cover events there as part of foreign news.
Many say that democracy cannot grow in Bosnia without independent, professional broadcasting. Mr. Westendorp is now proposing a transitional measure to assure nonpartisan television. He has asked the contact group of countries sponsoring the international effort to approve creation of a board of judges and journalists -- part international, part local -- to set editorial standards and enforce them until Bosnia creates a similar system of its own.
President Izetbegovic volunteered, in our conversation, that the Westendorp proposal "should apply to us, too." Bosnia state television is relatively mild on ethnic matters but boosts the Izetbegovic party, the S.D.A. A Croat-run station broadcasting from Mostar is more biased; its weather map colors the Croat-dominated area of Bosnia as part of Croatia.
Sarajevo itself is a concrete sign of progress. There are still shattered buildings everywhere. But the electric trams are running again, and new shops open day after day, giving the city a bit of the cosmopolitan look it once had.
For most people economic conditions remain tough. Seventy percent rely on remittances from abroad or family members who have jobs with international organizations. But the mood is not dejected.
One thing seems absolutely clear: No part of this modest-sized country can attract investment -- can prosper -- as a separate state. That is one reason a recent rash of op-ed articles in American papers urging partition of Bosnia puzzles Bosnians. They know also that any attempt at partition would mean more war.
But the talk of partition is irresponsible for a larger reason. It would mean yielding to the most vicious racism in Europe since the Nazis, and destroying a country that is a multi-ethnic symbol. Why do that just when Dayton shows signs of working?
"The plan was to kill Bosnia," Prime Minister Silajdzic said. "That's not possible anymore."

HEADLINE: A Soaring Dow Masks Inflation

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Robert Eisner argues against raising interest rates in "When Bad Economic Theory Threatens Good Times" (Op-Ed, Oct. 11). But the issue is when interest rates should rise, and why. The stock market's doubling in less than three years is said to reflect growing earnings and a sound economy. But price earnings ratios that are at all-time highs are a form of inflation.
Soaring financial assets are a problem even when the cost of living is stable because the higher they rise, the harder they fall. Then, the ripple effects on pension funds, insurance companies and banks would be felt, and the average person, as well as the wealthy, would pay. 
 Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, is pursuing a shrewd policy of jaw-boning long-term interest rates up and the stock market down, to control the asset bubble.
Mr. Greenspan has warned that it would be foolish to expect earnings to continue to rise at such a pace. If he is right, stocks will be less attractive and the market will flatten, whether the Fed raises interest rates or not. But if the market continues to rise based on unrealistic earnings expectations, he seems to be saying the Fed will raise rates.
 
JOHN T. BENNETT
Alexandria, Va., Oct. 14, 1997
 
The writer is an economist.

LENGTH: 416 words

HEADLINE: A Bad Patent Bill

 BODY:
The Senate is considering a misguided bill to recast the patent laws in ways that would threaten small inventors and dampen the innovative spirit that helps sustain America's economy. The bill is so mischievous that it has attracted an unusual coalition of opponents -- including the icon of liberal economists, Paul Samuelson, the icon of conservative economists, Milton Friedman, and 26 other Nobel Prize-winning scientists and economists.
Patent laws currently require inventors to disclose their secrets in return for the exclusive right to market their product for up to 20 years. Early disclosure helps the economy by putting new ideas immediately into the hands of people who, for a fee to the patent holder, find novel and commercially applicable uses for these ideas. Extended protection, meanwhile, provides a huge incentive for inventors to keep inventing. The American system generates more and better patent applications than any other country's. 
 The Senate bill would weaken patent protection for small inventors by requiring inventors who file for both American and foreign patents to publish their secrets 18 months after filing rather than when the patent is issued. Small inventors say that premature publication gives away their secret if their application fails. It would also allow large corporations with the financial muscle to fend off subsequent legal challenges to maneuver around the patent even if it is later issued.
Worse, the bills would encourage corporations to avoid the patent process altogether. Under current law, companies that rely on unpatented trade secrets run the risk that someone else will patent their invention and charge them royalties. The Senate bill would permit companies whose trade secrets are later patented by someone else to continue to market their products without paying royalties. Encouraging corporations to hide secrets is the opposite of what an economy that relies on information needs.
Pesky patent holders do in fact get in the way of large corporations. But the economy thrives on independent initiative. Small inventors need ironclad patent protection so that they are not forced into a legal scrum with financial giants. The House of Representatives and the Senate Judiciary Committee approved the patent bill without hearing the country's leading economists and scientists make their case. Senate sponsors now say they will try. Congress needs to hear the critics out before proceeding to any more votes.

HEADLINE: Aid From Rich Nations to Poor Fell in 1996

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Foreign aid to the world's poorest countries has fallen to its lowest point in half a century, a report by private relief groups said this week.
The new survey, "The Reality of Aid," bases its conclusions on figures collected by 21 members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, which includes 25 leading industrial nations. It was published on Wednesday and released in the United States by Interaction, a Washington coalition of 150 United States agencies. 
 The amount of aid to developing nations from these 21 countries fell $3.8 billion in 1996, to $55.8 billion, the study found. This represents only one-quarter of 1 percent of the total gross domestic product of the 21 countries, down from one-third of 1 percent in 1992.
The United States had the lowest ratio of foreign assistance, with 0.12 percent of its gross domestic product going to help developing nations, including assistance to Israel.
Japan has also made deep cuts in foreign assistance, the study shows; though it remains the largest donor, Japan reduced aid by 15 percent between 1995 and 1996. An unfavorable exchange rate accounted for some of that decline.
Eleven industrial countries reduced their foreign aid in 1996, the report said. At the same time, private groups increased their aid by $80 million, to $234 billion, more than four times the amount provided by governments.
More than 1.3 billion people live in absolute poverty by world measures -- on income of less than $1 a day.
Because many live in countries with high population growth, the numbers of poor people grow even as poverty-reduction programs begin to make headway, James Gustave Speth, the administrator of the United Nations Development Program, said today. The United Nations has set aside Friday as the International Day for the Eradication of Poverty.
Mr. Speth also said today that private investment in the developing world was far from the panacea that some aid specialists predicted a few years ago. At least 90 percent of private investment has gone to China or to middle-income countries, a number of them in Asia. The 50 poorest countries got less than 1 percent of the investment.
Two-thirds of the people living in developing countries get by on less than $2 a day, Mr. Speth said.
The report also said the export of surplus farm products to developing nations, particularly from Europe, was damaging the livelihoods of farmers even as it relieved food shortages.
The European Union's export of subsidized beef to South Africa, for example, had led to a financial loss to that country's producers of something equivalent to 95 percent of Europe's aid there, the group said.
The study called for more debt relief for the poorest countries and said that the international monetary organizations were refusing to help the poorest countries while bailing out economies like those of Mexico and Thailand.

HEADLINE: Racing to Be First With a Harmless Substitute for a Cleaning Solvent

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
For the last six weeks, Jeffrey L. Battiston, the owner of a dry cleaning chain in West Hartford, Conn., has secretly been testing what could be the Holy Grail of his industry: a substitute for the toxic but commonly used cleaning solvent perchlorethylene that he said is harmless to the environment, nonflammable and cleans just as well as perc.
Meanwhile, a company using technology developed by scientists at Hughes Aircraft Company and at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, the birthplace of the atomic bomb, is just months away from a nationwide test of a machine that scrubs clothes with liquid carbon dioxide. And researchers at the University of California at Los Angeles are readying a report showing that dry cleaners who switch to machines that use water can defy industry expectations and clean nearly all kinds of clothes. 
 Across the country, teams of chemists, physicists, economists and entrepreneurs are hurriedly finishing off years of research and rushing to sell what each hopes will become a new industry standard for the nation's 37,000 dry cleaning establishments, most of which have relied on perc for decades.
Propelling that race are mounting concerns about the harmful effects of perc -- which include unpleasant odors, lower air quality, polluted ground water and tainted breast milk -- and increasingly strict regulations that experts say could force hundreds of dry cleaners in New York State alone to close up shop by the end of 1998. The increased concern was demonstrated most recently by the evacuation of a Harlem elementary school that had once been a dry cleaning plant.
Yesterday, Mark J. Green, the New York City Public Advocate, requested a new law that would shut down dry cleaning plants in residential buildings if they were cited three times for leaking illegal levels of perc.
In West Hartford, Mr. Battiston is testing Rynex, a new solvent developed by a Woodbury, N.Y., company. The solvent can be used in conventional dry cleaning machines after minor adjustments, which the company said would cost a few hundred dollars and could be completed in less than an hour. Mr. Battiston said that since he began using Rynex in late August, he had cleaned at least 5,000 garments with the new solvent, without their owners' knowledge.
"I haven't heard any complaints," said Mr. Battiston. "Two customers called just to say they smelled something different, and they asked me what it was."
Several customers interviewed yesterday said they, too, could smell a difference, but preferred it to the familiar scent of clothes cleaned in perc. Ellen Brassil-Horak, who picked up two blazers yesterday morning that had been cleaned overnight in Rynex, said they had "a very sanitary smell."
Mr. Battiston, a third-generation dry cleaner whose three stores handle 6,000 garments a week, said he had no financial stake in Rynex Holdings Ltd., the maker of the chemical. Rather, he said, he agreed to try it because "it really could save our industry."
"At least it could save it from a lot of headaches," Mr. Battiston said. "Let's face it, our industry's taken a lot of heat the last few years."
Industry experts remain cautious about Rynex Holdings, which lost credibility after previous promises of a replacement for perc failed to materialize. "I've got to see it to believe it," said William Seitz, executive director of the Neighborhood Cleaners Association-International, a trade group in Manhattan.
But William A. Hayday, an engineer who heads Rynex Holdings, said that tests were about to begin in two more cities, and that the product could be on the market by the end of the year.
If Mr. Hayday's invention does not untie the dry cleaning industry's Gordian knot, several competitors are preparing to cut through it.
In Los Angeles, Robert Gottlieb, director of U.C.L.A.'s Pollution Prevention Education and Research Center, said that a 12-month study of a "wet cleaning" shop had shown that cleaning clothes in water is, indeed, a viable alternative to dry cleaning for nearly all garments. Although the technology is several years old, Mr. Gottlieb said, there are fewer than 300 shops nationwide that specialize in wet cleaning -- including the Ecomat stores in New York -- partly because of a widespread industry belief that water is appropriate for only about 40 percent of garments. He said his report would show that perceived problems of shrinkage and bleeding can be controlled by computerized washers and dryers without sacrificing profitability.
Cleaning "dry clean only" garments in water so defies the conventional wisdom among dry cleaners, however, that at least two research groups are working on cleaning processes that would require investments of tens of thousands of dollars by shopkeepers.
In Raleigh, N.C., scientists at the University of North Carolina and North Carolina State University who invented a detergent that dissolves in liquid carbon dioxide have formed a spinoff company, MiCell Technologies, to bring the technology to market. R. Bradley Lienhart, the company's chief executive, who formerly oversaw production of perchlorethylene at Dow Chemical Corporation, said that MiCell would have its first prototype ready by the end of the year. The machines will sell for about $125,000, he said.
And in El Segundo, Calif., Global Technologies has licensed a similar carbon dioxide-based cleaning process, originally developed by Hughes Aircraft and scientists at Los Alamos to clean aircraft parts. Jack Belluscio, a Queens native who heads the company, said that prototypes would be ready for testing in five cities by next summer.
Mr. Belluscio said he had met with officials of the New York State Environmental Facilities Corporation this week, asking them to offer loans to dry cleaners to help them convert to his machines, which will retail for up to $80,000. In exchange, he said, he offered to make New York one of the five test cities.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1802 words

HEADLINE: Scrubbing the Air, Buffing the Cleaners;
Belated E.P.A. War on Pollutants May Infuse Value Into Companies

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
A few years ago, Nina Bergan French started Sky+ to perfect and sell a still rough but promising new method for analyzing toxic metals that she had licensed from a Federal research laboratory. She was certain that the Clean Air Act of 1990 would provide a ready-made market. But the years passed and the Environmental Protection Agency still did not crack down on the metallic contaminants. Ms. French lost her license, and switched Sky+ to government consulting to pay her bills.
Now, the E.P.A. is testing several monitoring devices, including the one Ms. French gave up, as it prepares to clamp down on airborne toxic metals. "Finally, the E.P.A. may create a market for me," said Ms. French, who wants Sky+ to do environmental consulting work for industry. 
 After several years of what polluting industries have called reasonable delays but what environmentalists call foot-dragging, the E.P.A. seems poised to tighten restrictions on smog, soot and airborne pollutants.
Its main targets are cars and other vehicles, particularly buses and trucks with diesel engines. But the agency is also aiming at factories and power plants. Specifically, it is expected to soon force industry to filter out soot particles that are one-fourth the size of the ones regulated now, to clamp down on emissions of nitrogen oxide and other compounds that form ozone, and to reduce allowable levels of toxic-metal molecules spewing from smokestacks.
Utilities and steel companies are complaining of multibillion-dollar costs. But air-pollution-control companies, many of which have not seen a profit for years, are singing of a multibillion-dollar market.
"The opportunities are breathtaking," said Jeffrey C. Smith, executive director of the Institute of Clean Air Companies, which predicts that sales of air-cleaning equipment, which have been flat for several years, will rise 7 percent annually.
Predictions, of course, aren't the same as money in the bank, and Wall Street, expensively fooled before by the false promise in environmental stocks, remains aloof.
The skepticism is understandable. R. Steven Maxwell, managing director of the Technology Strategic Group, an environmental consulting firm, estimates that $100 invested in environmental stocks 10 years ago would have grown to $300 by the early 1990's -- but would have shrunk to just $30 today.
Now, though, the pieces for a recovery seem to be falling into place. "This may not be a bonanza waiting to happen," Mr. Maxwell said, "but this will be a good business for companies that get it right."
The prospect of new E.P.A. rules -- assuming Congress does not countermand them -- is not all that's sending optimistic breezes wafting through the pollution-control industry. American manufacturers will soon have to replace the creaky precipitators, scrubbers and other air-cleaning devices that they installed two decades ago. Orders from Europe and Asia are soaring. And analysts speculate that the deregulation of the utility industry, now in its early stages, will spur interest in newer, cheaper pollution controls, as the utility companies compete to offer the lowest-cost electricity.
"Deregulation will drive the question of pollution-control investment even faster than E.P.A. standards," predicted William G. Rosenberg, president of E3 Ventures, an environmental consulting firm.
Indeed, Robert McIlvaine, president of the McIlvaine Company, an environmental market research concern, predicts that by the year 2006, power plants alone will spend $17 billion a year to remove sulfur from flue gases. And, he calls the proposed nitrogen oxide rules "the most attractive U.S. environmental business opportunity ever."
The environmental industry is primed to respond. Companies like Bee-Line Software are touting programs that can model how changes in fuel mixtures will affect emissions. Manufacturers like Thermatrix Inc., formed in 1992 to make low-temperature flameless oxidizers that neutralize organic pollutants without forming nitrogen oxide, are aggressively chasing sales. And, industry experts say, there are more products in the pipeline.
"People don't talk when they're working on a new black box because they're afraid someone will steal their idea," said William C. Anderson, head of the American Academy of Environmental Engineers.
Companies with older technologies are dusting off brochures, too. The Engelhard Corporation, for one, predicts annual sales of its decades-old nitrogen oxide-removal catalytic system to reach at least $50 million in 2001, five times current volume. And it hypothesizes a $1 billion market for a newer catalyst that converts ozone to oxygen.
"The technologies have been waiting for the regulations to show up," said Daniel W. Parker, Engelhard's general manager for environmental technologies, "and now it looks like they will."
Signs of hope abound. Advertising in the Air and Waste Management Association's magazine, which had dropped precipitously in the last three years, is way up again. And John A. Thorner, the group's executive director, said booths were already selling briskly for his annual technology conference in June.
The resurgence comes none too soon. One of the country's most thriving industries a decade ago, the air-pollution-control business has declined steadily in the 90's.
Sure, a few companies with special market niches did well. The Smith Environmental Corporation, a subsidiary of Haden Maclellan Holdings P.L.C. of Britain, has had steady growth in sales to paper companies of devices intended to destroy ozone-forming compounds -- in good part, Smith's president, Robert C. Hyde, suggested because the forest-products industry has "never been as good as the utilities at pressuring Washington to delay rules."
Companies with products that cut costs as well as pollutants have also done well. Turbodyne Technologies Inc., a six-year-old maker of "air enhancement flow" products that increase fuel efficiency as well as reduce pollutants, has seen sales increase steadily, to $55 million this year. "People are more receptive if they don't have to trade fuel economy for clean air," said Edward M. Halimi, Turbodyne's founder.
But most air-cleaning products represent an end-of-the-pipeline cost with no inherent savings. And for the companies that sell them, the last seven years have been a financial disaster. Many small ones have gone out of business, and despite the rosy future that supposedly lies just over the horizon, even some industry stalwarts are bailing out.
Wheelabrator Air Pollution Control Inc., which in 1992 branched into fancy machines to control and monitor ozone-forming pollutants, has retreated back to its core scrubbers and precipitators for removing dust and sulfur dioxide. "The market didn't develop, because E.P.A. did not promulgate its rules," said Paul J. Feira, the company's president.
Air and Water Technology's Research Cottrell division, whose name was once synonymous with scrubbers and electrostatic precipitators to the point that such devices are called "cottrells" in much of Europe, has been losing money and is looking for a buyer. Last month, General Electric Power Systems, a unit of the General Electric Company, sold Environmental Services Inc., which does about $50 million in sales a year, to a Canadian company, Marsulex Inc., for $13 million. "It never became a strategic part of our $7.3 billion power-generation business," a G.E. spokesman, Bruce Bunch, said.
Wall Street has jumped ship, too. Share prices for Environmental Elements, Wahlco Environmental Systems and Thermatrix -- all pure plays that only make pollution-control devices -- have plummeted. "No one thinks the environmental industry is a good investment these days," said John T. Schofield, Thermatrix's chairman.
That sounds like an understatement to Joan B. Berkowitz, managing director of the consulting firm Farkas Berkowitz & Company. "Being labeled an environmental firm is the kiss of death with investors," she said.
But if buyers for environmental stocks remain scarce, buyers for environmental companies are starting to appear. "We're getting interest from companies that want to enter this business, and even from financial players who just see profits to be made," a high-ranking executive at Research Cottrell said.
Similarly, Physical Sciences Inc., which makes spectroscopes that use spark plugs to measure an airstream's components, already has a loan from the Small Business Administration and is talking to several large companies about an infusion of cash to develop the market.
"The investment community is still leery, but we're exploring licensing and partnerships," said Michael L. Finson, the company's executive vice president, who said new E.P.A. rules could more than double his annual sales of $16 million.
The new rules are not a done deal. In fact, the Air Quality Standards Coalition, a multi-industry group formed to fight stricter rules, is still lobbying with members of Congress to forestall the smog and soot regulations, arguing that they will cost 200,000 jobs and $150 billion.
Some coalition members, speaking off the record, concede that the last-ditch effort will probably fail, and that the new rules will take hold by next year, at the latest. Still, it will take longer than that for most air-cleaning companies to feel well off.
For one thing, the juiciest markets are in Europe and Asia. In a novel marketing partnership, Turbodyne is donating half a percent of gross sales to the United Nations, which in April gave the company's technology United Nations flag status -- a designation that endorses it for improving conditions in third world countries, and qualifies it for marketing and publicity assistance from the United Nations Development Program's Global Technology Group.
But few other environmental companies have the cash or connections to cultivate relationships in other countries.
And competition is intense, not only among pollution-control firms but from purveyors of clean-burning fuels, from engineers who tinker with industrial processes to stop pollutants from forming, and from chemical companies that refine formulas for paint or other substances so that they do not emit fumes.
"There are dozens and dozens of new technologies coming on line that could meet the regulations," said Gary S. Guzy, counselor to the E.P.A. Administrator, Carol M. Browner. "And in the long term, solar energy and biomass fuels will be developed that meet air-quality rules."
Still, it seems, none of the obstacles can prevent optimism from pervading an industry that is bone-weary from years of depression.
Or, as Mr. Smith, the trade association executive, put it, "It's not something to pop champagne corks over, but things are definitely getting better."

Electrostatic precipitators -- Used to clean smokestack emissions.
 
Catalytic reduction -- Reduces nitrogen oxide from coal- and oil-fired boilers.
 
Scrubbers -- Remove 95% of sulfur dioxide emissions from utility boilers' smokestacks.
 
Valve seals and detection equipment -- For controlling and detecting leaks in pipes in chemical and oil refineries.
 
New coolants -- Air-conditioners use alternative gases for cooling instead of ozone-depleting chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's.
 
Catalytic converters -- Used on wood-burning stoves to make them cleaner.
 
New paints and coatings -- Used on consumer products to make them free of noxious fumes. (Source: Environmental Protection Agency)(pg. D5)

HEADLINE: Social Security Benefits to Increase 2.1%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
The tens of millions of Americans who get Social Security and other Federal benefits will get an increase of 2.1 percent in their checks in January, the second-smallest raise since automatic cost-of-living adjustments began in 1975, the Government said today.
From the recipients' point of view, the skimpy increases are the not-so-pleasant aspect of the nation's success in subduing inflation, as most goods, such as shoes, creep up slowly while a few, such as used cars, actually decline. Even inflation in services is under 3 percent. 
 There was further evidence of that trend today when the Consumer Price Index for September, which provided the final piece of data for calculating the benefits increase for 1998, showed that prices edged up by two-tenths of 1 percent, a bit less than most economists had expected and the same increase as in July and August.
"Today's news confirms that inflation remains under control," said Kenneth S. Apfel, Commissioner of the Social Security Administration. Seeking to take the edge off possible disappointment that the average monthly benefit will rise only $16 a month, he added, "Low inflation is good for America, particularly for many Social Security beneficiaries with limited incomes."
The Treasury, of course, on behalf of taxpayers, benefits from paying out less in cost-of-living adjustments. Still, even the small increase might overcompensate for price increases, because it is based on the Consumer Price Index, which many experts say exaggerates actual inflation.
One reason is that the index is intended to measure not the cost of living but a relatively fixed basket of goods and services and thus does not allow for the fact that if the price of, say, roast beef rises sharply, consumers tend to switch to less expensive hamburger or chicken.
Nonetheless, even by that gauge, inflation has been modest. And in September, the so-called core price index, which excludes the wide-swinging food and energy components, was up only two-tenths of 1 percent, like the overall index.
"What we see is strong, constant and relentless downward pressure on prices," William J. Hudson, chief executive of AMP Inc., a large Harrisburg, Pa., electronics company, told a gathering here of the National Association of Manufacturers. He and other speakers cited global competition and productivity improvements as the main factors preventing revived inflation despite an uninterrupted business expansion of more than six years.
And the only signs of upward pressure on labor costs, added Dana G. Mead, chairman of Tenneco Inc., are for workers in high technology.
Today's report, economists said, lent little support to any inclination the Federal Reserve might have to tighten monetary policy to slow the economy down. "If Mr. Greenspan was in search of some basis for raising interest rates, he did not get it," said Joel L. Naroff, chief bank economist in Philadelphia for the First Union Bank.
Some, however, such as Frank McCormick, senior economist at the Bank of America, were less sanguine. "We see this as sort of the end of the good news on inflation," he said, predicting that higher oil prices and the dollar's decline in world currency markets would contribute to Fed decisions to raise rates twice, in quarter-point increments, by spring.
Although the C.P.I. report showed energy prices jumping 1.3 percent last month, this had little overall effect since energy accounts for only 7 percent of the index.
Food inflation decelerated to one-tenth of 1 percent, aided by a downturn in coffee prices following six month of increases totaling 24.2 percent. Prices of apparel rose following a sharp August decline and air fares, a choppy component, 2.1 percent. Prices of new and used cars showed little change last month but used cars are now 5.6 percent cheaper than in September 1996.
Separate reports today showed that first-time claims for unemployment benefits edged up 2,000 last week, to 306,000, while business inventories during August rose two-tenths of 1 percent.
Social Security benefits for the average retiree will rise to $765 a month from $749, the agency said, with the maximum benefit for a worker retiring at age 65 in January set at $1,342.
The average benefit for an aged couple who both receive benefits will rise to $1,288; a widowed mother and two children will get $1,522; an aged widow or widower will get $731, and a disabled worker with a spouse and one or more children will get $1,198, all of these reflecting increases of 2.1 percent. The only year in which the percentage increase in payments was lower was 1987.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Census Report Shows Suburban Growth

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In 1995, the economic expansion in the New York region was strongest in some of the wealthiest suburban counties surrounding New York City -- Bergen in New Jersey, Fairfield in Connecticut and Putnam in New York -- according to an analysis released yesterday by the Federal Bureau of the Census.
Although the report offered no more recent data -- providing a well-documented but lagging indicator, as is typical of the Census -- it revealed a geographic portrait of the New York region during a year when economic expansion was beginning to accelerate after more than five years of little or no growth. 
 As measured by the number of businesses and payrolls in each county, those that fared best combined large concentrations of people commuting to jobs in Manhattan and prosperous suburban economies. Manhattan fared about as well as the best-performing suburban counties.
In Bergen County, the number of businesses increased by 3 percent, to 32,034, while the annual payrolls for those businesses increased 9 percent, to $14.6 billion, the report said.
In Putnam, a more sparsely populated county, the number of businesses grew 10 percent, to 2,119, the report said, and the annual payroll rose 8 percent, to $403.3 million. In Fairfield, the number of businesses increased 5 percent, to 91,189, it said, and the annual payroll rose 8 percent, to $47.1 billion.
The report said that the number of Manhattan companies rose 2 percent, to 99,779, and that annual payrolls jumped 9 percent, to $92.2 billion. THOMAS J. LUECK

HEADLINE: No Talks, Just Faxes, in Amtrak Dispute

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Amtrak and the union that may strike over wages next week did not meet today but traded unfriendly faxes, each making statements that threaten the continued operation of Amtrak and commuter lines across the country.
The head of the bargaining committee for the union, the Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employees, said today that it had reached an agreement with Metra, the commuter rail agency in the Chicago area, that would allow that line to continue running if there was a strike. 
 The union has been negotiating for three years and will be free to strike at 12:01 A.M. Wednesday.
The union also released a copy of a letter it sent today to Transportation Secretary Rodney Slater, repeating its commitment not to interfere with commuter railroads.
But the head of the bargaining committee, Jed Dodd, cautioned that his union might not be so friendly toward commuter lines operated by Amtrak, like Marc in Maryland and Washington, the Shoreline East in Connecticut and the Purple Line in the Boston area. Mr. Dodd said he had no argument with commuter lines that were not involved in the contract dispute with Amtrak, but he said some of the lines employed members of his union under the terms of the contract now at issue with Amtrak.
Metra, the Long Island Rail Road and New Jersey Transit in the New York region and Septa in Philadelphia are government-run railroads that use some Amtrak tracks or stations. The commuter railroads directly run by Amtrak carry 174,000 passengers a day; 357,000 are carried by commuter railroads operating over Amtrak's tracks. Amtrak's inter-city service carries about 60,000 a day.
An Amtrak spokesman, Clifford Black, said the meaning of the union's agreement with Metra in Chicago was not clear.
"To the extent they stop train traffic at Union Station by ceasing to work, they stop both of us," Mr. Black said.
The union workers perform such jobs as track inspections that must be made twice a week, he pointed out. And if the union takes actions that stop Amtrak trains from using Union Station in Chicago -- or stopped Amtrak trains in other cities with commuter lines -- Amtrak might take other unspecified actions that would shut down the commuter trains, Mr. Black said.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, plans to hold a news conference in New York on Friday morning with representatives of the union, the Long Island Rail Road and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the agency that supervises the Long Island Rail Road. Mr. D'Amato wants to describe how the Long Island Rail Road might keep running over the westernmost four miles of track leading into Pennsylvania Station. That part of track is run by Amtrak.
Mr. D'Amato said Amtrak had been invited and added, "We need Amtrak's cooperation."
The exchanges today over commuter railroads show the differing strategies of the parties. Some union officials are convinced that if they shut down the commuter lines, Congress would step in and end their strike, an action they do not want. Amtrak, on the other hand, does not want to let its unionized employees pick and choose what functions they will perform.
New Jersey Transit officials are supposed to meet with the union on Friday. The system has a more serious problem because its operations are on the Northeast corridor, which Amtrak owns and operates.
The union today also released a letter it had received on Wednesday from Amtrak asking for the quick approval of a two-week extension of the "cooling-off period" imposed by President Clinton on Aug. 22. The period expires next Wednesday.
Amtrak said the purpose of agreeing to an extension now would be "reassuring the riding public," and it asked for a response by 3 P.M. on Thursday but did not get one. The union characterized Amtrak's letter as an ultimatum, but said it would consider the request.
Amtrak also asked the union for a plan for allowing the continued operations of the commuter lines. Mr. Dodd, who heads the negotiating committee, said he was not able to draft such a plan because he did not know the railroad well enough.
The union represents 2,300 workers who are paid about $15 an hour to maintain tracks, bridges, tunnels, signals and electrical systems. Amtrak said that with overtime, the workers are paid an average of $41,000 a year.
The railroad has 13 unions, comprising 26 bargaining units, 21,000 union workers and 2,000 managers. All but one of the contracts with the unions are open for renegotiation, but no others are close to being allowed to strike.
The Presidential Emergency Board appointed in August said the workers deserved the same pay as those employed by freight railroads. Amtrak says that those railroads earned nearly $4 billion last year but that it lost $83 million and that its losses this year will be even bigger, while the board's recommendation would cost it $25 million this year.
The board suggested that Congress appropriate more money, but both the White House and Congress plan to phase out Amtrak's operating subsidies over the next five years. Mr. Dodd said the increases recommended by the board would do no more than restore purchasing power lost to inflation since the early 1980's.

HEADLINE: Teen-Age Girl in Chicago Embarks on New Experience: School

BYLINE: By BILL DEDMAN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 16

 BODY:
The caller to the Chicago schools' special truancy line wanted to ask a hypothetical question. What would happen to a parent if her 15-year-old daughter were not in school? In several days of coaxing conversations, the mother acknowledged the truth: Her daughter had never been to school. In fact, the girl hardly went out of the house.
This week, the girl went to school for the first time -- in junior high -- and no one knows why. 
 "She knows her A B C's. She knows her colors," said Maribeth Vander Weele, chief of investigations for the Board of Education. "She learned her days of the week by looking at a calendar. She's a shy child, very isolated. She wants to learn. She wants to be a teacher."
Schools officials are not sure why the mother never sent the girl to school, aside from a few days of kindergarten, and why no one reported her absence before now. The girl's 26-year-old brother attended public school and is taking college courses. Her 8-year-old sister is in second grade, and the mother has been conscientious about that daughter's schooling, picking up report cards and attending parent-teacher conferences. The father has not been with the family for several years.
The mother, who is unemployed and on public assistance, told officials that she feared for the safety of her teen-age daughter, who would have to walk through their rough South Side neighborhood to get to school. But she allowed her youngest child to attend a neighborhood school.
The Illinois Department of Children and Family Services will evaluate the family, including the mother's mental state.
Officials have not identified the family publicly.
The girl has no physical or mental disability, officials said, although she does need glasses. Nor does she appear to have suffered any abuse. The home was clean, and the girl was well fed and clothed. It is unlikely that the mother will face a criminal charge of educational neglect, officials said.
The girl told officials that she had gone to the grocery store, but had mostly stayed at home. She studied there some with her younger sister, officials said.
This week the girl sat in classes so she could get used to being with other children. Officials chose to place her in junior high school, for now, because that age group seemed most appropriate. She is being evaluated but will need intensive remedial instruction. Today, after The Chicago Sun-Times publicized the case on the front page, an anonymous donor offered to pay for tutoring.
"It's amazing that in this day and age you can have a child who has gone 15 years without ever having enrolled in school," said Paul G. Vallas, chief executive officer of the Chicago public schools. "But we've had a lot of unusual cases."
The special truancy line, set up a year ago, has helped bring more than 2,000 students back into the Chicago public school system, which has 425,000 students. Truancy rates have declined 18 percent among boys and 9 percent among girls, officials said. Most of the truants had been out only a few days, but officials have found entire families of children who are not in school and are not receiving home instruction.
"There are a lot of forgotten children out there," Ms. Vander Weele said.

HEADLINE: Zurich Group-B.A.T. Deal Is Made Firm

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 16

 BODY:
The Zurich Group of Switzerland announced a firm agreement today to take control of B.A.T. Industries' insurance businesses in a complex merger that would create one of the world's biggest financial-services companies and a major new player in the United States.
Under the agreement, which was expected since Zurich said on Sunday that the companies were talking about a deal, the two companies would pool their insurance and money-management businesses and the tobacco business of B.A.T. would be spun off into a separate entity. 
 Zurich would own 55 percent of the new financial company, with B.A.T. owning the rest. Though neither company would announce full terms of the transaction, saying they would be provided early next year, the new financial services company would have a market capitalization of roughly $32 billion.
But while the merger would rank among the biggest ever, it produced a surprisingly lukewarm reaction from some investors. Analysts who follow Zurich Group complained that the merger was unnecessarily complicated, would produce relatively insignificant cost savings and had murky strategic objectives.
Shares of Zurich Group have climbed about 5.2 percent, to 630 Swiss francs, since Sunday. Shares of B.A.T., which was eager to split off its insurance operations from its cigarette business, have jumped about 10.5 percent, to 609 pence.
By any measure, the new company will be a giant, based in Zurich and run by Zurich Group's chairman and energetic deal maker, Rolf Huppi. As a money-management concern that is growing with Zurich's current acquisition of the American mutual fund company Scudder, Stevens & Clark, it will oversee more than $342 billion in assets. As an insurance conglomerate that includes the Chicago-based Kemper Corporation, a Zurich unit, and the Los Angeles-based Farmers Insurance Group, a B.A.T. unit, it will have annual premium income of $40 billion.
B.A.T. is hoping that the deal will raise the stock market value of its insurance businesses, which have been under a cloud caused by B.A.T.'s extensive cigarette interests. As the owner of Brown & Williamson, which makes Kool and other American brands, B.A.T. has been under persistent pressure from investors as a result of the threat of tobacco litigation in the United States.
But the merger's complicated structure was criticized by some analysts. Zurich Group and B.A.T. shareholders will jointly own the new company, to be called Zurich Financial Services Group, through two separate holding companies that will themselves be listed as publicly traded stocks. B.A.T.'s tobacco interests, meanwhile, will remain separate as yet another publicly traded company, called British American Tobacco.
"It is unnecessarily complex and lacks transparency," complained Michael Lindsay, an insurance industry analyst at Lehman Brothers in London. "Some investors won't like it, simply from that point of view."
At a news conference in Zurich today, Mr. Huppi made it clear that he expected the deal to shore up his company's presence in the United States. Zurich Group bought Kemper last year for $2 billion and has reached an agreement to buy Scudder for $1.7 billion. B.A.T.'s key financial holding in the United States is Farmers, which has a sales force with more than 14,000 representatives.
Analysts said the appeal of this sales force, under the same company that will also be distributing Kemper's and Scudder's products, was one of the motivations for the agreement.
But unlike other mergers in the insurance and banking fields, this one is not expected to yield quick profits through cost-cutting and consolidation. Nor will it suddenly give Zurich big new economies of scale. Rather, Mr. Huppi justified the merger on the basis of "long-term" strategy.
"This transaction is not a short-term cost-saving measure," Mr. Huppi said. "What you have is a positioning taking into account long-term developments within world markets."

HEADLINE: U.S. Maritime Agency Moves to Bar Most Japanese Cargo Ships From American Ports

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
In an unexpected intensification of a trade dispute with Japan, the Federal Maritime Commission ordered the Coast Guard today to bar most Japanese cargo ships from American ports and to detain any Japanese ships currently in port.
The order was not expected to take effect until Saturday at the earliest, and presumably would be suspended if a long-brewing dispute over American access to Japanese ports is resolved in negotiations that continued tonight. 
 The commission took its vote today after it learned that Japan's three largest shipping companies -- apparently on orders from their Government -- were refusing to pay $4 million in fines imposed last month. The commission levied the fines in an attempt to force Japan and the politically powerful group that operates its harbors to drop a series of complex rules that American shippers contend make it expensive and sometimes impossible for them to move freely in and out of Japanese harbors.
The commission, invoking a 1920 law that gives it authority to bar or detain any ships moving through American ports, took the White House by surprise with its action, and sent Administration officials scrambling to contain the damage.
Any prolonged cutoff of the billions of dollars in trade between the two countries -- everything from consumer electronics to computers, wine and automobile components -- could quickly ripple through the world's two largest economies. It could also upend the final stages of talks over a civil aviation accord, an agreement that is significantly higher on Washington's agenda.
"I think the Japanese are a bit shocked at the severity of the commission's action today," an Administration official said. "We were taken aback a bit ourselves."
Administration officials say they had no advance warning of the commission's decision, which was announced at 3 P.M. That announcement apparently contributed to a late fall in both stock prices and the value of the dollar.
The order could be lifted immediately if the Japanese shipping companies agree to pay the fines or reach a settlement. But if the Coast Guard begins to bar entry to American harbors, the trade disruption could be considerable.
The vast majority of goods that move between the two countries are transported in container ships. The rest includes items that require specially designed ships, including cars, bulk materials like grain and other agricultural goods, and oil.
Although President Clinton has the authority to overrule the commission on national security grounds, a senior Administration official said, "There has been nothing in the air to suggest he's thinking of that."
The shipping dispute that led to today's order involves arcane rules that anger American shipping companies -- but that in some cases also apply to Japanese companies.
The rules are set by the Japan Harbor Transportation Association, a politically powerful private group that represents stevedores and terminal operators.
American and other foreign shipping lines have long complained that the association, which has a monopoly on harbor operations throughout Japan, requires all shippers to receive prior approval for even the most minor operational changes in handling cargo in Japanese ports. Those changes include alterations of schedules, substitutions of one ship for another and re-routing of ships.
The association has a strong interest in resisting reforms, which they fear could threaten their workers. But the issue is complicated by the fact that the association is also a major contributor to Japanese politicians, and the widespread belief in Japan that harbor operations have close links to Japanese organized crime groups.
Perhaps one reason that this dispute has intensified so quickly is that the talks are taking place outside of the ordinary trade apparatus and are being conducted by officials unaccustomed to the carefully orchestrated dance of trade talks between the two countries.
The talks, which resumed here this week, are being run by the Department of Transportation and its Japanese counterpart. The United States trade representative's office and Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry, the usual gladiators in trade disputes, are not involved.
One of the unwritten rules between the two countries is that denying access to each other's markets is the ultimate sanction, the nuclear weapon of trade talks.
The last time the issue came up was during the high-stakes face-off on Detroit's ability to sell American cars and car parts to Japan. For weeks, the White House debated and refined its plan, and in the end President Clinton, meeting with his economic advisers, settled on some very limited sanctions, involving luxury cars made by a few Japanese automakers. The sanctions never actually went into effect because of an 11th-hour settlement.
The three Japanese companies affected by the commission's order are Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha, known as K-Line in the United States, Mitsui OSK Lines and Nippon Yusen Kaisha. An executive close to one of the companies said on Wednesday that they have been eager for a settlement, in part because they, too, waste time and money following the rules of the Japan Harbor Transportation Association. But the companies know that their best bet is to benefit from what the Japanese call "gaiatsu" -- foreign pressure -- brought by American companies.
The three shipping companies were apparently prepared to pay the $4 million in fines, which represent a tiny fraction of the value of the cargo they move each week between the two countries. But late Wednesday night, they were ordered by the Ministry of Transportation not to pay, according to corporate officials.
The commission did not receive word of this refusal until it was already meeting today. So it reacted instantly, invoking the section of the Merchant Marine Act of 1920 that permits it to tell the Coast Guard to "deny entry for the purpose of ocean-borne trade" and to detain vessels already in port.
The action may be particularly surprising to the Japanese, because independent regulatory bodies in Tokyo traditionally have little power to actually shut down commerce. It is almost inconceivable that Japan's regulatory bodies would risk a move this big without checking through the political chain of command.
In this case, the Federal Maritime Commission is not actually conducting the negotiations, but some Administration officials speculated today that the commission may be taking a particularly activist role at a time that Congress is seeking to pare down the number of regulatory agencies.
The Interstate Commerce Commission, which regulated trucking, was eliminated two years ago, and its remains were folded into the Transportation Department.

HEADLINE: With Transit Surplus Comes Subway Fare-Cut Proposal

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
Bus and subway ridership are up by about 10 percent since July, far beyond the Transit Authority's expectations. The taxes that subsidize the authority have brought in much more money, thanks to the city's booming economy. The Transit Authority is, relatively speaking, awash in money in 1997, its balance sheet about $110 million healthier than projected.
So it was, perhaps, inevitable that someone would propose cutting the fare to $1.25. 
 That someone was the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone. At yesterday's Transit Authority board meeting, he asked the authority to consider offering 12 rides for the price of 10 to Metrocard users starting in January, rather than the 11-for-10 deal the authority plans to offer them. Mr. Vallone said that the authority's unexpected income would cover the cost of the rollback, which would bring the fare to what it was in 1995, when it went up to $1.50.
"If we can actually show the citizens of the city that we can make improvements and at the same time pass on a discount to them," he said, "why not seriously consider reducing the fare to a buck and a quarter?"
Transit officials said it was far too soon to make plans for the extra cash: revenue from the buses and subways has been increasing only since July, when free bus-to-subway transfers were first offered, though the increase in tax revenues began several months earlier.
"One swallow doesn't make a summer," said Daniel T. Scannell, the authority's vice chairman.
But John S. Dyson, a Transit Authority board member who is also an adviser to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, urged the authority's staff to draw up a plan by next month to see if the extra discount would be feasible, if not by January, then maybe by July.
"We owe everyone a serious, businesslike analysis," he said.
For the first eight months of this year, according to figures released at the meeting, the subways and buses brought in $1.46 billion in fares, $25 million more than budgeted; almost all that increase has come since July. Tax revenue from sales, petroleum and utilities, among other things, stood at $674 million, $42 million more than expected. At the same time, the authority's expenses are down $44 million, to $2.33 billion, mostly because of savings on rentals and employee benefits. The surplus was first reported yesterday in The Daily News.
In addition to the Council Speaker and the Mayor, Ruth W. Messinger, Mr. Giuliani's election opponent, voiced support for the rollback.
"The whole point of fare cards," she said, "was to allow discounts for regular riders and provide for commuter and monthly passes. If they've got a surplus, they can do it now."
One board member, Beverly Dolinsky, who also heads a rider advocacy group called the Permanent Citizens Advisory Committee to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, asked her colleagues to consider saving the money for future debt payments, which are scheduled to balloon after 1999.
"If you can't do that," she said, "given that people are used to the fare now, it might be better to provide them with more and better service."
But Gene Russianoff, staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, another rider group, urged the board members to spend the money one way or another. He reminded them that in 1994, the authority rang up a $113 million surplus, only to see it vanish when the city cut subsidies for student subway passes by that amount.
"You don't leave a surplus sitting around," he said. "Someone will steal it."
