HEADLINE: Companies Get Second Helping Of Tax Breaks

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
New York City's use of corporate tax breaks has become so pervasive that some of the city's most powerful and profitable companies are getting a second helping of incentives and subsidies at a time when New York's economy appears to be thriving.
In the latest example of what is known as corporate retention, the Giuliani administration is expected to announce next week that it has granted a $25 million sales tax exemption to Reuters, the British media company that threatened to leave Manhattan but instead will now build a corporate headquarters in Times Square. The administration says it is saving 1,850 jobs and getting a new office building out of the deal. 
 The tax break would be the second package of incentives that Reuters would enjoy at the office tower in the middle of Times Square. The site at the northwest corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue already has what many in real estate, government and urban planning circles regard as the city's most extensive tax breaks, worth an estimated $118 million over 20 years.
Under the 42d Street redevelopment project, the incentives for the Reuters site, and three other parcels, were worked out in the 1980's to enable developers to put office rents below those of surrounding landlords and to lure tenants to what had been a blighted neighborhood. Blighted is not a word anyone would use to describe Times Square today, which prompts many urban planners and even some real estate brokers to ask why the city is adding another share of tax incentives now.
"To the degree we're doing these deals two and three times, it aggravates an unfortunate situation," said H. Claude Shostal, president of the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit planning group. "These deals allow corporations to make suckers out of the public sector. I can't believe that Reuters wouldn't have done this without the tax break."
And Reuters is hardly alone. Conde Nast Publications, a unit of Advance Publications, threatened to move to the Midwest, Smith Barney to Hartford, and the Equitable Companies to Westchester County, and as a result, all received either a second package of tax incentives or a new, improved deal on a tax break granted years earlier. Bear Stearns & Company did not even bother to issue a threat, yet in August, it still received a second round of tax breaks.
The city has given tax incentives to some of Manhattan's most prominent companies -- from Credit Suisse First Boston and Paine Webber to The New York Times -- so it is hardly surprising that some companies have got into line for more. And under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the city's Economic Development Corporation has struck more than twice as many corporate retention deals in the last three years as his predecessor, Mayor David N. Dinkins, did during the last three years of his administration.
 
Necessary Tool, Or Misspent Money?
City officials have long contended that incentives, which include breaks on sales and property taxes and electricity costs, are a necessary tool. But a growing number of urban planners, budget watchdogs and anti-tax groups, along with State Senator Franz S. Leichter and economists at the Federal Reserve Bank, assert that a city would be better off spending the tax money on roads, public transportation, job training and other areas that improve the overall business climate. No new jobs are created in the region when a company moves to Manhattan from Jersey City, they say, and the tax breaks shift the tax burden from the large corporations that get them to mid- and small-sized companies that do not.
Mr. Giuliani is following a path established by his predecessors, Edward I. Koch and Mr. Dinkins, in the 1980's and early 1990's, when they gave $235 million in incentives to Chase Manhattan Bank and $106 million to Prudential Securities after those companies threatened to flee Manhattan. Since Mr. Giuliani took office in 1994, he has provided 34 companies with tax breaks and other incentives totaling $666.7 million. The city could not provide comparable numbers for previous administrations.
City officials maintain that they are doing better deals at a lower cost per job and linking a larger part of the benefits to job growth. In the case of Reuters, the city is offering the company a $12 million sales tax exemption to retain the current number of employees and linking the remaining $13 million in benefits to increases in the company's work force, according to city and state officials involved with the deal.
"Every deal we've done has improved upon the last one," said Randy L. Levine, Deputy Mayor for Economic Development. "It's not just about retaining jobs. We're getting job growth and a new building. The citizens are getting a net gain rather than a net loss. So we don't think it's double dipping."
But while the so-called retention deals have become somewhat smaller, the number of deals continues to rise. Large corporations seeking new office space routinely threaten to move to New Jersey or Stamford, Conn., or elsewhere to obtain tax breaks from the city. Whether the companies truly intend to abandon New York for the suburbs is harder to determine.
"A lot of people come out and kick the tires and then go back to New York and negotiate a deal," Richard LeFrak, the developer who runs Newport City, a corporate complex on the waterfront in Jersey City. "It's part of the process of getting subsidies out of New York."
That is not to say that all companies threatening to leave New York are simply bluffing, or that other states are unwilling to use tax incentives. Connecticut lured Swiss Bank and 1,300 employees from Manhattan to Stamford in 1994 with a $120 million incentive package. More recently, Zurich Centre Group, an insurance and financial services company, obtained what is perhaps the richest single tax break in the country. Zurich plans to move its operations and 400 employees from lower Manhattan to Stamford in return for $190 million in tax credits, the equivalent of $475,000 per job.
 
Jobs 'Moved Around,' One Official Says
"No new jobs are created in the process," said Robert B. Reich, the former United States Secretary of Labor. "They're merely moved around. Meanwhile, the public spends a fortune subsidizing these companies. But there's no way that mayors or governors can withstand the heat once a major company announces it is thinking about leaving."
That is why Mr. Reich, Representative David Minge of Minnesota and Arthur J. Rolnick, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank in Minneapolis, say that the only way to end what they call the war between the states is to enact Federal legislation that would treat these tax breaks, cash grants and other incentives as corporate income, thereby gutting the value of the subsidies.
"I'm all in favor of states competing over who has the best-educated work force or the best transportation infrastructure," Mr. Reich said. "That's healthy. It bids up the value of public capital."
Last August, the Giuliani administration announced the city's second deal in six years with Bear Stearns, granting a $75 million tax package in return for the investment concern's promise to remain in Manhattan for the next 50 years and to build a new headquarters at 383 Madison Avenue, just north of Grand Central Terminal and perhaps the most valuable office development site in the city. Bear Stearns can collect a part of the benefits, up to $30 million, only if the company adds jobs to its current work force of 5,700.
James E. Cayne, chief executive of Bear Stearns, said at the time that during his company's three-year search for new office space, it had never threatened to leave the city. But that did not prevent the Giuliani administration from saying it had saved 5,700 jobs and sparked construction of a new office building.
More than half the jobs at Bear Stearns, however, had been "saved" by the Dinkins administration in 1991, when it granted the company an incentive package valued at $35 million to $45 million after it had threatened to move its back-office employees to New Jersey. The 15-year deal, which included tax breaks and low-cost electricity from the New York State Power Authority, covered 3,350 back-office employees, who moved to the Metrotech complex in Brooklyn, and the headquarters staff at 245 Park Avenue.
Mr. Levine, the Deputy Mayor, contends that the city jettisoned the Dinkins agreement and cut what he says is a better deal that covers a greater number of employees and anchors Bear Stearns to Manhattan for 50 years. But some analysts question the wisdom of a long-term deal with Bear Stearns, a profitable company whose deal could become moot if it were swallowed up in a wave of mergers that are sweeping the financial industry.
 
Reaping the Benefits Of 2 Retention Deals
Travelers Inc., the financial conglomerate, has reaped the benefits of two different retention deals. In 1994, Travelers received a $22.1 million tax package from the Giuliani administration in exchange for keeping 8,970 employees in New York, 94 percent of them at the company's subsidiary, Smith Barney. The city's news release did not mention that Travelers and Smith Barney were already benefiting from tens of millions of dollars in tax credits and low-cost electricity from the State Power Authority at its headquarters on Greenwich Street, under a deal struck in the mid-1980's. Those benefits had been given to Shearson Lehman, which was acquired by Travelers in 1993 and combined with Smith Barney.
"Travelers inherited the benefit," said Jack Murphy, a Power Authority spokesman. "There was a commitment to maintain at least 2,500 jobs in Manhattan."
After threatening to move to New Jersey in 1994, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, then a wholly owned subsidiary of the Equitable Companies, got $29.5 million in tax breaks after it agreed to move 1,950 jobs from 140 Broadway to a new headquarters at 277 Park Avenue. A year later, Equitable drew a $9.3 million tax package to keep its headquarters and 1,750 employees in Manhattan, instead of moving to Westchester. Although the benefits of both deals accrue to Equitable, the Giuliani administration and Equitable say the deals cover two separate companies with two separate payrolls.
City officials say they were able to come up with a better deal with NBC in 1996, when the company asked for its second special tax break. In 1987, Mayor Koch had given NBC a $100 million tax package to keep the broadcasting company from moving to Secaucus, N.J. After NBC agreed to buy its longtime Manhattan home at 30 Rockefeller Center, the Giuliani administration gave an additional $7 million tax cut. Unlike the Koch administration's package, which did not impose any conditions on the network, the latest deal requires NBC to keep at least 2,250 employees in New York until 2010 to obtain the additional benefits, city officials say.
Nowhere in the city are the layers of tax deals more apparent than in Times Square. The Giuliani administration gave a $10.75 million tax break to Conde Nast last year after the publishing giant threatened to move a number of employees to the Middle West. Although many real estate brokers and publishing executives could not imagine Conde Nast editors ever leaving Manhattan, the Giuliani administration said the deal insured that one of the first new office buildings of the mid-1990's would be built in Times Square.
Like Reuters, Conde Nast will also benefit from millions of dollars in tax breaks attached to the property as part of the 42d Street project.
"As a community," said Ira Schuman, executive vice president of Julien J. Studley Inc., a commercial real estate broker, "we need to be having a discussion as to what level of assistance the government should be providing, especially when we have a healthy economy."

HEADLINE: Messinger Opposes Helping Yankees Move to Manhattan

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Ruth W. Messinger said yesterday that she opposed spending city funds to build a new stadium for the Yankees in Manhattan and would support only a relatively limited effort to improve Yankee Stadium in the Bronx and prevent George M. Steinbrenner 3d from acting on a threat to move his team to New Jersey.
Ms. Messinger, the Democratic mayoral candidate, went to a sidewalk in front of Yankee Stadium to dramatize one of the clearer distinctions between herself and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani: how far the city should go to try to keep the team after its lease at Yankee Stadium expires in 2002. "What I want the Mayor to tell us specifically is whether he will commit to bar the use of any public funds, or any public lands, to move the Yankees out of the Bronx," Ms. Messinger said. 
 Mr. Giuliani has said that while he prefers that the Yankees remain in the Bronx, he is prepared to support dramatic steps, including building a stadium in Manhattan, to keep the Yankees here.
Ms. Messinger's attempt to draw a distinction between herself and Mr. Giuliani on this issue came on a day when she encountered more evidence of gaps in her Democratic base. In a highly unusual bit of political theater, Mr. Giuliani appeared at City Hall with Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the state's longtime Democratic Senator, where they announced a lawsuit intended to overturn the Presidential line-item veto.
Both men said they were brought together only by the opposition to the new law. But the result, intended or not, was the unusual image of Mr. Giuliani, whose central campaign effort this year has been to blur partisan distinctions, and Mr. Moynihan jostling and smiling broadly as cameras clicked away.
"I've endorsed the Democratic candidate," said Mr. Moynihan, who has not campaigned with her. When reporters asked about the political significance of the event, Mr. Moynihan responded with a twinkle in his eye and a curl to his lip, "I've taken an oath to uphold and defend the Constitution of the United States against all enemies foreign and domestic." His audience burst into prolonged laughter.
At the same event, Dennis Rivera, the president of 1199 National Health and Human Service Employees Union, a stalwart Democratic union that provided the organizational base for David N. Dinkins's two mayoral campaigns, delivered some more bad news for Ms. Messinger by disclosing that his union had decided to stay neutral in this contest.
"The nonendorsement of 1199 should not be construed an endorsement of the Mayor, or lack of an endorsement," Mr. Rivera said. "It's essentially that. The union has taken a stand of nonendorsement of many, many, many races." Mr. Giuliani also won the endorsement yesterday of Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union.
In discussing Yankee Stadium, Ms. Messinger was in part responding to polls suggesting that voters do not support moving the stadium or providing economic aid to Mr. Steinbrenner, her aides said. Mr. Giuliani these days rarely talks about what the city should do to keep the Yankees, and Ms. Messinger's remarks yesterday were intended to force Mr. Giuliani to address the issue.
"I believe there are much more important priorities for this city than spending a billion dollars to move the Yankees," Ms. Messinger said, standing with the shuttered stadium behind her in a cold autumn drizzle.
As Manhattan Borough President, Ms. Messinger has opposed the idea of building a new stadium, at a cost of up to $1 billion, on the Hudson River, between 30th and 33d Streets. She went further yesterday, saying that while the city should spend more money to improve such public facilities as subways near Yankee Stadium to entice Mr. Steinbrenner to stay, she considered such expenditures less important than spending money on city services like classrooms.
Mr. Giuliani's communications director, Cristyne F. Lategano, said the Mayor understood that the baseball team was a business. "You can't force them to stay in the Bronx," she said. "You can't force them to stay in New York City. If they are seriously pursuing New Jersey, he would look at them as a business."
At her news conference, Ms. Messinger initially said she would not support any public expenditures on the stadium itself. "This is a private business, a private team," she said. "The profits go to the private team. The private team should make the investment."
Later, after she spoke briefly with the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, she walked back over to reporters who were leaving the event to amend her remarks. She noted that the stadium was a public building and that she might support spending some money to improve it.
"My preference for public money is for the infrastructure around here, because it's used all of the time and not just for games," she said. "But I just wanted to make clear I wasn't closing out that direction."
Ms. Messinger said she did not believe that Mr. Steinbrenner was serious about moving. But she said she considered enticing Mr. Steinbrenner to stay less essential than improving other city services.

A week after Hurricane Pauline lashed the coast of Mexico, thousands of people in Acapulco stand in lines to pick up half-liter bottles of water. Although 1.3 million gallons of water are being trucked in each day, many of the city's 1.5 million inhabitants must turn to unsanitary sources for drinking water. NATIONAL A16-33
 
Clinic Uses Frozen Eggs For Human Pregnancy
In an advance that promises to make it vastly easier for older women to remain fertile, researchers at a private clinic in Atlanta said they had frozen human eggs, thawed them, fertilized them and created a successful twin pregnancy. Fertility clinics have long been able to freeze sperm and embryos, but they had been stymied by their inability to freeze eggs. One immediate consequence would be to allow women to freeze their eggs when they are young, for use later when they are older and their eggs are of poorer quality. A1

Sulzberger Steps Down
Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, who steered The New York Times through 34 years of expansion and enormous changes in the way it delivers the news to its readers, retired as chairman and chief executive of The New York Times Company, the newspaper's parent company. Mr. Sulzberger had relinquished control over the newspaper's daily operations in 1992, when he stepped aside after 29 years as publisher in favor of his son, Arthur Sulzberger Jr. The generational changing of the guard was made complete with the announcement that the elder Mr. Sulzberger, 71, had also turned over corporate leadership to his son. HEADLINE: Garment Shops Found to Break Wage Laws

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Federal investigators have found that almost two-thirds of the companies in New York City's garment industry violate overtime or minimum-wage laws, Labor Secretary Alexis Herman said yesterday.
At a news conference, Ms. Herman painted a picture of an industry that still resembled the sweatshops of the early 1900's when immigrant laborers often toiled 70 hours a week in unsafe conditions for minimal pay. 
 Ms. Herman said the Federal Government's first compliance survey done through inspections found wage and hour violations at 59 of the 94 garment makers that were visited, or 63 percent.
"Obviously, these results are unacceptable," Ms. Herman said. "We must redouble our efforts to seek solutions to the serious sweatshop problem in New York City."
Federal officials said they randomly chose the shops from among the city's 4,000 garment factories, which range from mom-and-pop shops with 15 workers to sprawling operations with more than 200. Investigators inspected them last summer and looked for violations over the preceding 90 days.
They found that of the 94 garment shops they inspected, 54 percent violated overtime laws and 20 percent flouted minimum-wage laws. The officials said they found minimum wage or overtime violations in 90 percent of the clothing shops inspected in Chinatown.
The violators have been cited and will be required to pay the back wages.
Altogether, 37 percent of shops complied with all overtime, minimum-wage and record-keeping laws, the investigators said.
Joanna Cheng, director of the Garment Workers' Justice Center in Manhattan, hailed the report for focusing attention on what she said was a huge problem that was growing worse. Ms. Cheng said that on Wednesday, an immigrant from China who was working in a Manhattan garment shop went to her office to complain about being paid $180 for a week when he worked 84 hours, equivalent to $2.14 an hour. The Federal minimum wage is $5.15 an hour.
"To many people, sweatshops are something that take place in third-world countries," said Bruce Raynor, executive vice president of the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees. "Unfortunately, sweatshops take place in states like New Jersey and New York for thousands of workers."
Industry experts say that sweatshops were largely wiped out in New York City in the 1950's and 1960's. But the shops crept back in the 1970's and 1980's as immigrants flooded into New York in search of work and garment entrepreneurs increasingly cut corners in the face of low-wage competition from overseas and from the many clothing manufacturers that fled to the nonunion South. Sweatshops, which sometimes produce well-known clothing lines, have flourished as the labor movement's domination of New York's economy has waned.
Secretary Herman called on retailers and manufacturers that contract with New York garment shops to hire monitors to periodically check on the factories, supplementing the inspections done by the Federal and state labor departments.
Ms. Herman used Los Angeles as an example, noting that manufacturers there have joined a program to monitor more than half the garment shops in that city. She cited a Federal survey that found overtime violations at 25 percent of the monitored clothing shops and at 61 percent of the shops that were not monitored.
In New York, investigators found that 1,400 workers were due a total of $412,300 in back pay at the 59 factories where there were violations, coming to almost $300 per worker.
"That might not sound like much," said Suzanne Seiden, Acting Deputy Administrator of the Federal Wage and Hour Division, "but for a lot of workers that comes to two weeks' wages. For these folks, it's a matter of putting food on the table."
Owners of garment factories asserted that they were pressured to cut corners by intense foreign competition and by retailers who often paid them late or too little for what they produced.
"A lot of retailers don't pay on time, and that makes it hard for some shops to pay their workers properly," said Charles Wang, executive director of the Greater Blouse, Skirt and Undergarment Association, which represents 300 unionized New York shops. "The retailers often pay a piece rate that is too low that translates to paying people only $3 or $4 an hour."
Ms. Herman disclosed the findings at a news conference she held in Newark alongside Archbishop Theodore E. McCarrick, who announced a broad plan for Newark's Catholic schools to combat sweatshops.
The archdiocese will identify the manufacturers of Catholic school uniforms that are sold in Newark and then work to insure that those companies comply with labor laws. The plan, developed by the archdiocese, the garment workers union and Federal and state officials, calls for teaching Catholic school students in grades 7 through 12 about labor issues and sweatshops.
"Catholic social teaching has stressed, always, that everyone has a right to fulfill their basic human needs for food, clothes, health care and housing met through just wages and through safe working conditions," the Archbishop said.
Some New York officials took umbrage that Ms. Herman traveled to Newark to issue a report that criticized clothing makers on the other side of the Hudson.
James Dillon, the state's Acting Labor Commissioner, said New York shares Federal concerns about sweatshops, adding that the state has focused on the problem by strengthening its investigative task force on sweatshops. While the Federal Department of Labor has no plans to seek prosecution of the violators, Mr. Dillon said New York State has prosecuted more than twice as many sweatshop operators as in 1994.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
MERGER TO CREATE LARGE CREDIT-RATING AGENCY

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
Fitch Investors Service L.P. said yesterday that it had agreed to merge with IBCA Ltd. in a $175 million deal that will create the world's third-largest credit-rating agency. It will compete with the Standard & Poor's Corporation, a unit of the McGraw-Hill Companies, and Moody's Investors Service Inc., a unit of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation. Fimalac of France, which controls IBCA, will buy Fitch from the Van Kampen Group, based in Grand Haven, Mich. The new company, to be called Fitch IBCA Inc., will have combined revenue of $105 million and more than 550 employees. Fitch, based in New York, focuses on rating bonds and borrowers in the United States public finance, taxable debt and structured finance markets. IBCA, based in London, specializes in rating banks and financial institutions worldwide.

HEADLINE: Where Affirmative Action Ranks in Importance With the Architecture

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Etched on the plaques around the rotunda of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center are the names of governors, million-dollar-plus donors and Gus Heningburg, the affirmative-action consultant for the project.
"I don't think you will find another building in the state where they list the name of the affirmative-action officer along with the architect, board members and others," said Mr. Heningburg, a longtime resident of the city, which as of 1990 was 58 percent black and 27 percent Hispanic. 
 Lawrence P. Goldman, president of the center, said the decision to list Mr. Heningburg reflected an unabashed "social agenda" that required that at least 33 percent of the construction hours be worked by members of minorities and that at least 25 percent of the contracts go to businesses owned by minority groups and women.
In the end, minority workers accounted for 39 percent of the worker hours and 32 percent of the minority contracts.
"We did this very consciously and are not ashamed of it," Mr. Goldman said. "We want to be an economic engine for the city, and where this has happened best is where the arts centers have taken a strong position in making it happen."
Mr. Heningburg is a veteran of efforts in the 1970's to place minority workers in the construction trades in Newark and surrounding Essex County.
In 1975, he founded the Newark Construction Trades and Training Corporation, which grew out of demonstrations that closed a number of publicly financed building sites where minority-group workers had had trouble being hired.
Over the years, with the help of Federal and city money, the corporation trained 3,000 workers and helped pave the way into unions.
Mr. Heningburg said in the process he learned that the simplest way to increase hiring at construction sites was to include it in contracts with construction companies and subcontractors just as a clause would require that a roadway be level, or the companies would not be paid.
"It makes it an economic issue, not a moral or social issue for the contractor," he said.
Mr. Goldman said the center "never had to fire a contractor, but we did have some dicey moments and had to withhold payments for a time."
"The point, though," he added, "is that when faced with challenges, we didn't blink."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 21, 1997, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about affirmative action efforts at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark misstated the residence of Gus Heningburg, the affirmative action consultant for the construction of the center. He has long worked in Newark, but he lives in in Secaucus, N.J.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Strengthens vs. Mark As German Rate Fears Ease

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar surged against the mark yesterday after officials of the Bundesbank eased concerns that German interest rates would soon rise, while talk of a rise in United States rates mounted.
A member of the Bundesbank's policy council, Reimut Jochimsen, said yesterday that the central bank was not likely to raise interest rates in the next few weeks, though it was watching for signs of inflation. Another council member, Klaus-Dieter Kuhbacher, said later that he saw no reason for more rate increases before the end of the year, the German news agency VWD reported. 
 Also yesterday, larger-than-expected gains in United States industrial production and housing starts signaled that the economy might be growing fast enough to prompt the Federal Reserve to raise rates soon, or at least sooner than a rate rise by the Bundesbank. Industrial production rose seven-tenths of 1 percent last month for the third consecutive monthly gain, while housing starts jumped 7.9 percent last month, after two months of declines.
"The market thinks there's going to be a delay in moving German interest rates while rates in the U.S. may rise," said Ron Hudson, head of corporate currency sales at the Royal Bank of Scotland.
Robert Near, an institutional currency salesman at the Bank of New York, said, "The idea that German rates can stay where they are, while we're on the lookout for higher U.S. rates certainly favors the dollar."
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.7718 marks, up from 1.7435 late on Thursday. The 1.6 percent rise against the mark was the sharpest single-day gain since July 11.
The dollar rose against the yen after Finance Minister Hiroshi Misuzuka ruled out tax cuts aimed at reviving Japan's sagging economy.
The dollar extended its gains versus the yen in late trading after the United States reported a breakthrough in talks with Japan over a dispute on access to Japanese ports. Rising trade tension tends to drag down the dollar, so signs it may be abating often give the currency a boost.
In New York, the dollar settled at 120.68 yen, up from 119.65 yen on Thursday. In other trading, the pound fell to $1.6166 from $1.6179.

HEADLINE: Fed Official Not Worried About Economy

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 17

 BODY:
Though a tight labor market poses a troubling inflation threat, fresh reports of economic strength do not signal an immediate need to put on the brakes, a Federal Reserve policy maker said today.
"Currently, the availability of labor and the threat of a run-up in the cost of labor are at or near the top of many people's worry list," said Jack Guynn, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta. 
 Mr. Guynn is a voting member of the Fed committee that raised interest rates in March. The central bankers next meet on Nov. 12.
In a speech to the Economic Club of Florida, Mr. Guynn echoed remarks by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, who rattled financial markets last week by saying the economy has been on an "unsustainable track" of strong, noninflationary growth.
While Mr. Guynn said a Government report today of an unexpectedly large rise in factory output could be an inflation warning, much of the increase was from electricity plants and probably was temporary.
The Fed will not base policy on particular figures that "go up one month and down the next," he said. "The economy is operating at a very high level, which is very good as long as we don't get some kind of imbalance, We'll just have to watch."

HEADLINE: About New York;
Ex-Gangster On New Path, With Advice

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
FELIPE MERCADO slowly got up from the sofa -- he was tired after working all day as a building superintendent -- and ducked into the bedroom. He reappeared holding a denim jacket with cutoff sleeves, the kind that used to be seen in his Hunts Point neighborhood more often than intact ones. An arc-shaped patch on its back read "Savage Skulls."
In the 1970's, Mr. Mercado wore his colors like a flag. He was Blackie, the president of the Savage Skulls, a Bronx street gang with hundreds of members and perhaps as many rivals. He survived that era, as well as 11 years in and out of prisons, and returned to Hunts Point, where the challenges of making a living were more daunting than any danger that had lurked in wait from another clique. 
 He and some of his gang brothers are in their 40's now, but they sometimes wear their old colors like grizzled Veterans of Domestic Wars getting together for a smoker.
"I'm still a Savage Skull," said Mr. Mercado, 44. "But it passed. Everybody works. When we get together we go to a bowling alley. It's a family now. If one of the brothers is not working, we try to get him a job or help him out. We have cookouts, so our kids can go to the park."
What happened?
"You get older," he said. "Simple as that. You have your kids and you want a better life for them."
MR. MERCADO has been thinking a lot about children. Recent weeks have brought a flurry of reports, some overblown, about a new wave of youth gangs slashing away at innocent victims as they try to carve out a name for themselves on their turf. In response, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has vowed to crack down by deploying more police officers to "nip in the bud" any resurgence.
All this talk makes Mr. Mercado laugh.
"They had a task force with us before," he said. "They're going to go after the big guns, but then the other guys will be there without leadership and go crazy. Before you know it, everything you try will backfire. Let me put it this way. If you take the President and all his officials of the Government, who's going to make all the decisions for the country? People will just go berserk."
It happened to his gang when he was sent to prison. Wannabes and knuckleheads saw their chance and ran amok. He said there were new wannabes out there now, wilder and more violent. Yet one thing has not changed.
"Everybody wants something to belong to," he said. "My parents were never home. My father had passed away. My mother was working all the time. I was always alone. You need somebody to identify with. There is nothing for these kids today."
And when there is nothing to do, nihilism rules.
"They think it is easy to die," he said. "But it is harder to live. They take the easy way out. They go get shot up. In reality, give life a shot and see how far you can get if you survive."
As much as he has tried to talk to the young gangsters and others in the neighborhood, it has not been easy. Call it karma, but they insist on doing things their way and ignore his advice.
IT is not just the young people who have chosen to go their own way. He used to speak to schools and community groups about how to deal with youth violence, but it seemed that nothing changed. He was elected president of a local public school's Parents' Association, where he began a conflict-resolution program that fell victim to bureaucratic turf battles.
"I'm retired," he said. "I got tired of talking to people."
It would be easy to dismiss Mr. Mercado as an ex-con with a shady past, but he speaks thoughtfully and quietly. He has a trade and an education now, something that too many young people lack. They might get it in prison, but you don't have to be an economist to figure out that there are more cost-effective ways, he said.
"The system has to bend a little," he said. "You can't do things just by force."
His voice was weary. Life is hard, but it keeps him busy. When he's not fixing things in the building, he sits in his living room and paints, near a table where candles flicker by a statue of the Virgin Mary.
Outside, the sounds of an argument echoed. He shook his head in annoyance.
"It can go either way with these kids," he said. "Sometimes I don't even bother to think about it. Giuliani thinks he's doing something. He better stop and think. Even the people who are working are so stressed they can blow up. They try and try, and the more they do the more they get messed over. The kids feel like that, too. You know what I'm saying?"

HEADLINE: Strength in Economic Data Renews Fear of Fed Tightening

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Just when it seemed the economy had begun slowing to a safer speed, two Government reports today renewed fears that it still was running too fast for the anti-inflation police at the Federal Reserve.
Production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities jumped seven-tenths of 1 percent last month -- to make growth for the July-September quarter the biggest in 13 years -- as their operating rate edged closer to capacity. And builders broke ground on 7.9 percent more new homes in September, erasing nearly all the drop in housing starts over the preceding two months. 
 Taken together, the latest figures undermined assumptions fed by lackluster retail sales growth, regional surveys of factories and continued tame inflation that activity was slackening and that the Fed could likely avoid restraining it with higher interest rates.
Now, however, "It's a little too early to say the economy is slowing," Melanie Hardy, an economist at Bear, Stearns, said after digesting today's figures. She noted especially the rise in industry's operating rate, up three-tenths of a point, to 84.4 percent, the highest since February 1995.
Although there were mitigating factors in both reports, the unexpected strength contributed to sizable declines in the securities markets as traders and investors reassessed the possible outcome of the next Fed policy meeting, scheduled for Nov. 12.
"It's become clear that the economy can't continue to grow at this pace without good reason to expect some monetary tightening," said William A. Brown, chief economist at J. P. Morgan. He put the chances of a rate increase next month at "close to 50-50."
Still, today's statistics were not overwhelmingly strong. The production increase was swollen by a 4.4 percent leap in utility output after a cool August that minimized air-conditioner use.
In fact, manufacturing, which accounts for 86 percent of the Index of Industrial Production, climbed a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in September, half the increases of July and August.
Moreover, noted Maury N. Harris, senior economist at Paine Webber, higher output recently has been achieved without a corresponding rise in the number of hours worked in factories and thus should not raise fears of inflationary wage pressures.
"So far this year," Mr. Harris said, "manufacturing output has been rising by around four-tenths of 1 percent per month faster than factory hours worked -- a clear indication of the kind of productivity gains that the Federal Reserve System wants to see continuing in order to keep price inflation low."
And while housing starts were up for apartments as well as single-family homes -- and in all regions of the country -- specialists said they had merely plateaued at a high pace of 1.5 million that was no higher than June's.
"We don't have a surge in starts," said Paul Taylor, senior economist at America's Community Bankers. "What we have is a combination of good market conditions, which include low mortgage rates, modest price appreciation, well-managed inventories and the wealth effect" of rising stock prices.
Today, the National Association of Home Builders reported another decline in the proportion of members who rated traffic in model homes "high." October's 9 percent reading, which flirted with a five-year low, was seen as a signal that home building would slow in coming months even though the Government's report on September starts showed permits issued for future construction climbed 3.4 percent, to an annual rate of 1,445,000.
Groundbreaking rose 10.7 percent last month in the West, 9.7 percent in the Northeast, 9.3 percent in the Midwest and 5.6 percent in the South, the Commerce Department found.
The production report, compiled by the Federal Reserve, showed sizable gains for furniture, iron and steel, computers, semiconductors, aerospace and miscellaneous transportation equipment, paper, chemicals and petroleum refining.
There was a substantial decline, however, in industrial machinery other than computers and office equipment, and small declines in instruments and miscellaneous manufacturing.

HEADLINE: Stocks Tumble, With Dow Falling 91.85

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Stocks dropped sharply yesterday for the second consecutive day, hurt by bad news on corporate earnings, rising oil prices, fears of a United States-Japanese trade war and Government data that suggested renewed inflation.
The combined impact of these forces briefly sent the Dow Jones industrial average down nearly 180 points, or 2.4 percent, reviving some unsettling memories on the last trading day before the 10th anniversary of the stock market crash. 
 The Dow average recovered about half the loss to end down 91.85 points, or 1.16 percent, at 7,847.03, as fears of a trade brawl receded, after Japan and the United States announced they had settled their differences. But some traders said the psychological stigma of the 1987 crash, which sent the Dow average down 22.6 percent in a huge wave of selling, was a subtle influence hanging over the market that contributed to the decline yesterday. "Some of these stocks were taken apart on news that just wasn't that bad," said Donald M. Selkin, head of stock index futures at Prudential Securities, noting that the market had been relatively calm in recent weeks. "Just when we were about to whistle past the graveyard of what happened 10 years ago, we get this." The selloff was caused partly by another batch of weak earnings reports in the once-stellar technology sector, adding to a string of high-profile setbacks.
Seagate Technology Inc., a leading maker of computer disk drives and a technology bellwether, was the worst hit, after announcing an unexpectedly large third-quarter loss late Thursday. Its shares tumbled 5 5/16 , to 32 yesterday, a 14 percent drop. Its results compounded worries inspired by other disheartening earnings results reported Thursday.
"There were disappointing earnings in big, important companies," said Charles Pradilla, a market strategist at Cowen & Company. "This was Sears, Merck, Intel and Sun Microsystems among others. And those companies mentioned stuff that might not go away so fast."
Because of those concerns, entire legions of stocks were battered yesterday. On the Big Board, trading activity was heavy, at 625 million shares, and nearly four stocks fell for every issue that rose. Indeed, all the major stock indexes fell more than 1 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 11.07, or 1.16 percent, to 944.16, and the Russell 2000 index of smaller stocks fell 7.87 points, or 1.72 percent, to 449.29.
The drop in technology stocks was felt particularly hard on the Nasdaq Stock Market, where many computer-related companies are traded. The Nasdaq composite index fell 32.81 points, or 1.93 percent, to 1,666.85. And the Pacific Stock Exchange Technology Index lost 2.7 percent of its value.
Investors were also troubled by rising oil prices related to tensions in the Middle East and rising bond interest rates, which reacted to Government reports of unexpectedly robust industrial production and housing starts in September. Yields have been climbing since Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, hinted two weeks ago that pressures might build into inflation.
Several analysts, though, said they were perplexed by the two-day selloff in stocks, noting that earnings were not as bad as the market was suggesting.
"This is not a panic session," said Joseph Yurman, a managing director at Robertson, Stephens & Company. "Everyone's making comparisons to 1987 but we're nowhere near that."
Byron R. Wien, the chief United States strategist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, said the selling was not worrisome.
"Look, we've been going up for weeks, so the market was overbought and due for a reaction," he said. "But I think this is an interim correction, if we have a more serious decline it will occur early next year."
Of the Dow's 30 component stocks, 26 fell yesterday, led by I.B.M., which is due to report earnings next week, and Merck, which disappointed this week. Shares of I.B.M. fell 4 1/4, to 95 7/16 , and Merck lost 2 15/16 , to 95.
Within the technology sector, dozens of stocks saw huge losses. Besides Seagate, Sun Microsystems was down 3 15/16 , to 38 3/8; Dell Computer -- a market favorite -- lost 3 15/16 , to 94 7/8, and Intel was down 2 3/8, to 83.

HEADLINE: Japan Nears Pact With U.S. On Threat to Bar Its Ships

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
The United States and Japan said today that they were on the verge of a shipping agreement that appeared to defuse a looming confrontation between the Coast Guard and Japanese vessels entering and leaving American harbors.
The accord, the details of which are not final, is intended to remove the restrictions on American ships operating in Japanese ports, a source of contention for many years. But officials on both sides conceded that no matter what they put on paper over the next few days, it may not break the power of organized crime groups that are widely viewed as controlling Japan's ports. 
 But to both the Americans and the Japanese, that seemed almost secondary to the daylong scramble to patch together an accord that would persuade the Federal Maritime Commission to back away from its unexpected decision on Thursday to close American ports to Japanese cargo ships.
By early evening -- after meetings at the White House that involved the Treasury Secretary, the trade representative and the chief of staff, Erskine Bowles -- the commission decided not to order the Coast Guard to begin the embargo, which would have been the first since 1941, when oil shipments were halted. Japanese schoolchildren are still taught that the 1941 embargo precipitated the attack on Pearl Harbor.
The commission planned the embargo after Japanese shipping companies, on orders from their Government, refused to pay $4 million in fines imposed six weeks ago in an effort to force the relaxation of port rules. Whether they will still have to pay is among the unresolved issues.
In fact, the Administration could not seem to decide today whether this was a brewing crisis or a comic series of missteps on both sides. At one point, a senior official at the White House was even reciting the lessons of the Cuban missile crisis, which gripped Washington 35 years ago this week: before plunging into a naval embargo, it was important to make sure the other side had a graceful way out.
What happened today was that the unexpected decision by the Maritime Commission forced both Washington and Tokyo to elevate their long-running port dispute to the highest political levels. "Let's say it concentrated the minds," said Stuart Eizenstat, the Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, who was thrown into the talks along with the Japanese Ambassador, Kunihiko Saito.
Mr. Saito is no newcomer to Tokyo-Washington contretemps. His previous job was Deputy Foreign Minister, the top career diplomatic post in Japan, a position that offered plenty of opportunity to defuse trade disagreements that threatened to weaken the Japanese-American alliance. But today he was careful not to declare victory.
"I hesitate to call it a success yet, because some details are still being worked out," Mr. Saito said in an interview this afternoon. "There is a limit to what the Japanese Government can do, because there are private parties involved."
One of those parties -- the Japan Harbor Transportation Association -- has a stranglehold on port operations, which is the heart of the problem. For decades, its dictates on how shipping companies must operate, including requiring expensive advance clearance for every change in plans, have been the law of the waterfront. The situation is not eased by the fact that the dividing line between the association and the yakuza, Japan's organized crime groups, is murky at best.
"There are very powerful, well organized groups on the docks," Mr. Eizenstat said today, weighing every word, "with a great deal of muscle, in more ways than one."
In the accord today, Japan agreed that all shipping companies will be permitted to go through the Government to deal directly with port operators. Of course, many of those operators are members of the association, but, in theory at least, foreign companies may be able to open their own terminals.
"This new system certainly will be tested in the very near future," said Koji Tsuruoka, a Japanese Foreign Ministry official involved in the talks. "It remains to be seen what happens. But we are hopeful."
Mr. Tsuruoka insisted that the yakuza had been driven out of many of the ports and that its influence was diminishing. "The question is whether the association would harass someone using the new alternative route," he said. Japan has "given assurances that order will be maintained at the ports and Japanese laws will be enforced."
Such assurances are something short of an ironclad commitment, but many Japanese trade accords have been infused with the same vagueness.
When Japan and the United States reached a landmark accord on automotive trade in 1995, they described Japan's obligations in such differing terms that it sometimes seemed as if they had sat in different negotiating rooms. That agreement seemed to work for a year or so, but in recent months it has begun to fray, with American officials saying Japan is not living up to its commitments, and Japanese officials saying they never agreed to interfere with the operations of domestic automakers.
No one would be surprised if the same happened in this case. "This isn't the end of the issue, it's just the next step," a senior Administration official said. "But we won't be spending the weekend watching on CNN while the Coast Guard pulls up next to Japanese freighters."
The American negotiators were aided by the fact that even Japanese shipping companies have long chafed at the expensive, inefficient procedures at Japanese ports, though they have never had the political clout to subvert the control of the Japan Harbor Transport Association. So in an odd way they were allied with the Americans.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Another Big Marriage In the Accounting Industry
KPMG Peat Marwick and Ernst & Young are expected to announce as early as Monday that they will merge to create the world's No. 1 accounting firm, with $15.3 billion in global revenue and 11,712 partners. 
 Such a combination would eclipse in size the pending merger of Coopers & Lybrand and Price Waterhouse announced a month ago. Both deals would reduce the Big Six accounting firms to the Big Four. Page A1.
 
Stocks Fall Again
The stock market dropped sharply for a second straight day on a combination of disappointing corporate earnings, fears of a U.S.-Japanese trade brawl and news of unexpected strength in the economy that revived anxiety about inflation. The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled as much as 180 points before recovering half the loss to end down 91.85 points, or 1.16 percent. The Nasdaq composite index, heavily weighted with technology stocks, fell nearly 2 percent. D15.
 
Treasury bond prices fell on the Government's reports of unexpectedly strong housing and manufacturing data, which revived speculation the Federal Reserve could raise interest rates at its November policy-making meeting to thwart inflationary pressure building in the economy. D14.
 
The dollar surged against the mark after Bundesbank officials hinted German interest rates would not rise soon, while talk of a rate increase in the United States intensified. D4.
 
Accord on Shipping Near
United States and Japanese negotiators are nearing an agreement on shipping, officials said, defusing a confrontation between the Coast Guard and Japanese vessels entering and leaving American harbors. While the details are not final, the agreement is intended to remove restrictions on American ships operating in Japanese ports. A6.
 
Pressure Building on Worldcom
A big drop in Worldcom's share price underscored the potential vulnerability of its $34 billion offer for MCI, which is to be paid entirely in Worldcom stock. Analysts speculated further drops might pressure the suitor into sweetening its offer with some cash, in order to compete with a $28 billion all-cash bid for MCI by GTE. D3 .
 
Dow Jones, CNBC Said to Talk
Dow Jones executives are said to have met with potential partners or buyers of the company's troubled financial information business and are said to be in discussions with CNBC about a possible joint venture. Dow Jones stock rose 3 percent on speculation it might divest the Dow Jones Markets unit, which has been a drag on the company. D2.
 
Thinner McDonald's Earnings
Slow domestic sales and the strong dollar overseas contributed to a less-than-expected 1.9 percent earnings gain in the third quarter for McDonald's. The leading fast-food chain said it expected the dollar's strength to hurt its results in the fourth quarter as well. D15.
 
Software Merger Planned
Sungard Data Systems, a provider of computer disaster recovery services, said it would purchase Infinity Financial Technology, a designer of trading and risk management software, for about $313 million in stock. D3.
 
Oil Reverses and Ends Lower
Crude oil prices retreated sharply to end lower on eased concern of a wider conflict in Iraq that could disrupt supplies. Cocoa prices jumped on strong United States demand. D4.
 
Thai Reforms Advance
Emergency decrees designed to stabilize Thailand's troubled financial sector were approved by the Cabinet and took effect immediately. The rescue package was required by lenders who contributed to a $17.2 billion International Monetary Fund loan package to Thailand D14.

HEADLINE: Something in Common;
To Bridge a Gap, Korean Grocers Try a Little Creole

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
Gazing at his customers suspiciously, Mun Chae paced along the rows of eggplants, green plantains, bell peppers and other vegetables stacked neatly on the shelves of Chae Fruit and Vegetable Market.
Then Mr. Mun, the manager of the store, zeroed in on a familiar face, a large Haitian woman who was clutching a straw basket under her arms and examining a bunch of plantains. He approached her and spoke in perfect Haitian Creole. 
 "Sak pase?" said the Korean-born Mr. Mun, asking the woman how she was doing. "The plantains are good," he said, again in Creole, stretching his command of the language. The woman smiled and headed for the cash register. His mission accomplished, Mr. Mun smiled back.
Such genial, cross-lingual exchanges between buyers and sellers have become more common in the four-block stretch of Church Avenue between 16th Street and St. Paul's Place in Flatbush, Brooklyn, as Korean grocers, once perceived by their customers as aloof and worse, have begun to learn a smattering of useful Creole words, including a few earthy ones, to cater to Haitian and other Caribbean customers.
In trying to bridge the linguistic and cultural distance, the half-dozen Korean merchants on the shopping strip are in part responding to what they see as misconceptions about them among the Caribbean and other minority communities.
The two immigrant groups have often had bitter relations, which was heightened seven years ago after a Haitian customer said she was slapped by a Korean store owner on Church Avenue. That incident touched off a yearlong boycott of Korean stores, which became a political albatross for Mayor David N. Dinkins.
In the wake of the boycott, Koreans began reaching out to other groups in the city. These days, more non-Koreans are employed in Korean-owned stores. Seminars are offered to teach Koreans to smile more frequently at customers, something they say is rare in their culture, and to put change directly into a customer's hand rather than simply dropping it on the counter, as they would in Korea. On their own, they are learning Creole phrases from their customers and from Caribbean street vendors.
"Our problem has always been communication," said Mr. Mun, who also manages Bon Banane, another grocery store across the street. "The Haitians don't speak good English and the Koreans don't speak good English. So we make a little effort to understand their language. They like it and it's good for our business."
Many Haitians view the Koreans' attempt to learn even a few technical words and phrases as a sign of respect and admiration.
"It was incredible for me to be walking down Church Avenue and hearing this Korean guy calling out in Creole the names of vegetables that Haitians like," said Ronald Aubourg, a policy analyst with the Haitian Centers Council, a community group based in Brooklyn. "His interaction with his customers was fascinating. It's the kind of thing that could happen only in New York."
The Rev. Al Sharpton, who supported the 1990 boycott, said that he welcomed the merchants' attempt to reach out socially, but that their effort should be extended economically, by offering neighborhood residents more jobs and by using the services of local businessmen. "You must not just be courteous, but engage in economic reciprocity," Mr. Sharpton said.
In New York, merchants have traditionally made efforts to learn the languages of their customers. Decades ago, in response to an influx of Spanish-speaking residents, Italian and Jewish store owners in the South Bronx and parts of Brooklyn started using the familiar Spanish greeting "hola," and other expressions.
But it has been a long, uphill climb for Koreans, who began arriving in large numbers in 1965 after immigration laws were eased. Back home, they were mostly professionals and civil servants. In New York, they gravitated to food stores, because their weakness with English was not such a barrier in that business.
They could scrape together enough money to buy stores in blighted areas ignored by other merchants. Their formula for success was simple: stay open long hours and offer glistening fresh vegetables that catered to local tastes. They stock plenty of strawberries in Park Slope, for example, but not in Flatbush.
As the number of Korean stores citywide increased to 3,000, Koreans discovered that language was not just important for success, it was essential. Conflicts and confrontations, some caused by cultural misunderstandings, would sometimes spin out of control. Customers accused merchants of being rude, and merchants feared that some of their customers were predators. Critics said that those complaints seemed to focus on young black men.
The 1990 boycott, centered on the Red Apple grocery, was the bitterest manifestation of the gulf, and the ill will lingered even after the owner sold the store in 1991. But in the years since then, gestures like learning Creole and taking black and Hispanic community leaders to South Korea have smoothed relations.
"I think it's terrific that the merchants are doing this," said Grace Lyu-Volckhausen, who directs minority program evaluation at the State of New York Mortgage Agency. "Language unites you and makes you understand other people."
Mrs. Lyu-Volckhausen, who was Asian affairs liaison for Mayor Edward I. Koch, said that after the 1990 boycott began, Korean leaders developed a list of tenets for Korean merchants ignorant of American business practices and of their customers' culture and mores.
The big breakthrough has been the Korean grocers' efforts to learn some Haitian Creole, a melange of French and African dialects that is spoken by 10 million people, including 7 million Haitians and people from other Caribbean islands like Guadeloupe, Martinique and St. Lucia. To be sure, the merchants cannot carry on a discussion in Creole about the latest twist in Haitian politics, a subject that their Haitian customers debate passionately on the streets outside.
What they have done successfully is to learn enough words to conduct a brisk business.
"This is Church Avenue, and maybe 80 percent of our customers are Haitians," said Timil Kim, who works at Bon Banane and boasts of knowing about a dozen Creole words. "They come in to hear our Creole."
In the last few years, the sidewalks of Church Avenue have been crowded with Haitian women selling spices and condiments wrapped in plastic bags, reminiscent of the open-air markets of Haiti. But the Haitian women have met little or no resentment from the more established Korean grocers. Instead, the two groups seem to have created an informal joint venture. The bustle created by the Haitian street vendors spills into the stores, increasing business.
The vendors also teach Korean merchants Creole and point out the spices and vegetables favored by Haitians. The Korean markets carry Caribbean vegetables like yucca, red coco, dasheen and edoes, and other produce like yams, mango, tamarind and sugar cane. The stores also sell sorrel, a dark red root used to make a soft drink, and Crix, a popular biscuit sold in the Caribbean.
"We don't have any problems with the Koreans," said Marie Narciste, 41, a vendor who was selling an assortment of spices, candles and used clothes, a few feet away from the Korean-owned Caribbean Fruits and Grocery store. "We conduct our business and they do theirs. We're all trying to survive."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Timil Kim, a worker in the Church Avenue strip of Korean grocers in Flatbush, said that he had learned a little Creole and that it made the store more attractive to Haitians, who are 80 percent of Bon Banane's customers. (Nancy Siesel/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Westchester, Race Tight but Rivals Miles Apart

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 16

 BODY:
They represent the two faces of Westchester.
The Republican candidate for county executive, Ted Dunn, is a Harvard-educated multimillionaire. The Mayor of Rye, a small, affluent city on Long Island Sound, he lives in a 14-room house in an affluent community of waterfront homes. He is a retired managing director of Morgan Stanley who has raised $800,000 for his campaign and has added $1 million of his own. 
 The Democratic candidate, Andy Spano, has spent 36 years in government jobs, 25 as a teacher and school administrator and 11 as county clerk. Mr. Spano, who lives in an eight-room Cape Cod in Yorktown, a middle-class community in northern Westchester, started a computer-consulting business in 1993 after he retired as county clerk. Last year, the company lost $21,000. His campaign has raised $600,000.
Polls suggest that either man could win, a far cry from the tradition in Westchester, where for years Republicans have been as confident of capturing the county executive's job as a Kennedy would be of carrying Boston. Only one Democrat, Alfred DelBello, has been elected county executive in Westchester's history. In 1973, Mr. DelBello won the office in a race in which there was no incumbent, and he remained County Executive until 1983, when he became Lieutenant Governor.
Today, Mr. Spano finds himself in a similar position, with no incumbent in the race, since Andrew P. O'Rourke, who has been County Executive for 14 years, is retiring.
"My sense is that it's a very close race, but Spano has a real opportunity to win it," said Richard A. Berman, president of Manhattanville College, which released a poll in late September that showed Mr. Spano 10 to 12 percentage points ahead of Mr. Dunn, with 24 percent of voters undecided. The college put out a poll in July that showed Mr. Spano 18 points ahead, so Mr. Dunn has narrowed the gap.
"Dunn was successful," Mr. Berman said, "in putting a lot of money in and increasing his name recognition and garnering traditional Republican support, primarily around the tax issue, which our poll had previously identified as the most significant issue in the minds of Westchester residents."
Though Westchester is traditionally associated with wealth and suburban Republicanism, there are 38,000 more registered Democrats than Republicans in the county. But a quarter of registered voters have no party affiliation, and many of them vote Republican. Three percent belong to other parties, like the Right to Life Party, which also has a candidate, Michael Reynolds, in the race.
Both Mr. Dunn and Mr. Spano have focused on taxes. Mr. Dunn, an advocate of privatization, has pledged to keep taxes level, as he has in Rye since 1993, when he was elected Mayor, an unpaid job. He has also focused on environmental issues, and says he plans to upgrade the county's sewer system and create parkland along the Hudson River.
"He's been a model Mayor of the city of Rye," said Ira Brody, chairman of the Victory 97 campaign unit of the Westchester Republican Party. "He's held the line on taxes. He has a good record on the environment and a solid vision for Westchester and protecting the environment. He's also tough on crime."
Critics, however, question whether Mr. Dunn's experience running a wealthy, homogeneous community has prepared him to govern a county as diverse and large as Westchester.
"Rye's a nice place, and fortunately it doesn't have any problems," said Thomas J. Abinanti, a Democratic legislator from Greenburgh. "But county government is real government, and you're dealing with the full panoply of problems. I think it tells you how important the job of mayor is in Rye since there's no pay for it."
Asked if he can run a big government, Mr. Dunn points to his business success. "I ran a big business in Malaysia and I ran a big business in Italy," said Mr. Dunn, who speaks fluent Italian. "I'm accustomed to accomplishing things."
He said being wealthy and not a career politician allowed him to be independent.
"Andy Spano wants to take the fact that I've had a successful business career and hold that against me," Mr. Dunn said. "The fact that I've been successful in business allows me to do this job in Rye. I think it's good that I'm a political outsider in that I'm not dependent on this as a job. I'm beholden to no one."
His detractors say that, unlike the gregarious Mr. O'Rourke, Mr. Dunn will have a tough time carrying a populous, working-class city like Yonkers.
"Dunn's strength is not personal contact with voters," said Assemblyman Richard Brodsky, a Democrat. "He doesn't do well in groups he's not comfortable with. Spano is a much better campaigner, but I don't know that you can beat huge amounts of money by doing train stations."
Mr. Dunn, 61, who is married and has three grown sons, says he will have no problem reaching out to the diverse population of Westchester, noting that he sits on the executive committee of Covenant House and on the board of Mercy College, which has a large minority enrollment.
Mr. Spano, also 61, is married with six children and is thought of by his fellow Democrats as a down-to-earth, people-oriented politician. "I think Andy understands the normal person who uses government," Mr. Abinanti said. "He understands that government is there to provide services that people need, but that it shouldn't cost any more than it has to."
Like Mr. Dunn, Mr. Spano said he would create green space along the riverfront. He also said he would take steps to improve Westchester's economy, since it has the least amount of growth of surrounding counties. But Mr. Spano's major issue is a pledge to cut county taxes by 15 percent, although critics question whether such a large cut is possible. He said he would lower taxes by cutting the county executive's budget, reducing the number of automobiles available to county employees, reducing welfare and cutting the salaries of managers and commissioners by 5 percent, among other measures.
His detractors attribute his lead to name recognition, part of that the misperception that he is a member of a powerful Republican clan from Yonkers with the same surname whose members include a State Senator and the current county clerk. Mr. Spano takes exception to that assertion. "I've made a big effort over the years to divorce myself from them," he said. "I was county clerk for 11 years. It's an insult to people's intelligence to suggest they vote on a name."
To those who ask whether he can really cut taxes, Mr. Spano says he kept the county clerk's office under budget annually, resulting in surpluses that totaled more than $6 million in his 11 years in office.
His opponent concedes that there were budget surpluses, but characterizes Mr. Spano's tenure as county clerk as one marked by runaway spending, noting that the county clerk's budget went to $4.1 million from $1.7 million.
Mr. Dunn has also accused Mr. Spano of more than tripling spending for salaries during his 11 years in office, but Mr. Spano says that the County Executive and the Board of Legislators, not he, approved his budget and set the salary scale. In addition, salary levels were not tripled. Some of the increase was because of the addition of employees to the county payroll when state aid for these positions was withdrawn and because of the addition of a new archives unit to the office of county clerk.
Mr. Dunn was cited by the Westchester County Fair Campaign Practices Committee for misrepresenting the facts in asserting that Mr. Spano tripled salaries.
But Mr. Spano was also cited by the committee for misleading advertising. In one radio commercial, he says that although $1 million in taxes was collected by the Dunn administration to repair sewer lines in Rye, the sewer lines are still leaking. The committee found that the money to repair the sewer lines came from the sale of property held by the city, not taxes, and that there was no evidence presented to the committee that the sewer lines are leaking.
Much of the campaign advertising on both sides has been negative, and in recent weeks Mr. Dunn has added television commercials to his arsenal.
He has criticized Mr. Spano for his statements about political patronage, including one in 1993 in which he said, "I don't think patronage is a bad thing." Mr. Spano said recently that he was expressing his belief that "people who worked on my campaign or for the Democratic Party shouldn't be eliminated from the competition for jobs."
He added, "I hired people because they were competent."
Mr. Spano's latest commercial says that Mr. Dunn's campaign strategists are also used by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. Mr. Dunn has a commercial lambasting Mr. Spano for taking a trip to Walt Disney World with taxpayer money when he was county clerk.
Mr. Spano said that he was invited to Orlando, Fla., by I.B.M. to participate on a panel at its annual conference for municipal officials on re-engineering government because of his successes as county clerk and that I.B.M. reimbursed the county for the trip. If there was reimbursement, Mr. Dunn maintains that Mr. Spano violated the county code of ethics by accepting a gift of more than $75 from a company with millions of dollars in contracts with the county.
With all the charges and countercharges, one prominent elected official predicts that the race will be close. "I'm calling it a draw," he said. "And somebody's going to win by a couple of thousand votes."

Ted Dunn, the Republican candidate, was backed by the Westchester County Correction Officers Benevolent Association in White Plains. (Photographs by Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Are Hurt By Strong Econonic Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday after strong housing and manufacturing data again raised investors' worries about growth, inflation and interest rates.
Traders said a Market News report quoting unnamed Federal Reserve officials as saying that they were concerned that the inflation picture could rapidly deteriorate without a tighter monetary policy also brought more selling in the afternoon. 
 The 30-year bond dropped 19/32 , to a price of 99 6/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction rose to 6.44 percent, from 6.39 percent on Thursday. A drop in stocks saw some investors abandon that market for Treasury bills in a flight to quality. The rate of the three-month bill dropped to 4.90 from 4.91 percent.
The Treasury market initially posted losses after the Commerce Department said starts of housing rose 7.9 percent in September, after two months of decline. Traders said losses were extended by a Federal Reserve report that showed industrial production up seven-tenths of 1 percent and capacity at 84.4 percent last month, higher than the 83.9 percent some economists were expecting. In fact, it was above the 84 percent historical level that has been associated with inflation.
The reports showing strong economic growth only heightened the jitters in the market since Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, sounded a warning on inflation before Congress last week. Mr. Greenspan's testimony along with recent reports showing strong growth have raised expectations that Fed policy makers will raise short-term interest rates at their meeting next month.
But not all the data released yesterday pointed to strong growth. The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index slipped to 105.2 in October from 106 in September, traders said. (The Michigan survey is released only to subscribers.)
There was also talk of an Asian central bank in the market buying $1 billion of 10-year notes, which allowed the market to come back briefly.
And on Thursday, the Government said consumer prices rose a smaller-than expected two-tenths of 1 percent last month, suggesting that inflation remained subdued.
"The C.P.I. continues to delight and amaze bond market participants, as it rose considerably less than feared,"said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management. "But because of robust consumer spending, G.D.P. growth during the third quarter doesn't appear to have differed much from the 3.3 percent pace of the second quarter, and the perspicuous third-quarter inventory drag implies a rather hefty gain in real final sales.
"The Fed is not going to let down its inflation defenses, particularly with very tight labor markets, high capacity usage, and the pace of economic growth continuing above the Fed's concept of the maximum, noninflationary trend rate."
Market participants found little solace in a speech yesterday by Jack Guynn, president of the Atlanta Federal Reseve Bank, to the Economic Club of Florida. Mr. Guynn, a voting member of the Federal Open Market Committee, who expects the economy to post about a 3.5 percent growth rate this year, said he did not see consumer debt as much of a constraint on spending.
