HEADLINE: On the Stump, Whitman Touts Record Employment

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
With less than three weeks to go before Election Day, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday that New Jersey had regained all the jobs that were lost in the last recession, and announced that the state had reached a new high in the number of employed residents, surpassing the record set at the height of the last boom in 1989.
Standing under a suspended net of red, white and blue balloons in the vaulted stone and glass atrium at the Horizon Corporate Center in Mount Laurel, Mrs. Whitman chose a campaign setting that was in many ways emblematic of the economic changes in New Jersey since she took office: a ceremony marking the expansion of yet another white-collar financial services company, the PHH Mortgage Corporation. 
 "There are 3.7 million jobs in the state of New Jersey today -- more people working than ever in our history," Mrs. Whitman said, in announcing the numbers. "This is success."
But economists say that the job numbers, while clearly positive for the state, do not describe the reality that many ordinary residents see in their pocketbooks and in their workplaces. That discrepancy, they say, partly explains why Mrs. Whitman -- even bearing bullish news like yesterday's -- is facing a tight race with her Democratic Party challenger, James E. McGreevey. A new poll for The Star-Ledger of Newark by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University said yesterday that Mrs. Whitman's lead over Mr. McGreevey -- a little-known, small-city Mayor not long ago -- had slipped to just 4 percentage points, within the poll's margin of sampling error.
Whatever the economic realities, Mrs. Whitman chose a part of the state that is probably more appropriate to political realities. Many communities in the state's southern tier -- tied to the Philadelphia economy -- have not done as well as the areas to the north that are tied to New York City, which has become a major economic engine in the last few years. In her comments, Mrs. Whitman said that much had been accomplished and that companies like PHH Mortgage Corporation were leading the charge.
"PHH's expansion in Mount Laurel is an economic boon for South Jersey," Mrs. Whitman said. The balloons fell. The crowd of about 300 people applauded. A disk jockey played hip-hop tunes.
Mr. McGreevey, who did not campaign yesterday, and Mrs. Whitman were preparing for a debate today that is scheduled to be televised from 1 to 2 P.M. on the New Jersey Network and some cable stations. The debate will also include the Libertarian Party candidate, Murray Sabrin, who qualified based on meeting a goal for campaign contributions set under state law.
The economy, and what its numbers mean or do not mean, is expected to be a major topic at the debate, and at the two remaining debates on Tuesday and Friday.
Economists say the economic division of north and south is only one of the new patterns that have emerged in the 1990's that are being played out against the backdrop of the gubernatorial election. There is also a sense of dislocation, as the types of jobs and the mix of industries have shifted, and as indicators continue to show a level of economic stress among many residents. The economy, despite the numbers released yesterday, has not been restored to where it was eight years ago, but rather delivered to a new place.
"The industries that are creating jobs and are important today are very different from the ones in the late 1980's," said Mark Zandi, the chief economist at Regional Financial Associates, a West Chester, Pa., research company.
Traditional employers that provided jobs for about 40 percent of New Jersey's residents eight years ago -- construction, government and manufacturing -- are far smaller today than they were then, and continue to show signs of chronic contraction. About 2,100 more manufacturing jobs were lost in the state last month, the State Department of Labor said.
The state's average poverty rate for a two-year period ending in 1996 was unchanged from the previous two-year period, the United States Bureau of the Census said, despite the growth in jobs. New Jersey also had the unwelcome distinction last month of being singled out by the census bureau as one of only six states in the nation in which the number of people with health insurance declined over the two-year period.
Democrats also seized yesterday on the fact that the state's unemployment rate actually went up in September, to 5.4 percent, from 5.2 percent in August. The jobless rate increased, the state said, because more people were looking for work than there were new jobs. The national unemployment rate in September was 4.9 percent.
"If anything, New Jersey stands out because its unemployment rate is higher than the national average," Richard McGrath, a spokesman for Mr. McGreevey, said. "There's also an underlying anxiety about job security and employment prospects. That severely tempers the good news."
The New Jersey Department of Labor said in its monthly report that 20,100 more people in the state were employed in September than in August. That includes about 10,300 employees of United Parcel Service who returned to work after the settlement of a strike by the teamsters' union. The increase pushed the total nonfarm payroll total to 3,717,800 people. The previous peak was in March 1989, at 3,706,400 jobs, just before the onset of long and deep recession in the region.
But the significance of crossing that threshold also varies widely depending on one's perspective. By local standards, it looks pretty good. New York and Connecticut, by contrast, are not even close to regaining the jobs lost in the recession. New York City, in particular, has regained only about 40 percent of its lost jobs, despite strong and accelerating growth in the last two years.
By national standards, however, the state's performance is not so lustrous. The recession that battered the New York region was far milder across the rest of the country. Other major industrial states like Illinois, Michigan, Florida, Texas and North Carolina all regained their lost jobs several years ago. Neighboring Pennsylvania has more than 200,000 more jobs than it did at its pre-recession peak.
Economists say that the monthly totals conform to a pattern that the state has settled into, particularly in the last two or three years: the growth is steady and moderate, and concentrated in areas like business services, which includes everything from consultants to accountants.
"What the figures are suggesting," said John L. Wieting, the regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, "is that New Jersey is positioned for sustained and moderate job growth."

HEADLINE: As Crash Date Nears, Few Still Fear Stocks

 BODY:
From Wall Street to Main Street, the stock market crash 10 years ago, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell 508 points, is a distant memory for many.
Once seen as an arcane world reserved for the shrewd and the wealthy, playing the stock market has become almost everybody's game. It has replaced sports as lunch counter conversation even in the middle of Iowa, in Marshalltown, a town of 26,000 people -- and 12 stockbrokers. 
 Still, there have been some hiccups. Yesterday -- the last trading day before the 10th anniversary of Black Monday, Oct. 19, 1987 -- the Dow briefly tumbled nearly 180 points, or 2.4 percent. Indeed, some traders said that the psychological stigma of the 1987 crash was a subtle influence hanging over the market yesterday.
But stocks recovered, and the Dow industrials closed down 91.85 points, hurt largely in the end by concerns over corporate earnings and renewed inflation.
Despite the recent jitters, Wall Street denizens continue to count on America's love affair with stocks to keep the money rolling in.
Business Day, page D1.

HEADLINE: Little Panel That Could, Did, Posing Threat of Trade War

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
During the budget battle two years ago, Republicans in Congress proposed abolishing the Federal Maritime Commission, arguing that the regulatory agency had outlived its purpose. For most of the day today, the Administration sounded as if it wished it had gone along with the idea.
The commission's decision on Thursday to wield its considerable though little-known authority to bar Japanese cargo ships from American ports sent the Administration scrambling to avert a nasty confrontation with Japan that could easily have broadened into a trade war. 
 As a clutch of officials gathered at the White House to decide how to respond, trade negotiators worked through the day at the Department of Transportation to resolve a long-simmering dispute, which involves better access for American ships to Japanese ports and an earlier $4 million retaliatory fine levied on Japanese companies.
By the end of the day, though, the commission's bold action appeared to have forced the two parties to draft an agreement on the shipping dispute.
But during the crisis talks of the last 24 hours, the United States found itself in the unusual position of joining Japan in calling for an agency of its own Government to reverse itself.
Thus, the small maritime agency was persuaded late today to postpone any action until Monday, averting for now the improbable spectacle of Coast Guard cutters hunting down Japanese freighters in American ports. Page A6.
The drastic step taken by the commission's board, which has only four members rather than five at the moment, caught the White House and other agencies unprepared. All the more so since it occurred while the President, the Secretary of State and the national security adviser were all out of the country.
"We did not have advance notice," one official said curtly today.
The chairman of the commission, Harold J. Creel Jr., brushed aside those complaints today.
He said the agency's decision to resort to sanctions reflected a growing frustration with the inability of diplomats to resolve a dispute that was hurting American ships. Without the commission's willingness to show a little independence, he said, the dispute would still not be resolved.
"It's fair to say we were disappointed that diplomatic measures hadn't worked," said Mr. Creel, 40, a lawyer from South Carolina who previously worked for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and as a senior counsel to the Senate's Subcommittee on the Merchant Marine.
"But for imposing these sanctions, we would not have had the Japanese at the table today. That's the whole point of having sanctions."
The decision and the scramble it caused have shone a spotlight on an agency that in Washington's sprawling bureaucracy is so obscure that few outside of the shipping industry have even heard of it, or of its chairman, Mr. Creel.
Its surprising move has also underscored the extent to which even the most arcane of trade practices -- and the agencies that oversee them -- can have profound effects on foreign affairs.
"Maybe this is their 15 minutes," said one Administration official, who like many others, sounded more than a little put out by the commission's decision.
The Federal Maritime Commission was established on Aug. 12, 1961, to oversee the web of statutes and laws regulating the nation's ports and shipping industries -- from the Shipping Acts of 1916 to the Merchant Marine Act of 1920. It was that latter act that the commission invoked to justify what would have amounted to a blockade of Japanese ships.
In short, it regulates seaborne commerce to and from the United States, which totals more than $500 billion a year. While regulatory agencies are rarely popular among the industries they cover, the commission's mandate to insure that American ships are not burdened with unfair fees in foreign ports has won it strong company support.
And that, more than anything, may be what has saved it from extinction.
In the age of deregulation, many critics on Capitol Hill and beyond have argued that the commission has become largely irrelevant. In 1992, during the Bush Administration, one of the commission's own members proposed abolishing the agency, as did a panel appointed early in the Clinton Administration and the Republicans who swept to power in the House after the 1994 elections.
Each time, the commission survived the chopping block after lobbyists for the nation's shipping concerns -- and supportive lawmakers from states that depend heavily on their ports -- took up its cause.
In the vast Federal bureaucracy, the agency is certainly tiny -- with 140 employees and a budget of $14 million. The commission's members, including the chairman, are appointed by the President with the consent of the Senate. The appointees, who are by statute supposed to be bipartisan, serve five-year terms. Mr. Creel was appointed to the chairman's job in February 1996. He is a Democrat.
The association's independence is theoretically supposed to free the commission from political pressures from, say, the Departments of Transportation, State or Commerce, in disputes exactly like the one with Japan, which the United States accuses of setting exorbitantly high port fees and imposing dense regulations.
In this case, it certainly exhibited an independence -- much to the chagrin of the Administration.
A senior Administration official said the White House -- not to mention President Clinton's entourage traveling through Argentina -- learned of the decision to bar Japanese ships only after reports appeared on the news wires. But Mr. Creel insisted that lower-level officials at State and Transportation were kept abreast of the matter.
As news of the decision spread, one official at the State Department expressed disbelief that any agency in Government could have acted so decisively without a thorough review of the effects on foreign policy, especially since it is supposed to police unfair practices overseas in conjunction with the State Department.
While it operates in obscurity, the commission has threatened sanctions in the past. In 1983, it came very close to barring Venezuelan ships in retaliation for what it said were unfair practices -- only to drop the threat when diplomats hammered out a settlement in a scenario similar to this week's.
"That's certainly what we want out of all of this," Mr. Creel said, "a diplomatic resolution."

HEADLINE: U.S. SAYS CHINESE WILL STOP SENDING MISSILES TO IRAN

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
China has promised the Clinton Administration that it will no longer send anti-ship cruise missiles to Iran, senior American officials said today, 10 days before a state visit by China's President, Jiang Zemin.
China has also agreed in principle to halt its nuclear assistance to Iran, a senior official said, and key Administration officials flew to China today to complete an accord. If China signs such an agreement, President Clinton could then lift an American ban on sales to China of nuclear technology for civilian power. 
 Dealing with China has been one of Mr. Clinton's most awkward problems. While he wants to bring China into the web of international relationships and take advantage of its economic potential, his policy of engagement has been criticized by Republicans as appeasement of a threat to America's interests. Under the conflicting pressures, he has reversed course many times.
Mr. Jiang's visit comes as criticism of China has focused on its repression of dissent, its punishment of human-rights advocates, its restrictions on religious practice and its history of selling dangerous technology to Iran and Pakistan.
The Administration is using the visit to press Beijing to improve its behavior and will want to highlight its successes, while critics suggest that Chinese promises may prove to be hollow.
"The whole logic of this is backward," said Robert Kagan of the Carnegie Endowment, who is a critic of Mr. Clinton's China policy. "The Chinese want a nuclear cooperation agreement. And the Administration, which otherwise has nothing to show for this summit, wants to give Beijing what is in effect a present which shows the success of engagement, which the Chinese have not yet earned."
The new pledge to stop selling Iran the conventional cruise missiles, known as C-801's and C-802's, was made directly to Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright by the Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen. Congress and the Pentagon have criticized the missile sales as a danger to vessels in the Persian Gulf.
The pledge may take some criticism off Mr. Clinton. The issue has been used by Republicans in Congress to accuse the Administration of weakness in defending American interests, and an American law would require imposing sanctions on China if Beijing exported enough of missiles to "destabilize" the gulf.
China is not required by any international agreements to halt the missile sales to Iran, but Administration officials told the Chinese that relations with the United States were much more important to China's future than a low-level military supply relationship with Teheran.
The pledge, one officials said, is also an indication of a more fundamental Chinese decision "to no longer be seen as a rogue state on proliferation." That would mark a sharp change from a decade ago, when China saw no problems with the spread of nuclear weapons to the developing world.
Officials acknowledged that China had not always fulfilled past pledges to limit its export of arms, technology and materiel to both Pakistan and Iran. Washington still has concerns about China's exports of dual-use chemicals and missile technology. Under the Reagan Administration, China broke written commitments to restrict missile exports to Pakistan, and was penalized.
But they say that China has come a long way on restricting its export of nuclear materials and expertise, and that a deal can be struck that would let Mr. Clinton carry out, for the first time, a 1985 agreement allowing American companies to sell nuclear power reactors to China.
Such an agreement, if it is reached, is expected to be the centerpiece of Mr. Jiang's visit, the first state visit by a Chinese leader to the United States in 12 years. Mr. Jiang is to go to Washington, Philadelphia, Cambridge, Mass., Los Angeles and four other cities. At each stop he is expected to be met by hundreds of demonstrators protesting Chinese policies, especially on human rights.
While the repression of dissent and religious practice in China are the most prominent issues for Mr. Jiang's critics, Chinese nuclear and missile exports to Iran and Pakistan have dominated the recent Congressional debates about China.
Last week, Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, a New York Republican who is chairman of the House International Relations Committee, urged the Administration to get strict assurances from China that it is no longer selling weapons of any kind to Iran before authorizing the sale of American nuclear reactors to Beijing, even for civilian power production.
"Our members need to know that China is engaging in responsible nonproliferation behavior across the board, including all weapons of mass destruction and conventional weapons," Mr. Gilman said.
Administration officials say they are concentrating hardest on the nuclear issue before the summit meeting, hoping to allow Mr. Clinton to certify that China is no longer helping any other nation develop nuclear weapons. That would let the 1985 Peaceful Nuclear Cooperation agreement come into force and allow American companies like Westinghouse, General Electric and ABB Combustion Engineering Nuclear Systems to sell nuclear power reactors to China.
For the American companies, the potential deals could be worth $15 billion through 2010, according to industry advocates. And China's interest in their reactors comes at a time when nuclear power is no longer very popular in much of the rest of the global market.
American officials say four issues are involved in whether Mr. Clinton can satisfy himself that certification is justified.
One is nuclear exports. The Chinese have issued national regulations that are supposed to cover such exports by the military as well as those of semi-privatized companies.
On the second issue, officials say the Chinese have also kept to their pledge of May 11, 1996, not to provide help to any "unsafeguarded nuclear facility," meaning one not open to inspection by the International Atomic Energy Agency. That covers Pakistan, but Iran does allow such inspections, which had left aid to Iran a question.
On the third issue, Iran, the Americans have wanted China to phase out its nuclear cooperation and put that pledge into writing.
Last, the Chinese, just on Thursday, joined the so-called Zanger Committee, which groups equipment suppliers who have signed the treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear seapons and prepares lists of equipment that should not be exported without safeguards.
The Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Nonproliferation, Robert J. Einhorn, and his National Security Council counterpart, Gary Samore, flew to Beijing today to try to nail down the written pledge with Iran.
They also hope that Beijing will agree to even stricter export controls than the Zanger Committee requires, closer to the controls of the Nuclear Suppliers Group, which requires all importers of nuclear equipment to allow full inspections of all nuclear activity by the International Atomic Energy Agency.

HEADLINE: Deal Is Close On Keeping L.I.R.R. Going

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
With the deadline for an Amtrak strike that could also cripple local commuter railroads just five days away, union leaders and Amtrak reached a tentative agreement yesterday to keep the Long Island Rail Road running into Manhattan even if a strike occurs.
The union involved in the labor dispute, which represents track inspectors, agreed to let several dozen workers from other unions cross its picket lines to maintain four miles of Amtrak-owned tracks that connect the L.I.R.R. system with Pennsylvania Station, the destination of most of the L.I.R.R.'s 260,000 daily passengers. 
 "We have an agreement in principle," said Amtrak's chief spokesman, Clifford R. Black 4th, "provided various things are fulfilled." Among them, he said, were a consensus on the number of workers needed to keep the trains running safely and the agreement of the other unions.
But attempts yesterday to work out a similar arrangement for New Jersey Transit, which uses much more Amtrak-owned track, were "disappointing," said New Jersey's Transportation Commissioner, John Haley Jr. He said that meetings would continue Monday, but that yesterday's failure brought the state one step closer to a "transportation emergency."
There were no meetings yesterday concerning the underlying dispute over wages between Amtrak and the the Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employees, which represents 2,300 track inspectors. The two sides are not scheduled to meet again until Monday. But a spokeswoman for the National Mediation Board, the Federal agency that makes recommendations in rail disputes and seeks to aid bargaining, said the two sides were communicating.
A strike by the track inspectors would force the 35,000 people a day who ride Amtrak's Northeast Corridor line between Boston and Washington to find other ways to travel. Nationally, Amtrak has 60,000 daily passengers.
Amtrak also operates commuter lines carrying 175,000 people a day, and other railroads operating on Amtrak tracks carry an additional 357,000 passengers.
Among those 357,000 passengers are 65,000 on New Jersey Transit routes that use Amtrak's tracks to reach Pennsylvania Station from points as far south as Trenton; if an agreement is not reached to let those trains continue operating during a strike, those commuters would be forced into cars or buses, clogging highways. A strike would also cut off freight service to dozens of businesses and would damage New Jersey's economy, officials there said.
The New Jersey Transit lines that would be shut down are the entire Northeast Corridor line, which runs from Trenton to New York, the North Jersey Coast Line between Matawan and New York, and the Raritan Valley line between Westfield and Newark.
New Jersey officials have made contingency plans to roll out 500 extra buses to shuttle commuters on those lines from train stations to Newark, where they would take the PATH line to New York. The state also plans to add toll-takers and state police patrols and open up high-occupancy vehicle lanes to lessen traffic congestion.
Under the Long Island Rail Road agreement, reached after a two-hour meeting in Pennsylvania Station brokered by United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the track inspectors union is asking Amtrak signalmen, supervisors and dispatchers to cross the picket lines. "We don't normally do that," said Kevin Hussey, the union's New Jersey legislative director, "but we don't see any reason in the world why the commuters should be affected by an argument between the maintenance workers, who I represent, and Amtrak. Our quarrel is not with the Long Island Rail Road or the commuters who ride the Long Island Rail Road. Our quarrel is with Amtrak."
Mr. Hussey said he was confident the other unions would go along with the arrangement. "They're reluctant to cross the picket line," he said, "but it's our picket line, and if we say it's O.K., their guys are going to want to make money."
But an agreement to keep New Jersey Transit running was stymied because New Jersey Transit runs on 56 miles of Amtrak track across the state, while the Long Island Rail Road track uses Amtrak only from Pennsylvania Station through four tunnels under the East River to Queens.
Mr. Haley said Amtrak and the union could not get close to an agreement on how many workers -- who would have to be allowed across picket lines -- it would need to keep the New Jersey Transit system running, or on whether qualified workers could be found outside the track inspectors union.
After yesterday's Long Island Rail Road meeting, union, Amtrak and L.I.R.R. officials all said they were confident that replacement workers could run the system safely. Track inspectors maintain and inspect track, the third rails and overhead wires that power trains. Their inspections must be done as often as every other day.
If the Long Island Rail Road agreement cannot be finalized, a national Amtrak strike on Wednesday would throw the L.I.R.R., the nation's largest commuter railroad, into chaos. Its passengers would be forced to get off the train in Queens or Brooklyn and transfer to subways, adding an hour or more to their commutes.
Even if only New Jersey Transit and Amtrak are affected in the event of a strike, New York City officials are bracing for a big increase in car traffic and are considering suspending alternate-side parking rules.
Thomas Prendergast, the president of the L.I.R.R., said yesterday's meeting came after more than a week in which Amtrak had ignored a request by the L.I.R.R. to try to keep its trains running. The union said it asked Mr. D'Amato to intercede, and all sides credited Mr. D'Amato with making the agreement possible.
Maintenance of Way union officials have said they want to avoid shutting down the commuter lines because that could prompt Congress to step in and end a strike on terms that probably would not favor the union. Mr. D'Amato said that for exactly the same reason, some Amtrak officials would like to see any strike be as painful as possible.

HEADLINE: Touchy-Feely Schools

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Hurray for Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew! In his move to limit the independence of alternative schools (news article, Oct. 13), he has brought their questionable value to public attention. At some alternative high schools, teachers and students design projects that integrate subjects across disciplines and connect learning and life experiences. In a discussion of the role of power in their lives or in examining how families contribute to what we are, mathematics, grammar, history and science may be introduced. Graduation comes when the faculty approves the portfolios presented by students. 
 As someone who taught history at City University of New York colleges for 38 years, I feel able to say that waiting for academic topics to crop up in "touchy-feely" discussions is doing a grave injustice to our young people, most of whom need structure, content and skills training in order to enter our city's economic life.
 
SELMA CANTOR BERROL
New York, Oct. 14, 1997

INTERNATIONAL A3-7
 
China's Missile Sales To Iran to Stop, U.S. Says
Ten days before President Jiang Zemin visits Washington, China has promised that it will no longer send anti-ship cruise missiles to Iran, senior American officials said. This could allow U.S. companies to resume technology sales to China. A1 

Accord in Reach on Japan Ports
The United States and Japan appeared to reach a last-minute agreement to lift restrictions on American ships operating in Japanese ports, just hours before the Coast Guard was to begin barring Japanese vessels from entering or leaving American harbors. A6
 
The Administration and the Tokyo Government seemed to respond to pressure from the Federal Maritime Commission, which ordered the curbs on Japanese vessels. A1
 
Che Fights On From Mausoleum
The remains of Che Guevara were laid to rest in Santa Clara, Cuba, where he and his comrade-in-arms Fidel Castro won a crucial victory in their successful revolution against the dictator Fulgencio Batista. A coffin containing the skeleton was interred in a mausoleum and President Castro said Guevara was "everywhere there is a just cause to defend." His body was recently found in a mass grave in Bolivia, where he was executed in 1967. A3
 
French Review Algerian Killings
The French Government announced that it would open secret archives relating to the killing of dozens of Algerians in Paris in October 1961 after Maurice Papon, then the police chief in Paris, denied that police were responsible for the bodies fished from the Seine and city canals. Mr. Papon is on trial in Bordeaux, accused of organizing the deportation of 1,690 Jews to German concentration camps during the war. A5
 
New Prime Minister for Poland
A former anti-Communist activist, Jerzy Buzek, was named Poland's new Prime Minister. Mr. Buzek, 57, will lead a coalition of two parties, the union-based Solidarity Election Action and the market-oriented Freedom Union, which combined to defeat the former Communists in elections last month. His desire for Poland to enter the European Union has elicited opposition from protectionist force in Solidarity. Poland also ushered in a new Constitution that dilutes the president's powers. A4
 
Mexican Police Embarrassment
Mexico City's police chief disbanded an elite motorcycle unit after 12 members were arrested on charges related to the deaths of three youths detained last month. The chief reassigned 135 officers from the "Jaguar" unit to traffic duties; they used to patrol the streets in groups of six, wearing bullet-proof vests and toting machine guns. (Reuters)
 
Singapore Mops Up Oil Spill
Crews in Singapore struggled to contain the damage from the spill of 7 million gallons of oil off the coast. Two ships collided on Wednesday, eight miles south of Singapore. (AP)
 
NATIONAL A8-11, 16
 
States Move to Regulate Uses of Genetic Testing
Concerned that the Federal Government is acting too slowly to protect the confidentiality of genetic information, states are passing their own laws to regulate the use of genetic test results and to prevent discrimination by insurers and employers. Insurers contend that the laws will force them to raise premiums, while drug companies say the restrictions will make it harder to conduct research. At least 26 states have adopted such laws, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. Typically, the measures prohibit insurance companies and health plans from requiring genetic tests or using the results to deny coverage or increase premiums. A1
 
Racial Change in Minneapolis
Minneapolis has long boasted a tradition of generous social programs and enlightened views on American race relations even though only a tiny percentage of blacks actually lived in Minnesota. But the migration of blacks and other minorities is forcing residents and civic leaders to grapple with issues of race, class and crime that most other big American cities confronted long ago. A1
 
Clinton Vetoes 3 Projects
President Clinton vetoed several of what he called "unwarranted corporate subsidies" from the traditionally pork-laden spending bill for energy and water development projects. Mr. Clinton, exercising his new power for the third time in a week, eliminated three projects costing $6.3 million that the White House said were unjustified handouts to industry. The vetoed items were a copper-mining venture in Arizona, research on high-conductivity electrical cables and licensing subsidies for canisters to store spent nuclear fuel and high-level radioactive waste. A10
 
Miami Unites Behind Marlins
The Florida Marlins, who became the youngest expansion team to qualify for the World Series, which begins today, have bonded a city that has been increasingly fractured along ethnic and racial lines. The new team, started and owned by H. Wayne Huizenga, a Fort Lauderdale billionaire who made his money in garbage disposal and videotapes, is a mini-United Nations itself, with players from Cuba, Colombia, Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic. A8
 
Weapons Inquiry Widens
Federal and military investigators said they were looking into the possibility that the six marines arrested on Thursday for stealing and selling large quantities of military explosives and ammunition from Camp Lejeune, N.C., might not have been the only military personnel in the country involved in munitions and weapons thievery. A8
 
Tobacco Suit Thrown Out
A Federal judge in Philadelphia threw out a major class-action lawsuit against the tobacco industry, saying the statute of limitations had run out because the smokers should have known the dangers of cigarettes years ago. A9

A Kennedy Ghost Writer?
A recently discovered 40-year-old letter written by a history professor appears to support his claim that he wrote major portions of John F. Kennedy's Pulitzer Prize-winning book, "Profiles in Courage." Jules Davids, a professor at Georgetown University in the School of Foreign Service, wrote the letter in response to a query from a former university vice president after Senator Kennedy won the award in 1957. Theodore Sorenson, a longtime Kennedy confidant who has often been cited as the book's true author, characterized Mr. Davids's claims as an overstatement of his involvement. B7

Accounting Merger Likely
Two of the world's biggest accounting firms, KPMG Peat Marwick and Ernst & Young, are expected to announce as soon as next week that they will merge. The deal would create the world's largest accounting firm, with $15.3 billion in worldwide revenue. Two Government reports renewed fears that the economy is running too fast. Production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities jumped seven-tenths of 1 percent last month -- to make growth for the July-September quarter the biggest in 13 years -- as their operating rate edged closer to capacity. And builders broke ground on 7.9 percent more new homes in September. D1

SECTION: Section 7; Page 16; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 2721 words

HEADLINE: Baseball in Black and White

BYLINE: By Michael Anderson; Michael Anderson is an editor at The New York Times Book Review.

 BODY:

Jackie Robinson
 A Biography.
 By Arnold Rampersad.
 Illustrated. 512 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50. 
 HOW firmly he is fixed in the cultural firmament: even his name has become a cliche. Just as "Jackie Robinson" is now a synonym for trailblazer, so has Jack Roosevelt Robinson been simplified and reduced into folklore. The mythic Robinson exists as a succession of rousing, if fuzzy, impressions: of solitude, strife and flashing spikes, of base-running bravado and beanballs, of pennants and provocations and perseverance -- "the unconquerable doing the impossible," to borrow Red Smith's grandiloquence. With its suggestions of hero and martyr, the legend has reverberated in the national imagination "as the epitome not only of stoic endurance," Arnold Rampersad writes in his biography, "but also of intelligence, bravery, physical power and grit." Robinson's has been a decisive significance in what Rampersad calls the "complex drama involving the sometimes harmonious, sometimes conflicting needs and desires of black and white America." Robinson never shed his identification as the representative of his race, nor did he ever want to; with an earnest zeal he personified the ritualized angst of racial assimilation.
"The Jackie Robinson story is to Americans what the Passover story is to Jews: it must be told to every generation so that we never forget," Jules Tygiel comments in an afterword to Oxford University Press's paperback edition of "Baseball's Great Experiment" (originally published in 1983), his authoritative social history of baseball's integration. Robinson's 10-year career with the Brooklyn Dodgers (the players' names evoking the melting pot: Erskine, Furillo, Snider, Abrams, Hermanski, Shuba) has become a fable of integration. For white Americans, many of whom experienced improved race relations over the last 50 years as a series of encounters with the exemplary exception, Robinson is forever the first and the best -- just as his name was automatic in the litany of "firsts," and "onlys," whose memorization constituted (until recently) the pedagogy of black history. So familiar, in fact, is the Robinson legend that during the golden anniversary of his epochal rookie season this year, it exuded an unmistakable mustiness; too many of the public tributes sounded more dutiful than heartfelt.
Somewhat surprisingly, until now there has been no rigorous account of Robinson's life. Rampersad, who collaborated on Arthur Ashe's memoir after writing the definitive biography of Langston Hughes, has assembled a jumble of journalistic, archival and oral data into an elegantly rendered, meticulously documented narrative, a level-headed and sensitive chronicle of Robinson's life from his birth in a sharecropper's cabin, the grandson of a slave, in 1919 to his death 53 years later.
Telling a story that is well known if not always known well, Rampersad, with crisp economy, recounts the ageless anecdotes -- the first interview with Branch Rickey ("I know you're a good ballplayer. What I don't know is whether you have the guts"), or Leo Durocher's tart-tongued suppression of the players' revolt during spring training in 1947 ("I don't care if the guy is yellow or black, or if he has stripes. . . . I'm the manager of this team, and I say he plays"). In cleaning off the chestnuts, he also clarifies the legend. For example: about Pee Wee Reese, the Kentucky-born captain of the Dodgers, Rampersad writes that the "most telling single act" in his "important role" was when Reese "dared to put his white hand on Robinson's black shoulder in a gesture of solidarity"; he immediately adds, "Exactly when and where this moment came is uncertain." He astutely assesses the beanball savagery Robinson is celebrated for enduring: Robinson was hit by pitches six times in his first 37 games, the same number as the National League leader for the entire 1946 season. "While Robinson's color was almost certainly a factor in these blows," Rampersad writes, "it only compounded the tendency of pitchers to throw at rookies. Robinson was hit by pitches but three more times over the rest of the season. He had passed a key test of courage, one that broke many a young ballplayer."
Branch Rickey, the Dodgers' general manager, emerges as a moral entrepreneur of vision and stature. In the flamboyant, Bible-quoting oratory that inspired sportswriters to call his office "the Cave of Winds," Rickey issued multiple and conflicting explanations for his recruitment of black players, always denying, with proper Methodist humility, that he was interested in racial justice. Today it is clear that Rickey, determined to integrate baseball, enjoyed blowing smoke to camouflage his careful preparations and his intricate maneuvering; in his relish at scheming to achieve noble results through trickery, Branch Rickey is baseball's equivalent of Oskar Schindler. "Rickey's thinking clearly went beyond pragmatism," Rampersad writes; he seized the "chance to intervene in the moral history of the nation."
"Triumph of Whole Race Seen in Jackie's Debut in Major League Ball," a Boston newspaper declared. That such weight and intensity of racial identification was put on a professional athlete can seem baffling now; and it makes Robinson's rookie-of-the-year performance appear all the more majestic: in a sport that incorporates failure (as the bromide has it, even the best hitters make an out seven times out of 10), Robinson was compelled to succeed. "Over a period of six months . . . he had revolutionized the image of black Americans in the eyes of many whites," Rampersad writes. "Neither blacks nor whites would be quite the same."
It was a time when white indifference to racial inequity was a compound of complacent distaste, ineffectual benevolence and mildly guilty inertia -- comparable to the average city dweller's attitude today toward the homeless -- a time when the sole recognition most blacks expected from white society was some form of humiliation. So automatic and unspoken were caste taboos that the immortal Dodger broadcaster Red Barber -- a gentleman but one Mississippi-born -- made an immediate (and, of course, temporary) decision to quit when Rickey told him (in 1945) that the team would someday add a black player. It is impossible to underestimate how fundamental a need Robinson fulfilled for millions of people with his public assertion of dignity.
(In my early childhood, my grandmother often recounted attending one of Robinson's first games in Wrigley Field, when the overflow of black fans forced the ball park's ushers to keep expanding the black section of the stands. "Ah, hell, let 'em sit where they want!" one said finally; my grandmother always chuckled after mimicking his tone of exasperation, still savoring a rare and delightful little victory over the white folks.)
Back then, there were baseball-playing dads rather than soccer moms; Robinson's triumph within the national pastime proved particularly satisfying as spectacle. The visual startle of his presence forced spectators to confront the stark reality of segregation; the very fact of his presence provided instant rectification. Baseball is an enterprise energetic in the production of objects for obsessive, short-term adoration; the sport has long served to certify ethnic groups as worthy of general applause. Robinson allowed black people to join the Irish, Italians, Jews, Germans and good ol' boys.
Rampersad's effort to reveal the man inside the cliche benefited incalculably from the cooperation, without restriction or authorization, of Rachel Robinson. She has achieved iconic power of her own: in an age that has seen, alas, too many variations of the Noble Widow, no one has better kept the flame -- just as, when he was alive, "her reserved charm, easy intelligence and striking looks" amplified her husband's glow of cultivated vitality. (Her image was frequently included with Jackie's in what Rampersad notes were probably the first mass-market commercials to use blacks as spokesmen.) Her recollections of traveling in 1946 as a newlywed across the South to Robinson's first training camp become, in Rampersad's telling, a chronicle of the soul-searing effects of Jim Crow. Rachel, 23 years old, college-educated, confidently middle-class -- her "finishing-school poise," a New York reporter would sigh the next year, was not of "the Brooklyn baseball fan variety" -- set off from Los Angeles in regal attire and with a regal disdain. During a stopover in New Orleans, she ostentatiously ignored "Whites Only" signs on drinking fountains and restrooms ("The women stared at me, but nobody said or did anything. I sort of liked the women staring at me. I felt very strong"). Jackie and Rachel were bumped from one, then two flights, their seats taken by white passengers; they were directed to "dirty, dreadful" lodgings. Deciding to continue by bus, the weary couple were ordered out of their comfortable reclining seats to the rear, where they joined other blacks in sharing the few fixed-back seats. "What the laborers made of the strange couple -- the man asleep in his rumpled suit and tie, the lady with her massed curls and her ermine coat and alligator bag -- Rachel could only imagine." Thirty-six hours after leaving the West Coast, Jackie and Rachel arrived in Daytona Beach, Fla. "I finally began to realize that where we were going with Mr. Rickey's plan, none of us had ever been before," Rachel remembers. "We were setting out on something we really didn't understand."
Rampersad attributes Robinson's uncommonly resolute sense of mission -- "A life is not important except in the impact it has on other lives," he once declared -- to his mother, Mallie. Abandoned by her husband, she carried the 17-month-old Jackie, his sister and three brothers from a Georgia plantation to Pasadena, Calif.; with her wages as a maid ($8 a week at her arrival in 1920), she quickly bought a house in an all-white neighborhood. Mallie's "unshakable attachment to religion, the entirely willful way she delivered herself and her fortunes to God without becoming fatalistic or withdrawing from the world," nurtured in Jackie the rare and attractive quality of piety untainted by piousness: "A modest man," Rampersad writes, "he believed nevertheless that God was behind his life, guiding it, and intending him for some important purpose." Combining his relentless competitiveness (an eye-opening leitmotif of Rampersad's book is Robinson's fierce need to dominate) and his generation's commitment to racial uplift, "Robinson had taken it upon himself to carry forward his people's struggle against injustice."
The apogee of his political influence coincided with the second Eisenhower Administration. Fervently anti-Communist, resolutely capitalist and earnestly conservative, Robinson was the very portrait of the socially active business executive. "A year after quitting baseball," Rampersad writes, "Robinson had become a forceful, respected part of the civil rights debate" -- a nonstop fund-raiser and speaker for the N.A.A.C.P., a columnist for The New York Post, the host of a weekly radio interview program, a guest on "Meet the Press," a man who could confidently proclaim, "Knowing President Eisenhower as I do. . . ." He exercised his celebrity and prestige so relentlessly that Jet magazine asked on its cover, "Does Jackie Robinson Talk Too Much?"
Robinson marks a transformation in the black political posture from supplicant to scold. Rickey's demand that he turn the other cheek is famous ("If you want to take this gamble," Robinson said at that dramatic first meeting on Aug. 28, 1945, at 215 Montague Street in Brooklyn, "I will promise you there will be no incident"). Recalled less often is how brief was Robinson's forbearance: he opened his third season, 1949, warning opponents, "I'm going to be rough on them." Thereafter, as Tygiel has written, "no season went by without at least one major dispute surrounding Robinson." He assailed umpires, reporters, opponents, teammates, even his manager, Walter Alston. Having been dealt the trump of race cards, Robinson played it repeatedly. "If the public will analyze it," he declared in 1953, "they will see that those who have become opposed to me resent my success deep down inside only because I am a Negro." The shadow side of the Robinson myth is a cautionary tale of the limits of moral example and the dangers of moral vanity.
With the New Frontier, Robinson's political activity "trails off into disappointments and conditional sentences," as Roger Kahn wrote in "The Boys of Summer." Calling himself a one-man "pressure group for civil rights," Robinson traded heavily on his authority as the apotheosis of the American Negro. During the most tumultuous and factionalized years of the civil rights movement, he issued public, and personal, chastisements in his column in The Amsterdam News, across the board: Martin Luther King Jr., Malcolm X, Roger Wilkins and Adam Clayton Powell Jr.
He made a quixotic alliance with the Republican Party just as it began its lurch into reaction. Robinson ran aground of history by very publicly opposing John F. Kennedy in 1960. He remained a professed Republican but destroyed his standing in the G.O.P. by endorsing liberal Democrats in the 1964 and 1968 Presidential elections: "Robinson was a loose cannon, a force the party could not count on, and perhaps even a showboat," Rampersad writes. "I do not put personal feelings above the feeling I have for the masses of our people," Robinson stated with the gassy self-importance characteristic of his twilight years. Although his strident independence "would make him often appear noble in his loyalty to principle," Rampersad writes, "it would also make him seem to some people self-righteous and even undependable." By the time of his death in 1972, Robinson was the bitter, disillusioned man evident in the title of his memoir, "I Never Had It Made."
"Robinson was always a symbol, both an individual human being and also a figment of America's guilty, shame-filled imagination," Rampersad writes. His life emphasized how agonizing social transformation would prove to be, how clumsy governments and other established institutions were as agents to rectify abuses of human dignity, that race relations were less a "problem" to be solved than a situation to be lived with. Robinson eventually fell victim to the self-indulgent despair suffered by those who expect ideals to substitute for history -- more forgivable in any pioneer than in posterity, or in the glut of cheap sentiment that presumed to celebrate him this year. To ignore how profoundly the country has changed in half a century is to make nonsense of what Robinson did.
Although Rampersad implies otherwise, Robinson's public significance ended with his baseball career, when he struck out to end the 1956 World Series; and it is within baseball that Robinson's significance will be preserved. ("It's the box score that really counts," Robinson said the first time he met Branch Rickey, "that and that alone, isn't it?" "It's all that ought to count," Rickey replied.) Although it is ritual to bemoan the seasons lost because Robinson was 28 when he broke into the majors, the silver lining is that he was a seasoned athlete in his prime. From 1949 to 1954, Robinson averaged 100 runs scored a year with a combined batting average of .327; among active players, his six straight seasons batting over .300 were equaled by only Ted Williams and Stan Musial. Moreover, on a team of Hall of Famers, Robinson was the drink-stirrer: in his 10 years, the Dodgers went to six World Series (with two spectacular near misses), winning one. Yogi Berra said it best: "He could beat you in a lot of ways."
Robinson's plaque in the Hall of Fame has no mention of race, just as his rookie-of-the-year citation ignored, in the sniffy words of The Sporting News, "the sociological experiment that Robinson represented." (Another split between then and now: today, race alone would be qualification enough.) Absurd as it seems, there is something admirable about this narrow focus: forget everything else, baseball insists; Robby was a hell of a ballplayer. Perhaps baseball kept better faith than Jackie Robinson.

PUB-DATE: October 19, 1997

SECTION: Section 7; Page 44; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 848 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Laurel Graeber 

 BODY:

THE ARCHITECT OF DESIRE: Beauty and Danger
 in the Stanford White Family
 By Suzannah Lessard. Delta, $13.95.
The great-granddaughter of one of America's most celebrated architects describes a family life and legacy that were as dark and twisted as White's buildings were elegant and serene. White was not only a hedonist but a sexual predator, she writes; her own father was too, and more, having molested her during her childhood. "Few writers have ever captured the exquisite, delicate balance of architecture and memory as eloquently," Paul Goldberger said here last year.
 
OTHERWISE: New and Selected Poems
 By Jane Kenyon. Graywolf, $16.
The author's life included no small share of suffering: she frequently endured depression and died of leukemia in 1995, when she was only 47. But many of these poems sound an unmistakable note of hope and are a fervent but unsentimental celebration of ordinary things, from centipedes and chickadees to worn nightclothes and baled hay. Earlier this year our reviewer, Carol Muske, wrote, "Her words, with their quiet, rapt force, their pensiveness and wit, come to us from natural speech, from the Bible and hymns, from which she derived the singular psalmlike music that is hers alone."
 
GREAT BOOKS: My Adventures With Homer, Rousseau,
 Woolf, and Other Indestructible Writers of the Western World
 By David Denby. Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $15.
What happens when a middle-aged film critic goes back to his alma mater, Columbia University, and reimmerses himself in the Western canon? He falls in love again -- or, in some cases, for the first time. "The reader is left with a sense of optimism regarding the future of the humanities," Joyce Carol Oates said in these pages in 1996. Literature is also celebrated in A HISTORY OF READING, by Alberto Manguel (Penguin, $14.95), in which the author discusses not only the content of books but also their production, collection, shape and style. One feels "envious of his passion and grateful," Michael Milburn wrote here last year.
 
 GOOD EVENING MR. & MRS. AMERICA,
 AND ALL THE SHIPS AT SEA
 By Richard Bausch. Harper Perennial, $13.
This novel traces the sentimental and political education of Walter Marshall, a young idealist in the early 1960's. Hoping to become President, he learns that the road to the White House is rarely paved with good intentions. Its scenes are "funny and colorful," Gary Krist said in the Book Review in 1996.
 
 BRONX PRIMITIVE: Portraits in a Childhood
 By Kate Simon. Penguin, $10.95.
Selected as one of the best books of the year in 1982 by the editors of the Book Review, and now back in print, this memoir recalls immigrant Jewish life in New York in the years following World War I. Our reviewer, Helen Yglesias, called it "a splendid beginning of the wonderful tale of Kaila into Kate Simon." A journey is also at the heart of HALF A LIFE, by Jill Ciment (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95). The author's family moved from Montreal to Los Angeles in 1964, an event that marked the start of her father's mental deterioration and of her rebellion. This memoir is "sad, funny and affecting," Michiko Kakutani wrote in The New York Times last year.
 
 PARADISE POSTPONED
 By John Mortimer. Penguin, $11.95.
The author is known for his Rumpole courtroom mysteries, but this novel, just restored to print, concerns crimes of the heart: why would a left-leaning vicar leave his fortune to an unscrupulous Tory Member of Parliament? "Mortimer's wry authorial tone steers delicately between sentiment and satire," Wendy Lesser said in these pages in 1986.
 
 FOREVER, ERMA: Best-Loved Writing
 From America's Favorite Humorist
 By Erma Bombeck. Andrews McMeel, $10.95.
She wrote about the domestic moments that have been the stuff of women's lives for centuries, but it's no surprise that she also campaigned for the equal rights amendment. This collection of almost 200 of Bombeck's columns "is a modest measure of our loss," Eden Ross Lipson wrote in the Book Review last year.
 
 A WORLD LOST
 By Wendell Berry. Counterpoint, $12.50.
The narrator of this novel, Andy Catlett, looks back on the summer of 1944, when his rakish Uncle Andrew was killed -- not in the war, but in a dispute with another man. "Berry's economical prose works to great advantage," Tobin Harshaw said here in 1996. The same publisher has also reissued Berry's ENTRIES ($12.50), a collection of poems whose subjects range from his Kentucky home to his long marriage to his dying father. "One appreciates that Berry's writing about aging is not designed to comfort but only to tell the truth," one critic wrote in 1994.
 
 THE WINE OF ASTONISHMENT
 By Rachel Mackenzie.
 Books & Company/Turtle Point, $13.95.
Just restored to print, this novel concerns two sisters, ages 29 and 32 years old, whose sheltered lives end when their widowed mother dies. Both fall in love, with potentially ominous consequences. Set in upstate New York in the 1920's and 30's, this is "a big little book," Martin Levin said here in 1974. Laurel Graeber

HEADLINE: FILM;
For the Tapes of a Master, It's Worth the Wait

BYLINE: By PETER M. NICHOLS 

 BODY:
THEY MAY HAVE HAD THEIR differences, but now that the tapes are available, everybody involved with the project agrees that home video has stepped forward to do one of the jobs it is intended to do: acquaint people with a great filmmaker who is relatively unknown in this country.
"Once the video end got going, they did a fantastic job," says Ismail Merchant, who with James Ivory make up the Merchant Ivory filmmaking team. He is also an unstinting champion of the films of the acclaimed Indian director Satyajit Ray. In 1995, three years after Ray's death, Mr. Merchant and Sony Classics arranged the theatrical screening of nine Ray films across the United States. And last August, Columbia Tri-Star, Sony's video arm, released six of the films on tape. 
 "On each one they did very good posters and boxes," Mr. Merchant says with the circumspection of a man who, despite frustrations over a two-year wait for the cassettes, is not about to denigrate a good video promotion once it has begun.
When it comes to foreign films, Columbia Tri-Star's president, Ben Feingold, is more inclined to talk about works like "Das Boot," Wolfgang Petersen's reissued 1981 submarine adventure, which was a best seller for his company this year. As for Ray's films, which are typically closely observed studies of ordinary lives in black and white, they aren't big sellers immediately, but they will have staying power with collectors over the years. "A labor of love," he says of the Ray project.
For videophiles, the point is that Ray's deceptively simple, highly detailed human dramas are now accessible not just at occasional theatrical screenings but at any time. "Ray has always been the figment of critics and festivals," says Milos Stehlik, director of Facets International, a Chicago distributor that specializes in foreign films. "Whereas once you had works you could never see, now you have a whole world open up to you."
Nevertheless, the path to video has been arduous. Mr. Merchant grew up in India but encountered Ray's work only as a student in New York in 1958. Decades later he decided to restore the films, which by then had deteriorated to the point that it was questionable if some of them would even survive.
Hollywood didn't share his enthusiasm. "Studios were keen to distribute the films, but they didn't want to put up any money," Mr. Merchant says. "We went with a beggar's bowl to every Hollywood person we could think of. You couldn't get one of those guys to write a check for $1,000." Eventually the restoration, which cost more than $1 million, was paid for by the Merchant Ivory Foundation.
By then, he and Mr. Ivory had made "Howards End" for Sony Classics, and he was able to parlay that connection into support for the theatrical screenings of the Ray films. Home video, he says, wasn't as forthcoming. At first Columbia Tri-Star issued only the best-known Ray films -- "Pather Panchali," "Aparajito" and "The World of Apu" -- which are known as the Apu Trilogy. The other six films, including "The Middleman," "Charulata (The Lonely Wife)" and "The Big City," went unreleased.
"I sent them a letter of ultimatum," Mr. Merchant said. "I told them, 'If you don't bring them out, I'll get them manufactured and bring them out myself.' "
THE COLUMBIA TRI-STAR videos are finely produced and packaged. Mr. Feingold doesn't shy from the notion that economics apply to Ray films the same as they do to other properties. "We look at these films as works of art. They have their place in certain stores." A "Das Boot," he adds, sells at Wal-Mart.
At the other end of the spectrum, champions of foreign film contend that works by Ray and other major directors help spread appreciation of world cinema, particularly films from regions like Southeast Asia, where there are many large movie industries. "If the Ray films succeeded, it would be great if it opened the way for other Indian filmmakers," Mr. Stehlik says.
But Ray's universal style moves him far from his country's conventional cinema. "Indian films are very distinctive to South Asia," says the director Shyam Benegal, one of India's leading filmmakers. Made in all 16 official Indian languages, the 800 to 900 movies produced a year are often family-oriented melodramas that stress music and dancing. Most of them come without subtitles and, since they can be remakes of remakes, sometimes have the same titles.
"They are very popular in black and Arab Africa, the Middle East, central Asia, places like that," Mr. Benegal says. "They don't work well in Europe and the United States."
Distributors of foreign films on video agree that even the biggest names -- Fellini, say, or Truffaut -- occupy a niche that may not grow noticeably but is slowly expanding. "It's important to get exposure for the filmmaker," says Jose Lopez, executive producer of of New Yorker Video, a prominent distributor of foreign titles.
New Yorker was founded by Mr. Lopez's partner, Dan Talbot, who also owns the Lincoln Plaza, the New York theater where the Ray films were screened in 1995. The company releases the films of Rainer Werner Fassbinder and Werner Herzog among others, as well as the Ray titles, to the educational market. "The more they are shown, the more the film culture grows," Mr. Lopez says.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Cynthia McIntyre;
Helping People Learn to Save Money

BYLINE: By FRANCES CHAMBERLAIN 

 BODY:
CYNTHIA MCINTYRE of Newtown spends her days learning how to save money, and then passing her tips on to other people. Though it isn't exactly how the Kansas-born wife and mother of two envisioned her career niche, Mrs. McIntyre is determined to see her family not only survive but prosper on her husband's salary.
Her monthly newsletter, The Frugal Gazette (Post Office Box 3395, Newtown 06470), features recipes, cleaning solutions, tips on making major purchases -- anything that Mrs. McIntyre finds helpful in keeping a family's budget intact. 
 The following interview reflects Mrs. McIntyre's perceptions about American spending habits and the ways she has found to cut her own family's expenses by 40 percent.
Q. What led to the founding of The Frugal Gazette?
A. When we moved to Connecticut in 1991, at the height of the recession, it was as different from Kansas as day and night. My husband was able to take advantage of the opportunity to work on his M.B.A. full time, but we were shocked at the price of tuition. If we had stayed in Kansas we probably would have had to sell our house to allow him to return to school, because supporting it was based on two incomes. Here, we moved into a two-bedroom condominium. It was more a matter of how we approached the kids and helped them to understand that we wouldn't be living in the same way.
We had always been very frugal. Because of the way I was raised I was never allowed to spend money lavishly. I was raised to count pennies, to treat money in a respectful way.
When he finished school and we moved to Newtown, we decided to buy a house based on one income, just in case. We had been here about a year when I got laid off in Stamford. The last six months that I was working that job, I kept hearing myself as I drove to work, saying "this is not working, this is not working." We started re-evaluating our priorities, and I decided I had to do something different.
I had seen Amy Dcysczyn, editor of The Tightwad Gazette, on television six years before, and I thought, this is a woman of my heart. We're kindred spirits.
Q. Along with publishing your newsletter you have begun to give workshops at colleges in the state. Was this part of the mission of The Frugal Gazette?
A. One of my goals is to spread the word, by any means possible. I think there always has to be a Frugal Gazette. As a nurse I know that there are various types of personalities out there; I had to understand intimately what those were in order to educate people about various health-related issues like cholesterol and AIDS. There are many similar personality types out there in regard to spending habits.
Some people can just take the basic information and directly apply it. They'll go on and they'll be fine, and later I'll hear that they've saved so much money because I taught them the basics.
Other people won't make the connection, and they are going to need, monthly, a little infusion of support and encouragement. That is truly the intent of the Frugal Gazette, to provide that little nudge that says "Come on. Keep going." We are so flooded, constantly, with temptations to spend money, not to save, not to value our life force.
The Frugal Gazette reminds people on a monthly basis to save money. I'm also able to provide very current information. Things change constantly. It's really a war out there. People are trying to steal our money. The credit card people are 20 steps ahead of us and they have a huge marketing department. The grocery stores are out there doing stuff all the time, and we're just trying to make ends meet. The average person is just trying to live, to filter through all this stuff. I hope people get some information so they can say, "yeah, that's right. I can do that."
Q. Isn't this a little like being a personal trainer?
A. I feel like one sometimes. I'm one of very few people doing this. I like teaching because I like to be with people. Writing is lonely. Even the information that I present to people comes not from interviews, but lots of lonely research.
Q. What you're talking about is, in fact, saving both time and money.
A. I try to show people how to use their time and money in the most effective manner. That's the kind of niche I'm trying to fill. I try to reach out to working parents and those who stay at home as well. I don't have time to bake bread from scratch, so I use a bread machine. I look at the options of baking from scratch, using a bread machine, or buying it at the store and present those options. I try not to be judgmental, just give options. I'm just a conduit of information.
Some of my options my be unacceptable. Some people may not want to buy clothes at tag sales and that's O.K.
Q. I get the impression that one of the biggest ways that a family can save is in the kitchen, cutting back on the cost of fast food and eating out?
A. My experience is that this is the biggest source of excess spending. Many people don't recognize that, or if they recognize it, they think they have no control over it, because we have to eat. They think that if they put a lot of thought toward it, then they'll spend too much time. They might believe that it's a more efficient use of their time just to go buy something, when in fact, it's not. When you think of the time it actually takes to prepare something, compared to the time it takes to go to the store, buy prepared food, come home and eat it, you'll see the difference.
People need to plan meals, plan purchases. I struggled with this planning process and that's when I developed the frugal meal planning system. I've taken acceptable main dish recipes, that my family enjoys, and put basic information on index cards. Meals are planned around my supplies or whatever is on sale on a particular week.
Q. What is your favorite cost-cutting measure?
A. Meal planning, because that took the biggest bite out of our expenses. After that, after you have reduced your food expenses, cost cutting becomes a life-long challenge. You're constantly looking for ways to save money.
Q. What are some of the more important things to remember about saving money?
A. Too often people don't pay attention to the prices in grocery stores and the cost per unit. We really need to watch that carefully. We are well protected by laws, but too often stores ignore those laws.
I did a careful evaluation and reported eight different stores to the Consumer Protection Division. They inspected the stores and found them to be in error. The State of Connecticut says each store must be consistent about the unit of measure for unit pricing, so you can compare apples to apples. They can choose whatever unit they want; it can be the price per pound of toilet paper if they want, but then all the toilet paper has to be priced per pound. If you are charged anything, other than the price on the shelf, they are obligated to give you a free product.
Q. What are other important ways to save?
A. The majority of our money goes out for food, and then clothes. For clothes, it's a matter of being creative. Even consignment shops have sales. Also, people tend to buy brand new cars. It's ridiculous because you should really buy cars that are 2 or 3 years old. It has depreciated completely, and yet there's still a lot of life in it. And all the bugs have been worked out.
It's the same with clothes. If you buy things in a consignment shop or at a tag sale, they've already been washed and you know they aren't going to shrink or fade.
There are many other ways to cut back, such as on heating or cooling costs. It doesn't have to be something real complicated; these can be things that you do for yourself.
Q. How does your family feel about living frugally?
A. Our kids were raised with the understanding that Mom and Dad don't have an endless pot of money. They know that we don't have to spend everything; we can save something. They don't seem to notice any difference.
My daughter loves clothes, loves to spend, but she has truly embraced the concept of frugality. She bought 130 books at library book sales for less than $10 this summer.
She has learned, through my example, that there are other ways to reach an objective. And we have taught them that giving of yourself, your time, is one of the best gifts.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cynthia McIntyre, publisher of The Frugal Gazette, clips coupons from the newspaper before going shopping. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 2; Page 31; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL VIEW;
Holding Listeners Hostage in the Name of Art

BYLINE: By Bernard Holland 

 BODY:
MUSIC LOVERS BREATHED a sigh of relief when the musicians of the Chicago Symphony voted to accept a new contract this month. Listeners were thus assured that the Chicago would keep on blowing them away with its musical might. It was also nice to know that players wouldn't be rooting around in garbage cans for their next meal.
It is a curious spectacle. One's heart goes out to migrant workers clamoring for a decent meal, a dry place to sleep and a few dollars to take back home. It is harder to visualize the plight of employees whose salaries average in excess of $100,000 a year, and who receive generous benefits and vacation time. Picture junior partners at a Wall Street law firm picketing for bigger bonuses and more clout in management decisions. 
 But higher-echelon orchestra musicians are dead serious about their demands. Threats are the common negotiating currency: "Give us what we want now, or we'll scuttle your opening night." Contract strategies like this are common in opera houses and concert halls across the land, and Chicago was no exception as the orchestra prepared for its gala reopening of a renovated hall. Hostage-taking in the name of art: an interesting concept.
"Unfair," musicians will respond. "Managers are blackguards, assaulting our collective dignity, hoarding the revenues for which we are responsible and robbing us of creative freedom." Fair enough. Musicians trained as soloists in conservatories don't like being told by a conductor how to play, and they don't like being pushed around by their front offices. Admittedly, both sides in this argument are capable of not being very nice; on occasion they deserve each other.
I have spent my life around musicians, and I continually wonder at how the makers of such beautiful sounds can be so prone to malice, spite and envy. Wage standards among the country's top dozen orchestras, for example, begin not at home but at someone else's orchestra. The polite word is parity, but it's really, "Johnny has a bigger piece of cake than I do, and I am going to throw a tantrum until I get one like it." Don't doubt that players in New York, Boston and Philadelphia are thinking, "If Chicago got an $81,900-a-year minimum, we want as much when our contract expires, or maybe more, because we're better."
Forget who is at fault. This is the Balkans. It is also a terrible atmosphere in which to make music. These days, only a truly charismatic conductor can raise American orchestra musicians from their pervasive sulk. Some, bless them, enjoy their work. Others are too busy resenting their lives to waste much time on beauty. A critic who accompanied a major Eastern orchestra on a recent European tour told me that the constant complaining about hotels, rehearsals and travel arrangements so sickened him that he packed his bag midway and came home.
How can we take seriously the musicians of the San Francisco Symphony when they distribute leaflets asking audience members to demonstrate support at concerts? Labor disputes are a time-honored activity in this democracy, but to mix them with the making of music demonstrates poor taste and contempt for the art.
Such strategy generated little sympathy at Carnegie Hall a year ago, even less when San Francisco players naively repeated it in London. British orchestra musicians earn about 60 percent less than their American colleagues. They work harder, and studies show that they like their jobs better. London newspapers had a good time excoriating our exported presumption.
"But we are artists," players tell me, "and we are treated like cattle." Well, maybe they are oboe players and violinists, not artists. And maybe they are treated not like cattle but like employees, which is what they are. I remember a once-prominent Viennese pianist on world tour who found himself barred from Japan. For "occupation" in his passport he had stated not musician or pianist or even Kunstler but artist. The Japanese thought he was a circus performer.
Orchestra musicians work with their hands, perhaps with a bit more refinement than plumbers but with no great difference from cabinet makers or master brewers. "Artist" is one of those inflationary terms that promise much and mean nothing. All beautiful products, whether made of mahogany, rayon or meter and rhythm, come from craftsmen working with love, not artists.
"We have no creative freedom," I am told. Well, orchestra musicians are company employees. I am, too, and so are a lot of you. We do our best to be ourselves, but ultimately we do what we are told. It's part of the deal. If orchestra musicians want artistic freedom, they should relinquish the handsome salaries and benefits, and take their chances in the free market. None of us can have it both ways.
The Philadelphia Orchestra recently resolved a bitter strike. The Chicago players have had their way. Contracts will soon expire in Boston and New York. Who will draw the line? I reserve little sympathy for managements; their cravenness about the bottom line is not a pretty sight. My quarrel with musicians is also clear. My true thoughts are for the public, for listeners fed up with infantile squabbling between well-heeled musicians and their bosses. Even untrained ears are beginning to sense the antimusical effects on performances.
I advocate no strikes, no lockouts. But I think all parties might be surprised to find how nicely cultural life in big cities would survive if management and musicians chose to sit on their hands. In one city I know, the prolonged absence of its principal orchestra would be a ripple barely felt.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
