HEADLINE: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers;
Kimchi Alley

BYLINE: By Ruth Reichl; Ruth Reichl is the restaurant critic for The New York Times.

 BODY:
Korean food is so exhilarating that from my very first bite, all I have wanted is more. Asia's most robust cuisine combines everyone's favorite flavors: sugar, salt, spice and peppers. It is fresh, healthy and low in cholesterol. Koreans graze through every meal, cooking at the table and eating with their fingers. Yet even in New York, this fascinating food remains a mystery. Why? A midnight stroll across 32d Street, in Manhattan's Koreatown, offers a couple of answers.
Koreans call it Sam Ship Iga, which simply means 32d Street; its heart is the block between Fifth Avenue and Broadway, but the district extends a few blocks in each direction. Lured by cheap rents, Koreans moved there en masse during the recession of the early 70's, when it was considered a dangerous area. Today, the block feels like one of the most secure in town. Even late at night the restaurants are filled with young people who gather in the new bakery, Pari Pari Ko, drinking coffee, laughing raucously and snacking on curiously delicious pastries filled with beef, pork and onions. 
 Many restaurants are open 24 hours, and one of the busiest is always Gam Mee Ok, which serves just a dozen dishes. Before you order, the waiters bring kimchi, the ubiquitous and breathtakingly spicy pickled cabbage that is cut with scissors as it is set on the table. Nearby, noisy teen-agers eat modum possam, a do-it-yourself oyster taco, made with oysters, pork and chili peppers rolled into pieces of lettuce. If you are in need of a little energy, there is nothing so refreshing as sul long tang, a snow-white soup filled with rice, noodles and pieces of meat. The idea is to add scallions, rock salt and pepper, along with generous lashings of kimchi.
My favorite place is just across the street. Open the door of Kang Suh and you are immediately assaulted by the smell of chilies, charcoal and garlic. Sit down and your table is instantly covered with bowls of savory pickled vegetables and spicy seafood. You could make a meal of these panchan, but they are merely free side dishes whose purpose is to make the rest of the food more interesting. What you probably want is bulgogi, the classic Korean marinated sirloin. The coal man arrives with glowing embers to fuel the barbecue in the middle of the table. You grill the meat, snatch it from the fire and place it on a piece of lettuce. Hot and cool, sweet and salty, bulgogi is eaten with the fingers, a lot like American barbecue, only better. Haemul pajun is another voluptuous dish, a savory seafood pancake also designed to be eaten without utensils.
I could easily sit here all night, sipping beer or soju (Korean vodka) between bites of barbecue and tastes of pajun -- and I can't imagine why everyone else in New York hasn't joined me. Yet I often find that I am the only non-Asian person in the place.
But times may be changing. Several signs suggest that Korean cuisine is finally ready to be the next crossover hit. Manhattan's first upscale Korean-accented restaurant, Mirezi, in Greenwich Village, opened a year ago to great success. And in Sam Ship Iga, where English menus are still rare, one new restaurant, in an effort to be more enticing, now describes the haemul pajun as "Korean pizza." Can "Seoul food" be far behind?

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kimchi, the common denominator of the Korean table. (Gilles Peress/Magnum, for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers;
New York's Parallel Lives

BYLINE: By John Tierney; John Tierney is a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine. His column on New York, The Big City, appears once a month.

 BODY:
The worlds of New York have inspired many collective metaphors -- melting pot, a boiling pot, a rainbow, a patchwork quilt, a gorgeous mosaic -- and none of them really work. Seven million people do not resemble an inanimate object. The best image of the city's diversity is not an abstraction. It is alive in Central Park and called the Skate Circle.
 Like most of New York's worlds, it evolved spontaneously and haphazardly, starting 20 years ago with a few roller skaters dancing separately to music from their radios on a dead-end road just west of the bandshell and south of the 72d Street transverse. One day they tuned their radios to the same station and danced together. Then a self-appointed disk jockey began playing tapes on a sound system. Soon hundreds of people were skating in concentric rings around the speakers every weekend afternoon: teen-agers in spandex, 60-year-olds in hiking shorts, Wall Street traders, Broadway dancers, Brooklyn detectives, German bankers, Brazilian nurses, Nigerian vendors, celebrities like Morgan Freeman and Margaux Hemingway bopping along next to bicycle messengers. 
 At first glance the Skate Circle seems to be one great melting pot, one big, happy family of man. But of course it's not quite that simple, or friendly. Most of the skaters barely know one another. They arrive separately and leave separately, and as they perform for the international crowd of spectators, they're concentrating on their moves, not on their brother and sister skaters. These dancers, skating side by side, crammed together competing for attention, are a model of the city's chaotic social structure, an assortment of subcultures that occasionally overlap but are mostly oblivious to one another. The worlds are what Tom Wolfe has called statuspheres: self-contained realms where people compete for status according to their own rules instead of traditional class structures. Statuspheres exist in all cities, but they are especially important here because they serve as surrogate families for the millions of displaced and solitary New Yorkers without extended families nearby. No other city has so many strangers from so many different worlds crowded into such a small space.
Consider, for instance, the evening of Oct. 6, a relatively quiet night because it was a Monday and because many people were at home watching the Yankees in a crucial playoff game. Still, Governor Pataki was speaking at a benefit at Lincoln Center; NBC's president, Robert Wright, was addressing another fund-raiser at the Plaza. Senator Edward Kennedy and Lauren Bacall were being honored at two other events. On 57th Street, the usual hordes of teen-agers going to the Hard Rock Cafe and Planet Hollywood had to negotiate a flock of limousines bringing investment bankers to Carnegie Hall's season opening. On the Upper East Side, while Ivana Trump was attending a book party for Joan Collins at Mortimer's restaurant, a committee of women with older money and more traditional literary tastes was at the Cosmopolitan Club planning a dinner to raise money for the restoration of Edith Wharton's home in the Berkshires.
As lawyers practiced their golf swings at the Chelsea Piers driving range, the staff at Mother, a nightclub nearby, was working on the scenery and props (a caldron and a coffin) for a drag-queen show called "The Witches of East Village." College kids were bowling in the dark -- the pins were illuminated by black light -- as a deejay played trip-hop music at the Bowlmor Lanes in the Village, half a block from a restaurant where a middle-aged crowd was listening to the waitress-opera singer belt out "On the Street Where You Live." A few blocks north, models and people with the right music-industry connections were being escorted through a throng into Cheetah, the black club of the moment, where Janet Jackson and Wesley Snipes were holding court.
Down on the Bowery, Chinese immigrants were taking classes in Word Perfect, and Neil Young and Iggy Pop were attending a party for the film maker Jim Jarmusch at C.B.G.B., the vintage punk-rock club that's next door to a small opera house. As television cameras filmed the guests arriving at C.B.G.B., across the street a Catholic social worker born in Cleveland was handing out egg-salad sandwiches to men living in flophouses. Two of the lodgers, both young and unemployed -- Miguel, from a Puerto Rican family in the Bronx, and Malik, from a black family in Brooklyn -- were amusing themselves by watching the pedestrians go by and guessing which worlds they belonged to: suburban club kids on their way from St. Marks Place, busboys going home to Queens, gay men headed for Chelsea, uptowners trying to fit in downtown.
"I bet they just came out of Bowery Bar," said Malik, pointing to a 30-ish couple in denim walking from the direction of the nightspot favored by the fashion industry.
"No, her dress is too long and baggy," Miguel said. "Watch. I'll ask them." After the couple confirmed his suspicion, Miguel shook his head as he watched them walk away. "They'd never get into Bowery Bar dressed like that."
 These disparate worlds are a result partly of New York's size -- most other cities don't have enough people close together to sustain a thriving subculture devoted to skate dancing -- and partly of its peculiar social disorder. Political capitals like Washington, London, Paris, Rome and Tokyo are dominated by national institutions and traditional aristocracies; most other cities have social ladders determined by the leading churches and families and industries. But New York has never had a fixed, homogenous hierarchy since it was colonized in the 17th century by people speaking 18 languages. The old Dutch families shared the island with their English conquerors, as well as French Huguenots and African slaves. Unlike Puritan Boston and Quaker Philadelphia, Colonial New York was a religious hodgepodge, and later attempts to impose social order, like Mrs. Astor's list of 400, were always doomed by new people and new money.
A meal with the Mayor at Gracie Mansion has no more cachet than an invitation to the right Fifth Avenue parlor, midtown restaurant soiree, downtown gallery opening or nightclub V.I.P. room. New York has old families, but most New Yorkers don't even know their names; it has captains of industry, but too many for anyone to be in charge. The closest thing to an upper class today are the bold names in the gossip columns, and these are a haphazard sampling from dozens of different worlds. They are an ephemeral aristocracy based on talent, power, beauty, money and, above all, style.
The ambitious members of New York's worlds share the basic passion of the dancers in the Skate Circle -- Look at me! -- and these days they're enjoying remarkable success with audiences outside the city. New York has become the most popular destination in the United States besides Hawaii. New Yorkers, accustomed to hearing out-of-towners sneer that they wouldn't want to live here, were stunned by a poll this year in which Americans ranked New York first among the places they'd like to live. The city's hot reputation, though, is deceptive, because the economy is still relatively moribund, except for the tourist industry and Wall Street -- most of those out-of-towners eager to move here couldn't find well-paying jobs or affordable apartments. Los Angeles, Houston and San Diego have more dynamic economies and are attracting their own hordes of immigrants. But the homogenous neighborhoods in these cities will never become tourist attractions.
Now that crime has dropped and news is spreading of New York's safe streets, the city's diversity has probably become its chief economic asset -- a uniquely marketable commodity that distinguishes it from other capitals and tourist meccas. Like Paris, New York has famous sights and a cultured elite in residence, but it is more than a museum city renowned for past glories. Like Los Angeles, it has an eclectic array of industries and cultures, but it also has sidewalks where they all mix -- if only superficially.
On the eve of the 1929 mayoral election, Mayor Jimmy Walker went to Harlem and gave what Walter Winchell called "the shortest and sockiest political speech in the history of American politics." Walker was "pretty squiffed" and needed a little assistance reaching the podium, but sufficiently sober to deliver the following, as recorded and annotated by the columnist:
"Ladies and Gentlemen . . . the usual Walker pause . . . and I mean Ladies and Gentlemen. lusty hand clapping While I was driving up to this last big and most important rally of my campaign, a man on one side was telling me about all the things I did for the Negro while I was in the State Assembly. A fellow on the other side of me was telling me of all the things I did for the Negro while I was Mayor of the City of New York. Well, I'll tell you the truth. In all my political life I never did anything for the Negro! . . . big Walker pause -- with consternation on all sides I never did anything for the Catholics either; I never did anything for the Jews or Italians or the Germans -- because, Ladies and Gentlemen, I don't know the difference! Good night."
Walker was re-elected the next day. The speech was an absurd lie, but one that New Yorkers occasionally like to believe. They have always been ambivalent about their separate worlds: anxious to preserve them but also desirous of a common culture. The melting-pot metaphor has been around at least since 1782, when M.G. Jean de Crevecoeur, a naturalized New Yorker, declared, "Here individuals of all nations are melted into a new race of men." In 1908, the metaphor became the title of a Broadway play in which a Russian deliriously happy to be in New York addresses a group of immigrants at Ellis Island: "A fig for your feuds and vendettas! German and Frenchman, Irishman and Englishman, Jews and Russians -- into the crucible with you all!" The play was an instant hit, but the reality outside the theater remained quite different. "The point about the melting pot is that it did not happen," wrote Nathan Glazer and Daniel Patrick Moynihan in their classic 1963 study, "Beyond the Melting Pot."
The ethnic array analyzed in their book -- blacks, Puerto Ricans, Jews, Italians, Irish -- seems parochial in comparison with today's New York. During the 1990's, more than 100,000 people from 187 countries have been arriving every year,further dividing and subdividing the city's ethnic worlds. American-born blacks who have taken the municipal bus-driving jobs once held by the Irish are now in a political fight with Caribbean-born blacks who operate competing private van services. New Spanish-speaking arrivals, like Mexican tortilla-manufacturers in Brooklyn and Dominican bodega owners in Washington Heights, do not necessarily identify with Puerto Rican politicians reared in the city's housing projects. Restaurants are no longer merely Indian or Italian -- they are Southern Indian or Gujarati, Tuscan or Milanese.
The separate worlds are especially obvious after dark, when New Yorkers seek out familiar faces in social clubs, nightclubs and restaurants. This voluntary segregation is often ascribed to hatred and fear, which may sometimes be true, but it might be more accurately caused by love -- or, more precisely, by the urge to reproduce, which is the force that ultimately drives individuals and social groups. When it comes to choosing a partner, people in every culture tend to put aside their ideals of universal brotherhood and practice what anthropologists call "positive assortative mating."
"When you're seeking to form a new family," says Lionel Tiger, an anthropologist at Rutgers University, "it's easier for most people to choose someone from a similar family than to write a letter, 'Dear Mom, I just met the most wonderful Inuit.' It's not surprising that for the courtship rituals that occur in restaurants and nightclubs, New Yorkers freely choose places filled with people like themselves. Where else are they going to find mates? At the Knickerbocker Club?"
New Yorkers like to celebrate the moments when different worlds unite -- veterans of the Skate Circle are proud that their diverse gathering has resulted in at least three marriages and 10 children -- but these are exceptions. "The metropolitan ideal doesn't make sense to most people," Tiger says. "Communities work best when there's a public sphere open to all and private ones to repair to at the end of the day. A Jamaican who spends the day at the World Trade Center negotiating a deal with someone from Sumatra takes comfort going back to Queens to eat ackee and saltfish or going dancing with other Jamaicans. That's one of the city's great gifts: you're a subway ride away from home."
New Yorkers need their separate worlds to cope with what is the most unnatural aspect of the city: the loneliness of people far from their families. More than half of the population was born outside the city -- 2.5 million in foreign countries and more than 1 million in other parts of the United States. One-third of the city's adults have never married; Manhattan has the highest concentration of single-person households in America except for an island in Hawaii settled as a leper colony. No matter how cosmopolitan they think they are, they belong to a species that evolved in small, exclusive clans. They have an innate urge to recreate similar worlds here. The melting pot could never turn New York into a happy family or any other kind of family. No sane human would ever wish for seven million relatives.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 5; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: SUNDAY VIEW;
A Curious Voyage Into Uncharted O'Neill

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby 

 BODY:
THE VAGUELY deconstructionist production of "More Stately Mansions," now at New York Theater Workshop (through next Sunday), has its isolated, sometimes quite arresting rewards. Yet it is less a presentation of an essentially realistic play than a stylized analysis of it, performed as if it were a religious rite so familiar that much of its language need not be understood but heard only as the drone of remembered cadences. If you don't know the catechism, you often won't have a clue as to what's going on.
As was reported in detail in these pages two weeks ago, "More Stately Mansions" is the severely abridged adaptation of a Eugene O'Neill play he never completed to his full satisfaction. In 1943 the playwright burned all longhand drafts of his gargantuan manuscript, saving one typescript that was later found in a Yale University library with the note: "Unfinished Work. This script to be destroyed in case of my death! Eugene O'Neill." 
 He died in 1953, but the text, with the approval of Carlotta Monterey, his widow and literary executor, was eventually entrusted to Karl Ragnar Gierow, then director of the Swedish Royal Dramatic Theater, in the hopes he might whip it into shape. Gierow cut and rearranged the material, which had been translated into Swedish, and came up with a new text, first performed in Stockholm in 1962, and said to be composed entirely of O'Neill's words.
It is this play, translated back into English, that was the basis for Jose Quintero's 1967 Broadway adaptation, as well as for the production now being performed here, pared down some more and without Mr. Quintero's interpolations. After the intervention of the O'Neill biographers Arthur Gelb (a former theater critic and editor of The Times) and his wife, Barbara Gelb, the current production, which was initially being presented as "a play by Eugene O'Neill, as adapted by Karl Ragnar Gierow," is now being billed as "by Eugene O'Neill, as adapted by Karl Ragnar Gierow from O'Neill's unfinished manuscript."
It is easy to understand why theater people as well as O'Neill scholars are drawn to "More Stately Mansions," particularly as it exists before it was edited. Familiar O'Neill obsessions, echoing such monumental works as "Strange Interlude," "The Iceman Cometh" and "Long Day's Journey Into Night," reappear here in significantly new variations. The shade of Freud again haunts the family at the play's center. In this case, however, the characters inhabit a historical time and place whose conflicted social, economic and political values both mirror and shape the split psyches of the characters. American civilization, says O'Neill, is doomed, hopelessly caught between its professed democratic ideals and the greed that fuels its progress.
The play's original fragment -- it is called a fragment though it might run 10 to 12 hours in playing time -- is a work of both grandeur and grandiosity. It was to be the sixth play in "A Tale of Possessors, Self-Dispossessed," which O'Neill planned as a cycle of 11 plays tracing the corruption of America as reflected in the fortunes of the Harford family from the early 19th century into the 20th. The only play of the cycle he completed and offered for production was "A Touch of the Poet," which was designed to precede "More Stately Mansions."
Covering the years from 1832 to 1842 and set in and around a Massachusetts mill town, the original fragment of "More Stately Mansions" is a brilliant, verbose, numbingly repetitious play about an Oedipal triangle: Simon Harford, a young man with the soul of a poet; his ambitious, sensual wife, Sara, the daughter of an Irish immigrant pub keeper, and Deborah, Simon's possessive mother whose fantasies are something more than pipe dreams.
Largely to please the social aspirations of Sara, and to beat his rich father at his own game, Simon abandons letters to go into cotton milling. To everyone's surprise, he becomes a successful, ruthless tycoon, at least in part because he treats it as if it were an abstract game. His goal: a vertically integrated empire of plantations, ships, mills, railroads and retail outlets. (Though "More Stately Mansions" spans only 10 years, O'Neill encapsulates so much of American industrial history in it that you might wonder how he was going to fill the five plays that were to follow.)
The Gierow adaptation of "More Stately Mansions" underplays Simon's business mania, including O'Neill's comments about the Presidency of Andrew Jackson (which sounds like Jimmy Carter's) and how it affects the interests of right-thinking American businessmen. The production at New York Theater Workshop, staged by Ivo van Hove, a Flemish director, goes even further in separating the play's characters from the context in which O'Neill so painstakingly placed them.
Mr. van Hove's "More Stately Mansions" is set in a timeless void, that is, on an orange-carpeted stage against a black backdrop, dramatically lighted from time to time to italicize particular monents. The three principal players -- Simon (Tim Hopper), Sara (Jenny Bacon) and Deborah (Joan MacIntosh) -- enter at the beginning of each act, walk to the front of the stage, bow impassively to the audience and then retire to chairs at the side of the stage to await their cues.
These entrances have the formality of the start of a sumo match, which is probably intentional. What follows is a series of genteelly choreographed encounters -- some of them knock down and drag out -- between husband and wife, wife and mother-in-law, mother and son. Throughout the play, their roles change and change again: adversaries become allies, lovers become competitors. There is one moment when the lusting Simon and Sara tear their clothes off each other for an obligatory, acrobatic nude scene. Deborah doesn't bare all, but she bares her breasts for a Pieta pose with Simon. The production's three supporting actors enter and leave the stage as they are needed.
Even though the text has been freely pruned, there are thousands of words to be gotten through, many of which, especially those in the spoken thoughts that are O'Neill monologues, are delivered in the speedy monotones most often associated with Beckett. Another ploy is to have two characters speak at the same time, which if done consistently, would cut the play's running time in half. That you can't easily understand what's being said seems to be beside the point of this production, which, even in its abbreviated form, still runs about 3 1/2 hours, including two intermissions.
The production takes on dramatic urgency when the director gives the actors time and space in which to realize some of the complexities of the O'Neill characters. Only then is it possible to recognize the gifts of America's greatest playwright. Consider the scene in which Simon invites Sara to his office to make her a proposal. He is fed up with his role as tycoon and has been rendered impotent after years of living under the same roof with both Sara and Deborah; they have merged into a single figure in his consciousness.
To separate his wife and his mother, who have become allies, and to possess each as he did when they loathed each other, he asks Sara to become his daytime mistress in the privacy of the office. After each assignation, he will assign her another share of the company, while allowing her to assume those corporate duties that no longer interest him. Sara tries to act shocked but she is exultant. She loves Simon, but she also loves money.
In time, she becomes more ruthless than Simon, who longs to return to childhood when he and his mother shared her secret garden. Simon, Sara and Deborah are each a battleground on which the forces of light and darkness are in fatal stalemate. As the Harfords go, says O'Neill, so goes America.
Though Mr. Hopper, Ms. Bacon and Ms. MacIntosh are at the mercy of the director, they manage to give identity to their characters when they are not being upstaged by the denaturing formality of his concept. Also commendable is Robert Petkoff as Simon's ineffectual younger brother (whom his mother describes as "God's most successful effort in taxidermy").
For those who might want to further pursue "More Stately Mansions," the complete text of the original fragment is available in the Library of America's three-volume collection of O'Neill's works. It is a long, sometimes boring but frequently extraordinary read, revealing, among other things, how he worked, creating plays out of early drafts from which absolutely nothing was left out. His words being often blunt and heavy, it was like sculpting granite, but he retrieved life from the most inert of raw materials.
I think of Deborah's line when she tells Simon, who has grown away from her over the years, that she would be as indifferent to his death as to the death of a stranger. He protests. She is brutal.
"That is what Time does to us all," she says. "We forget and pass on."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 31; Column 3; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC;
Traditions of East and West Gather at the River

BYLINE: By LINDSLEY CAMERON; Lindsley Cameron's biography of the Japanese composer Hikari Oe will be published in the spring.

 BODY:
WESTERN OPERA AND Japanese Noh drama might seem to be incompatible. The word "operatic" has come to be synonymous with "flamboyant." Noh connoisseurs, on the other hand, prize subtlety and restraint. Yet one work, at once powerful and exquisite, successfully unites the two traditions: Benjamin Britten's one-act opera "Curlew River."
The Britten work will be presented along with Juro Motomasa's "Sumidagawa," the 15th-century Noh play that inspired it, beginning on Wednesday evening at the Japan Society, on East 47th Street in Manhattan, as part of its Japanese Theater in the World festival, which runs through February. Although the works have often been performed together in Japan, this is said to be the first professional production of the two together in the United States. 
 "Sumidagawa" ("Sumida River") and "Curlew River" share a simple plot. A widow has gone mad because her young son has disappeared. Searching for him, she boards a ferry, and the boatman explains that crowds are gathering at its destination in hopes that the spirit of a kidnapped boy who died there will work miracles. Hearing details about the dead child, the woman realizes that he must have been her vanished son. Joining in the prayers at his grave, she hears a voice and recognizes it as his, and his spirit appears, restoring her sanity.
"Sumidagawa" is the most popular play in the Noh repertory, undoubtedly because of its striking emotional immediacy. (Performances were forbidden at emperors' and shoguns' palaces from 1600 to 1868, because the story was considered inappropriately upsetting.) Noh, generally, is virtually devoid of action. A typical drama consists of one character telling another about something that happened a long time ago; the character who tells the story often turns out to be a ghost. In "Sumidagawa," rather than just hearing about the protagonist's experiences, the audience makes the crucial discovery along with her, and she regains her sanity on stage.
Hideo Kanze, the director of the illustrious Tessenkai Noh Troupe of Tokyo, will direct "Sumidagawa" and play the Madwoman. Traditional Noh is all-male, and the art is passed down in families. Kan Hosho, who will play the Boatman, was trained from age 7 by his father and grandfather, eminent specialists in such roles. And Mr. Kanze's roots stretch back to Noh's beginnings. He is descended from the "Sumidagawa" playwright, whose grandfather, Kanami, founded Noh in the 14th century.
"The blood line is not so important," Mr. Kanze said by telephone from Tokyo."What is important is the cultural lineage, being raised in the traditions of Noh, which have been cultivated for so many generations."
What do Western audiences need to know to appreciate the play? "Only the story," Mr. Kanze said. "It doesn't matter if they can't follow the words line by line." The Japan Society will in any case provide librettos.
Britten had long been fascinated with Asian music by the time he saw "Sumidagawa," in two different productions, in 1956 in Tokyo. He was intrigued by its musical aspects. It made a tremendous impression on him, he wrote, as "a totally new 'operatic' experience." But it was surely the story that seized his imagination above all. Like many of his operas, it is centered on the death of an innocent figure, and it inspired him to create, in the Madwoman's poignantly fragmented narratives, unforgettable musical evocations of devastating loss. The plaintive motif she shares with the curlew birds that give the river its name uses pitch intervals evoking those characteristic of the chants of Noh drama.
Eventually, "Sumidagawa" prompted Britten to create something radically new of his own: a new kind of opera, a small-scale work that exploits modest resources ingeniously to re-create quintessentially Japanese effects in Western terms. Its haunting libretto, by the South African novelist William Plomer, transposes the play's Buddhist transcendence into Christian terms, preserving the dramatic and many of the poetic qualities of the original text.
The transformation took some doing. Britten did not write "Curlew River" until 1964, in Venice. There he saw a procession of monks, which apparently suggested a solution to the formidable problems involved in adapting a work from an exotic, non harmonically based tradition of musical theater. "Curlew River" begins and ends in plainchant, and the singers, rather than enacting the story straightforwardly, are supposed to be monks representing its characters as though in a mystery play. Just as in Noh, therefore, the whole cast is male. (The role of the Madwoman -- that is, of the monk who plays her -- was written for Britten's longtime companion Peter Pears.)
"Curlew River," created to be performed in a church, was such a departure from conventional Western forms that Britten called it a "church parable" rather than an opera. And because "Curlew River" deploys its stark musical resources sequentially rather than simultaneously, and gives the instrumentalists and singers freedom to proceed at their own tempos, Britten invented a new kind of fermata, or sustaining symbol. Called a "curlew mark," it looks like a bird in flight and indicates where performers should wait for others.
Jonathan Eaton, the stage director of "Curlew River" at the Japan Society, has been involved with Britten's music in England intermittently since his childhood, when he sang the treble solos in the "War Requiem." But Mr. Eaton is probably best known to audiences here for a notably gory production of Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana" in 1992 at the New York City Opera. His fundamental challenge in this "Curlew River," he said, is to find a theatrical substitute for what is lost by not performing in a church, where "you would automatically get a dimension of ritual and ceremony, connecting to the spiritual resolution at the heart of the piece."
He sees the work as Britten's triumphant answer to a longstanding artistic crisis.
"It seems to me he was looking for a new voice, even a new way of writing music," Mr. Eaton said. "Through this piece, he discovers a confluence. The river is an interesting image. It divides East and West, old and new, ancient and modern, the grieving mother from the spirit of her child, the land of the living from the land of the dead. But it's also a meeting point. The revelation about the boy's fate comes in the middle of the river. Threads come together there as well as being sundered. In the piece there's a confluence of Oriental musical influences with Britten's own uniquely English, Western voice, and I think it points forward to the rest of his musical output."
The work calls for no conductor. Joseph Colaneri, a staff conductor at the City Opera and the musical director of this production, will play a small organ on stage and provide musical cues.
"The traditional Noh orchestra basically consists of flute and drums on stage, and Britten adapted that idea," Mr. Colaneri said. "He uses the instruments very economically.
"Noh is fascinating, it moves at a timeless pace, and it's very intense, not only for the performers but even for the audience. There is no counterpart to it in Western music except in 'Curlew River,' where Britten has managed to demonstrate the spirit of Noh without resorting to pastiche. It's miraculous, really."

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 1; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: Westbury Closing by Venerable Firm Angers Its Workers

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
PHIL KLAUS of Hicksville rode a forklift and worked in receiving at the King Kullen grocery warehouse in Westbury for 21 1/2 years. His late father, Felix, also worked in the warehouse, moving his family from Brooklyn to Hicksville in 1960 to be near his job when the warehouse moved from Jamaica, Queens.
But now, Mr. Klaus said, King Kullen, the sole remaining family owned supermarket chain on Long Island, has turned its back on its employees by closing the grocery warehouse, leaving just the produce and meat warehouses. 
 King Kullen said it had decided to contract out its grocery warehousing for economic reasons and offered the workers severance pay when their contract expired on Aug. 31. The union refused the proposal and set up picket lines on Sept. 2. Talks resumed last week.
On July 28 the company gave the 112 warehouse employees, 27 of whom had worked there more than 20 years, a month's notice "to get our lives in order and go away," he said.
Mr. Klaus, a member of the negotiating committee for teamsters Local 282, said that the employees had heard rumors about the sale of the warehouse but that the management had assured them the rumors were false.
"We fully expected them to sell off part of the warehouse, but we never thought for a minute that it would try to outsource," Mr. Klaus said about the company's decision to hire Bozzuto's Inc. in Cheshire, Conn., for its warehouse operations.
A consultant for King Kullen, Jerry Columbus, said the contract with Bozzuto's was signed after the company had "made a strategic decision to get out of the grocery-distribution business."
"We want to focus on our stores," Mr. Columbus said. "Distribution has become an increasingly specialized business, technology focused with sophisticated systems. King Kullen is family operated, and we had to choose where to focus our business over the next five to 10 years."
A number of supermarket chains have moved to outsource their warehouse operations, according to James T. Rogers, president of the Food Industry Alliance of New York State, which represents 850 retailers, wholesalers and suppliers.
The profit margin in the grocery section of supermarkets is about 1 cent for every $1 of sales, Mr. Rogers added.
"When you combine that profit margin with intense competition -- and there is a great deal of it on Long Island -- supermarkets look to see how they can operate more efficiently," Mr. Rogers said. "As changes occur, unfortunately things like this happen. It's a very difficult situation. There's no doubt about it."
A teamsters' representative, Sandy Pope, said the union workers had decided to "make a stand" after having seen union employees lose their jobs when other warehouses in the region had closed.
In January 1996, she said, Grand Union closed warehouses in Carlstadt, N.J., and Mount Kisco, N.Y., and contracted with the nonunion C & S Wholesale Grocers Inc. in Brattleboro, Vt., causing 500 union employees to lose their jobs.
"Grand Union had been losing money for years and had been in bankruptcy more than once," Ms. Pope said. "Their warehouses were very old, and while we tried to negotiate we couldn't reach an agreement. The company was broke, and we couldn't ask them to invest in the future while we also gave up something.
"This whole area had been served by union warehouses. Grand Union broke that when C & S was able to come in with much lower costs, because of its lower-wage operations in Vermont, Connecticut and Massachusetts."
On the other hand the teamsters' averted a move by Safeway Inc. to close a warehouse in Maryland. "We negotiated to keep them open and gave concessions," Ms. Pope said. "The state helped out, and the company agreed to invest in the warehouse rather than close. We saved 800 jobs."
Last year, when Royal Ahold N.V. of Zaandam, the Netherlands, bought Edwards supermarkets, the union lost 300 jobs from layoffs at a warehouse that Edwards used in Edison, N.J., Twin County Grocers.
"So in the last year and a half we have conducted some boycotting of Edwards and Grand Union and had a fair amount of informational leafleting," said Ms. Pope.
If the union did not take a stand now, she said, it feared that the only other chain on Long Island with its own warehouse, Waldbaums, would also outsource.
The executive vice president for finance and administration at King Kullen, J. Donald Kennedy, implied that King Kullen had little choice after Grand Union and Edwards had switched. Those chains, he added, now had "a distinct competitive advantage over us."
Ms. Pope said the union and its employees believed that King Kullen would change its mind and agree to reopen its warehouse. "We think it can be done," she said. "The contract with Bozzuto's can be broken. We know that if King Kullen's conscience gets the better of them we would be able to find a solution to keep them competitive on Long Island and keep these jobs."
A spokeswoman for King Kullen, Katherine Heaviside, said the president of the teamsters, Ron Carey, was directing the protest from Washington.
"Ron Carey has chosen, as he said, to try to destroy King Kullen," Ms. Heaviside said. "We cannot allow Washington teamsters to try to ruin one of our Long Island companies."
Ms. Pope said Mr. Carey was "not looking for fights" to boost his standing for the next union election.
"Union members here would have hung Ron Carey had he not taken them out on strike," Ms. Pope said, referring to the picketing that the workers have been conducting even after their contract expired on Aug. 31. "This was not a from-the-top-down strike. There is no chance he would do something like this without the overwhelming support of other teamster members and other unions."
"It is the Washington-based teamsters who are making an organized attack on King Kullen for their own purposes," Mr. Columbus said. "They are not supported by any nonteamsters unions. This is purely a teamsters attack."
Of the 4,400 employees at the company, 90 percent are members of other unions, and all are working, he said. The only workers who are honoring the picket lines are 45 teamsters in the produce warehouse, also in Westbury.
Their contract expires on March 31, and Ms. Pope said they feared that King Kullen would close that warehouse on April 1. Executives of the company say no decision has yet been made.
The teamsters also represent 23 employees in the meat warehouse, also in Westbury, who are continuing to work. That contract expires in 18 months, Ms. Pope said.
The executive vice president of operations for the company, Brian C. Cullen, said competition on Long Island had changed from 20 or 30 years ago. Then, he said, multinational supermarkets were not known and neither were large so-called warehouse like BJ's, Price Costco and Sam's Club.
"They have all put more pressure on us to be competitive in the marketplace," said Mr. Cullen, a nephew of Michael Cullen, who started the business in 1930.
"Even if our union members worked for free," Mr. Cullen said, "they would have to pay us for us to realize the kind of comprehensive savings" with Bozzuto's.
King Kullen, Mr. Klaus said, did not base its move on economic considerations, but rather "greed and deception."
"They are saying they are doing it to be competitive with the multinationals," he said. "But their biggest competitor is Waldbaums, which employs 350 teamsters at its Islip warehouse. What they are doing by going to another company is destabilizing the industry. In going to the lowest bidder they are going to start a price war."
"King Kullen," Ms. Pope said, "had other options that would have saved them millions and kept the warehouse jobs. But Bozzuto's saved them more millions, savings that just mean more profit. And customers frequently don't realize those savings."
Mr. Columbus denied that the Bozzuto's contract had an escape clause. It is irrevocable, he said, and King Kullen would be "liable for all expenses should we break it." Those expenses, which he said could run to millions of dollars, include new space to supply the 47 King Kullen stores, adding tractor-trailers and other handling equipment and hiring additional supervisors and workers.
Bozzuto's, Mr. Cullen said, was interested in talking to the King Kullen workers to see whether they wanted jobs in Cheshire. King Kullen, he added, offered workers training like tractor-trailer driving and other skills. He said there was a shortage of drivers on Long Island.
"We do not believe the union communicated that offer to its members, because we know of one employee who spent his own money to learn how to drive a tractor-trailer," Mr. Cullen said.
The workers, he added, could also seek work elsewhere in the company, and "we had strong leads on other Long Island jobs."
Mr. Klaus said all the company did was "give us a list of jobs it got out of the newspaper."
"There were a total of six jobs with no addresses, only a job description and the town," he added.
Mr. Klaus said that it took two hours to drive to Bozzuto's and that he would have had to "uproot my family to work for $280 a week, when I was making $780 here."
"I'd also have to start out at the bottom in a nonunion place," he added, "and my wife, Debi, would have to quit her job as an accounting manager." Mr. Klaus said King Kullen had not given the workers an opportunity to negotiate for their jobs. At the meeting on July 28, he said, "they walked in with a corporate and labor attorney and said they were not there to negotiate."
Mr. Cullen did not dispute that, but said the company was "prepared to try to do the right thing for our employees by providing them with severance and retraining."
Although there was no legal requirement for severance, Mr. Cullen said, on July 28 "we offered everybody one week of pay for every year of service."
"In addition," he said, "we offered to extend the contract, from Sept. 1 through Sept. 30, so they would have had two months' notice."
Asked why the company made its announcement a month before the end of the union contract, Mr. Columbus said King Kullen had begun studying the issue a year earlier and did not decide until late June on the five-year contract with Bozutto's.
"Once we made the decision," Mr. Cullen said, "we had significant concern over the union's reaction. From the time we made the announcement until the last day of the contract, absenteeism was at the 50 percent level. And the productivity of the employees who showed up was equal to the poor attendance record. We couldn't service our stores, because productivity was down 40 to 50 percent. We had to recruit temporary workers to supply our stores. On Sept. 2 the union went on strike."
Although union officials said the company had told them that the decision to close the warehouse was not based on economic reasons, Mr. Columbus said:
"Everything has an economic component. To compete with the multinationals here on Long Island we must streamline our cost structure and offer more items at lower cost. So certainly there was an economic component."
Ms. Pope said the company was using half its 33-acre site in Westbury. "The company is making a very good profit, and it could expand the warehouse if it wanted to," she added. That will not come to pass, said Mr. Kennedy, who added that the company was "actively seeking tenants for the warehouse building."
"We're now selling off the tractors and trailers we don't need anymore," he said.
Mr. Columbus said union suggestions to expand the warehouse and to have King Kullen buy produce for other chains on Long Island were unrealistic. "You're talking about the lifeblood of a business, purchasing," he said. "A supermarket chain is not going to rely on a competitor to buy for it."

HEADLINE: Long Island Q&A: Robert Rosenthal;
From Baking to Investment Management

BYLINE: By DAVID WINZELBERG 

 BODY:
HE has been called one of the new architects of Long Island, and although Robert Rosenthal couldn't tell you much about bricks and concrete, he knows how to make dough.
The former chief operating officer for the bakery corporation Entenmann's, Mr. Rosenthal is currently president of First Long Island Investors in Jericho, managing $800 million in assets of some of the area's wealthiest individuals. As co-chairman and co-chief executive officer of the New York Islanders, Mr. Rosenthal recently helped engineer the pending sale of the team to a consortium of owners, who are planning to build a new arena and develop the area around the Nassau Veterans Coliseum. 
 A past president of the board of the Sid Jacobsen Jewish Community Center, Mr. Rosenthal, 48, serves as vice chairman of the board of the North Shore University Health Network and is also a member of the Dean's Advisory Council for Hofstra University Law School. Active in civic and charitable efforts, he is a father of four and lives with his wife, Jodi, in Old Brookville.
Q. Why is it so important to have a professional sports franchise on Long Island?
A. The Islanders are part of the cultural infrastructure of Long Island. They became a significant part of its history and tradition by winning four consecutive Stanley Cups in the early 1980's. They are also the anchor tenant in a building that provides entertainment for people of all ages. The Islanders as a sports team links all of the kids involved in youth hockey, which has really grown on the Island in the last few years. They can go visit their local pro sports team that is vying for a championship and I think it's really great to be a part of that. We can't afford to lose any more sports teams. We once had the New York Nets. They're gone. We had the Jets, and they're gone. And we had Roosevelt Raceway. That's a wealth of entertainment that now is only represented by the Islanders. We need that cultural mecca.
Q. Is having three N.H.L. teams within a 100-mile radius overkill?
A. You've got three million people between eastern Queens and Montauk Point. If we put a competitive team in the Coliseum with a decent facility, they will support the Islanders. The rivalry between the Rangers and the Islanders and the Devils is probably the most exciting rivalry between three teams in professional sports. It's explosive. If you've ever been to the Coliseum when the Rangers play the Islanders, you know it's a phenomenon. And I think with having three million people who are sports-minded within this small geography there's no question that the Island can support the Islanders.
Q. The new owners of the Islanders are making a pretty big investment. What is going to insure support for the team and how are they going to fill the seats?
A.The new ownership, which includes Steven Gluckstern and his partners, is the whole package in my opinion. They have business acumen, they have a commitment to win, which is very important, and they understand professional sports. With the nucleus of young players that we've given them, and with the cooperation of the county and the state, who we've been working with for the past three years, when you put all of that together with what this group brings to the table, I think they will be very successful.
Q. When you acquired a percentage of the Islanders several years ago, it was valued significantly lower than the price you recently sold it for. How did you build the value of the franchise?
A. We viewed it as three opportunities within the acquisition of the Islanders. The franchise itself, which is a great franchise that won four Stanley Cups but has fallen on hard times. We thought if we could build a nucleus of young players, that would improve the value of the hockey team itself. In addition to that, there was a very unique Cablevision/ Sportschannel agreement for broadcast rights to the Islanders games. I worked with John Pickett to renegotiate that so we have a 35-year agreement, and that has very substantial value, which adds to the overall value of the franchise. The third part would be the building, and the opportunity to derive more revenue from that building and participate in its development. So when you take a rebuilt, revitalized team, the Sportschannel agreement and perhaps the opportunity to participate in a new facility and the space around it, we believed we could enhance the value and we did.
Q. You have talked about a "wholistic approach" to building Long Island's strength as a region. What do you mean by that?
A. There has to be leadership, balance and investment. Government officials and private industry must provide leadership, planning and investment to build the right infrastructure. You have to have a combination of commerce and culture, taking advantage of Long Island's natural assets. I'm a big believer that there's no need for anyone on Long Island to migrate to New York City for basic services such as entertainment and sports, health care, retail, education or financial services. So that combination of balance, leadership and investment builds the right infrastructure and is my approach to building Long Island.
Q. In recent years we have seen record sales volume in Long Island residential real estate, but economists attribute the boom to the success of the stock market. What is to prevent the bubble from bursting as it did in 1987?
A. I believe this is a new economic era. We have an industrial revolution of technology and communications going on that I think is as far reaching and far changing as the old Industrial Revolution of steel and railroads. We have a world that for the most part now has peace, without the threat of nuclear war. We've got a global economy, where people no longer look at the economy as being just coast to coast in the United States, it transcends the entire world. We have very little inflation and we've gone from years of worrying about massive Federal budget deficits to a surplus. All of these factors contribute to a very vibrant long-term economy, which I think helps us all prosper going forward, and will not result in the kind of market crash we had in 1987 or the kind of crash that existed in 1929. However, that is not to say there won't be market volatility. There will. But long term, all of these economic and political factors I think contribute to a very signicant economy of growth with low inflation.
Q. The current favorable economic climate has spawned a great deal of commercial development; including expansion of existing malls and construction of new ones. How many more places to shop do Long Islanders need, and at what sacrifice to rapidly shrinking open space?
A. Long Island needs balance in its development. When we talk about a new Coliseum and people suggest that the surrounding retail space will just be more of the same. Not true. The new Coliseum should be surrounded by sports family entertainment. It should be like a Madison Square Garden east, an entertainment mecca. We need to plan the space intelligently with open space, parks, perhaps outdoor ice skating rinks. It might be coordinated with Hofstra and New York Tech. It should be a unique, family entertainment-type of facility amongst the 70 acres where the Nassau Coliseum is right now. So we're not duplicating the existing malls and retail space, we're complimenting that.
Q. You handle investments for some of Long Island's wealthiest individuals. What advice can you give the average Long Islander who is looking to invest?
A. Be a long-term investor. Invest in great businesses that can endure volatility in economic cycles. Companies like Intel, Pfizer and Gillette. Don't try and time the market. Either getting in with an investment or getting out. Take advantage of the new law on long-term capital gains, which is the difference between a 40 percent effective tax rate and a 20 percent rate.
Q. How did you get started at Entenmanns?
A. My father was the outside accountant and labor adviser for the Entenmann family and I had known the family since I was 5 or 6 years old. There were some manufacturing difficulties that required a more technical business perspective, and I was called in on a college vacation to go out to the bakery and work with William Entenmann and his brother. It was Christmas vacation and I remember my dad said, 'They need you out at the bakery,' and that launched a career. That was back in 1970. I ended up going to law school at Hofstra University, while I worked full time at Entenmann's.
Q. What is your favorite Entenmann's product?
A. There are two. One is the crumb coffee cake and the other is the chocolate doughnut.
Q. There has been tremendous consolidation in health care, and North Shore has been one of the biggest players in mergers and acquisitions of other hospitals. What effect does this have on the quality of care at the smaller community hospitals that North Shore has absorbed?
A. I think that the network we have created, which includes more community hospitals, has been very beneficial to them. There is no duplication of resources, so if a smaller, community hospital is part of the system, we can help develop their strengths. We can provide assistance in gaining financing and increasing the quality of those institutions in the network, so that the people get the benefit of stronger, local institutions. But at the same time if they have a need for more specialized care, that can be handled within the North Shore network, such that we're not spending money in both places.
Q. How can Long Island continue to thrive in the future?
A. For those of us that have achieved some success on Long Island, I believe we have an obligation to invest the time and financial commitment to build the infrastructure of Long Island, to make it an even better place to live and raise our children. It's a responsibility that we have. I think its important that as communities are confronted with challenges in a changing world, that we work together with local government and we support that infrastructure. Everybody involved in our organization has to spend time working in the community supporting philanthropy. I think its something that's vitally important to Long Island, and there are a lot of people who feel the same way. What makes Long Island special is the fact that there are some wonderful people who are willing to spend their time and their money to enhance what already exists here by supporting some worthwhile endeavors. You've got to give something back, you can't always take. That's something that's very important to me and my company.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert Rosenthal, at First Long Island Investors in Jericho. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Interview

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Condo Market in Fairfield Is on the Upswing Again

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
WHEN Jennifer and Carl Ruspini came to Stamford in 1989, they bought a one-bedroom, 750-square-foot condominium at Harbor House for $205,000. Still in immaculate condition, it has a 24-foot living-dining room, marble fireplace, a small den or breakfast room, top-of-the-line appliances, powder room, and a 25-foot deck overlooking the harbor and 100 boat slips that rent for $72 per foot.
"We are the original owners," Mrs. Ruspini said. "We were the first people to move in. We had our choice of 60 units."
Six weeks ago the Ruspinis' first child, Christopher, was born, precipitating a need for more space. They put their apartment on the market six months ago at $215,000, but it has not sold. "We haven't even had offers," she said. "I think realtors don't want to bother with a 5 percent commission on a condo when they can get so much more selling million-dollar homes." 
 Her reasoning is on target: home sales are booming. And her anxiety is understandable. But she also has reason for hope, because the condo market in Fairfield County is on its way up. "With so many people coming in for Swiss Bank," she said, referring to newest major addition to downtown Stamford, "there's got to be a bachelor out there for whom this would be perfect."
Real estate brokers agree that the roller coaster that propelled condominium prices to precipitous highs in the 80's and calamitous lows in the early 90's has halted. In the last year, prices have risen and condominiums have regained the interest of investors and an array of empty-nesters, first-time home buyers and young professionals.
Joseph L. Policastro, 28, a graduate student studying for a master's in business adminitration at the University of New Haven, bought a two-bedroom, two-bath unit at Chesterfield Condominiums on Bedford Street in Stamford. "I was looking for investment properties to rent out for two or three years, then move into myself," he said. He paid $176,000 for the unit in March and rented it for $1,750 in April. His profit, he said, "is $310 a month, plus a lot of tax benefits." He is planning to buy a second unit in the same complex.
"That is a smart young man," said Lisa Bush, broker at Coldwell Banker in Stamford. "I have advised people to do just what he has done. People looking to buy may be having second thoughts about waiting and saving more money. But they don't understand that when the market is good and the forecast is good, savings are not going to match the rise in real estate prices."
Owning can be cheaper than renting. A hypothetical unit selling for $80,000, she said, "with $3,000 down, will cost about $600 a month for the mortgage payment, $150 a month for common charges, and $110 for taxes, a total of $860. Rent for the same unit would probably approach $1,000."
"Your deduction for taxes and mortgage interest brings the $860 down further," she said, "and you are almost certain to profit on selling, or have a positive cash flow if you move out and rent the unit."
STAMFORD and Norwalk condominiums have only partly bounced back from the 30 percent they lost after prices peaked in 1986, unlike the experience in more homogeneously affluent towns like Greenwich. Average prices there have remained in a relatively close range of $304,000 in 1990, dipping to $280,000 in 1991 and up to $355,885 this year, according to Greenwich Board of Realtors figures.
The William Pitt brokerage concern computed the average sale price this year in Stamford at $149,435, with 463 units sold to date and an average of 86 days on the market. During the same period last year, 369 units were sold in an average of 112 days at an average of $140,169.
The rest of the state has usually suffered more from economic downturns and taken longer to recover.
The Hartford Board of Realtors, for example, lists the average price of a unit at $77,590 today, compared with $130,900 in 1990. But there is a bright side even in Hartford, with an average of 88 days on the market and 479 units sold so far this year, compared with 1990 figures of 187 days on the market and 301 units sold year to date.
"Condominiums always lag about 20 percent below the cost of cheaper single-family homes," said Gurdon Buck, a specialist in condominiums at the Hartford law firm of Robinson & Cole. "When the recession hit, it hit hardest on condos, because the price of single-family homes came down to where people could afford them instead of condos."
Most of the middle-range complexes are now investor-dominated, he said. "If someone is getting $650 a month rent, it's worth $28,000 to an investor, who puts 25 percent down, pays $150 a month for taxes and insurance and gets a 12 percent return." A block of nine units at the 96-unit Claremore Condominiums on Maple Street in Norwalk is for sale to investors. Dan Carlucci of William Pitt Real Estate in Stamford expects them to fetch about $540,000. "Most of the residents work at Norwalk Hospital next door, and pay an average of $750 a month rent," he said.
"We are seeing a lot of activity," he said, "because banks are lending again. Secondly, people have had time to digest the reality of loss. It's difficult to have paid $200,000 and come away with $150,000." Older buildings, he pointed out, those that were converted from rental apartments to condominiums during the boom, have higher common charges because the utilities are included. "That drives the price down and for an investor with cash it's a good deal," Mr. Carlucci said. But, he said, "banks look at common charges, not operating expenses, and demand a 20 percent down payment."
"For a home buyer with 20 percent, it makes more sense to pay 10 percent on a much better unit or a house."
The dwindling supply of condominiums and the attendant rise in prices, estimated by brokers at an annual 5 to 10 percent, depending on age, quality and location, has sparked new construction for the first time in years. Christopher di Martino, head of Executive Land Developing of Pleasantville, N.Y., will begin work this winter on Quarry Close Farm, a 12-unit complex in three buildings opposite Byram Park in Greenwich, expected to open next summer.
Uva Construction Company in Stamford sold out the first phase of two-bedroom units at River Turn, for sale since April of this year and priced at $279,000 and $295,000. A second phase of the 77-unit complex on Turn of River Road will be priced somewhat higher, said Richard Uva, the company president. These are just two examples of a growing number of new projects spread through the county.
While most of the older high-rise buildings are filled and some, like Fountain Terrace in Stamford, are undergoing renovations, the turnover is heavy and expected to increase. Sales prices in such buildings are being influenced by policies of Fannie Mae (the new name for what had been the Federal National Mortgage Association), which favors having investor-owners, rather than renters in such buildings. Because of this preference, Fannie Mae will not accept mortgage loans that have been issued by banks to purchasers in complexes that exceed the 40-60 percent ratio of rental to owner-occupied units unless the down payment is 25 percent.
Consequently, "resident owners who bought for $90,000 are selling for $60,000," Mr. Carlucci said. "They don't like living with tenants. Tenants tend to leave fast food wrappers in the lobby."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
In Low-Cost Housing, the Key Is Selling Fast

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
BUILDING moderately priced houses for mostly first-time buyers may not be as lucrative as targeting a higher-income market. But builders say the payoff comes in generating faster sales, thus greatly lowering carrying costs.
When houses sell for $156,600 or less the market is spurred by mortgages offered at below-market interest rates by the State of New York Mortgage Agency, known as Sonyma, to buyers who qualify under the agency's income ceilings. 
 Richard and Larry Rush, the principals of Rush Properties in Great Neck, for example, have started sales at Stratford Farms, a development of 40 town houses to rise on 3.3 acres on Jerusalem Avenue in Uniondale. The property had been a small farm.
Prices range from $123,990 to $149,990 for two- and three-bedroom town houses, all of which are 1,225 square feet in size. The architect is Martin A. Passante of Hauppauge. "We want to sell out fast and so we are being aggressive on our pricing to move the product," said Steven Krieger of Cedarhurst, who is acting as a consultant to the Rush brothers.
The developers are applying for Sonyma's Construction Incentive Program. The program offers first-time buyers of new houses 30-year mortgages requiring no down payments, with initial interest rates that are now 5.25 percent. Rates rise to 7.25 percent in the fifth year of the loan and remain at that amount for the remaining 26 years. Buyers must pay 1.5 points at closing. A point is 1 percent of the mortgage amount.
In the Stratford Farm development, for example, a buyer borrowing 100 percent of the $123,990 purchase price would pay $684.42 monthly in mortgage payments. Monthly taxes are $300 and common charges are $76.69, bringing the total monthly payment to $1,061.11.
If no more than 30 percent of income can go to payments on a house, as most banks require, a family would need an annual income of about $42,500 to qualify.
"We expect to be sold out by the end of the year," Larry Rush said.
Even if a builder is not enrolled in the Construction Incentive Program, Sonyma currently offers a mortgage interest rate of 7.5 percent with a 3 percent down payment and a payment of 2 points.
In all areas except those considered economically depressed, where guidelines are more liberal, annual income of buyers cannot exceed $65,070 for two persons or $74,830 for a four-person household. House prices cannot exceed $156,600.
Sonyma's low-interest-rate programs are often criticized as being unrealistic because of the $156,600 cap on house prices in most areas. But as Stratford Farms demonstrates, some new housing even falls within that guideline in Nassau County, and in Suffolk County several builders are offering new housing below that limit.
Saddle Ridge Properties of Ridge has been selling detached houses in Ridge on half-acre lots at prices that start at $149,990 for a 3-bedroom, 2-bath 1,400-square-foot ranch with a basement and a one-car garage. Since sales began 18 months ago all but one of the 37 houses in the development have been sold, said Gloria Ivezaj, executive director of Saddle Ridge Properties. She added that 96 percent of the purchasers had been first-time buyers.
Crystal Bay Homes in Centereach builds houses throughout central Suffolk at prices that start at $139,900 for a 3-bedroom, 1,100-square-foot ranch on a slab. A 3-bedroom, 1,300 square-foot high ranch with an 800-square-foot unfinished lower level sells for $147,900, as does a 2-bedroom, 900-square-foot Cape Cod with an unfinished 800-square-foot upper level. A three-bedroom colonial with a basement and 1,490 square feet sells for $151,000.
Lots, which are either in small subdivisions or on scattered sites, vary in size from a third of an acre to an acre.
UNDER the Construction Incentive Program, of which Crystal Bay Homes is a member, the purchaser of the $151,000 colonial would pay $1,375 monthly on a $151,000 mortgage, including $400 for taxes, said Daniel Hurney, the builder. A family with a $49,000 annual income would be able to qualify, he said.
Another builder active in that price range is the Toussie Group of Companies, which has its offices in the Manhattan Beach section of Brooklyn.
"We build houses ranging in price from $99,000 to $300,000, from the Nassau border to Exit 66 of the Long Island Expressway," said Isaac Toussie, vice president of the company, which builds about 300 houses a year on Long Island and Staten Island. Lot sizes range from a quarter of an acre to 1.25 acres, he said. Buyers with an annual income of $38,000 can qualify for the $99,000 ranch, which has 3 bedrooms and 1,100 square feet of space, Mr. Toussie said.
In a Manorville subdivision called Northmore Woods, Patmar Development of Manorville is building 30 houses on one-acre lots. Although prices range up to $250,000, a 3-bedroom ranch, with a basement and a one-car garage, is available for $150,000, said Mark M. Salomon, the president of the company. Of the 30 houses, 21 are sold.
The availability of low-cost financing often comes as a surprise to buyers like Christine and Brian McDonald, who will be closing this month on a $156,000, 3-bedroom colonial that they are purchasing from Crystal Bay Homes. They and their two children are currently renting a one-bedroom apartment in Middle Island for which they pay $750 a month in rent. The new house under construction in Centereach on a half-acre lot will cost them $1,100 monthly, Mrs. McDonald said.
"We thought we couldn't afford a brand-new house, but we didn't know about the Sonyma loan," she said. "But when we heard about the interest rate, we realized, 'Yes we can.' "
Also available to Sonyma borrowers is housing sponsored by the Long Island Housing Partnership of Hauppauge and other nonprofit groups, which is sold at below-market prices because of state and Federal grants that provide a $25,000 subsidy to each buyer. Income limits vary according to location and project.
Upcoming Housing Partnership projects, for which builders have applied for grants, include a 50-unit condominium town-house-style development called Victorian Homes at Medford, which Scro & Scro Development of Melville will build on an 11.39-acre site. There will be 25 two-story attached and semi-attached buildings each with two two-bedroom apartments.
New York State grants of $25,000 will be used to reduce the price of each 1,175-square-foot unit to $74,990, said David Scro, president of the development company. Sonyma mortgages will be available. The most a family of four can earn is $47,300.
Although most units receiving grants are initially allocated to eligible buyers through a lottery, those left over for various reasons -- chiefly because original applicants don't qualify for mortgages -- are sold conventionally on a first-come, first-served basis.
For example, the Park Ridge Organization of Ronkonkoma still has 11 houses available in a development in Riverside called Brookside Estates. The 3-bedroom, 1,700-square-foot colonials each on a half-acre lot are priced at $83,990 because of the availability of a $25,000 New York State grant to each buyer. With a Sonyma mortgage, the total monthly mortgage payment, including $200 for taxes, would be $900, said Charles Mancini, vice president of Park Ridge. A family of four can earn no more than $50,720.
Favorable mortgage rates and down payments are also available for low- and moderate-income borrowers from the Federal Housing Administration and from banks that resell loans to the Federal National Mortgage Agency, known as Fannie Mae. Mortgages with down payments as low as 3 percent are available.
Fleet Bank is providing down payment assistance loans of up to $7,500 to first-time buyers. The interest rate is the same as the mortgage interest. The down payment loan may be repaid over a maximum of 15 years.
For families making less than $66,500 a year, the EAB bank offers mortgages with interest rates .25 percent lower than the prevailing rate. The loans require a 3 percent down payment.
And Roosevelt Savings Bank of Garden City also has loan incentives for moderate-income buyers. It allows borrowers to spend up to 33 percent of income on mortgage debt instead of the standard 28 to 30 percent. It also waives its $550 attorney fee if buyers fill out mortgage applications over the phone.
