HEADLINE: Where Pollution Hampers New Uses for Old Buildings

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
THEY used to make hats in Danbury, so many hats that it was nicknamed the Hat City. They used mercury to make the hats. Today, the hat makers are gone but the mercury remains, scaring away investors from redeveloping the properties where the hats were made.
Danbury's former hat factories are among approximately 500 unused industrial properties throughout Connecticut that have been termed brown fields. These properties are contaminated with pollutants not badly enough to be declared Superfund sites and qualify for emergency clean-up funding, but sufficiently to discourage any banks from loaning money to rebuild on them. 
 "They're wastelands," said Dennis Elpern, Danbury's director of planning. One of the properties, the former Mallory hat factory, is a half-acre parcel on Rose Street. The abandoned building, which is said to have served as a drug den and squatters' camp until it was badly damaged by arson, was condemned, and torn down. Mr. Elpern remembers how the factory used to pour pollution into the Still River. "You could tell the color dye they were using for the hats that day by the color of the river," he said. Today, the soil on the empty land is contaminated with mercury and oil that may still be leaching into the stream. Danbury has foreclosed on the property for back taxes, and hopes to add it to its development program. Five years ago, that would have been far more difficult than now.
For Connecticut, brown fields present a serious hurdle to economic development in the old mill towns along rivers, and in cities and villages near inlets and harbors along Long Island Sound.
The communities have lost taxes and jobs as developers by-passed them in favor of cleaner properties that had never been used for industrial purposes. But in a few years, local and state economic development officials have made progress through creative development programs and laws to help reclaim the commercial value of brown-field properties. New Federal initiatives sponsored by two of the state's congressmen are expected to add to the momentum toward a solution.
Tax legislation sponsored by Representative Christopher Shays, a Republican of Stamford, and Representative James Maloney, a Democrat of Danbury, and signed by President Clinton in August, allows brown-field developers to write off all their clean-up costs in the year they are incurred, rather than over 20 to 40 years as the tax code previously provided.
The legislation will cost an estimated $1.5 billion nationwide in lost tax revenue, but the two congressmen expect that by making the redevelopment of brown fields more profitable, it will generate more than that amount in increased revenues through business and job growth. It may also add local tax revenues in older industrial cities, which in Connecticut have had the greatest difficulty recovering from military industry cutbacks.
Besides its effect on economic development, brown fields are also an environmental issue. Cleaning up the pollutants that contaminate them is a benefit as much as is job growth or expanding local tax bases. "If you make an investment in one of these properties, you can make a big difference in the quality of the environment, and to a community's finances," observed Mr. Maloney.
One reason that economic development officials in Connecticut have been as creative as they have is that the state's environmental laws are among the strictest in the nation. These regulations require the owners to bear the expense of removing pollution from their properties, and in most cases they bear that liability even if previous owners contaminated the properties long ago. Banks that hold mortgages on those properties may even find themselves financially responsible for cleaning them up. Another difficulty is that state and Federal environmental laws were poorly designed to address brown fields. Usually the laws and regulations required far more environmental remediation than some think is necessary to reuse brown-field properties for commercial or industrial purposes.
Higher clean-up costs give many properties a negative value. A former factory property in Norwalk would be worth about $200,000 if it were available for development, but removing mercury in the soil and asbestos in the buildings is estimated at $900,000, according to Edward Musante, executive director of the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency.
Often, brown-field properties are abandoned by their owners, who cannot afford to pay for their restoration. The banks that hold their mortgages and the cities owed their taxes refuse to foreclose for fear they will become responsible for cleaning them up.
The state has created a revolving loan fund to help pay for assessing the clean-up needs, said Kip Bergstrom, the economic development director in Stamford. To build up the fund, 20 percent of the local property taxes from redeveloped brown-field properties is paid into it. "We think that will help move some sites that have been sitting in limbo," Mr. Bergstrom said.
Interest in redeveloping brown-field properties in Connecticut grew when the state's economic recovery began about five years ago, allowing local officials to turn their attention to the nagging problem. They discovered that their greatest stumbling block was that little was known about either the extent or type of contamination at most brown-field properties, or how much their remedial clean-up costs would be.
Two of the earliest efforts were in Waterbury and Bridgeport. In both cities today, the fruits of those labors are clearly evident. A new shopping mall has opened on the site of a former brass factory in Waterbury, and construction of a minor-league baseball stadium has begun in Bridgeport where a valve factory once stood.
There are many others. The redevelopment of an old brass rolling mill in Thomaston is underway, part of a concentrated, cooperative brown-field program of communities along the Naugatuck River.
Officials in Derby hope to reclaim that city's waterfront by cleaning up O'Sullivan's Island, a contaminated peninsula at the confluence of the Naugatuck and Housatonic rivers.
Mr. Maloney said that as a state senator, he had helped Waterbury secure a $30 million grant through state bonding in 1994. Two-thirds of those funds were used to level and clean up the 100-acre Scovill Brass property along Interstate 84, which had been used as a brass mill since the early years of the Industrial Revolution and was contaminated with asbestos, metals and lead paint. "You had a kind of toxic cocktail," he said.
The property is now the home of Brass Mill Center, a shopping mall, creating hundreds of jobs for the Waterbury economy and adding $160 million to the city's grand list of taxable properties. "It's recognized as the major urban development in Waterbury since the Second World War," Mr. Maloney said.
That project got Mr. Maloney interested in brown-field redevelopment, but he said he didn't realize the extent of the problem until he began his campaign for Congress last year. He discovered that nearly a third of the state's identified brown-field properties are in the Naugatuck Valley between Torrington and the river's confluence with the Housatonic.
Redevelopment officials from those cities who met with him begged for his help, he said. They had already banded together regionally, aided by a coalition of church groups, unions and others who were interested in reducing unemployment and stimulating economic growth in their communities.
Jay Klemendt, executive director of the coalition, the Naugatuck Valley Project, said the Valley Regional Planning Agency realized it needed to take a united regional approach toward brown fields after failing in 1995 to get a Federal grant for property contamination assessment.
It required abandoning the traditional approach of Connecticut municipalities to work alone and compete with each other. The new approach worked, and the agency won a $90,000 grant from the Federal Environmental Protection Agency last year. The grant will be used to complete an inventory of brown-field properties in the region and begin assessing their clean-up needs and costs. "If we're going to attract resources to our part of Connecticut, we're going to have to work together," Mr. Klemendt said.
Michael Freimuth, director of planning and economic development in Bridgeport, said his city knew since the 1980's that it had to address its brown-field problem. "In a city where 98 percent of the land is developed, you have to reuse the old," he said. In 1994, Bridgeport acquired a $200,000 Federal EPA grant to support one of two national pilot programs on brown-field recovery. Besides identifying the brown-field properties and assessing them, Mr. Freimuth said the city decided policy changes were also necessary to allow their redevelopment to proceed faster and less expensively.
Bridgeport was joined by other cities in a lobbying drive aimed at revising cumbersome state laws and regulations. He noted that the cities did not ask that environmental standards be lowered, just that they set different criteria for different land uses. Industrial or commercial land need not meet the same standards as land for residential development, he said.
Danbury hopes to return the Mallory property to its tax rolls soon as well. It received a $45,000 E. P. A. grant to determine exactly how much pollution there is and if there are other ways to address it besides excavation, which could further pollute the river. Jack Kozuchowski, director of environmental and occupational health services, said they might use bacteria or plants that absorb pollutants and neutralize them. Investors have been inquiring about the property. "It's going to work," he said.

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 1; Column 5; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1230 words

HEADLINE: Small Businesses Fight the March Of Big Retailers

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
LIKE Davids fending off advancing giants, many small merchandisers are waging a battle for survival. Mom-and-pop businesses, in Westchester and the rest of the United States, are digging in their heels despite the onslaught of mammoth retailers.
"Sometimes I feel as though we're on the verge of extinction; other times I know we can win," said Jack Nicolais, a 47-year-old pharmacist and owner of Saxon Chemists who ekes out a living in the shadow of a busy CVS in White Plains. 
 "I work hard," Mr. Nicolais said. "I'm honest as the day is long, yet somehow the big guys keep getting bigger."
Statistics indicate that, in fact, the big-box merchandisers -- a phenomenon of the last decade -- are gaining ground. In Westchester, superstores occupied 10 percent of the retail market last year, according to the County Planning Department.
While some small merchandisers are surviving, others have been unable to hold out in the face of mounting competition.
In Yonkers, Herbert Lockwood recently shuttered his building-supply and home center, a fixture in the region for 70 years. Nearing retirement, the 60-year-old Mr. Lockwood said he was not willing to risk his life's savings to compete with the Home Depot, which opened in nearby New Rochelle a year ago. Another Home Depot is to open next year in Yonkers.
"The little guys made our country what it is," a weary Mr. Lockwood said outside his empty lumberyard. "For a long time, we were the nation's backbone. Now some of us are being pushed aside."
In addition to the Home Depot in New Rochelle, three other big-box retailers had moved into the county by last year: Sam's Club in Elmsford, BJ's Wholesale Club in Yorktown and Price Club (now known as Costco Wholesale) in New Rochelle, according to the Planning Department. Another Home Depot is opening in Cortlandt on Oct. 30.
"Small businesses shouldn't just drop off the face of the earth," Mr. Nicolais said. "There has got to be room for all of us."
North of the main thoroughfare in White Plains, in a shopping center that serves many thriving neighborhoods, Glenn Jacobi, the owner of Kadish Pharmacy, is similarly determined to be what he calls "my own man." Next door to his pharmacy, a Stop & Shop is expanding, adding a prescription department and threatening the small businessman's livelihood. The chain offered jobs to the druggist and his employees, but for his part, Mr. Jacobi refused.
"They offered me the position of chief pharmacist," Mr. Jacobi, 43, said. "But I've gone that route before. I've spent 10 years with the chains, and now I want to make it on my own."
Armed with a stack of petitions from his customers -- who are grateful for the personal service the pharmacist offers, the credit he extends when they need it and the knowledge that he will drive to the store to fill a prescription even in a blizzard -- Mr. Jacobi decided not to sell out.
"The easiest thing would be to take the money and go work for the competition," he said. "The alternative is that I have a wall of I.O.U.'s, and sometimes I get beat. But my customers are like family to me, and I'm not going to let them down."
Although news of a big-box retailer's arrival often engenders fear of unfair competition, traffic jams and other ills, and sometimes sets off zoning battles, superstores are welcomed in many quarters.
Such a dichotomy can be seen in Port Chester, where the Home Depot's proposal to build a 101,400-square-foot retail outlet and an 18,000-square-foot outdoor garden center has sparked a bitter contest between two municipalities.
While Port Chester's Mayor, Christine Korff, said her village would be happy for the added business and increased tax revenues that the superstore would bring to the struggling village, nearby Rye fears overburdening its residential streets with traffic.
In New Rochelle, Mayor Timothy C. Idoni could not be more pleased with two superstores in his midst and $2.5 million a year in sales-tax revenues from them -- which is the equivalent of an 8 percent property tax increase, he said.
The successes of Costco Wholesale and the Home Depot have also spurred renewed interest in other commercial real estate in New Rochelle. In particular, the New Rochelle Mall, which closed in 1995 after Macy's left, is planning to open once again with new tenants.
Big-box retailers can indeed prove to be a boon to municipalities, said Katrina Blauvelt, a spokeswoman for the Atlanta-based Home Depot. The company offered 275 jobs to residents in New Rochelle, hiring "master plumbers, do-it-yourselfers, second-career workers and employees from all walks of life and age groups," she said.
"As people get to know us, they realize we can be a real asset," she added.
The chain had 512 retail outlets nationwide at the end of 1996, and projections are that there will be 623 by December. Budd Bugatch, a senior researcher at Raymond Jones & Associates, business analysts in St. Petersburg, Fla., called it "the best retailer in the world."
Still, merchandisers like R. G. Brewer in Mamaroneck say they can offer shoppers something better. The hardware store, which has been in business since 1879, has carved a niche for itself over the years and thereby withstood the vicissitudes of a fickle market, Anthony Lividini, the general manager, said.
"Our customers may go away for a while, but they come back," said Mr. Lividini, whose store specializes in fine woods and marine supplies.
In White Plains, Mr. Jacobi said service was the key to his success. "That's what I have in my slingshot," he said. "That's my ammunition.
"There's a Revco up the street, so if my customers thought a chain was better, they would have left by now. My wife and I know everyone's name. It's the old-fashioned touch that works."
Many hardware stores, pharmacies and other small concerns have joined cooperatives to maximize their purchasing power. In Chicago, the Truserve Corporation, the parent company of True Value and Servistar Stores, has 10,000 members.
"In the late 1980's and early 1990's, as the big-box stores marched up the East Coast and across the country, there was a significant fallout among the weaker independent hardware stores and home centers," said Paul E. Pentz, president and chief operating officer for Truserve. "Now they're able to fight back."
Mr. Nicolais, chairman of the board of directors of the Westchester and Rockland Society of Pharmacies, said there was a net loss of 400 pharmacies in the state last year because of competition from the chains.
He has also joined a purchasing cooperative, which has enabled him to match prices with CVS.
Dr. Kenneth Stone, an economics professor at Iowa State University and an expert on the impact of superstores on small businesses, said there are a "fair number of success stories" out there.
"I tell retailers not to go head to head with the competition, because they'll seldom win at that game," Dr. Stone said. "They have to learn to do it better, differently."
But not all economists are optimistic.
"The reality is that these big stores are called category killers for a reason," said Al Norman, nicknamed "the guru of the anti-Wal-Mart movement" by "60 Minutes," the television news magazine. "Their culture is to decimate the competition. The best way to fight them is to keep them out to begin with -- to stop them at the pass."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 24; Column 3; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 621 words

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
An Ancient Tragedy Told as a More Recent One

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
IN stunning prologue to "The Darker Face of the Earth," a celebratory rush of resplendent theatrical effects spills over the stage of the Crossroads Theater Company: choral chants, grand gesture, masks and movement everywhere. Slaves and conspirators, among a company of 20 are momentarily conjoined in an invocation of life. The ritual ends in a moment of exultation. A newborn child is lifted high, as if favored by the gods.
What a way to set the stage for a tragedy. Destiny's chosen child is a universal symbol of mythic transport from an outcast in exile at Colonus to the leader of an insurrection in antebellum South Carolina. Oedipus, a sacrificial victim and a symbolic savior through suffering, is morphed into Augustus, a slave born of a white mother and a black father. He, too, is a savior, honored for freeing the other slaves. 
 True to a classical vision of inevitability -- preordained freedom for all black people -- Rita Dove, who was the poet laureate of the United States from 1993 to 1995, has dreamed up one striking parallel to Greek drama for her first full-length play.
Where she means to be prophetic, Ms. Dove is working on the side of dramatic logic and theatrical tension. But the poet-playwright is not merely retelling a classic tale with both primordial and psychological connections; she is also overreaching to the other side of credulity with analogies between the ancient rites of sacrifice and America's racial divide.
Although Ms. Dove has said and written much about clarity and economy of phrase, the play (which has been published by Story Line Press of Brownsville, Ore., twice, in 1994 and last year with an altered ending) is murky and long-winded. The Crossroads production, staged last year by the Oregon Shakespeare Festival in Ashland, is more notable for theatrical embellishment, like the viscerally exciting prologue and striking performances, than for poetic language. The play is mightily served by the theatricality of Ricardo Khan's direction, Dianne McIntyre's choreography and Richard L. Hay's set design, which takes in the cotton fields, the slave cabins and the big plantation house, not to mention dream sequences.
Momentum is more hindered than helped by the lamentations of a Greek-style chorus wailing ("There's a curse on the land," "Lord help us all," "Mercy, mercy"). Ceaselessly reminding the audience that "the net draws closer," "the net draws tighter," the imposing Trazana Beverley, hunched over and twisted as Scylla, is a conjure woman and doomsayer for the ages. Ramon Moses touches nobility as the demented slave Hector, catcher of snakes and Augustus's father, even when the actor is given lines like "What are you doing in my swamp?"
With a rare touch of levity, Ezra Knight as the adult Augustus observes, "The Greeks were a bit too predictable." Although he is made to intone "Sometimes I feel like a motherless child," Mr. Knight is a force to behold.
Amalia (Augustus's mother, owner and lover) is no warmhearted Jocasta type, but a "she-fox" who "grows eviler year for year." In the role, Felicity La Fortune travels an enlightened, painful journey of pre-feminist rage and confusion, from retaliatory wife of a philandering husband (David Adkins as Louis, the plantation owner) to haughty slave owner to helpless, doomed woman, out of control.
Ms. Dove has not grasped the vital signs of classical drama, but how she has reached. And how Crossroads has delivered something really big.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Thinking Small, but Acting Globally

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY MIDDLETON 

 BODY:
WITH small-company stocks rallying in the United States, can the rest of the world be far behind?
"It's just a matter of time before the fundamentals assert themselves," said David Herro, manager of the $70 million Oakmark International Small Cap fund. The bottom lines of many small companies overseas are strong, he said, but they have gone largely unnoticed. Conditions in Europe, meanwhile, are particularly ripe for the kind of economy that benefits small, domestic-oriented companies and encourages investors to buy them. 
 "International small cap is probably one of the most attractive and oversold areas of the global equity universe," he said.
Lately, however, nearly all the market's vogues and vagaries have hurt small foreign companies. The current fascination with index funds, for example, benefits mostly large corporations, while the United States productivity revolution has left much of the rest of the world in the dust. The only foreign companies to profit from a strong American dollar have been exporters -- usually big companies. And a currency calamity in Southeast Asia is hurting the economies of that region -- punishing small companies the most because their business is mostly domestic.
A result has been fire-sale prices among the stocks of small foreign companies -- and of the mutual funds that invest in them. The data base of Morningstar Inc., the fund researchers in Chicago, includes 18 foreign-only funds whose median market capitalization is below $1 billion. Their average gain in the first nine months of the year was a lackluster 8.5 percent, or considerably short of the 10.4 percent gain in the most common international benchmark, Morgan Stanley Capital International's EAFE index, a measure of mostly large companies in Europe, Australia and the Far East.
"It's been quite hard for international funds over all to do well," said Iain Clark, chief investment officer of Seligman Henderson in London. He added, however, that he expected foreign stock markets to pick up in coming months, particularly in Europe.
"Two things are happening," he said. "We're getting quite a solid economic recovery now, and that's generally not a bad period for small caps. Second, we're getting quite good earnings growth in Continental Europe, as we see companies there taking a closer interest in what they're delivering to shareholders."
Corporate restructuring fueled explosive growth in United States stocks early in this decade, and the same kind of revamping is beginning to spread from Britain onto the Continent, said Simon Rudolph, manager of the Templeton Foreign Smaller Companies fund, one of the few international small-company funds to outperform the EAFE this year. And a flurry of recent billion-dollar deals and hostile takeover bids -- perhaps the most flamboyant being a $9 billion hostile bid by Generali, the Italian insurer, for AGF of France -- only accelerate the European push toward improved efficiency and competitiveness.
"Restructuring is one of the very good reasons why Europe is looking more attractive," Mr. Randolph said. His fund has 55 percent of its $108.3 million of assets there and only 15 percent in Asia, mostly in Hong Kong.
In picking a fund that invests in foreign stocks, the ability of its managers to pick the right spots geographically is probably more important than any other consideration, said Lewis J. Altfest, principal of the financial planning firm bearing his name in Manhattan.
"There are great diversities abroad," he said. "If you've invested in Europe, you've been a winner. If you've invested in Asia, which was known as the area of guaranteed growth, that has been a major disappointment."
Economic problems have been festering throughout Asia, from recession-scarred Japan to Malaysia and Thailand, which have seen their currencies devalued.
"In Southeast Asia, economic growth is probably 5 percent or 6 percent, which is much stronger than growth in any of the developed markets but still slower than it used to be," noted Leila B. Heckman, head of global asset allocation for Smith Barney. "And they're raising interest rates to defend their economies, and that's a drag on the stock market."
Small companies usually command higher prices than large ones, relative to their earnings, because of greater growth potential. In the United States, the ratio of current prices to forecast 1998 earnings is 19.5 for small companies and 17.7 for big ones, according to Smith Barney, reflecting in part the high number of small high-technology companies on which investors have pinned hopes for outstanding growth.
Overseas, however, the roles are often reversed. In Brazil, the ratio is 12.7 for big corporations and 7.5 for small ones, according to Smith Barney. In the Netherlands, it is 17.6 for big companies and 13.7 for small. China has the most extreme disparity, with big-cap companies selling at 71.4 times prospective earnings, compared with 19.6 for small caps.
Mr. Herro, of the Oakmark fund, says many of his holdings trade at a fraction of the prices of bigger companies, especially those based in the United States.
He cited the example of Enix, a Japanese maker of computer games. "It sells at five times cash flow," he said. "Among larger-cap companies, whether in Japan or elsewhere, 10 or 20 times is usual."
Lambert & Fenchurch, a small British insurance broker, trades at five times this year's forecast earnings. "A comparable big-cap United States insurance broker would trade at close to 20 times earnings," he said.
Fyffes, an Irish vendor of bananas, sells for nine times this year's earnings, Mr. Herro said. By contrast, Dole Food's multiple is 17 and Chiquita Brands' is 18. "And Fyffes is a much better company," he asserted. "It's much safer financially and has a management that's more value-adding than these bigger names."
Mr. Clark of Seligman Henderson cited the example of Tarkett, a German maker of floor coverings. The company recently absorbed the floor-covering business of a French rival, making the combined concern "a genuine global competitor to Armstrong," the United States leader in this industry, he said. The Seligman Henderson Global Smaller Companies fund, which invests in the United States as well as abroad, owns shares of the company.
"We think they can achieve cost savings amounting to 50 percent of operating profits over the next two or three years," he said. "That should produce earnings-per-share growth of 25 percent-plus in the same period." Tarkett's price-to-earnings ratio, however, is only 13 times this year's expected earnings.
THE bargains in international small-cap stocks only brighten their fundamental allure for American investors: their value in diversifying an equity portfolio. Joseph Leung, manager of the Barr Rosenberg International Small Capitalization fund, said the United States stock market and the international small-cap market have had a low correlation over the last five years -- meaning that they have not tended to move in tandem. Their correlation was 0.22; by contrast, markets with the maximum correlation, 1.0, move in lockstep.
Barr Rosenberg, a pioneer of the school of investing known as modern portfolio theory, demonstrated that international small caps, unlike domestic ones, reduce risk because of this low correlation, as well as enhance returns for portfolios that are mostly invested in large United States stocks, said Dick Saalfeld, president of Barr Rosenberg Mutual Funds.
"You can invest one-third of your equity assets in United States small caps and get the benefit of increased return," he said, "But you'll also pick up incremental risk. Only with international small caps do you get the double benefit of reducing the risk and increasing the return."
Ronald W. Roge, a financial adviser in Bohemia, N.Y., says he recommends that investors put one-third of their equity capital into foreign stocks. He uses the Tweedy, Browne Global Value fund and the Sogen International fund, both of which own American as well as foreign stocks.
Mr. Roge acknowledged that international small-cap investments could provide useful diversification. But among mutual funds that use a foreign-only small-cap strategy, he said, "we haven't found anything that's got an outstanding record long term."

HEADLINE: 2 Candidates, Different Plans

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN 

 BODY:
IN most states, voters consider a politician's position on education, taxes or the economy when they go to the polls. But not in New Jersey this year. According to recent polls, voters have auto insurance on their minds.
While both of the two leading candidates for governor have promised to help motorists agonizing over their high premiums, their approaches are miles apart. 
 Governor Whitman, a Republican, wants to lower premiums by limiting the number of lawsuits that can be filed after an accident, and by reducing legal fees and excessive medical bills -- some of the main causes of the state's high rates.
Under Mrs. Whitman's proposal, drivers could choose between several plans that would allow them to save between 5 percent and 25 percent of their premiums. The most savings would go to those motorists who gave up their right to sue for pain and suffering. Such damages exist over and above the cost of medical bills and lost wages, which would be covered.
The Governor's Democratic rival, State Senator James E. McGreevey, who is also Mayor of Woodbridge, says that as governor, he would order insurance companies to reduce rates for all drivers by 10 percent. Unlike Mrs. Whitman, Mr. McGreevey says that all drivers would get lower rates without giving up their rights to sue.
Mr. McGreevey says that the across-the-board rate cut would force insurance companies to crack down on fraud, which insurance regulators estimate could be inflating premiums by as much as 20 percent. But several experts who have reviewed Mr. McGreevey's proposed rate reduction say that it could be struck down by the courts if the insurance companies were able to prove that it hurt their ability to earn a fair profit.
Mrs. Whitman's plan to limit lawsuits is not without its own problem: It is unclear whether it could ever become law. Her proposal faces fierce opposition from the state's trial lawyers, who have widespread support among state legislators, many of whom are lawyers themselves.
Mrs. Whitman offered a similar proposal early this year, but only months later had to put the plan on hold. She could not find enough support for it from legislative leaders, even though her own party controls both houses of the Legislature.
Mr. McGreevey has attacked Mrs. Whitman's record on auto insurance during her first term, saying that she seems to be too close to insurance companies, and has been too easy on them as a regulator. Regulators approved 11 rate increases for 11 insurers , on top of the automatic annual rate increases of at least 3 percent that all insurers received in the first three years of her term.
Mr. McGreevey wants voters to elect the state insurance commissioner, rather than having the top regulator appointed by the Governor. He says an elected commissioner would help keep state regulators independent from insurers and responsive to consumers.
To fight fraud, Mr. McGreevey would add a special criminal prosecutor's office to the Department of Banking and Insurance. And, he also wants to permanently revoke the state licenses of doctors, chiropractors, lawyers and body shops who commit fraud.
Experts on auto insurance often say that Michigan has one of the country's best auto insurance systems. Mrs. Whitman has incorporated part of Michigan's law into her plan.
Michigan, like New Jersey, has a no-fault insurance system, which allows accident victims to get reimbursed automatically for medical bills without filing a lawsuit or proving who was at fault. Unlike New Jersey, Michigan has put strict limits on lawsuits so that only the most seriously injured can sue for pain and suffering damages.
In Michigan, a lawsuit can be filed to recover those intangible damages only in cases of death or serious injury. And, even though a Michigan auto insurance policy provides more medical coverage than a policy in New Jersey, Michigan drivers now pay $645 on average to insure each vehicle -- $368 less than motorists in New Jersey.
Mrs. Whitman has put similar lawsuit restrictions in her plan. For example, those drivers who wish to save 10 percent on their current rates would be subject to the limits similar to Michigan's.
Trial lawyers also oppose this portion of the Governor's plan, which makes it unclear if it could ever become law.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CONEY ISLAND;
Just How Does the Killer Klown Get Through the Winter?

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
On a chilly Columbus Day, Coney Island is a shadow of its summer self. Rubbish piles up on sidewalks and streets. Most stands and stores are shuttered, and scream-inducing rides are shut down. A lone couple rides the carousel on Surf Avenue; on the boardwalk, one child bounces on a caterpillar ride.
The desolation, the emptiness, prompts a question (or three): Whither two-foot-tall Gloria, billed as the world's smallest adult? Where is Koko the Killer Klown? And how is Zenobia, the Bearded Lady, paying her bills? 
 Just as California has its strawberry pickers and Colorado its ski instructors, Coney Island has its seasonal workers, from the sideshow attractions to the army of laborers who sell tickets and operate rides.
The ways they pass the winter are as varied as their job descriptions, and often determined by their place in the employment hierarchy. Owners vacation, lounge in Miami, travel to amusement park conventions around the country and refurbish their rides. Their workers, in contrast, may return to homes in Caribbean islands or Coney Island. Some will collect unemployment, others find odd jobs. Some squirrel away their summer pay, often minimum wage, and live off it the rest of the year, and in winter take a nominal vacation. "I just take it easy, hang out at home," said Louise Bennett, 70, who has sold tickets and trinkets at the Eldorado arcade for 30 years.
The performers at Sideshows-by-the Seashore have their own ways of making do in their dry season. Koko the Killer Klown, who chose not to reveal his real name, said he has a 1-month-old baby to help care for, and a new job with a Subway sandwich shop on Coney Island. As a Subway Man, clad in a giant sandwich costume, he will travel to schools to lecture children about nutrition.
The Bearded Lady, whose real name is Jennifer Miller, said she would rehearse and raise money for her one-ring Circus Amok, which performs occasionally in parks in the summer. But to earn money, she said, she needed freelance gigs, and so far, this year has been dry.
If no work surfaced before her money ran out, she said, she might resort to bike messenger work. She said, however, that her quest for off-season work was complicated by a form of discrimination: she said she had been rejected for jobs, including a stilt-walking stint just last week, because of her beard.
Frank Hartman, inside talker and master of ceremonies, whose talents include fire-eating and sword-swallowing, said he tried to survive on bookings for private events. If not, he said, he would rely on "good old-fashioned standbys": welding, cooking and unemployment compensation. "You do what you got to do to pay the bills," Mr. Hartman, 26, said, adding that he missed the sideshow desperately in the off season.
Then there is Brendan Goldblatt, who in winter and summer is the company face, but for different companies. In winter, he is a greeter for Sprint PCS in the Flatiron Building in Manhattan, bidding customers hello and directing them to the appropriate customer service representative. In summer, he is the outside talker at Sideshows-by-the Seashore, exhorting passing ladies and gentlemen to pay to view the "congress of oddities" on display inside.
Mr. Goldblatt, 19, seemed to be handling the transition with aplomb. "Instead of wearing a costume on a stage, I'm in a suit," he said. "And not as many people are screaming at you." AMY WALDMAN

HEADLINE: Disinflation, Anyone? Prices of New Cars Are Declining, for a Change

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

 BODY:
CAR and truck prices are falling, for the first time since the nation entered its current period of economic expansion in 1991.
The chief reason: the industry's excess production capacity, with auto makers around the world turning out more vehicles than they can easily sell. 
 The chief beneficiary: the American consumer, who stands to get more car for less money as manufacturers cut suggested prices and offer rebates even on models that were just redesigned.
"We're seeing an outright decline in average new car prices year-to-year," said David Littmann, senior economist at Comerica Bank in Detroit. "In August -- for the first time in the six and a half years of this business cycle expansion -- car prices dropped. And the declines will continue."
Indeed, the Consumer Price Index for September showed that new-car prices fell 0.28 percent from August and were down 0.7 percent, adjusted for seasonal variations, from a year earlier. Mr. Littmann said he expected prices to drop further through next year. The average selling price of a new car has fallen back to about $19,000 after rising above $20,000 this year.
And manufacturers are keeping their suggested list prices flat, or even cutting them. The Ford Motor Company is holding its average prices constant for the 1998 model year. The Chrysler Corporation has reduced car and truck prices by six-tenths of a percent. The General Motors Corporation raised prices by an average of 1.3 percent, its smallest increase in a decade.
But G.M.'s Saturn Corporation unit recently adjusted its 1998 prices and sent refunds of the difference to buyers who had already paid the higher prices. Saturn reduced the price of its SL1 sedan by $300. It raised the prices of its SL2 sedan, SW2 station wagon and SC2 coupe, but added air-conditioning, normally a $950 option, as standard equipment, so that the cars cost less with comparable equipment. About 14,000 people who had paid higher prices for 1998 models received refunds of $300 to $960.
Chevrolet also reduced prices for its 1998 Prizm, which has been completely redesigned and has more standard features. The most basic Prizm sedan now starts at $12,463, down from the initial 1998 pricing of $14,118 and a 1997 price of $13,245.
Even before the recent price adjustments, 1998 prices had held relatively steady compared with 1997.
Honda, which completely redesigned its Accord for 1998, increased the price of four-cylinder models by only $110, or five-tenths of a percent, and reduced prices of the V6 version by $950.
In announcing prices this week, Nissan's luxury division, Infiniti, kept prices of its Q45 luxury sedan and QX4 sport utility at 1997 levels.
Even though 1998 prices are flat or falling, and although the '98 model year began just three weeks ago, some manufacturers are also offering rebates and low-interest financing on the latest models.
Chrysler is offering rebates of $1,500 on the 1998 Dodge and Plymouth Neon and as much as $1,000 on 1998 Dodge, Plymouth and Chrysler mini-vans. An alternative to rebates is financing of 1.9 percent on loans as long as 60 months. The Neon program is in effect through Jan. 5; the mini-van incentives expire on Oct. 31. For the Jeep Grand Cherokee, loans of up to 48 months are available with an interest rate of 4.8 percent, through Jan. 5.
Ford is also offering cash rebates or low-interest financing on numerous 1998 models. A rebate of $500 or financing of 2.9 percent to 6.9 percent is available on the Ford Ranger, Ford Escort and Escort ZX2 and Mercury Tracer. The Ranger is all new, and the ZX2 was introduced only last spring.
Ford is paying $750 or providing low-interest financing on the Ford Contour and Taurus and on the Mercury Mystique and Sable. It is offering $1,500 on the Windstar mini-van and $2,000 on the Mercury Villager, for which interest rates as low as 1 percent are available.
"The trend of prices is very clearly downward," Mr. Littman said. "The consumer couldn't ask for a more ideal market."

HEADLINE: Speed Limit and Deaths

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A study of 1996 data by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety found that higher speed limits caused a substantial increase in traffic fatalities (news article, Oct. 12). The story is not that simple. 
 According to the National Safety Council, traffic fatalities rose 1.9 percent in 1994 and 2.8 percent in 1995. But when speed limits were increased in 1996, the fatality trend dropped to essentially zero growth. This trend is continuing to decline in 1997.
Comparing the first five months of 1997 with the same period in 1996, fatalities increased in two of states reviewed by the insurance institute but declined in nine. The jury is not yet in on the question of speed limits and fatalities.
 
CHARLES LAVE
Irvine, Calif., Oct. 14, 1997
 
The writer is an economics professor, U. of California at Irvine.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;
'87 Crash: The Other News

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Where were you when the lights went out on Wall Street?
Ten years ago today, the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 508 points, the worst day in the stock market since the crash of 1929. Or, as The New York Post put it, "WALL ST. BLOODBATH." 
 But the financial news did not completely dominate the day. In fact, there seemed to be no such thing as a slow-news day back then, with much of the excitement coming from the New York criminal-justice system.
No less than four major trials involving homicide or assault were beginning, under way or ending that Monday. The "Subway Vigilante," "Howard Beach," "Westies" and the "Preppie Murder" trials, to give them their tabloid headlines, were all part of the late 1980's traffic jam of news.
Television, movies and the theater provided New Yorkers with some escape by providing alternate versions of New York. That evening, the top-rated Cosby show depicted the Huxtable family as the picture of family devotion in a Brooklyn brownstone.
In the No. 1 movie, "Fatal Attraction," Michael Douglas, as an adulterous Manhattan lawyer, fought off a knife-wielding Glenn Close. On Broadway, Patti Lupone was winning rave reviews in the Cole Porter revival "Anything Goes" as the New York cabaret singer who gets no kick from champagne.
Still, the real-life New York was interesting, too. Billy Martin savored his return, his fifth time at bat, as manager of the Yankees. Mia Farrow was expecting Woody Allen's first child and shopping for baby clothes. And Bernhard Goetz, who shot four young black men he said were about to assault him, was sentenced to six months in jail for weapons possession and promptly told The Associated Press that he would shoot them again if he had to.
Elsewhere, community groups were mobilizing against Donald Trump's proposal (since scaled back and relocated) for a skyscraper complex called Television City on the Upper West Side. "It's so obviously a mistake," said Robert Caro, a West Side resident and the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of "The Power Broker."
And on the Lower East Side, the principal and teachers at Junior High School 22 were wearing boots, long johns and coats because the school, on top of a major mice and rat infestation, had no heat.
But if this October day was anything, it seemed to be the nexus of several sensational trials. Not only had the Goetz saga come to a close, but the Howard Beach trial was under way. Timothy Grimes, one of three black men said to have been attacked by white youths in Howard Beach, Queens, exploded with obscenities after hostile questioning by a defense lawyer. The three accused white men were later convicted of manslaughter.
And in another Manhattan courtroom, a prosecutor accused eight men of being part of the Westies gang, which "terrorized" Hell's Kitchen with "horrible and ghoulish acts of murder, kidnapping and assault." Seven of the eight were later convicted of racketeering charges.
Meanwhile, the "Preppie Murder" case was about to start. Robert Chambers, a former private school student, was accused of killing Jennifer Levin; he said the death was accidental and had occurred during "rough sex." Mr. Chambers later pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter.
New York sports was at a crossroads, too. "Replacement football" came to a close for the Giants and Jets as a 24-day players strike of the National Football League ended, but without a collective bargaining agreement.
The big story, however, was Billy Martin. Martin, 59, had been angling to return as manager, despite his four previous dismissals by George M. Steinbrenner 3d. Martin's hiring marked the 14th managerial change in the 15 years Steinbrenner had owned the team. In a prepared statement, Martin said that he was "anxious" to return.
And what of the "bloodbath" on Wall Street? Not quite so bloody as first thought. While the market continued sluggish into the 1990's, hurting the local economy, the bull market eventually roared back, more than quadrupling the Dow to more than 8,000. ANTHONY RAMIREZ

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE;
A Gang of Hustlers Turns a Dime Bank Into a Cash Cow

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

 BODY:
One economic postulate of the streets holds that where there is cash, there is crime. But even hard-boiled police officers are marveling at the ingenuity of the latest low-end scam to hit the East Village. Beat cops from the Ninth Precinct report that a gang of ragtag hustlers are picking off bank card codes of unsuspecting customers at the Dime Savings Bank branch at Eighth Street and Second Avenue and taking thousands of dollars from their accounts.
The police say one gang member stands outside the bank's large plate-glass and peers in at the customer using the nearest automated-teller machine, which has a large, easily readable touch pad. After the customer completes a transaction, the machine asks if he would like to do anything else. Often a customer leaves and neglects to clear the machine. Account information can be gotten and additional transactions carried out just by re-entering the access code. No bank card is needed. 
 If the machine has not been cleared, another hustler, who appears down on her luck and trying to earning an honest dollar, graciously steers customers away from the "hot" machine to other available ATM's as the man outside the glass window flashes the departed customer's access code to a third associate in line for the ATM near the window. That person proceeds to withdraw the maximum amount from the account.
Although bank cards usually allow withdrawals of no more than $500, someone with a credit card access code may withdraw up to the card's limit. Lieut. Arthur F. Monahan said that in late August, the gang took nearly $5,000 using the credit card access code of a Japanese tourist in the East Village. "It is an obvious scam, if you have your wits about you," Lieutenant Monahan said. "But people don't typically want to put off a person who looks homeless." At least 10 people have been victimized, the police said.
The precinct has stationed an officer outside the bank for six weeks and five people have been arrested inside, mostly for trespassing, the police said. More serious charges could be filed after a review of surveillance tapes, the lieutenant said. The manager at the Dime branch, Anthony Vattuone, declined to comment and calls to the director of marketing, David Totaro, were not returned.
The police said they have identified the core group of scam artists, including Ronald Furgeson, 35, who was charged with assault on a police officer and criminal trespassing after an incident on Sept. 1 in which he struggled with Lieutenant Monahan who was working undercover inside the bank. They tumbled through the plate glass window when Mr. Furgeson reached for the lieutenant's gun, according to the police.
The police recommended that bank patrons do not take directions from homeless people, that they notify the nearest police officer if they feel they are being harassed; that they not use the machine if drunk, and that they complete each transaction and take their bank card. CHARLIE LeDUFF

HEADLINE: Faces of the New York Economy;
A Laborer At Hard Jobs For Low Pay

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
"IF you can survive the New York economy," Jennifer Fields said, "you can survive anywhere."
Ms. Fields, 42, has survived, though many New Yorkers would have trouble understanding how. 
 A single mother of three, she has traveled through the city's labor market, underground economy and maze of public assistance to land a job that pays her $15,192 a year plus a bonus, taking her place among the city's estimated 900,000 working poor.
Calculating whether the city's lowest-income workers give more than they receive comes down to hard cases like Ms. Fields.
She has become a productive worker with the help of city programs that many taxpayers resent, but she still needs government help to maintain her status.
Ms. Fields attended public schools in New York, as do her children.
She received welfare benefits for eight years while one or another of the children was in preschool, and Medicaid benefits for longer.
She has used city-financed homeless shelters and drug-treatment programs; one of her children spent time in city foster care. She lives in public housing built partly with city funds.
But Ms. Fields has contributed to the city's economy, as well, by performing low-paying, difficult, but much-needed work.
She has provided respite to families caring for sick relatives and remedial help to public school students in Bushwick, the Brooklyn neighborhood where she grew up. She also worked making perfume boxes in a Brooklyn factory.
Now she is a full-time aide at Concord Family Services, a nonprofit agency in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood, where her work ranges from filing to doling out affection and discipline to teen-agers in foster care.
For that, she gets health insurance and $1,266 a month -- triple her welfare income, and enough for cable television, manicures, sofa slipcovers and Timberland boots for her children.
Ms. Fields still gets government help, however: subsidized rent, child care and food stamps.
Moreover, her salary at the Concord agency is paid under a city contract, a tiny portion of the $2.6 billion that the city spent on social service program contracts in the 1996 fiscal year.
At least until now, by cold, hard calculation, she might be classified as a debit on the city's ledger.
But Ms. Fields says she has moved to the credit side.
"No matter what your past is, with effort you can change," she said. "You can be a productive citizen." AMY WALDMAN

HEADLINE: Faces of the New York Economy;
Big Earner, Big Spender, Little Burden

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
PHILIP G. POTTER, who develops investment products for high-net-worth clients of Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company, likes to think of himself as an "uberconsumer."
Last year, he spent his bonus on a 50-inch TV and a $3,500 Rolex watch. He wears custom-made $800 suits, custom-made $80 shirts -- always with white collars and white French cuffs -- and $200 shoes. He is "totally wired," as he puts it: His home phone forwards messages to his pager; he answers them over a tiny $800 cellular phone. 
 A member of what he calls the "young affluent" class, Mr. Potter, 25 years old, represents the icing on the cake of New York's economy.
Though he declined to say exactly how much he earns, he allowed that depending on his bonus, he may well make "just over the goal line" of six figures this year. That would put him into the highest city tax bracket, meaning that City Hall will take at least $3,300 from his paycheck.
He spends at a rapid clip, whether at stylish restaurants in his Park Avenue South neighborhood, at downtown clubs like Lucky Strike or the 10th Street Lounge or in replenishing the Bombay Sapphire and single-malt Scotch in the bar at home.
Besides the rippling economic effects of tipping waitresses and buying drinks for his friends -- he drops $300 into the pond on an average weekend -- Mr. Potter's spending returns sales taxes to city coffers.
Yet he asks little of the city. Single, childless, healthy and young, Mr. Potter uses virtually no services; he rarely even rides the subway.
Moreover, like so many young people, his money stays in Manhattan. "I never leave the city," he said. "I just don't want to. I'm so in love with the city, I start getting withdrawal symptoms the moment I go over a bridge or in a tunnel."
His devotion to the city flows naturally from his work. "New York is where it's at," Mr. Potter said. "You need to be sitting down the hall from the division manager, not in a branch office in Minnesota. I wouldn't be able to do anything like this except at the headquarters."
Mr. Potter graduated from Yale in 1994 with a degree in physics, and after a short stint at a hedge fund, joined Morgan Stanley that November. He acknowledges that he has never been through a sustained market downturn but says he is confident that he would survive any Wall Street bloodletting.
"I can continue to come up with new products, to add value," he said. "I'm not responsible for getting money. Getting it's hard when the market goes down. But there will still be products to sell. It'll just force me to be a little more creative." DAVID M. HALBFINGER

HEADLINE: Faces of the New York Economy;
Immigrants Providing a Global Link

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
IN 1994, Zan Ng, a commercial photographer, persuaded Joseph Liu, an advertising executive, to join his fledgling ad agency, which Mr. Ng hoped would attract business from American companies trying to sell products to Asian consumers.
Today that midtown agency, Admerasia, employs 50 people and bills $20 million a year, joining a growing number of immigrant-owned businesses that have successfully capitalized on ethnic connections. 
 "The cultural and ethnic mix gives New York a special energy that makes it possible for people like us to succeed," said Mr. Liu, the agency's managing director.
Mr. Ng started Admerasia in 1993 with $250,000 that he and his two brothers had saved over the years. For advertising skill, he turned to Mr. Liu, who had started an agency of his own but had grown weary of the entrepreneurial headaches and now wanted a job with less risk but some chance of building equity.
Both came to America in 1975 and are now United States citizens. Mr. Ng, 40 and a father of five, was a penniless immigrant from a poor village in Fujian, China. Mr. Liu, who was reluctant to give his age but quick to say he is single, arrived on a student visa from Hong Kong with only a rice cooker, hoping to find work as an artist.
Drawing from the city's large pool of talented professionals who are native speakers of Asian languages, the agency quickly built its business by helping American companies sell to Asian consumers in the United States. Its clients now include Citibank, MCI Communications and Ajinomoto U.S.A., the American subsidiary of the Japanese manufacturer of seasonings and processed foods.
Admerasia's business is expanding to include a telemarketing company, 618 Easy, and services that help American companies market their products in Asia. The company plans to open an office soon in Los Angeles.
Mr. Liu said New York's rapidly growing immigrant populations allowed him to select the best talent from a variety of ethnic groups, including Chinese, Korean, Japanese, Vietnamese and Russian. Staff members say they are often overlooked by mainstream Madison Avenue agencies because they lack a native's grasp of American language and culture.
"I had a lot of creative experience in Taiwan," said Jeff Lin, the agency's creative officer. "But American agencies would not hire me because my English isn't perfect." JANE H. LII

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2720 words

HEADLINE: A Financial Capital? Yes. A Model Economy? No.

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
MAYBE it isn't the economy, after all.
While voters' economic insecurities propelled Bill Clinton to the White House, New York City's economic prospects hardly seem a factor in the mayoral contest. Just two weeks before the election, the campaign is mired in quarrels about pressing matters ranging from Rudy Guiliani's bedside manner to Ruth Messinger's ambivalence toward porn parlors. 
 That certainly fits Gothamites' fatalistic pride in their ability to roll with the economic punches. After all, the city went down for the count in the national recessions of 1969, 1974 and 1990 -- and was shaken to the core by the stock market collapse just 10 years ago this week. But New Yorkers have always brushed aside predictions that the local economy would be overwhelmed by the problems dogging older American cities since the 1960's.
The current cycle of recovery seems to be proving them right again. Optimists are crowing about the city's 7.6 percent gain in wage income last year and the prospects for an equally strong increase in 1997. Office buildings are filling up, Manhattan co-ops are selling for record prices and the city budget is balanced. "The whole image of New York as a place to live and work has turned around," said Randy Mastro, New York's Deputy Mayor for operations.
Pessimists, though, have no difficulty finding the dark lining in this silver cloud. While employment has been rising the last five years, the city has recovered only half the 650,000 jobs lost from 1987 through 1992. Unemployment remains above 9 percent -- nearly twice the national rate -- even as New York enters an era in which Federal welfare reform will force tens of thousands into the job market. And while income growth has been strong, the gains have been concentrated in the top niches of the notoriously cyclical financial services sector.
"Now more than ever, New York City is captive to forces beyond its control," argues Carol O'Cleireacain, an economist at the Brookings Institution who was the city's Finance Commissioner in the Dinkins administration.
On first (and maybe second and third) look, the facts favor the gloom and doomers. By most measures, New York has lost its competitive edge in the national economy, and few experts see much chance that the city can reclaim it. New York seemingly has neither the financial resources nor the political will to make the radical changes needed to attract the sorts of businesses that fled to the suburbs and the Sun Belt during the last three decades.
But while the city's strengths are less tangible, they should not be dismissed. New York continues to dominate a variety of high-paying, high-profile service industries ranging from advertising to broadcasting to theater. It still exudes a sense of vitality that attracts the best and brightest. And both history and cultural diversity give it a claim to pre-eminence in the global economy. "New York is the economic capital of the world," concludes Robert Hormats, an executive at Goldman, Sachs who contributed to a new Council on Foreign Relations study, "The City and the World."
 
The Drawbacks
Let's start with the bad news:
 
DEPENDENCE ON WALL STREET In the mid-1950's, nearly a million New Yorkers worked in manufacturing. But in each postwar recession, manufacturing jobs were lost and never returned. Today, just a quarter-million of these jobs are left.
Fortunately, declines in both manufacturing and government employment the last four years have been more than offset by job gains elsewhere, with retail trade, business services, media, finance, insurance and real estate leading the way.
The catch is that the good new jobs have been concentrated in relatively few businesses. Rae Rosen, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, notes that the incredible incomes of a few thousand deal makers and traders pulled up the earnings of the average securities industry worker to $169,500 in 1996, more than four times the average New Yorker's pay. Member firms in the New York Stock Exchange reported profits of $11 billion in 1996 -- up from just $1 billion in 1994.
Of course, when Wall Street prospers, the benefits spill over directly into accounting, legal services, advertising, insurance and public relations -- and indirectly into myriad businesses that service the high life. What's more, the resulting windfall in income taxes yielded a modest budget surplus this year that allowed Mayor Giuliani to increase spending on overcrowded schools.
But with 15 percent of City Hall's tax revenue coming from income levies on Wall Street, and with multibillion-dollar budget deficits looming just a few years away, New York's fiscal future seems precarious. "When the securities business hits a bump, it will be payback time for the city," warned David Hensley, an economist at Salomon Brothers.
 
BLOATED BUSINESS COSTS Patrick Howie, an economist at Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa., estimates that the cost of doing business in the New York City region is 29 percent above the national average and more than 40 percent above the average in Sun Belt cities like Houston, Dallas and Oklahoma City.
In part, these costs reflect economic strength rather than weakness: high rents in Manhattan are driven as much by demand as by supply. By the same token, high wages are largely offset by high labor productivity: James Parrott, an economist in the office of New York State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, calculates that "unit labor costs" -- wages per unit of output -- are just 3 percent above the national average.
The Guiliani administration has instituted "one-stop shopping" for a variety of commercial licenses, busted up the mob-dominated commercial garbage collection cartel and cut business taxes on commercial rent and unincorporated business income.
But there are still high hurdles to commerce in New York -- from traffic congestion to regulation to taxes, which aren't likely to become competitive in the foreseeable future.
For one thing, the city must contend with a huge tab for deferred maintenance: tens of billions of dollars would be needed to bring schools, roads, bridges and other infrastructure up to snuff. For another, it has a property tax that, by state law, is biased against business: Commercial buildings representing 30 percent of the value of city real estate pay 50 percent of the tax.
Dean Mead at the nonpartisan Citizens Budget Commission points to a third problem: deeply ingrained government inefficiency affecting everything from the size of the public school bureaucracy to the location of firehouses. While there have been marginal improvements, he estimates that "the city still uses 25 percent more employees than average to deliver services, who are on average paid 25 percent more than employees of other cities."
 
CHRONIC POVERTY Like the rest of the nation, New York suffers from a wide -- and widening -- gap between rich and poor, explained largely by strong demand for skilled workers and weak demand for the unskilled.
Ms. Rosen of the New York Fed notes that many of the 180,000 manufacturing jobs lost in the last recession -- not to mention the 36,000 government jobs lost to downsizing in 1995 and 1996 -- came at the expense of unskilled workers. Roughly two-thirds of all the growth in wages during the recovery has been in financial services, where all the rewards go to the skilled and the lucky. The State Comptroller's office estimates that bonuses, almost exclusively associated with high-wage Wall Street jobs, represented 23 percent of all wage growth in the city from 1990 through 1995.
Along with making New York a less attractive place to work and live, poverty makes it more expensive. While crime rates have fallen sharply, New Yorkers have paid heavily for the benefits. Last year the Police Department employed 46,800 people -- 8,000 more than in 1994. And while the welfare rolls have fallen by a quarter-million since 1994, one New Yorker in eight is still receiving cash grants, and the city's bill for public assistance and medical care is a near-record $5.5 billion this year.
 
The Bright Spots
But wait, there's good news for the city, too:
 
DECENTRALIZATION IS AN OLD STORY According to the conventional wisdom of the 1980's, the tumbling cost of communications and air travel would gradually undermine the economic advantages of urban density. Manhattan, the densest urban center of all, has indeed suffered, losing dozens of Fortune 500 corporate headquarters to both the suburbs and to Sun Belt cities with lower wages, taxes and rents.
But Mitchell Moss, director of New York University's Taub Urban Research Center, argues that countervailing forces are also at work. In the high-fashion business, for example, the flexibility that comes from being close to designers and wholesalers offsets higher production costs.
Strikingly, the city economy has benefited even from what might be casually perceived as the mother of all threats: the computer age. New York is home to "Silicon Alley," more than 1,000 small companies in the software business. And according to the calculations of Mr. Moss and his Taub Center colleague, Anthony Townsend, New York has the highest concentration of Internet domains of any large city. "Density still counts," Mr. Moss concludes.
New York has also proved adept at recycling obsolete manufacturing and commercial space, making it profitable for some cost-squeezed businesses to stay in the city and for others to come in. The publishing industry moved from midtown to lower Fifth Avenue. Big retailers colonized the lower part of the Avenue of the Americas. Wall Street moved north (while the advertising industry moved south) into TriBeCa. Led by the Walt Disney Company, Times Square is again a center for glitzy entertainment.
 
DIVERSITY PAYS While New York's capacity to support radically different cultures is often celebrated as an achievement in itself, diversity has more direct payoffs. The city's welcome mat for gays and lesbians, for example, helps sustain its edge in arts and entertainment, which nourish both tourism and high-end consumption by residents. More prosaically, gays and lesbians have high average incomes and relatively few dependents -- meaning they pay a lot of taxes and, with the AIDS epidemic past its peak in the gay community, make few demands on city services.
The acceptance of ethnic differences also creates uniquely efficient market niches. Ten Korean grocers trying to break into business in a large city would face daunting challenges. But a thousand Korean grocers can support their own wholesalers and lenders and create a labor exchange for immigrants not fluent in English. "There are economies of scale to ethnicity," said Joel Kotkin, a senior fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy in California.
Probably most important, diversity attracts the young and talented. The Harris survey in May 1997 that ranked New York as "the city Americans would most like to live in" may be a fickle barometer. But high-end businesses are apparently having little difficulty recruiting, despite high living costs. And there is no doubt that diversity has also helped make New York the nation's most popular destination for foreign tourists, which creates jobs for the unskilled as well as reinforcing the city's dominance in theater, music, dance and the visual arts.
 
GLOBALIZATION While New York has a hard time delivering services competitively in the American economy, it is in a favored position to capture the fruits of global economic integration. New York may have high costs compared with those of Chicago or Houston, but even with today's relatively strong dollar it remains a bargain compared with Tokyo, Frankfurt or Milan. And the city has been able to capitalize on this strength in industries where it is already a big, if slipping, domestic player. "If you're a foreign bank that is only going to have one branch in America, that branch will probably be in New York," Ms. O'Cleireacain said.
In the brave new global economy, people as well as goods and services cross borders. While New York's attraction to immigrants is a mixed blessing -- the city's schools are crowded with their children -- immigration's constant renewal of the city's energy has almost certainly outweighed the costs.
For one thing, immigrants have filled the void in many neighborhoods left by deindustrialization and corporate downsizing. The city's foreign-born population, just 18 percent at its nadir in 1970, reached 28 percent in 1990 and is still rising rapidly, with Dominicans, Russians, Chinese, Jamaicans, Guyanans and Indians leading the charge.
For another, immigrants reinforce the city's strengths as an international financial center. The presence of large, distinct immigrant communities makes it easier to house and school foreign nationals, as well as to find local labor that speaks foreign languages. And "unlike Los Angeles, New York has strong ties to Europe as well as Asia and Latin America," Mr. Hormats of Goldman, Sachs said.
Immigrants also create natural markets for ethnic products that give manufacturers a chance to expand to the rest of the country -- and the world. For example, the House of Spice in Queens sells some $30 million of packaged Indian foods nationwide and exports to the Caribbean. Doreen Interiors, a firm started by Yemeni Jewish craftsmen, sells high-end upholstered furniture and draperies in Europe and the Persian Gulf.
 
The Prognosis
The Wall Street boom will end: it's not a matter of whether, but when. And the resulting fall in securities industry wages, bonuses and profits will send shock waves through a dozen key New York industries, from law to real estate to high-end retailing. That, in turn, will probably prompt a fiscal crisis for City Hall, which is projecting budget deficits in the next few years even if the local economy remains strong.
How the city weathers this crisis (and the next and the next) turns on a host of imponderables. The exchange rate of the dollar and economic growth abroad affect both the appeal of New York to foreign tourists and the demand for financial services. Albany's generosity, or lack thereof, will decide whether school class sizes grow and whether the inevitable spikes in the welfare caseload are buffered with cash. Elusive social factors will decide whether the coming demographic bulge of teen-agers raises the incidence of crime and single-parent households.
Some experts -- notably those not in government -- argue that New York could pull itself up by its bootstraps. And at least in theory, there is no end to the potential for making the city a more attractive place to work and live: increasing the efficiency of government, deregulating housing, developing the waterfront, rationing access to congested Manhattan streets. "If there's a will, there's a way," argued Mr. Mead of the Citizens Budget Commission.
But the mayoral candidates are long on generalities and short on controversial initiatives. Both see improvements in public education as crucial to the city's economic viability. Beyond reducing classroom sizes with money from unspecified sources, however, their plans are unclear.
Ms. Messinger, the Democratic candidate, wants to refocus economic development aid, notably tax breaks, from large to small businesses. And she wants city contractors to draw their unskilled workers from city residents.
Mr. Giuliani, the Republican incumbent, argues that the business-friendly face of his administration has restored half the jobs lost in the last recession, and that the key to continuing success is further progress in cutting crime, delivering government services for less money and paring business taxes.
With either candidate as Mayor, then, probably the best that one can hope for is incremental progress in containing the liabilities that too often make daily life in New York harsh. But with or without good luck, good government and the will to self-improvement, a striking number of urbanists are bullish on the city's long-term prospects.
"In the final analysis New York has what it takes to be a renaissance city," said Mr. Kotkin of Pepperdine -- "creativity and diversity."
