HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Glamorous Internships With a Catch: There's No Pay

BYLINE: By DAWN GILBERTSON 

 BODY:
HOPE WAGNER, a sports administration major, scored a dream summer job.
Ms. Wagner, a senior at the University of Nebraska at Kearney, worked in the media relations department of a professional sports team. She drafted news releases, clipped newspaper articles and helped with community relations programs. 
 Her big project, the one that will be front and center on her resume, was a 75-page media guide for the coming season, which she helped finish over Labor Day weekend.
Ms. Wagner, one of five interns, took home plenty of souvenirs from the team -- T-shirts, bumper stickers, key chains and watches -- but not a penny, not even gas money for all the errands she ran.
She was an unpaid intern, one of thousands of students working for nothing but experience and, sometimes, for college credit.
"They treated me well while I was there, but I just think the whole idea of unpaid internships isn't fair," Ms. Wagner said. "At times I just got so frustrated thinking how many hours I put in for free."
Internship experts estimate that 50 to 60 percent of all student internships are unpaid. The figure is closer to 100 percent in glamorous fields like entertainment and politics, they say.
To be sure, there are plenty of paid internships, some of them with bigger paychecks than the students' parents earn.
Intel, the chip maker, pays undergraduates $450 to $750 a week and provides moving expenses, discounted housing and a free rental car, according to "America's Top Internships" and "The Internship Bible," sister guides that are part of the Princeton Review series by Random House.
Interns at General Motors earn $450 to $600 a week and receive health insurance, paid vacation days and round-trip travel, according to "The Internship Bible."
BUT internship listings often show no compensation. And the programs aren't all offered by struggling nonprofit organizations or small businesses. The Princeton books and "The Yale Daily News Guide to Internships" list unpaid internships for well-known businesses like Barney's New York, Merrill Lynch and NBC.
Although internships seem largely unregulated, there is a law governing the programs. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, which established minimum wage and overtime protections for workers, lists six criteria employers must meet for interns to be considered trainees and thus not guaranteed the minimum wage. Even internships that offer academic credit must comply.
Labor lawyers zero in on two stipulations: the intern cannot displace a regular employee and the company must derive no immediate advantage from the student's work.
"The bottom line here is whether the activities primarily benefit the individual or the employer," said a spokesman for the Labor Department.
Ms. Wagner's internship experience was not uncommon, and neither was that of Kerrie Brown, a St. Bonaventure University student, two years ago. Ms. Brown, now a senior, worked for a small cable television station in Maryland. She wanted to get a taste of broadcast journalism and was told she would learn about news writing, production and more. All she did was answer phones and watch television for commercials the station produced.
"They had me doing secretarial work that they should have been paying someone else to do," she said, adding that she quit when a paid internship opened up at a local newspaper.
So how do so many businesses and organizations continue diving into a gigantic pool of free labor year after year?
College career counselors and others say various factors are at play. First, the law is not aggressively enforced and is somewhat ambiguous. Second, there is no shortage of applicants for unpaid positions, especially in glamorous fields.
And both the interns and the businesses seem to enjoy, or at least tolerate, the benefits of the system enough to not rock the boat. Interns can gain invaluable training and good credentials, and there is not much of an incentive for blowing the whistle; the businesses gain free labor and a first peek at workers who are about to graduate.
"In the 12 years I've been in the field I've never heard of a case where an employer has been even chastised for abusing that law," said Dawn Pettit, executive director of the Cooperative Education Association, an organization in Columbia, Md., that promotes work-classroom programs.
A Pittsburgh labor lawyer, Donald O'Connor, said there had been some cases, including one nearly three years ago in which a public relations agency reached a settlement over billing of clients for the unpaid work of interns. The firm agreed to pay more than $30,000 in back pay to a group of former interns and to pay future interns.
The Labor Department says there have not been many violations, but concedes that it typically does not investigate a company unless there are complaints.
"It's not like we have an enforcement program focused on interns," the Labor Department spokesman said.
Ms. Pettit said she would be concerned if a student's unpaid work contributed to big profits.
"When the student is going there and they're part of a team working on a project ultimately resulting in millions of dollars of income -- some software program, for example -- then, no, it's not fair if she's the only one not being paid," she said.
Unpaid internships, however, may be seen as a rite of corporate passage. As Samer Hamadeh, 28, co-author of "The Internship Bible" and "America's Top Internships" says, "This is the way you break into the work world in America."
The numbers bear that out. Some internships attract a flood of applicants. "America's Top Internships," for example, says the "Late Show with David Letterman" gets about 750 applicants for 30 unpaid positions, even though they rate high on the guide's busy-work meter -- running lots of errands, making copies and answering phones. Penguin Books gets about 200 applications for eight unpaid positions in editorial, marketing, sales and other departments, while 250 applicants vie for one summer internship at Elite Model Management in Beverly Hills, Calif., the Yale guide said.
Mr. Hamadeh, whose internships included a paid stint pumping airplane grease through pipes for Chevron, now hires interns and pays them. But he said there were additional costs for a company.
"You have to spend a lot more time training them," he said. "They're often much younger and have no office skills."
The companies would "never hire any of these people otherwise," he added.
INCREASINGLY, said Jack Tinker, director of career services for Connecticut College in New London, Conn., potential employers want -- and schools require -- work experience. And that encourages the current system, with would-be interns unwilling to demand pay.
Mr. Hamadeh, quoting figures from the National Society of Experiential Education, said that as recently as 1981, just one in 36 college graduates had done an internship. Ten years later, the figure jumped to one in three. Mr. Hamadeh said that more recent surveys put the figure at about two out of three.
Supporters of unpaid internships say the benefits outweigh the short-term sacrifices.
"Our students are coming out with contacts, they're coming out with confidence, they're coming out with stronger resumes," said Laura McKaie, assistant dean of career education at the Long Island University Brooklyn campus, where the median age is 26 and many students support families.
Internships are especially crucial in industries where contacts are the only way in the door. Steve Cook, a 1997 graduate of Northwestern University's film school, said the Hollywood jobs in which he was interested were not advertised, so it was essential to have a network of people to call regularly.
Mr. Cook, who just directed his first film, "The Choir Invisible," started internships as soon as he graduated from the Lawrenceville School near Princeton, N.J. He spent his college summers in California, working without pay for companies including Hollywood Pictures, NBC, the Gersh Agency and Prufrock Pictures, the actress Meg Ryan's production company.
Despite her frustrations and empty bank account, Ms. Wagner said she would do her internship with the sports team all over again. She sought the job and volunteered to do the media guide, for which the team was prepared to hire a graphics artist.
"I thought it would be a good opportunity for me to try something big like that," she said. Ms. Wagner lived with her parents, who took care of her bills.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 10; Column 3; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: Along the Old Silk Road, a New Effort to Shine

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: KHIVA, Uzbekistan

 BODY:
Historians say that no one knows when this ancient Silk Road town was founded, but that has not prevented President Islam Karimov from declaring October as its 2,500th anniversary.
For weeks laborers have been working frantically to clean Khiva's streets, repair its imposing monuments and build towering scaffolds to hold powerful lights and loudspeakers brought from Germany for the occasion. Mr. Karimov has planned lavish celebrations to which he has invited officials from around the world, and to spice the invitation he has announced that this month is also the 2,500th birthday of the town of Bukhara, where he is staging another extended party. 
 Khiva, Bukhara and nearby Samarkand are built around spectacular mosques and palaces that testify to this region's astonishingly rich history. Each was once the center of an empire, attracting titanic figures like Alexander, Genghis Khan and Tamerlane.
Because it stood at the heart of the Silk Road, the land that is now Uzbekistan attracted traders from across Europe and Asia. It acquired a sense of self-importance and destiny that President Karimov now seeks to embody.
Mr. Karimov -- whose term of office expired in 1995 but was extended for five years after a referendum in which a reported 99.6 percent of the people voted to keep him in power -- also embodies the tradition of authoritarian rule that has dominated life here for centuries.
With 23 million people, Uzbekistan is the most populous of the five Central Asian countries that emerged in 1991 as the Soviet Union collapsed, and senior officials make no secret of their ambition for regional leadership. The celebrations they are holding in Khiva and Bukhara, like their failed attempt to bring the Olympic Games to Tashkent, the capital, reflect their desire to lift Uzbekistan out of anonymity and make it a player in world affairs.
The Central Asian republics are being courted by outside powers in part because of their strategic location between Russia, China, Iran and the Indian subcontinent. Their markets and resources, which include large oil and gas deposits, have only begun to be exploited. A country that can emerge as dominant in this region, Uzbek leaders reason, will have a voice in international politics.
But those ambitions are stumbling over political and economic obstacles. Although Mr. Karimov insists that he is committed to reform, the habits he and other Uzbek leaders learned while rising through the Communist system have proved hard to break. Their plans for opening the country to democracy and foreign investment are clashing with their instinctive fear of losing control.
Human rights conditions here have improved since the early 1990's and especially since President Karimov's visit to Washington last year. Still, there is no independent press, protest meetings are forbidden and opposition political parties are banned.
But despite the slow pace of change, there is no ground swell of protest against the Government. Two neighboring countries, Afghanistan and Tajikistan, have been consumed by ethnic and religious wars, and many Uzbeks seem willing to accept Mr. Karimov's heavy-handed rule as long as he keeps the country stable and at peace.
"Ninety-nine percent of the people in this country don't even think about democracy and human rights," said Tohir Bokayev, a metalworker in Bukhara. "Their main concern is everyday life. People here have no experience with Western-style democracy."
Mr. Bokayev is trying to chip away at the monolith. He applied several months ago for permission to start an independent newspaper, and as he expected, it was denied. Now he plans to publish a newsletter that will carry only advertising and information like bus and train schedules.
"You don't need permission to start a newsletter as long as it doesn't carry news," he said. "I want to start this way, and then as time passes maybe we can expand it into a newspaper."
As in most parts of the former Soviet Union, life is hard for most of Uzbekistan's people. Even in Tashkent it is unusual to find an ordinary person who earns more than $1,000 a year. Prices are high, and many people find that rising costs have put health care and other social services out of their reach.
Efforts to diversify the cotton-based economy depend largely on foreign investment, but corruption and broken promises have driven some investors away and deeply frustrated those who remain.
Currency controls are so strict that foreign businesses often cannot withdraw their own money from banks. Local employees may not be paid in dollars, and companies that want to send Uzbeks abroad for training often find it impossible to obtain exit visas for them.
To put it another way, conditions for foreign business here are so difficult that not even McDonald's has arrived yet.
"They sign contracts without even reading them," a German hotel manager said. "When you have a disagreement with a local partner, you tell him to look at what's written in the contract and he says: 'Contract? What's that?' "
The impulse that makes the Government reluctant to open the economy also leads it to equate political opposition with subversion.
"Because of Karimov's authoritarian style, Uzbek society is stagnating," said Mikhail Ardzinov, leader of a human rights group the Government does not recognize. "In Russia you see dynamic economic thinking and open debate about problems and possible solutions, but Karimov will not tolerate that here."
Although the Government denies holding political prisoners, Mr. Ardzinov estimates that there are 32, nearly half accused of fomenting Islamic radicalism. The powerful security police keep close watch on mullahs and other religious figures, determined to prevent the growing interest in Islam from spilling over into politics.
"I am very happy that our President is banning Islamic fundamentalism," said Dildora Alimbekova, a Tashkent seamstress who has formed an association of female entrepreneurs. "I'm a bit surprised to see what is happening in my own family. I have 48 nieces and nephews. These young people are very interested in Islam, and half of my nieces are covering themselves in the old Islamic way. I discuss it with them, but they don't accept my point of view and argue strongly against me."
Uzbekistan remains a decidedly secular country where there is no taboo against drinking alcohol or wearing short skirts and where one of the capital's most popular restaurants is called Pork Chop. But especially in the northeast Fergana region, the country's most densely populated, there are signs of an Islamic revival.
At the bazaar in Kokand, one of the largest towns in Fergana, it is no longer unusual to see veiled women. Vendors sell cassettes on which prominent mullahs extol the virtues of religious education and belief.
In Andijan, another Fergana town, a 60-year-old trader, Abdulrahim Abdulaim Oghli, said he had dreamed all his life of making the hajj, the Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca but never believed it would be possible because such pilgrimages were banned by the Soviet authorities.
"Now, praise Allah, I have made the hajj twice," he said. "Since independence, people have followed their desire to become more religious. My grandson is reading the Koran and is about to finish it."
President Karimov, though determined to prevent fundamentalism from taking hold, has sought to conciliate and co-opt the Muslim leadership rather than repress it. Always seeking to balance competing forces, he speaks warmly about Islam despite the fact that for years he served an officially atheistic system.
Confronted with a choice about whether to make the hajj himself, which might set too strong a religious example, or to stay at home, which might offend practicing Muslims, Mr. Karimov came up with a typically adroit compromise. He traveled to Mecca, but although he visited holy sites he did it out of the hajj season so he would not seem to be encouraging excessive devotion.
"You may not like Karimov, but most people think he's what we need at this moment in our history," said Odil Ruzaliev, a reporter for one of Tashkent's Government-controlled television stations. "Let's give him a chance. In such a young country, why criticize?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: October has been declared the 2,500th anniversary of Khiva, Uzbekistan. Two Uzbek women swept in front of one of the town's ancient buildings in preparation for a celebration planned by President Islam Karimov. (Staton R. Winter for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 9; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 860 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Betting on Sector Funds to Cash In on Deals

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
INVESTORS looking for a way to participate in the consolidation wave that keeps sweeping over vast sections of the economy might consider industry-specific sector funds.
The three-way bidding war for MCI Communications -- involving Worldcom, GTE and British Telecommunications -- is the latest and largest manifestation of merger mania. But aside from telecomunications, a number of other industries -- from financial services to utilities to military contractors -- are still in the process of molting into businesses dominated by fewer, bigger participants. 
 "Consolidation really is everywhere," said David J. Williams, a managing director of the United States Trust Company and manager of its proprietary $230 million Value and Restructuring fund, which invests in a wide array of restructuring or consolidating industries and is up more than 40 percent this year. "To the extent there is too much competition, there tends to be consolidation."
So far this year, telecommunications funds have done well, slightly outpacing the growth of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. But they are not the best-performing collection of sector funds; those funds that concentrate on financial service companies are currently in the lead.
As a group, the dozen telecommunications funds tracked by Morningstar are up just over 29.5 percent this year, compared with 29 percent for the S.& P. By comparison, the 19 funds that focus on financial service companies were up 39 percent through Thursday, according to Morningstar's figures.
Buying into a fund that holds a number of stocks in a particular industry reduces the risk of placing wrong bets on a couple of individual stocks, analysts said.
Kevin Gooley, an analyst at Standard & Poor's, said that just now such diversity is particularly valuable in the telecommunications industry.
"The difficult thing right now, especially in the United States, is the uncertainty that is hanging over the market," he said. "The Telecommunications Act of 1996 was supposed to open all the elements of the telecom market to new competition, but none of that has really happened. Given that uncertainty, making a bet on individual companies is risky, with certain exceptions."
One of those exception, Mr. Gooley noted, is Worldcom, an upstart provider of a range of telecommunications services that is not as heavily regulated as AT&T or the Baby Bells.
Bruce E. Behrens, co-manager of the Flag Investors Telephone Income fund at Alex. Brown Investment Management, owns a good bit of Worldcom and a chunk of GTE. But in an interview he stressed that playing the consolidation game is not what the fund, which was formed in 1984 after the breakup of AT&T, is about.
"Consolidation is not why we are in this industry," he said. "This is a sector with a difference, and the difference is that it is a really big industry with enormous capitalization that cuts through a lot of aspects of the economy and society. It has enormous financial possibilities and there is a lot of opportunity for entrepreneurs."
Peter Di Teresa, an equity fund analyst at Morningstar, said that while consolidation was something for investors to think about, it should not be a driving force in selecting a sector fund.
"If you are a long-term investor, it should be a low-ranking priority," he said. "Market timers might tend to make a decision this way, but more often than not they tend to get burned."
Mr. Di Teresa said that of the dozen telecommunication funds tracked by Morningstar, the best performers have tended to be those with foreign exposure. Over the last year, a number of former government-owned telephone companies have been privatized, and portfolio managers are upbeat about growth prospects in those markets.
"If we take the United States as a model, most developed and developing countries have room for a lot more line growth," Mr. Di Teresa said.
So far this year, the best-performing telecommunications fund is Invesco Worldwide Communications. The fund, which is up more than 36 percent through Thursday, lists Telebras, the recently privatized Brazilian telephone company, as its biggest holding. But it also has significant positions in Portugal Telecom and Telecom Argentina.
Although it has some foreign exposure, Alex. Brown's Flag Investors Telephone fund is primarily invested in American telecommunications companies for now.
"We can have up to 20 percent foreign exposure and have been as high as 15 percent," Mr. Behrens said. "Currently, we have about 5 percent to 6 percent exposure because we think there is better opportunity domestically."
At least some investors seem to agree. The fund, which has close to $700 million in assets under management, has seen an increase in inflows in recent weeks, Mr. Behrens said. The fund has risen 33 percent so far this year and is up nearly 8 percent over the latest four weeks.
"For the past couple of years, we have been steady at around $600 million," he said. "But we have seen a reasonably significant uptick in cash flows over the last couple of weeks. I don't know if it is because of MCI, or the improving performance of the fund."

HEADLINE: Iran Sees Pistachio Ban As Foul Play by Enemies

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 15

 BODY:
It is not often that something as small as a pistachio can create so much stir, but remember this: in Iran, pistachios are big business.
After oil and carpets, pistachios are Iran's biggest source of foreign currency, bringing in about $600 million a year. More than 350,000 people earn a living from the nut, most of them in vast groves of the desert oases in the country's southeast. The bountiful harvests make Iran the largest exporter of pistachios in the world. 
 It is little wonder, then, that a decision by the European Union last month to suspend imports of Iranian pistachios has drawn dark allegations that someone, somewhere, has decided to wage economic war.
European officials said they had imposed the ban after discovering a shipment contaminated by a cancer-causing toxin. But Iranian officials said the move had to have been political.
"The ban is triggered by America, not the Europeans, because they want to replace us in the world pistachio market," said Mohammed Shams-Fard, president of the Dried Nuts and Fruit Exporters Association.
More than two-thirds of Iran's pistachio exports end up in Europe, so Iran has reason to be worried. The ban has left in limbo thousands of tons of nuts that were en route to Europe and has left the farmers completing their annual harvest with little to do but wait.
"All we want is to prove that our pistachios are safe," said Iran's Agriculture Minister, Isa Kalantari.
An alarm was raised in Europe last July after Dutch authorities found unacceptable levels of the carcinogen aflatoxin B1 in 275,000 pounds of Iranian pistachios shipped via Dubai.
Iranian officials have blamed improper storage in the emirate for the problem; the high heat and humidity there help to foster the growth of molds that produce the carcinogen.
But the Europeans have said that several countries found high levels of aflatoxin in as many as 70 percent of Iranian batches they had tested, and the scare reached such a level that one country, Belgium, went so far last month as to ban the sale of all pistachios, no matter what the origin.
Determined to demonstrate that what was discovered was nothing more than an isolated case, Iran opened its warehouses and inspection sites to European experts who visited the country earlier this month. Although the ban runs until Dec. 15, Iranian officials have said they hope it will be lifted soon, once they report their findings at a meeting in Luxembourg.
"On the whole, they were fully satisfied with what they obtained from here," Mr. Shams-Fard, the Iranian industry official, said in an interview.
But the Iranian efforts to mend fences have not overcome the suspicion that something bigger than pistachios must be at work. Relations between Europe and the Iranian Government have been rocky since last spring, when the European Union withdrew its Ambassadors from Teheran after a German court implicated Iranian leaders in the murder of dissidents in Berlin.
Although Europe is now ready to send the Ambassadors back, their return has been snagged over Iranian insistence that the German diplomat be the last to return, a condition that other European countries have unanimously rejected. Some Iranians have suggested that the ban on nuts is somehow connected to the diplomatic tussle.
But within Iran's vast pistachio industry -- in which the family of the former Iranian President, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, has a large share -- the main theory is that the United States must be behind the current troubles.
No pistachios from Iran are sold to American markets because of a United States trade embargo.

HEADLINE: LEGACY OF THE '87 CRASH;
A Decade and a Bull Ride Later, Complacency Reigns

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
AS trading moved toward a close on the worst day in stock market history, a crowd of young investment bankers gathered around the fringes of the trading floor at one of Wall Street's premier firms.
They did not work on the trading floor, and arguably had no business being on it. But there they stood, in stunned silence, watching the electronic ticker tape march across the wall. 
 It did not matter to them that the prices on the tape were hopelessly out of date, an hour or more old and, in some cases, dozens of dollars higher than the real prices at which trades were being made. The bankers were watching what was obviously an epochal event, wondering if it meant the end of their careers and of the comfortable, even extravagant, way of life that had made Wall Street an oasis of wealth.
The chief stock trader, who had spent the day desperately trying to preserve the firm's capital while witnessing selling on a scale never before seen, looked up a little before 4 P.M. and saw the assembled bankers. "I'm sure," he said, a bit testily, "that you have other things to do."
They didn't, of course. But they rapidly dispersed. It was not the time to offend senior management.
When the tape finally caught up with all the trading, the Dow Jones industrial average ended that day -- Oct. 19, 1987 -- down 508 points, or 23 percent, at 1,738.74. It was the greatest crash ever, or certainly since 1929. There had never been a day when prices fell so far.
Now, a decade later, the 1987 crash seems like a footnote in the great bull market that began in 1982 and still lives. That is true even after the Dow fell 210 points in the final two days of last week, in what one wag called "an anniversary celebration." Larger dips have been quickly reversed many times since 1987, as investors learned what has become the great lesson of the crash. That lesson is not one that seemed apparent at the time.
"The No. 1 lesson was that you should buy when Wall Street has a one-day sale," said David Shulman, the chief equity strategist of Salomon Brothers. "That lesson may be overlearned by now."
It certainly has been widely learned. Barton Biggs, Morgan Stanley's chief strategist for global equities, tells of trying to find a plumber in Ketchum, Idaho, where he has a home, over Labor Day weekend this year. Most were on vacation. The one he finally found knew quite well who Mr. Biggs was, and was scornful of his recent bearishness.
"You're lucky to get me, because I'm doing less plumbing these days," the plumber told Mr. Biggs. "I've got $300,000 in the market on margin. I'm making three times as much money this year from trading stocks as I am from plumbing, and I don't have to stick my hands down other people's drains. For years now, I've bought stocks on dips when you Wall Street guys were beating your breasts and crying bear."
In 1987, the crash seemed to teach quite different lessons. One that may be the most relevant today was that sophisticated derivative securities were highly destabilizing to the market, even though they were being used in what investors thought were conservative ways. Now there are new techniques -- being used in different ways -- that could have a similar impact, by leading to heavy selling after prices fall. If the market ever does break sharply again, those strategies will come under intense scrutiny.
A LESSON of 1987 that seemed clear at the time, but not now, concerned valuation. Stock prices by many measures were very high at the 1987 peak, and the crash seemed to vindicate those who had been warning of severe overvaluation.
Now, by many of those same yardsticks, stock prices are much more overvalued. Yet Wall Street for the most part does not care. It is said that prices are quite reasonable, given falling interest rates, the outlook for low inflation and continued economic growth. Those who spoke of excessive valuations a year ago have been largely discredited by the market's continued advance.
Immediately after the crash, one certainty to many people was that the plunge must have contained an economic warning. Stock prices, after all, are part of the index of leading economic indicators.
"Analysts all said that the market is saying something, and what it is saying is that 1988 is going to be a very bad year," recalled Richard Pucci of I.B.E.S. International Inc., a company that tracks earnings estimates by Wall Street analysts and publishes consensus figures. "So they lowered estimates dramatically."
In fact, the economic effect of the crash was minimal, and the analysts spent the rest of 1988 raising estimates. It was the only year since 1980 that analysts, as a group, underestimated a year's corporate profits at the beginning of the year.
The crash did have a depressant effect on Wall Street, and on the New York economy, for a number of years. For instance, a woman who sells very expensive furniture in Manhattan says that only this year has business been as good as it was in the months before the 1987 crash.
But for most of America, there was little impact. In fact, it is possible that business was a little stronger in 1988 than it would have been without the crash. The Federal Reserve Board, which had been pushing interest rates up, changed course abruptly after the market plunged, stimulating an economy that was doing fine anyway.
It took some time to appreciate just how much of the selling on Oct. 19 and the days around it had come as a result of an institutional investment strategy known as portfolio insurance. Details varied, but the basic idea was that institutions could lock in profits, at minimal cost, by selling stock index futures contracts as prices fell. Then, every future sold would lock in previously made profits on the stocks. Or so the theory went.
What happened was that such selling overwhelmed the market, driving down prices in the futures market much farther than they otherwise would have fallen. It did not start the crash, but it made it much worse. (It is also possible that the confidence induced by portfolio insurance drove prices higher before the crash than they otherwise would have risen, because investors who thought stocks were overvalued saw no need to sell them, given that they had an insurance policy against losses.)
Portfolio insurance was destabilizing precisely because it required selling at the worst possible time -- when prices were already falling. Such selling drove down the prices of stock index futures and brought in index arbitragers, who bought the futures and then sold individual stocks.
In the aftermath of the crash, portfolio insurance got a very bad name. Because it relied on selling index futures only after prices had begun to fall, it was compared to buying fire insurance amid the flames.
That particular strategy has died. But related ones have made strong comebacks in recent years. Those strategies depend on options of one sort or another, and come in all kinds of flavors. Most are based on so-called over-the-counter options, which are usually sold to institutions by investment banks and commercial banks.
Such an option might protect an institutional investor with a lot of technology stocks by giving it the right to sell a basket of those stocks at a certain price by a certain date. In return for an upfront payment for that kind of option -- a put option -- the investment bank would guarantee that the technology stock investor would lose no more than a certain amount. To keep the insurance analogy going, that is equivalent to buying insurance before a fire begins.
The investment bank that issued that option probably does not want to bet on technology stocks. So it can hedge its exposure in a variety of ways. One way, called dynamic hedging, bears a suspicious resemblance to the portfolio insurance of old. If prices fall, the bank will hedge by shorting the underlying stocks. It they rise, it will buy back stocks. Either way, it is going with the market flow, thus adding a bit to volatility, which has been high lately.
How much of that volatility is due to dynamic hedging? No one knows, because no figures are made public on trading in over-the-counter options. "I suspect there is less now than in 1987," says Bruce I. Jacobs, a principal with Jacobs Levy Equity Management in Roseland, N.J., and a longtime critic of dynamic hedging. "But it is hard to know. It is a total unknown."
Such hedging has the potential to destabilize the market as portfolio insurance did in 1987. The dynamic hedgers will do fine if the next bear market is a gradual affair, but will suffer greatly if prices plunge before they can put their hedges into place.
The increasing sophistication of derivative securities has made it possible to cut up the risks of owning stocks, and to transfer all or part of those risks to any number of others. Whether those risks are being handled wisely, and whether they pose threats either to individual firms or even to the overall market, cannot be known now, while stock prices are high.
Were there to be another crash, the economic impact could be much greater. Such a crash, of course, might signal something fundamental about the economy. In any case, a prolonged slump in stocks would directly affect more people, if only because there are more investors now. While many aren't as deeply invested as Mr. Biggs's plumber, many now have retirement money in defined-contribution plans, like 401(k)'s, rather than in traditional pension plans, and would thus feel pain if stocks fell sharply.
IT is unlikely, but not impossible, that stock prices will again fall 23 percent in one day. The New York Stock Exchange has put in place circuit breakers that would halt trading temporarily at various levels after sharp declines. The longest planned halt, of an hour, would come if the Dow fell 550 points, about 7 percent at current levels. But such a halt could come early enough that the market would reopen late in the day with no more artificial floors.
Circuit breakers have worked relatively well in commodities markets, including in stock index futures, where they have clicked in on some bad days. But while a rule that restricts some trading strategies has often been invoked, circuit breakers have never halted stock trading. It is possible they would perform as hoped, giving investors time to conclude that prices were cheap and send in buy orders. But investors might see the halt as a chance to submit sell orders before prices fell further.
In 1929, those who sold at the first crash proved to be the fortunate ones. Those who held on were wiped out in the ensuing depression. In 1987, those who bought in the first crash -- which turned out to be the only one -- were the fortunate ones. Since then, the belief that stocks are always the best long-term investment has been embraced by many investors and market commentators. That theory, which would have seemed incomprehensible to someone who survived the 1929 crash and the long bear market that followed, will no doubt stimulate buying on weakness and make a new crash less likely.
In connection with the crash anniversary, Elrick & Lavidge, a polling firm, conducted a survey for American Century Investments, a mutual fund group. Most respondents said they thought there would not be a crash in the next five years, and a majority agreed with the statement that if there was a crash, it "would not be a major concern to me because I am a long-term investor."
In 1987, the crash traumatized investment bankers and small investors alike. A decade later it has produced something that no one could have forecast: complacency.

HEADLINE: The World;
The 21st Century Belongs to . . .

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
LISTENING to President Clinton's speeches in Latin America last week, audiences might have concluded that Washington's economic hopes and preoccupations lay to the south. But wait a week. Next Sunday, China's President, Jiang Zemin, arrives in the United States for an official visit. And chances are that visions of a vast Chinese market with a bottomless appetite for consumer goods -- or of a repressive and militaristic China -- will relegate every other place to the sidelines again.
As the summit meeting approaches, television sets and newspaper columns, seminar rooms and breakfast talkfests are already resounding with opinions about a nation that seems, for good or evil, to loom over the next century like no other country in the world. Apart from its size -- 1.3 billion people -- its economic independence and aloofness make China all the more irresistible to those who see its potential as largely untapped. Add to that the so-far seamless return to China of British Hong Kong, an economic dynamo in its own right, and it is hard to avoid the conclusion that China is a land of destiny writ large. 
 But some economists -- as well as politicians and foreign policy experts -- think this obsession with China is not healthy or smart, not for foreign policy or even for trade and investment, especially when other areas of the world are also enjoying robust economic growth.
"We are obsessively obsessed by China because of its huge numbers and rapid growth rates," said Jagdish Bhagwati, professor of economics at Columbia University. "But no one can maintain these growth rates in the long term. Sooner or later China will have to rejoin the human race. It seems to me that as you look around the world, China is a big market, but only one market. There are other sizable economic powers. And China is still full of uncertainties."
Among the regions economists suggest as alternatives worth looking at are not just Latin America -- where the average growth rate has settled at just over 4 percent, a climb out of negative growth two years ago -- but also South Asia, dominated by India and Pakistan. That region's growth rates hover around 6 percent and are expected to rise. And with India nearing the billion-people mark, South Asia will soon surpass China in population.
Moreover, raw economic data like growth rates don't tell the full story of a place's potential. The nations of the European Union had an average growth rate of only 1.6 percent and the United States' gross domestic product increased by only 2.4 percent last year, but few find either fact reason enough to avoid those nations.
Professor Bhagwati, who toured Latin America recently, said the region is reaping the benefits of democratic government, a free climate for economic activity and a new respect for economists. The Latin military can no longer demand a major role in industry as the army does in China.
"The spirit of reform is enormous in that part of the world now," he said. "The success that economists have enjoyed in having killed things like hyperinflation gives them enormous credibility. New governments have replaced old dictatorships. They are opening up in a very dramatic way." By 2010, Clinton advisers say, United States trade with Latin America will surpass trade with Europe and Japan combined.
Susan Kaufman Purcell, vice president of the Council of the Americas in New York, said that Latin American countries have always faced harsher scrutiny than have China or other Asian nations -- and that this puts them at a disadvantage.
"If you look at U.S. policy toward Latin America, to a much, much larger extent, we have pressed for democracy," she said, adding that it might be time to revise old opinions in light of the currency turmoil in Southeast Asia. "There was this vision that Asia was a very stable place and that even though many of its governments were authoritarian it was perceived that somehow they had better business values than the Latin American governments. But now people realize that the Asians are only beginning to focus on what Latin Americans have already accomplished in terms of opening their economies, privatization, democracy, transparency."
Europeans score even higher in the reliability sweepstakes, as the recent movement there of battered funds from Southeast Asia demonstrates.
"There is compatibility in the rule of law, openness in the economy," said Christopher Matthews, a spokesman for the European Commission in New York. "There is also a longstanding link with the United States: they are each other's biggest investment partners and trading partners -- over a trillion-dollar relationship."
 
Dismissing the Hype
Western Europe also thinks of itself as a gateway to the countries of the former Soviet bloc. "Some of them are small and coming up from a very low level, but their growth rate is very high." Mr. Matthews said. In addition, European companies have begun a wave of mergers and, cautiously, layoffs that are producing higher productivity and profits.
Nancy Pelosi, a Democratic member of Congress from California who has pressed for a harder line on human-rights issues in dealing with Beijing, thinks too many Americans have been sold inflated dreams about the riches to be had in the China trade.
"The facts are that we do not have access to the Chinese market, except for a small exporting elite," she said. "What the Chinese want is access to our markets and that is what they have. When they do allow a U.S. brand name to be sold in China, they immediately ask for an export plan. They want our technology, and they insist on technology transfer. Then they start their own production. It is a hoax to say that U.S. jobs are dependent on China. Under 200,000 jobs are."
Not everybody agrees with Ms. Pelosi. In fact, disputes between human-rights hard-liners like her and those who emphasize economic engagement do much to keep attention focused on China.
And so the decibel level will rise again next week. But as it does it may be worth recalling all the cheerleading about Latin America only a few days ago during President Clinton's visit, and considering what is not being said very often about some other places.

HEADLINE: Citizens;
France Confronts Its Jews, And Itself

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
AS a bloody century wanes, repentance is in vogue, a sort of global purging of the soul before the millennium. A world relatively becalmed, perhaps moderately bored, is confronting the upheavals of the past hundred years as a form of atonement. British colonialism, Nazism, Communist totalitarianism, apartheid: the candidates for expiatory examination are rich and varied. But nowhere, perhaps, is the process more fraught or obsessive than in France's contemplation of its treatment of the Jews during World War II.
The forces pushing France toward an orgy of retrospection are similar to those at work elsewhere: the passing from power of the generation that lived the war years; the end of the cold war with its bending of truth to strategic imperatives; the odd moral magnetism of the number 2000, so evocative of a circle completed as to be an invitation to what Pope John Paul II has called "the purification of memory." 
 Here, as in other countries, there appears to be an almost physical realization of the sheer weight of the century's slaughter, and the triumph of the ideology of human rights in a post-ideological age leads naturally to the examination of past brutality.
 
Moment of Masochism
Yet in France, whose Revolution of 1789 shattered the old theocratic order and ushered in the shifting modern age, this penitential process has acquired a special intensity. France, which competes with the United States as a model of enlightenment, seems determined to clear its conscience. It is as if the first avowedly modern state -- that of the empowerment of citizens, of the enshrinement of dignity in the Declaration of the Rights of Man, and of the first formal emancipation of the Jews, in 1791 -- is unready to take on a new century without sweeping away the shadows that form part of France's eternal, sometimes maddening, ambiguity.
"This is a moment of extraordinary masochism in France," said Michel Lussault, a sociologist. "We have a need to make a spectacle of our past errors and settle every outstanding account."
Apologies to the country's 650,000 Jews are pouring in -- from the Roman Catholic Church in France, from the French medical association, from the police -- for acts of commission and omission that date back more than a half century, to the time when the Vichy regime ruled at the sufferance of France's Nazi occupiers.
Couched in terms of great humility, these requests for pardon have been marked by extraordinary frankness for a country traditionally more inclined to the discretion of a church confessional than the public display of emotion, and which has long wrestled with its "Jewish question." Until 1995 France portrayed Marshall Philippe Petain's Vichy regime as an imposed aberration that left unsullied the French Republic, an institution coeval and so eternally synonymous with the quest for equality and dignity.
At the same time, the trial in Bordeaux of 87-year-old Maurice Papon, the first and almost certainly the last Vichy official to be prosecuted for the deportation of Jews from France, has confronted the French with an agonizing fact: Mr. Papon is not a monster, but everyman, a bureaucrat par excellence, a servant of the French state and a product of its meritocracy who prospered under both Vichy and the subsequent Gaullist Republic, whose views on the Jews in the 1940's were almost certainly quite average, neither rabidly anti-Semitic nor inclined to see the Jew as a citizen like any other. His trial is therefore that of a certain France, one whose death throes now appear to be in progress.
These death throes involve different forms of absolutism that have at times blurred memory and fueled conflict: the infallibility of the church, the honor of the Republic, the doctrine of the glory of France itself. In their place, some now see a new France emerging: more tolerant, more pluralist, less dogmatic. Naturally this shift is not without opponents, particularly the rightist National Front, but a change is perceptible.
That this transition involves Jews is perhaps inevitable. For the Jewish question in France has never been a peripheral one; it has occupied a place near the heart of what are sometimes called "les guerres Franco-Francaises," the internecine struggles of the French.
From the Revolution to the Dreyfus Affair, from Dreyfus to Vichy, and from Vichy to the contemporary National Front, the place of the Jews in French society has been a recurring issue. Its resolution would be a significant turning point.
The Revolution of 1789 created the concept of a nation constituted by the will of its equal citizens, and those citizens included the Jews. French nationality became, in Ernest Renan's words, "a daily plebiscite," an act of personal volition. Jew, Provencal and Longuedocien were all citizens, and citizenship was nationality.
This, for the long-oppressed Jew, was deliverance. It opened avenues previously closed, and some led to the heart of power. Adolphe Cremieux, one of the first Jews to be a minister in a French government, held that a new Trinity had been created: God, the Revolution and the Republic of 1870. To these deities Jews owed their devotion.
Marc Bloch, the great French historian who was killed by the Nazis, declared, "The time of the Messiah came with the French Revolution." Before his execution, he declined the presence of a rabbi. "I will die as I lived," he said, "as a good Frenchman." For many, many years, even after Vichy, the peculiarity of Franco-Judaism was its intense patriotism.
But of course the Revolution was fiercely contested, and it divided France. Where the American Revolution ushered in a nation of citizens on relatively virgin soil, the French involved the destruction of an old order. As Toqueville remarked, Americans were lucky enough to be born equal, rather than having to become equal.
The French attempt to become equal was naturally a violent process. The effect of the Revolution, the historian Francois Furet once said, was to turn the French into "this strange people that cannot together like all their national history."
The old order was strongly represented in the Roman Catholic Church, and for the counterrevolutionaries it was natural to portray the forces out to destroy the Catholic soul of France in the name of secularism and egalitarianism as a collection of Jews, Protestants and Freemasons. In the trumped-up charges against Captain Alfred Dreyfus, the Angst of French society reached an apogee. The fact that Dreyfus, a Jew, had risen to represent a pillar of French tradition, the army, made the case explosive; for French anti-Semites, it showed that the danger was now within.
 
Revenge of Dreyfus
The cracks engendered by the Revolution never entirely disappeared, perhaps because they were not fully acknowledged. The rear-guard action continued to involve anti-Semitism. The Jew remained a potential proxy for all that was not traditionally French. For the influential writer Charles Maurras, Vichy was the "divine surprise," and his conviction for treason at the end of the war "the revenge of Dreyfus."
Of course, if three-fourths of France's Jewish population survived the war, it was precisely because many people rejected such attitudes and helped the Jews. Still, an easing of tensions after the war never involved a full accounting of what had happened under Vichy, and official attitudes to the Jews proved vulnerable to the politics of the Middle East. In a notorious phrase, de Gaulle, in 1967, called the Jews "an elite people, sure of itself and dominating."
The two sides of French society clung to their divisive myths: the church to its immaculacy, the Republic to the illusion that it had nothing to with Vichy's deportation to their deaths of 70,000 Jews.
Here, it seems, lies the critical importance of the events of the last few weeks. Both church and state have abandoned their pretensions. The church, by confessing to errors and begging the Jewish people for forgiveness, has adopted a position of striking modesty. It has, said Pierre Birnbaum, a sociologist, "Finally abandoned any notion that it represents some eternal France."
Similarly, after President Jacques Chirac's acknowledgment in 1995 that Vichy was the French state, the start of Mr. Papon's trial has exposed the human failings of the Republic. The fervent religion of republicanism -- one that many French Jews embraced -- has been dealt a blow, leaving more space for the reasoned embrace of republican values.
These changes, Mr. Birnbaum suggested, could herald a France with its old battles behind it, a more adaptable France shorn of its divisive myths. "Without quite embracing an American multiculturalism, we are turning toward a more pluralist model," he said. Certainly, a Jewish community invigorated by the arrival of large numbers of North African Jews has changed its attitudes: emancipation is no longer synonymous with the abandonment of Jewish traditions.
Resistance remains virulent. The National Front, with 15 percent of the vote, is now the third-largest party, and last week its paper, National Hebdo, bore the screaming headline "JUDAPO." This is the acronym the party uses for what it calls "politically organized Judaism," the malevolent force it sees behind the Papon trial and the bishops' statement of repentance.
The Front is the standard bearer of a new rightist coalition, bolstered by France's 3.6 million unemployed, if largely deserted by the church. Its central theme is an old one: the degeneration of France through the pollution of traditional values. That pollution, for the National Front, has many sources: Arab immigration, globalization, Jews and the like. But for now this force seems unlikely to outweigh the powerful tug of a millennial reconciliation of the old French demons.

HEADLINE: Not So Fast;
Speed Has Hit the Wall

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
ON an ancient, dry lake bed in Nevada last week, a British team broke the sound barrier on land, 50 years after Chuck Yeager first did it in a plane. Just for fun, General Yeager reprised his performance again last week, this time making a routine flight in an Air Force jet. Also last week, more than 100 million Americans got to work by car and more than 10 million others took airplane flights. But they didn't get there any faster than the week before, the year before or the decade before.
The experiment in the Nevada desert showed that science can develop the technology for greater speed. Less remarked upon is the fact that there is probably not the means to put it to practical use. On land, sea and air, for reasons of economy, ecology, safety and mundane factors like congestion, people are not moving any faster these days -- a departure from centuries of advances in the speed of everyday travel. 
 "It's neat that they did it," said Mark Edwards, the head of the safety department at the American Automobile Association, commenting on the British speed team. "But I don't think it makes any difference to the average American." In fact, he said, the speed record had lost some of its allure since racers started using jet engines instead of internal-combustion engines; he called the Thrust SSC, which set the record, "a military plane with the wings sawed off."
 
Slowing Down
Even though every now and then some whiz-bang technology lets someone break a speed record, ordinary vehicles are tending to move slower, in a reversal of a long trend.
Take ships. The Titanic was a marvel in 1912 partly because it cruised at 22 knots, about 24 miles per hour -- pretty swift for the time. Forty years later another passenger liner, the United States, crossed the North Atlantic (with considerably more success) at 36.8 knots. But the Queen Elizabeth 2, launched in 1969 after the speed derby had been lost to airplanes, was built to cruise at only 32 knots, and today passenger liners no longer race across the Atlantic. Pretty much the only big passenger ships afloat now are cruise ships, which amble from port to port at 14 to 18 knots. And hydrofoils -- the ballyhooed speedboats that ride just above the water at speeds of up to 40 knots -- seem to have gone the way of supersonic transports: there are some, but they haven't really caught on. Problems include cost and environmental considerations.
In the air, the costly Concorde, the only supersonic passenger plane, is a prime example of the speed versus practicality problem. Introduced in 1975 and capable of flying 1,336 miles per hour, it now appears to be at a technological and economic dead end. Beyond the national airlines of Britain and France, which built it, no other airline bought one, and it is not clear when anyone will build another supersonic plane. For a long time commercial planes went faster and faster. A benchmark was set in January 1970, when Pat Nixon christened the first Boeing 747 in commercial service; it could cruise at over 600 miles per hour. Now Boeing's new 777 usually flies at only about 500 miles per hour. That's plenty fast enough to keep up with traffic in the sky, which gets denser all the time.
Around the United States, many trains run slower now than they did 40 years ago because railroads decided to scrap expensive and complicated high-speed signaling equipment. Amtrak's metroliners reach 120 miles an hour between Washington and Boston, not much different from 40 years ago. Amtrak is trying to replace its Metroliners with American Flyers that will go 150, but the railroad's financial survival is not assured. Europe and Japan are still pushing trains to greater speeds, though.
 
Reaching the Limit
The question becomes: Are mere mortals pushing up against some kind of natural speed limit?
In the world of everyday travel, it would seem that way. Cars really can't go much faster (legally anyway) largely because of traffic and speed limits to insure people's safety. And every air traveler knows about airport congestion and delays -- the practical problems of getting from one place to another quickly.
With speed, the envelope isn't being pushed so much as it is being filled, with more people. Even if planes are not getting faster, the number of people riding in them is climbing rapidly. In this country, there will be almost 550 million passenger boardings this year, and the industry anticipates almost 830 million by 2008. It does not anticipate faster planes, though.
"I think speed has reached a limit," said Matthew Lynn, a British journalist and author of a recent aviation history, "Birds of Prey: Boeing vs. Airbus" (Four Walls Eight Windows, 1997). "The Concorde halved the journey time from London to New York from six hours to three hours, but the number of people prepared to pay for the extra hours was never that great.
"You could put the same argument to the supersonic car," he added. "If they could sell it to you, your journey time to your office might go from 1 hour to 4 minutes, and you'd pay something for that. I don't know what this car costs, but you wouldn't pay $2 million -- A, because you haven't got it, and B, wouldn't be worth it." Among other problems, he said, would be finding a road to drive it on.
In Washington, the Government is supporting a major push for improvements in cars, but these would be in fuel consumption, emissions and safety. Maintaining acceleration is on the list, but speed isn't.
There are some long-term long-shots, like "intelligent highways" where computer controls allow cars to travel bumper to bumper at 80 miles per hour. But don't hold your breath.
"That just sounds awful," said Ivan Amato, an expert on technology and author of another new book, "Stuff, The Materials the World is Made Of" (Basic Books, 1997). "There you are 10 yards behind and in front of some other car, or maybe 10 feet, and maybe you can get people up to 70 or 80 miles per hour." Then, he said, what happens when one car stops?
 
Virtual Travel
Still, some experts say that if cars could go 20 percent faster on highways, highways could handle 20 percent more cars, without adding any new lanes. It sounds as futuristic as, well, a supersonic car.
In some parts of Europe, of course, speed reigns. The Germans have some roads without speed limits, where a 175-mile-per-hour sports car can actually approach 175 miles per hour. But this is the exception, not the rule.
And even in Europe, there are moves to slow things down. This month the Swedish Parliament adopted "Vision Zero," a goal to eliminate road deaths. It calls for traffic humps and other devices to reduce speed, and lets local governments cut speed limits to 30 kilometers per hour (about 20 mph) from 50 kilometers per hour.
Some things go faster, of course. Runners, for example, are always breaking records. And an important factor making travel, and travel speed, less essential is ever-swift communications.
"I think technology has moved elsewhere, to computers," said Mr. Lynn. "You can now get from New York to a virtual London, and do that instantly."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Becoming Unstuck On the Suburbs

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
PLYWOOD has a lifespan of 40 years. Over time, the glue that holds plywood together dries up. Then, walls buckle, split and peel. Panels pop loose. Rooms, doors and windows morph into trick-or-treat versions of themselves. Suburban America, this is to say, is becoming unstuck.
Fifty years ago, the first Levittown opened in Hempstead, N.Y. A planned community of 17,000 identical houses, Levittown instantly became the prototype for the mass suburban development that would pour over the countryside in the decades to come, displacing pastures, potato fields and orange groves with affordable versions of the American dream. 
 Fifty minus 40 equals a nice round 10. The postwar suburban dream is now entering its second decade of physical obsolescence, and there's not much Martha Stewart can do about it. No wallpaper pattern, potpourri scent or colonial stencil can reverse the effect of passing time on the ranch houses, Cape Cods and saltboxes that millions of Americans have called home. What planners call the first-ring suburb, the belt of single-family houses built between 1947 and 1977 around metropolitan cores, is fast wearing out. But some planners believe that the recycling of the first ring is the key to determining the way that Americans will live in the next 50 years.
The social glue in these communities has also weakened. The population of the first ring is aging. The parents of the baby-boomers, the Depression Era generation that pioneered what the historian Kenneth T. Jackson called the crabgrass frontier, are long retired. Houses are not only physically decrepit; their designs are out of date. As recently as 1978, 79 percent of the residents in the first-ring suburbs of Minneapolis were members of one-job, two-parent nuclear families. By 1996, the proportion had declined to 28 percent. Zoning prevents the redesign of suburban houses and the subdivision of lots to meet the needs of the new population.
The relationship between suburb and city -- bedroom communities and urban workplaces -- has been eroded by edge cities, office parks, and second and third rings. This new suburban configuration is poorly served by public transportation. The commercial corridors that once linked housing, jobs, shopping and social services now connect mainly to car dealerships, fast food outlets, big box superstores and other overly identified flying objects of the free-floating American landscape.
New, poorer first-ring residents find it hard to gain access to a physically dispersed job market. The transition from an industrial to a service economy has undermined the security of the blue-collar middle class. In short, the first ring is in a state of emergency similar to that suffered by the cities suburbanites fled.
 
City to Suburbs: Drop Dead
No doubt many city dwellers would love to see that headline. After all, aren't suburbanites the people who left the city to rot? Who drained the city of middle-class stability? Who abandoned the public realm in pursuit of private gratification? Who cares if their ticky-tacky walls come tumbling down?
In fact, according to William Morrish, a professor of architecture at the University of Minnesota, the older center cities have a major stake in the future of the first ring. Mr. Morrish, director of the university's Design Center for Urban American Landscape, points out that 40 years ago, first-ring suburbs defined the metropolitan edge. Today, they have been repositioned from the edge to the middle. A deteriorating first ring gives investors and corporations one more reason to bypass cities altogether in favor of the second and third rings. Why jump into an even larger rotting core?
Moreover, the border separating the urban center from the first ring has become porous. Suburbanites fear the spread of crime and other social problems from the city, but the reverse can also happen. Rundown suburban communities can destabilize adjacent city neighborhoods. Inadequate schools and libraries can serve as a reverse magnet, propelling first-ring dwellers toward already overtaxed amenities in the city.
Thus far, the first ring's predicament has drawn scant official attention; it doesn't look as apocalyptic as inner-city blight. Buckling plywood may make an ideal subject for "This Old House," but not for the evening news. And there is a perception that Federal and state governments have already done too much for suburbs at cities' expense: Highways, mortgage programs, artificially low prices for gas.
In recent years, new ways of thinking have emerged to grapple with suburban development. The Congress for the New Urbanism, a group founded in 1993, has drawn nationwide attention for advocating compact communities composed of neo-traditional houses. Andres Duany and Elizabeth Plater-Zyberk, two of the group's founders, came to prominence with the planning of Seaside, an elite resort town on Florida's Gulf Coast.
The Congress has concentrated its energies more on improving the design of new suburban developments than on rehabilitating old ones. Still, its annual conferences have helped foster a corps of architects and planners who specialize in suburban redevelopment. And it has increased public awareness that the city has spread far beyond its historic 19th-century dimensions.
By contrast, the Design Center for American Urban Landscape has less faith in architectural esthetics. Physical solutions alone will not solve economic, social and political problems, Mr. Morrish says. With his wife, Catherine R. Brown, a landscape architect, he has developed an approach based on coordinating public policy, town planning and environmentally responsible design.
In 1995, the center embarked on a two-year project devoted to reversing first-ring decline. Sponsored by the McKnight Foundation of Minneapolis, the enterprise, Community Connections, has thus far focused on suburban communities encircling the Twin Cities. Next year, the group will sponsor the first national conference on first-ring issues.
Mr. Morrish and Ms. Brown begin with the assumption that the first ring confronts planners with an unprecedented historical condition. They believe it should be seen as a testing ground for new urban models. As an example, he points to the recycling of National Boulevard, a decayed industrial strip in Culver City, outside Los Angeles.
Over the the past decade, Frederick Smith, a developer, and Eric Owen Moss, a leading California architect, have gradually converted several large factory sheds into offices for graphic designers, movie makers and other media-related firms. The result is an impressive fusion of economic renewal, innovative design and cultural awareness. Factories left empty by the export of manufacturing were transformed into a lively boulevard of the informational city.
National Boulevard illustrates a basic principle of the Community Connections project: rejuvenating aging major commercial and transit corridors. It advocates relaxing zoning rules to allow greater density and to give homeowners more freedom to alter their houses. Community-based organizations, this thinking goes, should provide social services.
 
Counting on the Wives
There is an important cultural dimension to this group's work. That is the argument, implicit in much of the new thinking about suburban redevelopment, that the first-ring suburbs are trapped by cultural forces as well as by physical and economic ones. Their problems are hard to solve in part because many Americans prefer not to acknowledge that the cultural conditions that produced them no longer exist.
It is not an accident, for example, that the first ring is poor in mass transit and other services. In the postwar decades, the wife provided many of the services. She shopped, drove and helped organize community as well as domestic life. Her entrance into the work force deprived the suburbs of a key component of its basic infrastructure.
Yet it is deceptive to regard the one-job, two-parent nuclear family as traditional. As the political analyst Kevin Phillips documented in "Boiling Point" (Random House, 1993), the Levittown family was a historical aberration produced by postwar prosperity, a blip that lasted less than 30 years. Most 18th- and 19th-century wives worked, albeit often at farm chores rather than as part of the outside work force.
The suburbs lured millions of Americans into thinking they had found the new repository of American virtues. Half a century after Levittown, that dream is coming apart at the seams.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:

MERGERS
Another Suitor for MCI
Joining America's richest corporate takeover battle ever, the once-stodgy GTE, the nation's third-largest local telephone company, made an unsolicited $28 billion offer for MCI Communications. That's $2 billion less and two weeks later than a bid in stock from upstart Worldcom. The original suitor, British Telecommunications, with three board seats and 20 percent of MCI's shares, may now emerge as kingmaker... An Italian insurer, Generali, made a hostile $9 billion bid for AGF of France, and the Zurich Group agreed to take over B.A.T. Industries' insurance business, creating one of the world's biggest financial services companies....Is accounting's Big Six (only a few years ago it was Big Eight) about to become Big Four? Ernst & Young and KPMG Peat Marwick are expected to announce a merger, although neither would confirm it on Friday. Coopers & Lybrand and Price Waterhouse have already agreed to merge.
 
MARKETS
Earnings or Expectations?
It has become a mantra on Wall Street: the market is earnings-driven. Actually, it's greed-driven. Or, to put the matter more sophistically, is the existential question reality (earnings) or illusion (expectations thereof)? Compaq Computer reported a 41.6 percent profit increase on Thursday, topping the consensus forecast by 3 cents a share, but the market slashed 6 percent from its share price. The Street wanted more. Ford reached a 52-week high of $50.25 on Monday, beat forecasts with a 64 percent profit gain on Wednesday and saw its share price nibbled; G.M.also had solid earnings but slipped in price. Merck had a 19 percent increase but was a penny below estimates. Traders pushed its shares down 4.5 percent, and it helped grease the skids under the Dow, which finished the week at 7,847.03, off 198.17. Intel reported earnings of 88 cents a share, 3 cents below forecasts, and its shares, too, were pounded, despite news of an ultrafast microprocessor chip that it is developing with Hewlett-Packard. The Nasdaq composite lost 77.18 TK for the week, closing at 1,666.85. But the houses behind all this trading did well. Big profit gains were reported by Merrill Lynch, J. P. Morgan, Travelers, Bear Stearns and other Wall Street firms.
 
GOLDMAN, SACHS
Teachers for a Day
To be fair, some on Wall Street are taking time off from doing well to do good. Some 2,000 employees of Goldman, Sachs & Company, from secretaries through investment bankers, are serving as teachers for a day in New York City public schools. Besides giving lessons on basic business concepts, they hope to demonstrate to students that successful business people are not that different from them. Andy Derrow, above, skips rope in Inwood. "In a lot of these neighborhoods the most successful business person is the local drug dealer," said Peter Mertens, executive vice president of Junior Achievement of New York, which coordinates the volunteers.
 
NOBEL LAUREATES
A $1 Million Formula
Since the Bank of Sweden began awarding the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 1969, Americans have dominated the list of winners the way the Yankees once dominated the American League. This year Robert C. Merton, right, of the Harvard Business School and Myron S. Scholes, left, a Canadian-born professor emeritus at the Stanford Business School, will share the $1 million award for helping to devise a mathematical formula published in 1973 to answer a simple but seemingly insurmountable problem confronting Wall Street: how to measure the worth of an option? Their solution served as a foundation for today's vast global marketplace.
 
AUTOS
A Clean, Lean Machine
Toyota beat its rivals -- not only Nissan and Honda, but also Detroit's Big Three and Volkswagen -- in unveiling the world's first gasoline-electric hybrid car. Hiroshi Okuda, Toyota's president, climbs into the car, the Prius, which the company said got as much as 66 miles a gallon during test drives while emitting only half the carbon dioxide of a regular gasoline engine. It will sell for $17,700 in Japan -- a loss leader, since analysts estimate it costs $41,000 to produce each one. Consider the difference an advertising expenditure, they said, as Toyota cloaks itself in the mantle of environmental leader. It may be sold in the United States in about six months, Toyata said.
 
NEW ORLEANS
The House Goes Bust
New Orleans, whose unofficial motto is "let the good times roll," has rolled snake eyes. Casino gambling, legalized by the Louisiana Legislature in the early 1990's, was to sweeten the city's allure to tourists and challenge Las Vegas and Atlantic City for a piece of the action. But over the last three years, all three downtown riverboat casinos, including the Flamingo, above, have foundered on economic, regulatory and legal difficulties. The city's only land-based casino has folded, too. Analysts cited high taxes on the take -- 18.5 percent, compared with an average of 7 percent elsewhere -- as a chief problem. Hillary Crain, chairman of the State Gaming Control Board, called for "some creative financing."
 
THE ECONOMY
The Taming of Inflation
Retail sales rose three-tenths of 1 percent in September and were revised upward for July and August. That pushed down bond prices on Wednesday, but analysts contended that the gain masked an economy that was actually decelerating. Indeed, the Consumer Price Index for September edged up a less-than-expected two-tenths of 1 percent. Because of inflation's slowdown, Americans who receive Social Security and other Federal benefits will receive an increase of only 2.1 percent in January, the second-smallest since automatic cost-of-living adjustments began in 1975.
