HEADLINE: LEGACY OF THE '87 CRASH;
The Next Crash Foretold, or Maybe Not

 BODY:
When will the next crash come, and why? Here, from a game group of financial professionals and one layman, are some answers, including several that dispute the premise.
 
Burton G. Malkiel
Professor of Economics, Princeton University
 The next crash will occur for some unexpected reason. It could be Iran and Iraq go to war again and the supply of oil is curtailed, or there is a revolution in the former Soviet countries. I think it is basically unpredictable and the timing is unpredictable.
 What concerns me is hearing so many investors say the market's been going up 15 to 20 percent for years and therefore it will continue to go up. I also worry about that so-called New Era thing, that the business cycle has been repealed and we are in a new world where the old relationships don't hold. We said the same thing in 1929. I do not believe it is correct.
 
Byron R. Wien
Chief United States strategist, Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company
A crash could happen sometime, but I don't think it is likely to happen soon, and if it does it will be for different reasons than in 1987. A confluence of fundamental and technical factors led to that crash. The stock market was extraordinarily overvalued back then, interest rates were rising and we were just feeling our way with equity derivative products.
Today, the market is not as overvalued and we have learned a lot more about equity derivative products. An important culprit of the '87 crash, portfolio insurance, is no longer part of the mix. On a scale of 1 to 10, my level of concern about a crash is about a 3.
 
Harald B. Malmgren
President, the Malmgren Group, trade and financial consultants in Washington
A market correction of as much as 15 percent is possible. But then everyone will be back, chasing yield. That is so because the American economy, objectively, is by far the most attractive capital market in the world. The banking and manufacturing crises are behind the U.S. market. Interest rates are low. No other country or region has those fundamental positives. Japan is in bad shape. Southeast Asia has problems and Europe, which has very heavy social burdens, will have turbulence.
In addition, the populace of the advanced countries is getting older and the pension funds, be they public or private, are looking hard at how to raise yield. The pressure is greatest in Japan -- the source of about one-third of the world's savings and a country which has a huge percentage of that savings in fixed-income investments.
 
Edward Yardeni
Chief economist, Deutsche Morgan Grenfell
In 1999, there is an increasing likelihood of a 20 percent decline in stock prices, as investors become concerned about the year 2000 problem, in which many computer systems, if not fixed in time, will recognize 00 as 1900 rather than 2000.
This is a trivial yet overwhelming problem that is unlikely to be 100 percent repaired by 2000, and there are bound to be economic disruptions. No one can be certain if those will be relatively minor and uneventful, or serious enough to cause a recession.
 
Ron Chernow
Author, "The House of Morgan" and "The Death of the Banker"
The same bountiful cash that has buoyed the stock market and financed new technologies has also created a surplus of everything from espresso bars to giant bookstores. Within a year or two, we will be sated with miracle gadgets and will need time to digest the excess. So I worry about overcapacity and deflation more than resource shortages and rising wages.
Though I can picture a thunderous correction that might feel suspiciously like a crash, 'a la 1987, we are probably safe until the gluts translate into lower profits. A repeat of the 1929 crash is unlikely since so many investors are now prisoners of retirement plans and cannot desert financial assets for sustained periods.
 
James S. Chanos
President of Kynikos Associates, a money-management firm that specializes in short-selling
 A more important question than a crash is what might cause the next bear market. Crashes and panics are relatively short-term affairs, with lots of causes. The last traditional bear market was in 1990; people forget that it was occasioned by falling interest rates. I think we will have another bear market in our lifetime. The question is how bad it will be and how investors will handle themselves.
 
Thom Rogers
Software engineer in Denver
I'm not concerned. I subscribe to the view that things have improved so much with the global economy. There's a cachet to things American that didn't used to exist. There's a sense here that anything is possible.
Granted, I'm not old enough to remember '29, but excess lending went on then. And I just don't see other alternatives. If you're a guy like me, 40 to 45 years old, you're not going to put your money in the bank.
 
G. Kenneth Heebner
Manager of the CGM Capital Development fund, one of the best-performing stock funds of 1987.
If we have a big market decline, it will happen slowly, not suddenly like it did in 1987. Since then, confidence has grown enormously that stock prices will always bounce back. The depth of that conviction will not be destroyed in a short period of time.
In the last big market decline, it took five years, from 1969 to 1974, for the mood to go from euphoria to despair. Plus, we've now set up a whole new industry of investment advisers, which has created a process of looking at Morningstar reports and selecting a five-star fund. That has given mutual fund investors a perception of safety and protection -- which, in reality, isn't there.
 
Richard C. Breeden
Former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission
For the average person, those of us who are not Alan Greenspan, we can't expect that we're going to spot the trigger of a potential problem. So I shouldn't invest more than I am capable of losing or having become illiquid. The question is: Can you ride through? Can you pay the rent, keep food on the table, send your kids to college? The question to ask yourself is: If the market did shut down, would I be all right?

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thom Rogers, a software engineer in Denver, does not believe a crash as serious as 1987's is likely to occur again. (Kevin Moloney for The New York Times)
 
Graphs: "Then and Now"
Since 1987, the financial world has changed immensely, and not at all. Graphs show statistical snapshots.
 
THE STOCK MARKET
Traditional yardsticks that said stocks were overpriced in 1987 have been left even further behind in 1997; trading is busier than ever.
 
ON WALL STREET
Stock offerings have kept pace with the bull market; mergers and acquisitions have grown faster, though paying for them with junk bonds is less common.
 
MUTUAL FUNDS
The number of funds has tripled and their assets have quintupled; most of the money is now in equities.
 
ON MAIN STREET
Unemployment and inflation are lower and households now have nearly twice as much of their wealth in stocks.
 
INTEREST RATES
Inflation seems a more distant threat in 1997 than it did in 1987; interest rates are lower, and bond yields include smaller premiums for inflation risk.

HEADLINE: In America;
Days of Terror

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The bonfire was symbolic, as was the noose that dangled from a lower limb of the willow oak outside 29 East Fourth Street in the East Village. The film maker Ric Burns was shooting a scene for his 10-hour PBS documentary history of New York City. The events symbolized by the fire and the noose, collectively known as the draft riots, took place in July 1863. It was a period of panic and terror that is difficult to imagine today.
The story is not well known. Historians and other chroniclers tend to give it a nod and move on. It's as if the city were still ashamed. 
 "It was the largest civil insurrection in American history other than the South's rebellion," said Eric Foner, the DeWitt Clinton Professor of History at Columbia University.
The rioting began on July 13, a hot and muggy Monday morning. Enormous crowds, enraged by the wartime draft imposed by the Lincoln Administration, surged through several neighborhoods in Manhattan, heading at various times toward Central Park and the draft board offices at Third Avenue and 46th Street and Broadway and 29th Street. The people in the crowds were mostly poor and mostly Irish and they carried with them a long litany of resentments.
The war had already driven prices up and wages had not kept pace. Moreover, the Army had broken strikes in New York City just a year earlier. Abraham Lincoln was not seen as a friend of the economically distressed immigrants and sons of immigrants who were now subject to the draft. They saw no reason to fight and possibly die in a war that they assumed would result in tremendous numbers of Negroes being freed and coming North to compete with poor Irish immigrants for jobs.
Men could legally avoid the draft by paying a fee of $300. But that was not an option for workers with families who were lucky to make $500 in a year. The existence of the fee only fueled the resentment of the poor.
More and more people, men, women and children, took to the streets that Monday morning. The rhetoric and the passions escalated and at some point the crowds went wild.
Certain types of people were subject to attack on sight. They included police officers, known Republicans, anyone who looked prosperous and, especially, Negroes. Mobs went from house to house, pillaging and burning. The Colored Orphan Asylum at Fifth Avenue and 43d Street was invaded and the children were driven out. One of the orphans, 10-year-old Jane Barry, was killed when a bureau dropped from the window of an upper floor landed on her head.
While many people were murdered, the atrocities committed against blacks during the four days of rioting were at least as grotesque as anything that ever emanated from the Deep South. A disabled black coachman named Abraham Franklin was dragged from his home by a mob and hanged from a lamppost. "In a grisly denouement," wrote Iver Bernstein in his 1990 book, "The New York City Draft Riots," "16-year-old Irishman Patrick Butler dragged Mr. Franklin's body through the streets by the genitals as the crowd applauded."
Mr. Bernstein added: "After yet another hanging . . . rioters cut off their black victim's fingers and toes."
No one knows how many people were lynched. Maybe 15, 18, a couple of dozen. William Jones was hanged from a tree on Clarkson Street. Then a fire was set beneath the body so the leaping flames could burn his flesh.
Other blacks were forced into rivers and drowned.
The rioting raged out of control until Thursday. Police officers, in some cases armed only with sticks and clubs, fought several desperate battles with mobs that at times numbered in the thousands.
"New York was tipping toward anarchy," said Mr. Burns, who is making the documentary with a colleague, Lisa Ades. "There was a real question whether it was possible to maintain order in a humane way."
More than 100 people were killed and some estimates put the toll at 1,000 or more. Many thousands were injured. Whole neighborhoods were destroyed. Order was not restored until Federal troops that had been called back from Gettysburg took command of the streets.
The most lasting lesson of the draft riots was a fundamental one. The middle and upper classes, shaken and appalled, vowed never again to allow the city to spiral so far out of control. That led to the beginning of modern law enforcement in New York.

HEADLINE: Libya Is Reported to Lobby to Settle Pan Am Explosion Case

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Apparently encouraged by African and Asian support for its campaign to have United Nations sanctions lifted, Libya is lobbying the families of people killed in the explosion of a Pan Am jet over Scotland in 1988 in the hope of persuading them to settle the case, the mother of one victim says.
Libya has been under limited sanctions forbidding international air traffic in or out of the North African country because it has refused to turn over for trial in Scotland two Libyan suspects the United States and Britain want to see tried. 
 Susan Cohen, the mother of Theodora Cohen, who was 20 when Flight 103 exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland, said in an interview that families in the United States received a letter early this month from Libya's United Nations representative drawing attention to speeches made in support of his country in this fall's General Assembly debate.
The letter said that only Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Foreign Secretary Robin Cook of Britain objected in speeches to Libya's request to have the sanctions lifted before the suspects are extradited.
Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, has made various offers over the years, most recently agreeing to have the two tried under Scottish law and by Scottish judges -- but not in Scotland. He has suggested a trial in a third country, or at the International Court of Justice. Britain and the United States have rejected the offer. This week, Libyans have been in The Hague, arguing that the International Court should take over the case.
Libya has been accused of being behind not only the destruction of Pan Am 103, with the loss of 270 lives, but also the explosion that destroyed a French airliner over Niger in 1989, in which 171 people died.
Mrs. Cohen, who lives in Cape May Courthouse, N.J., said families of the Lockerbie victims were divided about how to keep their campaign alive, with some relatives urging others to accept compensation from the Libyans. She said a group of lawyers has been asking American families to settle out of court.
A similar offer is making some headway in Britain, she said, as is backing for Libya's plan to hold a trial in a third country.
"I am very worried about this," Mrs. Cohen said. "I don't want Qaddafi to get away with a payoff. My life's been destroyed by this."
Some families have filed a civil suit hoping to settle with the Libyan Government. But Libya's main purpose in lobbying the families is to get their agreement for a trial outside of Scotland, which would open the way to removing the sanctions.
Recently, the Arab League and the Organization of African Unity adopted positions sympathetic to Libya. Many diplomats are convinced that enthusiasm for continuing sanctions has been steadily waning.
President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, current chairman of the Organization of African Unity, told the General Assembly in his speech that the settlement of the Lockerbie case and the lifting of sanctions were of great concern to Africans.
"In addition to the families of those who lost their lives, many other innocent third persons continue to suffer as a result of the sanctions imposed on Libya," Mr. Mugabe said.
A debate over the high human cost of sanctions, particularly prolonged sanctions, has been steadily building at the United Nations. Relief organizations are most concerned about Iraq, which has been under a comprehensive embargo since 1990, with no relief in sight.

HEADLINE: Best-Paid College Leader Is at Northeastern U.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
When John A. Curry resigned as president of Northeastern University last year, he received $711,358 in an early-retirement and severance package in addition to his base salary of $284,000. The total of $995,358 made him the most highly paid college president in the nation in the 1995-1996 academic year, according to an annual survey of private colleges and universities conducted by The Chronicle of Higher Education.
The next most highly paid executive, Joe B. Wyatt, who is the chancellor of Vanderbilt University, received $479,072. Seven other presidents received more than $400,000. 
 The 22-page survey of pay and benefits is based on data gathered from Federal tax returns filed by 477 of the nation's leading institutions of higher education. It will appear in the issue dated Oct. 24, due out on Monday.
The tax returns studied were the latest available.
Dr. Curry declined to be interviewed, but George F. Matthews, chairman of Northeastern's board of trustees, said that Dr. Curry's large compensation was a one-time event and reflected "his absolutely sensational 35-year career at Northeastern."
"He nearly doubled our endowment, pushed student S.A.T. scores up more than 80 points, oversaw a $100 million building program and greened the campus, which won an award from Barbara Bush as one of the best-looking urban campuses," Mr. Matthews said. "If he had done that in the business world, his compensation would have been a lot more."
Janet Hookailo, a spokeswoman for Northeastern, said that the breakdown of Dr. Curry's benefits package included a $295,000 buyout of a five-year teaching contract and a $100,000 bonus for "exemplary service," recommended by the school's trustees.
Northeastern, in Boston, has 11,000 full-time undergraduate students, mostly from the Boston area, but it has more than twice that number counting part-time students, as well. Tuition, fees, room and board amount to $20,468.
Michael Schoenfeld, a spokesman for Vanderbilt, in Nashville, said that Dr. Wyatt's compensation reflected the facts that under his leadership the university's endowment grew to $1.3 billion from $200 million, that academic programs have "risen dramatically in quality" and that Dr. Wyatt's 15-year tenure makes him one of the most senior of the leaders of major research universities in the nation.
Dr. Peter Diamandopoulos of Adelphi appeared near the top of the list because he was still active, and highly paid, at $421,070, as the president of Adelphi University in the 1995-96 academic year. He and the trustees of Adelphi were dismissed by the New York State Board of Regents in February.
A spokeswoman for Hofstra University, Valarie Zurblis, said that Dr. James M. Shuart's benefits had been unusually high, $411,922, because they included a deferred compensation package intended to go into effect when he retired at 65. But the school's trustees persuaded Dr. Shuart not to retire and therefore he received two sources of income in the 1995-97 academic year.
Kevin Cox, a spokesman for Wake Forest University, in Winston-Salem, N.C., said that Dr. Thomas K. Hearn Jr.'s salary and benefits, $447,748, had been justified by the trustees because he must oversee not only the undergraduate college but also graduate programs, the business school, the law school, the medical school and plans for a divinity school scheduled to open in 1999.
Scott Jaschik, deputy managing editor of the weekly newspaper for academicians, said that Form 990, the Internal Revenue Service form used in the study, might not provide a complete picture of compensation at private colleges because some institutions may have found ways to hide parts of the money or benefits that they give their chief executives.
"These forms are the best possible source of information we have, but of course it's not perfect," Mr. Jaschik said.
The average total pay and benefits for presidents of research universities was $333,239. It was $176,482 at doctorate-granting universities, and $170,180 at baccalaureate institutions.
About half of the nearly 400 presidents who worked full years in the 1995-96 academic year had pay increases of at least 4 percent while the national rate of inflation was 2.8 percent.
Presidents were not the most highly paid professionals in academe. Seven professors of medicine reported pay and benefits of more than $1 million, and another dozen professors of medicine earned more than $800,000.
Coaches and athletic directors were also highly paid. The top earner was John Robinson, head football coach at the University of Southern California, who was paid $484,250 in salary and $20,766 in benefits.

HEADLINE: Argentina Backs U.S. In Restricting Global Gases

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: NAHUEL HUAPI NATIONAL PARK, Argentina, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Framed by the ancient Patagonian wilderness, President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina appeared with President Clinton here today to endorse Mr. Clinton's call for developing nations to join developed ones in restricting gases that contribute to global warming.
Under pressure at home and abroad to address global warming, Mr. Clinton is seeking to negotiate binding limits on emissions for all countries, including developing ones. Many of those countries say industrialized countries that have benefited most from polluting should bear the costs of addressing it. 
 Mr. Menem declared "we agree with the United States when you say that a global problem such as climate change requires a global answer, coming from all countries."
But he also made clear that he expected the United States, the world's leader in emitting greenhouse gases, to bear the greatest burdens. Unless the United States takes on "the greatest of responsibilities," he said, "any achievement arrived at will be of short duration or not deep enough."
After rarely addressing the issue in his first term, Mr. Clinton began to sound an alarm over the summer that climate change could cause flooding, drought and outbreaks of disease. He is preparing for a December conference in Japan at which more than 150 nations plan to negotiate over reducing greenhouse gases. Talks to prepare for that meeting are to begin in Germany on Monday.
Mr. Clinton is seeking what he calls "realistic and binding" limits for greenhouse gas emissions by all nations. But he has not completed his proposal on limits, and it is far from clear what mechanism he would want -- or what Mr. Menem, or any other leader, might accept -- to enforce such restrictions. Mr. Clinton plans to announce his emissions proposal later this week.
During the announcement by the two Presidents today in this remote and stunning park, pollution seemed a distant problem. As they stood on a hillside here, a blue wrinkled lake stretched away behind them and all around stood iron-gray Andean crags, joined by razorback ridges and surmounted by snow.
The two countries agreed to enact "joint implementation," under which a company in one of the countries can receive credits for reducing emissions by helping a company in the other to cut greenhouse gases. The program is intended to speed the spread of effective environmental technologies to developing countries.
In his remarks today, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that industrialized countries produce most greenhouse gases, although industrial groups and some scientists argue that uncertainty about the climate justifies the delaying action on . "But emissions from the developing world are expected to grow dramatically," he said. "Forty years from now, they will exceed those of developed countries."
Mr. Clinton's aides said that they regard Argentina as a developing nation. But because it is one of the most industrialized Latin American countries, with a high per-capita income, the aides said Argentina was particularly attractive as a partner in emissions control.
"These are precisely the guys we need to get," said one senior White House aide. "We don't need the desperately poor countries."
Mr. Clinton planned to fly home overnight tonight after his weeklong Latin American trip, devoted primarily to promoting his goals for free trade in the hemisphere. He has also spoken regularly about global warming. Brazil and Venezuela, the other countries he visited, have not yet agreed to a declaration like the one issued here today.
Jim Steinberg, Mr. Clinton's deputy national security adviser, praised Argentina's move as a "concrete commitment to the idea there should be emissions limits."
He acknowledged that no mechanism was spelled out for enforcing any limits but said "it would not be meaningful, in our view, unless there were some assurances" that the limits would be met.
Industrial groups and some scientists argue that uncertainty about the climate justifies delaying action on such limits.
Five years ago, at an environmental summit in Rio de Janeiro, the United States and other industrialized nations agreed to reduce their emissions to 1990 levels by the year 2000. But most now acknowledge that they will not achieve that goal, and the United States is projected to be 13 percent above it.
To the dismay of environmentalists, some of Mr. Clinton's economic and environmental aides have urged him to delay until the year 2010 or beyond any deep reductions in pollution. By contrast, European nations, who would have an easier time restricting their emissions, have proposed reductions of 15 percent below 1990 levels by 2010.

HEADLINE: ANALYSTS EXPECT HEALTH PREMIUMS TO RISE SHARPLY

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
After four years of near stability brought about by the spread of managed care, the premiums that most Americans pay for their health insurance are poised to rise significantly next year, industry groups and health care consultants report.
Many say the average charge for health benefits, deducted from paychecks, will go up at least 5 percent, or more than twice as much as wages and inflation have been rising. For very large employers with great negotiating clout, the increases could be smaller, they say. Such companies in California, for example, appear to be holding the line at 1 percent. But across the nation, at some small companies with older and illness-prone employees, analysts say, the premiums might rise as much as 30 percent. 
 "We're finding about a 5 to 10 percent increase across the board with our renewal rates" for managed care plans, said Mark Psleger, director of marketing for the Blue Cross Blue Shield Association in Chicago, which represents the nation's Blue Cross companies.
"I'm sorry; it's going to happen," said John C. Erb, a principal of the William M. Mercer benefits consulting firm who surveys employers on health care trends. Mr. Erb, who is based in Miami, said he had three large clients in the area. One negotiated a health benefit increase from its insurance company of 3.5 percent. "But one had 12 percent," he said, "and the other had about 6."
Chris Jennings, President Clinton's chief White House health care adviser, said: "Do I expect premiums to go up at a higher rate than in the last few years? The answer is probably yes."
But with most private industry contracts still being negotiated, with the economic impact hard to discern as yet and with costs stable in two big Government health insurance programs -- Medicare for the elderly and Medicaid for the poor -- Mr. Jennings said he did not yet see grounds for Government complaint or intervention.
Most experts doubt that the 1998 increases portend an explosion in premiums like that of the 1980's and early 1990's, which was driven by surging hospital and doctor fees. That led to Mr. Clinton's failed effort to overhaul the health care system, and to the proliferation of managed care plans that have achieved most of the cost savings that were one of the President's goals.
Many health industry analysts expected significant increases this year, too, as insurance companies and managed care organizations began trying to raise premiums to recapture profits that they were losing after they froze or cut premiums in the intensely competitive market for patients and their employers. And they had predicted that medical costs would increase by 5 to 10 percent in 1998, increasing the pressure to raise premiums.
But in contract negotiations this year, employers resisted the pressure. Thus, the average premium has risen just 2.1 percent this year, said Jon Gabel, director of the Center for Survey Research at KPMG Peat Marwick, a large accounting and consulting firm.
"But they underpriced their products," Mr. Gabel said. "They ran out of profits. And now they're trying to catch up."
This fall, one giant, often trend-setting employer, the Federal Government, agreed to substantial increases for the first time in five years. Nine million Federal employees, retirees and family members, from members of Congress to park rangers, are covered by contracts negotiated by the Office of Personnel Management. Under the 1998 contracts that the office signed last month, Federal employees face an average 8.5 percent increase under the 350 health plans covering them.
Because of the formula used to allocate payment of the premium, many employees will actually pay about 15 percent more each month, though still somewhat less than most private industry workers with equivalent coverage. The Government, which, like most employers, shares the cost of health insurance with its workers, will pay 6 percent more.
As a result, Federal workers who insure only themselves will see an average charge of $27.74, up from $24.42, for health care in their twice-monthly paychecks next year, an increase of 14 percent. The average charge for family coverage will rise 16 percent, from $54.15 to $62.79.
What is also driving the increase is an underlying 6 or 7 percent annual rise in medical cost inflation, a result of new technology and an aging population, said Edward Flynn, the personnel office's associate director for retirement and insurance.
Managed care programs helped purge the health care system of cost increases exceeding medical inflation, he said. "But there's a point at which the big gains from managed care begin to diminish," he said, and future gains will be much smaller. "All employers are going to face the same things we have this year," he said, "and I don't think they will be as successful as we have been."
Indeed, managed care groups can be expected to invoke the contracts they worked out for Federal employees in negotiations with private industry. "That program's a bellwether of what we'll see in rates," said Kate Paul, president of the Rocky Mountain division of Kaiser Permanente, a part of the nation's largest health maintenance organization.
The parent Kaiser Foundation Health Plan and Hospitals has said it will lose money this year for the first time in its 50 years in business. Many other health care organizations and major insurance companies like Aetna, the Cigna Corporation and the Prudential Insurance Company of America are suffering losses this year or acute erosion of their profits.
The dynamics of the marketplace have shifted in other ways. In many communities, the fierce competition for customers has driven out some contenders, leaving those remaining freer to seek higher rates.
Meanwhile, doctors and hospitals, once pressed by insurers and health maintenance organizations to cut charges and fees if they wanted to participate in the organizations' programs and keep their patients, are now uniting into stronger bargaining groups. "They're not stupid," Mr. Erb of the Mercer firm said.
In addition, employees are demanding more choice in their health plans. In a reaction against the closed system of a health maintenance organization, in which patients make appointments with a "gatekeeper" doctor who can refer them only to specialists within the network, employees are choosing more open preferred-provider organizations and point-of-service plans that let them bypass gatekeepers and seek out specialists anywhere.
Greater choice also involves higher costs. Tom Bowser, executive vice president of Blue Cross Blue Shield of Kansas City, predicts increases of 5 to 8 percent for H.M.O. members, but 9 to 12 percent for preferred provider organizations. For very small programs with disproportionately high numbers of chronically sick members, he predicts increases exceeding 30 percent.
Only the largest employers, and those in cities where competition for customers remains fierce, are expecting lower increases than the 5 percent or more that most face.

Danube's Vast Wetlands Are Being Restored
At the immense delta of the Danube River, engineers from several countries are trying to reverse one of the biggest land-grabs in recent history, when the previous Romanian Government tried to turn wetlands into farmland. They have punched gaps in dikes and dams and begun to let the river spill back over the land. 1
 
Cuban Pitches in World Series
Cubans are thrilled by the exploits of Livan Hernandez, the 22-year-old who defected two years ago and now is a starter for the Florida Marlins in the World Series. Politics aside, he shows "the high quality of Cuban baseball," exulted one fan. 1
 
Bittersweet Opening in Spain
An acclaimed Guggenheim Museum opens today in Bilbao, Spain, but the festivities grew somber after terrorists killed a policeman. 8

Argentina's President endorsed joint restrictions on both developed and developing countries to prevent global warming. But he told President Clinton that the United States should bear the greatest burdens. 13

Interest Groups Join Debate

HEADLINE: RACE FOR CITY HALL: The Republican Candidate;
A Mercurial Mayor's Confident Journey

BYLINE: By BARRY BEARAK and IAN FISHER 

 BODY:
There he is in the photos, aflame with conviction and heady with success: class president, editor on the law review, bold young prosecutor, No. 3 man at the Justice Department, crime-fighting United States Attorney, archenemy of the Mafia, the 107th Mayor of the City of New York. Quite a run!
And now, working from City Hall, Rudolph William Giuliani, 53, has become New York's one ubiquitous figure, hurrying from a burned-out building to a subway derailment to the bedside of a wounded police officer. He is Gotham's action hero, self-cast as the take-charge guy who is reliably among the first at every scene. 
 By most reckonings, including those of many adversaries, Mr. Giuliani has coupled this celebrity with effective leadership. A seemingly ungovernable city now seems responsive to discipline, its crime rate in a plunge, its tourist-stocked streets palpably safer.
Still, however many his accomplishments, there is something else striking about the Mayor: his temperament. He seems to believe in mayoral infallibility, at least so long as he is the Mayor. To question his righteousness is to risk his wrath. A devil's advocate often seems regarded as the devil himself.
Rudy Giuliani has been described as the best and worst of New York, combining its exceptional talent and its ruthless energy.
This makes for a strange set of paradoxes, for some of Mr. Giuliani's strengths are his weaknesses as well. The adept and decisive manager can be imperious, to the point where surveys show his manner to be his greatest political liability. The candidate who, according to polls, seems headed to an overpowering victory on Nov. 4, can unleash attacks on his opponent that verge on fury. The man with a clear vision of a safer, more livable city can be disdainful of even well-intentioned critics.
"He is a good mayor, but he'll never be a great one," said Edward I. Koch, once a committed ally who now says he will vote for him with a reluctant pull of the lever.
"He can't accept disagreement," Mr. Koch said. "When it occurs, he wants to destroy you. He goes for the jugular."
Despite -- or perhaps because of -- these contradictions, Mr. Giuliani has risen to become the city's most important politician of his generation, a nationally known figure with larger political aspirations.
To understand Mr. Giuliani's rise to City Hall, it helps to have a map of his boyhood and earlier career. Signposts include a Roman Catholic education, doting parents and prominent mentors. Directions come from schoolmates, teachers and colleagues.
The Mayor himself was a grudging participant in this article. For two months, his press office pledged cooperation only to withhold it.
Finally, just before publication, the Mayor agreed to be interviewed. He attributed his wariness to recent articles in several newspapers and magazines about rumors of an extramarital affair, which he has strongly denied. He also complained about what he called unfair political coverage in The New York Times.
Seated in a comfortable armchair in his office, however, the Mayor seemed relaxed and genial. He said he knew all too well that people thought he was harsh and overbearing. But at least on this occasion, such characterizations made him laugh.
"I've been accused of storming out of press conferences that I'd been at for 45 minutes," he said with a chuckle. "Maybe I just had to leave. Maybe I had to go to the bathroom. So I would say, 'That's the last question,' and walk out. The next day it would be written that I stormed out, or that I was bristling. It fits the stereotype."
Anyway, the perception often works to his advantage, the Mayor added, because when people meet him, they say, ' "Oh my God, he's very different from what I thought.' "
 
Parents
Strong Convictions And Early Instruction
A grandson of Italian immigrants, Rudy Giuliani grew up in richly Catholic surroundings, before Vatican II, with meatless Fridays and the mysteries of the Latin Mass. Goodness, he was taught, required diligence. And his teachers say that young Rudy, more than most, was hard-working and intellectually keen.
Immigrant struggle was a staple of family lore. His father, Harold, traced his roots to Florence and nearby Montecatini, and his mother, Helen, to Avellino and other towns near Naples. Their stories were many because their families were big.
Harold and Helen wanted a large family of their own, but year after year they were disappointed. Friends say that on May 28, 1944, when the Giulianis' only child was born, they considered him a miracle baby, a blessing born of prayer.
Harold and Helen took Rudy home to East Flatbush, Brooklyn. Harold supported his family by tending bar at a place he owned with a brother-in-law, near Kings County Hospital.
At home, Rudy grew up under the instructive hand of his parents and his maternal grandmother. Helen, according to her son, had excelled in high school and been a spelling champion. Her dream had been to be a teacher, but her chance at higher education was frustrated by financial difficulties and, later, the demands of motherhood.
Her son would be her only pupil. Biographies and history books were Helen's selections for reading aloud, even when Rudy was a toddler. Must-see TV included political conventions and the Kefauver hearings on organized crime.
Unlike her husband, Helen was a Republican, though she would switch over to the Democrats with the rise of that wonderful young Catholic, John F. Kennedy.
Of the two, Harold Giuliani, who died of cancer 16 years ago, was more of a churchgoer, attending Mass every week, his son said. Harold suffered bad eyesight and a weak heart. Tending bar did not fulfill the promise of his sharp mind.
"My father wasn't terribly successful, but he had no bitterness," the Mayor said, pausing for an afterthought: perhaps his father's need for achievement "was sort of pushed into me."
Harold was a forceful, gregarious person who had many friends, though Vincent Noce, whose father owned a funeral parlor near Harold's bar, also recalls a moody man whose smarts often inflated into arrogance.
During summers, with doors open and a huge fan blowing, the sound of Harold's voice blustered into the street. "If you were walking by the bar," Mr. Noce said, "you could hear him yelling, telling people, 'You don't know what the hell you're talking about!' "
The Mayor extols his father's warmth and generosity while also recalling an extremely direct man whose temper was sometimes the tripwire to unpredictable explosions.
Many of Harold's convictions were unshakable. Among those beliefs, the Mayor said, were a love of the Yankees -- bold for a bartender in Dodgers territory -- and a hatred of the Mafia, which gave Italian-Americans a bad name.
Harold also believed that life provided a continual series of tests -- of character, of friendship, of respect.
These tests occurred during times of tragedy and need. A real sign of friendship, the Mayor quoted his father as saying, is showing up "at wakes and funerals, not at weddings."
"At a wedding everyone is joyous. They don't need you."
 
School
A Quick Study Flirts With the Priesthood
Peter J. Powers, the Mayor's friend since high school and until August 1996 his first deputy, commends Mr. Giuliani's "incredible ability to assess a situation." Mr. Powers first observed it, he said, during their senior class trip to Washington. One night, he, Rudy and several others began a carpet-sopping water fight in their hotel. The manager, furious, ordered them to pack up and be downstairs in 10 minutes.
"Most of us were scared silly," Mr. Powers recalled. "We thought we'd get kicked out of school, never graduate. But Rudy just said, 'He's bluffing, and I'm going to bed.' And Rudy was right."
They attended Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School in Brooklyn, run by the De La Salle Christian Brothers. Each parish in Queens and Brooklyn and on Long Island could send only two of its best male students.
For Rudy, the commute to Loughlin required a tedious ride on the Long Island Rail Road. When he was 7, his parents had joined the exodus to suburbia, first to Garden City, then to a split-level in North Bellmore.
Most of the enrollment at Loughlin came from working-class families -- Irish, Italian, Polish -- and nearly all went on to college. It was a rare chance for the sons of blue collars to be like those of blue bloods, good boys with good educations headed for good things.
"We thought he was going to become a priest," said a North Bellmore neighbor, Ray Jacobelli.
So did Rudy. Priests, brothers and nuns were so much a part of growing up Catholic that many young men and women felt the pull of a religious calling.
Indeed, at Loughlin, the air itself seemed consecrated. Each class began with a prayer: "Let us remember that we are in the holy presence of God."
Rudy thrived. "He was a bright kid, on the honor roll, a rather charming kind of person," said Brother Peter Bonventre, a school administrator. Fellow students recall his mischievous humor -- he could be quite the cutup. But some also thought him an oddball -- enthralled by the Kennedy family and so in love with opera that he started an opera club.
Rudy's best friends, Mr. Powers and Alan Placa, were club recruits, sharing in the world of Verdi and Puccini. The students would also double-date, their brotherly companionship often more important than the young women.
"After we'd drop off the girls, Rudy and I would spend hours in the car or walking down the sidewalks, debating ideas: religion, the problems of the world, what we wanted to be," Mr. Placa said. Similarly, Mr. Powers recalled he and Rudy abandoning their dates in the living room while the two of them talked current events in the kitchen with Helen Giuliani.
Weekends were often spent near an idyllic cliffside off Sound Beach, at a cottage rented by Rudy's grandmother. Aunts, uncles and cousins frequently spent the night. Suppers brought everyone together, with talk of politics as much a part of mealtime as the pasta.
The summer of 1961 would bring another topic to the table: Come fall, would Rudy go to college, pursuing vague plans to become a doctor, or to the seminary, to prepare for life as a missionary?
His parents had a preference. "The Giulianis wanted grandchildren," Mr. Jacobelli recalled.
Rudy did not quite decide, enrolling at Manhattan College while still pondering the priesthood. His mind would teeter back and forth during the next four years, he said: Was God truly summoning him?
Not until he began law school did he finally rule it out. "The priesthood is a vocation," the Mayor remembered, "and I probably didn't have it. I probably just thought I had it."
Like most young men, he was feeling a hormonal calling as well. "I had dated and enjoyed it," he said.
The choice would probably have been different "if the priesthood had encompassed marriage."
Manhattan College, in the Bronx, had much in common with Loughlin. It was all male, overwhelmingly white and run by the Christian Brothers. Mr. Powers and Mr. Placa were at Mr. Giuliani's side.
Mr. Giuliani majored in political science and minored in philosophy. He relied more on a good memory than a quick pencil, a former classmate, B. J. Leddy, said: "He would sit back and make a note or two. He was so self-collected. He knew what would be demanded in the end."
Doctor, lawyer, priest, pilot, journalist: he considered all of these careers. Once, Mr. Giuliani said, he and Mr. Placa even thought of getting Ph.D.'s and becoming "practicing philosophers," hanging out a shingle and "just sitting somewhere, developing ideas and thoughts."
A political career, the Mayor said, was not often on his mind, "like fourth of fifth on the list." Nevertheless, he ran for his first office, winning the sophomore class presidency. He lost the following year, and his main extracurricular interest shifted to Phi Rho Pi, his fraternity.
Manhattan College was a commuter school, and none of its fraternities had a house. Still, the groups were a good way to make lasting friendships. Mr. Giuliani had first pledged to high-status Alpha Sigma Beta, but he hated the hazing, especially "getting beat up with a paddle."
So he approached Phi Rho Pi, which had only a few members. They welcomed him and several of his buddies, agreeing to go easy on the humiliations.
Mr. Giuliani was a commanding figure at meetings, with "a sense of standing, a sureness about what is right," said a fraternity brother, Thomas Hefele.
As Phi Rho Pi grew, a rift opened. Sal Scarpato was the leader of a more boisterous faction that wanted more raucous parties, more tormenting of pledges. Mr. Giuliani was the champion of the better-mannered. They ran against each other for the presidency, and Mr. Giuliani won.
Mr. Scarpato said that before the vote, he got a very unexpected phone call from Harold Giuliani. As he remembered it: "Rudy's father took the liberty of asking me to withdraw from the election.
"He said it was more important for Rudy to be the fraternity president, more important because Rudy was someone going places."
 
A Law Career
The Inquisitor Makes The Front Page
In 1965, Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Powers enrolled at New York University Law School. "I went in with the mental attitude that if I enjoy it, I'm going to stay," the Mayor said. "If I don't, I'm going to leave, get a master's degree in history or something."
But he was quickly smitten with torts, contracts and the rest. The courses stimulated his highly rational mind, the Mayor said. He excelled, making the law review.
Irving Younger was Mr. Giuliani's faculty adviser. The two opera lovers would retreat to the professor's office and listen to an aria while Mr. Younger reminisced about his days as a prosecutor. He made it sound as if no life was complete without a stint as an assistant United States attorney.
Mr. Giuliani surely had the makings. To be a prosecutor pointing an accusing finger seemed a natural pose for Mr. Giuliani, with his virtuous ire. His classmates found him bright, memorably combative and, to their astonishment, able to function on four to five hours of sleep a night.
"He was very funny, but he was also much like he is now," said Peter D. McKenna, a friend who became the law review's editor in chief. "He could give a joke but not take one. When he thought he was right, he'd become arrogant and call the other guy a crybaby."
Representative Peter T. King, a Republican from Long Island, said, "I was struck by him being very, very smart and really, really liberal."
The two men had met in 1967, when they were summer interns at a law firm that included Richard M. Nixon. Mr. Giuliani, the Kennedy zealot, talked briefly with the future President on two occasions, both times managing to refrain from using his scornful nickname for Nixon: the Trickster.
"That summer, there were riots in Newark and Detroit, and Rudy was very sympathetic to the rioters," Mr. King said. "He told me he had gone to a bar and started in on a black guy because he wasn't radical enough. Rudy said before the conversation was over he'd turned him into a Black Power guy."
A week before Mr. Giuliani graduated, an assassin murdered his hero, Robert F. Kennedy, but even that could not destroy so promising a spring. He was departing with cum laude honors. He had lined up a prestigious clerkship with Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon of Federal District Court in Manhattan.
And he was getting married.
Regina Peruggi and Rudy Giuliani were hardly strangers. They had dated sporadically in high school and college, then more seriously during Mr. Giuliani's final year of law school. Their fathers were first cousins.
The wedding and reception, on Oct. 26, 1968, was as much a family gathering as a marriage celebration. For their first dance as newlyweds, the couple chose Frank Sinatra's classic pledge of love, "All the Way."
Among the guests was Judge MacMahon. A tall, forbidding man, he could be gruff with his clerks. But he treated Mr. Giuliani as a protege, guiding his young career.
Surely, the clerkship saved that career from an interruption common during the Vietnam War; the judge wrote a letter to the draft board, securing his clerk a deferment. Any further chance of induction was later forestalled by a high number in the draft lottery.
Judge MacMahon strongly recommended Mr. Giuliani for a job as an assistant United States attorney in the Southern District of New York. Once on the job, Mr. Giuliani assumed twice the normal caseload.
"Rudy had this ability to focus, more than any other person I've ever worked with," said Michael B. Mukasey, a Federal district judge who was then a fellow prosecutor. He recalled how grateful he was when Mr. Giuliani "rounded up a bunch of office people and came to my father's funeral," barely weeks after the two lawyers had met.
In the autumn of 1974, Mr. Giuliani's courtroom skills catapulted him onto the front pages during the bribery trial of Bertram L. Podell, a former three-term Brooklyn Congressman. After hours of Mr. Giuliani's grueling cross-examination, Mr. Podell -- quite calm at the start -- became so flustered that he poked out a lens of his glasses, requested a recess and then pleaded guilty.
Yet however ferocious Mr. Giuliani might sound as an inquisitor, he hardly looked the part. He was still on the wrong side of pudgy, with an oversized forehead and slouching shoulders.
When Bob Leuci, a corrupt police detective who had turned Federal witness, first glanced at Mr. Giuliani, he saw a nerdy kid in a sloppy suit. But as the prosecutor began to talk, Mr. Leuci sensed a rare combination of formal education and street smarts. "He's asking one question, but he's like seven moves ahead of you in the chess game," Mr. Leuci said.
Mr. Giuliani's task was to get the detective to testify against his partners -- his best friends. The prosecutor's persuasiveness would later become part of the movie "Prince of the City." Glossed over was the fact that the two men became close friends.
Mr. Giuliani was overcoming his social gawkiness as power tilted his way, Mr. Leuci said. "He could see that when he said something, people would listen and he could develop a fan club. Once Rudy got that, he lost weight, he began working out, he recognized that all of a sudden women were attracted to him."
The one thing that did not change, Mr. Leuci said, was the obsessive work. At Mr. Giuliani's office, the detective would sometimes ask: " 'Don't you have a life?' And he would tell me: 'I have a life. It's right here. I don't enjoy anything more.' "
 
Washington
A Rising Star Sees His Marriage Falter
In 1975, Mr. Giuliani gained a mentor in Harold R. Tyler Jr., a Deputy Attorney General in the Administration of President Gerald R. Ford. Mr. Tyler needed nimble assistants, and his friend Lloyd MacMahon had always filled his ear about Rudy Giuliani.
Mr. Tyler brought the young prosecutor to Washington as his deputy. He said he never regretted the choice, though "once in a while I'd have to tell Rudy to pipe down: 'I'm in charge, you're not.' He was so ambitious, and still is, God love him."
Mr. Tyler was a Republican. But Mr. Giuliani was politically adrift, having grown impatient with a Democratic Party that he thought was "naively" sliding far to his left. He registered as a Republican.
The following year, Jimmy Carter's victory would mean the boot for Republicans in high places. Mr. Tyler accepted a named partnership in what became Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler, a trusted guardian of old money. Mr. Giuliani followed his boss, also becoming a partner.
The work was tame compared with the pursuit of renegade cops, but Mr. Giuliani became something of a mythic figure to younger associates. Admired for his competence, he was also known for practical jokes, an irreverence toward senior partners and occasional partying at trendy nightspots into the wee hours, sometimes ending one day with breakfast for the next.
"He asked me to dance, and I had no idea who he was," recalled Renee Szybala, then a rising young lawyer at the firm. "He told me he was one of the partners. I was flabbergasted. This was not the usual way to meet partners."
By the mid-70's, Mr. Giuliani's marriage was in trouble. The couple agreed to a trial separation in 1975, but the remedy would prove insufficient.
"Rudy's wife was very nice, very quiet, and we could sense the unhappiness there," Mr. Tyler said. "I don't think she liked the limelight.
"And Rudy, of course, did."
 
The Reagan Years
A Crime Fighter Defends a Dictator
That limelight intensified when Ronald Reagan became President in 1981. The Justice Department needed an experienced crime fighter in its top ranks. With Harold Tyler as an advocate, Mr. Giuliani was given the No. 3 job, in charge of all the United States attorneys, drug enforcement, immigration and prisons.
Much of his time was spent in South Florida, where each month hundreds of Haitians were floating ashore in flimsy sailboats -- or drowning in the effort. The Administration considered the vast majority to be fugitives from hunger and want, not refugees from political repression. Mr. Giuliani became the point man for a policy that combined attempts to intercept the Haitians at sea and detain those who made it to land.
Amid class-action lawsuits and public quarreling, Mr. Giuliani made a two-day trip to Haiti, then testified about his findings in Federal court. In words that would be unforgettable to a generation of Haitians, he said that "political repression, at least in general, does not exist" in that dictatorship, and that the boat people were in no danger when sent back.
Mr. Giuliani later insisted that his remarks -- though repeated many times in his testimony -- were quoted out of context. "I knew there were people who fled political oppression in Haiti and that they were entitled to asylum," the Mayor said. "But I also knew that the vast majority of people were coming for economic reasons."
The chief purpose of his trip was to guarantee the Haitians' safety upon return, he said. Indeed, during his testimony, he recalled a 75-minute conversation with President-for-Life Jean-Claude Duvalier: Mr. Giuliani demanded and received the brutal dictator's "personal assurance" that the boat people would be safe.
At the time, Mr. Giuliani seemed to relish the verbal combat, often appearing on network news programs.
But while his work in the capital carried the weight of importance, he was unhappy living in what he considered a one-industry town. People related to each other according to a pecking order of political clout "rather than interacting like normal human beings," the Mayor said.
Regina Peruggi had not accompanied her husband to Washington. In 1982, Mr. Giuliani filed for a legal separation and, within a year, divorce. After 14 years, the marriage would also be erased in the eyes of the church through annulment.
The grounds for annulment, the Mayor said, involved the couple's unintended failure to obtain a dispensation -- necessary at the time for "second cousins once removed" to marry.
"This has been painted as, well, something sneaky," Mr. Giuliani said. "But I was under the impression that we were third cousins because I never calculated the lines of consanguinity. I can't tell you what Gina thought. I don't think we ever discussed it in any great detail."
After his divorce, the Mayor said, he inquired about a possible annulment to Alan Placa, his longtime friend, who had entered the priesthood.
"He said, 'You were related, you must have gotten a dispensation,' " Mr. Giuliani remembered. "I said: 'Alan, I don't recall doing that. I don't recall realizing that I had to get one.' He said, 'Well, you know, the priest may have gone ahead and done it anyway' " because -- as church experts confirm -- approval would have been routine.
But a search through church records found none of the required paperwork, said the Mayor, who, like his former wife, had previously refused to discuss the matter. Ms. Peruggi, also a person of accomplishment, has been the president of Marymount Manhattan College since 1990.
Divorce and annulment had become matters of immediacy for Mr. Giuliani. In early 1982, a friend had met Donna Hanover, a divorced Miami newscaster, and later played matchmaker.
Mr. Giuliani ordered his secretary to phone her, arranging not a date but an interview. The couple then began a two-month courtship before Mr. Giuliani proposed, at Walt Disney World.
On April 15, 1984, Father Placa presided at their church wedding.
To some, returning to Manhattan in 1983 to be the United States Attorney seemed an odd career move. Wasn't he already the boss of all the Federal prosecutors? But at age 38, Mr. Giuliani was returning to the work he loved in the nation's most visible city.
The Colombo crime family, the mobster Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno, the briber and former Bronx Democratic leader Stanley M. Friedman, the stock manipulator Ivan F. Boesky: the convictions by Mr. Giuliani's office seemed to connect the dots through the money-mad 1980's.
Never shy about success, Mr. Giuliani was an obliging star at news conferences. When accused of showboating, he would typically respond, "I feel a Government office should be open, and I have an obligation to maximize public education."
His good press would prove insulation from much of the bad -- an important thing, because not every big case went his way.
By the time Mr. Giuliani left office, critics were accusing him of overzealousness, prosecuting cases to serve his political ambitions.
In 1987, Mr. Giuliani anguished publicly over whether to run against Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. But the decision was never really a close call, the Mayor said. If he was ever going to endure the "terribly difficult experience" of a campaign, he wanted to end up running something, not legislating.
His options, then, were governor or mayor -- and he seemed to favor City Hall. Advisers warned against it, Mr. Giuliani said: The city was a mess, the job a career-killer.
His last day as a Federal prosecutor was Jan. 31, 1989. By early February, he and Mr. Powers were charting campaign strategies. Presumably, the race would be against Mayor Koch, though possibly his Democratic challenger, David N. Dinkins.
"We had no money," Mr. Powers said. "Politically, it was so naive."
But they had read the polls.
The renowned crime fighter was 20 points ahead.
 
The Mayor's Office
A New Giuliani Takes A Political Turn
The race was the political novice's to lose, and lose it he did, with the help of an elbow to the ribs from Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
Mr. Giuliani was an awkward campaigner, and he would be bruised before winning the Republican primary. Ronald S. Lauder, heir to a cosmetics fortune, spent $14 million to tarnish his reputation. Mr. Lauder's political oomph was supplied by Mr. D'Amato, whose off-and-on relationship with Mr. Giuliani was in a phase of darkness.
Mr. Giuliani lost the general election to Mr. Dinkins, whose victory as the city's first black mayor seemed to be tipped by the racially motivated killing of a black teen-ager in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn.
But the defeated candidate had someone else to blame: "To the extent that Al D'Amato was a large part of it, then he has to take responsibility for that."
The media, too, had disappointed Mr. Giuliani. When he was a Federal prosecutor, reporters seemed in competition for fresh superlatives. Now, like human seismographs, they recorded his every quake and slip. At times, they made him seem like an ogre.
The public had him pegged all wrong, he complained. Donna Hanover shared a painful memory several years ago in an interview with The New York Times. On the night of his defeat, Mr. Giuliani crumpled at the foot of their bed and asked, "Do they really think I'm mean?"
Looking toward a 1993 rematch, the candidate would find ways to become new and improved. He spent hundreds of hours in a self-designed seminar, inviting experts to tutor him on urban reforms. He also submitted to a political airbrushing by new strategists. Weight was lost, a tan was added. He danced a two-step at a hoedown in SoHo, greeting people with "Howdy."
At heart, however, Mr. Giuliani was still the scrappy prosecutor in a city where voters seemed willing to blame the incumbent for a staggering murder rate, homelessness and a general sense of disorder. He believed then -- as he does now -- "that in New York, you have to be a fighter."
He beat Mr. Dinkins by a margin of two percentage points, becoming the city's first Republican mayor in a generation. His campaign themes were true to his roots: part nostalgia, part law and order. He promised nothing less than to restore a better quality of life.
His inaugural speech seemed the dare of a new sheriff, busting through the saloon doors. "The era of fear has had a long-enough reign," he said. "As of this moment, the expressions of cynicism -- New York is not governable, New York is not manageable, New York is not worth it -- all of these I declare politically incorrect."
Mr. Giuliani considered himself a warrior in the free-for-all between cops and robbers. He was the people's choice for top cop, and, therefore, to oppose him was to rob the public of its collective will.
In his third month as Mayor, the one-time political science major had occasion to describe his philosophy of government at a New York Post forum on crime. His passage from the liberal beliefs of his younger years was complete.
Freedom does not mean "people can do anything they want, be anything they can be," he said. "Freedom is about the willingness of every single human being to cede to lawful authority a great deal of discretion about what you do and how you do it."
In New York, he seemed to announce, that lawful authority was his.

HEADLINE: Two Republican Rivals, One Purpose on Taxes

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: SMYRNA, Ga., Oct. 18

 BODY:
The House Republicans' antitax road show came rolling through Newt Gingrich territory on Friday night, playing a tune that might well have been called "50 Ways to Loathe Your Tax Code."
Before a whooping, cheering, overflow crowd of several thousand, a country-music-quoting Representative Dick Armey of Texas squared off in amiable debate against Representative W. J. (Billy) Tauzin, a tub-thumping Louisiana orator. The Congressmen's topic: whether to replace the graduated income tax with a flat tax or a national retail sales tax. 
 With an implicit wink, the two men used much of their two-hour debate for a common purpose: to demonize the income tax for the sake of the Republican Party's re-election agenda next year. By night's end the lawmakers had the audience on its feet demanding the repeal of the 16th Amendment to the Constitution, ratified in 1913 to allow the collection of a Federal income tax. Unlike many Americans, the people in this crowd knew what the 16th Amendment did.
After two previous debates, in Ohio and California, the Congressmen were well practiced in their facts and their banter. "This current tax code is anti-family," Mr. Armey said. "It makes you hate your brother-in-law. How many of you know darn good and well that your brother-in-law has got benefits and breaks under that tax code that you don't have and he ain't telling you about?"
Mr. Tauzin described the Internal Revenue Service as an agency "drunk with power" and recommended, "If you've got an agency that's drunk with power, the first and most important thing you do is take the liquor away -- the I.R.S. code itself."
It is not clear how quickly the Republican Party plans to progress beyond the debate tour, intended to stoke sentiment for change, and actually try to pass either a national sales tax or a flat tax. The road show was to continue tonight in Chicago.
Mr. Gingrich, who welcomed the debators into his Congressional district in this town just outside Atlanta, promised a healthy national dialogue. He said the debate would contrast with what he described as President Clinton's effort "to cram" a health-care overhaul "down people's throats" in 1994.
"When you talk about something like replacing the entire tax code, that's in every family's life," Mr. Gingrich said. "Every American deserves to know what the alternatives are, deserves to have time to think about it."
The Democrats were nowhere in sight but are already on the defensive. Mr. Clinton came up last week with his own modest package of ways to rein in the I.R.S. And Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, has been clamoring unsuccessfully to be allowed into the Republican debate.
Mr. Gephardt, who has his own tax-simplification proposal, said recently that Mr. Armey's flat tax "dramatically helps taxpayers at the top and hurts taxpayers in the middle and the bottom." He threatened that a "Democratic fair tax caravan" would follow the Republicans' tour.
Democrats were only mentioned as whipping boys on Friday night, with even Mr. Tauzin taking a ribbing for being a recent convert to the Republican Party. And if the evening was any indication, the Republicans are mining a rich vein of discontent.
Drawn by talk radio, the crowd at the Cobb Galleria Centre was so large that hundreds of people were left outside the debate room to watch on television.
"The tax situation in this country is ridiculous," said Jennie Johnson, the 38-year-old owner of a car repair shop. "It's so hard to follow and there's no reason for it."
Ed Powell, 65, said that he had long favored a switch to a national sales tax because it would make members of the underground economy, like "prostitutes and bookies," pay taxes.
Both Republican Congressmen insist that their rival plans would vastly simplify the tax code.
Mr. Armey, who favors a flat tax, displayed on an easel a 10-line tax form that Americans would use under his plan.
Mr. Tauzin, offering to show what a tax form would be like like under his national sales tax, drew laughter when he put up on his easel a blank white piece of paper.
"April 15th becomes just another day," he crooned.
Mr. Armey's flat tax would set a single 17 percent rate on both indiviudal and business income. Individuals would pay taxes only on wages, not on interest, dividends or capital gains. All the current tax deductions and credits would be repealed, including the popular home-mortgage deductions and benefits approved just this year, including the $500-per-child tax credit. But a large personal exemption -- $33,800 for a family of four -- would help the poor.
Mr. Tauzin's proposal would abolish the income tax, along with the I.R.S., (but not the payroll tax for Social Security and Medicare) and replace it with a national sales tax of 15 percent. That would come on top of any state or local sales taxes. To help the poor, who generally spend a larger percentage of their income than the wealthy, Mr. Tauzin would give every family below the poverty line periodic rebates.
Citizens formed long lines to ask questions ranging from how they could afford a 15 percent sales tax on the purchase of a new home, to how they could be assured that a flat tax would not eventually grow back into the current tax code.
A flat tax, said one questioner, Don George, a 50-year-old physician, "really depends on the self-discipline of Congress, and self-discipline is not the first thing that comes to mind when I think of Congress."
Fending off concern that his plan would eliminate the cherished home mortgage deduction, Mr. Armey said at one point: "The great American dream is not to own your own home. The great American dream is to get your kids out of it."
Even skeptics rose to their feet when Mr. Tauzin called on the hall to remember America's rebel roots in the Boston Tea Party. "This is not just about money," he said to thunderous cheers. "This is much more serious than that. This is about freedom and liberty."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bob Terrell, left, and Don Westbrook showed their support for the remarks of Representative W. J. (Billy) Tauzin, Republican of Louisiana, during a debate on tax reform proposals in Smyrna, Ga., on Friday. (Associated Press for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 1; Page 37; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk; Second Front

LENGTH: 1027 words

HEADLINE: In New Jersey Governor's Debate, Focus on Taxes and Car Rates

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Locked in a tight ace, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and State Senator James E. McGreevey used their first televised debate to draw sharp contrasts today between their approaches to the two biggest campaign issues: property taxes and auto insurance.
The one-hour debate at Rowan University in Glassboro gave voters their first chance to see Mrs. Whitman and Mr. McGreevey on the same stage. Recent polls show their race to be close, surprising some political analysts who predicted only months ago that Mrs. Whitman would easily win re-election. 
 Mr. McGreevey, who is also the Mayor of Woodbridge Township, had the most to gain from the debate, because he is not well known around the state and needs to show that he is an acceptable alternative for voters unhappy with Mrs. Whitman's record but reluctant to make a change.
Appearing more relaxed and confident today than he did in the debates during the Democratic primary, Mr. McGreevey seemed well prepared as he hammered Mrs. Whitman's record on auto insurance and property taxes. He tried to portray himself as the candidate who better understood the needs of working families. "The basic problem with auto insurance in the State of New Jersey," he said, "is whose side is the Governor on?"
He also attacked her fiscal policies: "The problem of what has happened in New Jersey in the past four years is that the Governor cut the income tax by a third, but then increased spending by $2 billion."
But Mrs. Whitman, who first proved that she was a formidable debate opponent during her 1990 campaign against United States Senator Bill Bradley, let no accusation go unchallenged, and swatted away much of Mr. McGreevey's criticism by repeatedly attacking his legislative voting record.
"I heard the Senator say that I had increased spending $2 billion," she said. "In one budget that he voted for, under the Florio administration, he increased spending in one year more than I have in four budgets, in four years."
Questions came from the audience of southern New Jersey residents in a town-meeting setting. The debate, sponsored by The Philadelphia Inquirer and New Jersey Network (NJN), was broadcast live on NJN from 1 to 2 P.M. It will be rebroadcast Sunday by NJN at 7 P.M. and by WPVI-TV, Channel 6, in Philadelphia at 5 P.M.
In response to a series of questions about automobile insurance rates, Mr. McGreevey accused Mrs. Whitman of allowing 12 rate increases and not cracking down hard enough on insurance fraud. He said that if elected he would order insurance companies to cut rates by 10 percent.
"We're not prosecuting fraud, we're paying for it," he said.
Mrs. Whitman said she had already taken steps to curb fraud, citing nine pieces of legislation she had signed since 1994. "That is a good start," she said. "Unfortunately, my opponent voted against most of those bills."
The Governor dismissed Mr. McGreevey's auto insurance proposal, which he says would impose a mandatory 10 percent reduction on auto insurance rates. She said that his plan was "a cruel hoax" and that hers would allow most consumers to save 10 percent, and up to 25 percent if they accept limits on the amount of damages they can seek in a lawsuit.
"What he is proposing is unconstitutional," she said. "The only people who are going to benefit from what Mr. McGreevey is proposing are lawyers."
Mrs. Whitman and Mr. McGreevey shared the stage with Murray Sabrin, the Libertarian Party nominee, who used the forum to present himself as the only candidate committed to making substantial change. Both Mrs. Whitman and Mr. McGreevey virtually ignored him and his comments.
But Mr. Sabrin offered an energetic and spirited performance, and sometimes sounded like the college professor that he is. He received the most overall cheers and applause from the studio audience, particularly when he promised to return decision-making about public schools to the communities and to reduce taxes significantly by dismantling state government.
On auto insurance, his solution was simple. "We need a free, open and competitive market," he said. "It is called freedom. It is called free enterprise. It is called getting government out of an area that they have no business in."
Mr. Sabrin is the first third-party candidate to raise enough campaign contributions to receive taxpayer dollars and earn a place at the official debates. The state's campaign finance law requires that all gubernatorial candidates who receive public funds participate in at least two debates.
On property taxes, Mrs. Whitman dismissed Mr. McGreevey's criticism that her 30 percent cut in the state income tax forced communities to increase local taxes to compensate for lost revenue. She faulted local governments for not restraining local spending the way she has done at the state level, but she said she would make reducing property tax rates a top priority in a second term.
Mr. McGreevey said there was "a property tax crisis" in the state. "The Governor says that is not her priority," he said. "I want to make it my priority." He vowed to use future tax revenue growth to help school districts lower property taxes.
On the subject of education, questions focused on the Governor's academic standards and school financing. When one member of the audience suggested that her income tax cuts had forced reductions in state education aid, Mrs. Whitman said more money did not necessarily improve education.
Mr. McGreevey, meanwhile, seized the opportunity to attack Mrs. Whitman's academic standards, calling them among the "worst in the nation." He also said that the Governor's income tax cuts had led to a decrease in state spending on schools and an increase in the property tax rate.
The state share of local school costs "fell from 42 percent to 37 percent," he said, "so who makes up the burden? We do, middle-class property-tax payers."
All three candidates will meet again for two more televised debates in the coming week. On Tuesday night, the state Chamber of Commerce is sponsoring a forum in Whippany. The final debate will be held on Friday evening at William Paterson College of New Jersey in Wayne.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Remarks by Whitman and McGreevey

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the remarks of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and State Senator James E. McGreevey during a debate yesterday in Glassboro, N.J.
 
Auto Insurance
 Q. What would you do to crack down on fraud, so that auto insurance premiums could be reduced? 
 McGREEVEY: I support a fraud prosecutor. For the last year of the previous administration, there were $7.3 million of fines. And this past year, $2.5 million in fines. We're not prosecuting fraud, we're paying for it.
The Governor criticizes my plan. Governor Cahill had a 15 percent rollback in 1973. And, I'll do it in 1998. The point is that over the past four years, the Governor has granted 12 increases. We're paying a billion dollars more, while auto insurance companies have doubled their profits.
WHITMAN: We've already taken the first steps on that. I've signed nine pieces of legislation since 1994 dealing with auto insurance. One of those makes it easier for us to get at the books of the insurance companies.
Just this spring, I signed legislation that stopped the insurance companies' ability to have an automatic rate increase every July 1, stopped their abilities to put surcharges on your license, stopped their ability to drop good drivers for no particular reason, increased the number of fraud investigators to the highest number we've ever had, gave us the ability to fine insurance companies up to $25,000 each and every time that they fail to report fraud to us, and gave us the ability to take away the licenses of people who engage in fraud.
 
Education
Q. Should all public education be funded by a broad statewide tax and not the property tax to reduce the tax burden on homeowners?
 McGREEVEY: There is a tax crisis in New Jersey. It's a property tax crisis. The problem of what has happened in New Jersey in the past four years is that the Governor cut the income tax by a third, but then increased state spending by $2 billion.
Ultimately, the state share to municipalities of state aid and to the school districts fell. The percentage for school districts fell from 42 percent to 37 percent. So who makes up the burden? We do, middle-class property-tax payers.
WHITMAN: Property taxes, as you know, are basically and finally and foremost a function of spending decisions at the local level, with the state having a great deal of responsibility in helping those districts. Today, state aid to localities is $29.8 billion.
I heard the Senator say that I had increased spending $2 billion. In one budget that he voted for, under the Florio administration, he increased spending in one year more than I have in four budgets, in four years.
 
Closing Remarks
McGREEVEY: I was born in Jersey City, New Jersey, raised in Carteret. My dad's a Marine Corps drill instructor. My mother's a nurse. We grew up in a middle-class neighborhood, and those are the families that I represent.
In the past four years, we have had a growing national economy. Certain states have used it as an opportunity for lower property taxes and to raise educational excellence. But not in New Jersey. With Governor Whitman, we have the highest auto rates in the nation, we have the highest property taxes in the nation, and now we have $10 billion worth of debt. Eighty percent of workers have lost in terms of real income. And our educational standards have been found to be the worst in the nation.
What's up should be down, and what's down should be up. I want to tackle these questions.
WHITMAN: Four years ago, the people of the state of New Jersey gave me a job to do. They said cut taxes, cut government spending, restore jobs, get our education system educating our children, go after crime and break the back of welfare. They were big jobs, but we did it.
We have cut government spending to a 50-year low. Cut taxes 14 times. More people are working today in the state of New Jersey than ever in our history. We have world-class academic standards. And crime is at a 23-year low. Our welfare rates are down 31 percent.
With the same determination that we put at those issues, we need to now go after property taxes and auto insurance. And I promise you that in a second Whitman administration, it will be that same level of energy and focus.
We've done a lot. We've made progress in those areas. But we can do better.
