RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI
 To reporters at a firehouse in Williamsburg, Brooklyn: 
 "The most important poll that came out this week for the future of the city -- reaching its hundredth anniversary on January first of next year -- is the poll that said that 55 percent of people on Staten Island are against secession now and are in favor of being part of the city of New York. That concerned me greatly four years ago when I ran for mayor. Staten Island voted to secede, over 60 percent, four years ago. Queens had a secession movement that was beginning, and they wanted to get into the same position as Staten Island. They wanted a resolution on the ballot. And Howard Golden gave a speech saying they were going to consider it. The city of New York could have split apart if we didn't take the city and change the direction of the administration of this city out into the boroughs."

Council member Albanese has a following in his district and in this community; there are people who will listen to him. There are a whole bunch of people in this city that will vote for me because I'm committed to improving their schools and restoring their after-school programs and addressing the problem of unemployment, which hits a community like this as well. HEADLINE: Guggenheim Built in Spain Opens Under Militant Cloud

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: BILBAO, Spain, Oct. 18

 BODY:
When the new Guggenheim Museum Bilbao opens to the public on Sunday, visitors entering the strikingly unusual titanium and stone-covered building will walk past bouquets of flowers marking the spot where a Basque policeman was shot and fatally wounded this week while foiling a terrorist attack.
The Basque separatist group known by its initials E.T.A., which stand for Basque Homeland and Freedom, had apparently planned to disrupt the inauguration of the museum today by King Juan Carlos of Spain. The ceremony went ahead as planned this evening under heavy security, but celebrations were muted by mourning for the policeman, Jose Maria Agirre, and by a new wave of public anger at E.T.A. 
 The terrorist action on Monday nonetheless served to underline the important political as well as cultural role that the museum is expected to play here. For many people, it represents the city's desire to turn its back on its recent past of industrial decay and separatist violence and to present a new image of economic and urban renewal and openness to the world.
The museum's architect, the American Frank O. Gehry, has described the bizarrely shaped building on the banks of the Nervion River as a ship run aground. Tonight. the Basque region's President, Jose Antonio Ardanza, said he saw it as a ship about to be launched, its "valuable cargo" carrying a message.
"For us Basques, it is a message of confidence in ourselves, in our capacity to renew and innovate, in our determination to overcome the traumas of the past and to come back to the path that leads to the future," he said.
Although the museum is to be administered by the New York-based Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, the Basque regional government has covered the $100 million construction cost. Furthermore, it has donated $50 million for new acquisitions, paid a $20 million fee to the Guggenheim and agreed to subsidize the museum's $12 million annual budget.
But for the Guggenheim Foundation, it also represents a gamble: besides its New York museums on Fifth Avenue and in SoHo, it already runs the Peggy Guggenheim Collection in Venice, it will open the Deutsche Guggenheim Berlin in the Deutsche Bank headquarters in November, and it is hoping to establish a permanent presence in Asia. But the Guggenheim Bilbao, which is almost twice the size of the Frank Lloyd Wright building on Fifth Avenue, represents the foundation's biggest expansion in almost 40 years.
On the eve of its public opening, at least part of the gamble has paid off. Although several hundred people demonstrated against the museum this afternoon, complaining that the investment should have gone to local culture, the Basque authorities and most Bilbaons seem to have embraced the project with enthusiasm.
"I walk down the street here and people grab my hand to thank me," said Thomas Krens, director of the Guggenheim Foundation.
And architecture and art experts who visited Mr. Gehry's building during construction as well as during two weeks of previews this month have almost unanimously acclaimed it, above all its soaring atrium, its "tumbling boxes" profile and its 430-foot-long "ship" gallery.
Resembling a huge sculpture from afar, the museum had raised questions whether its powerful architecture will overwhelm the art on display. But Mr. Krens said, "The art has a sympathetic resonance with the architecture." And among many visitors here this weekend, John Walsh, director of the Getty Museum, and Norman Rosenthal, artistic director of the Royal Academy in London, said they were impressed by how the art works look here.
The opening exhibition, "The Guggenheim Museums and the Art of This Century," features some 300 works from the Guggenheim's 10,000-piece collection along with some 50 works newly acquired by the Guggenheim Bilbao.
"This is essentially a 'collection' show," said Lisa Demmison, chief curator at the Guggenheim. "It is not an encyclopedic show because the Guggenheim is not an encyclopedic museum like the Met. We have used the 19 galleries to provide chapters of a -- not the -- story of modern art, from Braque and Picasso to Damien Hirst."
The art works loaned by the Guggenheim in New York and Venice will rotate, but Bilbao will also hold temporary exhibitions that will travel here from New York. The main disappointment so far was that the Reina Sofia Art Center in Madrid refused to lend Picasso's "Guernica" -- his homage to the bombing of the nearby town of Guernica by Nazi planes during the Spanish Civil War -- on the ground that it was too fragile to travel.
Mr. Krens said he still hoped to show the huge oil painting here.
"We have developed a plan, including construction of a special climate-controlled truck, so the painting could be brought here without having to be unstretched and rolled," he said. "I'd like to think we will show it some time in 1998."
The Guggenheim Bilbao has tightened security after the E.T.A. action this week, when three militants dressed as gardeners tried to install 12 remote-controlled rocket-propelled grenades in a large flower-covered sculpture called "Puppy" by Jeff Koons. When the policeman on guard spotted false plates on the delivery van, he approached the militants, who shot him. One of the three guerrillas was later arrested.
Tonight, Mr. Ardanza and other speakers paid tribute to Mr. Agirre in the presence of King Juan Carlos.
Earlier today, Mr. Krens said that during six years of coming here, he had received no threats from E.T.A. But last Monday coincided with the opening of a trial of 23 members of E.T.A.'s political front, Herri Batasuna, in Madrid. The visit of the King today also guaranteed that any terrorist action would be given wide coverage. "But I don't think this will be an ongoing issue," Mr. Krens said. "After all, the museum is a Basque institution."

HEADLINE: Big, Bold Effort Revives the Danube Wetlands

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS 

DATELINE: TULCEA, Romania

 BODY:
Marius Condac, a wildlife warden in the immense delta of the Danube River, remembers when a sudden frenzy rippled through this quiet, waterlogged world, one where change is normally measured by the rising and falling of the seasonal floods, by the reed harvest or the nesting of pelicans.
It was the mid-1980's and Romania's Communist dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu, a man known for ambitious and destructive schemes, had decreed that large slices of the delta be transformed into grain fields. He sent 6,000 men to build dikes and pump the land dry. Water plants died and animals were driven from more than 240,000 acres and the new grounds were flattened and planted with wheat and rice. 
 There was more. Uncounted pelicans and cormorants were shot because they were eating too many fish. The birds were upsetting a state plan known as "optimizing fish species."
By the time Mr. Ceausescu was himself executed by a firing squad in 1989, the delta scheme was failing.
"The soil was not suitable and there was no money for chemicals," said Mr. Condac, 39, standing on deck of a boat as it chugged along one of the river's murky branches near its mouth at the Black Sea.
In the name of economics and the environment, scientists and engineers from several countries are now trying to reverse one of the biggest land-grabs in recent history.
They have already punched gaps in half a dozen dikes and dams and let the river spill back over more than 9,000 acres. Other drained areas are set to be reflooded. The agency overseeing the project is the Danube Delta Biosphere Reserve, which was created by the Romanian Government in 1991 and encompasses most of the wetlands' 2,200 square miles. Ukraine, which owns about one-sixth of the delta, is expected to join. Financing comes from the World Bank's Global Environment Facility and other foreign donors.
The boldness of the restoration project has caught the attention of engineers and ecologists elsewhere in Europe and in the United States.
"Nothing on this scale has ever been tried before," said Erika Schneider, a scientist at the German Institute for Flood Plains Ecology, an arm of the World Wide Fund for Nature, which is involved in the plans. "We know about no other delta being destroyed and restored within such a short period."
Converting wetlands into arable land and construction sites is, of course, an age-old practice and such land is rarely returned to nature. But that view is being slowly eroded by a new movement to restore wetlands and flood plains for the purpose of protecting wildlife and control flooding by giving the river more space. The thinking is that fish or flood protection may be more valuable than farmlands, as in the Danube delta, where agriculture barely succeeded. Experts involved in restoring flood plains along great rivers like the Mississippi and the Rhine are keenly interested in the Danube plan, Miss Schneider said.
"For restoration projects along the Rhine," she said, "people are already happy with a few acres."
The Ceausescu technicians damaged almost one-fourth of the delta on the Romanian side, said Marian-Traian Gomoiu, until recently the head of the Biosphere Reserve. "They completely changed the philosophy of water circulation, and they made a mess." He explained that the reclaimed lands quickly became too dry, producing prairie vegetation, and that irrigation with river water was difficult because water evaporated quickly and left behind too many minerals.
At this point, the remains of the grand scheme are still visible in the extensive network of levees. Discarded rusting machinery is scattered along the banks downstream from Tulcea.
But the Danube delta remains Europe's largest wetland west of the Volga. Straddling the border of Romania and Ukraine, it is a vast patchwork of islands and swamps created by the river's final split into three main branches, each with its channels and backwaters where water and nutrients breed a multitude of living things.
On the flyways of many migrating birds, the delta serves as breeding, resting or feeding grounds for 325 species, with large flocks wintering here. Some are rare and threatened, like the black stork, white pelican and pygmy cormorant.
In spring, shad and sturgeon make spawn runs up the river and there are fat carp, bream and pike nudging among the rushes and the water lilies. President Ceausescu and senior Party officials used to come here to hunt wild boar and deer.
Of the 20,000 people living in this watery maze, a number were forced to move to make way for the Ceausescu plan. But many others remain in small villages and hamlets in the swamps, trapping fish and game and earning tiny sums from harvesting the reeds they sell as mats, roof covering or, especially, for cellulose. Some keep bees, taking advantage of the summer blanket of wildflowers.
"It's lush now, but it's very harsh here in winter," said Radu Mihnea, a biologist at the Marine Institute in Constanta, already noting the autumn chill. "People are cut off, sometimes they have to use icebreakers to get to a doctor. I've seen swans with their feet stuck in the ice."
For the delta's people, long removed from the outside world, the fall of Communism has brought its own changes. For example, they are seeing a new species: the first Western tourists, led by tour operators who have spotted an exotic destination. The visitors -- among them devoted bird-watchers -- stay on ships because hotel accommodations remain rudimentary. In Tulcea, a savvier town of rundown shipyards and fish canneries, word is already out that the tourist boats are largely self-sufficient and leave little money behind. There is talk of starting a catering business.
There is also the novel notion of protecting nature. Mr. Condac commands a new contingent of 92 wildlife wardens. He said he needs another 40 of them because poaching is much worse since the dismantling of Communism.
"Poachers respect nothing -- fish, otters, wild boar -- even if it's the breeding season," he said.
A fishing ban for sturgeon is under consideration. Once plentiful, it has dwindled because its roe is prized as caviar.
Unexpected support has come from the Eastern Orthodox Church. Its spiritual leader, Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew, who is based in Istanbul, has made the defense of the region's damaged environment church policy. Last month he invited scientists and priests to a symposium on the Black Sea, including the Danube delta.
On the Ukrainian side of the wetlands, Orthodox clerics have recently signed an agreement with the nature-reserve director, Alexander Volaskevic. Mr. Volaskevic will use some of his funds to repair old monasteries and priests will exhort the faithful to respect God's creation. Boris Alexandrov, a marine biologist from Odessa, recalled some recent meetings in Vilkova, in the delta, attended by fishermen, scientists and priests. As a result, Vilkova fishermen are now replanting reed beds. They also were told from the pulpit not to fish until two weeks after Easter.
Other crucial issues cannot be solved in the delta. From its source in southern Germany, the Danube -- Europe's grandest waterway -- sweeps through eight countries and a catchment area of 80 million people, collecting untreated sewage and farm and industrial runoff along the way. The delta acts as the river's giant kidneys, a great sedimentation bed where minerals are transformed and water is purified. But the kidneys have been failing because of the overload and the delta's imbalance is visible in the algae blooms that regularly suffocate other life. The Danube countries have signed an agreement to clean up the river, but progress is slow.
Delta restoration is moving faster. The waterscape will not be the same because the old natural ponds and channels were flattened by bulldozers. But Julia Orlatan, a botanist, said land that was reflooded two years ago already has rushes and coot nests and she saw plenty of carp in the muddy water.
Mr. Condac recalled the day he watched the breach of an embankment.
"It was spring, the water was very high," he said. "So as soon as the machine had dug a hole, the water broke through with great power. We all cheered. The river was winning back its land."

HEADLINE: Money's No Object in This Council Race

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
It took a staggering $900,000 -- most of it his own money -- for Andrew S. Eristoff to win and keep his City Council seat in two elections four years ago as a Republican representing the heavily Democratic East Side of Manhattan.
This year, when most Council incumbents are expected to sail to re-election, Mr. Eristoff, 34, the scion of the industrialist Henry Phipps, is having another run for his money. 
 Once again ignoring the city's voluntary campaign spending limits, he has raised more than $315,000 and does not rule out an infusion from his personal accounts. His opponent, Eva Moskowitz, a 33-year-old college professor, has denounced his campaign spending but has pulled in nearly $180,000 herself, an astounding amount for a first-time political candidate. The combined sums virtually guarantee that their Council race will be among this year's most expensive and hotly contested.
Mr. Eristoff, a former tax lawyer, said he was taking nothing for granted, because Democrats outnumber Republicans 2 to 1 in the district. While often referred to as the "silk stocking district" because it includes the Upper East Side, the district in fact, he said, "runs the gamut in terms of economic and social makeup" as it snakes down the East Side from 96th to 14th Streets.
He also is mindful that his margin of victory was wafer thin in 1993. He defeated his Democratic challenger, Jane R. Crotty, by 57 votes in a special election to fill out the term of Carolyn B. Maloney, who became a Congresswoman, and then beat Ms. Crotty by a mere 201 votes nine months later in the general election.
Mr. Eristoff enjoys certain advantages of incumbency. He has been endorsed by the United Federation of Teachers, even though his opponent is a professor, and by District Council 37, the city's largest municipal employees' union. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has also endorsed him, and echoing one of the Mayor's principal themes, Mr. Eristoff is campaigning on a record of having pushed for quality-of-life improvements. Mr. Eristoff wrote legislation restricting panhandling near bank machines and banning reckless Rollerblading.
Ms. Moskowitz assailed Mr. Eristoff as weak on education and blindly loyal to Mayor Giuliani, pointing to his votes against an independent police review board and his lone vote for the Mayor's failed proposal to make it easier for so-called megastores to come into the city. She reserved her harshest criticism for his refusal to participate in the campaign finance program.
"When you don't abide by the city's spending limits, it means that instead of the candidates' being selected on their merits, it's just a fund-raising race," she said.
A history professor who has taught at the Staten Island College of the City University of New York and who now runs a faculty seminar on American studies at Columbia University, Ms. Moskowitz has assembled a list of campaign contributors that includes dozens of professors and teachers and at least one student (who gave $1). Mr. Eristoff's list includes big donations from the Republican County Committee of New York ($10,000, according to his last filing) and from the Republican Pro-Choice Political Action Committee ($1,000) and occasionally reads like the Social Register, with names like Rockefeller, Frick, Loeb and Luce.
Mr. Eristoff stressed that his support was very broad based and that the average contribution was $159.
Mr. Eristoff has given only $700 to his campaign this election, a tiny fraction of the $600,000 he put into his two campaigns in 1993, but he said he would increase the amount if necessary to counter actions by his opponent. With two weeks to go until the election, Mr. Eristoff has already blanketed the district with two mailings and run his first radio commercial. Ms. Moskowitz has spent very little of the money she has raised and waited until this weekend to send out a general mailing on her candidacy.
Despite her financing disadvantage and the fact that this is her first run for office, Ms. Moskowitz is not a political novice. She coordinated the volunteer effort for Councilman A. Gifford Miller in 1995 and ran Ms. Maloney's campaign last year.
"She may be a newcomer to the public spotlight, but she's not new to politics," said Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., the Manhattan Democratic leader. He said the Democratic Party had not given her campaign any money, "but whatever we can do for her, we have tried to do because all races against Republican incumbents in this day and age are important." She has been endorsed by United States Representative Charles E. Schumer, City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi and former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Ms. Moskowitz said that if elected she would be an advocate for education and would lobby to end tenure for principals and to improve training for teachers. Acknowledging that the Council has little direct influence over those issues, she said, "I wouldn't underestimate having an advocate who's constantly asking the question, 'Why isn't education on the front burner?' "
Mr. Eristoff said he would like to sponsor the creation of a master plan for the East Side and continue attacking quality-of-life problems like the posting of advertising stickers on doorways and phone booths.
As for Ms. Moskowitz's criticism that he lacks independence, he said he was a strong supporter of Mr. Giuliani, but that he had voted against him on several issues, including some of the Mayor's proposed budget cuts in 1994 and more recently on a measure allowing college students on welfare to perform their workfare assignments on campus.
"I am independent, but I also want to be someone on the Council who is willing to help the administration move forward rather than throw up obstructions in the name of limited political gain," he said.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
Buying the House and Fixing It Up With One Loan

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
A YEAR ago Kim and Robert McBratney bought their neighbor's house, at 131 Elizabeth Street in the West Brighton section of Staten Island. Mrs. McBratney explained how it happened.
They were living in Mr. McBratney's mother's two-family house at 121 Elizabeth Street, where Mr. McBratney, a 34-year-old fireman, had lived since he was 2 years old. With growing dismay, they were watching their neighbor's house go to wrack and ruin. 
 The owner had moved to Seattle. Her son, who was living in the house alone, was a drug addict. So dreadful had the condition of the house become that neighbors wanted it condemned and demolished.
Why not buy it and renovate it for our own family, thought the McBratneys, who have four children. They have done just that. They paid $56,000 (plus closing costs) for the house a year ago and spent $50,000 on an eight-month reconstruction job, with Mr. McBratney acting as his own contractor. They moved in last July.
"Now everybody is coming by and asking us how we did it," Mrs. McBratney said.
They did it with a $100,000 acquisition-and-rehabilitation loan, a fixed-rate 30-year mortgage. Through a mortgage banking company on Staten Island, Community Home Mortgage, in New Dorp, they obtained a specialized loan that has been offered for years under the Section 203k of the Housing Act of 1961, a mortgage-insurance program administered by the Federal Housing Administration of the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
But the Section 203k program, while usable in many locations in the metropolitan area, is often inapplicable in places where house prices are too high for its mortgage limits. Now Fannie Mae (the name formally adopted by what was once the Federal National Mortgage Association) has come forward with its own version of a mortgage that includes money for rehabilitation.
The new Fannie Mae loan could become the vehicle for greater marketability of older homes, and more affordable improvement activity, in the metropolitan area. Many buyers use more expensive forms of credit -- including credit-card loans -- to do improvements after they buy a house. Or they put them off or do not do them at all.
The mortgage limits under the F.H.A. program are $160,950 on a single-family house, $205,912 on a two-family, $248,887 on a three-family and $309,337 on a four-family.
In the Fannie Mae program, the limits are $214,600 on a one-family, $274,550 on a two-family, $331,850 on a three-family and $412,450 on a four-family. As much as half the loan can be devoted to rehabilitation, as opposed to acquisition. The lender's appraisal is based on the post-rehabilitation value, and the borrower is expected to put in at least 5 percent of the total cost in cash.
The acquisition-and-rehabilitation loan is one of several forms of rehabilitation-oriented home loans that Fannie Mae's New York office -- which embraces Long Island, Westchester and Rockland Counties -- has lately been aggressively promoting.
These mortgages are not made directly by Fannie Mae, but rather by major banks and other lenders who originate the loans and then resell them to Fannie Mae. By making a secondary market for the loans, Fannie Mae encourages lenders to offer them. It also provides direct information to consumers by phone (1-800-7FANNIE) or internet (www.fanniemae.com).
Another form of rehabilitation-related loan that Fannie Mae is promoting can be used to refinance an existing mortgage on a one- to four-family house, with money for rehabilitation added to the mortgage amount (and mortgage limits the same as they are for the acquisition-and-rehabilitation loan). Another is a pure home improvement loan, made as an F.H.A.-insured second mortgage (up to $25,000 for a one- or two-family house). A third would enable an investor-owner of a 5- to 12-unit building to upgrade the property with an F.H.A.-insured second mortgage, limited to $60,000.
How widely these programs are used depends not only on how well-tailored they are to the market's needs but also on how vigorously they are promoted by sales brokers, who often lead buyers to sources of mortgage financing. And their vigor often depends on how quickly and efficiently the processing can be done. Brokers (and buyers and sellers) are unenthusiastic about programs that require too much paperwork and delay a closing during the weeks it may take to qualify a buyer.
"Three to four weeks between a handshake and a commitment from a lender is normal," said Glen Calderon, a broker with Prudential Action Real Estate in Ozone Park, Queens, who handles many 203k loans. "At worst, it's three months." The lender has to send in a contracting consultant as well as an appraiser to estimate the cost of the work. As the work goes forward, the lender releases payments to the contractor.
In an interview last week, Naomi S. Bayer, director of the New York office of Fannie Mae, elaborated on the new Fannie Mae loans. She noted, for instance, that in a house that now has one or more rental apartments, rents are deducted from the the owner's monthly housing costs in determining how much money the owner can borrow. "That can make as much as a $20,000 difference in the income the buyer has to have to get a rehabilitation loan," Ms. Bayer said.
Over the last year, only 236 renovation loans have been purchased by Fannie Mae in New York City, she said, suggesting that the company has been only a modest factor in this form of lending so far. Through the F.H.A.'s 203k program, 1,085 loans were made in the metropolitan area over the last year, up from 634 loans the year before.
A loan made two years ago in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn exemplifies the type of sales activity that may be stimulated by the Fannie Mae program. Pascale Kersaint, 34, an assistant manager at Bell Atlantic, set about to buy a house by studying bank listings of foreclosed real estate. She wanted a foreclosed property needing extensive renovation.
She found the four-story brownstone at 257 Carlton Avenue, a rundown building set amid well-maintained brownstones on a tree-lined street. "It had great bones, and seven marble fireplaces," she said. It was selling for only $180,000 but it needed $100,000 in improvements.
MS. KERSAINT found a $236,000 acquisition-and-improvement mortgage running 30 years at 8 percent from the Dime Savings Bank of New York. She moved in in July 1995, found two renters, and has been renovating the building ever since. "The inside is great now, but I haven't started on the exterior yet," said Ms. Kersaint. A graduate of Stuyvesant High School and the University of Pennsylvania, she started buying United States savings bonds in 1989 and cashed them all in to make the down payment on her house.
Emerson Atkins, the broker with the Wallabout Management Corporation in Brooklyn who found the loan for Ms. Kersaint, said that a third of the two or three dozen sales made through his office each year were of houses that could use upgraded kitchens or baths or plumbing or windows or other features, usually at a cost of $10,000 to $30,000.
"It's always better to get the money for rehab in one package," he said. Instead, some buyers use credit cards, piling a maximum debt on several cards. "Nine times out of 10, they get in trouble," he said.
In Staten Island, Robert McBratney said that he had never taken out a mortgage in his life before he went to the New Brighton office of Neighborhood Housing Services, a national nonprofit organization that assists moderate-income urban home buyers. He took classes over a two-month period on mortgage finance and other aspects of home ownership. The office led him to Jay Sullivan, of Community Home Mortgage, who got them the F.H.A. loan.
"Would I do it all over again?" Mr. McBratney asked rhetorically. "Without a doubt. I put down only $8,000 to buy the house."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Modern Creed For Ancient Church

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS 

DATELINE: ODESSA, Ukraine

 BODY:
SOME have called it "the greening of the Bible." In Europe they talk about "eco-missionaries." In the United States, a recent magazine headline asked, "Science and God: A Warming Trend?"
Across the West an alliance is linking theology and science, two forces that long ago diverged in their search for truth. What unites them is a concern over the destruction of nature and the recognition that each can use the other to rally to its defense. 
 Sometimes their plans to protect the Creation unfold in unusual ways. A highly visible strategy session was held last month aboard a huge Greek ferry that circumnavigated the polluted Black Sea for seven days with 300 biologists, philosophers, economists, priests and a sprinkling of politicians and Jewish, Islamic and Hindu scholars. The host for this symposium was the Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew I of Constantinople, since 1991 the spiritual leader of some 170 million Orthodox Christians. The Patriarch will arrive in the United States today for a 30-day visit.
As the ferry called on ports of the six countries along the Black Sea's shores and other Orthodox patriarchs and their retinues boarded, the message became unmistakable: the Orthodox Church was speaking out on the environment.
The Eastern Orthodox Church is not the pioneer of environmentalism. In 1971 the Anglican Church declared that abuse of nature was "blasphemy." Since the late 1980's, in Europe and America, clergy of all the major faiths have talked with scientists about the need for action.
Patriarch Bartholomew has now made the fight against pollution church policy. The Patriarchate has even declared abuse of nature a sin. In 1995, Metropolitan John of Pergamon, an influential theologian, spoke words approved by the Patriarch himself: "Evil is not only a matter for human beings but affects the entire Creation."
Many followers have been been surprised by the activism because they know their church more for its lengthy Byzantine rites and mysticism. It is a faith that has largely managed to avoid the impact of the Reformation, the Enlightenment and the political and industrial revolutions.
 
A Cost to Humans
 Much of the Church's drive to embrace this modern creed comes from Patriarch Bartholomew, who is said to be troubled personally by the enormous health problems caused by pollution during the Communist years. He wants to modernize Orthodoxy but needs a consensus since the world's 15 Orthodox churches are self-governing. Church conservatives and nationalists have already criticized him for his openness to the West and ecumenical conciliation.
But environmentalism is a unifying theme in a church full of rivalries. On this journey, it appeared to work. In Novorossisk, a dirty Russian oil port, the local archbishop said, "Our once health-giving waters have turned into a source of disease."
Defending the Creation poses no theological problems. "The Orthodox are less focused on mankind alone," said Deacon Tarassios, who is close to the Patriarch. "They never abandoned the view that man is part of nature."
The church has just published a book in several languages, titled "Orthodoxy and Ecology" (Syndesmos), which quotes Scripture and provides ideas for community activities. In Greece and elsewhere in the Balkans, monasteries are clearing waste and protecting their wildlife.
The Black Sea was perhaps a natural choice for the trip. Orthodoxy is dominant in five of the six countries on its shore -- Georgia, Russia, Ukraine, Romania and Bulgaria. Islamic Turkey is the exception. Some believe that this sea, once a freshwater lake, was the site of the Flood.
But now overfishing, raw sewage and industrial and farm runoff have made the Black Sea one of the planet's most damaged waters. A 1994 convention to clean it up has faltered because of a shortage of both political will and funds.
With his voyage, the Patriarch hopes to galvanize both. Among the passengers were some practiced in the dialogue between religion and science, including Richard Chartres, the Anglican Bishop of London, and Jane Lubchenko, a marine biologist and outgoing president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. Europe's Commissioner for the Environment, Ritt Bjerregaard, pledged funds.
In the end, funds can be found for projects, and priests can preach about nature. But the harder part may be addressing the consensus that emerged on the ship: protecting nature, the support system for human life, is not an economic or technical question but one requiring a reordering of social values. "We have left it to the politicians to deal with the environment crisis," said Bishop John of Pergamon. "We must realize that politics cannot be effective without a moral code."

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By RAY CORMIER

 BODY:

Renting a Yacht
 Q. Five couples want to rent a power yacht with staff for a weeklong Mediterranean cruise next summer. Can you list any agents who can help? -- Eugene Kraft, Detroit 
 A. There is no shortage of ads for agents and brokers in sailing magazines. But to avoid getting seasick over a bad charter experience, Terri Jacome, charter manager for Yachting magazine, says your best bet is to work with a charter broker.
She advises that you call several brokers and work with the one you feel most comfortable with. "A charter can be as formal or as informal as you want," she said, "and it's vital to let the broker know exactly what your desires are."
In choosing a broker, she and others strongly suggest asking whether they are members of one of the major broker associations -- the American Yacht Charter Association, the Charter Yacht Brokers Association or the Mediterranean Yacht Brokers Association. Other questions: How long have they been in business? Do they attend trade shows and inspect the yachts? Are they bonded? Where do they hold deposits? (They should at least keep an escrow account.)
Beverly Parsons of Interpac Yachts is a director of the Charter Yacht Brokers Association. Brokers are "basically travel agents, but only do boats," she said. American Yacht Charter Association members, like herself, generally have more familiarity with Europe than do brokers who are in the Charter Yacht Brokers Association only, she said. Interpac is at 1050 Anchorage Lane, San Diego, Calif. 92106; (888) 999-2248, fax (619) 222-0326.
Lynn Jachney, the American Yacht Charter Association president, said that the group's 25 members must have at least five years in the business and be recommended for membership. She runs Lynn Jachney Charters, Post Office Box 302, Marblehead, Mass. 01945; (800) 223-2050, fax (617) 639-0216.
The Mediterranean association is for European brokers, like Alex Braden of Yachting Partners International, Department Y, 28-29 Richmond Place, Brighton, Sussex BN2 2NA England; (44-1) 273 57 17 22.
These brokers are among dozens listed in the September issue of Yachting. The magazine is at 20 East Elm Street, Greenwich, Conn. 06830; (203) 625-4480, fax 625-4481; subscriptions, (800) 999-0869.
National tourism agencies can provide listings of agents and brokers, too. For example, the French Government Tourist Office, 444 Madison Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10022, offers an "Easy Reference Guide -- France," which includes listings for boat and yacht rentals; call (212) 293-9173, fax (212) 838-7855.
No matter whom you choose, Ms. Jachney said, you should expect to pay 50 percent of the rental when you sign a contract, and the balance a few weeks before sailing. There will also be an extra fund for expenses, like food and fuel, usually about 25 percent of the charter price.
How much will you pay? Ms. Jachney said the 108-foot Admiral Bolitho, a "reasonable" Mediterranean ship that sleeps 10 and has a crew of 6, this year rented for $31,500 a week plus expenses and tax.
 
A Day in Guayaquil
Q. I will be in Guayaquil, Ecuador, for a day and would like a tour of the city, in English, in the afternoon. -- Sally Bachrach, Brooklyn, N.Y.
A. In the 1997 Lonely Planet Guide's "Ecuador and the Galapagos" ($19.95), Rob Rachowiecki lays out a two-to-three-hour walking tour past most of the major sites of Ecuador's largest city.
But many guidebooks and even tour agents warn that there are some areas in Guayaquil best avoided on foot. So, despite the traffic, you might consider hiring a tour guide and car. South American Journeys, 419 Park Avenue South, New York, N.Y. 10016, offers three such tours, says the manager, Louis Espinosa.
One lasts three hours and takes in the major attractions. These include Simon Bolivar Park, where iguanas roam; La Rotunda, a statue commemorating the only meeting of South America's two great freedom fighters, Bolivar and Jose de San Martin; the Barrios Las Penas, where many colonial homes have been turned into art galleries, and the busy waterfront. There is a panoramic view at Santa Ana Fort.
Mr. Espinosa also offers a tour of three museums. It stops at the Anthropological Museum of the Central Bank; the Municipal Museum, famous for its tzantzas, or shrunken heads; and Museo Nahim Isaias Barquet, a religious art museum.
A third option is a five-hour trip to the Botanical Gardens, about 40 minutes outside Guayaquil. This garden is famous for its tropical species, especially orchids.
Mr. Espinosa says the cost for these tours would be about $50, or about $30 to $35 each if sharing the car. Call him at (800) 434-0540, fax (212) 696-2607.
 
Working in Rome
Q. I am a college professor and lawyer and am moving to Rome. How can I find out about job opportunities there, including teaching? -- Ron Senese, New York, N.Y.
A. The bad news is that unemployment in Italy has been above 12 percent this year; Transitions Abroad, a magazine about living and working overseas, says "the job search in Italy will be extremely difficult for citizens of non-European Union countries." The good news is that there is no shortage of resources.
The Italian Embassy suggests contacting Vittorio Tedeschi in the Italian Commercial Office, 1601 Fuller Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20009; (202) 328-4750, fax (202) 328-5538. Also, the American Chamber of Commerce in Italy, 1 Via Cantu, 20123 Milan, Italy, publishes a newsletter in which you can take out a want ad (for about $50); it goes to about 2,000 companies. You can also buy its directory of 1,200 member companies plus 7,000 others doing business in Italy for about $175, including postage; call (39-2) 869-0663.
Transitions Abroad publishes an extensive list of reference material and organizations dealing with studying and working abroad. It is $4.75 an issue from Post Office Box 1300, Amherst, Mass. 01004; (413) 256-3414, fax (413) 256-0373.
One listing is International Employment Hotline a newsletter of current job openings, Post Office Box 3030, Oakton, Va. 22124; (703) 620-1972. But for jobs in academia, the newsletter's editor, Will Cantrell, recommends The Chronicle of Higher Education, Department E, 1255 23d Street, N.W., Washington, D.C 20037; (800) 728-2803. The listings are also on line at http://chronicle. merit.edu.
 RAY CORMIER

PUB-DATE: October 19, 1997

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 4134 words

HEADLINE: Premium Shock

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
ON a gloomy day in April, Paul Pugliese strapped a wooden barrel around his nearly naked body, glued an auto inspection sticker to his chest and headed to a protest rally at the foot of the State House steps.
For years, Mr. Pugliese, of Long Branch, had paid more than $2,000 a year to insure his 1992 Toyota Tercel and 1981 Chevy van. The barrel, he said, would soon be all he could afford to wear if nothing was done to bring down his rates. 
 The rally drew hundreds of angry drivers to Trenton. They wanted Governor Whitman to know their disgust at paying the nation's highest average car insurance rates. Later that day, the Governor said she understood. After all, she and her husband, John, who live on a farm in Hunterdon County, where premiums cost less than in most other counties, paid $2,533 a year to insure a 1993 Volvo 850, a 1992 Mercury Sable and a 1990 Ford pick-up.
But the Governor's sympathy is not enough for frustrated drivers in this largely suburban state, who have little choice but to own a car because even the local market may be miles away.
Motorists here open their insurance bills each year to find premiums that seem almost haphazard in their calculations. A traffic ticket, a move to a city or a teen-ager who begins to drive can add hundreds or thousands of dollars to the bill.
And then there are drivers who may be paying thousands of dollars more than they need to, simply because they did not shop around.
For example, a couple in Jersey City with a 1995 Pontiac Grand Am and a 1990 Chevrolet Astro van may be offered rates ranging from $1,439 to $3,709 for the same coverage, their final premium depending on which insurance company they happen to call.
But whatever the variations, one thing is clear: the average cost of auto insurance in New Jersey is now more than 50 percent higher than the national average.
While experts say that New Jersey's rates may always be high because of the state's high cost of living and congested roads, they also say the premiums do not need to cost as much as they do now.
Part of the problem is that insurance companies must now pay out more in legal fees, medical bills and financial settlements for pain and suffering in New Jersey than in most other states.
And when insurers spend more on such claims, they make up for it by charging all drivers higher rates.
Think of the state's auto insurance system as one big pool that all drivers toss money into each year. Out of that pool, insurance companies pay commissions to their sales agents as well as advertising and routine office expenses. But mostly they pay claims.
New Jersey lawmakers tried to save policyholders money several years ago by limiting lawsuits in accidents involving minor injuries. Since all accident victims get their medical expenses paid automatically under the state's no-fault laws without having to file a lawsuit or prove who was at fault, there is little need for people with minor injuries to sue. But lawyers have found loopholes in those laws so that even someone who complains of a sore neck can win thousands of dollars for pain and suffering -- damages that are over and above the cost of lost wages and medical expenses. And one way to get those hefty legal awards is to show a court a pile of medical bills for that sore neck, which adds to the cost of medical claims that are paid for by all New Jersey drivers.
Insurance companies are also now taking more money out of the pool for themselves in the form of profits. The state's auto insurance companies almost doubled their average profits in 1995 -- to 7.7 percent from 4.1 percent in 1994. But almost all of that money was earned on the portion of insurance premiums known as collision and comprehensive coverage, which pays to repair or replace damaged or stolen vehicles. In fact, even though motor vehicle thefts are declining rapidly in New Jersey, premiums for comprehensive insurance rose three times faster here than in the rest of the nation in the last four years.
Finally, state insurance regulators estimate that as much as 20 percent of the money in the pool could be going to pay for fraud, which they say is more pervasive in New Jersey than elsewhere. Some of that fraud is due to outright scams. For example, insurance company investigators said this year that they had uncovered the nation's largest organized auto insurance fraud ring in northern New Jersey, a scheme that involved hundreds of people who faked fender benders and filed at least $75 million in bogus claims. But most of the fraud happens when drivers, medical providers, lawyers and body shops take advantage of state insurance laws to pad insurance claims after a real accident.
While many New Jersey politicians have offered solutions, almost every time lawmakers have set out to bring down rates, the result has usually made the system more expensive and more complex. Legislators have found themselves repeatedly under siege from special-interest lobbying by trial lawyers, medical providers and insurance companies, who each earn hundreds of millions of dollars from the auto insurance pool, and even more as premiums rise.
J. Robert Hunter, a former Texas insurance commissioner who has studied New Jersey's system and is now director of insurance for the Consumer Federation of America, said it doesn't have to be that way. While New Jersey's premiums may always be high, he said, drivers do not have to be throwing as much money into the pool as they do now.
For example, Mr. Hunter said New Jersey could adopt a no-fault law similar to one in Michigan, which strictly limits lawsuits by allowing only the most seriously injured accident victims to sue. Even though drivers get much more medical coverage in Michigan than they do in New Jersey, rates in Michigan are about 35 percent lower.
"You can't get rid of the fact that you have the highest concentration of cars and high average salaries," Mr. Hunter said. "But things can be done."
 
A National Leader In Auto Premiums
In 1995, each New Jersey driver spent an average of $1,013 to insure each vehicle they owned, while the average cost nationwide was $665.
But New Jersey drivers are not alone in their frustrations over high rates. In New York, each motorist spent an average of $906 on auto insurance in 1995. And, in Connecticut, the average cost was $881.
In fact, thousands of drivers in neighboring states pay auto insurance premiums that are just as expensive as New Jersey's rates, or even more so. And, some of those drivers wonder what the fuss over auto insurance in New Jersey is all about.
"It's nonsense," said Leonard Kramer, who just moved to Brick Township, N.J. from a rural town in northern Westchester County, New York and was surprised when his $2,000 premium did not rise after the move. "It really is."
Some of the factors that make insurance expensive in New York and Connecticut, also make it costly in New Jersey. And, many of these factors are hard to control.
For example, most things cost more in the New York City metropolitan area, including medical care and auto repair, which forces insurance companies to charge higher rates to cover the cost of accident claims.
The region's roads are crowded with cars, making accidents more likely than in rural areas and keeping accident claims flowing into adjusters' offices. New Jersey is the most densely populated state in the nation, has more registered vehicles per square mile than any other state, and lies in between New York City and Philadelphia, which makes the state a corridor for even out-of-state commuters.
The region's residents also have high annual incomes, and they like to protect their wealth, as well as their Lexuses and BMW's, with expensive insurance policies. In 1996, each person in New Jersey earned an average of $31,334. Of the 50 states, only the residents of Connecticut earned more.
Because of such demographic factors, New Jersey, like its neighbors, is bound to have high auto insurance premiums.
But based on dozens of interviews and a review of numerous auto insurance studies, statistics and public records, New Jersey's premiums do not have to be as expensive as they are now. The review found that New Jersey's auto insurance system is fraught with problems that have added unnecessary and excessive costs to accident claims, which insurance companies simply pass on to their customers.
 
'See You in Court': Words That Cost Money
In a state where residents are the nation's most litigious and where there are more lawyers per capita than anywhere else, accident victims in New Jersey are much more likely to hire a lawyer than in most other states.
That means that more of each dollar spent on insurance premiums goes to lawyers. In 1995, for example, $16 of every $100 spent on insurance premiums went to lawyers in New Jersey, according to estimates by the Insurance Information Institute, a New York City research group that is funded by insurance companies. That is about 33 percent higher than the average for the nation where lawyers received $12 of every $100 in premiums.
New Jersey legislators have long known that excessive lawsuits -- and the higher legal fees, medical costs and financial settlements that result from those lawsuits -- have added to the cost of New Jersey's auto insurance. But numerous legislative attempts to rein in the litigation has failed because of powerful lobbying by the state's trial lawyers. The lawyers give hundreds of thousands of dollars each year to the campaigns of both Republicans and Democrats serving in the State House.
Gerald Cardinale, a Republican who chairs the State Senate committee that debates insurance issues, tells a story about a fund-raising party he held on a golf course in the late 1980's. That day, a lobbyist with the statewide association of trial lawyers made the Bergen County Republican an offer: If the senator would vote against a bill pending in his committee that was aimed at limiting the lawsuits filed after auto accidents, the trial lawyers would pay the entire cost of his next campaign.
"I refused," said Mr. Cardinale, after retelling the events recently. "But they continued to come to my fund-raisers."
But the trial lawyers have successfully wooed the majority of state legislators -- many who work as lawyers themselves. And, the legislators often fulfill at least some of the wishes of lawyers, who argue that they are simply trying to ensure that accident victims are compensated for their pain.
Perhaps the trial lawyers' biggest coup was a last minute amendment to a bill in 1972 that created the state's no-fault insurance system. The amendment helped create what became the most expensive auto insurance system in the country.
"They reworked the details," said Senator Cardinale. "And we've been trying since the early seventies to rearrange the details."
Under no-fault insurance, a policyholder is automatically reimbursed for medical expenses after an accident without having to file a lawsuit or prove who was at fault. But to pay for those new, expensive medical benefits, the 1972 legislation had tried to save costs elsewhere by limiting the number of lawsuits filed by people with minor injuries such as neck and back pains. The goals of the proposed no-fault law: that all accident victims get their medical care paid immediately, that more money go to people with serious injuries, and that less money go to lawyers.
The last minute changes in 1972, however, made it easy for lawyers to keep filing cases. Unlike a successful no-fault law in Michigan, which allows only the most seriously injured accident victims to sue, New Jersey's amended no-fault law allowed a person to sue if their medical bills amounted to $200, an amount that proved almost meaningless.
While state legislators later tightened the litigation limits in New Jersey's no-fault law, making it harder for those with minor injuries to sue, lawyers are still finding ways around the law. The lawyers make their money be keeping about 33 percent of the settlement that an accident victim receives for pain and suffering damages.
Only 13 states have passed no-fault laws. And, since accident victims in those no-fault states do not have to sue to get their medical bills paid, the involvement of lawyers should be less in those no-fault states than in those states without no-fault laws.
But that is not the case in New Jersey.
According to a 1994 study by the Insurance Research Council, a group based in Wheaton, Illinois that is funded by insurers, 61 percent of the people filing accident claims in New Jersey in 1992 had hired a lawyers compared to 46 percent of the people filing claims nationwide. Only Massachusetts, Maryland and Rhode Island had a higher level of involvement by lawyers in claims.
Lawyers say that they are not to blame for the high cost of insurance premiums. They say that they are only making sure that all accident victims are properly cared for and justly compensated for their pain. And, they say that insurance companies force many accident victims to file lawsuits by refusing to pay their medical bills.
"If they did not have medical bills that were piling up and not being paid, they would not have to hire an attorney," said Michael S. Berger, president of the New Jersey chapter of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America.
The insurance companies' "job is to make money, and they make money by denying claims," Mr. Berger said. "Our goal is to get what is justly due to our clients."
 
The Fraud Business: Bilking the System
It is the lure of golden legal settlements for pain and suffering that is also fueling some of the recent brash acts of insurance fraud, a problem that state insurance officials say adds as much as 20 percent to the cost of premiums.
In Passaic County, for years, members of an organized fraud ring have piled four to six people into cars, slowly driven the vehicles into each other and then filed claims and lawsuits to collect for pain they never suffered, according to several lawsuits recently filed by insurance companies. The insurers filed the lawsuits in an attempt to stop payment on the ring members' claims that they estimate have reached $75 million.
In another multimillion dollar example of fraud, Attorney General Peter Verniero announced in April that he had settled a case against two chiropractors who had billed two state-run auto insurance pools for $52 million in unnecessary medical care to bolster the pain and suffering settlements of more than 5,000 people. The chiropractors lost their licenses for at least five years and were forced to pay $750,000 to the state, but state prosecutors were criticized for not filing criminal charges against the two men.
And, this summer, Dr. Henry Miles Sherman, a physician in East Orange was ordered jailed for two-and-a-half years for routinely filing claims for examinations he never provided. Some of Dr. Sherman's patients were caught by state investigators when they scrambled aboard a public bus after an accident that the investigators set up in a 1991 sting operation. The sting was an attempt to catch insurance cheats and "ghost riders," those who falsely claim they were injured in public transportation accidents so that they can collect insurance settlements.
The insurance companies say that some of the same legal provisions that allow people with minor injuries to collect thousands of dollars in settlements for pain and suffering are also leading to fraudulent medical claims and to medical bills that are excessive or unnecessary. Claims for medical bills are now the fastest rising cost of auto insurance in New Jersey.
For example, to sue for pain and suffering in New Jersey, most accident victims must prove they have a serious injury. Judges and juries are more likely to decide that an injury is serious if they see a pile of medical bills.
"Injuries are serious, if they cost a lot of money to treat," said Senator Cardinale. "There's a lot of doctors who work hand in glove with the attorneys. The incentive is too make things cost more. It's a vicious treadmill."
People do not like to be treated by chiropractors, he said. But they do it "because there is a pot of gold offered to them."
 
A Regulated Industry Reaps Larger Profits
Between 1991 and 1995, the number of car thefts in New Jersey declined by about 30 percent. But while insurance companies may be paying out less money as they replace fewer stolen cars, drivers are not paying any less to insure their cars against theft. In fact, they are paying much more.
During those same years, the premiums charged for the comprehensive insurance that pays to replace stolen cars rose three times faster in New Jersey than the national average, allowing insurance companies to earn hefty profits on that portion of each auto insurance bill. About 50 percent of the comprehensive premium covers stolen vehicles. The rest of the premium covers such things as vandalism, broken wind shields, and stolen stereos.
And, the insurance companies have also boosted the cost of collision premiums, which pay to repair or replace a vehicle after an accident. New Jersey's average collision premium rose seven times faster than the national average between 1991 and 1995.
With those rate hikes, New Jersey's insurers earned a 20 percent profit on comprehensive and collision premiums in 1995, according to the National Association of Insurance Commissioners.
"Those rates could be cut now," said Robert Hunter of Consumer Federation of America.
One reason for those high comprehensive and collision rates can be tied to a 1989 state law that allowed auto insurance companies to raise rates by at least 3 percent a year whether they needed it or not. The law was changed this summer so that now insurers must prove to state regulators that they need to raise rates to cover their costs.
The law was part of pages of state laws that makes New Jersey's auto insurance market one of the most regulated in the country. In New Jersey, the state requires insurance companies to get approval before raising rates, regulates how claims are settled and limits the profits that insurers can earn.
Governor Whitman's insurance officials say that even if the automatic rate-increase law allowed insurance companies to earn high profits on comprehensive and collision premiums, another state law makes sure that they cannot earn more than 6 percent in profits overall.
Under that law, if insurers make more than 6 percent a year, after their profits are averaged over three consecutive years, the companies must pay rebates to policyholders.
So while the companies may be making excessive profits on collision and comprehensive insurance, the state officials say, they are making far less money, or even losing money on the rest of the insurance premium, which covers injuries to drivers and passengers.
"That's the way the current system works," said Donald Bryan, an assistant insurance commissioner.
But even so, after years of losses or meager profits, auto insurance companies are making money in New Jersey.
According to the most recent statistics kept by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, New Jersey insurance companies' 1995 profits were the highest since 1986.
And, while insurance premiums are now rising less than the inflation rate across much of the nation, that is not the case in New Jersey, where the automatic annual rate increases and the additional rate increases approved by the Whitman administration allowed premiums to rise overall by 5.2 percent in 1995.
Executives with New Jersey's insurance companies say that their profits have been far from lucrative and below the national average for years. Company officials say that much of the recent increase in profits is due to healthy earnings on their investment funds. And, they say that while the number of car thefts is declining, the cost of replacing the vehicles is increasing.
But some legislators in Trenton, including State Senator James E. McGreevey, the Democrat who is trying to unseat Mrs. Whitman in next month's election, contend that the insurance companies are hiding their true profits and using accounting shenanigans to get around the state's profit limit.
Instead of recording higher profits in some years, these legislators say, the companies are putting the money into a separate reserve fund, saying that they will need it to pay future accident claims. That way, the companies do not have to pay rebates, the legislators say.
"The company may ask for an increase in its rates because of a lack of profit," said Assemblyman Sean F. Dalton, a Democrat from Gloucester County, "but it is not a true picture of the company's economic status."
Mr. McGreevey says that insurers may be charging their auto insurance policyholders too much for administrative expenses, such as top executive salaries and office costs. And, he wants state regulators to examine insurers' financial books every two years to make sure they are not earning more than the 6 percent profit they are allowed under state law.
 
Once No-Fault; Now Whose Fault?
ONCE, more than a quarter-century ago, the price of auto insurance did not fester in the minds of New Jersey drivers. Then, cars did not have to be insured.
But in 1972, Gov. William T. Cahill changed all that by signing a bill that made auto insurance mandatory.
That bill, which also created the state's no-fault insurance system, was intended to lower premiums. But a last-minute amendment, tacked on by state legislators after lobbying from the state's trial lawyers, increased insurance costs by making it easy for accident victims to file lawsuits, even after their medical expenses had been paid under no-fault.
No governor since has been able to fix the flaws, and some administrations have made things worse.
When Gov. Brendan T. Byrne refused to raise insurance rates to cover the rising cost of accident claims, the insurance companies responded by refusing to insure thousands of drivers, who were forced into a special insurance pool that charged extremely high rates.
To help those drivers, in 1983 Gov. Thomas H. Kean created a state-run insurance pool, known as the Joint Underwriting Association. That move essentially put state government into the business of insuring automobiles, a complicated job that proved to be fiscal folly. The fraud-ridden pool, in which state officials allowed insurance companies to decide how to spend public money and to earn more commissions for themselves the more public dollars they spent, was soon more than $3 billion in debt.
To pay for the mess, the state demanded that every driver in the state pay surcharges as high as $220 a year, which angered motorists across the state. In 1988, one angry driver, forced to take out a loan to pay his $4,400 insurance bill, battered a jalopy with a sledgehammer near the State House's front door.
Buoyed by that rage, Jim Florio made promises of lower premiums a key to his successful gubernatorial campaign in 1989. But while Governor, he ended the surcharges, and premiums fell to the second-highest in the nation for the first time in years. He also created another state-run insurance pool as a temporary replacement for the Joint Underwriting Association; almost immediately, the pool turned pink with the red ink of costly claims it could not pay.
Governor Whitman inherited those unpaid bills -- more than $1.3 billion. She ordered insurers to pay part of that debt, and she borrowed $705 million to pay the rest. Those bonds will be paid off by a surcharge on bad drivers until the year 2011.
But Mrs. Whitman also eliminated the state's Office of the Public Advocate, a watchdog for consumers that could challenge insurers' requests for rate increases, and premiums rose steadily during her first three years in office.
In January, the Governor herself reminded voters that they were paying too much for auto insurance. In her State of the State address, Mrs. Whitman vowed to take on the trial lawyers and the insurers by proposing to lower rates as much as 25 percent if drivers gave up their right to sue for pain-and-suffering damages after an accident.
But a few months later, she gave up on that plan when she found little support from her fellow Republicans who control both the Senate and the Assembly. The lawmakers had been heavily pressured by the trial lawyers to reject any bill that limited their livelihood.
However, with Mrs. Whitman's prodding, the Legislature passed a bill that ended the practice of letting insurers raise their premiums by three to six percentage points every year, regardless of whether the companies needed the money. MELODY PETERSEN

Charts: "Lower, but Still Highest"
Though the average automobile insurance premium in New Jersey fell in the early 90's, it is still the highest in the country. One reason is that payments for injuries, below, are much higher than in other states. Graphs track average insurance premium and average cost per vehicle for injury claims, since 1987. "Are You Paying Too Much?"
To help drivers buy auto insurance, the State Department of Banking and Insurance does an annual survey of rates. The survey shows that drivers can save hundreds of dollars by shopping around. Copies of the full survey for your area can be obtained by calling (800)446-7467.
 
Chart shows a selection from the survey, highlighting the rates offered in urban, suburban and rural areas. The examples assume that the vehicle is used mostly for pleasure (driven less than 7,000 miles a year or for a daily commute of less than three miles one way). The examples also assume that the drivers have no traffic tickets or accidents on their records, and that they agree to accept the no-fault insurance law's verbal threshold, which allows accident victims to file lawsuits only if their injuries are serious enough to meet the legal threshold. (Source: 1996 Automobile Insurance Premium Comparison Survey, State of New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance)(pg. 8)
 
"The Bottom Line: Why Insurance Costs So Much"
Nothing about the way New Jerseyans drive can explain why rates here are the highest in the country. Charts shows difference in a side-by-side comparison of costs per type of claim.
 
"See You in Court" shows the share of the average premium in 1995 that went to pay various insurance costs. A major difference between New Jersey and the rest of the country lies in costs associated with lawsuits: lawyers' fees, pain-and-suffering and medical bills. (Source: Insurance Information Institute)(pg. 9)
 
"Cost-Saving Tips"
 
SHOP AROUND -- The Department of Banking and Insurance does an annual survey of rates. To obtain a copy, which includes a phone number for each insurance company, call the department at 1-800-446-7467.
 
REVIEW YOUR BILL -- One family in Gloucester County recently found that their insurance company was charging hundreds of dollars too much by placing them in the wrong county. The insurance company charged the premium based on the family's zip code, which covered parts of both Gloucester and Camden counties.
 
DISCOUNTS -- In New Jersey, insurers must offer discounts for certain anti-theft and safety equipment. A defensive driving course could also lower rates.
 
OLD CARS -- If you own an older car, it may no longer be prudent to buy collision and comprehensive insurance coverage.
 
MEDICAL COSTS -- You may be able to lower your premium for personal injury protection, which is often referred to as PIP, by selecting your health insurer to pay for medical bills after an auto accident rather than your auto insurance. (pg. 9)
