PUB-DATE: October 19, 1997

SECTION: Section 6; Page 60; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3116 words

HEADLINE: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers;
Floyd Flake's Middle America

BYLINE: By James Traub; James Traub is a staff writer for The New Yorker. His last article for The Times Magazine was about John Sexton, dean of New York University Law School, and appeared in May.

 BODY:
The congregants of the Allen African Methodist Episcopalian Church started lining up early for the 8:30 service one morning in July. It was a momentous occasion: the unveiling of the church's $23 million cathedral at the edge of the St. Albans neighborhood in Queens. The older women wore hats -- raspberry-colored straw numbers with the brims rolled up, bluebird confections decorated with lace and little pearly beads. Many of the men were in suits; the ushers had on white dinner jackets and white gloves. In their daytime lives, these men and women were bus drivers and police officers and electricians and small businessmen -- members of the vast black middle-class community that stretches eastward from St. Albans to the Nassau County line. And the soaring new cathedral, with its burgundy carpet and oak pews and its great balcony suspended way up in the air, held an almost allegorical power for them. It spoke of prosperity and permanence and shared sacrifice. Last year, the congregation had coughed up $5.3 million, or close to $1,000 per adult. Allen takes in more in a week than many black churches do in a year.
By the time the service began, at least two-thirds of the cathedral's 2,500 seats were filled. The church was brimming with good feeling; I've never been hugged by so many strangers in my life. (It wasn't easy to imagine the all-white setting in which a black person would be welcomed with such open arms.) After the crowd had been primed with some preaching and gospel singing, the pastor, the Rev. Floyd Flake, sprang to the pulpit. In his daily life, Flake was the Congressman from southeastern Queens, though the following week he would announce that he was stepping down to devote himself full time to church affairs. Flake is an elegant, dark-suited figure who moves comfortably among New York's bankers and plutocrats. Behind the pulpit, however, he was a different man. One of the worshipers told me that in the old church, the reverend would sometimes vault over a railing at moments of high passion. Today he was wearing a splendidly embroidered black floor-length gown that his wife, Elaine, had bought in Africa. He announced the theme of his sermon: "purposeful forgetfulness." 
 At first Flake talked about people who haven't succeeded because "they are carrying around so much negative baggage." Then he said, "There will always be somebody who will not tap in or tune in to your dream." It had happened to him. As a boy, people had told Flake, 1 of 13 children of parents with fifth- and sixth-grade educations, that he would never go to college. But they hadn't reckoned on his mother, who taught the kids how to sew and wash and cook, or his fiercely self-improving father. "What people don't understand," he thundered, pointing an index finger into the sea of faces, "is that if you have a good work ethic, it doesn't matter what people say about you!"
Here was the traditional oratory of the pre-civil-rights black church -- the language of self-reliance, of "values." It might have drawn a smirk in some quarters, but the worshipers at Allen burst into delighted applause. And Flake had a sharp and stinging post-civil-rights point to make. "So if all you're doing in life," he cried out, "is sitting around and saying, 'I'm black, I can't do it"' -- and here his voice went sardonic and whiny -- "'all the laws are working against us, they don't give us a chance, they're taking away our affirmative action, they're taking away our welfare,' I say to you, there was a time when we lived without it, and if they take it away, we can live without it again!" Now the whole congregation rose as one. The organist was making musical punctuation marks. Flake shouted that the K.K.K. era was in the past -- plunk -- that white people were no longer the enemy -- plunk -- that he was tired of "1970's rhetoric." And he ended by pointing all around the marvelous cathedral, saying: "This is now. This is where we are. This is a new thing." And the folks around me, in their suits and hats, nodded and said softly, as if to themselves, "This is a new thing."
If the worshipers at Allen respond passionately to what Flake calls his "middle-class message," it's because they see themselves in him. They are, like him, first-generation success stories, and they have good reason to feel that the rules have worked for them. The quarter-million black people who live in the neighborhoods of southeastern Queens that Allen draws upon for its congregation constitute one of the country's largest black middle-class com-munities. According to 1990 figures compiled by Andrew Beveridge, a sociology professor at Queens College, household income for blacks in these two districts is $43,456, about 60 percent higher than the average figure for blacks in New York City -- and $1,000 more than the comparable figure for whites in the area. Four percent in the area receive public assistance -- a fifth of the rate for blacks in New York. Rates of educational attainment are significantly higher, and crime rates much lower, than those in black neighborhoods elsewhere. In its values and in its hard-won prosperity, southeastern Queens resembles middle-class ethnic enclaves in older cities all around the country. If that seems surprising, then perhaps we need to examine our racial stereotypes.
The black presence in southeastern Queens dates to the 1930's and 40's, when entertainers like Count Basie and Lena Horne began moving into the large Tudor homes in the Addesleigh Park section of St. Albans. For wealthy blacks barred from the actual suburbs, St. Albans became the suburban alternative to elegant Harlem neighborhoods like Convent Avenue and Strivers' Row. After the war, the black population began to fan out northward and eastward into vast tracts of middle-income housing, displacing white Catholics who were moving farther east to Nassau County. These newer Queens neighborhoods look more like Middle America than anything else in New York City. Starting in the center of Laurelton, which borders Nassau, you can drive for a mile in any direction and see virtually nothing but one-story brick homes with retractable awnings and scrupulously maintained patches of lawn.
A few days after the church service, I went to visit Gerard McBean, who had been sitting a few rows behind me with his three children and his wife's grandmother; his wife, Karen, was backstage working on the audio system. The McBeans live in the old section of Laurelton, where the streets are lined with big shade trees. Gerard has been living in the house since 1974. The family next door has owned its house since it was built, in the 20's. Longevity in the neighborhood is the norm.
Karen said: "Our block is a very old-fashioned block, where you still have neighbors who watch out for the children, parents who watch out for the children. And we're some of the parents who do that." Karen is a small, delicate woman. Gerard, who was still wearing his hard shoes and faded green trousers from work, has bulging biceps and, at 33, the beginnings of a gut. Neither of them attended a four-year college, though they have associate degrees. Both of them work at the Port Authority, Gerard as an electrician and Karen as a computer technician. Karen worked the midnight shift for five years while Gerard went through his union's apprenticeship program.
They have now reached a sort of plateau -- secure jobs, good kids, postponed dreams. It is a life that is all foundation and not much ornament. The living room we were sitting in was almost bare of furniture. Gerard and Karen are proud that all three children are in gifted and talented programs at school, but Gerard conceded -- without noticeable bitterness -- that "in all likelihood, we won't be able to pay for the best college for all of our children."
The McBeans are acutely aware of the bedrock of values upon which their success rests. Gerard's mother had moved the family to bucolic Laurelton from Queensbridge, a rough area where, he recalled, "everybody robbed somebody." She had enforced the kind of rules that come engraved on tablets: "If you want to eat, you're going to church." And, Gerard added, "you didn't ever not go to school." Karen's parents had emigrated from Panama as teen-agers. She inherited their strong sense of propriety and self-restraint. "My grandparents raised my parents in a certain way," Karen said as her 5-year-old nestled on her shoulder. "And my parents raised me that way, and we're raising our children the same way."
Gerard and Helen were Catholics who left the church because, Gerard said, "I wasn't learning anything." Both had felt disengaged. At Allen, which has dozens of "outreach ministries" and innumerable activities, they have as much engagement as they could want. Gerard volunteers for the Rites of Passage program for adolescents; the kids are in the Shekinah youth ministry. The church offers them an institutional incarnation of the values they absorbed as children.
Flake does not have to convince the McBeans of the merits of his bootstrap, post-civil-rights philosophy. When I asked Gerard if he had experienced much racism, he laughed and said: "Oh, yeah. During my apprenticeship program, I got called a lot of names, really bad names. But, you know, you have to laugh at it. You're not going to change a person's upbringing. And if you don't laugh, you're going to become self-destructive. I've known a lot of people who have ruined their lives that way." In any case, he said, racism has never materially hindered his progress.
Over the course of several weeks, I talked at length with a dozen or so people with some connection to Allen. Virtually all of them had stories that resemble the McBeans'. They grew up in the projects in Brooklyn or the Bronx; they were pushed hard by a parent; they saved up and they persevered to get through school. Most are not immigrants, but they have what we now think of as "immigrant values" -- the values that the securely suburbanized middle class has had the luxury to jettison. They do not see race and racism as the defining
feature of their lives. Nor do they seem to share the sense of racial embitterment that Ellis Cose chronicles in "The Rage of a Privileged Class," his disturbing account of blacks who have made it into the white-collar, and very white, middle class. I often wondered why that was the case. Perhaps it's because the lawyers and academics and corporate executives whom Cose talked to live in a world of heavily coded signals and informal networks where kinship and fellow feeling have so much to do with success. The hierarchies that govern bus drivers and corrections officers are much more explicit. And people like the McBeans have the safe harbor of home. Integration is a nonissue for most of them. They are people who work in a mixed environment and live in an all-black one -- and that's fine with them.
Late last month, Floyd Flake became one of the few black officials to endorse the re-election of the Republican Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. He was swiftly denounced by the Rev. Al Sharpton, who had sought the Democratic nomination. Flake is well out in front of his congregation in this regard. Most of the people I talked to credited the Mayor with reducing crime but couldn't imagine voting for him. They consider racism a powerful force in the larger world and had words of encouragement for Sharpton, though they didn't seem eager to vote for him, either.
The literature of race relations tends to gloss over these relatively contented and politically moderate citizens, but there's good reason to believe that they represent a vanguard. Many blacks have begun to have doubts about the efficacy of the regime of entitlements established over the past 30 years. Twenty-seven percent of black voters in California came out in favor of Proposition 209, which ended affirmative action in public institutions. These doubts are not inconsistent with racial pride: nobody would mistake Flake's congregants and constituents for the snobs and dandies whom E. Franklin Frazier excoriated in "Black Bourgeoisie." The McBeans and the others are members of a post-civil-rights generation who gratefully acknowledge that they owe their union and government jobs to the struggle against racial injustice. But they do not think of themsleves as victims needing redress. They sound, in fact, like homeowners everywhere. Gregory Ford, an accountant with the Police Department, said to me, "It's nice to come home and pull out a chair and watch the stars." His dream is to move to the suburbs someday. "I want to be able to not hear a siren at night," he said.
Allen A.M.E. is best thought of as a community-development project fueled by the commitment and wealth of the church and its worshipers. Since Floyd Flake arrived in 1976, he has turned the attention of his congregation steadily outward. The church has built a 300-unit housing complex for seniors and a highly successful private school for children in grades pre-K to 8. It has turned a row of dilapidated storefronts across from the school into a clean and bustling strip mall, and it has spawned a for-profit transportation company that now owns five luxury buses and grossed almost $900,000 last year. The church's annual budget is $25 million, and it employs 800 people. It is often described as a model of church-based economic development.
Allen is also one of the major suppliers of new housing in central Queens. Five years ago, working with the New York City Partnership, the church took over a piece of va-cant land and created a new neighborhood of 71 houses. Last November, the church and the Partnership opened up another such development, Allen A.M.E./Hall Estates, which is situated right behind the senior-citizens complex. The 50 homes are beige vinyl-and-brick-veneer boxes placed on either side of quiet dead-end lanes and separated by tiny lawns kept in perfect trim. Each house costs $157,000 with the help of a subsidy and has three bedrooms downstairs and three more in a separate unit upstairs; the owner rents out the upstairs for $850 to $1,000, thereby defraying about three-quarters of the mortgage costs. Potential purchasers have to be earning between $33,000 and $53,000 and must be first-time owners. The whole system, devised by the Partnership, is designed to create a new class of bottom-rung homeowners -- a budding version of Laurelton or Cambria Heights.
At the monthly meeting of the Allen/Hall Estates Homeowners Association that I attended, most of the people looked to be in their 30's. The meeting began with a "meditation": "We come together, a new community, with an opportunity to be an example to the community around us. ... We have made an investment, and we want to see our investments flourish. ... Amen."
Floyd Flake is a thoroughly worldly figure who wears fine suits and drives a big Mercedes. His political career almost came to an end in 1990, when he and his wife were indicted for failing to report $177,000 in income, which they had allegedly diverted from church accounts. The case was dropped when a judge ruled crucial evidence inadmissible, but it may have ended whatever hopes Flake had of pursuing higher office. Even within his congregation, where he seems generally to be deeply respected, Flake has not been immune to muttering: in the 6:30 A.M. service that opening Sunday, his wife, Elaine, who is also an ordained minister, railed pointedly against the "rumor" and "hearsay" that dog the successful.
Flake is a restless figure, a builder and a doer, and as a Congressman he has been known for skipping the polemics and bringing home the bacon. A 1995 Daily News survey found that Flake had won more Federal dollars for his constituents than any other downstate New York Congressman. He has benefited mightily from his friendship with Alfonse D'Amato, and the Republican Senator gets a warm welcome on his regular visits to the church. (On one such visit D'Amato pledged $10,000 toward the new cathedral.) Flake is a little bit of an old-time machine politician, but he is also a genuine dissenter from racial orthodoxy. He was one of only four members of the Congressional Black Caucus who supported Republican legislation authorizing school vouchers -- which, of course, would benefit the Allen Christian school -- and one of three to support the capital-gains tax cut.
With his passionate belief in the virtues of hard work and self-reliance and his scorn for the politics of protest, Flake is a kind of modernized version of Booker T. Washington. When I spoke to him a few days before he inaugurated the cathedral, he kept returning to the observation that black leaders have denigrated the free-market system and thus helped keep blacks from following the route to success traced by other disadvantaged groups. "We basically take the economic arena out of play," he said, "and then we wonder why we're always playing this game of catch-up or looking for some set-aside." Flake also argues that the successes of the civil rights movement made blacks put too much store in political power, and he worries that far too many of his own constituents and congregants work for the government -- an employment sector with a poor future. (He himself once worked as a marketing analyst for Xerox.)
Flake's resignation from Congress thus has a symbolic dimension: he is leaving politics to focus on his job as head of a large, growing enterprise. The church had taken on a $15 million loan to build its mighty cathedral, and Flake felt that he needed to "build a new infrastructure to increase the cash flow and service the loan.
Flake understands the alchemy required to turn devotion into money. Back on that first Sunday, he had paced around the pulpit explaining just how much the church would need to pay off the mortgage. The faithful marched up to deposit their tithes in big brass buckets. But Flake wasn't finished. He brandished a crumpled piece of paper that apparently held the price of one of the gorgeous pews. "Is there anyone who can trust the Lord for $20 this morning? he cried. I heard the soft sound of checks being torn from checkbooks all around me. "All the $20 folks, stand up!" People popped up throughout the church. "Everyone who will give between 10 and 20, stand up! Everyone who will give between 5 and 10. Everyone who will give anything!" Now the entire congregation was on its feet. The money poured up to the front of the church. Here was the kind of tangible token of commitment that Flake appreciated. And only when the giving was finished did he stride back to the pulpit, open his Bible and begin his sermon.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 13; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1897 words

HEADLINE: D.C. Confidential

BYLINE: By Alan Brinkley; Alan Brinkley, a professor of history at Columbia University, is the author most recently of "The End of Reform: New Deal Liberalism in Recession and War."

 BODY:

TAKING CHARGE
 The Johnson White House Tapes,
 1963-1964.
 Edited and with commentary
 by Michael R. Beschloss.
 Illustrated. 591 pp. New York:
 Simon & Schuster. $30. 
 THIS book is an extensive selection of conversations taped by Lyndon B. Johnson during the first nine months of his Presidency -- beginning on the day of the Kennedy assassination and continuing through the close of the Democratic National Convention in 1964, at which Johnson was triumphantly nominated. There are no stunning revelations and no recorded moments of epochal importance. But "Taking Charge" is a riveting book nevertheless. This is partly because it has been superbly edited and annotated by the historian Michael R. Beschloss, who has made everything -- even the most arcane references -- accessible to ordinary readers. But it is also because the book gives us an incomparable picture of the character and style of one of the most remarkable personalities ever to inhabit the Presidency.
The Lyndon Johnson who emerges from these conversations is simultaneously dazzling and dismaying. He is a man of volcanic energy, monumental ambition, large vision and great pettiness; a man who seized power quickly and decisively at one of the darkest moments of recent American history, who very rapidly enacted a historic legislative program, who positioned himself to win re-election by the largest margin in modern times, but who through it all was almost morbidly sensitive to even the mildest criticism and deeply fearful of his rivals in the Kennedy family and among their allies.
Johnson taped both telephone and office conversations extensively, although selectively, throughout his Presidency and frequently used transcripts of them to remind himself of what he had said to whom. And for good reason, if the conversations in this book (most of them conducted over the telephone) are any indication; for Johnson often dramatically changed his position on an issue from one minute to the next, depending on the views of the person with whom he was speaking. When talking to his longtime mentor, Senator Richard Russell of Georgia, and other Southern conservatives, he described himself as an almost passive observer of the progress of the 1964 Civil Rights Act through Congress -- a bill, he liked to claim, that he had inherited from Kennedy and had no choice but to support. (He disingenuously told Senator Russell Long of Louisiana: "This civil rights thing -- I came in. The bill was up there. I couldn't say, 'Tear it down, I'm against it.' I haven't called a human being" to lobby for the bill.) When talking to liberals and civil rights leaders, he presented himself -- much more accurately -- as the dynamic and inexhaustible legislative genius he was, pulling levers, twisting arms, doing anything humanly possible to steer the bill to enactment.
When talking to Robert Kennedy's friends and family, and to Kennedy himself, he was an earnest, solicitous friend to the Attorney General, working to help insure his bright political future. When speaking with almost anyone else, he was suspicious and resentful and spoke contemptuously of what he considered Kennedy's lack of accomplishment, his excessive ambition and his unscrupulous efforts to force himself onto the ticket with Johnson in 1964 -- something Johnson spent an enormous amount of time and energy working to deflect. Johnson's unctuousness has been one of the best-known aspects of his personality. But even some of those who knew him intimately will probably be unprepared for the levels of flattery, manipulation and insincerity that these conversations reveal.
It is hard, however, to read these conversations without also feeling considerable admiration for Johnson's unmatched political skills, for his ability to make enemies into allies, for his capacity to juggle dozens of issues and problems simultaneously without letting any of them fall. Much of his time in his first months in office was devoted to dealing with what then seemed an ominous scandal involving his relationship with the Democratic political operative Bobby Baker, with whom Johnson apparently had some questionable business dealings before he became President. (In a scenario unthinkable in today's scandal-obsessed political culture, he successfully stymied investigations into his convoluted financial history simply by withholding information and offering evasive responses to difficult questions.) But the Baker affair, which Johnson considered a very serious problem at the time, appears to have had no effect on his ability to focus on other issues as they came up and to deal effectively with the very members of Congress who were attempting to fan the flames of the scandal. He could hang up from a conversation with friends in Texas about "handling" the investigations and a moment later talk forthrightly and decisively with Robert McNamara or Dean Rusk about problems in Cuba or signals from the Soviet Union. His ability to compartmentalize -- to prevent troubles in one area of his life from intruding into other areas -- was something he later seemed to lose, but it is impressively on display in these conversations from 1963 and 1964.
Almost everything Johnson did in his first months in office was shaped in some way by his awareness of the coming election. He pushed the civil rights bill to passage because he knew he had to establish his liberal credentials with Democrats in the North (and also, it seems clear, because of genuine, if newfound, conviction that it was the right and necessary thing to do). But he worried constantly (and presciently) about the effects of his success on the Democratic Party in the South and sought to shore up his conservative credentials with a conspicuous economy drive and a lean Federal budget. He took an almost obsessive interest in his public opinion polls and quoted them frequently in conversations with people he was attempting to impress or cajole. Almost from his first days in office, he began to dream of winning 48 states in 1964; much of his concern about the South, in fact, had less to do with fears of losing the election than with the prospect of winning by something less than a historic landslide.
Perhaps his lowest point in these early months in the White House was not the aftermath of the Kennedy assassination (during which he was publicly subdued and even humble, but privately very much in charge) but the controversy in the opening days of the Democratic Convention over the seating of the Mississippi delegation. Two groups of delegates -- one representing the regular, all-white party regulars, the other representing the integrated, mostly black Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party -- were fighting to be seated; Johnson's fabled abilities to forge a compromise seemed to be making no progress. Convinced that an open floor fight would drive the entire South out of the party and alienate black voters in the North, Johnson considered -- apparently quite seriously -- withdrawing from the race on the eve of his nomination and throwing it open to the convention (which he had no doubt would, if left to its own devices, nominate Robert Kennedy). "I do not believe I can physically and mentally carry the responsibilities of the bomb and the world and the Negroes and the South," he told his aide Walter Jenkins as he wrote out a statement announcing his withdrawal. He complained self-pityingly about what he considered the uniformly negative press coverage he was receiving (in reality, Johnson's press was very good throughout 1964). Only when Hubert Humphrey -- desperate for a place on the ticket with Johnson -- finally helped cobble together a compromise that prevented a floor flight and limited the walkouts to the two Mississippi delegations did Johnson's spirits revive and the talk of withdrawing cease.
Competing with the personal, political and legislative issues that preoccupied Johnson during most of his first year in office was the steadily darkening problem of Vietnam. The material here does not add anything dramatically new to what we already know about the process leading to the disastrous American intervention in the conflict, but it does suggest the need for some modest revisions to existing accounts.
The Gulf of Tonkin incident in August 1964, long seen as a critical moment in the escalation of the war and as a somewhat cynical pretext for exacting a resolution from Congress in support of increased military efforts there, appears here to have had a rather more complicated history. Johnson's first instinct after North Vietnamese patrol boats fired on an American ship was to respond with restraint and minimize the incident. Its importance grew as the news media began reporting the events and as Johnson became concerned about attacks on him from the right if he did not react more decisively. He and his aides were even more reluctant to respond to an alleged second North Vietnamese attack, which ultimately precipitated the Gulf of Tonkin resolution, because they themselves were uncertain about whether it had actually occurred. But once again, the press began reporting the attack even without official confirmation, and Johnson feared that he could not deny that it had happened without seeming weak.
JOHNSON does not appear to have had any doubts about the domino theory and the importance of "credibility" to American foreign policy and about the connection of Vietnam to both. But more than most of those around him, he also understood the dangers -- both to himself and to the nation -- of a deepening involvement in the war. These conversations help confirm the arguments of Leslie Gelb, Larry Berman and other scholars who say that Johnson resolved this issue much as he resolved others -- politically. The political risks of failing to respond decisively, he consistently concluded, were much greater than the dangers of increasing the commitment. And in 1964 -- with the antiwar movement in its infancy, with Johnson facing his biggest political problems in the South and with the President in the midst of a campaign in which his opponent, Barry Goldwater, was a right-wing hawk -- it would be hard to argue that in the short term, at least, he was wrong.
The appearance of "Taking Charge" helps mark the beginning of an important scholarly project: the publication of taped conversations of three of the most important postwar Presidents. Besides this book and the impressive volume drawn from tapes made in the Kennedy White House during the Cuban missile crisis, there is a volume drawn from recently opened Nixon tapes, edited by Stanley I. Kutler, scheduled for publication in February. These, and others that are certainly still to come, will give us a picture of the private world of the Presidency that we have never had before and will probably never have again. (There was no extensive taping of conversations by any President before Kennedy; and, as far as we know, there has been none at all since Nixon.) They also provide us with a very rare opportunity: the chance to hear the spontaneous, unfiltered voices of major historical figures. No collection of manuscripts, no after-the-fact oral history, no contemporary account by a journalist will ever have the immediacy or the revelatory power of these conversations. Reading them is an extraordinary experience.

PUB-DATE: October 19, 1997

SECTION: Section 6; Page 68; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1958 words

HEADLINE: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers;
Where The Boys Went

BYLINE: By Jesse Green; Jesse Green, a regular contributor to the Magazine, is writing "The Velveteen Father," a memoir.

 BODY:
He called himself -- right there in the Yellow Pages -- the Legend of the Village, and I suppose it was part of his legendary status that, on the Sunday night of Labor Day weekend, 1980, in the middle of the kind of heat wave that makes even the brownstones weep, he alone among air-conditioner merchants answered the phone. The unit that ended up in my window that midnight lasted only one season, and the tag dangling from its chassis provided instructions on the use of a hand grenade ("remove pin . . . "), but it was my first night in Greenwich Village and I was overjoyed because my neighborhood offered everything in the world, or something like it, and I was now part of the legend, too.
Hard to say what that legend was, exactly, but it had something to do with late rent, intellectual coffee, naked theater, naked men. Here in the Village -- just that unmodified noun, as if there were only one in the world -- the fringe became the garment itself, no longer just the decorative brocade. Even as a child I would have known from musicals like "Bells Are Ringing" and "Wonderful Town" that this was where young people with artistic hopes went to change the world, and where older people with artistic chagrin dragged on, making weary remarks about how the world changed them. Somehow, too, I would have known that this was where gay men went if they wanted more from life than drawn blinds, florist shops and special pen pals. In the Village, the bars had picture windows, and love was made wherever it was found. 
 Whether you were a celebrant or a celibate, the sense of freedom was compelling. I had come for graduate school, or so I told myself and my parents, but when that fizzled I didn't rush off somewhere else. My real education was just beginning, and the subject of my anti-bachelor's thesis was how to be gay without being an exile from the cultural mainstream. It wasn't hard to learn in the Village. That first grenade-cooled morning, I looked out my window to find a large tour group looking right back. "Here we see a tiny Federal townhouse, built by Aaron Burr in 1829," the guide bellowed. "Later it was a stop on the underground railroad, then a Jazz Age bohemian salon -- and now me! In 1980 it was still possible to connect the life I lived in my little rooms to the life described in books by Villagers like James Baldwin and Djuna Barnes.
Barnes -- the author of an early lesbian novel -- had lived on Patchin Place, a quaint cul-de-sac of low brick buildings arranged about a cobbled courtyard as if this were Montparnasse. It took hours to find it the first time I looked; every block seemed to be a quaint cul-de-sac of low brick buildings. Yes, a street might start out straight, but inevitably it twisted itself into a question mark. In the Village, macadam was destiny. Settled before Manhattan's grid got superimposed on the wilds north of Wall Street, much of the neighborhood was platted along Indian paths now long forgotten, forcing last century's map makers into such marvelous perversities as the intersection of 4th Street and 10th Street, of Waverly and Waverly. These unlikely conjunctions provided generations of Villagers with a model for the unlikely conjunctions of their lives -- not to mention the sudden turnings and obscure cul-de-sacs in which to live them.
This was heaven for gay men, of course, but it was heady even if you weren't gay. Tourists came to see the show with minds cautiously open -- to entertainment, at least. Nuclear families could be seen photographing themselves below the marquee for "Vampire Lesbians of Sodom" or pointing discreetly at the fauna of Christopher Street, little knowing they were mostly pointing at one another: that furry man in the leather chaps and not much else was probably from New Jersey. Indeed, for all its sweaty peep-show decadence, the Village was never really about sexual display. It was instead a hometown for those who had left their hometowns behind. It was where gay men's history, the only history they knew about, had happened -- though by the time my own diaspora brought me there, the Stonewall Inn, hallowed as the Bastille of gay liberation, had become a bagel shop.
If the Village was a neighborhood of exiles, at least it was a neighborhood. Many mornings, so Barnes's biographer tells us, her friend E.E. Cummings called out through his window on Patchin Place, "Are ya still alive, Djuna?!" -- as if she could answer if the answer were no.
By 1985, the Stonewall was a Chinese restaurant and Washington Square Park a 10-acre drug mart. Little fires popped up in the night; one's garbage got rifled for five-cent redemptions. What forces wreaked havoc on the Village in the 80's were only those forces wreaking havoc everywhere: trickle-down economics, corporate hubris, the deinstitutionalization of the mentally ill. Oh, and a virus. A realtor I knew told me with only a tinge of regret that she'd never had so much business: filling the studios of men who'd gone home to die with Wall Street trainees who skated to work. She didn't say what happened to the men whose families wouldn't have them back, but I knew; I saw them hobbling down pharmacy aisles, all belt and cane and Adam's apple.
Had I been the kind of person to venture above 14th Street -- well, I had gone to Williams-Sonoma to ogle the armadillo chutney -- I might have learned sooner what was happening to Chelsea: it was becoming the new gay mecca. Gay men had always lived there, of course; the Chelsea Hotel was for years a redoubt of silk robes and swish. But a few closeted homosexuals were not enough to give the place a discernible identity. In fact Chelsea's identity was a lack of identity: it was the emptiness between the Village and Macy's. As a result, it had been beyond the usual process of quaintification, in which gay men and other bohemians move into characterful, historic but seedy areas, pretty them up and then get priced out.
But if Chelsea had once been No Man's Land, it was now undeniably Boystown; in an episode of spontaneous mass self-exile reminiscent of religious schisms, the subculture formerly headquartered at Christopher Street had transplanted itself, lock, stock and leather, a mile to the north. Yet it was not the same subculture when it arrived -- and not just because the dead and the drag queens got left behind. Organized along broad avenues, not inchoate "places" and polygonal "squares," the New Land offered a new life. On Sixth Avenue, superstores ensconced themselves in former Ladies Mile megaliths to serve the cash-rich gay colony. On Seventh, male couples in baseball caps, chinos and other tropes of suburban normality cruised the aisles of Calphalon. But it was on Eighth that the brave new culture came into its own: every dusk on the Avenue of the Deltoids was a regimental parade of the pumped.
Visitors from what's left of the Old Land may not feel welcome. The promenaders, for all the exposure, are more imposing than inviting; instead of sexuality you sense a hard, cold challenge. Quick, jump out of the way of the skater! Look out on the left for the lethal cheekbones! At a bar called Splash the go-go boys are no more shapely (or shaven) than the patrons. On the narrow sidewalks, men with pectorals the size of saute pans wait for tables at trendy eateries with defensively retro names like Big Cup. Is this a neighborhood or an underwear ad? Whatever it is, at least it's alive; while ghosts were busy colonizing the Village, hard bodies had come to Chelsea in droves.
The two facts are not unrelated: no one likes to build on a graveyard. It's apt that the first outpost of the gay migration was the establishment in 1982 of the Chelsea Gym, for the theme of the new order was Muscle -- not just political muscle and the rejection of ingrained social passivity, but also muscle as a literal response to the waste and wasting of the epidemic. New Gay Man did not see a contradiction between his sexuality and his world. He was, for most of the day, a suit, gay in his body only; naturally his body became baroquely articulated to signify that. No "gay" energy remained for Village Man's traditional pursuit of poetry and street beautification. As a result it is not pretty in Chelsea, and never will be, except for the people.
Or is it too soon to tell? The transformation that began in 1982 has only recently completed its first stage -- a milestone best marked, perhaps, by the 1994 relocation to 19th Street, after 10 years on a tawdry West Village block, of the community's major bookstore, A Different Light. Or perhaps it is best marked by a more ominous Chelsea development: the dramatic rise in antigay violence (which continues to decline in the Village). If gay men no longer see themselves as very gay, certainly their antagonists do. Which may mean that the promise of normalcy that Chelsea represents is as dangerous as it is alluring, for no matter how much we may wish to dissociate ourselves from our former calamities, calamities have a way of persevering.
But young gay men do not want to be reminded of the unfortunate times. They do not want to repair a past, let alone consort with it; they want to fit into a healthy mesomorphic present, to abjure the ghosts not only of AIDS but also of the whole weird struggle for liberation. They are already, God knows, liberated; liberated into what is another matter. Aside from their physiques they are indistinguishable from their heterosexual contemporaries, and wasn't that the point? They feel they have earned the right to be square: square haircuts, square chests, square apartments on square streets. Here, where the Manhattan grid takes over in earnest, there are only right angles as far as the eye can see.
That 17th Street never intersects itself does not make Chelsea soulless. And there are advantages to a community that aims to serve its residents and not just amuse the tourists. As a place to live and buy efficiently, Chelsea has more to recommend it than the Village ever did: more supermarkets, more movie theaters and now, thanks to a migration of galleries, more art -- or at least more of the business of art. In the Village, which generally rose at noon for its first cigarette, all this would have seemed too purposeful. The people who for decades made their homes there were employed in a kind of labor that efficiency studies cannot detect. They were scientists in our culture's research-and-development lab, conducting astonishing experiments into the nature of freedom -- of the body, of the mind -- and trying to tinker with the prevailing balance between the ideal of individual liberty and the need for sustainable community.
If the Village ultimately erred on the side of liberty, it has paid too dearly. Are ya still alive? is the cry that echoes, often unanswered, in its irregular courtyards and incorrigible streets. The men staring out of the bars' picture windows seem not so much bold as impassive now, and even the reincarnated Stonewall cannot attract enough customers to survive. It took a Village to make Chelsea possible, but it seems that the Village outwitted itself. Rents are too high for the neighborhood to spawn any more revolutions. And now the thing blase gay men say is not I never go above 14th Street but I never go below.
Meanwhile, Aaron Burr's house is for sale; know any poets with $1.4 million to spare? And the Legend of the Village is no longer listed. Not to worry; if a gay man moves to the city on a hot summer night, he's probably moving to Chelsea, and he can buy a nonexploding air-conditioner, along with a map-of-the-world shower curtain, at Bed, Bath and Beyond. He will hardly miss anything, up there. Anything but the legend.

HEADLINE: Inflation? Where?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Maria Ramirez is right when she claims that additional Federal Reserve monetary tightening would be a mistake (Op-Ed, Oct. 14). However, her reasoning is incorrect. The Fed should not be tightening because there is no inflation or any sign of it. 
 Increased global competition, deregulation in many industries, the growth of discount operations in retailing and the increased use of new technologies have all reduced pricing flexibility in most industries. In fact, the vast majority of companies are now under the assumption that they cannot raise prices at any time in the near future.
Ms. Ramirez's assertion that consumer debt is too high is just not substantiated by the facts. The increased use of credit cards and the increased propensity of home ownership have accounted for a significant portion of the increase in consumer debt. Also, much of the debt is held by those who are benefiting from the huge increase in the stock market -- their overall financial conditions have actually improved, despite higher debt levels.
 
LAWRENCE CHIMERINE
Washington, Oct. 15, 1997
 
The writer is senior vice president and chief economist of the Economic Strategy Institute.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
National advertisers strive to brand their product names on the minds of the consumer.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

DATELINE: DANA POINT, Calif.

 BODY:
IF, as they say, the future is where we will spend the rest of our lives, America's biggest and most persistent consumer marketers are striving to insure that we will spend that future, well, spending.
"Branding the Future" is the theme of the 88th annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers, which began on Friday with about 580 people at the Ritz-Carlton Laguna Niguel here. The featured speakers, as well as those attending the conference, have been ebullient in their belief that name-brand products have recaptured the hearts and minds of consumers -- as the booming economy indicates. But they urged marketers in competitive categories to remember that keeping that loyalty is no sure thing. 
 " 'Branding the Future' is right on target because, for the consumer, a trusted brand is a continuous promise of future satisfaction," said Irvine O. Hockaday Jr., president and chief executive of Hallmark Cards Inc.
Brands are for "a competitive and, incidentally, an economic advantage," he said, referring to the higher prices that brands often command, "a differential."
Hallmark is working to "move from being a brand consumers prefer to a brand consumers insist on," Mr. Hockaday said, through efforts like intensified brand-building advertising and improving distribution and display at retail outlets.
That latter point is becoming more important, said Ralph Rydholm, chief executive and managing partner of Euro RSCG Tatham, a unit of Havas Advertising, because of "the way the retail business has evolved into mega-stores where there is no one to help you at the point of sale.
"The brand has to speak for itself," he continued, "so consumers have to have a good idea of what the brand stands for."
If a brand must speak to a consumer, the reverse also needs to be true, asserted John Hayes, executive vice president for global branding and advertising at the American Express Company.
"The real branding opportunity today is to create and sustain a dialogue with your customer," Mr. Hayes said. "Those who know how to do that well will be the ones with an advantage over other brands." Interactive advertising can play a crucial role in supporting such two-way brand communications, he added.
Charlotte Beers, chairwoman emeritus of American Express's principal advertising agency, the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of WPP Group P.L.C., said the "brand relationship" American Express had built with customers bought the company time to fix its problems earlier this decade when credit cards began eroding the market share of the American Express green charge card.
But, Ms. Beers warned, a decision to support brand-building efforts is by itself no guarantee of success because "brands are still failing and declining."
That was underscored by the juxtaposition of two events on Friday. As the McDonald's Corporation announced lower-than-expected earnings because of problems selling its fast food in the United States, a primary rival, the Burger King Corporation unit of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., was honored at the conference when Paul Clayton, president of Burger King North America, was named a Marketer of the Year for 1997 by the trade publication Brand Week.
The top honor, Grand Marketer, was shared by two executives for their efforts in helping make the inaugural season of the Women's National Basketball Association so successful. They are: Val Ackerman, president of the women's league, and Rick Welts, chief marketing officer of the National Basketball Association, which developed the new league.
In all, 15 marketing executives received the Brand Week awards, including three in media and entertainment: Howard Roffman, vice president for licensing at Lucasfilm Ltd.; Karen Edwards, brand management director of Yahoo Inc., and Judy Fearing, chief marketing officer for the ESPN cable television network, which is owned by the Walt Disney Company.
Preston Padden, president of another Disney media unit, the ABC television network, offered a slick presentation of his network's much discussed branding campaign, carrying the theme "TV is Good."
The campaign, which was debated for its tongue-in-cheek tone, "takes the love side of the viewer's love-hate relationship with TV," Mr. Padden declared.
And Lisa McRee, a new co-host of ABC's "Good Morning America," showed attendees at a general session a videotape promoting "The Century," an ABC News series of six two-hour programs about the 20th century scheduled to be shown in early 1999. The audience, of course, was filled with potential buyers of commercial time on those special programs.
ABC's competitors are also taking turns sponsoring portions of the conference: The CBS unit of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the Fox Broadcasting Company unit of the News Corporation and the NBC unit of the General Electric Corporation. Each network is paying the association $100,000 for its sponsorship, hence the hard sell during each network's presentation ranging from the ABC commercial for "The Century" to a visit from an NBC sitcom star to notepads with CBS eye logos.
In business matters, the association made its annual change in elected officers. James J. Garrity, senior vice president and advertising director at First Union National Bank, part of the First Union Corporation, was named the 1997-98 chairman. Mr. Garrity, who was vice chairman for the last year, succeeds the 1996-97 chairman, Ronald O. Cox, group vice president of the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company.
John Costello, senior executive vice president and general marketing manager of Sears, Roebuck & Company, was elected the 1997-98 vice chairman.
Separately, Mr. Cox was presented the Robert V. Goldstein Award for his work as campaign manager for a child abuse prevention effort produced by the Advertising Council. The award is named for a former member of the association and the council.
The conference continues through Monday.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1557 words

HEADLINE: Man in the News;
'Quintessential Salesman' Is Poised to Take the Helm at AT&T

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 19

 BODY:
When C. Michael Armstrong became the chief executive of the Hughes Electronics Corporation in 1992, he wasted no time. He and his lieutenants labored night and day for three months on a plan to restructure the bloated military contractor and cut thousands of jobs.
When the plan was ready, a former Hughes executive recalls, Mr. Armstrong summoned the corporate staff into an auditorium and spoke for more than an hour, without a written text, about the need for the change. His speech was so inspiring and convincing that the audience gave him a standing ovation -- even though half of them were about to lose their jobs. 
 The story illustrates his extraordinary intensity and brilliant salesmanship, two of the main attributes that he is expected to bring to the AT&T Corporation. The announcement of Mr. Armstrong's appointment as the new chief executive at the telecommunications giant is expected as soon as Monday.
His experience at Hughes would help in efforts to cut AT&T's bureaucracy and costs, shore up its eroding lead in the long-distance business, move it strongly into local phone service, and steer the company through a consolidation in the telecommunications business that in some ways resembles the same process in the aerospace industry.
Mr. Armstrong's move from Hughes to AT&T would not be his first from aerospace to telecommunications. He has already made a similar shift within Hughes itself.
He has transformed the Los Angeles-based company, which is a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, from a military contractor that valued technology over profits into a customer-oriented and global company focused on some fast-growing segments of the non-military telecommunications business such as DirecTV, the nation's largest satellite-to-home television service. Hughes's stock was less than $20 a share when he took over. It closed at $65.25 on Friday.
"Hughes was absolutely third in a two-man race when it came to competing, other than on technical excellence," said Michael Beltramo, an aerospace consultant in Los Angeles. "He really changed that."
Mr. Armstrong is expected to be succeeded at Hughes by Michael T. Smith, who is vice chairman and head of the military business. Mr. Smith was a financial officer at General Motors who worked on the acquisition of Hughes in 1985. He then came to Hughes as chief financial officer and began the process that Mr. Armstrong continued -- instilling business discipline into the company.
Mr. Smith, who has been based in the Washington area, is described as having a good sense of humor and being strong on financial analysis. "He's much more likely to explain a decision in terms of numbers," said one senior Hughes executive. "Armstrong is more likely to try to capture your imagination."
Mr. Smith is the younger brother of the General Motors chairman John F. Smith Jr., but Hughes executives said they had no worries that this would cause awkwardness in the day-to-day contacts between the two companies.
The moves come at a critical juncture for Hughes. Mr. Armstrong was scheduled to embark in early November on a road show aimed at winning G.M. shareholders' final approval for what has been termed Hughes's "triple play" reorganization.
The company's defense business will be sold to the Raytheon Company for about $9.5 billion. The Delco automotive electronics unit -- which General Motors combined with the old Hughes Aircraft Company to create Hughes Electronics -- will be returned to G.M.'s direct control.
Hughes will be left with communications satellite manufacturing, wireless and satellite communications and DirecTV. These businesses had revenues of about $4.1 billion last year, of a total of $15.9 billion. But Hughes is a leader in all those segments and Mr. Armstrong has said he expected them to grow at least 20 percent a year.
Still, the future of even this remaining part is open to question. Aerospace executives say that General Motors might spin off Hughes, which has little connection to its automobile business. Or it might sell all or parts of the subsidiary. Aerospace industry executives say the Boeing Company has shown some interest in buying the satellite manufacturing business.
With the transition of Hughes nearly complete, and with Hughes shrinking to a third of its former size, Mr. Armstrong, who turned 59 on Saturday, might have felt it was time to move onto the bigger stage at AT&T.
He himself has not commented publicly about the long-rumored move to AT&T, though in a Hughes internal newsletter last month he seemed to disavow interest. "The reality is, I'm not looking for another job," he wrote. "I've just bought a new home in the Los Angeles area, I thoroughly enjoy what I'm doing at Hughes and I am enthusiastic about our prospects for the future."
Hughes executives said they do not expect any problems completing the breakup. And they insisted that Mr. Smith and other managers will be able to carry on well without Mr. Armstrong.
Still, General Motors wanted to keep Mr. Armstrong enough that earlier this year it gave him a grant of $10 million in its class H stock, which tracks Hughes's performance. He will lose that grant if he leaves the company before 2003. That retention agreement apparently convinced Mr. Armstrong, who had been renting a house, that he would stay put long enough to buy one.
Mr. Armstrong, a gregarious but demanding manager, was born in Detroit and studied business and economics at Miami University of Ohio, where he also played football.
He spent three decades at the International Business Machines Corporation, ending up as head of its international marketing operations. One blemish on an otherwise stellar career was that I.B.M. began to squander its lead in personal computers under his watch.
Still, Mr. Armstrong was considered a leading candidate to become the next leader of I.B.M. until, in late 1991, he was told by the company's chairman, John Akers, that he would not get the top job. The reasons were not clear, though it might have been because Mr. Armstrong was too old to have much time in the top post after Mr. Akers retired or because I.B.M.'s board had already decided that an outsider was needed.
So Mr. Armstrong left I.B.M. to head Hughes, the company founded in 1932 by the eccentric billionaire Howard Hughes. Until the acquisition by General Motors, the company had been owned by the nonprofit Howard Hughes Medical Institute, and it paid little attention to costs and profits.
Mr. Armstrong has cut more than 25 percent of the Hughes work force, shuttered or sold noncore businesses, changed the salary system to reward performance and re-directed research labs from blue-sky projects to those aimed at the bottom line.
Mr. Armstrong is to some extent harvesting crops planted before he arrived. Hughes had already developed DirecTV and other telecommunications businesses.
And the ultimate success remains to be seen. DirecTV, which transmits 175 channels of television to pizza-pan-sized antennas, has 2.9 million United States subscribers, but its growth has been slower than initial rosy expectations. And competition has intensified. AT&T owns 2.5 percent of DirecTV with options to expand its stake.
Those who know him say that Mr. Armstrong is a hard worker, sometimes making round trips in a single day to Washington in the company plane.
As a manager, he thoroughly dissects each business and draws up detailed plans laying out each person's responsibility. "Assume nothing" reads a sign he keeps on his desk, reflecting his belief that a manager cannot assume things will get done unless subordinates are held accountable.
"There are no excuses working with him," said one Hughes executive. Mr. Armstrong will review the progress of a project every quarter, this executive said. But if targets are missed, the reviews will increase in frequency to every two months, then every month, then every week. After that, the manager will be replaced.
Mr. Armstrong is at his best listening to customers and making pitches to them. "He's the quintessential salesman," said John E. Koehler, a former executive. "You could brief him and then he'd go in and his arguments would be better than what you hoped."
But Dr. Koehler, who is now president of Tachyon Inc., a communications company, said that Mr. Armstrong sometimes vacillated rather than take a firm stand. "A really good salesman is a chameleon," he said. "I guess I think there was an awful lot of that in Mike."
Mr. Armstrong brings the same intensity to recreation. In tennis, he is not overpowering but returns almost every volley until his opponent makes a mistake. And after he began riding a Harley Davidson for fun, he became so smitten he invested in the motorcycle company and discussed strategy with its management.
On Friday night, Mr. Armstrong attended a small retirement dinner for a Hughes vice president at the Regency Club in Los Angeles. While he told the people that he could not say anything about the news reports, he went on to thank those there for the good times he had at Hughes.
The dozen or so people there could not applaud something that was not official but emotions were high just the same. Said one attendee: "It was more like an unspoken acknowledgement that we're going to miss him."

SECTION: Section A; Page 15; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1492 words

HEADLINE: Why the U.S. Fell Short of Ambitious Goals for Reducing Greenhouse Gases

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Four years ago, President Clinton stood in the Rose Garden and declared that by the end of the decade his Administration would reverse the increase in the nation's emissions of pollutants that threaten to warm the planet's climate.
On Oct. 17, 1993, as he issued a 50-point plan, the President said, "Today, I reaffirm my personal, and announce our nation's, commitment to reducing our emissions of greenhouse gases to their 1990 levels by the year 2000." To skeptics who called the plan too weak, he promised periodic reviews and modifications to keep the reduction of emissions on track. 
 Mr. Clinton's detailed promise, and how the nation is breaking it, will be at the heart of the Administration's problem this week in Bonn when representatives from around the world once again meet on the climate. They will be negotiating how quickly the industrial nations must rein in the emissions of carbon dioxide and other so-called greenhouse gases that build up in the atmosphere and trap the heat of the sun.
The talks are supposed to end in December in Kyoto, Japan, with a new treaty on climate change to strengthen the one most of the world's nation's agreed to in Rio de Janeiro in 1992. And while the United States has called for a binding new treaty, it is also calling for what the White House calls realistic targets and timetables for reducing emissions that cause the greenhouse effect.
At the current rate of growth, the emission of greenhouse gases by the United States will be 13 percent above the level of 1990 by the end of the decade. The Administration has indicated that it will most likely postpone until the year 2010 or beyond the goal Mr. Clinton pledged to meet by 2000. Instead of accomplishing the goal in the year Mr. Clinton leaves office, the country would have to wait until well after his successor finished a second term.
The reason, many critics say, is that the Administration refused to impose mandatory measures, like requiring the fuel efficiency of automobiles to be increased, or raising energy taxes to force people to conserve fuel. Greenhouse gases come mostly form burning fossil fuels, like coal and oil, and one of the best ways to reduce their emission is to save energy.
"The only thing we know for absolute certain is that voluntary programs won't work," said Jessica Tuchman Matthews, an environmentalist who worked for Mr. Clinton at the State Department and is president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. "And that is progress. It was probably a stage that we had to go through."
Kathleen McGinty, the top environmental aide at the White House, cited three main reasons for the failure of the 50-point plan to achieve its goals: Congressional cuts in financing for energy conservation, the unexpectedly high rate of economic growth and fuel prices that were cheaper than anticipated.
Other factors, too, helped to undermine the Administration's efforts. Congress temporarily blocked the Energy Department from issuing new energy efficiency standards for household appliances, and the department itself failed to issue new efficiency standards for electrical distribution transformers on power lines, where about 7 percent of all the nation's power simply leaks away.
A proposal to label car tires so that consumers could tell which ones provided the best gasoline mileage went nowhere; the same fate awaited a tax proposal to discourage employers from subsidizing parking spaces for their employees. And forestry agencies missed the goals for planting trees, which absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere as they grow.
Only 70 percent of the projected reductions in greenhouse gases materialized, and even these reductions were offset when the booming economy brought a growing demand for fossil fuels.
When Mr. Clinton issued his action plan four years ago, he projected that it would reduce greenhouse-gas emissions by about 109 million tons a year by 2000. That would be enough to return emissions to their 1990 level: 1.58 billion tons of carbon, an amount that had grown only slightly to 1.59 billion tons in 1992, the year before the plan was announced.
Instead, the emissions in 1995 totaled 1.67 billion tons, and when the annual report for 1996 is issued later this month, it is virtually certain to show further growth. To be sure, the growth would have been even greater without the energy-saving plan.
Michael Oppenheimer, a climate scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund, called the reductions achieved "nothing to sneeze at."
"It is a very big achievement, that voluntary programs were able to do that well," he said. "The trouble is, the legs were cut out from under the voluntary program. Volunteerism works a lot better when it is matched up with mandatory measures. Jawboning is going to be less effective unless there is a cap on emissions."
A report by the State Department in July predicted that if the present levels of spending on energy conservation programs are continued under the plan, the emission of greenhouse gases would exceed 2 billion tons by the year 2010 and 2.2 billion tons by 2020.
So the Administration wants to impose a new cap on future greenhouse gases. Under its plan, companies would be given permits to emit greenhouse gases, but at a reduced level. Companies that can inexpensively reduce their emissions below the cap would be allowed to sell their excess permits to companies that have a harder time cutting emissions. This approach, advocates say, would drive down the overall cost of compliance while guaranteeing that the nation's emissions' goals would be met.
But the utility industry, which did more than any other sector to slow the growth of emissions under the voluntary plan, opposes stricter measures.
"We just have a basic disagreement," said Robert A. Beck, vice president for environmental affairs of the Edison Electric Institute. which represents electric companies, "We believe you have not maximized the voluntary programs yet."
Hundreds of utilities signed up for a voluntary program called the Climate Challenge, and the steps they have promised to take are estimated to have cut 45 million tons from emissions of greenhouse gases that otherwise would have occurred by 2000.
But despite those reductions, the total emissions from the utility companies nationwide are going up, not down, and many of the reductions came from actions like switching to natural gas from coal, which might have occurred anyway.
Of the reductions utilities say they achieved, 30 percent came from nuclear power plants, which do not emit any polluting gases, notably the opening by a Texas utility of a nuclear power plant that was ordered decades before global warming appeared on the nation's agenda. Only 7 percent of the reduction came from renewable energy projects, for example solar and wind.
In the transportation sector, which accounts for about a third of the nation's greenhouse gas emissions, the action plan offered almost no proposals to reduce emissions in the short term, and none were forthcoming. A series of negotiations among industry, environmentalists and Government officials, aimed at achieving 2 percent annual increases in automotive fuel efficiency, broke down in disagreement.
Instead, the Administration is banking on long-term research into new technologies, expecting that in the decades ahead automobiles can go two or three times as far on a gallon of gas -- or some other fuel.
Opposition in Congress to spending on energy conservation and renewable energy appears to be waning. Based on actions in Congress so far, it appears that spending on these areas at the Energy Department next year will grow 10 percent, to about $924 million.
Although that is still less than the $1.1 billion spent in 1995, the Sustainable Energy Coalition, a group of business, consumer, environmental and policy organizations, said the shift "reflects growing Congressional awareness that energy efficiency and renewable-energy programs offer a cost-effective solution to environmental pollution -- including global climate change."
The Administration's voluntary programs have helped demonstrate that big companies can easily adopt more lighting that uses less electricity and otherwise conserve energy in commercial buildings.
But some of the most effective actions taken under the Clinton Administration's plan were not voluntary. Rather, they involved old-fashioned command and control regulations.
The Environmental Protection Agency, for example, sets rules under the Clean Air Act that require large landfills to capture and burn their emissions of methane, a gas that contributes to the greenhouse effect. When the agency issued the rules in 1996, it acted more strictly than planned, and the latest estimates are that the emission of greenhouse gases will be reduced by 8 million tons by the year 2000. That is 60 percent more reductions than the original plan predicted.

HEADLINE: U.S. Alliance Brings Prestige To Argentines

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 19

 BODY:
For many Argentines, President Clinton's decision last week to name their country a non-NATO ally of the United States was the latest proof that Argentina is finally returning to prominence in the industrialized world after decades of social and economic ruin.
While the distinction of non-NATO ally is largely symbolic -- title holders have access to surplus military equipment -- Argentina is the first country in the hemisphere to receive it, joining Israel, Egypt, Jordan, Japan, South Korea and Australia. 
 "There is a certain amount of prestige, real or imagined, associated with having this official title of close friend of the United States," said Felipe A. Noguera, a political analyst for Mora y Araujo Noguera, a major polling concern.
"Argentines have always thought of themselves as more advanced than the rest of Latin America, and for many people this non-NATO distinction justifies those sentiments, at least vis-a-vis the United States," Mr. Noguera said.
Mr. Clinton, who left Argentina and returned to Washington today after a weeklong trip to South America that included stops in Venezuela and Brazil, said he intended to make Argentina a close United States ally as a reward for sending troops on 16 peacekeeping operations from Bosnia to Cyprus to Haiti.
"In recognition of your country's extraordinary contributions to international peacekeeping, I have notified our Congress of my intention to designate Argentina as a major non-NATO ally under our laws," Mr. Clinton said. "Our alliance of values goes beyond our efforts against threats to peace and security, but it begins there."
President Carlos Saul Menem, who has often tried to convince Argentines that recent economic and social reforms are returning their country to the first rank of developed countries, praised Mr. Clinton's decision.
In the 1940's, Argentina was one of the world's 10 most affluent countries, but a string of coups and economic missteps sank it into chaos.
Just a decade ago, it seemed implausible that Argentina, then a staunch critic of the dominant presence of the United States in the world, would become its most loyal ally in Latin America.
But since taking office in 1989, Mr. Menem abandoned the isolationist polices of former President Juan Domingo Peron, and shifted Argentina's historically antagonistic relationship with the United States to one of almost unconditional support, particularly in foreign policy.
For example, at the request of the United States, Mr. Menem's Government abolished its program to build medium-range ballistic missiles with the help of Egypt and Iraq, placed its once-secret nuclear program under international inspection, and strongly backed such United States policies as Washington's military intervention in Haiti and its continuing condemnations of human rights violations in Cuba.
At the same time, Mr. Menem pushed economic changes, including selling off unprofitable Government businesses and lifting tariffs, that have brought stability, more foreign investment, and high growth rates to a country once plagued by hyperinflation.
Mr. Menem also restructured the armed forces, placing them fully under civilian control after years of military repression in which more than 30,000 people are estimated to have died or disappeared.
"We have seen a 180-degree change in the way the Argentine Government deals with the United States," said Carlos Fedrigotti, president of the American Chamber of Commerce here.
But Argentina's neighbors, Chile and Brazil, are upset that the United States did not grant them the same status and expressed concern that Argentina's designation could upset the regional balance of power.
Asked about that possibility, Mr. Clinton said: "There is nothing here designed to upset the military balance in South America. We want Argentina to be working with Chile, to be working with Brazil."
Foreign diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Argentina had pressed the Clinton Administration to grant it the non-NATO ally status as a show of good faith, after the United States, against Argentina's wishes, agreed to sell Chile F-16 fighter jets.
In the past, the diplomats said, the Clinton Administration had rewarded Argentina with "mere crumbs" for its strong support of United States policies. For example, Mr. Menem was the first Latin American leader to visit the White House after Mr. Clinton took office. And last year, the Clinton Administration eliminated the visa requirement for Argentine citizens traveling to the United States temporarily for business or pleasure, making them the only Latin Americans who do not need a visa.

HEADLINE: 'Soft Money' Talks

 BODY:
With the battle over campaign finance reform legislation resuming in Washington today, opponents of reform are again arguing that Americans do not much care. Many citizens may not be able to see how their lives are affected by all those coffees, receptions, telephone calls, fund-raising letters and other campaign rites. But any suggestion that hustling for dollars has no bearing on ordinary Americans is dispelled by a new report from Common Cause outlining how the open-ended donations at the center of recent scandals have had a far-reaching effect on government.
Common Cause examines 11 elements of the budget and tax deal enacted earlier this year. Its conclusion is that the biggest winners in that accord were not Americans in general but the individuals and companies that since 1995 generated $300 million in the virtually unregulated category of contributions known as "soft money." These donors, in effect, got billions of dollars in help from the Government in exchange for millions of dollars in contributions. 
Some of the country's biggest corporations, for example, won a change in the way their business taxes will now be calculated, saving them billions of dollars over the next five years. The revision involves a relaxation of the rules governing the so-called "alternative minimum tax," enacted as part of the tax reforms of 1986. This tax was designed to insure that companies taking advantage of tax breaks were at least required to pay some minimal tax. By far the heaviest lobbyist in favor of the change was the oil and gas industry, which had contributed $13.4 million in soft money to the Republicans since 1995 and $5.5 million to the Democrats.
One of the best-known provisions of the tax bill, a $50 billion tax credit for tobacco companies, was repealed this fall as soon as the public realized its connection to the $11 million soft money contribution by the industry to the Republicans. Another provision allows broadcasters to retain the licenses for their current broadcast bands even after they make the transition to digital television. Media companies were almost equally generous to both political parties, contributing $2.2 million to Democrats and $2.6 million to Republicans.
The cut in the capital gains tax also resulted from lobbying, largely by the securities industry, which contributed $10.5 million in soft money to the Republicans and $7 million to the Democrats. When the capital gains cut was approved, Congressional supporters advertised it as a way to boost the economy. The more obvious explanation is that it was a payoff to the rich individuals who have become the bankrollers of the political system.
The list goes on and on. A change in the Medicare law allowing recipients to set up tax-exempt Medical Savings Accounts gave a tremendous benefit to the companies that will now make money from setting up the accounts. These companies were major donors to the Republicans. A restructuring of the Superfund law failed to extend the life of certain taxes that had become a major liability for oil, chemical and insurance interests. These industries were generous donors. A change in the tax on airline tickets will be more onerous for passengers on low-fare airlines than on major carriers. The major airlines gave $2.4 million to both parties in soft money, while the smaller airlines gave $200,000.
The practice of giving political donations and getting benefits is never going to be eliminated, but Congress has a chance to impose some restrictions. The best means would be a ban on soft money contained in the McCain-Feingold bill. If members of Congress care at all about the deepening cynicism of Americans toward their corrupt political system, they will approve the bill.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Says Global Trade Surplus Rose 37%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Japan said today that its merchandise trade surplus in September rose 37.1 percent from a year earlier, to $8.81 billion. The increase, though significant, was smaller than economists had expected.
The politically sensitive trade surplus with the United States rose 30.2 percent, to $4.28 billion, from September 1996, the Japanese Finance Ministry said. 
 Japan's global surplus has tripled since April, when higher taxes slowed sales of imports and forced manufacturers to export more television sets, automobiles and machines. In September, the Japanese shipped more automobiles and electronic goods to the United States.
Economists say that the surplus with the United States will continue to rise as long as the American economy stays healthy.
