HEADLINE: Soros to Donate Millions More to Help Russia

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
George Soros, the Hungarian-born American financier and philanthropist, said yesterday that he would donate as much as $500 million in the next three years in Russia trying to improve health care, expand educational opportunities and help retrain the military for civilian jobs.
In a telephone interview from Moscow, Mr. Soros said he would announce the initiative in eight fields today. This latest gift would make him the leading philanthropist in Russia, as well as a donor whose presence exceeds that of the United States, which gave Russia $95 million in foreign aid last year. 
 In the last decade, Mr. Soros, 67, has committed close to $1.5 billion promoting what he calls "open societies" -- the expansion of civil liberties, a free press, and political pluralism -- at home and abroad. Since 1994, he has donated more than $350 million a year to his foundations in more than 30 countries, spending more than $259 million in Russia alone. This new gift would make his foundation in Moscow, the Open Society Institute -- Russia, his largest presence in any country, including the United States.
Mr. Soros's latest gift comes less than a month after Ted Turner, the billionaire founder of Cable News Network, announced that he would donate up to $1 billion, or up to $100 million a year for 10 years, to benefit United Nations programs. When he made his gift, Mr. Turner identified Mr. Soros as the philanthropist he most admired, and his role model returned the compliment.
In a telephone interview from Hong Kong at the time, Mr. Soros called Mr. Turner's gift "wonderful" and urged other wealthy people to emulate the example.
Mr. Soros said that he had spent the last two weeks touring Russia and that the new program reflected the needs he identified during his trip as well as an evaluation of what his foundation has already accomplished. He said that while his tour was "rather strenuous and in some ways frustrating," he believed that the Russian Government led by President Boris N. Yeltsin both needs and deserves Western confidence and assistance.
"I think this Government will be there for at least three years," Mr. Soros said, brushing aside reports that the Government could face a no-confidence vote in the Russian Parliament as early as Wednesday.
While acknowledging that rampant corruption and mismanagement have created a "precarious situation" for the Government, he said he doubted that it would collapse any time soon.
"But during the next three years, the Government must deliver if it wants reform to continue," he added.
In addition to his philanthropy, his Soros Fund Management, the principal investment adviser to the Quantum Group of Funds, based in Curacao, has invested more than $2.5 billion in Russian business, making him the leading Western investor in that country. Mr. Soros said yesterday that he intended to continue investing in Russia as a sign of confidence in the country's leadership, despite controversy among rival investors stemming from his decision to mix philanthropy and investment there.
Mr. Soros has emotional ties to Russia, where his father was imprisoned during World War I. As a child in Hungary, he said in a speech this month in Moscow, he came to know Russian culture and greatly respected its literary traditions and the determination of its people to survive all kinds of oppression. He began his philanthropy in Russia in 1987, before the collapse of the Soviet Union.
He is an American citizen who escaped the Nazis as a Jewish adolescent in Budapest and emigrated to the United States in 1956, after graduating from the London School of Economics.
Mr. Soros's international investments have come under fire, particularly from Mahathir Mohamad, the Prime Minister of Malaysia. He has repeatedly accused Mr. Soros of mounting politically motivated attacks on his region's currencies, which Mr. Soros has denied.
During the summer, Mr. Soros shut down his foundation in Belarus after Aleksandr Lukashenko, the popular but autocratic Belarusian President, fined a Soros foundation $3 million for alleged tax violations and seized its bank account.
In the United States, Mr. Soros has been harshly criticized for programs that challenge the nation's antidrug laws and other controversial government programs.
But the growing pressure on Mr. Soros's philanthropic empire -- which stretches from South Africa to Haiti, employs more than 1,300 people and has regional offices in New York and Budapest -- appears only to have stiffened his resolve to promote political pluralism and economic reform.
This year alone, he opened five new offices in Central Asia and another in Guatemala and announced plans for nine new foundations in southern Africa, which would expand the number of countries with Soros foundations to 40.
Given his growing personal fortune, which friends estimate at $5 billion although he has not commented on his wealth, he says his efforts are likely to continue at current levels for at least a decade, and perhaps for two.
Mr. Soros said that the details of the new programs for Russia were still being worked out, but that all of the money, which will total a minimum of $300 million and as much as $500 million in the next three years, would be channeled through his Open Society Institute -- Russia. He was forced to restructure the foundation and to replace its leaders last year after discovering that employees were diverting foundation funds into Swiss bank accounts and using them to buy luxury cars.
"The foundation is now operating very efficiently," Mr. Soros said.
Donna Shalala, President Clinton's Secretary of Health and Human Services, said she was informed of Mr. Soros's prospective gift several weeks ago. She said the Russian Health Ministry was among the more "efficient" Government agencies and predicted that the Yeltsin Government would use the money well. "It's the right gift at the right time," Ms. Shalala said.
Mr. Soros said some of the health care money would be used to set up three to five demonstration sites offering cost-efficient programs to detect and treat tuberculosis, both in prisons and in the general population. Another new project will diagnose and treat drug-resistant bacteria, a leading cause of death in Russian hospitals and what he called "a major health threat not only in Russia but throughout the world."
Health problems in Russia rival those of the poorest African countries. Tuberculosis, for instance, is rampant, affecting an estimated 10 percent of the more than one million people in prisons and labor camps. Only one child in five is born healthy, according to official data, which many experts say understate the problem.
Since 1992, the average life expectancy for men has fallen from 62 years to 59 and is still falling -- as it is for women, though more slowly. No country that reports to the World Health Organization has a life expectancy as low. The death rate has risen by 20 percent, an increase without modern precedent, doctors say.

HEADLINE: France vs. U.S.: Warring Versions of Capitalism

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Anti-Americanism is an old theme here, almost a ritual, one that Prime Minister Lionel Jospin rehearsed recently when he declared that America could not impose its laws on the world and that "ultra-capitalism" was unacceptable.
What was surprising, though, was to find the new American Ambassador to Paris, Felix Rohatyn, agreeing with him. Not, of course, on the question of new French investments in Iran -- the subject that gave Mr. Jospin the occasion for his gibes -- but on the broader issue of American economic domination. 
 "We have no monopoly on ideas," Mr. Rohatyn said here the other day. "We do not believe that what works for us is automatically the best approach for anyone else." And as if to quash forever galloping French fears of an American "ultra-capitalist" system engulfing the globe, Mr. Rohatyn declared roundly: "There is no such thing as the American economic model."
These self-deprecatory remarks, made at the French Institute of International Relations, had a quite different ring from what was said just three months ago, at the Denver summit of major industrial powers. There, it was precisely America's unabashed vaunting of its economic successes and its exhortation to its European allies to follow its free-market recipes that led the French President, Jacques Chirac, to talk huffily about defending "our model."
The clash at Denver underscored the fact that the old sparring that strained but never undid an old alliance has gained a new edge, and a different scope, as France has set itself up as perhaps the nearest thing the United States has to a serious ideological rival in the last decade of the 20th century.
There used to be, of course, a shared enemy: the Soviet Union. Measured against that totalitarian power, the systems in America and France clearly had more in common than set them apart. France may identify the universal message of its Revolution with equality where Americans embrace liberty, but not even the French wanted to be equal on Soviet terms.
The situation has changed. Now that nobody wants to abolish capitalism, and its different forms lie at the heart of the global ideological debate, France and America offer two models whose different merits may be argued. The countries have been freed to explore their differences.
And differences there are: France has vastly better public medicine than America, safer cities, higher minimum wages, less crime and more job security, particularly in its huge state sector.
But it also has a 12.6 percent unemployment rate that is more than double the American, much higher taxes, a long-stagnant economy, crippling social security charges that discourage hiring, scant venture capital and a debilitating anxiety about change that has held back its investment in new technologies.
Which sort of society do you prefer? That is the essence of the debate that has raged here throughout this year and whose core question is: How much, if any, of French solidarity and social protection should be given up to achieve the faster growth and job-creation of the United States?
Unfortunately, the debate has tended to be argued in terms of caricature, increasing resentments between the countries that have then compounded real, if manageable, differences over their roles in Africa, Iran and elsewhere.
Here in France, the image of America generally presented is in some ways an echo of what the Soviets once drew: one of growing urban ghettos, overcrowded prisons, 19th-century wages and galloping capitalist cruelty. It is not uncommon to hear economists declare simply that the American system has failed.
In the United States, the French are almost uniformly presented as clinging stubbornly to archaic socialist ideals even as their unemployment rate climbs close to 13 percent and a wired world passes them by. It is not the merits of French public medicine that gain attention but the silliness of French strikers.
"The old Franco-American antagonism, the almost genetic rivalry, has been aggravated," said Jean Baudrillard, a sociologist. "The idea of a French exception, a French difference, is absurd, but a certain American triumphalism and our own relative decline has turned the idea into an obsession."
The new tone of Mr. Rohatyn, a former partner of the Lazard Freres investment firm in New York who took up his new post last month, was clearly intended to get beyond these obsessions and the accompanying caricatures.
If France was troubled by Medicare cuts, and if it does not want globalization to mean the relentless erosion of workers' rights, well, Mr. Rohatyn intimated, these were themes with which the Clinton Administration could sympathize.
He spoke of the need for fairness in the distribution of wealth, the need to promote "social values," the problems of big cities and crime, and the quest to insure "adequate retirement for our aging populations." In short, he seemed to make a limited defense of the very welfare state France is so determined to safeguard.
"The American in me is very pleased with our economic performance," said Mr. Rohatyn, who was born in Vienna. "The European in me understands your ambivalence about some of the choices that have been necessary to return to economic health."
The day after he spoke, Hubert Vedrine, the French Foreign Minister, made remarks that were perhaps even more surprising. To a group of foreign correspondents, he declared, with disarming frankness: "We are a country that has trouble facing up to the reality of the world."
It was no good, Mr. Vedrine said, to have excessive pretensions -- to wallow in the old, rankling talk about the universality of French civilization and its values; the notion of occupying a position close to the center of the world; the harkening after past glory. "There is," he said, "something unhealthy in all that."
What was needed instead was a new realism, he said. And realism led France inexorably to the fact that there was only one superpower: the United States. To imagine otherwise was only to invite the terrible fits of melancholy that have periodically overcome France in the last year.
France, Mr. Vedrine continued, was still very important, one of a group of perhaps seven countries -- including Russia, China, Japan, Britain and Germany -- with the power to have an influence throughout the world. It was firmly allied with the United States, but that did not mean it would always agree with America.
"France is not at the center of the world," he said, "but that is not a reason to despair. Let us try to have relations with the United States that are normal, calm, dispassionate and useful."
This new tone on both sides appears closer to the nuanced reality behind the caricatures. For it is not in fact so much America that is forcing France to reconsider its welfare state but the pressures of a European integration of which France is a chief architect.
France has freed capital movements, sold off swathes of state industry, embraced budget austerity and made a strong franc a pillar of its policies because the opening of European borders and the push for a single European currency, the euro, have required such changes. But it is much easier to market these changes -- and Mr. Jospin continues to push them -- behind a veneer of anti-American statements than to dwell on what the euro means for France.
Similarly, the talk of the defense of "a French model of civilization" against the American masks the fact that the French private sector shows every sign of embracing a rugged American capitalism complete with storming corporate raiders.
In recent weeks, multibillion-dollar hostile takeover bids have been the talk of the bourse, as one giant supermarket chain tried to swallow two others and the rags-to-riches financier Francois Pinault bid $5 billion for the heart of the financial establishment, Worms & Cie. The fact that American pension funds are among the biggest investors in French companies suggests that the France-as-basket-case image is more than a little simplistic.
Moreover, French popular culture has embraced the American in a way not paralleled in Britain or Germany. The reversed baseball cap, basketball shoes, American movies and music -- these are the frame of reference of a majority of French kids. The anti-Americanism glibly wheeled out by intellectuals and politicians finds little echo among ordinary French people.
But this remains a people that wants to dream -- "to aim for the ideal and understand the real," as the socialist Jean Jaures once said. It is the legacy of the Revolution of 1789: the idea of a perfectible society, of equality and freedom reconciled, of what the historian Francois Furet called "a universal promise of earthly well-being."
In the same remarks that poured scorn on America's attempt to legislate for the world, Mr. Jospin outlined his own notions of "earthly well-being." He talked of his plans to institute a 35-hour work week in France in place of the current 39-hour week without a loss of salary. Thus, he suggested, more jobs would be created as the cake would be divided among more people.
Such ideas naturally make many Americans smile, laugh out loud or despair. They seem to confirm notions of the French basket-case.
But Mr. Jospin has proved a shrewd politician. He is as pragmatic as his Foreign Minister. He knows that without ideals and enemies, the French cannot function, and that a small dose of anti-Americanism is a useful camouflage for the changes that are inexorably bringing French society closer to the American.
Mr. Rohatyn -- and the Clinton Administration -- now seem equally aware of the need for camouflage: by questioning American economic failings, and implicitly flattering the French, they may actually encourage change faster than through confrontation.

HEADLINE: Immigration Law's Fine Print Emerges, Setting Off a Debate About Welfare Provisions

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

 BODY:
On Dec. 19, the Government will begin enforcing a new law that will make it more difficult for poor and working-class immigrants living legally in the United States to have members of their families immigrate to join them.
The law will require an income test for the half a million legal immigrants and citizens who annually seek to bring relatives to the United States. Research sponsored by the Government found that 30 percent of the sponsors of immigrants would not have passed the new income test. 
 Under the new law, the sponsoring relatives will generally be required to prove that they earn 125 percent of the poverty level, or $20,062 this year for a family of four.
Forty pages of rules spelling out how the law will be applied and when it takes effect will be published today in The Federal Register.
The new law also requires the sponsoring families to sign contracts to support the newcomers and to reimburse the Government if their relatives receive welfare benefits.
But the new rules limit the definition of such public aid to the major anti-poverty programs -- food stamps, Medicaid and income supports for low-income families and for poor people who are elderly or disabled.
The new reimbursement requirement will have little impact for at least a few years because the welfare law adopted last year made most legal immigrants who enter the country after August 1996 ineligible for the major Federal anti-poverty programs for at least five years.
The rules exempt the sponsoring families from reimbursing the Government if their relatives use a range of smaller programs, including school lunches, Head Start, foster care, student loans and emergency medical care.
Before the new law was passed, there was no income requirement for families sponsoring their relatives, nor had the courts found sponsors' general promises to support relatives to be legally enforceable.
Typically, able-bodied immigrants who showed proof that they had a job waiting for them in the United States were not required to have sponsors who promised to support them indefinitely.
The new rules drew sharp criticism on Friday from an author of the law, Representative Lamar Smith, Republican of Texas and chairman of the House immigration subcommittee, who said the Clinton Administration had defined the liability of sponsoring families too narrowly and should have defined welfare benefits more broadly.
"The effect of the Administration's groundless interpretation will be to relieve immigrants' sponsors of all responsibility to repay the taxpayers for a vast set of welfare benefits," Mr. Smith said.
But Federal officials said their interpretation of which welfare benefits were covered was consistent with both the law and Congressional intent. They included programs in which benefits are based on recipients' incomes and spending is mandated by Congress. Programs like Head Start, whose financing is discretionary, were not included.
The Clinton Administration opposed the new income test for sponsors, but it supported the requirement that sponsors sign contracts to support their relatives.
Despite their disagreement over the definition of welfare benefits, both the Congressional authors of the provision and Clinton Administration officials say the law, part of the immigration bill adopted in September 1996, sends an important signal to immigrants that their sponsoring families are responsible for supporting them.
Under the guidelines, sponsors will have to commit to supporting immigrant relatives until the new arrivals have become citizens, worked for 10 years in this country, left the United States permanently or died. If the immigrants receive welfare benefits, state and local government agencies will be able to sue their sponsors for reimbursement.
Advocates for immigrants and some scholars say the income test will have unnecessarily harsh consequences and is likely to backfire. It will prevent many poor and working-class immigrants and citizens who do not meet the new test from legally bringing in relatives even though those relatives would be unlikely to wind up on welfare under the new welfare law, they said. And it will encourage wives, children and others who want to be reunited with their families in this country to come illegally, the critics of the income test say.
"It's another example of the law of unintended consequences," said Thomas Espenshade, a sociology professor at Princeton University. "It's particularly perverse because Congress has long set as its objective to preserve legal immigration and reduce the number of immigrants coming illegally."
The new income test will make it extremely difficult for immigrants who work in the underground economy and do not pay taxes to bring in relatives, even if the relative has a job offer here.
For example, some farm workers, day laborers and sweatshop workers may have trouble qualifying as sponsors. The new guidelines state that sponsors must provide income tax returns for the past three years to establish their income.
The new law is also likely to hit Mexicans and Salvadorans hard because their incomes are generally lower than those of other groups, according to research sponsored by the Immigration and Naturalization Service that has not yet been released. The analysis of a random survey of 2,160 statements signed by sponsors of family immigrants in 1994 found that roughly half of Mexicans and Salvadorans would not have met the new requirement.
A third of Dominicans and Koreans, a fourth of Chinese and Jamaicans and a fifth of Filipinos, Indians and Vietnamese would not have met the requirement, say several people familiar with the survey, including both critics and supporters of the new law. Over all, the survey found that 3 immigrants in 10 had incomes below the new standard.
Similarly, a study of 1993 Census Bureau data by the Urban Institute, a nonprofit research group in Washington, found that 40 percent of immigrant families and a quarter of Americans born in the United States would not make enough to sponsor an immigrant.
But it is impossible to predict how many prospective immigrants will be excluded because the guidelines provide two ways that poor families can bring in their relatives, even if the head of household alone does not earn enough to qualify.
Family members who have lived in the sponsoring household for at least six months can pool their earnings to reach the income standard, though each person must then sign a contract promising to help support the newcomer.
The family is also allowed to find an employer, friend or relative who is not part of the household to co-sponsor the immigrant. Again, the co-sponsor has to sign a contract to support the immigrant in hard times.
Advocates for immigrants say that families who are considering sponsoring relatives fear that the new rules can spell financial ruin in extreme circumstances and play havoc with relations within families.
What if a relative develops a catastrophically expensive illness after arriving? What if a husband brings in his wife, and she leaves him for another man? Under the guidelines, divorce does not release a sponsor from the responsibility to support a former spouse. In fact, immigrants can sue their sponsors for financial support under the new rules.
The immigration service says it will keep computer records on the estimated 565,000 immigrants who will be sponsored annually by family members and will make this information available to state and Federal agencies that provide welfare benefits.
Sponsoring relatives will be required to notify the immigration service if they move. Sponsors who fail to send in a change of address form can be fined $250 to $2,000, or up to $5,000 if they know that a relative they sponsored has received welfare benefits.

HEADLINE: Once AT&T Names New Leader, Climb Back to Top Will Be Tough

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
When the AT&T Corporation names a new leader, it will be a long-awaited move in the company's effort to regain unquestioned leadership of one of America's fastest-growing industries.
The company, which hired a presumed heir apparent for the top job last year only to reject him nine months later, is now widely expected to appoint C. Michael Armstrong, the head of Hughes Electronics, as AT&T's new chairman and chief executive. That announcement could come as soon as today. 
 With its management in turmoil and its financial results eroding along with its share of the telecommunications market, AT&T is under increasing pressure to bring in a new leader as many smaller competitors are moving quickly to steal its customers. Indeed, when the company reports its latest quarterly financial results today, profits are expected to be significantly lower than those of the comparable period last year.
"The industry is at a crossroads and every day there seems to be an industry-changing deal," said Jack Grubman, a telecommunications analyst for Salomon Brothers, the Wall Street investment house. "And nobody, no matter how big, is immune to seeing their competitive position threatened by the changing of the landscape."
Mr. Armstrong, who is 59, would instantly become one of the nation's most closely watched corporate executives. Analysts and colleagues described Mr. Armstrong's tenure at Hughes as one marked by extraordinary intensity and brilliant salemanship. Page D1.
Even though AT&T has been split up twice since the early 1980's -- the first time under Government pressure, the second on its own initiative -- the company's shares remain the most widely owned in the country, the quintessential "widows and orphans" stock counted on by millions of Americans to deliver a reliable dividend and steady growth.
And while the dividend checks have not stopped coming, AT&T's financial path has been anything but steady of late. That is why, in the minds of telecommunications experts, the next year or two will be crucial in setting the company's long-term course.
"With AT&T, they still have vestiges of a great franchise and brand name," Mr. Grubman said. "But if I'm Michael Armstrong or anybody else coming into this job I have to answer four questions. One, what is my local strategy? Two, what is my international strategy? Three, how do I get my data capabilities up to snuff? And four, what do I do when the Bells come into my market and threaten my profitability?
"Those are four questions that frankly should have been addressed already and they haven't," Mr. Grubman said. "How the new team answers those four questions will determine the future of the company."
Word of a new leader for AT&T comes as the MCI Communications Corporation, the No. 2 long-distance telephone company behind AT&T and one of its most important rivals, has been at the center of a recent torrent of takeover efforts in the telecommunications industry.
By contrast, AT&T, despite tentative discussions in the last year with the GTE Corporation and abortive merger talks last summer with SBC Communications, a regional Bell company, has remained primarily on the sidelines as other companies scramble for partners to offer more, better and different kinds of communications services.
From plain old telephone service, to the Internet, to new sorts of advanced wireless systems, telecommunications services have become one of the main engines of the American economy. But AT&T's is no longer the main hand on the throttle.
AT&T has been looking for a new head since July, when John R. Walter, who had been brought in as the designated successor to AT&T's long-time chairman, Robert E. Allen, resigned after barely nine months with the company. As he departed, an AT&T board member publicly stated that Mr. Walter, who had previously been chief executive of the commercial printing giant, R. R. Donnelley & Sons, lacked the "intellectual leadership" to ascend to the top job at AT&T.
Even before Mr. Walter's appointment last October, Mr. Armstrong, the head of the Hughes unit of General Motors and a highly regarded executive, was known to be a leading candidate to succeed Mr. Allen. But he reportedly balked at Mr. Allen's plan to remain as chairman and chief executive for a transitional period -- a condition Mr. Walter accepted. This time, AT&T is expected to give the titles to Mr. Allen's designated successor immediately.
AT&T would not comment yesterday and telephone calls to Mr. Armstrong over the weekend were not returned. But reports of his impending appointment have circulated since Friday, and an executive familiar with Mr. Armstrong's plans said he understood that Mr. Armstrong had agreed to take the AT&T job.
The industry's mad scramble is a result of the Telecommunications Act of 1996. The law was meant to unleash the biggest changes in the communications industry since the court-enforced divestiture in 1984 that left AT&T as the long-distance telephone company still bearing the company's name while it spun off its local phone monopolies into seven regional Bell companies.
After some consolidation there are now five regional Bells -- Ameritech, Bell Atlantic, BellSouth, SBC Communications and U S West -- and the Telecommunications Act allows them to offer long-distance service within their regions for the first time, provided they meet a regulatory checklist. AT&T, meanwhile, is free to return to the local phone business -- though few antitrust experts believe that the Government would allow the company to do so by, say, acquiring a Bell company.
Still, telecommunications analysts are almost unanimous in the belief that AT&T's long-term future could hinge on its ability to exploit its local-market opportunities.
The $100 billion local telephone business offers much higher profit margins than those in long distance. And in any case, whether AT&T succeeds or falters as a local service provider, the regional Bells are expected to grab from 10 percent to 40 percent of the $80 billion long-distance market in the next few years -- much of that at AT&T's expense.
"The perversity, the irony, of AT&T's current situation can be traced back to the fact that it doesn't have any local franchise," said Bryan Van Dussen, an analyst for the Yankee Group, a high-technology research company in Boston.
"The root causes of AT&T's challenges are its fragmented, disjointed and inefficient local-market capability," he said. "As 'location, location, location' is to real estate, 'local access, local access, local access' is the key to the future of telecom."
But AT&T has yet to make an aggressive move into local markets. Part of the reason is that a Federal court rejected the Federal Communications Commission's highly technical rules giving competitors access to the existing local telephone networks. The F.C.C. has taken its appeal to the Supreme Court.
But at least as important as the regulatory uncertainty, analysts say, has been the apparent inability of AT&T's management to decide whether they want to lease local access, build the company's own local links or employ some combination of those two approaches.
"They have not been quick enough, they have not been agile enough to take advantage of the opportunities," said Eric Strumingher, an analyst for Paine Webber. "You can fault lack of leadership, an overly bureaucratic organization, a lack of people who are willing to take a risk and have a sense of urgency to get something done."
Mr. Armstrong is mostly an unknown quantity among Wall Street's telephone fraternity, but he brings a reputation as a manager who can reorient companies quickly to take advantage of small windows of opportunity. "Given Michael Armstrong's track record, they may be able to pull together very quickly," said Linda Meltzer, an analyst for UBS Securities.
Many analysts suggest that AT&T's best option to enter local markets may be to acquire a small competitive local phone company, like Teleport Communications Group, that has been taking on the Bells and winning a fair number of big-spending business accounts.
Mr. Armstrong's ability to move fast could also prove especially important as AT&T tries to assert itself in the market for Internet service and other kinds of high-speed data communications.
AT&T has not had as high a profile on the Internet as MCI or the Sprint Corporation, the No. 3 long-distance company, both of which are major providers of high-capacity Internet "backbone" networks used by private corporations and on-line service operators. And if Worldcom Inc. succeeds in fending off GTE and winning the battle to acquire MCI, Worldcom -- already a big Internet player itself -- will control a majority of Internet traffic.
"If there was one market that was about to happen that AT&T should have been leading, it should have been the Internet," Mr. Van Dussen said. "And AT&T has been fairly slow to get into the corporate data communications market as well.
"AT&T is still the old AT&T, despite its efforts to be the new one," he said. "And management has to take much of the responsibility for that. If there's going to be a change, maybe it will help."

The constant changes have created uncertainty at AT&T at a time when competition, both nationally and internationally, has become intense and mergers and takeovers are realigning the industry. HEADLINE: McGreevey Is Running on Record as Mayor

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: WOODBRIDGE TOWNSHIP, Oct. 19

 BODY:
The day after James E. McGreevey took over as Mayor of this sprawling suburban town on Jan. 1, 1992, two Federal agents arrived at his office unannounced to investigate the disappearance of $650,000 in health insurance funds during the previous administration.
It was far from being the only problem that Mr. McGreevey says he discovered in his first days on the job. Four town employees were also accused of taking kickbacks from a contractor. About $400,000 in uncashed checks made out to the township was found in a desk drawer. And his advisers estimated that there was a $24.5 million gap in the town's $60 million budget for the coming year. 
 "It was an utter disaster," Mr. McGreevey recalled in a recent interview. "The good news was that you could only go up from there."
Now, as Mr. McGreevey, the Democratic gubernatorial nominee, wages his campaign against Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, he frequently points to his six years as mayor as evidence that he has the experience to govern the state.
He says he cleaned up a mismanaged and corrupt government and brought in a more businesslike approach. His campaign aides say he kept property taxes under control while maintaining the same level of services. If elected, he said, he would run the state the way he ran the township.
By most accounts, Mayor McGreevey did restore confidence and fiscal stability. A review of state and town records, along with interviews with dozens of residents, business leaders, and government officials, supports much of what he says.
"There was a time when you didn't want to pick up the newspaper," said Frank G. Pelzman, a Democrat who has served on the township council for 10 years. "Every time you picked it up there was bad news in it for Woodbridge. Jim McGreevey has turned this town around."
Mr. McGreevey said his biggest achievement was putting the township back on firm financial footing. It came at a cost to taxpayers, not from significantly higher property taxes or deep cuts in services, but from $34.6 million in borrowing during his first year in office.
The borrowing, which was intended to cover what Mr. McGreevey said was a $24.5 million budget gap, and a shift in the start of the town's fiscal year from January to July will cost taxpayers $55 million to $60 million over 19 years. The township's outstanding debt has risen to $111 million, from $65 million when Mr. McGreevey took office.
The increased debt prompted Robert F. Gawroniak, 66, a former Democratic Councilman who served two years on the council after Mr. McGreevey took office, to switch to the Republicans and volunteer for the Whitman campaign.
"He sold us on the idea by exaggerating the problem," Mr. Gawroniak said. "There was no $24.5 million deficit. They told us that taxpayers would have to make up the difference, and if I didn't vote for it, some would lose their homes. Now our town is carrying all of this debt."
Mr. McGreevey defended his handling of the town's fiscal woes by saying the previous administration had emptied surplus accounts, overestimated state aid and failed to budget enough money for a costly labor agreement and pending tax appeals.
The problem was aggravated, he said, because the previous Democratic mayor, Joseph DeMarino, had cut the municipal tax rate in 1991 by 20 percent as an election-year ploy, making it difficult for the new administration to balance the books.
It had been a bitter mayoral campaign between Mr. McGreevey and Mr. DeMarino, Just months before the primary, Mr. DeMarino was indicted on charges of bribing two council members in a nearby town. He lost the primary, but stayed in the race as an independent. Even though Mr. DeMarino was acquitted before Election Day, Mr. McGreevey, then a 33-year-old lawyer and one-term Assemblyman, defeated him and a Republican opponent in the general election.
As Mayor, Mr. McGreevey has also angered some residents by imposing fees on some municipal services that had been free for years, like picking up old refrigerators. But Mr. McGreevey and his top aides point out that the $30 fee was an example of smart management that the state government should emulate.
"When we had special garbage pickups, we had people from outside the town, from all over the area, dropping off their trash for free pickup here," said John E. McCormac, the town's chief financial officer. "After we instituted the fee, we cut special pickups by 80 percent. We raised $30,000 in fees and saved $160,000 in tipping fees. All with one minimal fee."
In some ways, Mr. McGreevey and Mrs. Whitman share the same approach to running government. He sounds almost like a Republican when he talks about the fiscal controls and cost reductions his administration has imposed in the last six years to hold the property tax rate to a few cents above what it was in 1990.
Most services have been maintained, but changes have been made to cut costs. The town now pays Middlesex County to operate its transit program for the elderly. One township pool was closed after repairs were deemed too costly. Another pool was turned over to the local Young Men's Christian Association to run. Three branch libraries were closed, but two are now being operated as reading rooms by community and church groups.
Mr. McGreevey said his record as Mayor showed that he could do more than fill potholes. He created an economic development corporation that he said had brought 1,800 jobs and $800,000 in tax revenue. Both violent crime and property crime have decreased since Mr. McGreevey took office, in line with state and national trends.
A mix of residential neighborhoods, shopping malls and industrial sites, Woodbridge is the fifth-largest town in New Jersey. There are 10 distinctive communities, each with its own ZIP code and fire house. Because the Garden State Parkway and New Jersey Turnpike intersect in the township, local officials call it "the crossroads of New Jersey." The Chamber of Commerce, though, calls it "the crossroads of the world."
According to the 1990 census, 82 percent of Woodbridge Township's 93,000 residents are white, 20 percent have at least a college education and two of three are homeowners. The median household income was $45,516 in 1990, slightly higher than the statewide average of $40,927. Democrats outnumber Republicans by a ratio of 2 to 1, but most voters are unaffiliated. In the 1993 race for governor, Gov. Jim Florio outdrew Mrs. Whitman here by only 39 votes.
Throughout this community, there is visible evidence of improvements since Mr. McGreevey took office. Main Street, like many others in New Jersey, had fallen on hard times. The pavement was broken. Trees had not been pruned. There were vacant storefronts. Now Main Street is dotted with old-fashioned lamp posts, new red-brick sidewalks, vendor kiosks and park benches. A microbrewery and a coffee house recently opened.
"Mr. McGreevey and City Hall are really trying hard to get a good mix of business in the downtown," said Lee J. Neves, 51, owner of Neves Jewelers and president of the Woodbridge Downtown Merchants and Property Owners Association. "They somehow get the job done."
More than $1 million was spent to restore the Woodbridge train station. A pedestrian promenade has been built in Sewaren, along the waterfront at the Arthur Kill. And the old Town Hall was torn down and replaced with a $15 million municipal complex that opened last year.
But Mr. DeMarino, the former mayor, said Mr. McGreevey could not take all the credit for the improvements. He said the plans had been under way before Mr. McGreevey arrived. Mr. McGreevey said, however, that he was the one who saw the plans through to completion.
While Mr. McGreevey may win high marks from many residents and business leaders for cleaning up town government and hiring competent officials, it is striking how many of those officials have close ties to the Democratic Party. The town's law director since 1992 is Paul R. Weiner, a law partner of State Senator Raymond J. Lesniak of Elizabeth, who is the former chairman of the State Democratic Committee and now a top fund-raiser for Mr. McGreevey's gubernatorial campaign.
Labor matters are handled by a law firm headed by Angelo J. Genova, a lawyer for the State Democratic Committee. One of two financial advisers for the township's $34.6 million borrowing was Consolidated Financial Management, the company founded by Joseph C. Salema, who was chief of staff to Mr. Florio when he was Governor.
But what some residents say most bothers them about Mr. McGreevey is that he broke a campaign promise in 1991 to serve as a full-time mayor. A year after he was sworn in, Mr. McGreevey won election to the State Senate.
"I often wonder who is running the town," said Barbara A. Wyatt, a lifelong Republican who is vice president of the township's library board. "Two years after he first ran for mayor, he ran for the Senate, and now is campaigning for the governorship. I don't know if we have gotten our money's worth in terms of a full-time mayor. He tells you that he works 72 hours a week, but I think that is to cultivate a constituency for his next step."
Mr. McGreevey's decision to hold two elective offices has apparently not angered everybody. He captured 70 percent of the vote when he ran for re-election as mayor in 1995. And as he makes his fifth run for office in eight years, he can depend on local voters to be firmly in his column.
Mr. McGreevey says town residents support him because they are treated like customers. He describes himself as a disciple of Stephen Covey, the management consultant who wrote "7 Habits of Highly Effective People." Mr. McGreevey said that he abided by Covey's principles emphasizing hard work, integrity and measureable goals.
"It is a credo," said Mr. McGreevey, who arranged Covey management seminars for his staff after attending several himself. "I am result oriented and result driven. You need to understand where we want to be and how we are going to get there. You need to create a mission-driven organization with specific goals and a plan to implement them."
The township government has its own mission statement, and the directors of various departments must report weekly on their progress toward goals outlined earlier in the year. Mr. McGreevey's staff keeps computer records of taxpayers' complaints to help insure that their concerns are met by multiple city departments if necessary, and to help detect patterns that might suggest recurring or developing problems.
But the Mayor said that some complaints got his special attention even during the campaign. Last Friday, he opened a letter that began "Dear Jimmy." It was from an elderly resident who explained that she had waited in line to pick up free biodegradable bags from the township for its mandatory leaf collection program, only to be told that there were no bags left. It was a cost-saving measure that did not generate as many protests as had been expected. It saves about $250,000 annually in overtime costs and landfill fees.
To address what he called his "customer's concern," Mr. McGreevey said that he asked the public works department to deliver the free bags to the woman's home. "We went the extra mile because, frankly, we ought to have been there," Mr. McGreevey said. "I did not want her to have to come back. That's what makes the difference."

HEADLINE: Goals Clash in Shielding Privacy

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
Senator Dianne Feinstein was dismayed last year when it took only three minutes to get her confidential Social Security number, like millions of others, from an on-line look-up service available to Internet users around the world.
"People are losing control over their own identities," Ms. Feinstein, a California Democrat, told Congress in April as she introduced the Personal Information Privacy Act, a bill to limit the circulation and sale of Social Security numbers without the individual's written consent. 
 That measure is now one of at least 40 privacy bills pending in Congress, a flotilla launched by legislators on a rising tide of public concern about the loss of privacy in an electronic age. Some are modest, like a postal code amendment that would let people stop the post office from selling their change of address to direct marketers. Some are ambitious, like legislation to govern how the health care industry handles personal medical information.
But with few exceptions, the proposals seem to be going nowhere. Beneath the surface of their popular appeal, most are mired in unresolved conflicts over contradictory goals: on the one hand, preserving personal privacy, and on the other, the advantages of quick, computerized access to personal information for fighting crime, fraud and waste, or promoting growth in the information economy.
Ms. Feinstein herself illustrates the deep ambivalence behind the stalemate. To combat illegal immigration, for example, she proposed requiring all employers to telephone a high-tech national database and punch in the Social Security number of every job applicant. The plan has been denounced by privacy advocates as "1-800-Big-Brother."
To curb the use of counterfeit identity documents, Ms. Feinstein urged adoption of a "biometric" ID card and database with the digital fingerprints, retinal eye scans or voice patterns of all eligible workers and benefit recipients in the United States. And to fight voter fraud, she favored a bill that would require anyone registering to vote in a Federal election to provide their Social Security number.
Such a requirement would make the numbers part of the public record and, critics say, more accessible than ever.
"Everybody wants to have it both ways," said Robert Gellman, a lawyer and privacy expert in Washington. "Nobody is willing to pay the price for privacy."
Until a scandal erupts, many people remain unaware of the growing amounts of computer-gathered information that could jeopardize their privacy. But legislation drafted in response to such scandals is often watered down by opposition from business or law enforcement, weakened by exemptions, and finally shelved with general ambivalence about its broader consequences.
Earlier this year, for instance, Mr. Gellman headed advisory hearings for the Clinton Administration on the disclosure of health care records without the patients' consent. Under current practice, the intimate details of almost anyone's treatment are available to hundreds of thousands of billing and insurance clerks at computer terminals across the country.
Everyone who testified, from industry officials to consumers, agreed that Federal restrictions were needed, Mr. Gellman said. Everyone agreed that individual consent for release of information was important to protect privacy. "And everyone," he added, "wanted to be exempt," citing such needs as cost containment, peer review and public health research.
In the end, a sweeping exemption giving access to law enforcement and intelligence agencies was written into the recommendations. It brought a storm of criticism from privacy advocates in Congress as well as powerful players in the health care industry.
"The members of Congress are ambivalent about privacy, as are all Americans," said Robert Ellis Smith, a privacy watchdog and publisher of The Privacy Journal.
The White House is no less ambivalent, said Alan Westin, a Columbia University law professor and consultant to Equifax, the credit-checking and medical records giant.
"The Clinton Administration now views privacy as a wonderful quality-of-life issue," Mr. Westin said. "But the Administration has come out in favor of self-regulation when it comes to the on-line world," partly out of fear of stifling commercial development of the Internet.
What Mr. Westin calls the classic tension between privacy and surveillance is illustrated by a law that was passed last year to establish a "new hires" database to help the Federal authorities find parents who fail to pay court-ordered child support.
The privacy consequences got little notice in the rush to embrace the plan, said David Banisar, a lawyer and policy analyst at the Electronic Privacy Information Center, an advocacy group in Washington, because it sounded like a way to cut welfare.
"People want privacy for themselves," Mr. Banisar said, "and of course they're not welfare recipients, so they don't care about that."
What many failed to grasp, he said, is that the database would include not only deadbeats but eventually also every working parent in the United States.
Mr. Gellman, the lawyer and privacy expert, sees a pattern.
"Set up a database for some hard-to-defeat purpose," he said, "add another use, and then everybody is selling records to private detectives."
Many private investigators increasingly rely not only on electronic databases but personal information bought in an underground market that includes telephone records, bills, even medical histories.
Already the purpose of the new-hires database shows signs of expansion: under a bill sponsored by Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, Democrat of Manhattan, the Treasury Department could use the database to collect delinquent Federal debts, like student loans.
Yet Ms. Maloney is also the sponsor of one of the 40 pending privacy bills, a proposal to insure that when Federal Bureau of Investigation records containing sensitive personal information are provided to the White House, they are properly protected for privacy and security.
Like some other privacy bills, it was drafted after a scandal, in this case the revelation that low-level aides in the Clinton White House had improperly obtained confidential F.B.I. files on more than 800 officials from previous Administrations.
A single horror story that attracts a burst of media attention has often prompted privacy legislation, though the affected industry usually scrambles to defuse the issue. Last year, for example, Lexis-Nexis, one of the nation's largest information brokers, began offering individual Social Security numbers, the key to vast amounts of personal and financial information. The company abandoned the service after a public outcry, but the publicity helped lead to Ms. Feinstein's information privacy bill, among others.
Another incident might help win passage of some version of pending bills on children's privacy. Several were introduced after a California television reporter, using the name of a notorious child killer, bought a list of households with young children from the Metromail Corporation, a leading supplier of direct mail information.
Few privacy advocates were satisfied with any of the resulting proposals, including one introduced by Ms. Feinstein, which would bar the collection and sale of children's personal information without written parental consent. Yet the children's privacy bill met strong and well-financed opposition from business interests like the Direct Marketing Association, the leading trade group.
The association, whose lobbyists include Tommy Boggs, one of the most influential in Washington, contends that market forces and industry self-policing are preferable to laws regulating commerce in personal information. After pressure from industry lobbyists, the Feinstein bill, for instance, was scaled back, so it would forbid selling lists of children only when the seller knows the data would be used for harm.
A bill to protect the privacy of genetic information seems to have the best chance of passage. Sponsored by Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, and Representative Louise M. Slaughter, Democrat of New York, the bill has a vocal, well-organized constituency: women, already galvanized by the issue of breast cancer, who fear discrimination from insurers and others if their genetic information predicts a greater likelihood of the disease.
Bills on data encryption, on the other hand, are locked in the kind of impasse that characterizes many Federal battles over privacy. The subject -- technology that scrambles private communications by telephone and computer -- makes most people's eyes glaze over. Yet on both sides of the issue, those close to the battle describe the stakes in apocalyptic terms.
The American Civil Liberties Union is trying to overcome both the lack of a broad-based privacy constituency and the traditionally patchwork, reactive approach to legislation. The effort is an ambitious campaign, called "Take Back Your Data," that seeks an omnibus privacy rights bill, said Don Haines, legislative counsel for the A.C.L.U.
The privacy effort has involved unusual political alliances. The coalition opposing the so-called 1-800-Big-Brother plan, for example, included the Christian Coalition, the National Rifle Association and the A.C.L.U. Because of strong opposition, the plan was scaled back but survived in the form of six pilot projects to be established later this year in California, New York, Illinois, Texas, Florida and Iowa.
Part of the frustration for privacy advocates, said Mr. Banisar of the Electronic Privacy Information Center, is that they find themselves spending much of their energy fending off the unintended consequences of other bills.
Some states have been quicker to pass tough privacy laws than Congress, but in every area, this fuels conflict over whether weaker Federal bills should pre-empt them.
"They've made us fight a lot of little privacy battles, and we've so far lost the war," said Edmund Mierzwinski, program director for the United States Public Interest Research Group, a consumer organization. "We have not been able to create the notion that privacy is a right. It's always an afterthought."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 24, 1997, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about pending privacy bills in Congress referred incorrectly to Equifax, a credit-checking company. It disbanded its health care information unit last year and is no longer in the medical records business.

HEADLINE: Israelis and Palestinians Nearer to Accord on Gaza Strip Airport

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Israeli and Palestinian negotiators said today that they were closer to agreement on the operation of a Palestinian airport in the Gaza Strip.
Israeli leaders also hinted at flexibility on Jewish settlements, suggesting they were willing to shelve new construction projects for a few months. They were the first signs of progress in negotiations after months of setbacks. 
 The United States envoy Dennis Ross returned to the Middle East on Sunday to supervise the work of the committees, and has been shuttling back and forth between the two sides. Mr. Ross met early today with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, but there was no statement after the closed session.
Emerging from talks later in the day with the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, Mr. Ross said the sessions involving American, Israeli and Palestinian officials were proving productive. "We are giving this a push," Mr. Ross said.
The status of the airport is being discussed by one of nine committees working on outstanding issues from accords that have already been signed. Opening the airport, which Palestinians envision will bring in a half-million passengers a year, is of enormous symbolic as well as practical importance to the Palestinians. Most of Gaza has been autonomous since May 1994, but Israel has maintained strict control over the airspace.
There were indications today that Israel might be softening its stance on settlement construction after a demand from the United States for a "time out" in new building. Foreign Minister David Levy told the Israeli radio that Israel would limit construction in Jewish settlements to a "necessary minimum."
"We want to move forward and not create a situation that would make all our efforts to advance the process irrelevant," he said.
Despite friction over the settlement issue, Israel said progress by the working committees was heartening.
"Chances are that we will continue to work in an intensified fashion and reach results fairly soon," said Eitan Ben-Tsur, the director general of Israel's Foreign Ministry.
Other issues being discussed include the establishment of a Palestinian seaport in Gaza and the creation of "safe passage" routes for Palestinians across Israeli territory between the Gaza Strip and the West Bank.
Security has been a major sticking point in airport talks. Israel fears militants could use the airport to smuggle in weapons or to flee. It has insisted that only nations that have flight agreements with Israel itself, such as Jordan and Morocco, be allowed to use the airport.

Peace Center Opens in Tel Aviv
 TEL AVIV, Oct.20 (Reuters) -- Scores of foreign statesmen and business leaders showed support for Middle East peace moves today at the inauguration of a new peace institute founded by the Israeli Nobel peace laureate Shimon Peres.
"Apparently we struck the right chord," said Mr. Peres, who is the architect of Israel's historic Oslo accords with the Palestinians.
 Mr. Peres, a former Labor Party Prime Minister, was defeated by Mr. Netanyahu in 1996.
The Peres Center for Peace is a private institute set up to promote peace through projects that foster economic opportunity.
Mr. Peres said: "If we wait, the cost of peace will not go down but if we wait the price of not having peace will go up. None of us want a sixth Middle East war."

HEADLINE: Pope's Trip to Cuba Pulls at Exiles

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

DATELINE: MIAMI, Oct.19

 BODY:
Elisa Flanigan-Chovel says she initially hesitated after hearing that the Archdiocese of Miami planned to take a cruise ship with American Catholics to Cuba for the Pope's visit in January. What would people say if she went? Would she be ostracized?
But the 49-year-old real estate agent decided that "the one that I ultimately have to answer to is God." She is going. 
 Bishop Agustin A. Roman, 69, an auxiliary bishop of the Archdiocese of Miami, is just as sure of his decision. Expelled from Cuba in 1961 with 129 other priests and a bishop, Bishop Roman says he supports the trip as a show of solidarity with Cuba's Catholic church and its people. But he is not going.
"I never wanted to leave Cuba," he said. "It's good that I remind the Government of Cuba that I'll never return until he who expelled me is gone himself."
The Pope's visit to Cuba, his first to that nation of 11 million people that was once predominantly Catholic, will likely draw the largest group of Cuban exiles to return at one time to the island since Fidel Castro assumed power in 1959. But the trip has posed a moral dilemma to many Catholic Cubans who are struggling to reconcile their political stance against Mr. Castro with a religious calling to follow their Pope's lead.
The church is for the first time prompting many to think about what once was unthinkable, returning to Cuba, however briefly, while the Government that caused their exile is still in charge.
The cruise ship sponsored by the Archdiocese of Miami, with capacity for 1,200 passengers, is expected to travel to Havana Jan. 23 to 26 to join Catholics there in welcoming Pope John Paul II. The travel agency handling the trip, Vision Travel in Coral Gables, said it had fielded calls from all over the country and Canada and had already booked 260 passengers in 145 of the ship's 528 cabins.
Several cities, including New York, are planning their own pilgrimages, by airplane.
Ticket sales for the cruise have been slower than predicted by Vision Travel when it began taking reservations on Oct. 7, partly because the cost of the trip, ranging from $599 to $1,399, depending on the accommodations, is nonrefundable.
Most of the interest on the trip, and opposition to it, has come from South Florida, where plans are under way for a protest flotilla to head for Cuba without permission during the Pope's visit and where conservative Cuban-American political leaders and Spanish-language radio have urged Cuban Catholics to stay home.
The hardliners, while not necessarily opposed to the Pope's visit, have been critical of the Archdiocese's sponsorship of the cruise ship because they regard it as setting a precedent for increased travel to Cuba and a weakening of the United States economic embargo. The cruise ship, however, would travel to Cuba under existing embargo rules that allow visits for "clearly defined educational or religious activities," a senior official with the Department of the Treasury said.
The debate ignores the close economic ties, both legal and illegal, that already exist between Cubans on the island and those here, notwithstanding the embargo. Cuban-Americans, for instance, are legally allowed to send up to $200 worth of food, medicine and other such items once a month. They are also permitted to visit relatives in Cuba once a year in cases of "extreme humanitarian need" like a medical emergency, but they must fly there from a country other than the United States. Sending cash is prohibited.
But a whole industry has grown around the illegal shipping of both cash and goods. Economic experts have estimated that Cubans receive as much as $800 million a year in contributions from individuals in the United States.
Some experts on Cuban affairs say that at the heart of the opposition to the trip is the basic conflict between how the Catholic church and much of the Cuban exile leadership view Cuba: The Vatican has long been for reconciliation between Cuban exiles and Cubans in the island and against the embargo; exile leaders are generally pro-embargo and in a state of war with Cuba.
"It poses a real contradiction" for Cuban-American Catholics, said Max Castro, a sociologist with the University of Miami's North-South Center, "if you take these values seriously and you believe in the church and the Pope."
But those going on the trip say the trip is not about politics but about supporting Cubans, who have suffered years of religious repression under socialist rule, in a renewal of their faith. For those like Mrs. Flanigan-Chovel, the cruise ship visit would mark her first return to Cuba since her family left the island in 1962 and cut all ties.
For others, like Eric Campillo, 29, a hospital case manager who left Cuba only two years ago, the trip is a chance to exercise his religion openly for the first time. He also hopes for political change.
"If this trip would make Fidel open up things a little more," Mr. Campillo said, "it would be worth it."
In interviews at several Catholic parishes, those who are refusing to go cited safety concerns in Cuba, grievances against the Cuban Government, like the confiscation of family property, and a general distaste for visiting an undemocratic country. Some were troubled by the Archdiocese's involvement in the trip.
"Let them just travel to Cuba as people do now but let's not have the church directly involved in an activity that inevitably has political overtones," said Antonio Jorge, an economics professor at Florida International University.
The Archdiocese of Miami is doing a delicate balancing act to avoid violating the embargo and straining already frayed emotions. Passengers on the chartered Norwegian Cruise Line ship must sign an affidavit stating the trip is solely for religious purposes and to abide by the embargo's regulations, which, for example, allow a visitor to spend no more than $100 a day.
Passengers will eat and sleep on the ship. The ship's casinos and discos will be closed and a number of vigils and liturgical ceremonies are planned during the four-day voyage, which is barely long enough to get to Cuba, attend the papal Mass in Havana and come back.
The trip is cast as a pilgrimage, not a tour, whose main purpose is to accompany the island's Catholics in a "spiritual journey."
"We join our voices in prayer," the Archbishop of Miami, John C. Favalora, wrote in a letter included in the application packet for those booking space on the ship, "that the Holy Father's visit to Cuba will touch the minds and hearts of all Cubans, wherever they may be, and help bring about that true peace built on justice that all Cubans of good will long for."
Cuban-American Catholics like Mrs. Flanigan-Chovel believe it will, and she wants to be a part of "one of the most important moments in the history of Cuba."
"I want my great-grandchildren to know that their great-grandmother was on that ship," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: AN EXILE GOING BACK -- After a moment of hesitation, Elisa Flanigan-Chovel, at her home in Coral Gables, Fla., decided to join an Archdiocese-sponsored ship cruise to Cuba in January to join Catholics on the island in welcoming Pope John Paul II on his first visit to that country. A BISHOP'S RESISTANCE -- While he supports the Catholic Church's planned cruise to Cuba in January to welcome the Pope, Bishop Agustin A. Roman, an auxiliary bishop of the Archdiocese of Miami, decided not to go because, he says, he will not visit his country as long as Fidel Castro, remains in power. HEADLINE: In a Step Toward a Better Electric Car, Company Uses Fuel Cell to Get Energy From Gasoline

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
The Energy Department and an engineering company plan to announce on Tuesday that they have produced electricity from gasoline through a new method that yields twice as much useful energy per gallon as a car engine does, and with pollution 90 percent lower.
The development raises the prospect of an electric car, still quiet, swift and clean, but without the problem of heavy batteries that must be recharged often. Instead, such a car would be refilled with energy in minutes from the pump at the corner gasoline station and get twice the gas mileage of a comparable car with an internal combustion engine. 
 "We have a terrific breakthrough here," said Federico F. Pena, the Secretary of Energy, in an interview. He said, however, that the technology was not about to go into immediate use. Such cars could be on the road by 2010, Mr. Pena said.
Other experts not directly involved with the new system praised it as an important technical achievement, although several pointed out that important steps remained before the method could be commercialized.
The method uses a fuel cell, a device first used by NASA for the Apollo moon program, that makes electric current by combining hydrogen and oxygen into water. Oxygen can be pulled out of air, but hydrogen has always been a problem, because it is expensive to produce and store.
The new method, developed by Arthur D. Little Inc., with $15 million from the Energy Department and technical aid from a nuclear bomb laboratory, is the first practical way to extract hydrogen efficiently and cleanly from gasoline, which is made of hydrocarbon molecules.
Mr. Pena said that because gasoline is available worldwide, auto makers could produce a new generation of ultra-clean vehicles that would achieve twice the fuel economy, without having to develop a new network of refineries, pipelines, trucks and service stations for a new fuel. That barrier has largely defeated efforts to wean America's 180 million cars from gasoline to methanol, ethanol or compressed natural gas.
The Chrysler Corporation has already announced that it wants to build a fuel-cell car that runs on gasoline. "A lot of people thought this was a crazy idea," said Christopher E. Borroni-Bird, a fuel-cell expert at Chrysler. "This shows it is technologically feasible." The Exxon Corporation and ARCO are also involved in fuel-cell research.
Making hydrogen from another chemical is called reforming. Some companies have reformers that process methanol, an easier task from a chemist's point of view because methanol is a simpler fuel than gasoline, but the reformer is too big for cars, and very few filling stations sell methanol. Fuel cells in fixed locations can use natural gas, but that is hard to load on vehicles, too.
Eugene Smotkin, a professor of chemical engineering at the Illinois Institute of Technology and an expert on fuel cells, said "reforming gasoline is quite a feat."
"We already have gasoline everywhere," he said. "If you can actually reform gasoline, to give you hydrogen, that would be ideal. The infrastructure is already there."
There are other ways to achieve high efficiency with reduced pollution, and the new technology will have to compete with them. Sheila A. Lynch, the executive director of the Northeast Alternative Vehicle Consortium, which backs electric and hybrid cars, pointed out that Toyota announced last week that it would soon sell a hybrid -- an electric car with a small gasoline engine to recharge the batteries -- and that it, too, doubled gasoline mileage. And, she said, a demonstration electric vehicle is scheduled to drive on Thursday from City Hall Plaza in Boston to the New York Academy of Sciences, more than 250 miles, on a single charge.
The vehicle, the Sunrise, which was built with grants from the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency and the National Institute for Standards and Technology, is ready for mass manufacturing, according to the builder, the Solectria Corporation of Arlington, Mass.
The A. D. Little system would be a step forward if it achieveed the efficiencies it claims, Ms. Lynch said, "but it does not mean we should wait around for many years to see if this technology is commercially viable."
A key question for a fuel-cell car is the cost of the fuel cell itself. Auto industry experts say they need a cell that costs $100 to $150 per kilowatt of capacity for such cars to be marketable, but existing models cost about $1,500. In contrast, conventional gasoline engines cost about $35 per horsepower, which works out to $50 a kilowatt. But engineers are confident that mass production will bring down prices.
The A. D. Little innovation, which was tested earlier this month, mixes oxygen with the gasoline fumes, breaking up the complex hydrocarbon molecules into H2 and carbon monoxide, which is a pollutant.
If carbon monoxide exceeds about 40 parts per million, it will poison the fuel cell. To prevent such damage the new system includes a device built at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, a nuclear weapons laboratory, that accepts the gas and adds a second oxygen atom to the carbon monoxide, producing carbon dioxide. Engineers were able to accomplish that difficult step without adding oxygen to the H2 , a step that would rob the fuel cell of its fuel.
Then the gas, almost pure H2 , goes to a fuel cell, an older technology that has been gradually improved in the last few years. The hydrogen atoms, which consist of one proton and one electron, flow down one side of a permeable membrane. On the other side is oxygen from air. The hydrogen's proton wants to join with the oxygen, to create H2 O, or water, and is drawn through the membrane, but the electron is left behind. With the positively charged proton on one side and the negatively charged electron on the other, the membrane creates an electrical difference that becomes a current.
As is often the case in science, the membrane was initially developed for an unrelated purpose. Du Pont first manufactured it for making insecticides.
The testers used one cell from Ballard Power Systems Inc., the Vancouver company that sells buses powered by fuel cells, and another cell from Plug Power of Latham, N.Y., which plans to offer them for home use within two years.
In 16 hours of tests earlier this month at a Little laboratory in Cambridge, Mass., a processor ran smoothly on gasoline and ethanol, officials said. It produced enough hydrogen for 50 kilowatts, big enough to run a medium-size car. Ethanol can be produced from corn, and the Energy Department hopes it will eventually be the main fuel for such cells. Gasoline might therefore be a transitional step to ethanol, which is completely renewable.
The system delivers 84 percent of the energy in a gallon of gasoline to the fuel cell, said Jeffrey M. Bently, a vice president of Little, and the fuel cell turns most of that energy into electricity. In contrast, an internal combustion engine loses more than 80 percent of the energy in a gallon, either as heat out the tail pipe or friction in the drive train.
One use for a fuel-cell system, which Chrysler has been pursuing even in advance of the new development, is to perfect an electric car without a breakthrough in battery design. Such a car might still carry a few batteries, for quick starts and for recapturing energy when a driver brakes the car, but existing battery designs could handle that easily.
"This blows the doors off any battery-powered electric vehicle," Mr. Bently said in a telephone interview. Batteries take hours to charge, he said, but this car could be re-fueled "with a five minute fill-up anywhere in the free world."
A major jump in efficiency could be a big step in fighting global warming, Mr. Pena said. He predicted that third-world countries that hope to add cars by the hundreds of millions in coming decades could move directly to cars powered by fuel cells. "They can leapfrog us like they did with cell phones," he said, referring to countries that skipped the older technology of phones tied to copper wires.
Even before cars, though, the new system could be used to make electricity for houses, according to the Energy Department and companies involved in the research. Such a system could run on propane or natural gas, two hydrocarbons that are widely available in homes. Plug Power, a joint venture between DTE Edison, which is the parent company of Detroit Edison, and Mechanical Technologies Inc., a 36-year-old technology company in Albany, N.Y., says it will have demonstration units available within a year and units for commercial use in two years. Plug Power says it will install the units in homeowners' basements and sell the electricity at a price below what is paid by about 25 million households.
The package would be "roughly the size of a small dishwasher," said Gary Mittleman, president and chief executive of Plug Power. "You won't have to pay a penny for the device," he said, but it will have an electric meter on it, charging for power at 8 to 10 cents a kilowatt-hour, depending on the price of hydrocarbon fuel.

GRAPHIC: Diagram: "Using Gas More Efficiently and Producing Less Pollution"
The Energy Department and an engineering firm plan to announce today that they have produced electricity from gasoline using a method that they say is more efficient than current car engines and produces less pollution.
 
Fuel is vaporized . . . And mixed with air, pro-ducing carbon monoxide and hydrogen.
Sulfur compounds are removed.
Steam is added, and it reacts with most of the carbon monoxide to form additional hydrogen and carbon dioxide.
The remaining carbon monoxide is burned.
The hydrogen gas combines with air to make electricity, water and heat with few emissions.
