HEADLINE: U.S. Says Its Greenhouse Gas Emissions Are at Highest Rate in Years

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
As negotiations resume in Bonn on a new treaty to save the planet from global warming, the United States said today that its emissions of heat-trapping gases into the atmosphere grew last year at the highest rate since the nation pledged to cut them back.
Emissions of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases grew 3.4 percent in 1996, the latest year for which comprehensive estimates are available, the Energy Department said in a report. The department attributed the increase to strong economic growth, unusually severe weather and increased use of coal by electric utilities. 
 Emissions from energy use in residential and commercial buildings grew 6.3 percent and 5.5 percent, respectively, despite programs intended to increase energy efficiency.
At the same time, the report said, growing consumption of fuel by less efficient cars and light trucks suggests that motor vehicles may soon overtake industry as the largest source of gases suspected of causing global warming by effectively creating a greenhouse around Earth.
"The economy is booming, energy prices are relatively low, and a lot of people are paying a lot less attention to energy efficiency," said Steven Nadel, deputy director of the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy, a nonprofit research organization.
"If you have unfettered energy use and big economic growth," Mr. Nadel said, "it is not surprising that carbon emissions are going to increase. We need more active and aggressive policies. Laissez-faire does not work."
The report is acutely embarrassing to American negotiators at the climate talks, because the United State, with less than a 20th of the world's population, gives off almost a fourth of the gases that trap heat in the atmosphere, threatening widespread climate change.
In a treaty on climate change signed by 160 nations in 1992, the United States and other industrial countries pledged to reduce their emissions of such gases to 1990's level by 2000.
But American emissions in 1996 were 7.4 percent above 1990 levels, the report said. For some time the Clinton Administration has forecast that by the end of the decade, emissions of the gases in the United States will be 13 percent higher than in 1990. With the economy still growing and people driving farther in cars that use more gasoline per mile, the upward trend is widely expected to continue.
The parties to the treaty are meeting in Bonn this week to try to negotiate a new, binding agreement that cuts emissions beyond 2000. The talks are supposed to conclude in December in Kyoto, Japan.
European nations, saying they are well on their way to achieving the target for 2000, are pressing for deeper cuts in emissions by 2010.
Emissions of carbon dioxide, the main heat-trapping gas, increased to record levels in all five sectors that the Government report tracked: residential buildings, commercial buildings, industrial sites, transportation, and electricity generation.

HEADLINE: QUANDARY FOR U.S.: ADVISER ON TIBET

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
With only a week to go before the visit of China's President to the United States, the Clinton Administration finds itself in a diplomatic predicament of its own making over its pledge to appoint a "special coordinator" to oversee American policy toward Tibet.
The appointment is bringing protests from Beijing, which regards the planned office as interference with its internal affairs, while members of Congress are accusing the State Department of dithering. The Administration, caught in the middle, is scrambling to avoid a confrontation just as President Jiang Zemin arrives for a weeklong tour of America, starting on Sunday. 
 "The question is: Is there a way to deal with this appointment without poisoning the overall atmosphere of the summit?" asked Jonathan D. Pollack, a senior adviser at the Rand Corporation.
Under pressure from Democrats and Republicans in Congress, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright announced three months ago that she would create the office to raise the profile of Tibet in the making of foreign policy. The problem, diplomatically, is that she pledged to do so by Nov. 1, the final day of Mr. Jiang's visit, which both sides intend to be a culmination of months of efforts to improve relations.
With the visit and deadline approaching, the State Department has yet to announce an appointment, though Ms. Albright's spokesman, James P. Rubin, said she would make it as promised. But other officials in the department and at the White House have strongly suggested -- in interviews and in discussions with members of Congress -- that the appointment will be put off until after Mr. Jiang's visit or at least after the Washington part of it ends on Oct. 30.
While the Administration has sought to engage China's Communist Government on a variety of fronts, a vocal faction in Congress has accused it of putting pragmatic concerns like trade over issues of principle involving human rights and religious freedom.
Tibet, which has sought a greater degree of autonomy from China since Chinese troops violently established Communist rule over the region beginning in 1950, has long been a sensitive subject for the Chinese. The debate over creation of the position comes as awareness of Tibet's cause has mushroomed here, in part through popular depictions in Hollywood.
An appointment on the eve of the visit, the Administration officials said, would almost certainly be seen by the Chinese as an affront to Mr. Jiang. And that could upset the progress the Administration hopes to make on a variety of matters, including a pledge by China to stop selling missiles and nuclear technology to countries like Iran.
"It definitely is not very good for the atmosphere," an Administration official said, speaking on condition of anonymity.
The Chinese have objected to the creation of the coordinator's office. Senior officials from Beijing have repeatedly raised the matter in the flurry of preparatory meetings leading up to Mr. Jiang's visit -- most recently during one between Ms. Albright and Foreign Minister Qian Qichen in New York City late last month.
"Our position is very clear," said Yu Shu Ning, a counselor at China's Embassy in Washington. "We are opposed to any interference in China's internal affairs."
The Administration's failure to fill the job by now is already drawing criticism from Tibet's supporters in Congress, who say Beijing is brutally repressing Tibet's unique culture, language and religion. Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, sent a letter to Ms. Albright two weeks ago pointedly, if politely, recalling the deadline and urging the appointment of "someone of stature who will command respect." Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, sent his own letter last Friday.
Representative Nancy Pelosi, a Democrat from California who is one of the most outspoken critics of China in Congress, said the Administration risked losing a perfect opportunity to highlight Tibetan issues in a way the Chinese could not ignore.
"I think if the Administration is serious about the Tibet coordinator," she said, "that person would be appointed before the Jiang Zemin visit so that he or she could be present at the table."
The United States does not regard Tibet as an independent country, nor does it support its independence from China. But it has long been supportive of Tibet's spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1989 for peacefully advocating more autonomy for his homeland.
In addition to coordinating policy toward Tibet, which now falls between the separate bureaus in the State Department that oversee China and human rights, the new office is supposed to promote talks between the Dalai Lama's representatives and the Government in Beijing. Ms. Albright promised that the coordinator, while not an Ambassador with diplomatic credentials, would travel to the region.
Mr. Rubin, Ms. Albright's spokesman, said today that there were "intensive discussions" under way to select the coordinator by Nov. 1. And he played down any connection between the appointment and the visit.
"The purpose of the special coordinator is to promote our interest in the human rights of the people of Tibet and a dialogue with the authorities in Beijing," he said.
Mr. Jiang is likely to be dogged by protests throughout his trip, which includes stops in Williamsburg, Va., Philadelphia, New York City and Los Angeles, as well as a speech at Harvard and the official visit in Washington on Oct. 29. On the night of Mr. Jiang's state dinner, for instance, the International Campaign for Tibet plans to have a protest dinner.
The campaign's director, John Ackerly, said President Clinton and Ms. Albright should not simply paper over differences with China. "They will leave themselves vulnerable," he said, "if they try to push aside too many of the controversial issues."

HEADLINE: Kravis-Led Fund Is Backing Internet Lab

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN

 BODY:
An investment fund established by Henry R. Kravis is collaborating with Ericsson, the Swedish telecommunications company, to open a high-technology business center in lower Manhattan to help Internet entrepreneurs tinker with new ideas.
Called Cyber Lab East, the center plans to open early next year and will cost $2 million a year to operate, said representatives of Ericsson and the New York City Investment Fund, who are scheduled to announce the details of the venture today. 
 "The Investment Fund views Cyber Lab as a critical part of the infrastructure that will help New York capture the jobs and business opportunities that will be generated from the Internet industries in the years ahead," said Mr. Kravis, the financier who is chairman of the fund.
Ericsson will provide $1.5 million, and the fund, which aims to create jobs and generate economic development, will lend Ericsson $750,000 to support the project, said Kathryn S. Wylde, president and chief executive of the fund.
Ms. Wylde said the goal was to create a nurturing and intellectually charged atmosphere in which Ericsson engineers and programmers will offer tips.
The laboratory will be stocked with computer equipment, and companies will rent the space for as little as $5,000 a week.
Companies seeking space have to submit proposals to Ericsson for approval, with the criterion being that the plans complement Ericsson's strategy of integrating the Internet and telecommunications, said Joseph L. Hagan, chief financial officer of Ericsson Inc., whose American headquarters are in Richardson, Tex.
The plan is for a permanent staff of up to five Ericsson employees, helping up to 15 projects at a time.
"It's a bit like a ski lodge, where we provide the ski lifts and teachers and some equipment, but you use the slopes to test new skis, snowboards and other equipment," Mr. Hagan said.
The 5,000-square-foot center will be on the 16th floor of the New York Information Technology Center at 55 Broad Street, said William C. Rudin, president of the Rudin Management Company, owner of the building. The 400,000-square-foot building, billed as "wired" because of its abundance of high-speed computer connections and preference for new-media companies, is fully occupied.
The center is not the first such collaborative effort. In 1993, New York University established the Center for Digital Multimedia Production, Publishing and Education, which works with new-media companies to develop products. Last year, Ericsson founded the Cyber Lab in Menlo Park, Calif., a model for the New York center.
The Investment Fund, which was established last year with a pool of $60 million from some of the best-known investors and corporations in the city, had mainly focused on retail development and job-creation projects, investing $4.75 million. That strategy has broadened, Ms. Wilde said, to include supporting the Internet industry.
In addition to the Ericsson deal, the fund this month pledged to allocate 10 percent of its capitalization, or $6 million, to help finance small high-tech companies.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S. Seeks Changes In Microsoft Browser Policy
The Federal Government asked a judge to order Microsoft to stop forcing makers of personal computers to include its Internet browser when they install Windows 95.
The challenge to Microsoft promises to have broad implications for the heated contest between it and Netscape over which company's browser will dominate the Internet. Netscape's stock soared. Page A1. 

ITT Finds a White Knight
ITT accepted a friendly $9.8 billion purchase offer from Starwood Lodging Trust, a deal that apparently thwarts Hilton Hotels' hostile quest to buy ITT, its rival in the hotel and gaming industry, for $8 billion. The deal would also bring to a quiet end the leadership career of Rand V. Araskog, above, the ITT chairman known for his tenacity in repelling unwanted takeover advances during the 1980's. A1.
 
AT&T Picks Hughes Chief
As expected, AT&T named C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman of Hughes Electronics, as its next chief, one year after the introduction of a previous choice, John R. Walter, who instead left AT&T. Mr. Armstrong will replace Robert E. Allen on Nov. 1. D4.
 
General Motors, which owns Hughes, said it had no intention of selling the subsidiary and that it would not be hurt by the departure of Mr. Armstrong. Hughes's vice chairman, Michael T. Smith, will take his place. D5.
 
Earnings News Lifts Stocks
Stocks posted robust gains for the first time in a week, as strong earnings from AT&T, Eli Lilly and other companies heartened investors. The Dow industrials rose 74.41 points, to 7,921.44. A rebound in technology shares lifted the Nasdaq composite, which rose 18.60 points, to 1,685.45. D10.
 
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.42 percent from 6.44. D20.
 
Banc One in $3 Billion Deal
Banc One is buying First Commerce of New Orleans for $3 billion in stock in a deal that would make the acquirer the biggest bank in Louisiana. D6.
 
Levi's Account in Review
Levi Strauss unexpectedly placed in review its Levi's brand account, with billings estimated at $87 million, after 67 years at Foote, Cone & Belding and a predecessor agency. D8.
 
I.B.M. Profit Above Estimates
I.B.M. said that its quarterly earnings rose more than 6 percent, beating estimates, as it holds its course as other technology companies are buffeted. D3.
 
$1.1 Billion for Pipeline Company
Kinder Morgan Energy Partners, a pipeline and coal-transfer company, has agreed to buy Santa Fe Pacific Pipeline Partners for about $1.1 billion in cash and stock. D3.
 
Thai Currency Tumbles
The Thai currency tumbled against the dollar, hurt by concern that the resignation of Thailand's Finance Minister would hinder economic reform. The South Korean won and Taiwan's currency also fell sharply as currency turmoil continued to roil Asia. D17.
 
Union Pacific Turns a Bend
Union Pacific Railroad said it had turned a corner on the congestion that has choked its system and caused shipments to be delayed or canceled. D10.
 
A Better Electric Car?
The Energy Department and an engineering company have produced electricity from gasoline through a new method that yields twice as much useful energy per gallon as a car engine does, but with less pollution. The development raises the distant prospect of an electric car without the problem of heavy batteries. A14.

HEADLINE: For Hoffa, Nearly Everything Is in a Name

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: MAYWOOD, Ill.

 BODY:
Up in the grandstands, his back to a 30-foot-tall window overlooking the racetrack, James P. Hoffa was whipping up a crowd of 1,000 truckers and their wives the way his legendary father did, telling them that last year's election for the teamsters' presidency was stolen from him.
At this harness track outside Chicago, the air was far more electric than at many political rallies as the varied group of muscle-bound truckers and scraggly, long-haired drivers, of teamster newcomers and union potentates wearing pinky rings, hailed Mr. Hoffa's every word as much as his famous last name. 
 For many, this stocky 56-year-old labor lawyer from Detroit is the second coming of their favorite labor leader. "If it weren't for Hoffa Sr.," one trucker said, "I wouldn't have my house or be able to support my family."
Shouting so his frenzied supporters could hear, Mr. Hoffa asked the teamsters at the $20-a-person fund-raiser and macaroni dinner, "Does everyone know why they have ordered a rerun? It's because the Ron Carey campaign stole $1.5 million of your dues money."
In one of those surprising twists of history, the son of James Riddle Hoffa, the longtime teamster leader who was repeatedly linked to organized crime, is on the political offensive attacking corruption under Mr. Carey, a darling of labor reformers who was first elected teamsters' president in 1991 on a platform of cleansing the union of mob influence.
But even as Mr. Hoffa portrays himself as a corruption buster, the Carey camp repeatedly points to lingering questions about his past and about his sponsors and mentors, among them union leaders who have been convicted of embezzlement and ousted for nepotism.
In August, Federal officials found that Carey aides had illegally diverted union money to help his re-election campaign, annulled his narrow victory over Mr. Hoffa and ordered a new election.
The stakes are high in the rerun this winter because the teamsters, one of the United States' most powerful unions, was long its most mob-infested one -- until the Federal Government and Mr. Carey began cleaning it up. Some government officials and labor leaders are wary of having someone else named Hoffa running this truckers union, which reaches into every nook of the economy and is prized by mobsters as a vehicle to ship contraband.
Despite the many questions about him, Mr. Hoffa depicted himself as an aggrieved white knight throughout the evening-long fund-raiser, which included 10 boxing matches and a $100-a-person party for teamster bigwigs in the track's Windy City Club Room.
"Is there anyone here who doesn't believe we won the last election?" Mr. Hoffa asked the crowd.
"No," they thundered in unison, all but ignoring the horse race going on behind and below Mr. Hoffa, a gregarious man who was wearing an un-teamsterish plaid sports jacket over a white polo shirt.
With Mr. Carey tarred by the scandal, Mr. Hoffa is widely viewed as the front-runner in the race to head the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, whose 1.4 million members include long-haul truckers, parcel deliverers, warehouse employees and sanitation workers.
Mr. Hoffa vows to clean up the union and transform it into the powerhouse it was under his father, who was easily the best-known labor leader of the last 50 years.
This anti-corruption pledge comes from a man whose mentors have included George Vitale, who went to jail in the 1970's for embezzlement and who was ousted from the presidency of a Detroit local in 1991 when Federal officials found that he stole $10,761 in union money and tried to embezzle a Lincoln Town Car. Another mentor, Michael Bane, president of a Detroit local, also went to jail for embezzlement in the 1970's and was caught in a famous photo stomping a teamster dissident.
Last year, soon after Mr. Hoffa chose William Hogan Jr., head of an 11,000-member Chicago local, to be No. 2 on his ticket, Federal officials kicked Mr. Hogan out of office because of nepotism. Mr. Hogan's brother was the local's No. 2 person, his son was recording secretary and together the three Hogans earned $477,000 a year. (At the Maywood fund-raiser, Mr. Hogan defended himself by saying that nepotism was commonplace in unions and in Chicago, and that Federal officials ousted him because they wanted to help Mr. Carey's campaign.)
In the late 1960's Mr. Hoffa was an investor in a partnership with Allen Dorfman, a friend of his father and a leading organized crime figure. Federal officials say Mr. Dorfman, who was murdered in 1983, siphoned more than $100 million from teamster pension funds to the Mafia.
Mr. Hoffa denies knowing that Mr. Dorfman was tied to organized crime and said he sold his investment as soon as he found out.
Ken Paff, national coordinator of Teamsters for a Democratic Union, a pro-Carey group that long fought corruption in the union, said Mr. Hoffa's most prominent mentor, Larry Brennan, head of the teamsters in Michigan, organized a group in the 1980's that beat up dissidents pushing for democracy in the union, an assertion Mr. Brennan's spokesman denied. Mr. Hoffa now works as Mr. Brennan's executive assistant.
In addition, Federal judges in New York and Michigan have lambasted Mr. Hoffa as wasting dues money in the legal defense of union officials who were found to have blatantly violated the law. In one case, Mr. Hoffa defended a Detroit local's president who refused to open the unit's books and records to some members.
"I always believe that if you sleep with dogs, you're going to get fleas," said Don Stone, a former Detroit trucker who successfully sued the president of that unit, Local 283. "I believe Hoffa's right in there with that whole Detroit bunch, who have been convicted of embezzling and other crimes. If he's elected, isn't he going to be very beholden to these old guard officials?"
Despite such attacks, many people in Detroit vouch for Mr. Hoffa, including some former prosecutors. Martin Crandall, who worked for the Federal Organized Crime Strike Force in Detroit, said he often opposed or negotiated with Mr. Hoffa, a graduate of Michigan State University and the University of Michigan Law School, when he represented unions and labor officials.
"I've never seen anything but honesty and integrity in his work," said Mr. Crandall, now a lawyer in private practice.
In a heated campaign where the two sides do not hide their dislike for each other, the Carey forces have sought to demonize Mr. Hoffa.
For example, they have published a pamphlet citing a book by Frank Ragano, a lawyer for mob bosses, which states that two well-known Mafia figures, Carlos Marcello and Santo Traficante -- in a gesture of friendship to the elder Hoffa -- each gave the younger Hoffa $5,000 as a wedding present. Mr. Hoffa attacks this story as untrue.
With stories like these, the Carey camp is pushing the notion that if Mr. Hoffa wins, he will let organized crime influence the union the way it did under his father. The elder Hoffa was president from 1957 to 1971 and disappeared in 1975 in what F.B.I. officials say was a mob slaying.
In an interview, Mr. Hoffa grew angry with assertions that he would let the Mafia back in.
"The most important thing," he said sternly, is that "my father was, I believe, murdered by the mob."
"The mob will never come back into the teamsters union," he said. "I will see to that."
Then, talking about the Carey camp, he added, "Why are these people who are accused of carrying out the biggest scandal in teamsters' history repeating things like that?"
Arthur Sloane, a University of Delaware professor who wrote a biography of the elder Hoffa, said the Carey forces were portraying the younger Hoffa unfairly.
"It can always be argued that he was friendly with some mobsters in his early years because they were friends of his father," Professor Sloane said. "But I think that these predictions by Carey people that if Hoffa wins, he's likely to bring back the old guard and some unsavory characters are simply wrong."
Knowing that the union is not peopled by choirboys, Professor Sloane seemed to pardon Mr. Hoffa's contacts with disreputable types. "You don't grow up a teamster, you don't come up to be a teamster leader in the 60's, 70's and 80's without meeting these people and associating with them in a pragmatic way," he said.
In an interview, Mr. Hoffa said, "I don't remember meeting any mobsters as a young man."
Mr. Hoffa said that to the best of his knowledge, his father did not associate with mobsters. "That's my belief," he said solemnly. He added: "He's not running. He's been gone for 22 years."
On the campaign trail, Mr. Hoffa often says he had the ideal upbringing to lead the union.
"As a child I stood by the fire barrel with my father during Detroit winters, standing with teamsters who were on strike," he said. "I attended union meetings my whole life. On weekends, my father took me down to the union hall. I had a great love affair with the members of this union."
Not surprisingly, Jimmy Hoffa's son decided to become a labor lawyer, and some Detroit locals close to the elder Hoffa were happy to hire him as counsel. He has sued companies, argued before the National Labor Relations Board and won reinstatement for dismissed workers.
"There isn't any aspect of teamster union life that I have not done," he said, "and that is what has prepared me for this union's presidency."
For many teamsters, the biggest question about Mr. Hoffa is who will run the union with him if he wins. Carey supporters assert that it will be Mr. Hoffa's pals from Detroit and Chicago, whom they brand an "old guard" more concerned about reaching into the union cookie jar than about raising wages.
"If Hoffa's elected, these are the people who are going to run the union with him," said Mr. Paff of Teamsters for a Democratic Union. "Has the guy ever had a client who wasn't unsavory? Does he work for any clean locals? He surrounds himself with Bane, Brennan, grifters and bums."
But Mr. Hoffa insists that as president he would turn not to the Detroit crowd but to the officials on his slate, including Chuck Mack, the respected teamsters head in San Francisco, and John Murphy, a left-leaning local president from Boston.
In many ways, Mr. Hoffa's coalition resembles the diverse one surrounding his father: it includes tough, pragmatic teamsters concerned about their members' well-being, long-time leftists who see the teamsters as a vehicle to increase workers' clout and pay, officials concerned about lining their own pockets, and members who detest the many outsiders from the mine workers' union whom Mr. Carey brought in to run the teamsters.
To be sure, his coalition also includes many rank-and-file teamsters in awe of the Hoffa name, like those who lined up at the Maywood fund-raiser to buy scores of $10 T-shirts saying, "Hoffa Now!"
One of those supporters, Tony Viren, a truck driver from Rockford, voiced confidence that Mr. Hoffa would be a good, honest leader.
"He came from a hell of a bloodline," Mr. Viren said. "He'll be in a fishbowl if he's elected president. He won't be able to do anything wrong because everyone will be double and triple checking him."

HEADLINE: Poll Finds Most Voters Have No Opinion About Messinger

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY

 BODY:
Two weeks before Election Day, Ruth W. Messinger remains an essentially unknown figure to a vast segment of New Yorkers, suggesting that the Democratic challenger to Rudolph W. Giuliani -- and indeed the mayoral race itself -- has not captured the attention of the city, according to the latest New York Times poll.
After a year of speeches, forums, handshaking and television advertisements, 60 percent of those questioned said they had no opinion, good or bad, about the woman who is seeking to become the next Mayor of New York, the Times poll found. 
 By contrast, the poll found that by almost every measure, New Yorkers feel good about their city and its Mayor. Many New Yorkers, though not necessarily a majority, say the city is safer, cleaner, less racially polarized and more prosperous than it was when he began his term.
Mr. Giuliani enjoys as strong a job approval rating now as he has at any point since he became Mayor. When the Times poll asked how they would vote if the election were held today, 49 percent favored Mr. Giuliani and 36 percent supported Ms. Messinger, with 14 percent undecided.
And Mr. Giuliani's numbers could be even greater if the lack of excitement about Ms. Messinger's candidacy produced a low turnout among her potential supporters. That is particularly true for black voters, who overwhelmingly support Ms. Messinger but who have yet to show deep enthusiasm for her campaign.
And the Mayor's support among blacks is one telling indication of his improved standing. In 1993, Mr. Giuliani won just 5 percent of the black vote against David N. Dinkins. Now, black voters indicated in the poll, he would win 25 percent.
There are a few rays of hope for Ms. Messinger on an otherwise dark political horizon. New Yorkers now rank education alongside crime as the most pressing problem facing the next mayor; Ms. Messinger has made her criticism of the Mayor's handling of the public schools a central issue of her campaign. One group of voters with whom Ms. Messinger enjoys a strong advantage is parents of children in public schools.
And despite the overall good tidings for Mr. Giuliani, the Republican Mayor has not won the support of more than 50 percent of New Yorkers in his match-up with Ms. Messinger, suggesting both an ambivalence many New Yorkers may feel toward their quarrelsome Mayor, as well as the 5-to-1 Democratic edge in the city. All of that could mean that Mr. Giuliani, should he win, may not achieve the overwhelming victory his aides have said they are looking for this November to position him for higher political office.
Still, it appears that it would take a fairly dramatic event to break the mold of this election. Ms. Messinger has less campaign money than Mr. Giuliani, and thus is limited in what she can do in the final two weeks. Also, two-thirds of the likely voters who were polled said that their minds were now made up, as is typical this late in an election.
The Times poll surveyed 1,538 adults throughout the city, including 1,022 who said they were registered to vote. It was conducted by telephone from Oct. 13 to Oct. 18 and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Ms. Messinger's aides said they were heartened by the Times poll, particularly because it came on a day when a poll in The New York Post found Ms. Messinger losing by a considerably larger margin, 29 percent. The New York Post-Fox 5 poll found 56 percent for Mr. Giuliani, 27 percent for Ms. Messinger and 17 percent undecided.
Jim Andrews, Ms. Messinger's senior campaign adviser, said he was struck by the fact that in the Times poll, Mr. Giuliani had not scored above 50 percent, which in most races would be taken as a sign of trouble for an incumbent.
"Elections involving incumbents are about incumbents," Mr. Andrews said. "Nobody ever said this was going to be easy."
And there are a few factors that could theoretically swing things toward Ms. Messinger. As Mr. Andrews noted, undecided voters traditionally favor the challenger. But the way the poll stands now, virtually all the respondents who said they had not made a decision would have to go to Ms. Messinger. And when pressed about how they were leaning, the undecided voters split evenly between Ms. Messinger and Mr. Giuliani.
Ms. Messinger would also be helped if Democrats who are now supporting Mr. Giuliani had a change of heart. The two candidates now enjoy roughly equal support among Democrats, reflecting Mr. Giuliani's strategy of distancing himself from his party while aligning himself at every opportunity with some of the most prominent Democrats in the city.
Ms. Messinger could also be helped if her voters turned out on Election Day while Mr. Giuliani's did not, particularly in a contest which this poll suggests will produce a low turnout.
Still, it is an uphill battle. Mr. Giuliani is leading in the polls among members of every age group. He is leading among Jews, once a solidly Democratic base of support. He is even tied with Ms. Messinger in Manhattan, her home borough. He is statistically even with Ms. Messinger among Hispanic voters, an increasingly influential segment of the city's electorate.
Indeed, although Ms. Messinger would be the city's first female mayor, Mr. Giuliani is ahead among women, by 44 percent to 36 percent.
This poll again showed sharp differences in the way black, white and Hispanic New Yorkers view the city, but that does not appear to be helping Ms. Messinger. And a low turnout among blacks could inflate Mr. Giuliani's final standing.
Mr. Giuliani's position today reflects what have from the start been three central dynamics of this race. Voters are generally satisfied with the state of the city. They view Mr. Giuliani as an effective leader. And if they have considered Ms. Messinger at all, they are likely to see her as unsuited to be mayor.
A revealing difference in perceptions came in response to two questions. In the first, 78 percent said Mr. Giuliani had "strong qualities of leadership," compared with just 38 for Ms. Messinger. In the second, 80 percent said they thought Mr. Giuliani was "tough enough to deal with the crime problem," while only 30 percent said that about Ms. Messinger.
Most of all, though, the poll underscored the impression that the election has not made much of an impression on New Yorkers. As a result, when voters were asked the routine question of whether they had a favorable opinion of Ms. Messinger, 60 percent said they had no opinion or did not know enough about her to have an opinion. And of those remaining, 20 percent said they had a favorable opinion of her, compared with 20 percent who did not.
By contrast, 29 percent said they were undecided or had not heard enough about Mr. Giuliani to have an opinion of him. Among those who did, 46 percent were favorable, compared with 26 percent who were not.
The other indication of the invisible nature of the Democratic candidate is the difficulties both candidates have had in affecting public discussion on the race. Ms. Messinger clearly had some role in raising public worries about schools -- it went from being listed as a priority for the next mayor by 19 percent of respondents in March to 31 percent now -- but the shift also coincided with the opening of schools.
But Ms. Messinger has hardly dented the city's political consciousness with her other major issue: the city's high unemployment rate. Similarly, Mr. Giuliani's attempt to raise concern about the use of drugs shows little sign of registering with voters.
Most of all, though, the lack of interest in the race appears to reflect Ms. Messinger's apparent failure to crack through the general satisfaction with Mr. Giuliani and the city.
Follow-up telephone conversations yesterday with respondents in the poll underscored the difficulties this has created for Ms. Messinger.
"I haven't heard that much in terms of commercials and advertisements," said Seymour Fiedler, 75, a retired salesman from Queens who said he was leaning toward Mr. Giuliani. "It seems you only get bits and pieces about the candidates. It seems like a low-key campaign compared to the last election, which was more intense. There seemed to be more ads then. Maybe it's because Messinger is not that popular and doesn't have a lot of money."
Ira Bernstein, 51, a business consultant who said he was a Liberal planning to vote for Mr. Giuliani, said: "This isn't a contest. There is no candidate running on the Democratic ticket who can tarnish Giuliani. Messinger is a noncandidate, running by default."
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 13 to 18 in all parts of New York City with 1,538 adults. Of these, 1,022 said they were registered to vote. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of city exchanges. The exchanges were chosen to assure that each area in the city was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey, to gain equal access to all adults in the households.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence, and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to borough, race, sex and age.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adult New Yorkers.
For smaller subgroups, the potential sampling error is larger. For example, among registered voters it is plus or minus four percentage points for whites, six points for blacks and seven points for Hispanic New Yorkers.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat varying results.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk;
In Bordeaux Rating, Economist Considers Price First

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
FOR the first time in almost a decade, Orley Ashenfelter, a Princeton University economist and an implacable foe of wine orthodoxy, has produced a new ranking of the chateaus of Bordeaux. No matter how big your pocketbook -- whether you buy in quantity at wine auctions or by the bottle at your local store -- his method could help you ferret out bargains.
Mr. Ashenfelter, the Joseph Douglas Green Professor of Economics at Princeton, ignores wine competitions and awards -- the so-called sniff-and-taste school of judging wine -- and bases his rankings on the price of mature wines at auction. 
 His methodology does not exactly break new ground. The best-known classification of Bordeaux's finest wines was done in 1855 by a syndicate of wine brokers who were trying to decide which wines should represent the region at an exposition in Paris. Businessmen rather than wine makers, they based their choices on the prices paid for the wines over the previous decade.
Mr. Ashenfelter promotes this point of view in his newsletter, Liquid Assets. "Instead of a subjective ranking by a small group of experts," he writes, "why not base a new ranking on the consensus of informed consumers who pay for the wines they drink with cold hard cash?"
Mr. Ashenfelter based his findings on more than 10,000 sales at London wine auctions from May 1994 to December 1996. As a benchmark, he chose Chateau Lafite-Rothschild, as he did in 1988, arbitrarily giving its price level a value of 100. Lafite was chosen because of its long history as an important Bordeaux property. Prices of the other wines from 200 chateaus were expressed as a percentage of the price of Lafite.
The list is valuable because auction prices are not directly reflected in prices at the store, so it gives the wine buyer hard figures on what the best buys are in any price category. For example, according to the Ashenfelter list, a bottle of Lynch-Bages should sell for about half the price of Lafite. If it's listed at less than that at the store, you've got yourself a bargain.
Vintages included in the survey were from 1957 through 1986. "It was critical for the sake of objectivity that the wines be at least 10 years old," he writes, explaining that younger wines do not have enough of a track record to say how good they eventually will be. The prices of these wines "are far too easily influenced by the opinions of wine writers or public relations experts."
In the new Liquid Assets classification, the top-ranked wine is Chateau le Pin, a small property in the commune of Pomerol, 30 miles east of the city of Bordeaux and the vineyards of the Medoc. Its price as a percentage of Lafite-Rothschild: 708, or seven times as expensive as the Lafite. Chateau Petrus, long considered the most expensive of all Bordeaux wines and first in the 1988 Ashenfelter survey, ranked second with a relative price of 369.
Le Pin is to Bordeaux wine what the Florida Marlins are to baseball: no other Bordeaux property has risen to the top so fast. It came into existence in 1979 and its first commercial vintage was 1981. Production in 1996 was a mere 15 barrels. In the second edition of his book "Bordeaux" (Faber & Faber, 1991), Edmund Penning-Rowsell called Le Pin a "pocket-handkerchief of a vineyard," describing its wines as "undeniably attractive and flattering, in a rather Californian and simplistic way."
Following Le Pin and Petrus in the Ashenfelter top 10 are Chateau Lafleur, another Pomerol, at 160; Mouton-Rothschild from Pauillac at 129; Cheval Blanc from St.-Emilion at 121; Latour in Pauillac at 113; Margaux in Margaux at 105; Lafite-Rothschild from Pauillac at 100; La Mission-Haut-Brion in Pessac-Leognan, part of the Graves region at 85, and Haut-Brion, from the same commune, 78.
Another new entry on the list is Chateau le Tertre-Roteboeuf, from St.-Emilion, which placed 24th with a price at 44 percent of that of Lafite-Rothschild's. Le Terte-Roteboeuf is generally made from 80 percent merlot grapes and helps to highlight another feature of the new ranking: the major presence of the merlot grape in contemporary Bordeaux winemaking.
The top three wines in the classification, le Pin, Petrus and Lafleur, are all from Pomerol and are made almost entirely from the merlot grape. Indeed, 9 of the top 25 wines are from Pomerol and 4 are from neighboring St.-Emilion, both communes heavily reliant on the merlot grape.
"The apparent commercial success of merlot-based wines displayed in our ranking helps to explain why some Bordeaux proprietors are moving toward increased planting of merlot vines," Mr. Ashenfelter writes. "It remains to be seen what long-term effects this change has on the reputation of wines from Bordeaux."
He acknowledges that his figures might be difficult to put to practical use in auction rooms, where prices change rapidly. But he insists that they can be helpful in buying wine in shops and restaurants. "Decide what price category of wine you are prepared to buy," he said, "then select the wine with the highest ranking in that category."
Liquid Assets is $20; its address is 32 Nassau Street, Princeton, N.J. 08542.
 
Tastings
A Big Burgundy
Clos de la Roche 1994, Domaine Dujac, Morey-St. Denis, Burgundy. About $80.
 
MANY Burgundy producers trace their ancestry in the vineyards back two or three centuries and have been estate-bottling their wines for 50 years. Jacques Seysses, to the contrary, arrived from Paris in the late 1960's, having worked there and in New York as a banker. Bored with banking, he opted for his first love, wine. After apprenticing at the Domaine de la Pousse d'Or in Volnay for two harvests, he created the Domaine Dujac in Morey-St. Denis and quickly became one of Burgundy's premier winemakers. Mr. Seysses owns about 5 acres of the 42-acre Clos de la Roche, one of five Grand Cru vineyards in Morey-St. Denis. From it he produces one of his most distinguished and long-lived wines. The 1994 is medium-bodied, with a magnificent bouquet and an exceptionally long finish. It is a structured wine that should improve considerably over the next five years and then last well into the next century. Like all Domaine Dujac Grand Cru wines, it was aged in 100 percent new oak.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Intense, Artistic, All the Rage? Must Be Disgusting

BYLINE: By Edward Rothstein

 BODY:
It is almost impossible to write about disgust without being disgusting. Words like squishy, sticky, squirmy and slimy can hardly be used without hints of a grimace. Others, like pus and phlegm, bring on anticipations of full-scale offense.
So reader, be forewarned. The disgusting is our subject: items that cause us to feel repulsed, even contaminated, by their very thought; behaviors that inspire intense revulsion and horror, experiences that even in memory inspire a shudder. 
 Which should make us feel right at home. For the disgusting has become commonplace in culture. It has become the subject of scholarly examination in at least two new books. Sometimes it even seems a welcome companion. Adventure and horror films seduce with rotting corpses, slithering layers of snakes, cannibalistic criminals, rank swamps and even (in "Men in Black") juicy, exploding cockroaches. Lollipops encasing worm larvae are a favorite candy for children. Body piercing and puncturing have become mainstream fashion. The daytime talk shows and best-seller lists are filled with chatty tales meant to inspire shock and, yes, disgust.
Disgust is even courted on the artistic scene. The avant-garde often deliberately tests the boundaries of the disgusting. (What, after all, was the scandal about that crucifix dipped in urine a few years ago but its deliberate invocation of disgust?) In politics, disgust may be more potent than legal niceties. (Which is likely to cause a more immediate emotional reaction: a pubic hair on a Coke can or political fund-raising on Federal property?)
We cultivate disgust as a moral reaction, to be invoked as an extreme weapon, proclaiming a particular disagreement to be beyond argument. Indeed, the disgusting may have even become so commonplace that it no longer seems outrageous: one of the remarkable aspects of the literary reputation of the Marquis de Sade, as Roger Shattuck argues in "Forbidden Knowledge" (St. Martin's Press), is that his writings have ceased to disgust us.
This preoccupation with disgust, though, does not seem accompanied by an increase in the quantity of disgust we are exposed to. The disgusting, with its implications of decay, disease and death, was far more prevalent in the days before plumbing and modern medicine; a stroll down some of 18th-century London's less savory streets would probably turn the modern stomach. Middle-class America is more protected from common sources of disgust than any society in history. But that makes our preoccupation with disgust still more remarkable. Disgust is less forced upon us than courted, toyed with, invoked, used and abused. Disgust is cultivated.
Two new books are also attracted to its powers. In "The Anatomy of Disgust" (Harvard University Press), William Ian Miller, a professor at the University of Michigan Law School, meticulously dissects the notion of disgust with the rigor of a legal brief, trying to determine its boundaries and powers. And in "Nightmare on Main Street" (forthcoming from Harvard), Mark Edmundson, a professor of English at the University of Virginia, argues that contemporary taste is dominated by a vulgar version of the Gothic -- that genre of horror that came into its own in the 19th century with its tales of menacing crypts and ancient evils, endangered innocents and horrific mutilations. Mr. Edmundson doesn't discuss disgust, but it is clear that in the Gothic, evil is the repulsive, the threatening and the alluring forces hidden behind an ordered facade.
What, then, is disgust? The psychologist Paul Rozin associated the feeling of disgust with the desire to avoid reminders of animal origins. The disgusting is related to the animal aspects of our lives, particularly our bodies, which, as Mr. Miller reminds us, "suppurate, die and rot." The anthropologist Mary Douglas associated contamination and disgust with a violation of cultural categories; something disgusts if it is out of place, anomalous. A hair on a head is innocuous; a hair in a bowl of soup is disgusting. The animal aspects of life -- so often seemingly disgusting in themselves -- are not contaminating if they stay in their place, regulated by socially approved sexual activity, dietary laws, social manners or hygienic habits.
Mr. Miller goes further. The disgusting, he argues, is more ambiguous and complicated. It can attract and yet overwhelm. It can be inspired by an overgrowth of life (as in a jungle or swamp) or by signs of imminent death (in decay and dissolution). Many things we find disgusting inhabit a nether world. They tend to be neither solid nor liquid, neither cold nor hot, neither alive nor dead, neither cooked nor raw, neither belonging in our bodies nor belonging outside them, perhaps even seeming neither human nor inhuman.
If culture orders the world and gives its objects value, the disgusting is what lies beyond culture's reach. We are repelled by it, but also drawn to it, the way a tongue probes a painful tooth. Mr. Miller says that "disgust is central to moral discourse and to the construction of our moral sensibility." In short, disgust helps create our culture.
Why, then, is disgust pursued in contemporary life? In his provocative book about the Gothic, Mr. Edmundson notes that the genre flourished in the years after the French Revolution. Those drafty castles with their dark secrets, the vampirish counts and the leering clergymen were all embodiments of the ancient regime, the old feudal order haunting the unsteady world of the new. Modern innocents are lured into that realm and nearly overwhelmed by it, until they exorcise its demonic control. The past is finally passed. The disgusting is contained, controlled, overcome.
But today, Mr. Edmundson argues, there is no clear resolution to our Gothic tales. Their haunting addictions and demonic figures keep reappearing in rock videos, computer games, television talk shows and horror films. But the villainy is ambiguous. No sooner do we start to hate the wife abuser on a talk show than we learn that he too is a haunted victim of abuse or a recovering addict. We are all villains and all victims, all disgusting and all agents of disgust. The result, Mr. Edmundson continues, is a culture suffused with sadomasochism.
In contemporary life, in fact, those categories that have traditionally defined culture have become porous and ambiguous; multiculturalism, relativism, gender bending -- these are some of the signposts of modern culture. There is no clear frame of reference, no guiding standard. But ambiguities and dislocation provide a nourishing home for disgust. In art and film, in fashion spreads and tabloid journalism, shocks multiply the way they do among a group of adolescents who are demonstrating their mastery over disgust with a series of ever-inflationary dares.
And so we live with our cultivated disgust. Disgust, for all its inchoate repulsiveness, even ends up becoming the only frame of reference. In our universe of cultural play where everything seems arbitrary and unclear, disgust often ends up the sole surviving force of natural law.
Disgust, Mr. Miller reminds us, has always helped give birth to culture; it has helped inspire notions of ethics and beauty that have tried to control or even banish disgust. So perhaps the disgusting, in the midst of its renaissance, may be ripe enough to inspire a cultural response. The disgusting tosses out a challenge: you want to make something of it -- or what?

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
To Repay G.I.'s and Rebuild America

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
The millions of men and women who returned to civilian life at the end of World War II have sometime since gone to gray, but memories of their reception remain green. Instead of being shrugged off like veterans of earlier wars, they were given generous unemployment checks, low-interest loans for houses and businesses and, most significantly, free education at colleges and trade schools.
"The G.I. Bill: The Law That Changed America" tells that heartening story mainly through the experiences of its beneficiaries, young Americans who grew up in the Depression, with no prospects beyond dead-end jobs, much less dreams of college diplomas, and suddenly found a world of opportunity opened to them. They took eager advantage of the Government largess, worked hard to catch up on the lost war years and succeeded not only in building careers and families but also in making the United States a middle-class country. 
 Tonight's historians remind us that Washington's openhandedness was prompted in part by unease lest the return of so many battle-toughened veterans without futures be accompanied by political volatility; memories of the fascist and Communist movements that came out of World War I were still disturbingly fresh. But there was also simple gratitude to those who had won a popular war, and the American Legion's all-out lobbying for what became known as the G.I. Bill of Rights didn't hurt.
This hourlong documentary plays a bit heavily on show-business personalities like Tony Curtis, Harry Belafonte, Walter Matthau and Rod Steiger, all of whom credit the chance to go to the dramatic workshop of New York's New School for Social Research with turning them into stars. But there are others who made it big in science, business and education. What they have in common is an appreciation, tinged with wonder, that their lives were changed utterly by a law.
The attention given to Mr. Belafonte and to Andrew Brimmer, a sharecropper's son who became the first black member of the Federal Reserve Board, diverts attention from the fact that black veterans had a much harder time than whites getting into an increasingly affluent mainstream. But the nation as a whole was transformed. By 1949, most Americans were homeowners; the suburban culture was created.
And with more than two million veterans going to college, barriers were broken at institutions like Harvard University, which had been wary of an influx of the unwashed. Even Ivy League bastions could not resist the tuition payments subsidized by Washington or deny that the veterans were serious students. Higher education was opened up, and so was much of American society.
Someone says tonight, "It was the most successful good program ever." As one of the many who went through college on the G.I. Bill, let me say amen.
 
'Divided Highways'
'The Interstates and the Transformation of American Life'
PBS, tonight
(Channel 13, New York, at 9)
Another mighty experiment in American social engineering, the highway building that took monumental shape in the 1950's, though far more criticized than the G.I. Bill, also opened the pleasures of suburbia to veterans and their young families and linked the nation as never before. Its less salutary effects, notably the destruction of neighborhoods, are not ignored in this colorful on-the-road history.
 
THE G.I. BILL
The Law That Changed America
PBS, tonight
(Channel 13, New York, at 8)
 
Ward Chamberlin and Tamara E. Robinson, executive producers; produced, directed and written by Karen Thomas. A co-production of WNET/New York and Film Odyssey.

HEADLINE: Eating Well;
Endorsements Raise Money and Questions

BYLINE: By Marian Burros

 BODY:
SINCE the American Heart Association changed its charter in 1988 to permit product endorsements, an arrangement it had prohibited from its founding in 1924, it has raised millions of dollars from such sources as the National Cattlemen's Beef Association, the Kellogg Company and Conagra.
The heart association, a nonprofit group, says the money supports research and education programs and helps spread its message promoting heart health. But critics are asking whether such arrangements confuse the public into thinking that a food endorsed by the group is better than one that is not. They also ask whether in the long run these arrangements are detrimental to charitable organizations by undermining their stance of objectivity. 
 Brigid McHugh Sanner, the heart association's senior vice president for communications and advocacy, said she had no comment on specific criticisms because she had not seen the data. She noted, however, that she objects to the word endorsement.
"We don't endorse products," she said. "We call those food-certification programs or corporate relationships. None of this constitutes an endorsement."
The American Heart Association is not the only nonprofit group to face concerns over corporate links. In August the American Medical Association withdrew its plan to endorse health-care products like blood-pressure monitors made by the Sunbeam Corporation after an avalanche of bad publicity. Even some of the group's members feared that the endorsement, the first in its history, could cause conflicts of interest.
The heart association charges varying fees for the use of its name. For $2,500, a company like Kellogg can put the association's heart-check symbol on, for example, a package of Fruity Marshmallow Krispies. The yearly renewal charge is $650.
That fee is modest compared with the $450,000 it cost the Florida Department of Citrus for an exclusive promotion and advertising contract with the association that lasted from 1994 until early this year. The exclusive agreement precluded any similar citrus trade association from using the heart association's endorsement.
The cattlemen's association paid $25,000 for its arrangement with the heart association, which promoted lean cuts of beef. Conagra's ads for its Healthy Choice products in The Wall Street Journal offer a nutrition tip and promote the association. In return for the use of its name, the nonprofit group agreed not to disclose how much it received from Conagra. For an earlier agreement with Conagra in 1992-93, it received $3,500,000 for a TV program on nutrition.
An association brochure says the heart-check certification program, established in 1992, is "designed to help consumers easily select foods in the grocery store that can be part of a balanced, heart-healthy diet." The association has so far certified 636 products. To be designated "heart healthy," a product must meet nutrient requirements established by the Food and Drug Administration or U.S. Department of Agriculture: it must be low in fat, saturated fat and cholesterol. The heart association also requires written assurance from the company that its nutritional labeling is correct.
ALL foods are eligible except those manufactured by a tobacco company or its subsidiaries. This excludes all products from Nabisco (a unit of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation) and Kraft, Post and Jell-O (all owned by Philip Morris). So Post's Raisin Bran cannot carry the heart-check symbol, while Kellogg's Raisin Bran can. And does.
Dr. James T. Bennett of George Mason University asks whether the heart association's arrangement with the Florida citrus group means that "California citrus won't help you with heart disease -- only Florida can." Dr. Bennett, a political economist, called such endorsements "ludicrous."
Dr. Bennett's sentiment was echoed by Dr. Michael Jacobson, the executive director of the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a Washington advocacy group. An endorsement "deceives people into thinking one product is better than another," he said.
For companies that want an exclusive agreement with the American Heart Association like that of the Florida citrus growers, the cost is $55,000 a quarter or $200,000 a year. Without exclusivity, the cost is $25,000 a quarter or $90,000 a year.
No matter the form of the endorsement, Dr. Jacobson said, "this is dangerous territory for nonprofits."
"The risk is if they get money from the dairy industry, will they be able to criticize the industry if the occasion arises?" he continued. "I think it's virtually impossible for a charity to bite the hands that feed it."
Dr. Bennett was particularly critical of the relationship between the cattlemen's association and the heart association, and pointed to their promotion of lean beef. The heart association also presented a "Champion of Heart" award to the group for its "contributions that have allowed A.H.A. to further its fight against heart disease and stroke." In exchange for "a very nice healthy grant," Dr. Bennett said, the cattlemen have a plaque to display from the heart association.
"They are compromising themselves, particularly when word gets out that they are getting big bucks," he said of the association. "Over time they will lose their credibility. They become a shill for corporate interests and there is no way you can dress that up as charitable activity. It is unethical." As soon as nonprofit groups are seen as an arm of industry, "it's going to hurt their fund raising, their stature," he added.
Ms. Sanner said research done by the association indicated the opposite. "We've done a number of marketing studies specifically about the certification program and we find the public is not confused about what the certification mark means," she said. But she added that the association has not done any surveys to gauge the public's reaction to the other promotional partnerships that have been forged with the food industry.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Renoir Portraits Show an Artist In Two Lights

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
"Great painters paint in order to learn to paint." The words of the French pedagogue and painter Andre Lohte apply with particular accuracy to the career of Pierre-Auguste Renoir. The great Impressionist spent his life moving restlessly from style to style, working under the spell of various contemporaries or masters from the past, loosening, then tightening his famously fluttery brushwork.
In "Renoir's Portraits: Impressions of an Age" at the Art Institute of Chicago," Renoir often comes across as the eternal student, an artist of many ups and downs, by turns dazzling, brittle or maudlin. Sometimes it even seems that he never quite hit his stride -- or rarely found it again after the 1870's. This is a startling reaction to have to such a historic figure, even one whose posthumous reputation has fluctuated as much as his has, and it's not clear whether it is his fault or the exhibition's. 
 Organized by Colin B. Bailey, chief curator at the National Gallery of Canada in Ottawa, where it originated last summer, "Renoir Portraits" benefits from the current popularity, bordering on frenzy, of Impressionist painting. The style may have hit Paris like a shock wave in 1874, when, led by Monet, a handful of renegades from the official government Salon defiantly organized their own exhibition. But by now Impressionism is so thoroughly adored that any exhibition focusing on any slice of its central players' careers is guaranteed success, regardless of quality. (The exhibition of Monet's Mediterranean paintings, now at the Brooklyn Museum, is a case in point.)
This show is not insubstantial. Renoir painted more portraits than any other Impressionist, and 62 of them, ranging through six decades, are gathered here. But many additional portraits are reproduced with Mr. Bailey's exceptionally detailed catalogue essay, and they suggest that the exhibition could have been stronger. Absent are key pictures, especially from the late 1860's, when Renoir was under the influence of Manet and Degas and made some of his most psychologically convincing portraits, and from the 1870's. (The show will lose several works when it goes to the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth in February.)
As seen in Chicago (through Jan. 4), the show's main purpose seems to be to please Renoir fans while reducing the chance that a larger, more definitive treatment of his portraits will be tried soon. Still, there's much to be learned from this selection of increasingly frothy, spun-sugar paintings with their high-key colors and unsettled brushwork, their oddly impersonal depictions of breathtakingly innocent children, young beauties and robust, matronly older women -- even if the lessons don't always flatter Renoir.
The son of a tailor, Renoir was the only Impressionist from a working class background. To the end of his long life, when he was considered one of the greatest living painters, he retained his plain speech, slightly rough manners and preference for models from his own social stratum (as opposed to what he called "those overbred females they call society women").
Because of his beginnings, Renoir was also the only Impressionist who was trained and then worked as an artisan before taking up fine art. During most of the 1850's, he worked in factories, painting china and later ladies' fans with felicitous portraits and pastoral scenes reminiscent of Watteau and Fragonard. (It was here as much as at the Louvre that he acquired his lifelong passion for 18th-century French painting.)
This background may have instilled practicality. When Impressionism failed to gain an art-buying public in the decade after its debut, Renoir began to paint for others to have money to paint for himself. He turned to commissioned portraits, soliciting clients and even submitting pictures to the Salon to establish his reputation.
To some extent, this may not have been such a leap. The exhibition begins with the artist's own words: "For me a picture . . . should be something likable, joyous and pretty -- yes pretty." The sentiment contradicts the haunted, Romantic look of Renoir's early self-portraits. It also echoes Matisse's thoughts on luxe, calm and comfortable armchairs, although Renoir's idea of pretty tended to be softer, without Matisse's hard-won formal rigor.
In the first three galleries, which contain the best, we see Renoir finding himself through the work of his elders -- Courbet, Manet and Degas -- sometimes with dramatic growth spurts. For example, a portrait of his brother from 1866 is all academic stiffness and small, affected flourishes; it suggests a gussied-up Thomas Eakins. Next to it, a portrait of the artist's father from 1867, is altogether different: a solid, engaging work, forthright in its physical handling of paint, subtle in its plays of pinks and white against grays and blacks, and complex in its emotional characterization. Manet's influence is everywhere evident. An 1867 portrait of Renoir's close friend, the painter Frederic Bazille, hunched over his easel has a similar directness of both feeling and paint.
 
The Impression: Tiny Heart of Gold
 Next, the brief span of high Impressionism is represented by several paintings that form the exhibition's tiny heart of gold. A standout is a brilliant little portrait of Camille Monet stretched out on a mountainous chintz sofa, reading. She is seen slightly from above, as if we are standing over her, about to interrupt her concentration. The informal pose, intimate space, soft suffused light and staccato brushwork are hallmarks of Impressionism, while the beguiling interplay of the flowered chintz and Camille's embroidered housecoat increases the work's unity. It has been brought off with an amazing economy of paint; up close one can often see the bare weave of the canvas.
Monet himself is shown in an even more active mode, painting, in two portraits. In one he stands at his easel in his overgrown garden, a floating, carefully controlled riot of reds and greens. The other, somewhat larger, places him indoors at the easel, catching him between brush strokes as he appraises an unseen subject.
From here on the exhibition becomes very uneven as it veers between commissioned works and more personal statements. Little stops you in your tracks, feels profound or looks inevitable. The large group portrait, "Luncheon of the Boating Party," Renoir's stagey, cloying masterpiece from 1881, is here from the Phillips Collection in Washington. Adjacent and playing David to this Goliath is the small, expertly tossed-off "Lunch at the Restaurant Fournaise," an image of two men and a woman lingering over wine, which is exquisitely subtle in its shadings of both light and human interaction.
Sometimes Renoir has the bravura of a slick society painter, as in the diaphanous portrait of the actress Henriette Honriot. Sometimes the sheer slipping, sliding clumsiness of the surface is startling, as in an 1882 portrait of the two daughters of the Impressionist's main dealer, Durand-Ruel. In a painting of two sisters as acrobats at the circus, he looks like a lesser Degas. In a late self-portrait and a pleasant, uncharacteristically thick-surfaced rendering of his wife, he looks toward Cezanne. The commanding portrait of Marguerite Charpentier sitting in her Japanese salon with her two cherubic children (now in the collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art) isolates luxurious passages of loose paint-handling within a conventionally realistic framework -- Impressionist technique in a proper Victorian straitjacket.
Renoir's idealizing, beautifying impulses often worked best in his paintings of children, especially the grave, dignified portraits from the late 1870's. Perhaps this was because their characters were relatively simple to begin with, their outlook genuinely untroubled, their faces more revealing.
But even this gift can pall from overuse. "Children's Afternoon at Wargemont," the final commissioned portrait in the exhibition, shows the three daughters of Paul Berard in their sitting room. Sharp edged, tightly rendered, the painting has the stiff almost primitive charm of a children's book illustration, and Mr. Bailey perceptively likens it to Balthus. But beneath its glossy surfaces is something that smacks of the artist's humiliation.
Mr. Bailey and other historians have argued that Renoir did not compromise himself in his commissioned portraits, and indeed their weaknesses may to some extent parallel similar dips in the rest of his work. (The Wargemont portrait, for example, was done in 1884, when Renoir, disillusioned with Impressionism, was flailing.)
 
How Security Affected the Art
 Nonetheless, things perk up in the exhibition's last two galleries, which feature the paintings of family and friends made after the late 1880's, when Renoir was financially able to forgo portrait commissions and was relying more and more on the Old Masters, especially Rubens, for inspiration.
Finally, the strokes stop sliding and curl gently around their inflated, almost cartoonish subjects. Colors are rich, odd and matte of surface, pointing toward Bonnard's drifting hues (and maybe even Color Field Painting). The best work is a portrait of the art dealer Ambroise Vollard from 1908. Shown in profile against a deep rose background, he sits with his elbows on a table, intently studying a little Maillol sculpture of a nude that he cradles in his hands. As with the earlier portraits of Monet and his wife, it is an image of attentive concentration, and it offers a comforting conclusion to Renoir's erratic journey through portraiture.
