HEADLINE: Despite the Bad News, The Fishing Is Good

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL

 BODY:
MAYBE there will always be plenty of fish in the sea.
Even as the country's beloved cod and flounder, bluefin tuna and native swordfish have become scarce, tons of fresh, mild-tasting white-fleshed fish from far-flung seas are softening the pain of the dwindling supplies. 
 Wild sea bass from Chile, yellowtail and greentail snapper from South America, red mullet or "rouget" from North Africa have turned airports into fish ports. And they may turn the hard times of American fisheries into a boon for food lovers in this country, while giving local fish stocks at least a chance to recover.
Today the best-priced and highest-quality fish around are more likely to hail from Icelandic waters or the Indian Ocean than from Cape May or Cape Cod. And many of the immigrant species are richer, more interesting fish. The flake -- the overlapping layers of flesh in the fillet -- tends to be larger in these fish, making them harder to overcook, and therefore capable of reaching gastronomic heights unmatched by the more delicate domestic varieties of white fish.
Ports from Chile to Thailand are now equipped with modern processing plants and staffed by experienced low-cost laborers. The fish are packed in customized foam-plastic containers and rushed to airports, reaching New York almost as quickly as from Cape Cod or Florida and usually less expensively. When they arrive at the Fulton Fish Market, the whole yellowtail and greentail snappers are glistening and quivering in their white insulated boxes. The eyes of the rouget -- even after so long a journey -- are clear and unclouded, and the startling fresh char smells like cucumber. This is perfect, pristine fish, the cream of the imported crop.
Last year, $6.7 billion worth of edible fish was imported, compared with the $3.6 billion of fish harvested in waters off the United States.
"Our fish imports are almost double what they were 20 years ago," said Dr. James Anderson, a professor of natural resource economics at the University of Rhode Island and the publisher of Seafood Market Analyst/ Seafood Report, a monthly newsletter in Narragansett, R.I.
"The Atlantic ground fish are scarce, with the exception of the Alaskan canning fisheries," he said. "The Pacific coast is in trouble and, thanks to the craze for blackened redfish, the Gulf fisheries are extinct as a commercial enterprise, though they are coming back as a recreational fishing area.
"We tend to import fresh, high-value seafood and export processed fish, lesser-quality fish, as well as good fish like mackerel, herring and fish roe that America has never developed a taste for."
In addition to formerly unfamiliar species, fish markets across the country are offering tuna and mahi-mahi from Ecuador, a glut of farm-raised shrimp from Mexico and Thailand, swordfish from Brazil and the Azores, cod from Iceland and farmed salmon from the Bay of Fundy in Canada.
David Samuels, the third-generation owner of Blue Ribbon Fish, a wholesale business at the Fulton Fish Market, said his grandfather would be shocked at the way he buys fish. Instead of dealing with individual boat captains, Mr. Samuels works the fax and telephone lines, worries about the price of international air freight and would be out of business without a reliable customs broker and shipper.
But his grandfather would be even more startled, Mr. Samuels said, at his prices. "I'm selling this gorgeous Atlantic salmon from Canada for the same price he sold domestic salmon 50 years ago," he said. "If I had to rely on domestic sources for salmon, tuna or sword, I'd be out of business."
If he were dependent on domestic sources for shrimp, salmon and tuna, he added, "the prices could triple."
Tuna taken in North American waters can fetch as much as $15 a pound, according to Steven Cohen, manager of the fish department at Balducci's in Manhattan, while tuna imported from Chile can bring as little as $5.
Mr. Samuels understands that the new global fish business offers opportunities for unscrupulousness among distant suppliers. He said there is "plenty of old scrubby fish around, fish that was improperly handled at sea or packed, fish that missed its airline connection, old, inferior fish." Mr. Samuels puts his trust in his own eyes and a handshake. Instead of driving to local ports, as his grandfather did, he flies to Brazil and Chile, to Iceland, China and Thailand.
The best wholesale importers deliver exquisite white-fleshed fish like Chilean sea bass and Arctic char that are mild-mannered and infinitely adaptable, fish that seem custom made for American taste -- they can slide nearly unnoticed into traditional recipes. The change from a local to an international fishery poses no trauma for cooks or diners.
At the same time there are some welcome culinary challenges. The imported fish tend to be richer than domestic white fish and have a larger and more forgiving flake; such character is irresistible to chefs, because it lets them invent more complex recipes for fish that can endure long, slow cooking. The rich, large-flaked fish allowed Eric Ripert to create a dish of Arctic char with fava beans and peas, for instance, delighting his customers at Le Bernardin in Manhattan.
But even with all the raves about foreign fish, a few Americans aren't buying.
Mike Foley, the third-generation owner of M. F. Foley in New Bedford, Mass., is one of the rare East Coast fish purveyors who have remained unwaveringly faithful to fish caught off New England -- what there is of it. (The harvest from New England's fisheries has dropped to 641 million pounds in 1996 from 780 million in 1980, but the most telling loss is among favored fish like cod: the catch fell to 31 million pounds from 118 million in the same period.)
Mr. Foley acknowledged that imported fish, because it is so plentiful, can be less expensive, but he said the foreign is not always top quality. For instance, he said, swordfish from Chile and tuna from Ecuador are harvested during their spawning season, and are therefore mushier and inferior. Recent reports of contaminated fish from South America also concern him.
But most fishmongers -- and American seafood aficionados -- are too grateful for a steady supply of relatively inexpensive fish to quibble over character and nuance.
"I love red snapper from the gulf more than anything in the world," said Mr. Cohen of Balducci's. "But there isn't any real snapper left in the gulf, so I'm learning to love the yellowtail snapper from South America. It's not red snapper, but it's good fish."
Such concessions may have already led to some recovery in the native fish stocks off North America. After years of concern over the depletion of the oceans, some environmental scientists believe -- perhaps hope is a better word -- that the lessons of the past have been learned. They even see new evidence that American fisheries are on the way back.
Preliminary statistics recently published by the National Marine Fisheries Service show the first hint that the free fall in Atlantic fishing stocks is stabilizing, according to Dr. Steven Murawski, the chief biologist at the Northeast Fisheries Center in Woods Hole, Mass.
"There's been a modest upturn," he said. "But there are still far too many vessels that are far too efficient for harvesting the stocks that will be available soon."
Marion Kaiser, the president of Aquanor Marketing in Boston, which imports fish from Iceland and Norway, said that stringent regulations in those countries have brought "a stunning recovery to their fisheries."
Congress is currently considering a one-year moratorium along some parts of the Atlantic coast on the use of super-trawlers, which are more than 350 feet long and can net as much as 250 metric tons of fish in a day.
But like many seafood lovers, Dr. Murawski said that a complete comeback of the native fisheries depends on a shift in public taste. Spiny dogfish, also called sand shark (the fish of fish and chips in England), is cheap, delicious and abundant, he said. So are mackerel, herring and whiting.
But the American taste in fish grew out of generations of eating only mild-tasting, white-fleshed varieties, so changing public taste is really a matter of changing habits. And habits die hard.
 
The Cautionary Tale of the Roughy
 AS the fishing industry searches the world for new fish, it is one thing to hope for a better environmental result this time and another to really believe in one. The history of the fishing industry gives one reason to pause.
"We need the imports to take the stress off the local fisheries," said Jasper White, the executive chef of Legal Seafoods in Boston. "But every solution to the fish riddle has a down side. The imports hurt the local fisherman and also run the risk of extinguishing entire species in other parts of the world. Look what happened to orange roughy."
In 1979, when domestic flounder was becoming more difficult to find, a treasure trove of roughy was discovered near the Challenger Plateau off New Zealand. Roughy, a firm, white-fleshed fish that can weigh as much as 20 pounds, is almost interchangeable with large flounder in the kitchen.
Before roughy started being filleted and frozen at sea and groomed for the American market, the fish was known as slimhead. Repackaged as orange roughy at about $2 a pound frozen or $8 a pound fresh, it became the American fish of the 1980's.
So quickly was roughy sucked out of the sea that as much as 80 percent of the population was wiped out before scientists realized that the fish, which lives up to 100 years, takes more than a quarter of a century to reach sexual maturity.
New Zealand took immediate action and strictly limited how much roughy could be caught. Scientists say that they now believe that the population has been restored to 60 percent of what it was before the boom, and that they expect it to be completely restored in a few years. New Zealand's fisheries are now considered among the best managed in the world.
"The right fish and the right marketing campaign can create a voracious appetite in America," said Marion Kaiser, the president of Aquanor Marketing in Boston, which imports farmed salmon, Arctic char and Icelandic cod. "We don't have to work to sell high-quality imported fish to Americans," she said. "We have to work to buy and sell responsibly."
 
ROUGET ESCABECHE
Adapted from "Fish and Shellfish" (James Peterson, Morrow, 1996)
Total time: 15 minutes, plus marination
 
 6 8-ounce fillets of rouget (red mullet)
 Salt and freshly ground black pepper, to taste
 1/2 cup flour
 7 tablespoons olive oil
 1 red onion, thinly sliced
 2 cloves garlic, peeled
 2/3 cup sherry vinegar
 2 bay leaves
 1/2 teaspoon fresh thyme leaves
 2 tablespoons chopped parsley
 6 baby artichokes, trimmed and quartered
 1 fennel bulb, sliced
 1/2 cup green olives, pitted.
 
 1. Season the fish fillets with salt and pepper, and dust lightly with flour. Warm two tablespoons of the olive oil in a large skillet and saute 3 fillets over high heat 2 minutes on each side. Carefully remove the fish, transfer to a nonreactive dish and pat dry. Repeat with the 3 remaining fillets.
 2. Wipe out the saute pan, add 1 more tablespoon olive oil and cook the red onion and garlic over medium-low heat about 7 minutes. Add the vinegar, bay leaves and thyme and simmer 5 minutes. Add 1 tablespoon olive oil and the parsley and cook 1 minute. Pour this mixture over the fish and marinate in the refrigerator at least 2 hours and up to 3 days.
 3. Before serving, steam artichokes until soft, about 10 minutes. Put 1 tablespoon olive oil in a medium saute pan and cook sliced fennel over medium-low heat until soft, about 7 minutes. Toss artichokes and fennel with the olives and serve alongside the marinated fish.
 Yield: 6 servings.
 
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 500 calories, 25 grams fat, 110 milligrams cholesterol, 680 milligrams sodium (before salting), 45 grams protein, 20 grams carbohydrate.
 
ARCTIC CHAR WITH FAVA BEANS AND PEAS
Adapted from Le Bernardin
Total time: 40 minutes
 
 4 tablespoons butter, thinly sliced, plus an additional tablespoon for greasing skillets
 4 7-ounce fresh Arctic char fillets
 Salt and freshly ground white pepper to taste
 3/4 cup shelled small peas
 24shelled fava beans, skinned
 12 snow peas, cut across into thin strips
 4 teaspoons cooked and julienned bacon
 4 scallions, the first inch of white only, quartered lengthwise
 1/2 cup shredded iceberg lettuce
 2 cups fish stock
 4 small sprigs fresh mint, plus 8 leaves chopped.
 
 1. Butter 2 12- to 14-inch skillets and set aside. Cut away the thin white belly section from the char fillets and season on both sides with salt and white pepper. Place 2 fillets in the middle of each skillet and surround with the peas, fava beans, snow peas, bacon, scallions and lettuce. Season the vegetables with salt and white pepper. (The fish can be prepared to this point several hours ahead.)
 2. Pour the fish stock into the skillets and place each one on a burner turned to high heat. Bring the stock to a boil. Lower the heat to medium-high. Cook 5 to 7 minutes, basting frequently.
 3. Carefully place 4 fillets on plates. Surround each with a quarter of the vegetables.
 4. Sprinkle the chopped mint over the vegetables and lay a mint sprig on each fillet. Serve immediately.
 Yield: 4 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 555 calories, 35 grams fat, 50 milligrams cholesterol, 385 milligrams sodium (before salting), 50 grams protein, 11 grams carbohydrate.

DOGFISH STEW
Adapted from "Provincetown Portuguese Cookbook" by Mary-Jo Avellar
(Morris Publishing, 1997)
Total time: 1 hour
 
 1 28-ounce can Italian tomatoes
 1 pound white onion, chopped
 1/4 cup fresh cilantro, chopped
 2 cloves garlic, minced
 1 jalapeno pepper, stemmed, seeded and chopped
 1/4 cup fresh lime juice
 3 tablespoons olive oil
 Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
 2 dogfish (sand shark) fillets, about 3 1/2 pounds, cut into 6 to 8 pieces
 1 pound medium-size shrimp, peeled
 1/2 cup fish broth, clam juice or water
 1 red bell pepper, diced
 1 green pepper, diced.

 1. In a food processor, pulse the tomatoes, onion, cilantro, garlic, chili, lime juice, oil, salt and pepper until smooth. Marinate the fish and shrimp in this mixture for an hour.
 2. Place the marinated fish in a heavy pot over medium heat. Add the fish broth and a cup of the marinade. Bring to a boil, reduce heat and simmer 30 minutes. Remove fish from liquid and cool. Add the shrimp and peppers and simmer over low heat 10 minutes. Meanwhile, when the fish is cool enough to handle, remove the skin and chunk into bite-size pieces. Return to pot, add salt and pepper and serve over rice.
 Yield: 2 quarts (6 servings).
 
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 450 calories, 15 grams fat, 255 milligrams cholesterol, 500 milligrams sodium (before salting), 70 grams protein, 6 grams carbohydrate.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up Against the Mark, But It Falters in Yen Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar turned in a mixed performance yesterday, helped by a rebounding United States stock market and hurt by a sharp widening in the American trade deficit.
The announcement of an economic recovery plan for Japan and a reduced outlook for higher interest rates in Germany also created cross-currents for currency traders. 
 In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.7896 German marks, up from 1.7725 on Monday. But the dollar slipped to 120.82 Japanese yen from 121.16. The British pound also rose against the dollar, climbing to $1.6353 from $1.6340.
The Government reported that the United States trade deficit widened to $10.4 billion in August, a bigger gap than expected. But while the flow of dollars out of the United States to buy foreign goods held down the dollar, rising stocks made dollars attractive to international investors. The Dow Jones industrial average, up 74 points on Monday, added 139 yesterday to regain the ground lost at the end of last week.
The dollar was also helped by a slowdown of the growth in Germany's money supply in September. The currency markets took this to mean that the German central bank, under an anti-inflation policy of holding down growth of the money supply, would be less inclined to raise its interest rates again.
The dollar rose after the release of these data despite another report, from Germany's Ifo economic institute, that business confidence rose by more than expected in September. That report would appear to bolster the view that further increases in rates, which could support the mark against the dollar, might be needed.
The dollar fell against the yen after Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party presented proposals aimed at lifting Japan's flagging economy. Though the plan did not lay out any specific measures for fiscal stimulus, it did emphasize deregulating the economy and reforming taxes. A bigger factor in the yen's gain may have been the rise in the United States trade deficit, however.
Claude LaMedica, foreign exchange trader at Republic National Bank in New York, said that he expected the dollar to rise against the yen over time in reaction to severe economic problems across the developing economies of the Far East.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Prices Retreat Sharply On Fears Supplies Will Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Copper futures fell sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, reversing days of gains amid perceptions that increased production and slack Asian demand would lead to a glut.
On other markets, grain and soybean futures rose sharply on concern that world demand would cause the fall harvest to dwindle rapidly. Natural gas futures jumped to nine-month highs as forecasts for colder weather in parts of the Northern United States increased demand. 
 Copper futures prices have tumbled in recent months as the Asian buying that buoyed the market early this year abruptly slowed to a trickle while the region grapples with a currency crisis. The financial problems have slowed construction; copper is used for wiring and plumbing.
Market participants have been encouraged by falling inventories in the last week on the London Metal Exchange, but supplies remain far above levels of a year ago and the Asian crisis could depress prices for the next six months, said William O'Neill, an analyst at Merrill Lynch.
Copper also retreated after Chile reported that a state-owned copper refinery, Chuquicamata No. 3, had returned to 100 percent production several days earlier than expected. A weekend fire had cut production to 85 percent of capacity at the refinery, which produces 690,000 tons of copper cathode annually.
Copper for December delivery fell 2.05 cents, to 94.90 cents a pound.
Grain and soybean futures prices rose sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade amid expectations that export demand soon would begin to cut into ample American inventories.
"They know demand is already starting to build, and people are afraid they're going to be left at the gate when the market takes off like they know it will," said Doug Hjort, an analyst at the farm marketing advisory firm Hjort & Associates.
December wheat rose 5 1/2 cents, to $3.76 a bushel; December corn rose 4 1/2 cents, to $2.87 1/2 a bushel; November soybeans rose 3 3/4 cents, to $6.94 3/4 a bushel.
Natural gas futures rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange as forecasts for below-normal temperatures in the Northeast and the Midwest lifted demand. November natural gas settled up 1.4 cents at $3.404 for each 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: Labor Department Focuses on 401(k)'s

BYLINE: Dow Jones

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
The Labor Department wants to know what employers are doing to keep down the costs to their workers of 401(k) plans, Labor Secretary Alexis M. Herman said today.
Fees for 401(k) plans are a front-burner issue for the department, Ms. Herman said at a meeting of the Erisa Industry Committee, which represents large employers with benefit plans. 
 The Labor Department will hold a daylong hearing on the topic next month, Ms. Herman said. In addition to considering what employers are doing to keep fees down, the hearing will look at whether employees realize how much they are paying.
Ms. Herman acknowledged that employees who invested their 401(k) savings in stock funds had not done badly in recent years. But stock market gains and a strong economy have not helped all Americans, she said. Wage increases have been modest and pension benefits remain out of reach for many, she said, and with widespread layoffs, job security is too low for many workers' comfort.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
30-Year Bond Extends Gain; Others Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Treasury securities ended mixed yesterday as comments from four Federal Reserve officials did little to ease investor uncertainty over whether the central bank would raise interest rates at its November policy-making meeting.
The 30-year bond rose 5/32, to a price of 99 18/32, extending its rebound from losses last week. Its yield, which falls when prices rise, eased to 6.41 percent, from 6.42 percent on Monday. But some shorter-term maturities fell in price.
dr 
 Greg Jones, an economist with Briefing.com, a market analysis firm in Menlo Park, Calif., said the market seesawed within a narrow range, influenced mostly by Fed comments that pushed prices one way or another.
He said many participants were awaiting the release next week of the Labor Department's Employment Cost Index for the third quarter as well as Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. Both events could provide some insight into whether inflationary pressures are rising.
Comments from Mr. Greenspan's subordinates did little to resolve uncertainty over the Fed's intentions.
Alice M. Rivlin, the Fed vice chairwoman, said the central bank must be on guard to prevent the economy from overheating, the Market News Service reported. Jack Guynn, president of the Atlanta Fed, said at the University of Tennessee that the central bank was determined "not to let ourselves lose the gains we've made on inflation." The San Francisco Fed's president, Robert T. Parry, said in Twin Falls, Idaho, that the economy was slowing to a moderate pace. And the Richmond Fed's president, J. Alfred Broaddus Jr., said in Rocky Mount, N.C., that the economy was doing well and suggested strong growth would push prices higher.
Early in the session the bond market weakened slightly after the Government reported that the August trade deficit widened to an eight-month high because of record imports, suggesting continued solid domestic demand.
Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns Securities, said she expected further volatility in the market ahead of the Employment Cost Index report next Tuesday and Mr. Greenspan's testimony next Wednesday.
Scott F. Grannis, a director and chief economist at Western Asset Management in Pasadena, Calif., noted that the long-bond yield was still bumping along at levels roughly 20 basis points higher than the lows achieved earlier this month. He attributed the increase to renewed investor anxiety about inflation.
Mr. Grannis also said the absence of any clear inflation evidence suggested that the Fed might not raise rates, laying the basis for a possible rally. "Today's lower bond prices represent an attractive buying opportunity in our view," he said.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Rose as China Swelled Gap During August

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit widened in August to $10.4 billion, driven substantially by a record imbalance with China, the Commerce Department reported today.
The release of the report, which shows the United States deficit with China at $5.2 billion, the most of any nation, comes a week before President Jiang Zemin of China arrives in Washington on his first state visit. The strong American economy and a higher dollar have swelled imports, including a tide of Chinese toys and Christmas decorations. 
 "There is no question," William M. Daley, the Secretary of Commerce, told reporters today, referring specifically to China, "that the mounting trade deficit remains a major concern for this Administration."
Imports rose six-tenths of 1 percent, to $88.32 billion, a record. Exports also rose to a record, but at $77.96 billion, up two-tenths of 1 percent, expanding the deficit by $400 million, to the widest since January.
Most analysts expect the gap for the full year to surpass the eight-year high of $111 billion set in 1996.
While the August deficit was wider than expected, economists said the report did little to change their view of business activity, other than trim estimates of total output for the third quarter.
But the trade figures may aggravate political problems for the Clinton Administration.
The White House is struggling to find enough Congressional support to win enhanced authority, or a fast track, for negotiating trade agreements. And President Clinton is to meet here with the Chinese President at a time when trade is a prominent sticking point between the two countries.
Insisting that "our exports have got to grow," Mr. Daley, the Commerce Secretary, said he expected that a Chinese buying mission that had just arrived in the United States would place orders for telecommunications equipment, environmental technology, energy equipment and an expected $4 billion worth of Boeing Company airplanes. Such purchases would make a huge, if temporary, dent in the trade deficit with China.
The United States deficit with China jumped 10.6 percent in August, today's report showed, with the category that includes toys and holiday decorations accounting for about half the increase.
But since figures for trade flows between two countries are not adjusted for recurring seasonal variation, analysts said China did not necessarily account for half the $10.4 billion overall American deficit.
By contrast, the American deficit with Japan -- often the biggest of any country -- narrowed to $4.5 billion from $5.2 billion, the first shrinkage since May. This occurred despite a slight rise in imports of Japanese motor vehicles and parts.
But on an annual basis the Japanese imbalance was still running 17 percent higher than the comparable 1996 pace, a situation that also drew the Administration's attention. Mr. Daley, noting a 1997 decline in American exports to Japan, said that while this was not surprising in light of the economic doldrums there, "we must continue to press for further deregulation, additional market opening and full implementation of our trade agreements with Japan."
Analysts tend to see the deficit with Japan as the more worrisome, partly because China's overall trade position is in relative balance while Japan ran an $8.8 billion merchandise surplus in September. Moreover, relatively little of Chinese imports to this country displaces American production.
C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, said today that the overall trade deficit "continues at a high and modestly increasing level" and predicted this trend would extend into next year.
"We're beginning to see the full effects of the stronger dollar," he said.
Exports, today's report showed, were paced by the first increase of the year in sales of American farm products and by a lesser rise in exports of industrial supplies and materials.
The biggest portion of the higher imports consisted of computer accessories and other capital goods followed by industrial supplies and materials. Analysts commented favorably on the fact that this appeared to reflect a process of expanding the supply of goods rather than of consumption.
The deficit with Canada widened by $300 million, to $1.6 billion, while exports to Mexico and imports from Mexico both hit records while leaving the deficit unchanged at $1 billion.

HEADLINE: Bull Market's Glitter May Be Blinding Investors

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA

 BODY:
It was less than a week ago that stock investors fretted about the possibility of a huge decline as the 10th anniversary of the Oct. 19, 1987, crash approached. But the real concern may be whether investors have become too giddy.
A recent survey of mutual fund investors would suggest so, raising the possibility they may be laying the basis for a major disappointment. 
 The survey by Montgomery Asset Management in San Francisco found investors expected an average annual return of 34 percent over the next 10 years, a figure that shocked many financial advisers because it is so far above historical averages.
"People have become completely enamored of the stock market; there's a love affair with it," said Raymond DeVoe, a market strategist at Legg Mason. "There is this total blind belief that the market can do no wrong."
That kind of bullish sentiment was clearly at work yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average rose sharply for the second consecutive session, up 139 points, or 1.75 percent, to close at 8,060.44.
Strong earnings reports from I.B.M. and Microsoft -- technology bellwethers that represent the old breed and the new -- helped touch off a rally that also sent broader measures higher.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index surged 16.67 points, or 1.74 percent, to 972.28, and the Nasdaq composite index jumped 27.09 points, or 1.61 percent, to 1,712.54.
For the Dow, the gains of yesterday and Monday erased the nearly 200 points lost last week when the market tumbled just as it was nearing the anniversary of the crash a decade ago. Rebounds like that inspire confidence, analysts said.
But what few investors know is that despite the outsized gains of recent years, the last 30 years have actually produced below-average returns, when adjusted for inflation. In other words, the great bull market that began in 1982 has not yet been powerful enough to undo the damage done in the previous 15 years, which included the bear market of 1973-74.
For some Wall Street analysts who lived through less exalted times, therein lies a lesson: beware first-time investors. Although these may be extraordinary times, history suggests that long-term stock market returns are much tamer, and so it is unlikely that stocks will continue to rise at this torrid pace.
In fact, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, offered just such a warning two weeks ago, when he cautioned investors that it would be "unrealistic" to expect stock returns to keep rising at the current rate.
For the last three years, the market has done little wrong. Few investors have suffered since the sharp increase in prices that helped send the Dow to gains of 33 percent in 1995, 26 percent in 1996 and 25 percent so far this year.
Never before has the Dow had three consecutive years with gains of 20 percent or more. Logical Information Machines, a research concern in Chicago, said that the current three-year run was one of the greatest of all time.
Those kinds of returns bolster optimism. Earlier this year, the Montgomery survey showed investors expected annual returns of about 22 percent over the next 10 years, compared with 34 percent in the most recent tally.
At a 34 percent pace, the Dow average would exceed 120,000 in the year 2007. That is assuming a dividend yield of about 3 percent, which is well above current prices.
Is such a gain likely? Theodore Aronson at Aronson & Partners, a money management firm based in Philadelphia, said the best 10-year run for the Dow average was 17.1 percent, in the period ending in June 1959. What does Mr. Aronson think of those who are expecting a 34 percent return? "They must have polled the loony bin," he said.
Jeremy J. Siegel, a professor at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, is gentler. He cautioned investors not to get too excited.
His studies show that after inflation, stocks achieve an average annual return of about 7 percent, going all the way back to 1802. In spite of wars, social upheavals and and other bumps on the road of history, stock returns tend to settle at that level.
"The long-run return is always the same, about 7 percent," Mr. Siegel said. "I've found this remarkable stability over time."
In the last 30 years, however, stock returns have trailed slightly, he said. The average stock return from 1966 to 1997 was about 6.03 percent compounded annually, nearly a percentage point below the historical average of 6.99 percent, after inflation.
In mid-1967, for instance, the Dow stood at 860.25. And 15 years later, in mid-1982, it stood at 811.94 -- a loss of nearly 6 percent, but much more when inflation is factored in.
Why take note of such figures? Because many investors are too optimistic, analysts say, and the higher the expectation, the greater the possibility that some will be scared out of the market during a sudden downturn.
"We have a stock market that's full of virgins," said Ron Chernow, a financial historian and author of "The Death of the Banker."
"They've had a very atypical experience in the market; it's had this very pleasant attitude of going up all the time," he said. "So we don't know how they'll behave during downturns."
Because so many of the nation's financial assets are locked up in the stock market, almost automatically, through 401(k) retirement plans, Mr. Chernow said he believed the market might be secure from a huge collapse.
But like other analysts and historians, he worries that the kind of crowd psychology that has driven prices ever higher could reverse course and depress a whole generation of first-time investors.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
The American Airlines pact with Asiana is part of a strategy to increase a Pacific Rim presence.

BYLINE: By Jane L. Levere

 BODY:
AMERICAN AIRLINES' new code-sharing and frequent-flier partnership with Asiana Airlines -- which is based in Seoul, South Korea -- is part of a long-range strategy by the Dallas-based carrier to heighten its presence in the Pacific Rim.
American, a unit of AMR and a powerhouse in the United States and Latin America, has been seeking -- so far unsuccessfully -- to join forces in Europe with British Airways since June 1996. It has historically been a minor player in Asia, especially compared with Northwest Airlines and UAL's United Airlines. Both Northwest and United have major hubs at Narita Airport in Tokyo that allow them to serve multiple points in the region; Northwest has been flying extensively to Asia since 1947, while United bought Pan Am's trans-Pacific operation in 1985. 
 American has no comparable hub capability in Tokyo and currently only flies there from Seattle, Dallas, and San Jose, Calif. It has resisted setting up its own point-to-point operation from cities in the United States to other cities in Asia, said James Beer, managing director of international planning, because it "hasn't made economic sense with the equipment that was available."
The best way for American to offer trans-Pacific service to the highly lucrative business travel market has been to strike cooperative code-sharing and frequent-flier agreements with Asian airlines, which in turn find the feed traffic from American highly desirable.
In addition to Asiana, American has struck code-sharing and frequent flier-pacts with China Airlines of Taiwan, Singapore Airlines and Qantas; it also has frequent-flier agreements with Japan Airlines and Cathay Pacific. Code-sharing agreements are also pending with Philippine Airlines and China Eastern Airlines.
"We want to build a network in Asia with some of our own flights and with alliances with others, to build a competitive passenger services network," Robert L. Crandall, chairman of American, said last week.
In the longer term, Mr. Beer said American might well deploy some of the 12 Boeing 777's it will receive between 1999 and 2000 on routes to Asia. The carrier is also seeking authority to fly the Chicago-Tokyo route in the United States' current bilateral negotiations with Japan, and it is conducting discussions about further cooperation with other Asian airlines to fill the gap in service in Southeast Asia, Mr. Beer said.
 
Travel Deal in Asia
One way to travel inexpensively through Asia today is to purchase Cathay Pacific's All Asia Pass, available only to individuals who have registered on the carrier's Web site (www.cathay-usa.com). Priced at $999, including all taxes, the pass is good for round-trip economy-class travel from either Los Angeles or New York to Hong Kong, plus unlimited economy-class travel to 17 other cities in Asia. There are seven-day minimum- and 30-day maximum-stay requirements, and all travel must be completed by Dec. 15.
Cathay Pacific officials said the promotion was created to stimulate traffic, which has dropped substantially since the July 1 handover of the Hong Kong Government to China.
 
Hotel Update
Hyatt Hotels and Resorts has consolidated details of all current promotional offers at its 107 hotels and resorts in the United States, Canada and the Caribbean into a program called Hyatt Extras, and is offering these data through a special telephone number (888-584-1234) and on its Web site (www.hyatt.com).
The ITT Sheraton Corporation has expanded its program that allows guests to check in at 9 A.M. and out at 5 P.M. to all guests who pay eligible rates and sign up at registration for its frequent-guest plan. Previously, the program was offered only to those who had previously been members of the plan.
Orient Express, a unit of Sea Containers Ltd., has opened a new, 120-room, Mediterranean-style luxury hotel near the zoo in Johannesburg, South Africa. The hotel, which features a spa, gym, five pools and two restaurants, is offering introductory rates, through Nov. 30 and from Feb. 1 to April 30, 1998, of $160 for a single and $200 for a double.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Worldthink Inc.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Why should professional opinion-mongers be the last to cash in on globalization?
Here we see the once-Big Eight accounting firms amalgamating into the Big Two. Gone are the worries about conflicting client interests; the new giant will handle Coke and Pepsi and profess not to tip their secrets to Dr. Brown's Diet Cel-Ray. 
 As that trend continues, the walls between advertisers will collapse, as the new hyperagency of Burnett, Thompson, Grey & Rubicam find no headache in simultaneously selling Tylenol, Excedrin and Advil and pretending to compete.
For competition means stress, and stress is seen to be evil. To avoid creating gastric acids among investment bankers, superbanker Goldman Salomon Barney will manipulate a merger among the Seven Sisters of oil with Russia's Gazprom monopoly.
Law firms will surely follow the trend set by single-bean accountancy and the superbankers going into the supertank. Where is it written, except in archaic ethics rules, that one huge agglomeration of attorneys (Jones, Baker, Skadden, Cravath & Case) cannot handle both sides in a civil dispute? Consider the efficiencies in having big-name criminal defense lawyers become "of counsel" to the local U.S. attorney.
This surge of corporate centripetalism is bottomed on the supposed need to compete on a global basis. Thus is competition squelched in the name of competition.
It's time that pundits got with the program. Hence my proposal for the creation of Worldthink Inc., the opinion superstore chain.
Surely if all the carriers of telecommunication can jack up stock prices to gobble up each other, we content-providers (formerly writers) can join forces, assemble our intellectual power, pool our marketable celebrity and earn the decent respect of the opinion of mankind while becoming multibillionaires.
Skeptics will ask: Wouldn't Worldthink Inc. reduce competition in the marketplace of ideas?
Just the opposite; the conglomeration of columnists will stimulate intercontinental argument, which, as is well known, is in danger of domination from group-thinking New Europeans and econo-cultural combines of bright-burning Asian tigers.
Isn't it time America marshaled the Sunday forces of Cokie Roberts, Tim Russert, Bob Schieffer and Sam Donaldson to combat the challenge from Rupert Murdoch's skyviews and the lockstep mind-bending of Russia's media oligarchy?
Can't the multicultural multinationals making obsequious deals with China's thought-controllers be countered by our food-fighting McLaughlinites, our fair-minded Lehrerites, our Capital Gangsters?
If the entire punditry dodge owned stock in the same company, we would be forever locked in immortal combat. Ownership of inflatable Worldthink stock would stimulate us to differ fiercely and entertainingly.
Controversy sells; or, as the younger pundits say in their vivid vernacular, objectivity sucks. On a dull day, David Broder and I can rail at each other about the media-government revolving door, or Mary McGrory can wake up the page with a pop at Nixon's ghost. Nobody dares take on profoundly commonsensical Meg Greenfield, but Maureen Dowd and The New Yorker's Tina Brown have developed a deliciously adversarial relationship.
As shareholders in Worldthink Inc., minds as contrary as Charles Krauthammer and Richard Cohen, or Al Hunt and Robert Novak, would have the same vested interest in sustaining interest. Intellectual jousting is thereby guaranteed, and consistency of Weltanschauung enforced; one could not be pro-Nafta- enlargement and anti-NATO-enlargement, or anti-Clinton and pro-Gore, without derision from cognitively consonant peers.
But what happens, investors may ask, when the worm turns? In a few years, the cry from overseas will be "Break up the Yankees!" The pendulum will swing, as it did against mindless conglomeration in the 80's, and "multi" will become a dirty prefix. The rush will be on to hire "niche" professionals who don't represent competitors.
Then we content-providers will spin ourselves off, as Worldthink splits into smithereens and Individualism Inc. becomes the hot stock. Make another fortune.

LENGTH: 714 words

HEADLINE: Russia and France Balk at U.S. Plan to Punish Iraq Even More

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Despite the personal intervention of Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, the United States is meeting sustained resistance in the Security Council to its plan for imposing new sanctions on Iraq, diplomats on the Council said today.
With a vote on the issue likely to take place in the next few days, the United States is trying to negotiate a compromise that would leave the threat intact but postpone the date the additional sanctions would be applied. 
 The Clinton Administration, unable to win approval for new sanctions now, is arguing for an automatic start for the new measures in six months unless the Iraqi Government significantly improves its accounting of prohibited weapons systems and cooperates fully with United Nations arms inspectors.
The United States, supported by Britain and more than half a dozen other Council members, would like to restrict the international travel of high Iraqi officials because of President Saddam Hussein's continuing failure to tell the truth about chemical and biological weapons as well as missiles. There are also some outstanding questions about Iraq's nuclear program. Furthermore, Iraqi officials have been interfering with the work of the United Nations inspectors.
Iraq has threatened to stop all cooperation with the weapons inspections if new sanctions are imposed.
Opposition to the new sanctions on Iraq, which has been under a near-total economic embargo since its invasion of Kuwait in 1990, comes primarily from Russia and France, which have hopes of large future business deals with Baghdad, a leading oil exporter before its attempt to seize Kuwait.
Bill Richardson, the United States representative at the United Nations, met today with the Russian representative, Sergei Lavrov. Mr. Lavrov said after the meeting that there had been no change in the Russian position.
But Calvin Mitchell, spokesman for Mr. Richardson, said this evening that there had been "some progress on the language of the text," and that technical aides to the American and Russian envoys continued their talks into the evening.
French officials say that they are not suggesting that the new measures may not have to be applied at some point, and that they are not trying to reduce sanctions in any way. What they object to, they say, is placing the burden of deciding whether or not to impose the travel ban on the leader of the monitoring operation in Iraq, Richard Butler, the executive chairman of the United Nations Special Commission.
Mr. Butler is due to make his next report to the Council in April. The French would like the Security Council to review it and act if necessary, not to sit back and watch sanctions go into effect automatically if Iraq is reported not to be in full compliance, as the Americans are demanding.
Today, Egypt joined the Russians and French in opposing the additional sanctions. Egypt, along with other Arab and African nations, also opposes continued sanctions on Libya, which the United States and Britain accuse of fostering international terrorism, in particular the bombing of a Pan Am flight over Scotland in 1988.
Egypt, a Security Council member, cannot veto the sanctions, however, because it does not hold a permanent seat.
In Paris and New York, French and American diplomats said that discussions between Ms. Albright and the French Foreign Minister, Hubert Vedrine, were still going on. Secretary of State Albright has also been in contact with the Russian Foreign Minister, Yevgeny Primakov. Her entreaties appear not to have changed any minds, however.
The State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said on Monday that a lot of give and take was to be expected, a lesson he and Ms. Albright had learned when she was the American representative at the United Nations.
"The negotiating process in the Security Council is designed to achieve an objective," he said at the daily State Department briefing. "The objective is the strongest possible result. Sometimes that means starting out stronger than you know you can get with the maximum number of votes. So you may be watching the diplomatic effort unfold, but we are not walking back from our original objective, which is to get the strongest possible Council action to achieve Iraqi compliance."

HEADLINE: Needed: Planet Insurance

BYLINE: By Alan S. Blinder; Alan S. Blinder, a professor of economics at Princeton, was a vice chairman of the Federal Reserve and a member of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers.

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
An American team in Bonn is deep in negotiations that, it is hoped, will lead to the signing of an international treaty on global warming in Kyoto, Japan, in December. Such a treaty would define the responsibilities of roughly 170 nations for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. President Clinton, who is scheduled to outline his policy on global warming today, must walk a fine line, balancing the concerns of environmentalists who worry about the fate of the earth and those of business and labor constituencies who worry about the fate of their companies and jobs.
But on what basis should the President strike that balance? The typical economic approach to such problems is cost-benefit analysis. But there is a big problem with applying that tool here. While we have some ability to quantify the costs of policies intended to retard global warming, we have little basis for estimating the benefits. The scientific consensus takes us only so far. Yes, global warming is for real. Yes, burning fossil fuels seems to be a significant cause. And yes, most potential climatic consequences are worrisome -- and some are truly horrifying. But scientists cannot tell us how the earth's climate will change if nothing is done. 
 So I suggest a different approach: Instead of weighing costs against benefits, it makes more sense to look at action against global warming as taking out an insurance policy. This is what homeowners do, spending hundreds of dollars every year to insure their families against the unknown, though presumably small probability that their house will burn down. Shouldn't the family of man do the same for its home?
As we shop for this global insurance policy, we should seek the most economical one. We can drastically reduce its cost by applying four basic economic principles:
* Market-based approaches work more efficiently than clumsy command-and-control techniques. The leading candidate in this case seems to be distributing or auctioning permits to emit, say, carbon dioxide, and then allowing free-market trading to establish their price. By now we have enough experience with emissions trading to predict that it will reduce pollution at a fraction of the cost of regulation. The President is expected to emphasize these kinds of incentives to reach his goals. It is time that the rest of the world got on board.
* Global problems require global perspectives and responses. It makes sense to reduce carbon emissions where that can be done most cheaply. We should therefore explore innovations like global emissions trading and allowing American companies to "buy" emissions reduction in other countries, although both are fraught with practical difficulties. It is important that all countries get involved. We cannot hold developing nations to the same standards as developed ones, but their eventual participation is essential.
* Haste makes waste. It's cheaper to engineer new products for energy efficiency than it is to retrofit old ones. That means we can greatly lower the costs of reducing carbon emissions if we allow our existing transportation fleet, factories, home heating systems and especially power-generating plants to wear out rather than scrapping them. We can afford such patience because it is the accumulated concentration of greenhouse gases that affects global temperatures, not the annual output of emissions. For these reasons, the much-debated target of reducing emissions to 1990 levels by the year 2000, as enunciated at the 1992 summit meeting in Rio de Janeiro, is too demanding. It would be more prudent to start slowly, then gradually grow more strict. We need to emulate the tortoise, not the hare.
* Reducing reliance on fossil fuels is not an anti-growth policy. It is an insurance policy against climatic disruptions that could severely damage the world's economies. We do not want people to turn off the heat and turn in their cars. We do need to make fossil fuels more expensive. But any revenues raised from, say, auctioning emissions permits should be promptly returned to the economy via tax cuts, research and development spending, and compensating victims (for example, coal miners).
These four principles do not constitute an instruction manual for American negotiators in Bonn. Nonetheless, accepting them would represent a giant step toward banishing both Chicken Little and Dr. Pangloss from the debate. Then we can get down to issues like how to design and enforce a global emissions trading system in the absence of any meaningful global government, and how to persuade developing nations to participate.
No, the sky is not falling; it is just filling up with greenhouse gases a bit too fast for comfort. But blithely assuming that nature and laissez-faire will take care of everything amounts to betting the earth's climate on a roll of the dice. If we lose the bet, our grandchildren will not likely forgive us. Nor should they.

HEADLINE: Citicorp Plans To Cut Payroll By 7,500 Jobs

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
Citicorp said yesterday that it would eliminate a total of 7,500 jobs as it moves to cut costs and streamline operations in nearly 100 countries.
Citicorp, the second-largest bank in the United States, said it would actually shed 9,000 jobs, mainly in computer processing and operations. But it expected 1,500 of the affected employees to take new jobs elsewhere with the company, moving from local offices to facilities in South Dakota, Ireland, Texas, Singapore and other locations. 
 The result is to be an 8.3 percent reduction in Citicorp's overall work force. The cuts are not expected to have a major impact on the New York area because Citicorp has already moved most of its processing jobs out of the region.
"The most important reason we are doing this is competitive pressure is increasing," said Thomas E. Jones, the bank's principal financial officer. "Standardization of our back office not only lowers our costs, it brings us better control and likely better quality."
To cover the cost of severance payments and disposing of unneeded equipment and real estate, Citicorp said it would take a third-quarter pretax charge of $889 million.
As a result, Citicorp said that its third-quarter earnings fell by 45.3 percent, to $511 million. Excluding the charge, the bank's profits rose by 14 percent, to $1.07 billion. The bank's per-share earnings of $2.19, excluding the charge, exceeded analyst expectations by 5 cents. With the charge, Citicorp's per-share earnings for the quarter were $1.01.
Citicorp has been telling investors for months that it was developing a restructuring program. Still, the bank's shares jumped $5.3025, to $144.1875, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange after the program's scope was detailed.
Analysts praised the bank's effort, but noted that it was hoping to do a lot very quickly. "The crucial issue is execution," said Diane B. Glossman, an analyst with Salomon Brothers. "The company has never done a comprehensive, enterprise-wide streamlining effort like this before."
In the last several years, Citicorp has consolidated many operating functions for its activities in the United States. For example, telephone calls from branch customers in New York and elsewhere are answered in Austin, Tex.
Now Citicorp, which operates in far more countries than any other bank in the world, wants to centralize operations in a handful of centers globally. For example, it hopes that its vast credit card processing center in Sioux Falls, S.D., will be able to keep track of charges for card accounts in 44 countries, from Spain to Singapore.
"The fact we have been so highly decentralized in the past has been a source of strength," Mr. Jones said. "The world is going more global and we cannot afford that luxury any more."
Savings from all these changes are expected to cover their cost within two years and ultimately save $750 million a year.
Citicorp, which had long prided itself on doing things its own way, said that it would also increasingly look to contract operating functions to other companies. For example, it will now buy automated teller machines from NCR, rather than build them itself.
About two-thirds of the restructuring charge applies to the bank's business with consumers -- credit cards, branch banking and private banking for the affluent. The rest applies to the trading and corporate banking areas.
These moves are being coordinated by Mary Alice Taylor, a former top official of the Federal Express Corporation who joined Citicorp in January to oversee all technology and operations.
The restructuring is part of a series of moves by Citicorp's chairman, John S. Reed, to build on a strategy that emphasizes the bank's worldwide reach. Eschewing acquisitions of either banks or brokers in the United States, Mr. Reed is focusing instead on building a global consumer brand, as well as international money transfers and local business lending in emerging markets.
Mr. Jones said that some of the savings from the layoffs would be used to expand such areas as banking on the Internet and business lending in emerging markets.
In the third quarter, Citicorp continued to be highly profitable, with a return on equity of 20.8 percent. Moreover, it is growing faster than many big banks, with revenue up 11 percent in the quarter from the corresponding period a year earlier. The rise of the dollar did knock nearly $90 million off its pretax income, Mr. Jones said.
Earnings for consumer banking were up only 4 percent, to $481 million, dragged down by rising credit card losses.
While credit card losses were higher than a year ago, the loss rate of 5.58 percent of loan balances declined from 6.13 percent in the second quarter of this year, the first decrease since 1994. The bank said that the number of credit card accounts in the United States declined by 3 percent.
Mr. Jones said it was too soon to predict whether losses on credit cards would continue to decline, and he said that Citicorp had chosen to remain cautious in this market.
Earnings for corporate banking increased 34 percent, to $689 million.
The turmoil in Southeastern Asian currencies during the quarter mainly benefited the bank, by raising trading volume, though it had some loan losses in Thailand.
More than a year ago, Citicorp began to worry about the economy in the region and began to slow its lending there. It also transferred to Hong Kong and Singapore some top executives who had previously run operations through the economic roller coaster in Latin America.
"There is criticism of Citicorp's exposure in emerging markets," Mr. Jones said. "We should get some credit for getting something right."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
ABB Will Cut 10,000 Jobs And Switch Focus to Asia

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 21

 BODY:
In one of the most striking examples yet of shifting global allegiances in business, the Swiss-Swedish engineering company ABB Asea Brown Boveri announced today that it would cut 10,000 jobs in Western Europe and the United States and invest in Asia instead.
The revamping will cost ABB $850 million and the impact is likely to be heaviest in Europe, where the company employs 102,000 workers and where this is likely to rank among the biggest single corporate retrenchments. Its American subsidiary, based in Norwalk, Conn., has businesses in many states and employs 23,000 people. 
 Company executives were exceptionally blunt today in saying that they would shift thousands of jobs from countries like Germany and Sweden to faster-growing markets in Southeast Asia and China.
The move provided a grim reminder that Europe's enduring problems with joblessness are far from over, even though economic data indicate that countries like Germany and France are poised for a significant recovery. As European companies increasingly embrace the hard-edged opportunism of American companies, they are coolly shifting capital to whichever part of the world offers the best prospects.
Many economists here believe that European unemployment will likely remain high even after recovery has taken hold. That is because the recovery largely results from a decline in the value of currencies like the German mark, which has made exports cheaper. The problem is that many countries still have high labor costs, high taxes and rigid workplace regulations.
"Our structural problems remain completely unsolved, and that means that structural unemployment is going to increase," said Hans Joachim Hass, chief economist at the German Association of Industry in Bonn.
ABB's cutback is far smaller than those imposed by many American companies. In 1995, for example, AT&T announced cuts of 40,000 people from its work force of 300,000.
But by European standards, the ABB cut is one of the biggest. Last year, the French automobile company Renault ignited huge protests when it said that a Belgian factory with 3,100 workers would close. Earlier this year, the Swedish household appliance manufacturer Electrolux announced plans to cut 12,000 workers. The recently merged steel mills in Germany of Krupp-Hoesch and Thyssen are expected to eliminate 7,000 jobs, through early retirement and other voluntary programs.
Unlike many steel mills and automobile companies that have endured big cutbacks in recent years, moreover, ABB's businesses in construction services, engineering and the manufacture of power generation equipment have not been that badly ravaged by global competition. But the company said that profits had been hurt by weak European demand and rising costs and that it would take an accounting charge of $850 million against earnings to cover future reorganization costs.
"Some of these actions will be difficult in the short term, but the issue is not going away on its own," said ABB's chief executive, Goran Lindahl, as he disclosed the company's latest earnings today in Zurich.
ABB said its nine-month profit slipped from $809 million last year to $774 million this year, and that sales had fallen from $23.5 billion to $22.6 billion. Much of that decline resulted from the rising value of the American dollar, because ABB reports results in dollars and its sales in local currencies translated to fewer dollars this year. But the company has said demand for its products in Europe remains sluggish.
ABB's announcements surprised many investors and the company's stock dropped sharply. ABB American depository receipts fell $7, to $126.50, in Nasdaq trading.
Beyond the 10,000 jobs to be cut, ABB will eliminate about 3,600 jobs at Adtranz, a manufacturer of railroad equipment co-owned by ABB and Daimler-Benz. Those cuts were announced on Monday.
This is not the first time ABB has undertaken such a strategic shift. In 1989, it bought more than 40 American companies for more than $3 billion, including the power distribution businesses of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the Combustion Engineering Group. But in the last seven years, the company has steadily reduced its work force in the United States and Western Europe and increased its presence in Asia and the formerly Communist countries of Central and Eastern Europe.

HEADLINE: Chicago's Scandal Resume Lengthens

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Sometimes regarded as a finishing school for the penitentiary, the City Council recently passed a strict ethics code, a man-bites-dog case for Chicago politicians better known for sneering at good-government reformers, who are known here as "goo-goos."
But with the United States Attorney shooting fish in the barrel at City Hall -- eight current or former aldermen, along with the Cook County Treasurer, have been variously charged with taking bribes, influence-peddling and extortion over the past three years -- something needed to be done. 
 Alderman Patrick Huels, the floor leader on the council for Mayor Richard M. Daley, was a sponsor of the ethics bill, a measure that vowed to clean up Dodge. Days passed, even weeks, without any new outbreaks of corruption at City Hall.
Now another big scandal has broken. It centers on Mr. Huels, the man behind the ethics legislation, who resigned today from the City Council after being accused of taking a $1.2 million loan from a company he helped win a city subsidy.
On top of that, council committees run by Mr. Huels and Alderman Edward Burke were said to have paid more than $600,000 in consulting fees to an executive of Mr. Huels's business. Alderman Burke, incidentally, had been a secretary of that business for five years.
"Although I am certain that I broke no laws," Mr. Huels said in his statement of resignation today, "I am equally certain that I exercised poor judgment in these matters."
 Traditionally, Chicagoans have tended to shrug off corruption, just as Alaskans shrug off the cold. But lately, it has seemed to be reaching a point of parody.
"Stop this shameful parade," declared the headline on a front-page editorial on Monday in The Chicago Sun-Times, the newspaper that broke the Huels story after its own investigation.
"Chicago cannot afford to be the City of Sleaze," the editorial said. It added: "There is more than pride at stake. Chicago cannot carry a venal reputation into the new century without losing national and world esteem, meaning fewer visitors, fewer conventions, lost contracts and lost jobs."
Over the past three years, it has become difficult to keep pace with the sting operations that have been directed at politicians at City Hall. One of them, Operation Silver Shovel, is targeted at those who took money for an illegal garbage dumping scheme. Another investigation, Haunted Hall, is centered on "ghost payrolling," in which politically connected people draw salaries for jobs that do not exist.
Despite the robust economy here, some civic leaders say such an image of corruption could tarnish Chicago's reputation as a good place to work or visit.
But then, it seems doubtful that people have ever been attracted to Chicago for its moral rectitude. Even a Roman Catholic Archbishop in Chicago, John Cardinal Cody, was the target of a Government investigation in the 80's that centered on the use of church money. (There was no prosecution, but the controversy plagued the Cardinal's final days.)
This is a city, after all, that not long ago named a tourist restaurant after Al Capone, a local boy who had a few scrapes with the law.
Before Mr. Huels's resignation, pressure had been building on Mayor Daley, who said he was "upset and mad and disappointed" with his floor leader, to force Mr. Huels from his committee chairmanship.
In recent cases of corruption at City Hall, many of those charged have been black. If Mayor Daley had not brought pressure on Mr. Huels, who is white, the appearance of unfairness could have hurt the Mayor with black voters, a group he has assiduously courted, with significant success. Mr. Daley, who has never been touched by any scandal, is expected to seek re-election in 1999.
There has been no comment on the case from the United States Attorney's Office.
Mr. Huels, who was a tight-lipped Alderman, grew up in the politically connected Irish neighborhood of Bridgeport, the same as Mayor Daley, and worked for the city as a tree-trimmer during summers while in college. He was a loyal soldier for the Democratic Regular Organization, known simply as The Machine, the powerful political system led by Mayor Richard J. Daley, the late father of the current Mayor.
At 26, Mr. Huels was appointed to the City Council, filling the spot vacated by Michael Bilandic, who became Mayor upon Mr. Daley's death in 1976. Mr. Huels was so closely guarded that even when he ran for alderman the first time, he did not hold a single news conference.
During Mr. Huels's high school days at De La Salle Institute, the Roman Catholic school attended by both Mayor Daleys, the yearbook printed his ambition: "To make a million before I'm 30 and to retire before I get a chance to work."
The trucking company for which Mr. Huels helped get the subsidy, and from which he took the $1.2 million loan, is owned by another Bridgeport boy, Michael Tadin.
Though some Chicagoans, and certainly the goo-goos, are aghast at the allegations being made against Alderman Huels and other politicians here, not everyone on the City Council sees anything wrong.
Alderman William Beavers, who usually opposes the Daley Administration, said he did not think that Mr. Huels had done anything untoward.
He added, "I wish I could find somebody who would give me a million-dollar loan."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

European Engineering Giant Is Cutting 10,000 Jobs
ABB Asea Brown Boveri, the Swiss-Swedish engineering company, is eliminating 10,000 jobs in Western Europe and the United States as part of an effort to focus more on the fast-growing economies of Asia. ABB said the revamping would cost $850 million.
Executives were blunt about the strategy shift, which will most heavily affect countries like Germany and Sweden, where labor costs are high. It was a sobering reminder that Europe's chronically high unemployment is unlikely to fall soon, despite evidence that much of the Continent is emerging from a prolonged economic slump. Page D2. 

No Higher ITT Bid, Hilton Says
Stephen F. Bollenbach, chief executive of Hilton Hotels, appeared to admit defeat in the 10-month struggle to take over ITT, saying he would not raise Hilton's bid in an effort to match a $9.8 billion offer by Starwood Lodging Trust. Still, Hilton's lower offer was left on the table. D5.
 
Strong Quarter for Big Banks
Operating results at a number of big banks -- Chase Manhattan, Citicorp, Wells Fargo and Banc One -- beat expectations. D4.
 
Strong Results at Drug Makers
Stronger third-quarter results were reported by Bristol-Myers Squibb, American Home Products, Schering-Plough and SmithKline Beecham. Analysts said the gains reflected growing demand in the United States and the industry's success at finding new ways to sell products and speed them to market. D5.
 
Legal Costs Cut Tobacco Profits
Settlements of tobacco litigation with Mississippi and Florida took a heavy toll on the earnings of Philip Morris and RJR Nabisco. Nonetheless, both companies' stocks rose as operating results were roughly in line with estimates. D4.
 
Unusual Trend Helps Oil Companies
Exxon, Texaco and Amoco reported robust earnings, helped by an unusual development for the summer months: raw material costs in the form of crude oil prices declined, while prices for their retail products, like gasoline and heating oil, rose. Market Place. D12.
 
Japan Stimulus Plan Is Criticized
Japan's Government disclosed a widely anticipated package of proposals to jump-start the moribund economy, but economists and investors declared them short on substance and long on political expediency. D2.
 
Troubles Trickle Down in Asia
In Malaysia, consumers are feeling the first twinges of an economic downturn that has swept through Southeast Asia. A1.
 
Thousands of people rallied in the streets of Bangkok, furious at the Thai Government's infighting and vacillation in the face of a severe economic crisis. A12.
 
Salomon Earnings Increase
Salomon said that earnings rose as gains from bond trading and investment banking offset losses from an arbitrage position related to British Telecommunications' bid for MCI Communications. D6.
 
Berkshire to Add Dairy Queen
Berkshire Hathaway, headed by Warren E. Buffett, agreed to buy International Dairy Queen for $585 million in cash and stock. D4.
 
Fidelity to Settle Suit
Fidelity Investments agreed to pay $10 million to settle a class-action lawsuit filed by Micron Technologies shareholders against the company and Jeffrey N. Vinik, former manager of the Magellan Fund, in which he had been accused of manipulating Micron's stock price. D2.
 
Microsoft Leader Defiant
William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, engaged in a testy exchange with a computer industry audience over whether the company's Windows 95 software operating system is structured to repress competition. The confrontation came a day after the Justice Department accused Microsoft of violating a 1995 antitrust agreement. D2.

HEADLINE: Clinton Alters His Approach Over Warming

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Stung by complaints that it is moving too slowly against global warming, the Clinton Administration has devised a set of rewards for companies that cut emissions of heat-trapping gases faster than the Government would require under a pending international treaty.
The approach, to be outlined in a speech by President Clinton on Wednesday, is meant to mollify environmental groups and European nations that have been demanding deep, early cuts in emissions. The Administration has resisted those calls out of fear that aggressive action might cause too much economic pain. 
 Even as the White House wrestled with the details of its latest plan today, aides were testing its appeal among business and environmental groups whose support could be crucial to its success. Administration officials and people who had been briefed described the plan's outlines, but cautioned that important elements had still not been decided by Mr. Clinton.
The United States is under pressure to explain its approach this week, as negotiations resume in Bonn on a treaty to reduce the world's emissions of pollutants that are building up in the atmosphere and threatening to disrupt the planet's climate during the coming century.
Carbon dioxide, the main heat-trapping gas, comes primarily from the burning of fossil fuels. With the economy booming and energy cheap, United States emissions have been accelerating.
The Administration's new approach has several elements, which include these:
*Energy producers and consumers that reduce emissions quickly would get credits, so that those moving fastest would benefit the most when, as the Administration envisions, the Government issues pollution permits that companies can buy and sell. This trading of pollution permits is the Administration's favored approach for letting the marketplace choose how to reduce emissions.
*Instead of a fixed deadline for reducing emissions, the United States would try to achieve its target within a few years on either side of a deadline. That would help to encourage companies to comply earlier.
*Tax incentives and subsidies, requiring Congressional approval, would also prompt companies to move more quickly.
The new approach would not substantially change the Administration's basic goal: to require in the new treaty that industrial nations emit no more of the gases in 2010 than they did in 1990.
The Administration is expected to propose at the talks in Bonn that industrial nations meet that target, as an average, during a multiyear period falling around 2010, probably during the period from 2008 to 2012. The Administration will also suggest that deeper reductions occur in later periods, perhaps a 5 percent cut below 1990's levels as 2020 approaches.
A White House official cautioned tonight that although President Clinton was attracted to the multiyear-average approach, he was concerned that the plan was too complicated and might have to be simplified.
By giving extra credit to those companies that lowered emissions fastest, the new approach would seek to put the United States, whose steadily growing emissions currently account for nearly a quarter of the world's output of greenhouse gases, on a downward slope as early in the 21st century as possible.
The initial reductions would be modest, but they would come soon. To meet the targets envisioned by the Administration, the United States would, as a practical matter, have to cut emissions by about 1 percent a year on average beginning in 1998.
To help reverse the current trend of growing emissions, the Administration would seek from Congress a package of about $5 billion in research spending, tax credits and other incentives for companies. This package would be in addition to the plan for pollution permit credits.
The Administration also wants to make sure that the deregulation of the electric utility industry does not lead to growing emissions of carbon dioxide from power plants that burn coal and other dirty fuels. Mr. Clinton is expected to address this issue as well in his new plan.
In drafting the speech that he is to deliver on Wednesday, at the National Geographic Society here, the President drew upon a set of options presented by senior economic and environmental aides last week. He basically took the most aggressive approach offered -- one that environmental groups had criticized as too weak -- and tried to strengthen it by providing more incentives for early action.
With the details still incomplete tonight, business and environmental groups that were told of the plan were reluctant to pledge their support.
"It could be viewed as a good minimum ante to put on the table in the negotiations" at Bonn, said Howard Ris, executive director of the Union of Concerned Scientists, which favors deep cuts in emissions. "The President has clearly rejected the do-nothing approach."
