HEADLINE: A New Kind of Veto Brings a New Way of Doing Business

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Heaven knows how many dams have been built, research grants awarded and Federal office buildings constructed over the years because lobbyists and Congressional staff managed to stick them into giant spending bills and because the projects were not so expensive that the President felt obliged to veto the entire legislation.
Now the rules have changed. For the first time in the nation's history, Congress has given President Clinton the authority this year to issue line item vetoes -- to veto specific spending and tax items without vetoing the bill as a whole. For lobbyists and lawmakers, this means that their pet projects may stand no chance if they are not cleared by the White House and its Office of Management and Budget. 
 "Government agencies and private entities are used to being able to lobby the two houses of Congress and get something into law," said Charles Black, who was a political adviser to Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush and is now a prominent lobbyist here.
"Now there's a third house, the Administration," Mr. Black continued. "O.M.B. will have to be contacted, and you'll have to get their approval for a special project. And depending on how conspicuous your project is, you may have to get approval at the White House too. We're counseling our clients this is what they'll have to do."
Mr. Black's view is widely shared on K Street, where many lobbyists have their offices. Last month more than 75 lobbyists paid $245 or $325 each (depending on how early they signed up) to attend a half-day seminar offered by Burson-Marsteller, the public relations and lobbying firm, called "The Line Item Veto: What You Need to Know, When You Need to Know It."
In an interview, Franklin D. Raines, the President's budget director, explained the new procedures this way: "The line item veto has elevated things to where projects that once got little scrutiny are subject to being analyzed by heads of departments, chairmen of committees, the White House and the press."
So far, President Clinton has been quite selective in how he has wielded his new authority. He has used the line item veto on six bills to reduce Federal spending by a total of $2 billion, only a tiny fraction of the overall cost of the measures.
In the $248 billion Defense Department appropriations bill, for instance, the President cut items worth only $144 million. In the $20 billion energy and water bill, one of the main vehicles for public works projects, he canceled eight projects worth only $19 million.
But already "the word is out," said a Senate staff member who insisted on not being identified, "that you can do things the old way and lose, or you can bring the White House in or the O.M.B. and maybe you'll get what you want."
One Senator who followed the latter course this month was Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut. He learned on Oct. 8 that an $18 million research grant he favored was on a list of items President Clinton was considering striking from the Defense Department bill. The grant would promote development of a process called X-ray lithography that could enable computer chips to be made smaller. Eventually, suppliers in Connecticut could expect to benefit from this technology.
Over a day and a half, Mr. Lieberman wrote to Mr. Raines about the matter and called Jacob Lew, the deputy budget director. Members of Mr. Lieberman's staff called John H. Gibbons, the President's science director; Deputy Defense Secretary John J. Hamre, and officials on the President's National Economic Council. The project survived and is now law.
In a similar vein, Representative Scotty Baesler, Democrat of Kentucky, rolled into action when he learned from a lobbyist, Stephen Evered, that a $25 million appropriation to buy a particular kind of lock for safes containing classified documents was in jeopardy of being vetoed.
The only company that makes this kind of lock, Mas-Hamilton, is in Lexington, Ky., in Mr. Baesler's district. It has about 150 employees, and the special lock is a good part of its business.
Mr. Baesler telephoned Rahm Emanuel, the President's senior policy adviser, and the project was removed from the veto list.
But not all lawmakers who intervened at the White House succeeded in preventing a line item veto. For instance, two military projects in New Mexico -- construction of an air combat simulator at Kirtland Air Force Base in Albuquerque, and repairs on the launching complex at the White Sands missile range -- were canceled despite the efforts of the state's two Senators, Jeff Bingaman, a Democrat, and Pete V. Domenici, a Republican.
The potential for the President to use his line-item-veto power for political purposes is enormous. For example, Mr. Clinton could agree not to veto pet projects of lawmakers whose votes he will need on legislation giving him expedited authority to enter into trade agreements.
Almost everyone who has studied the issue believes that if the line item veto survives a constitutional challenge, which could be resolved by the Supreme Court this term, Presidents will eventually use it for political leverage.
But so far, even Senator John McCain of Arizona, the most outspoken Republican critic of the way Mr. Clinton has used the line item veto, does not accuse the President of politicizing the process in this way. Mr. McCain's main complaint is that the President does not state in advance clear criteria for deciding which items to veto.
In at least one case, the line item veto seems to have backfired. In the budget for the new fiscal year that he sent Congress in February, Mr. Clinton asked for $46 million for a project to study a new fuel cell technology to convert oil and gas into electricity. The money was expected to be in the appropriations bill for the Interior Department.
Through a bit of Congressional prestidigitation, $1 million for a Vietnam veterans museum in Representative Sidney R. Yates's district in Chicago was shifted from the Defense Department bill to the Interior Department measure. In return, $6 million for Army research on the fuel cell technology program was shifted from the Interior Department appropriation to the Defense bill.
But the Clinton Administration apparently did not get wind of what was going on, and the President vetoed the $6 million item. Unless something unexpected happens, this means that the President will not get all the money he originally requested for the research.
In another case, Mr. Clinton himself rejected his staff's unanimous recommendation that he veto a $13 million appropriation for the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum, moored in the Hudson River at West 46th Street in Manhattan.
As best as could be learned, no one in Congress mentioned the matter to the President. Zachary Fisher, the chief promoter of the museum and chairman of its board of trustees, is a generous campaign contributor, giving to Democrats and Republicans alike, but he gave no money to the President in last year's campaign.
Still, Mr. Clinton gave a campaign speech at the museum in May 1996 and apparently was impressed by it.
"We thought it was not sufficiently high priority to justify the expense," said Mr. Raines. But the President disagreed.
"He knew more about it than I did," Mr. Raines continued. "So who was I to argue?"

HEADLINE: Citizen Soros

 BODY:
In a season of grand philanthropic gestures, George Soros has now joined Ted Turner in announcing a munificent international gift. Mr. Soros will increase his Open Society Institute's activities in Russia by $300 million to $500 million over the next three years. That will more than double his current programs in Russia and easily exceed Washington's $95 million annual donation to Russia's civilian sector. The contribution adds to the $1.5 billion Mr. Soros has already given away overseas, the bulk of it to build civil society and independent media in formerly Communist countries.
Some Americans may quarrel with Mr. Soros and Mr. Turner for spending so lavishly on foreign causes when problems in America go untended. Mr. Turner pledged $1 billion to United Nations humanitarian programs. Mr. Soros's Open Society Institute finances innovative programs in the United States. The works that he and Mr. Turner support abroad may help prevent political upheavals in Russia and other countries that could cost Americans dearly in the years ahead. 
 Other examples of American political largess abroad are not so commendable. Often they support ethnic extremism. Irish-Americans have formed the economic base of the Irish Republican Army. A retired Florida doctor, Irving Moskowitz, has bought properties in Arab neighborhoods in East Jerusalem and turned them over to right-wing groups eager to secure a Jewish presence there.
Mr. Soros's new donation will go to improving Russia's health care and education, and retraining Russian soldiers and officers for civilian jobs. The latter program could remove a major source of potentially destabilizing unrest in Russia's military.
There is a caution worth raising. Mr. Soros is not only Russia's biggest aid donor. He has also bought a nearly $1 billion stake in Svyazinvest, the privatized state telecommunications company. Mr. Soros has said that people might be confused by his dual role. He has not had to worry about possible conflict of interest in most of the countries where he gives money, in part because his support of civil society tends to infuriate autocratic governments. But in Russia, where he is both working with the Government and bidding on its companies, he must clearly separate his two roles.
It is always unsettling when a single private citizen wields so much influence in a strategically important country. Washington is fortunate that George Soros's foreign activities reflect American values.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS;
In Her Own Words

 BODY:

RUTH W. MESSINGER
At a news conference with Robert B. Reich, the former Secretary of labor, Ms. Messinger criticized the job-creation record of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. 
 "Over the last four years, New York City has ranked dead last among major cities in creating jobs. The unemployment rate in New York, which as the Secretary said is just pushing up toward double digits -- 9.5 percent -- is just about twice the unemployment rate in the nation. The gap between unemployment here, the percent of unemployment in New York and the percent of unemployment nationally, is the largest it has been since then Labor Department Secretary Reich started keeping statistics. Just yesterday, Forbes magazine announced its rankings of the best cities in the nation for small business. We came in No. 17 out of 22 cities ranked. I say that enough is enough. That we need to put New Yorkers back to work again, that we need an economic development policy that actually creates jobs for New Yorkers."

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE ECONOMY;
Candidates Clash on Issue Of Job Loss and Creation

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani defended his job creation record yesterday as Ruth W. Messinger, joined by the former United States Labor Secretary, Robert B. Reich, said the Mayor's administration had awarded tax breaks to corporations that have failed to keep jobs in the city.
Mr. Giuliani said his administration had fostered a climate that was friendly to business and had led to the creation of thousands of new jobs in four years. And his advisers said that while certain companies that had been given tax breaks had cut their payrolls, the administration's economic policies had led to an overall growth of jobs in the city. 
 "We haven't made up for all the things we have to make up for: the devastating damage of the Dinkins administration to our job base," Mr. Giuliani said. "But we've made up 170,000 of the 320,000 private-sector jobs they lost. There's 150,000 jobs to go just to catch up with the damage they did to us in 1990, '91 and '92 when we were losing jobs."
Standing in front of the News America Publishing building on Avenue of the Americas near 52d Street, the American headquarters of Rupert Murdoch's media conglomerate, Ms. Messinger, the Democratic candidate in next month's mayoral election, returned to one of the main themes of her campaign. Under Mr. Giuliani's economic policies, she said, big corporations had benefited but the public "too often gets nothing or very little in return."
"Rather than invest in our future," she said, "rather than use the power of city government to create jobs and opportunity for all New Yorkers, Rudolph Giuliani squanders New York City's taxpayers' tax dollars on corporate welfare for his corporate friends, like this one, News America."
Ms. Messinger, who was joined by Hillary Rodham Clinton the night before, received the endorsement yesterday of Mr. Reich, Labor Secretary in President Clinton's first term. Mr. Reich, now a professor at Brandeis University, said that New York's economic recovery had been lopsided and that the "rich are far richer in New York than almost every other place in America."
"The question is what can New York do to make sure that this success is shared by all," Mr. Reich said. "It isn't good enough, folks. And Ruth Messinger is concerned about the people who may not be getting all of the benefits of this recovery."
Shortly after Ms. Messinger's comments, Randy L. Levine, Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, flanked by Robert R. Kiley, president of the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce, and several other business leaders in front of City Hall, defended the Giuliani administration's economic policies. He pointed to figures released yesterday by the State Labor Department showing 10,600 jobs created during September.
"Everything is working," he said. "The economy is in good hands. It's very clear now that we want to continue the job growth that Mayor Giuliani has created, where tourism is at record levels, Wall Street is going well."
The addition of the new jobs, all originating in the private sector, helped push down the city's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for September to 9.3 percent, from 9.5 percent in August, according to a report by Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi. Despite the figures, the city continued to suffer from one of the highest unemployment and lowest job growth rates of any metropolitan region in the country. Nationally, the unemployment rate for September remained unchanged at 4.9 percent.
At the heart of yesterday's disagreement over jobs is whether the tax breaks given to more than 30 big corporations have been good for the city. The Mayor's economic advisers said the companies contributed $1.3 billion in direct and indirect tax revenue annually; Ms. Messinger said nine of the companies, including News America, Viacom and Republic National Bank, had announced layoffs since receiving tax breaks.
In a study of the 13 largest companies that had received tax breaks totaling $258.1 million in exchange for keeping jobs in the city, Mr. Hevesi's office said last month that they had maintained or increased New York employment. But Mr. Hevesi added that if the companies failed to honor their commitments, the city might not know, because the Economic Development Corporation, which is charged with negotiating the tax breaks, has not followed up by monitoring the recipients' employment practices.
Yesterday, Mr. Giuliani also tried to improve his administration's relations with gay voters by issuing a letter stating that he will urge the City Council to pass legislation to extend to same-sex partners the same health and other benefits granted to spouses of city workers. Later in the day, the Empire State Pride Agenda, a lobbying group for gay causes that received the Mayor's letter, released a fax saying that it will not endorse a candidate in the mayoral election.
The Mayor began the day by greeting morning commuters getting off the Staten Island Ferry -- whose 50 cent-fare he eliminated in July. For most of the day, the Mayor worked on consolidating his support in Staten Island, where polls show him leading Ms. Messinger by a wider margin than in any other borough, as he paid visits to Guy Molinari, the Borough President, and to two senior centers.
At the Mount Loretto Senior Center in Tottenville, Mr. Giuliani threw himself into a throng of seniors, who greeted him warmly. Next to a table laden with biscotti, he improvised a dance with Helen Trapasso, 71, as Mr. Molinari sang, "It's amore."
Marion Gennusa, 74, said, "He's done so much for Staten Island. The next thing he needs to do is cut the toll on the Verrazano."
After her appearance with Mr. Reich, Ms. Messinger visited a soup kitchen and attended a town hall meeting in Jackson Heights, Queens.

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefs;
Fall in Jobless Rate For New York City

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
The unemployment rate in New York City fell last month to 9.3 percent from 9.5 percent in August, the State Department of Labor said yesterday.
The city's jobless rate -- which is still nearly twice the national rate of 4.9 percent -- has now declined by seven-tenths of a percentage point from the 10 percent peak that was reached earlier this year, the state said, as relatively strong job growth in the city has continued. 
 The statewide unemployment rate remained unchanged for the month at 6.4 percent. The statewide job numbers for September included about 12,000 people who were listed as not working in August because of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters strike at United Parcel Service. But even after that one-time increase in employment was factored out, state officials said that September was still a better than average month for new jobs.
The number of nonfarm jobs statewide rose by 23,300, or about 0.3 percent, during September, when adjusted for seasonal fluctuations. That was a faster rate of increase than the nation as a whole, which had an 0.2 percent increase in jobs in September. KIRK JOHNSON

HEADLINE: At High Point, Revivals and the 'Pottery Barn Look'

BYLINE: By LIZ SEYMOUR

DATELINE: HIGH POINT, N.C.

 BODY:
IN a tailored chalk-stripe suit, Bill Blass looked out of place in the brightly lighted Pennsylvania House showroom. He was at the opening day of the International Home Furnishings Market to introduce a line of furnishings -- tables, chairs and beds, most under $3,000 -- that bear his name. Almost all were inspired by pieces from his own much-photographed home.
"I've collected for years," he said. "I saw other people coming out with furniture collections, and I finally thought, Why don't I do furniture?" 
 It makes a kind of sense. A fashion designer can earn double-digit royalties on a furniture group. The two most successful marriages of fashion and furniture -- Alexander Julian with Universal and Ralph Lauren with Henredon -- have been financial bright spots in the bleak $53.9 billion-a-year furniture industry. "There's a disconnect between consumers' life styles and what they see in furniture stores," said Ken Fonville, the president of Pennsylvania House. "There are people who are getting double-digit increases, and it's not full-line furniture stores."
But fashion names are not always the silver bullet -- note the quick exit of J. G. Hook and Laura Ashley from the furniture business. And the Bill Blass collection, with its sprayed finishes and machine carving, shows the inherent difficulty of translating haute couture antiques into ready-to-sell furniture.
But that doesn't keep companies from trying. Both Lane and Lexington introduced collections tied not to designers but to brands. The 150-piece Nautica collection at Lexington was a pastiche of English colonial styles in dark cherry and maple. Lane offered an outdoorsy 80-piece Eddie Bauer collection in pine with cherry veneer, including not only an armoire but also a "clocktail" table with a blown-up Eddie Bauer logo as the face of a giant clock under glass.
The skin-deep appeal of a recognizable name does not address the deeper desires of furniture buyers conditioned to nearly instant gratification. The success of Pottery Barn, Crate and Barrel and Pier 1 was invoked constantly at the show by manufacturers whose growth has stalled as people simply stopped buying furniture at traditional stores. Of the 10 fastest-growing furniture retailers last year, only 2 were conventional full-line stores.
"You drive past a big new house at night, and you can see right through it because there isn't any furniture," said Jeff Young, the president of Lexington Furniture.
When there is furniture, it is likely to look "relaxed," the catchword of the show, which started on Oct. 16 and runs through Oct. 24. The influence of the "Pottery Barn look" was evident at almost every price and style level, from a reproduction of a Colonial Williamsburg sofa in nubby cotton at Baker Furniture to a barely there finish offered as an alternative to the high polish on Mark Hampton's very traditional pieces at Hickory Chair.
The clean lines of midcentury modern -- American and French -- were another powerful influence. Larry Laslo continued his Deco-inspired look for Directional with several new streamlined pieces, including a high-back chair upholstered in brown zebra stripes.
Bernhardt introduced a Paris collection, a 45-piece group inspired by French moderne designs. Jacques Grange was back with some 40's French-style additions to his line for John Widdicomb. Bexley Heath, John Widdicomb's sister company, offered reissues of elegant 1950's furniture designed by T. H. Robsjohn-Gibbings, including a sculptural glass-top coffee table, while across the street Baker reintroduced classics from the Danish modern designer Finn Juhl, showcasing the Chieftain chair.
There was a hint of retro 80's in Mitchell Gold's low-slung sofa with skinny arms and little black legs. "Five years ago, you couldn't sell a straight-arm sofa," Mr. Gold said. "Now people are ready for a cleaner look."
The return of even retro modern could be taken as a hopeful sign. "When the economy is better, you see more contemporary, because people are willing to take a risk," said Michelle Lamb, a trend forecaster. Likewise, the return of color was hailed as a sign of optimism; after years of a largely oatmeal-on-oatmeal palette, melony oranges, pale green, aqua and lemon-custard yellow are slipping back.
But the most upbeat news is coming out of a handful of innovative companies that are busy and are speeding up delivery schedules. Leathertech, a six-year-old company that makes leather furniture designed by Vladimir Kagan, Jena Hall and John Mascheroni, among others, uses computers to cut deliveries to two weeks. Mitchell Gold, reporting a sales increase of nearly 80 percent over last year, has a quick-ship program for smaller dealers that gets them the goods in five days.
Ivan Lacroix, vice president of Baronet, a supplier for Crate and Barrel and Bloomingdale's, said that, far from fighting a recession, "we've been at full capacity so long that we've had to ask new stores to wait until we upgrade our factory."
"How's business? Very, very good."

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; House & Home/Style Desk

LENGTH: 1551 words

HEADLINE: Turf;
Co-op Boards Twist The Screws

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON

 BODY:
IN mid-September, a Wall Street trader and his stockbroker fiancee plunked down a hefty deposit to buy a co-op apartment on West End Avenue. In early October, the two were married, six months before they had planned, because their real estate broker said it would help them pass the building's co-op board -- for financial, not moral, reasons. The agent even suggested the minister: the Episcopal priest who was selling the apartment.
"She said boards typically have far fewer questions for people who are married," said the man, who asked to remain anonymous because the deal is technically still pending. The couple received a verbal O.K. from the board two days after the wedding. 
 Confronted with the hottest real estate market in years, and aware of what happened after the stock market crashed 10 years ago and the recession hit, the city's co-op boards have become tougher than they were even a year ago, according to brokers and managing agents, and the agents have become tougher right along with them.
In a report due for release next week, Charles H. Greenthal & Company, a real estate sales and management firm, tracked co-op board rejections in a sample of 70 Manhattan buildings. The rejections, up more than 50 percent from last year, from 4.2 to 6.6 percent -- affected apartments costing from $100,000 to more than $1 million. Greenthal also found that the greatest percentage of turn-downs now occur for one-bedroom apartments, and the majority occur in postwar, not the traditionally exclusive prewar, buildings.
In response to the tougher boards, made possible by a tight real estate market, a new breed of broker has arrived, stern taskmasters who scrutinize their clients' financial forms, raise the bar on the amount of cash and the depth of assets needed to pass the board, command rewritten reference letters and, in more than this one case, act as marriage brokers.
Within the last year, various brokerage firms have:
* Told prospective high-risk purchasers that to pass certain boards, they would have to place anywhere from one to five years of maintenance payments in escrow -- a lump sum that can easily total $100,000. One building management firm has even printed a new form for the payment.
* Become stricter on parental guarantees of maintenance fees, no longer accepting a letter taking responsibility as in the past. Cash, or a legally binding document, is now the only readily acceptable guarantee.
* Sent back financial statements from prospective buyers with as little as a dollar unaccounted for. Tossed back reference letters -- no matter from whom -- if they sound dull or, even worse, all alike.
* Required independent audits or accountants' statements for buyers who own their own companies. Claims of especially large earnings have even been toned down on the agent's advice, so as not to draw the board's scrutiny.
* Increasingly required proof -- usually in written form from an impartial appraiser -- for the values of real estate, artwork and jewelry listed as assets.
These pre-emptive strikes by brokers are used far more often than ever before, according to most of the agents interviewed. "More and more, we attempt to do some gentle steering, so people don't find themselves in embarrassing situations," said Frederick W. Peters, president of Ashforth Warburg Associates and also a co-chairman of the board of the residential division at the Real Estate Board of New York. "Most of us are pretty open about it. If there's an apartment at X that a customer wants to see, we'll say, 'But they're looking for a bigger net worth.' "
If the broker is representing the seller, Mr. Peters said, he will probably refuse even to take a customer who will not meet the board's unwritten but well-known standards. "Why waste everybody's time?" he asked.
Only a year ago, agents were wasting time, presenting seemingly acceptable clients to boards that were turning them down. Some of the largest Manhattan brokerage firms confessed that they had been confused by the rejections in buildings across the financial and social spectrum, from little side-street buildings in Greenwich Village to some postwar-era white brick buildings on the Upper East Side -- "wannabe" buildings, brokers said, that sought to emulate the exclusivity of the grand prewar palazzos along Park and Fifth Avenues.
Spoiled by the ease of getting clients through the board during the recession, the brokers had to adjust to a new reality. "In the nadir of the market, in the early 90's, if the board turned down a shareholder's applicant, it knew he might have to wait a year for another," said Dolly I. Lenz, Sotheby's top-selling broker. "Now, you know there's somebody right behind, who's usually willing to pay even more."
So the agents have wised up. "We've become hypercritical of the board packages," the documentation prospective buyers prepare for the co-op boards, Mr. Peters said. "If they say their place in the Hamptons is worth a million, or whatever, we want an appraisal from a broker."
The broker's tougher attitude often makes applicants mad, and Mr. Peters said he understands why. "I'm totally sympathetic," he said, "but we still have to do it." If an applicant is turned down, the broker emerges bloody, bowed -- and without a dime. And several agents say that often, a client who has been rejected won't work with the agent again.
Within the real estate community, some brokers have found that the number of clients rejected went down when they instituted the newer screening standards. Barbara Corcoran, the president of the Corcoran Group, said statistics from her company show a marked decrease from last year: a 2.4 percent rejection rate in the first nine months of 1997, down from 4.37 percent for the same period of 1996. Ms. Corcoran credited the decrease to the tougher approach by her brokers. Several other large firms -- including the Halstead Property Company and the William B. May Company -- said they did not keep statistics on rejections.
The brokers and their sales agents say that tough boards are seen across the city. And they stress that the boards' toughness does not necessarily correspond to the prices of the apartments. Buyers on Fifth and Park Avenues still need to show a net worth of three to five times the price of the apartment; off that Gold Coast, some buildings have increased the amount of cash down payment needed, from 25 percent to 50 percent, or increased the amount of net worth required.
Although apartment values on Riverside Drive below 96th Street have skyrocketed, Mr. Peters said those buildings continue to look for "nice families that can afford the apartments." But, he said, in some of the buildings in Carnegie Hill, an Upper East Side neighborhood in the 80's and 90's, "they suddenly want nice families that can afford twice the price of the apartment."
In its survey, Greenthal found that "purchase price appeared to have little bearing on the approval decision." Of the 16 turn-downs recorded in the first half of 1997, 5 of the apartments involved cost less than $249,000; 3 cost between $250,000 and $499,000; 6 were between $500,000 and $999,000, and 2 were more than $1 million.
High-income, low-asset buyers like stock traders -- with their half-million-dollar annual bonuses that can turn to sand the next year -- are finding the going particularly tough now, even when looking at apartments in the range of $1 million to $4 million.
"We've been talking to the boards," said Ronni Arougheti, the president of Heron Ltd., a sales and building-management firm. "They are particularly worried now about what's happening on Wall Street and comparing it to the 1980's," when, she said, boards approved stockbrokers and financial whizzes, some of whom landed themselves -- and their buildings -- in trouble. These fears have only intensified in the last year, she said.
Ms. Arougheti, herself a real estate lawyer, said she had seen at least two dozen high-risk applicants who had to put up escrow payments of a year's or more maintenance. Her company has printed a form expressly for calculating these payments.
"In previous years, the boards would have asked for parents to guarantee the maintenance payments, but these parents are often out of state; now, the boards want to see cash," she said.
The Wall Street trader buying the West End Avenue apartment, a prewar three-bedroom in the 90's that is selling for more than $900,000, said the board's toughness was "a function of the demand" in today's real estate market.
"There's a whole half a generation that's accumulated wealth since the last hot market in the 80's," he said. "There's a finite amount of places you'd want to live in."
The couple's agent, Maggie Ocampo of Heron, said she knew the board would be worried about their not being married because if they split up, the woman would not be able to afford the apartment on her own. The man said his wife, who was a stockbroker in Chicago, is in the process of moving to New York and deciding whether to switch careers. Her name is going on the deed along with her husband's, Ms. Ocampo said. Their being married made the board feel more secure.
"With today's boards," Ms. Ocampo said, "agents do not want to raise any red flags -- not even little ones."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
A Crude Story

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: KUWAIT

 BODY:
Follow the oil.
Just north of here, Iraqi refineries near Basra are producing tons of gas-oil used to fire power plants. Almost every day, small pirate vessels hugging the Iranian coast shoot up into the Shatt al-Arab waterway near Basra and load up on this Iraqi gas-oil, which the Iraqis sell the pirates at bargain prices. These small vessels -- always staying just inside the shallow Iraqi or Iranian waters, where the larger U.S. Navy ships maintaining the U.N. blockade on Iraq can't get at them -- then sail back down the Persian Gulf. Along the way the pirate captains, carrying wads of cash, pay off various Iranian admirals and Revolutionary Guard naval units to gain free passage through Iranian coastal waters. When the pirate boats reach the southern end of the gulf, they wait for when the U.S. Navy isn't around and then shoot across from Iranian waters into the United Arab Emirates or out into the Indian Ocean. In either place, they load their gas-oil onto larger tankers that take it to market. Iraq makes money, Iran makes money, the pirates make money. 
 Ain't capitalism wonderful?
This pirate trade is only one small way in which the geo-economics of oil is working against the U.S. sanctions on Iran and the U.N. blockade on Iraq. The even bigger story is this: There are today five great lakes of oil in this part of the world -- Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Iraq, Iran and the Caspian Sea in Central Asia. The way international oil companies make their big money is by entering into production-sharing agreements with oil states. That is, the oil company assumes the risk of exploring and developing a country's oilfields, and then shares in its production until the field is dry. This way the oil company has a steady flow of crude for years to pump, refine, ship and market, profiting at each stage.
But such deals are rare these days. Kuwait and Saudi Arabia booted the companies out in the 1970's in order to develop their own oil. They use foreign oil companies purely as technical advisers. Russia, Azerbaijan and Turkmenistan, along the Caspian Sea, have been ready to sign production-sharing agreements to get that oil out, but because they are fighting over who will get what share and where the pipelines will run, the Caspian remains locked shut.
That leaves Iran and Iraq. Both these countries understand what the oil companies want, and they are ready to give it to them. The deal just signed between Iran and the French, Russian and Malaysian oil companies is a production-sharing agreement for them to search for gas in Iran's huge South Pars offshore gasfield. You can see the allure: the oil companies get the kind of deal they've not seen in the Middle East since the 1970's, and Iran, whose oilfields are rundown, gets technical help from the best oil companies and a thumb in the eye to U.S. sanctions to boot. For now, Iran is limiting these production-sharing deals to offshore fields. But if Iran were to offer on-shore deals, and it's only a matter of time, every oil company in the world would be salivating.
Not to be outdone, Saddam Hussein has signed production-sharing agreements with French, Russian and Italian oil companies that give them the right to develop certain Iraqi fields the minute U.N. sanctions on Iraq are lifted -- thus turning the oil companies into an international lobby on his behalf. "The Iraqis are offering us incredible splits -- 60, 70 percent for the oil companies," one executive told me. That explains why France and Russia are resisting U.S. efforts to tighten U.N. sanctions on Saddam.
You need to spend only a few days in Kuwait -- hearing from some of the 600 Kuwaiti families who had loved ones abducted by Iraq during the invasion and never accounted for by Baghdad, or visiting the newly rebuilt Kuwaiti oil fields that Iraq gratuitously set ablaze, creating a mammoth ecological disaster -- to be reminded why Saddam is such a menace and why the sanctions on Iraq need to be maintained.
Unfortunately, the geo-economics is pulling the other way. Powerful, oil-driven forces are building against the U.S. sanctions on Iran. And Saddam is clearly hoping that if and when the Iran sanctions collapse, those on Iraq will fall next. No wonder Kuwaitis like to tell American visitors: "There is no cosmic justice. You got Mexico and Canada as neighbors, and we got Iran and Iraq."

HEADLINE: In America;
A Revolution Subsides

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
It's not more than a stirring at the moment, like a soft breeze that heralds a change of seasons. But it's there. It's happening.
The conservative hold on the national electorate is loosening. 
 The so-called conservative revolution has more or less exhausted itself. It has left its mark, but it has also left a majority of Americans to face the 21st century with the unsettling sense that they are on their own when it comes to such potentially overwhelming matters as earning a living, raising a family, sending their children through college, caring for aging parents, securing adequate health care and providing for their own retirement in an increasingly insensitive and unforgiving global economy.
The conservative philosophy tells these working Americans to forget about turning to their government for help. There is nothing to be done. We are in a new era in which giant corporations rule the economic world according to the merciless dictates of a free market. The best the government can do is get out of the way.
Not surprisingly, this cynical, self-serving and ultimately inhumane approach is increasingly being seen as unsatisfactory. The conservative revolution has not raised the standard of living of most Americans, has threatened such cherished and hard-won supports as Social Security and Medicare, and has not come up with a game plan for addressing the economic and cultural challenges ahead.
Ever so subtly, ever so warily, the American gaze is drifting to the left. Let's not get crazy. We're not talking about a paradigm shift. And God forbid we should use the term liberal. That's out. But "progressive" is O.K.
Whatever the terminology, the evidence seems to be there. We found that there was a great deal of sympathy for the workers striking against United Parcel Service, and overwhelming public support for an increase in the minimum wage. Last fall we saw Republican Congressional candidates sprinting away from Newt Gingrich and the harshest elements of the conservative ideology. And in the past two Presidential elections we have seen the so-called Reagan Democrats, as worried as anyone about the economic uncertainties, returning to the fold to vote for Bill Clinton.
A recently published book, "The New Majority: Toward a Popular Progressive Politics," argues that an opportunity exists for the Democratic Party to regain the support of a solid majority of the electorate by re-establishing its traditional identification with the struggles and aspirations of working Americans -- the middle class, the working class and the working poor.
The book was edited by Stanley B. Greenberg, a pollster and former adviser to President Clinton, and Theda Skocpol, a professor of government at Harvard. It's a compilation of essays by progressive (get used to that word) thinkers, including the historian Alan Brinkley; the president of the Economic Policy Institute, Jeff Faux, and the sociologist William Julius Wilson.
The book points out that while we have been in an economic recovery for several years now, the gains are not being properly shared. Most working Americans -- despite a booming economy and a recent modest uptick in wages -- are either treading water economically or slowly sinking.
A poll taken not too long ago showed that 60 percent of whites, 58 percent of blacks and 55 percent of Latinos say that, "compared to 10 years ago, they are now farther away from attaining the American dream."
Very few of those respondents see their interests being well served by the Republican Party, the conservative ideology or the corporate juggernaut. The question is whether the Democratic Party can get its act together and seize the opportunity to fashion this new majority. It can do so only by addressing in a compelling way the real-world concerns of working families.
Right now both parties are stumbling around Washington in a dance of mutual incoherence. The Republican leadership is feuding and the top Democrats are ducking subpoenas and hiding from special prosecutors. If there are any good ideas around, they are being carefully concealed.
Which is a shame. Because there is a new majority that is just waiting for responsible, progressive leadership.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
Stocks Soar in Seoul on Kia Takeover Plan

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 22

 BODY:
The South Korean Government's decision to take over the Kia Motors Corporation, the nation's third-largest auto manufacturer after Hyundai and Daewoo, sent stock prices to a record gain today and halted a decline in the nation's currency.
Investors often bail out of financial markets when governments take over private companies because they fear the intervention will hinder the free flow of capital. But until the Seoul Government announced its decision this morning, the markets here had been weighed down by the problems of Kia Motors, whose parent, the Kia Group, owes financial institutions more than $10 billion. 
 Kia Motors, in which the Ford Motor Company has a 16.9 percent stake, was struck today by workers protesting the Government takeover. Earlier, uncertainty surrounding the auto maker caused defaults at other companies as banks called in loans to offset their exposure to Kia. Stocks tumbled in recent weeks as foreign investors dumped assets denominated in the local currency, the won, and the benchmark index fell 27 percent in the last three months.
The Government's bailout plan, valued at 700 billion won, or $760 million, is the nation's biggest ever, exceeding the size of the rescue effort for the Daewoo Group's shipbuilding business in 1984. The Government will also provide financial aid to Kia's parts suppliers.
Today's announcement caused share prices to rally, and the benchmark composite index recorded its largest single-session gain ever. The index jumped 6.1 percent, led by Kia Group affiliates and their creditor banks.
"An early solution to the Kia problem is urgent to stabilize the financial market and improve our economy's overseas credibility," Kang Kyong Shik, the Deputy Prime Minister and Finance and Economy Minister, said in announcing the takeover.
Still, the stock market is not likely to rebound fully until the nation's economic problems lessen. Economic growth is at a four-year low, six of the 30 biggest conglomerates have become insolvent or are facing bankruptcy, and even profitable companies have been caught in the financial squeeze.
"It's a temporary reaction," Ok Kyung Moon, senior analyst at Asset Korea Ltd., a fund-management company, said of today's rally by stocks. "Fundamentally, the economy still has a long way to go."
The won rose 1 percent against the dollar today, ending three days of declines. On Tuesday, the won had closed at its lowest point against the American currency since South Korea established its current trading system in 1990.
Lee Young Il, a currency dealer at Seoul Bank, said: "It may be premature to say local investors' dollar enthusiasm soothed. But investors reduced the value of their dollar buying, expecting the settlement of the Kia crisis."
Under the Government plan, the state-owned Korea Development Bank will convert about 300 billion won of its loans to Kia into an equity stake. The bank will then apply for court receivership for Kia on behalf of its creditors.
After the conversion of its loans, the bank is expected to be Kia's biggest shareholder, with about 30 percent. The largest shareholder now is Ford Motor, which owns 9.4 percent itself and a further 7.5 percent through its Japanese affiliate, Mazda Motors.
The Government plans to sell Kia's commercial-vehicle business, the Asia Motors Company.
The Korea Development Bank's president, Kim Young Tae, said Kia Motors needed about 400 billion won in emergency loans. He said the Government would push Kia's management to step down and hand over the company to a third party once its finances improved.
Some 20,000 workers at Kia Motors' went on strike today, and unions at rival manufacturers threatened to follow suit, saying the Government wanted to give away Kia to a third party. "It's a Government plot to pave the way for a hostile takeover," said Lee Seung Woo, a union leader at Kia Motors.
The Kia Group said it would take legal action "to stop this malicious move."

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: The President Bets on Technology

 BODY:
The most important thing to understand about President Clinton's speech on global warming yesterday is that he has asked the United States, a hungry producer and consumer of energy, to reverse course. He has publicly committed the country to a plan to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide, the gas mainly responsible for what could be a calamitous increase in atmospheric temperatures. He has agreed to binding targets and a timetable -- the stabilization of greenhouse gas emissions at 1990 levels between 2008 and 2012. He has proposed a system for doing so, relying largely on market mechanisms, energy efficiency and technology.
His package is less than what many environmentalists had hoped for and not nearly as aggressive as the goals that some foreign countries will put on the table when the industrialized nations convene in Kyoto, Japan, in December to try to negotiate a global climate treaty. The Europeans, for example, are seeking net reductions from 1990 levels by a much earlier date, 2005. But the plan also asks American industry to make greater investments in cleaner fuels and new technologies than they have been asked to make in the past. The threat is clear. If industry does not make these investments, Mr. Clinton's successors may have to resort to far more expensive remedies to achieve the targets he has set. 
 Indeed, there are many who argue that even Mr. Clinton's relatively modest goals cannot be met without carbon taxes that would encourage switches to cleaner fuels, or stiff new gasoline taxes that would encourage energy conservation. Mr. Clinton has rejected that course, in part because he knows it would be difficult to sell to the present Congress and in part because he believes that innovation, incentives and the free market can get the job done without serious economic turmoil.
To that end, he proposes to give industries that achieve early reductions in emissions "credits" against the day when firm industry-by-industry emissions caps take effect. By giving extra credit to companies that lower emissions quickly, Mr. Clinton hopes to spur innovation and efficiencies and put the United States on a downward slope as early in the next century as possible. That is exactly the slope the country must be on if it is to scale back its emissions to 1990 levels.
Mr. Clinton has also embraced another innovative idea that could help solve one of the most vexing problems facing the negotiators in Kyoto -- how to bring developing countries like China and India into a global system. The developing countries will not be legally bound by whatever plan is hatched in Kyoto. Mr. Clinton's idea is to entice them into the system with an international emissions trading program under which rich nations can win further credits against their targets by helping poorer nations develop advanced, and presumably cleaner, methods of producing energy.
The environmentalists and the Europeans will surely press Mr. Clinton for a more accelerated timetable before his negotiators arrive in Kyoto. But that cannot obscure the fact that for the first time, a President has committed this country to changing the ways it produces and uses energy.

HEADLINE: Hebron Journal;
On This Street, It's All Painted Over but the Hatred

BYLINE: By JOEL GREENBERG

DATELINE: HEBRON, West Bank, Oct. 22

 BODY:
Perched high on a ladder on a recent afternoon, a workman dusted off a Spanish street light gracing the new brick sidewalks of Shuhada Street, a bitterly contested road here where Palestinians and Jewish settlers are uneasy neighbors.
Palm trees and flower beds now line the once-shabby stretch of asphalt through the old heart of Hebron -- a street that has received a facelift in recent months with the help of the American Government. 
 The Shuhada Street project, which is getting its finishing touches this week, was paid for and supervised by the United States Agency for International Development -- part of the American-brokered agreement in January that led to the withdrawal of Israeli troops from most of Hebron.
But the work is ending three months behind schedule and about $1 million over its budget, hampered by the same sort of troubles that delayed the withdrawal and that have bedeviled Hebron since the pullout left it divided into areas of Palestinian and Israeli control.
Clashes between Palestinian youths throwing rocks and Israeli soldiers along the dividing line, vandalism by Jewish settlers opposed to reopening the street to Arab traffic, and confrontations between soldiers and construction workers have shown that this was no ordinary project.
"We had to deal with Israelis and Palestinians, and it was a constant continuation of the negotiating process," said Christopher Crowley, director of the American aid agency's program for the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
As envisioned in the agreement, the renovation and reopening of Shuhada, or Martyrs, Street to Arab motorists is supposed to be a step toward the "normalization of life" in Hebron after the Israeli pullout.
The road, a main traffic artery that runs by the Jewish settlement enclaves in Hebron, has been closed to Palestinian motorists since February 1994, when a Jewish settler killed 29 Muslims at prayer at the Tomb of the Patriarchs shrine nearby.
Fearing a revenge attack on the settlers living on Shuhada Street, the Israeli Army barred Arab traffic and set up checkpoints at both ends of the road. The measures deterred Arab shoppers, ruined local businesses and forced Arab motorists to make long detours to get from one side of Hebron to the other.
The 450 Jews living in Hebron among 120,000 Arabs assert that the reopening of Shuhada Street to Arab traffic will expose them to drive-by shootings and possible car-bombings by Palestinian militants.
"The Arabs could cut us off by blocking the road with their cars, go into our homes and carry out a pogrom, and no one will be able to reach us," said Anat Cohen, a militant settler who lives on the street and has had several run-ins with construction workers.
The Hebron agreement stipulated that traffic on Shuhada Street would be restored within four months of the signing of the accord on Jan. 15, and it included a minutely detailed American plan to renovate the street. But work began only in March, and repeated delays have pushed off the planned reopening and increased the cost of the project to about $2.5 million.
Now that the work is done, Shuhada Street has the look of a neatly ordered avenue, a contrast to Hebron's worn, traffic-choked roads, which have sometimes turned into rubble-strewn battlegrounds where Palestinian youths have fought Israeli soldiers.
The color turquoise dominates the renovated street, splashed on freshly painted shop shutters and their spanking new metal signs and awnings. Ornamented street lights from Spain line red-brick sidewalks that run by sandblasted stone facades of old Arab buildings. Cast-iron fencing and litter baskets flank the the newly paved and painted road, under which water and sewage lines have been upgraded.
But the improvements did not come easily.
During the first weeks of the project when the road was dug up, Arab youths protesting construction of a new Jewish neighborhood in East Jerusalem fought Israeli soldiers daily in the mud, hurling chunks of asphalt from behind piles of sand and building equipment.
When the roadwork reached the Jewish enclaves, militant settlers shattered windows of bulldozers with air guns, injuring a driver, smashed curbstones and stoned Arab laborers, said the American construction manager, who wore a bulletproof vest on the job.
Shop awnings were slashed, a new street light was smashed, and Hebrew graffiti were sprayed on freshly painted Arab storefronts. The sign announcing the project was defaced with a Jewish star and the slogan "The Nation of Israel Lives!"
Israeli soldiers have beaten Arab workers in altercations at checkpoints and stolen sidewalk bricks, the construction crew said. An Arab storefront was spray-painted with the slogan "Here comes Golani," the name of the Israeli brigade stationed on Shuhada Street, and soldiers slapped black paint on other shop shutters to blot out anti-Arab slogans sprayed by settlers.
Noam Arnon, the Hebron settlers' spokesman, lives on Shuhada Street, which the settlers call King David Street. "Opening the road will put the Jewish homes under siege, and we will be surrounded on all sides," he said. "A concentration of Arab cars will provide ideal conditions for terrorists. They could jump out of cars with knives and by the time the soldiers realize what's going on, they'll be inside the homes.
"Most of Hebron is a closed area to the Jews, we're shut up here in a ghetto, and they want to funnel Arabs into our area. This will strangle the Jewish community."
The date for reopening Shuhada Street has still not been set, nor have road signs been put up yet to direct traffic. The traffic arrangements are a delicate issue, because they will determine whether Palestinians will be able to drive normally on both sides of the street, or only one way, on the side farther from the Jewish homes.
Arab shopkeepers on the street say that life there cannot go back to normal and that there will be no economic revival as long as the Jewish settlers remain nearby, with the accompanying Israeli Army checkpoints.
"People are afraid to come here because of the checkpoints," Yaaqub Abu Laban said as he stood near his spruced-up store. "We don't want renovations, we want people."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A main traffic artery in Hebron, Shuhada Street has been spruced up thanks to Washington's $2.5 million. But raw fear and mistrust on the part of Arabs and Jews alike keep the street simmering with hostility. (Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times)
 
Map shows the location of Shuhada Street in Hebron: Flower beds and palm trees now line Shuhada Street in Hebron.

HEADLINE: New-Media Industry Becoming Juggernaut

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN

 BODY:
With breathtaking speed, Manhattan's new-media industry has become one of the biggest players in the city's media business, doubling in jobs and companies in just the last 18 months to become a $2.8 billion-a-year juggernaut, according to a study to be released today.
The survey's findings are all the more stunning considering that the new-media business, consisting mostly of Internet and other high-tech companies, barely existed just a few years ago and even now is sometimes dismissed as a hobby run by the young and the indigent. But the survey portrays a business that is maturing, outperforming other businesses and becoming increasingly vital to the metropolitan region's economy. 
 "This makes it clear to anyone who didn't understand it yet that Silicon Alley is a very real phenomenon," said Charles Millard, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, using the nickname given to Manhattan's new-media industry.
The study was conducted by the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand and the New York New Media Association, and sponsored by the Empire State Development Corporation, the New York City Economic Development Corporation and Chase Manhattan Bank. The study, the second such survey conducted by Coopers & Lybrand, measures such economic indicators as demographics, compensation patterns, freelance employment and sources of financing.
The survey gauged the new-media business in Manhattan, in New York City and in the metropolitan area. The number of new-media companies in Manhattan almost doubled, to 2,128, compared with the 1,175 found in the first survey in early 1996. And annual revenues climbed 56 percent to $2.8 billion.
In Manhattan, the number of jobs -- full time, part time and freelancers -- jumped 105 percent to 55,973. This means that the new-media business (with 27,488 full-time jobs at the end of 1996 and 32,013 in mid-1997) is among the biggest in the media business, right up there with advertising (27,528 full-time jobs at the end of 1996) and periodicals (26,543 at the end of 1996).
In the metropolitan region, the number of new-media jobs jumped 48 percent to 105,771, including an increase of 162 percent in part-timers. The number of companies climbed 16 percent to 4,991, and revenues were up 50 percent to $5.7 billion.
To be sure, despite its rapid growth, the new-media industry is still dwarfed by other industries in New York City. The securities industry, for example, employs 155,000 people and the private health care industry has 315,000, said Jim Brown, an analyst at the New York State Department of Labor.
In addition, the new-media industry is different from other traditional businesses in that it is volatile and dominated by young entrepreneurs. Nearly a third of the companies have been established in the last 18 months; more than a sixth, meanwhile, have folded in the same period. Nearly three-quarters of the employees are under 40 years old. And a whopping 83 percent of the metropolitan area's new-media businesses generate less than $1 million in annual revenues.
At the same time, though, there are signs of maturation, said Brian Horey, a venture capitalist and a founding member of the New York New Media Association. The survey found that the biggest category of job creation was sales and marketing, suggesting that companies have gone beyond the product development stage and into the business world.
"Five years ago, this industry was immature," said Andy Zimmerman, a partner in charge of telecommunications and media consulting practice at Coopers & Lybrand. "Now, this industry is getting mature like Silicon Valley mature: more and more companies are employing people versus hiring freelancers, paying people more and obtaining traditional venture capital financing."
The survey said that companies are most concerned about the high costs of doing business in New York and the lack of technical talent, something that puts places like Boston and Silicon Valley, with M.I.T. and Stanford acting as laboratories, at an advantage. But the survey concludes by saying that the New York area's abundance of artists, designers and writers places it in a good position to capitalize on the growing importance of developing Internet "content" -- the stuff that appears on a Web site. And there are no signs that the the growth in jobs will let up.
"We expected rapid growth, but I have to admit that these numbers exceed even our expectations," said Gov. George E. Pataki, whose administration has cut taxes and supported economic development projects designed to encourage new-media businesses. "Ain't it great?"

HEADLINE: Stock Rally Stalls on Corporate Earnings

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING

 BODY:
A two-day rally in stocks was stalled yesterday as investors chose to focus on the latest spate of corporate earnings disappointments to drive their investment strategies.
Boeing and Allied Signal led a 25.79-point decline in the Dow Jones industrial average. Boeing said it would report an unexpected loss for its third quarter, while Allied Signal reported earnings that fell short of expectations. Boeing fell 4 1/8, to 49 7/8, while Allied Signal fell 3 1/4, to 40 1/4. 
 But after gaining more than 200 points in just two trading days earlier this week, the Dow may have been poised for a fall as investors became wary of moving prices higher after the quick gain, said Larry Rice, chief investment officer at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross in New York.
"I'm pleasantly surprised that the market didn't fall further," Mr. Rice said, but added, "that doesn't mean we don't need another correction" before moving higher.
"Any time you get in front of 8,000, you're dealing with prices that are 21 times earnings and the risk versus the reward doesn't justify committing money at these levels," Mr. Rice said.
The Dow closed at 8,034.65, about 23 points lower than its level one week ago, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.79 points, to 968.49. The Nasdaq composite index slipped 4.46 points, to 1,708.08. And the Russell 2000, a leading small- company stock gauge, lost 0.68 point to close at 458.25.
Despite yesterday's declines, Mr. Rice and other analysts remain optimistic that stocks still have room to rise, largely because the majority of third-quarter earnings reports have been positive. In addition, the economic fundamentals of benign inflation and moderate growth that have fueled this year's rally are still intact.
"The fact that earnings are coming in strong is one of a few favorable facts that should keep the market trending higher," said Scott Reed, United States strategist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover. "It helps cushion the downside when volatility arises."
Although higher stock prices are anticipated, investors will have to come to grips with slower earnings growth in future quarters, analysts said.
"In the last few days, we've had some high-profile companies that really haven't missed in a while," Kevin Parke, director of equity research at Massachusetts Financial Services, said of the recent earnings disappointments. "And you've had some companies like Boston Scientific that missed again. Investors tend to be less skeptical that they're single-quarter issues."
As a result, investors are becoming more selective and will reward companies that can produce revenue growth, much of which will come from new product introductions and expansion into new markets, Mr. Parke said.
Some of yesterday's declines showed that investors are taking a stern view of earnings disappointments.
After guiding analysts to lower 1998 earnings estimates, Boston Scientific, fell 6 7/16, to 51. The latest disappointment came a little more than one month after the medical device manufacturer cautioned that third-quarter earnings, which were reported on Oct. 8, would grow less than expected.
Although investor demand was initially expected to be strong for China Telecom's initial public offering Tuesday, its American depository receipts fell 2 1/2, or 8.3 percent, from the offering price, to 28, on their first day of trading yesterday. Analysts said the issue was plagued by weakness in the Hong Kong market.

HEADLINE: 3M Profit Rises 8% As Sales Are Strong

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Oct. 22

 BODY:
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said today that earnings grew in line with estimates during the third quarter, lifted by strong sales and cost controls.
The company's profit, before a gain, rose 8.5 percent, to $432 million, or $1.05 a share, from $398 million, or 95 cents a share, a year earlier. 
 A gain in the latest quarter of $495 million, or $1.20 a share, from the sale of 3M's billboard business in August resulted in net income of $927 million, or $2.25 a share. In the period a year earlier, operating earnings and net income were the same.
Analysts had expected 3M to report operating earnings of $1.04 a share. The company's shares rose $5.75, to $100.375 Revenue for 3M, whose products include Post-It notes and Scotch brand tape, increased 5.6 percent, to $3.83 billion from $3.62 billion.
The company said sales growth exceeded the economic growth rates of the countries in which it operates, aided by the introduction of products. Still, the stronger dollar, which reduces foreign profits when they are converted into the American currency for reporting purposes, lowered per-share earnings by 7 cents, in line with expectations.
Analysts said 3M was able to improve its margins by keeping expenses under control.

HEADLINE: U.S. Fails to Get U.N. Backing To Widen Sanctions on Iraq

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 22

 BODY:
The United States lost its battle to impose new sanctions on Iraq today and settled for a Security Council resolution that would keep only a strong threat of added restrictions.
Opposed by France, Russia, China, Egypt and Kenya, the United States and Britain had to draw back both from a plan to impose an immediate international travel ban on senior Iraqi military and intelligence officials and from an alternative proposal to put the ban into effect automatically in six months if Iraq continued to obstruct efforts to destroy its major weapons systems. 
 Instead, a day of negotiating among Security Council members produced a resolution, which may be adopted on Thursday, that expresses the Security Council's "firm intention" to order the travel ban in April if Iraq does not meet its obligations. The resolution also condemns Iraq for barring access to weapons sites, endangering the lives of inspectors and removing or destroying documents.
The resolution calls for a list of Iraqi officials who would be subject to a travel ban to be drawn up in the interim.
Bill Richardson, the United States representative, said he was satisfied with the resolution because it had broad support. Nine council members sponsored the measure.
More than six years after the Persian Gulf war, United Nations inspectors have yet to certify that Iraq has no more weapons of mass destruction or the factories and laboratories to build them.
The delay has been caused by Iraq's lack of cooperation. Inspectors have been told so many conflicting and false stories over the years that Iraq's credibility is now very low.
Iraq has been under a crippling economic embargo since its invasion of Kuwait in August 1990.
The United States and Britain, which have held the line against all efforts to weaken those sanctions, decided to try to impose the additional measures after Iraqi officials blocked arms inspections earlier this year and interfered with aircraft, putting inspectors at risk.
The Security Council decided in June to agree to the travel ban but to postpone putting it into effect until the fall. In September the Iraqis again interfered with inspections, while submitting a report declaring that all prohibited weapons had been destroyed. Richard Butler, the chief monitor of the Iraqi arms program, concluded that the report was not credible.
Failing to have sanctions imposed now, the Clinton Administration hoped to have them applied automatically in April, when Mr. Butler's next major report is due, unless Iraq had made substantial progress in accounting for its arms. France and Russia said that this put too much responsibility on Mr. Butler and left too little room for the Security Council to debate the issue.

HEADLINE: Million Women March Is Set With High Hopes

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22

 BODY:
Two years after hundreds of thousands of men came to Washington for a day of speeches and prayers at the Million Man March, a large group of women is expected here on Saturday for an event called the Million Woman March.
While organizers predict that as many as 1.5 million women from around the United States and beyond will participate, the city's chief planner said today that local officials were preparing for 500,000 women, most black, about the same number of people who usually attend the city's Fourth of July celebration. 
 But numbers are not the issue, march organizers insisted today, discounting comparisons with the various crowd estimates of two years ago -- 800,000, according to the men's march organizers, or 400,000, according to the National Park Service.
Nor are leaders of the women's event eager for their efforts merely to replicate the men's march.
"We are in no way trying to compare ourselves to the men or to compete against them," Phile Chionesu, a founder and co-chairwoman of the women's event, said in an interview. "Our brothers took the first step and opened the door. This is another step as we walk through the door."
Like the men's event, the women's march was planned to reflect and build upon experiences of black people, particularly those affected by crime, disintegration of families, homelessness and economic disadvantage.
But while the Million Man March was organized by a religious group, the Nation of Islam, and featured prominent religious and political speakers, like Louis Farrakhan, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and the mayors of major cities, the women's march has been organized by local community leaders without the support of any mainstream organization or even leading civil rights groups, like the local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. The daylong program includes only a few speakers known beyond the region.
Even so, Ms. Chionesu, the mother of a 9-year-old daughter, said the the march was designed to convince women of African origin that they should recognize their own economic, social and political might to overcome the ills of their communities. Often, she said, women feel overwhelmed and do not realize they have such powers or the support of others to initiate change.
In that context, organizers have chosen as keynote speakers Representative Maxine Waters, the California Democrat who has pushed for an investigation into accusations that the Central Intelligence Agency introduced crack cocaine into inner-cities, and Winnie Mandela, the former wife of Nelson Mandela, the President of South Africa.
Both Ms. Waters and Ms. Mandela are immersed in controversies. No evidence has emerged to link the Government with crack distribution, and Ms. Mandela, a leader of the anti-apartheid movement while her husband was in prison, has been accused of involvement in the subsequent kidnaping, torture and murder of eight people in South Africa.
Ms. Chionesu defended both woman, calling Ms. Waters "extremely courageous" for continuing to ask questions about crack and praising Ms. Mandela as a "persecuted" human rights leader who should be considered innocent until proven otherwise.
The program also includes dozens of other speakers whose messages, Ms. Chionesu said, reflect the 12-point program developed by march organizers.
While some of the aims are clear, like support for black public schools that would teach African languages and history, an end to homelessness and creation of programs that help women who have left prison, other points are nebulous. One advocates "the development of programming that will bring about a sincere and respectful environment that will foster the necessary interaction with our youth."
Sonia Jones, a 45-year-old mother of three grown boys and national coordinator of the march, said one of the organizers' objectives was to empower women to help themselves, rather than rely on community leaders or politicians.
"People feel like they have nowhere to turn anymore," Ms. Jones said, using the proliferation of drugs as an example. "Politicians say they are going to deal with it, but then they do nothing. I know the problem exists; I see it every day. But if we all come together, we can start to do something about it ourselves."
Ms. Chionesu said the ultimate beneficiaries of the march would be generations of black women that follow, in keeping with an aphorism that march organizers have emblazoned on posters, T-shirts and sweatshirts: "Great-grandmother taught grandmother. Grandmother taught mother. Mother taught me. I will teach you."
Interviews around the nation indicate varying degrees of enthusiasm for an event that has not created anything close to the publicity preceding some other major marches. An earlier effort at a Million Woman March, in Los Angeles in June 1996, brought out just a thousand women.
Organizers from the Chicago area say they are expecting 65,000 women from Illinois, about two-thirds of them from Chicago.
"This march is long overdue," said Carolyn Burt, a state employee in Chicago. "This is going to bring about so much unity, not just among women, but among men and women, that I'm ecstatic."
But organizers in Atlanta say it is unlikely that the turnout will rival the 10,000 men from Atlanta who attended the Million Man March.
"Women have more responsibilities than men," said Wanda Cunningham, executive director of the march's Southern region. "Men could just pick up and drive. They don't have to worry about the distance, the car breaking down or who's going to look after the kids."
Still, city officials in Philadelphia are preparing for a major event. Joe Certaine, the city planner, said the expectation of 500,000 was based on an estimate by organizers last month when they paid the $10,000 fee to stage the march, which will begin near Independence Hall and end in front of the Philadelphia Museum of Art.
"We're preparing as if it will be like one of our larger Fourth of July events," Mr. Certaine said. "I expect to have a maximum of 500,000, maybe 700,000. If it's more, we're prepared. If it's less, so be it."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Clinton may soon tackle the devilish Social Security issue.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WITH trade liberalization and global warming already on the menu, one might expect President Clinton to take a break before heaping another difficult-to-digest economic issue on his plate. In fact, the White House is close to making a decision on whether to add Social Security to his agenda. There is reason for the haste: while the President has three years left in office, the political window of opportunity for tackling this most sensitive of issues is narrow.
Creating the bipartisan will to cut benefits or force workers to set aside more of their incomes for retirement is only the first step. Actually designing the plan to eliminate $8 trillion in unfunded pension liabilities could prove far more difficult. For while there is wide agreement that the problem is technically manageable, the experts on whom Washington is depending for answers are deeply -- perhaps fatally -- divided on how to get from here to there. 
 After this summer's budget accord, a triumphant President Clinton allowed that the respite from fiscal crisis "gives us a rare opportunity to take steps for the long-term well-being of our country." If that is to include major changes in Social Security before the millennium, the White House is convinced the campaign must begin soon.
The most likely scenario goes like this. Over the next few months the President will sound out Congressional Republicans -- in particular the Senate leadership, which is more inclined to pragmatism -- on whether they are prepared to take on Social Security. If the response is positive, Mr. Clinton will probably propose an advisory commission in his State of the Union address in January.
The group, modeled after the Greenspan commission that provided the nonpartisan cover to put Social Security back on track in 1983, would be top-heavy with senior Congressional leaders. The idea is to draft legislation early in 1999, after the 1998 elections. That would give Congress a chance to vote before the Presidential campaign overwhelms bipartisanship.
Administration sources emphasize that the commission would have to be buttressed by a campaign to build public support. That may not be easy since, unlike 1983 when Congress could argue that the cupboard was bare, failure to act would have no immediately visible consequences. Payroll taxes will more than cover promised pensions for at least 15 more years, when the vanguard of the baby boomers heads for Sun City.
It may be even more difficult to cobble together a consensus plan than to convince taxpayers of the need for one. For while pension experts generally agree that changes are needed, they are all over the place on substance.
At one end of the spectrum are remnants of the New Deal coalition, led by former Social Security Commissioner Robert Ball, who want to limit reforms to tucks and trims that would delay the day of reckoning for perhaps an extra decade. At the other, conservative intellectuals ranging from a former Reagan adviser, Martin Feldstein, to the staff at the Cato Institute want full privatization of the system, perhaps along the lines of Chile's celebrated makeover.
In fact, the White House and the Republican leadership are both prepared to discount these extremes.
The serious players agree that the safety net, Social Security's minimum pension benefit combined with means-tested welfare for the elderly and disabled, must remain intact. They are in accord that reforms cannot be built around permanent increases in the payroll tax. But the divisions are still fundamental.
The center-right, notably the economists Carolyn Weaver of the American Enterprise Institute, Lawrence Kotlikoff of Boston University and Sylvester Schieber at Watson Wyatt Worldwide pension consultants, want to redirect a big chunk of the existing payroll tax into I.R.A.-style instruments. They want to finance the transition costs -- money needed to cover current retirees' pensions -- from temporary taxes or from substantial cuts in future benefits to those not yet retired.
The center-left, including Edward Gramlich of the University of Michigan and Henry Aaron of the Brookings Institution, may be willing to create personally owned retirement accounts on top of the existing Social Security structure. But their goal is to make additional compulsory retirement savings palatable to a younger generation unwilling to pay more taxes for what has already been promised them. If the center-left had its way, individuals would have little discretion over where the money was invested, or when earnings from personal accounts could be converted to spendable cash.
Social Security reform is not impossible. Hardly anyone, after all, predicted that Congress would pass radical tax reform in 1986. But, for the moment, optimism depends on faith in the wisdom of policy makers and the virtue of politicians.
