HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
A Conversation With Milosevic

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia

 BODY:
"We Serbs have a national characteristic," Slobodan Milosevic said. "We resent being pushed."
His point, which he made repeatedly during a two-hour discussion, was that American pressure on him and on the Serbs in Bosnia was counterproductive. 
 As an example, he cited the strong showing of Vojislav Seselj in the recent Serbian presidential election, in which he led but which was voided because the turnout was too low. Mr. Seselj was involved in atrocities as a paramilitary leader in the Croatian and Bosnian wars and now campaigns for a Greater Serbia. Robert Gelbard, the special U.S. envoy to the Balkans, has called him a fascist.
"It was a great mistake to keep sanctions on us," Mr. Milosevic said. "I told Gelbard it would only build up Seselj, and it did."
As for Bosnia, Mr. Milosevic emphasized that he supported the Dayton agreement and a single Bosnian state. Asked about the idea of partitioning Bosnia, he said: "Partitions are a bad idea."
He has tried to bring the two factions of Bosnian Serbs together, he said -- one headed by Biljana Plavsic, president of the Bosnian Serb entity, and the other by the forces around Radovan Karadzic, the indicted war criminal -- "to make them more civilized. Time and elections will change things" and marginalize the opponents of Dayton, he said. "But you Americans don't understand that, with your black-and-white view of life."
He made clear that he was actively engaged in Bosnian Serb affairs. Although he has been thought to favor the Karadzic faction, he gave some examples of arm-twisting it. For one, he said he had persuaded Momcilo Krajisnik, a Karadzic ally who is the Serbian member of the collective Bosnian presidency, to cooperate with the international task force on retraining police.
"Krajisnik should go," Mr. Milosevic surprisingly added: should be replaced in the Bosnian presidency. But he said that should happen in an election, as the result of gradual changes in attitude rather than outside pressure.
He reiterated his opposition to the International War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague. "Let us try war criminals ourselves," he said -- Serbs resented a court that they saw as aimed at them when "all sides were guilty in Bosnia."
The American view of these matters is altogether different. In Bosnia, real progress in implementing the Dayton agreement has come only with increased energy and pressure by the U.S. and its allies in recent months.
Vojislav Seselj is seen by most analysts as a product of Mr. Milosevic's policies, not of America's. Mr. Milosevic stirred up extreme nationalism among the Serbs when the political appeal of Communism waned, and started the wars that nurtured Mr. Seselj.
Mr. Milosevic's economic policies have also produced a desperation that can turn to extremism. During his 10 years in power the median income has fallen by more than half. Violence of a fascist nature is showing up in such things as brutal attacks on Gypsies.
The U.S. experience is that Mr. Milosevic cooperates, on Bosnia and other matters, only when pressure is applied. That is why the U.S. maintains what it calls the outer wall of sanctions, limiting Serbia's access to international finance.
Europeans have not ostracized Serbia economically. In June, Italian and Greek companies paid $900 million for a 49 percent share of Serbia Telecom. Mr. Milosevic used the money to pay overdue salaries and pensions before the elections.
Mr. Milosevic is in trouble now. In July he moved to the presidency of rump Yugoslavia, made up of Serbia and Montenegro: a ceremonial post that he planned to make powerful by constitutional change. But Montenegro has just elected an anti-Milosevic president who could block those plans -- if Mr. Milosevic lets the election result be honored.
In the former royal palace where he now has his office, he projects a calm, cherubic charm. He still has control of Serbia's army and police and most of the press. He has thrived on chaos in the past, surviving by guile and force. No one should count Slobodan Milosevic out.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Hong Kong Jitters Send Dollar To 2-Week High Against Yen

BYLINE: By Bridge News 

 BODY:
The dollar climbed to a two-week high against the yen yesterday as currency dealers grew nervous about investing in Asia after the Hong Kong stock index plunged overnight.
"People say sell yen and buy Europe at this point," said Jeffrey Yu, a senior dealer at Sanwa Bank. "Anything related to Asia is going to be sold off at this point, and no one knows where to put their money except for the Western Hemisphere." 
 In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 121.87 yen, up from 120.90 late Wednesday. The dollar was also quoted at 1.7682 marks, down from 1.7868.
Hong Kong stocks dived in response to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's move to raise its overnight interest rates to as much as 300 percent to defend the Hong Kong dollar from speculative attack. Hong Kong officials have vowed to continue defending the Hong Kong dollar's 14-year-old peg to the American dollar, calling it their first priority.
The yen also continues to suffer as currency traders question whether the economic stimulus package proposed by Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party earlier this week will do much to revive Japan's sagging economy.
"The market skepticism about Japanese policy and the economy is leaving the yen vulnerable to the continued fireworks in Asia," said Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst at Smith Barney.
The dollar slumped against the German mark, hurt by nervousness that the United States stock market would suffer after the meltdown in Hong Kong and Southeast Asian stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 186.88 points after being down more than 200 points during the day.
The American stock market's losses prevented the dollar from getting much mileage out of comments from Bundesbank officials, who suggested that German interest rates were likely to stay on hold for the time being.
Buying by Asian investors of traditionally safe European currencies like the German mark and the Swiss franc also indirectly sent the dollar lower. The dollar fell to 1.4639 Swiss francs from 1.4842.
The British pound was quoted at $1.6321, down from $1.6329.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Saddam's Triumph

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Mark the date: Saddam Hussein returned to Mideast political glory on Oct. 23, 1997, in a chamber of the United Nations Security Council.
He did it by forcing America into one of its most humiliating retreats at the U.N. Saddam's victory was particularly tasty because it was given to him by four countries that America has befriended with blood, treasure, trade or all three. He has shown the Mideast that countries the U.S. had counted on would put his interests above America's, given the right price. 
 Saddam's triumph also endangers the risk-taking U.N. inspection teams and their work -- hunting out his hidden nuclear, chemical and germ warfare capabilities.
Saddam's fine day came courtesy of France, which is supposed to be America's ally at least on alternate weekends; Russia and Egypt, which are supposed to be our grateful beneficiaries, and China, whose leader will be honored with a 21-gun salute when he arrives in the U.S. as the guest of President Clinton.
On June 11, the Council voted to apply somewhat tighter restrictions if by Oct. 11 Iraq had not stopped blocking U.N. inspectors searching for Saddam's supplies of weapons of mass destruction.
Iraq had been doing that ever since the gulf war ended in February 1991. It lied, shifted stockpiles around the country and used physical force to cripple the hunt for the weaponry the U.S. and its coalition partners were good enough to leave Saddam when he was defeated.
In a report on Oct. 6, Richard Butler of Australia, the new head of the U.N. investigation commission, spoke of progress on nuclear and chemical warfare inspections.
But he delivered a warning that set U.N. records for clarity. He said Iraq was still using every technique to prevent the inspectors from discovering the whereabouts, number and production sites of Saddam's current weapon of choice -- germ war shells that can be, or already are, loaded on planes and short-range missiles.
Aboard some inspection helicopters, Iraqi "minders" even grappled with U.N. pilots and photographers to prevent them spotting weapon sites.
The Butler report was expected to lead automatically to the threatened new sanctions. The U.S., Britain and seven other countries proposed a ban on international travel of Iraqis responsible for blocking inspections.
A mild sanction, but the four leaders of the Iraqi lobby were eager to fight it. To avoid a Russian, French or Chinese veto, the U.S. and Britain nullified the heart of the June 11 resolution. They proposed that the travel sanctions be delayed another six months, at least. The castrated resolution passed 10 to 0, with Russia, China, France, Egypt and Kenya abstaining, free to oppose sanctions on Iraq in the future.
Diplomats noted that the U.S. had been overpowered at the U.N. by its supposed allies and friends in the interest of its enemy. Not being witless, they noted too that President Clinton had failed to say that he was mad, or even peeved, or would remember the betrayal.
In this kind of crisis, without a voice heard from the White House about the double-cross, no U.S. delegate could do better after a defeat than Bill Richardson. He denounced the Iraqis, praised Mr. Butler and "regretted" the abstentions of its lobby.
But one day it may sink into the consciousness of the American public that the U.S. cannot count on France in the Mideast except to knife us -- or on Russia, Egypt or China anywhere, which should have been obvious long ago.
Why do these people do these mean things to us, daddy?
France and Russia, like some of our other dear ones, have signed oildeals with Iraq already. They work for the day that the sanctions on Iraq will be lifted or so weakened that they can be ignored. Then, contracts in hand, they can rush to the Iraqi trough, just as in good old days before Saddam started the gulf war.
China intends to be signing up Iraqi oil, too. But at the U.N. it has an immediate intent: to show that America is not all that super a power. It can be conned, betrayed and mugged without a twitch or peep from its own President in public, which is the only place it counts. Beijing was passing on a lesson about America it had learned long ago, to its profit and amusement.
Now, let's hear those 21 guns.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Luxury Assisted Living On the Upper West Side

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Hoping to capture a segment of Manhattan's growing elderly population, developers are converting an apartment hotel on the Upper West Side into luxury rental housing that will provide tenants with services and help with daily chores.
At present, 120 of the 217 units in the prewar building at 333 West 86th Street, between West End Avenue and Riverside Drive, are vacant and are being turned into assisted-living units. The studio to two-bedroom apartments, renting for $4,000 to $7,500 a month with hotel-like living arrangements, will offer residents meals, recreation and housekeeping services as well as assistance with dressing and the monitoring of medication. The remaining 97 occupied units are rent-stabilized. 
 The $63 million project is being developed by the Kapson Senior Quarters Corporation of Woodbury, N.Y., and the Philips International Holding Company of Manhattan. They are leasing the 22-story structure, which will be renamed Senior Quarters at West 86th Street, for 45 years from the owner, a group of limited investors. The building is now known as the Cambridge House.
The former lessee, Cambridge House Hotel Inc., ran the building as a residential hotel since the early 1980's. Under the conversion, which began last month and is to be completed next September, improvements like new mechanical systems and elevators and refurbished hallways are also planned. So is the renovation of 21,000 square feet of space on the lobby and lower levels into common areas for the assisted-living residences, like a dining room, beauty salon, convenience shop and activity-exercise room. The top floor will become a library.
"Given the city's demographics, there is a need for such housing, and the building's location in a residential neighborhood close to shopping and transportation supports it," said Evan A. Kaplan, Kapson's president. Despite the complexities of developing a partly occupied building, he said, "With over 100 vacant units, we can make the economics work."
Kapson owns and operates 20 similar projects in the metropolitan area and has 22 more under development, including 4 in New York City. Two of those are a 143-unit building in Kew Gardens and a 206-unit structure in Riverdale. They are being done in partnership with J. E. Levine Builders of Douglaston, Queens, which is the general contractor at the Manhattan project.
Assisted-living residences are among the newer alternatives to nursing homes for older people who need some help, but do not need constant medical care. They have been slow to come to New York City in general and Manhattan in particular because of high development costs and tight regulations.
By separating the housing operations from the health care services, companies like Kapson have found an entry. They avoid the need for state licenses or special permits to develop such projects.
The 86th Street conversion will be among the first upscale projects in Manhattan to offer such housing, though more are planned. They include projects at Battery Park City, at the former Towers Nursing Home site on Central Park West, and on Fifth Avenue between 109th and 110th Streets. One of four redevelopment plans for the old armory, set on one block from 14th to 15th Streets between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, also includes assisted-living units.
The 1990 Census found 953,317 people 65 or older in the city, of whom 102,554 were 85 or older, including 23,315l in Manhattan. That segment of the population, the fastest growing, is expected to rise to 212,000 by 2010, indicating a need for specialized housing with some health service, industry experts said.
"We welcome such housing," said Herbert W. Stupp, the commissioner of New York City's Department for the Aging, "because it provides more options for and another way to keep seniors of all income brackets in the city."
Existing tenants at the 86th Street building, while wary, are taking a wait-and-see attitude about their building's future, said Charles A. Carner, a member of the Cambridge House Tenants Association and a 23-year resident. "There's a sense of cautious optimism," Mr. Carner said. "Any physical improvements made to the building will be a benefit." He said he also hopes the new population will bring stability.
The assisted-living units at the building will range in size from 294 to 1,251 square feet. There is a charge of $1,000 a month for an additional person. Personal care assistance can be provided at extra cost by a Kapson affiliate and will be available to existing tenants.
Mr. Kaplan said he expected most of the renters at the building to be in their 80's and have annual incomes of at least $65,000. He said leasing is expected to begin by December, with occupancy next September.

INDUSTRY: SIC8059 NURSING & PERSONAL CARE FACILITIES, NEC (69%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (98%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (98%);

HEADLINE: Plurality of Workfare Recipients Said to Vote in Favor of a Union

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
Slightly less than half the 35,000 workfare participants in New York City have voted in favor of union representation, officials of an organizing group announced yesterday.
The group, the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, known as Acorn, said 17,000 people had voted to unionize. The nays totaled about 300. The votes were cast over four days at 250 polling sites. 
 It was the nation's first informal polling of workfare workers about unionizing. The largely symbolic vote is not binding. The Giuliani administration has refused to negotiate with Acorn leaders, saying that unionizing recipients would institutionalize the permanence of welfare.
"Welfare is supposed to be temporary," the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, Randy L. Levine, said. "People are supposed to move off welfare to work. The bottom line here is it's inconsistent for welfare recipients to become city employees."
The organizing director of Acorn, Jon Kest, said his group would request a meeting with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
"There is nothing in the law that prevents the Mayor from recognizing the W.E.P. workers," Jack Sheinkman, president emeritus of the former Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, who is assisting the drive, said at a news conference in Greenwich Village.
Several people who work in the program called the effort an important step to better conditions. In the city, participants typically work 20 hours a week in jobs like street cleaning and mopping hospital floors in exchange for $100 in welfare benefits.
Workers complain about not receiving the proper equipment. "There are some ladies who work outdoors with no bathroom facilities," said Sheila Duncan, 48, of Harlem, who has received workfare for about a year, since being laid off as a staff analyst at a bus service.

HEADLINE: Britain Reviews Iraqi Request to Free Millions in Frozen Funds

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Oct. 23

 BODY:
The British Government says it is weighing a request by Iraq to release some of the $760 million in assets frozen in 1990 so that Baghdad can pay for a legal defense against billions of dollars of claims stemming from the Persian Gulf war.
Iraq plans to use the money to hire a London law firm to combat the approximately $200 billion in claims filed by individuals, corporations and governments for losses incurred in the war. 
 A spokesman for the British Foreign Office, Carne Ross, said "the case is under review and no money has yet been released." Mr. Ross said Iraq did not specify how much of the money Britain froze in 1990 would be used to pay legal costs.
In Washington, a State Department official said the Clinton Administration had urged Britain to refuse the request, which was made earlier this year. The United States, the official said, believes the Iraqi Government has more than enough money in hand to hire lawyers.
"We've raised our concerns with the British and we hope they do the right thing," the official said.
Mr. Ross said the request was lodged earlier this year, but refused to say when. Iraq did not ask for a specific amount of money to be unfrozen, butlegal observers said lawyers defending such complex cases typically charged millions of dollars.
If Britain agrees to end the freeze, it would be the first exception by London since the moneywas frozen seven years ago, Mr. Ross said.
A United Nations commission in Geneva has been arbitrating the claims and Iraq's Ambassador to Geneva, Barzan al-Tikriti, said in a letter to The New York Times that the "harsh economic situation" meant Iraq "lacks the financial resources needed to pay for lawyers."
After the gulf war, the Iraqis agreed to pay claims approved by the United Nations Compensation Commission. A huge number of those were individual claims. As a result of the 1996 oil-for-food deal, the commission has been receiving $100 million a month to pay the hundreds of thousands of claims.
With the individual claims largely decided, the Geneva-based commission is turning its attention to the most costly claims. The Kuwait Government, for example, is hoping to recover the largest single amount, $130 billion. Corporations from around the world have entered claims for billions of dollars.
In July 1996, the Iraqi Government hired a prominent Geneva law firm, Lalive and Partners, to argue that it should share in some of the oil sale revenues to spend for legal advice.
The commission's governing body, whose membership mirrors that of the United Nations Security Council, rebuffed Iraq's bid for money, telling the country to make its case at the United Nations.
Instead, the Iraqis sought to unfreeze assets in Britain, hiring Teacher, Stern and Selby, a law firm specializing in education, medical and insurance law. Its senior partner, Jacob I. Rabinowicz, declined comment when reached by telephone in London.
In his Oct. 17 letter, Mr. Tikriti said "there is nothing in the Security Council resolutions which prevents states from releasing Iraqi assets frozen" in various countries to finance its legal representation.
An American official said that Britain was close to releasing the funds, and that the issue was being handled delicately because Britain and the United States are "good friends and allies." British officials, insisting on anonymity, expressed sympathetic views toward the Iraqi situation.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Soar as Investors Seek Safety in Stock Plunge

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasuries rose sharply yesterday, largely because of a "flight to quality" by investors seeking safety in United States Government securities after the selloff on stock markets.
The 30-year Treasury bond surged 1 14/32, to a price of 100 29/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, dropped to 6.31 percent, from 6.41 percent on Wednesday. It was the lowest yield since 6.23 percent on Oct. 7. 
 The stock plunge in Hong Kong spilled over to other markets, including American stocks, driving many investors to buy bonds.
Traders said activity among retail investors and central banks, including foreign participants, was heavier than usual yesterday in the Treasury market. Dealers said investors were paying higher prices for liquidity with international markets in flux.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said the international situation would be examined when the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee meets next month.
Still, he added, "domestic considerations, particularly the outlook for inflation, will remain the central focus of discussion."
On that front, the Government reported yesterday that initial claims for unemployment benefits rose last week to a higher-than-expected level, a possible sign of easing in the labor market, which would lessen the chances of higher inflation. The report, which showed that claims rose by 8,000, to 315,000, helped support the gains in bonds.
Next week, investors will get several significant economic reports and the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, will testify before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
Also on the schedule for next week are the auctions by the Treasury of new two- and five-year notes, and its announcement of the size of its quarterly refunding of debt.
"While Chairman Greenspan's testimony will certainly take center stage," Mr. Fine said, the Employment Cost Index for September, to be reported on Tuesday morning, could shake the bond market if it is noticeably above or below expectations.
But other economic reports could also have a big influence on the Fed's decisions on interest rates. Mr. Fine said he thought that reports on sales of new and existing homes in September would continue to point to a vibrant housing sector. Data on durable-goods orders and inventories for that month will give an early hint of industrial production in the fourth quarter.
And Mr. Fine said he expected a report on consumer confidence to show that buyers were still optimistic. The Fed will also issue its report on regional economic conditions.
David Ader, director of fixed income at Technical Data in Boston, agreed that the drop in international markets might reduce the chance of a rate increase by the Fed. "For today at least," he said, "if I had been giving the Fed a 40 percent chance of raising rates over the next couple of months, I might lower those chances to 25 percent."
Still, Mr. Ader contrasted the situation in Southeast Asia with the crisis in Mexico with the devaluation of the peso in 1994. He recalled that the Fed was not hesitant to raise rates as Mexico's troubles deepened. "And Mexico is nearer and dearer to us than Hong Kong," he added.
In when-issued trading ahead of next week's note auctions, securities firms were offering the new two-year notes at a price to yield 5.79 percent, and the five-year at a price to yield 5.94 percent.

HEADLINE: Trading on the Pollution Exchange;
Global Warming Plan Would Make Emissions a Commodity

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
If President Clinton has his way, rights to spew carbon dioxide into the atmosphere will eventually be traded by energy producers, utilities and even investors on exchanges the way pork bellies, German marks and interest rate futures change hands today.
 While the Administration's plan for curtailing greenhouse gases -- announced Wednesday in preparation for the world climate change talks in Kyoto, Japan, in December -- demands no immediate action by businesses, it confirms that a system of tradable emissions permits will figure prominently in any long-term effort to control pollutants. Such a system, already being used under the Clean Air Act of 1990 to cut sulfur emissions, would allow companies that voluntarily reduce emissions below a certain level to sell the difference to others as unused "rights" to pollute. 
 The reliance on free markets in reducing carbon emissions to 1990 levels has been greeted with enthusiasm by specialists who have long argued that managing the task with traditional regulation would be hugely wasteful.
"An approach that promises to reduce the cost of containment by 90 percent is certainly worth a try," said Richard Richels of the Electric Power Research Institute in California.
But many economists caution that emissions trading is no panacea. They emphasize the desirability of bringing developing countries into the trading systems as soon as possible and the need for care in designing the control mechanisms that will redirect billions or even trillions of dollars in pollution-control investments worldwide.
"At this point, the learning is more important than the doing," suggested Robert Hahn of the American Enterprise Institute, a research group in Washington.
The Administration's plan has been criticized by many foreign governments that will also attend the Kyoto conference, where the participants will try to work out a global climate treaty. The critics say the American plan is not aggressive enough because it would not roll back emissions to 1990 levels until sometime between 2008 and 2012. Whatever happens in Kyoto, Mr. Clinton seems committed to emissions trading.
It is no secret why: It costs less and keeps Big Brother in the background.
To date, the most ambitious use of tradable permits has been in containing the sulfur emissions from power plants that contribute to acid rain. Under the Clean Air Act, total sulfur emissions were capped by giving electric utilities rights to emit sulfur roughly in proportion to their lower, 1980 emissions levels. Companies that reduce emissions below their allowance by closing plants, switching fuels or attaching chemical scrubbers to their smokestacks are free to sell their surplus pollution rights, while others are free to exceed their limits by buying those rights.
The market for sulfur emissions has flourished as utilities with low-cost sources of clean fuel have found it profitable to operate within the Government standards and sell part of their allotments to pollute. Last year, the market price of sulfur allowances averaged just more than $100 a ton.
"Emissions have been reduced at a cost far lower than the most optimistic forecasts," said Richard Sandor, the chief executive of Centre Financial Products and vice chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade.
Some economists are confident that similar serendipities await a trading system for carbon dioxide and perhaps other greenhouse gases. Global warming occurs when such gases accumulate in the atmosphere, trapping heat.
"Since none of the effect is localized, carbon is a perfect pollutant for emissions trading," argued Dan Dudek, an economist at the Environmental Defense Fund who was instrumental in pushing through the sulfur program in 1990.
But many a slip is possible between cup and lip. For one thing, the scale would be much larger. A few hundred utilities with a few thousand power plants emit most of the sulfur regulated under the Clean Air Act. Carbon dioxide, however, comes not only from power plants but also from hundreds of millions of boilers and vehicles, which could not possibly be monitored like electric utilities.
That suggests the need for a different approach, says Robert Stavins, an economist at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government. He suggests that producers of coal, oil and natural gas be required to obtain emissions permits equal to the carbon content of their products rather than putting the burden on fuel consumers.
Limits on volumes that could be sold would raise the competitive price of all carbon fuels. But because coal emits more carbon dioxide for every unit of heat than natural gas, the price of coal would rise far more than the price of gas. That would give utilities an incentive to abandon coal.
Under the sulfur trading system, electric utilities receive roughly $1 billion (at current trading prices) worth of permits free each year -- a large but not overwhelming benefit to a $100 billion industry. And because utilities are regulated by the states, virtually all of the saving is passed on to rate payers. By contrast, if fossil-fuel producers received free carbon permits, there is no reason to think that the windfall, which could measure in the tens of billions of dollars annually, would go to consumers.
The Government would, in theory, have the option of auctioning carbon emissions permits rather than giving them away. But the political battle over limiting emissions is likely to be fierce: reducing carbon output to 1990 levels, for example, would almost certainly require phasing out coal as a boiler fuel within a few decades. Thus, while economists see merit in auctioning permits and using the proceeds to cut other taxes, coal producers and their unions would most likely work aggressively to block legislation that did not give them a big piece of the action.
The potential gains from international trading of carbon emissions permits are even greater than from domestic trading. While the industrialized world has a multitrillion-dollar investment in boilers and engines that would have to be scrapped rapidly to reach 1990 emissions levels, the third world has opportunities galore for easy carbon conservation.
Buildings have not been insulated; industrial boilers have not been retrofitted with efficient combustion systems. Most important, rapidly growing economies -- notably China -- have yet to sink huge sums in modern coal-fired boilers or fuel-hogging vehicles.
Opportunities to weaken the link between economic growth and carbon emissions are complemented by opportunities to preserve natural carbon "sinks" -- vast inventories of carbon stored in trees. Two big utilities, American Electric Power and Pacificorp, along with British Petroleum, are experimenting with a program to spare five million acres of forest in Bolivia from logging in what amounts to an act of philanthropy. The estimated cost of sequestering a ton of carbon this way is just 37 cents, less than 1 percent of the cost of many emissions-reducing industrial projects contemplated for Europe and North America.
The intuition that the greatest opportunities are in poor countries is borne out by computer simulations. William Nordhaus of Yale University estimates that the cost of meeting the developed world's commitment to getting back to 1990 emissions levels would be cut by at least 85 percent if the containment largely consisted of paying developing countries to adopt a carbon-lean growth strategy.
A strategy that used international trading to focus on containing carbon emissions in developing countries would also pay local dividends, such as reducing urban pollution. "Increasing fuel efficiency and switching to natural gas would incidentally mean lower levels of smog, which now threatens health in virtually all the big cities," notes Mr. Dudek of the Environmental Defense Fund.
Unfortunately, the difficulties in creating and enforcing a trading system that crosses borders are formidable, beginning with the problem of apportioning the initial obligations to contain carbon.
The European Community wants to start from a 1990 emissions base line, which would cost it little because Europe would receive credit for the conversion of Britain and eastern Germany from coal to natural gas in the 1990's. Meanwhile, Brazil, China, India, Indonesia and most of the rest of the third world want controls to kick in only when their per capita emissions have reached parity with the West -- a formula for doing nothing until the middle of the next century.
Thomas Schelling, an economist at the University of Maryland's School of Public Policy, emphasizes the distinction between making promises to reduce emissions by some amount at a certain date and translating talk into action. "Global emissions trading is an elegant idea," he said, "but I cannot seriously envision national representatives sitting down to divide up rights in perpetuity worth a trillion dollars."
That explains why President Clinton, who on Wednesday reaffirmed that "developing countries must participate in meeting the challenge of climate change," seems willing to fudge the issue for a while by encouraging voluntary investment of American cash and technology in third world efforts to contain emissions.
The American Electric Power-British Petroleum forest preservation project in Bolivia fits the model well. And Mr. Clinton is apparently planning to bolster such voluntary efforts by guaranteeing participants credits against mandatory emissions limitations highly likely to be imposed after 2008.
But Mr. Stavins of Harvard argues that monitoring such deals is bound to be problematic. Apart from the practical issues of insuring compliance in countries with inadequate infrastructure, corrupt governments and courts unwilling to enforce contracts, he is concerned that in agreements between companies, "both parties will have powerful incentives to exaggerate the gains."
American policy makers thus face some difficult issues. Market-based strategies to contain global warming promise far more bang for a buck than traditional regulation. But carrying out such efforts poses new problems that engender skepticism, even among free-market advocates. "We just have not thought through the mechanics of international trading," argued Mr. Nordhaus of Yale.
That is why many economists and some environmentalists are quietly pleased with the part of the Administration's plan that would delay mandatory market-based limitations for another decade.
"If it's worth doing," argued Paul Portney, president of Resources for the Future in Washington, "surely it's worth waiting long enough to do the job right."

"Meeting the Goal on Greenhouse Gases"
A Clinton Administration plan to reduce the amount of heat-trapping gases in the atmosphere to 1990 levels would allow companies several options to meet that goal. Here is how it would work.
A factory could try to reduce its emissions by upgrading its equipment or using cleaner fuel sources. If it did not succeed, it could . . .
 
OPTION 1. . . Buy the right to emit more heat-trapping gases from a company that has reduced its emissions below its target level.
OPTION 2. . . Pay to preserve forests. Because plants absorb carbon dioxide, the most prevalent heat-trapping gas, preservation of trees increases the amount of carbon dioxide the planet can handle.
OPTION 3. . . Pay to modernize a plant in a developing country and reduce its heat-trapping gas emissions.
(pg. D1)

HEADLINE: House Again Delays Vote on Money for Amtrak

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23

 BODY:
The House of Representatives failed for a second day in a row to vote on a bill that is needed to release $2.3 billion that is supposed to pay for new high-speed Amtrak trains.
But whether the railroad will actually get the trains is uncertain, because provisions in the bill set limits on liability suits, which the Senate refused to discuss last year. And even if Amtrak gets the money, some officials think it may have to be spent instead on operating expenses, like raises for track workers who are threatening to strike. 
 "This is probably the last chance to save Amtrak without a bankruptcy," Representative Bud Shuster of Pennsylvania, the chairman of the Transportation Committee, said on Wednesday before Republican leaders postponed a vote on the bill because they were uncertain whether it would pass. Republicans said this morning that they thought the bill would squeak through, but then postponed a vote again.
On the strike front, Amtrak did not appear to be making progress toward a settlement with the Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employees, and the brief extension of a strike deadline lasts until Wednesday. The parties did agree today on plans to let Long Island Rail Road, New Jersey Transit and South East Pennsylvania Transportation Authority commuter trains that use Amtrak rails keep running, at least briefly, in case of a strike. The Federal Railroad Administration must approve the plans.
The union is seeking -- and a Presidential mediating panel agrees -- to have its 2,300 members paid the same as workers doing similar tasks for freight railroads, roughly $3 more an hour for a total of about $18 an hour. But Amtrak's financial condition is bleak, and it says those raises -- applied to other unions, too -- would leave it deeper in the red.
Senator Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, today released a letter that he sent to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, a Republican, saying that he had been in contact with the track workers and hoped a disruption could be avoided. But Mr. Torricelli said in a telephone interview, "I have a lingering fear that Amtrak might intentionally allow the strike to interfere with commuter rail, to place political pressure on Congress and the President to step in."
The union, on the other hand, appears to want to disrupt only Amtrak, to avoid provoking Congress into ending a strike.
Transportation Secretary Rodney Slater and others have suggested that Amtrak could use the capital funds to pay for labor settlements, in effect spending the mortgage money to pay the grocery bills.
Congress has already agreed on how much the railroad should get in capital funds, in a tax bill passed this summer. But the Republicans are refusing to give final approval on the funds unless they are linked to the end of statutory protections against layoffs and outsourcing and making those the subject of labor-management negotiations.
And the provision would set limits on damages for passenger victims of railroad accidents. The Democrats complain that this would result in bigger awards to injured people who are highly paid -- and thus could show economic damage if they could not work -- than to children, the elderly and low-income people. Last year the Senate refused to take up a bill with the labor changes because it included these liability provisions.

HEADLINE: THE ASIAN CRISIS: BEIJING;
China Vows Not to Overrule Hong Kong Officials

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 23

 BODY:
Faced with their first major crisis since resuming sovereignty over Hong Kong, where the stock market went into free fall and lost 10.4 percent of its value today, Chinese officials responded calmly with promises not to intervene or overrule Hong Kong authorities.
Displaying a sophisticated understanding of market pressure, and pointing to the "one-country, two-systems" formula that Beijing has pledged to keep in Hong Kong, China's top banker employed caution and expressed confidence that Hong Kong's financial authorities would handle the situation. 
 "The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has the competence and capability to maintain the stability of the Hong Kong dollar," Dai Xianglong, governor of the People's Bank of China, told a Hong Kong newspaper in an interview to be printed Friday.
At the same time, Mr. Dai sent a signal to speculators by declaring that China was prepared to support the Hong Kong currency, if asked.
One of the main concerns in Hong Kong about Beijing's new rule has been that Chinese officials unfamiliar with modern financial markets might panic or interfere in a crisis.
Technically, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has sole say in the territory's fiscal matters. But if a serious disagreement arose between Hong Kong and Beijing during a financial crisis, it is anyone's guess who would prevail.
In a sense, today was the first test.
Acting calmly, Mr. Dai and other bank officials indicated that even before they took control of Hong Kong on July 1, they had anticipated just such a market meltdown. "We are fully prepared for this kind of situation," Mr. Dai said. "I have full confidence in the Hong Kong dollar."
Economists have been watching with growing bemusement over the last year as China's foreign exchange reserves grew ever higher, reaching $134 billion by the end of September. Mr. Dai acknowledged today that one of the reasons was to protect the Hong Kong and Chinese currencies in a crisis.
In view of the market turbulence spreading across the globe, Mr. Dai said, "The reserves are currently sufficient, not excessive."
Hong Kong's own reserves total $80 billion, and officials at the Hong Kong Monetary Authority have pledged to use what is necessary to defend the Hong Kong dollar's peg to the United States dollar of 7.75 to 1.
Just prior to the handover of power to Beijing, there was wide speculation in Hong Kong about whether Chinese authorities would try to support the Hong Kong stock market if it came under heavy pressure. Now that that has happened, however, a senior economist at the Bank of China insisted that it was inconceivable Beijing would authorize such a defensive operation.
"A lot of analysts thought the market became overvalued in the last few months, especially red chips," the economist said, referring to China-based companies listed in Hong Kong. "It makes no sense to support the stock market. It will rise and fall. The currency is what needs to remain stable."
Shen Guofang, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, echoed that sentiment. "No administrative agencies will interfere or intervene in the operations of the stock market," Mr. Shen told reporters. "We believe the 'one country, two systems' is being applied well in Hong Kong."
Eden Woon, director of Hong Kong's General Chamber of Commerce, said most business leaders supported the Government's policy. "This is a very political issue," Mr. Woon said. "Everyone sees it as an extremely important sign of stability and confidence in the territory. People know that a loosening of the peg would cost a great deal."

HEADLINE: THE ASIAN CRISIS: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Russia and Brazil Caught in Selling Surge

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
What had been an Asian problem looks more and more like an emerging markets problem, as even the most buoyant of these markets, like Russia and Brazil, succumbed to a tidal wave of selling yesterday.
The biggest repercussions were in the countries perceived to have the weakest currencies, and investors were reminded that a diverse portfolio representing many regions of the world does not necessarily provide real protection against a global downdraft. 
 Mutual funds specializing in Latin American stocks have been among the best performers this year, and Russian funds have been even hotter. But yesterday the major stock market indexes fell by about 8 percent in Brazil, 4.5 percent in Mexico and 5 percent in Russia -- two to four times worse than the 2 percent decline suffered by American stocks.
"There really didn't seem to be a place to hide yesterday," said Rajeev Bhaman, co-manager of the Oppenheimer Developing Markets fund. "When the sentiment goes against a class of assets like the emerging markets, everything goes together."
The widespread fallout from the Asian currency crisis, which caused the Hong Kong market to fall 10.4 percent yesterday, started to take a toll on American mutual fund investors, who previously this year have shown some skittishness at volatility in the American stock market.
At T. Rowe Price in Baltimore, investors generally appeared to be moving money out of international funds yesterday and into either United States stock funds or money market funds, said Steven Norwitz, a spokesman. Similarly, at Fidelity Investments in Boston, investors made slight redemptions in international funds yesterday while moving money into domestic growth stock funds or money market accounts, said Teri Kilduff, a spokeswoman. And at Charles Schwab & Company in San Francisco, investors made net withdrawals of $13 million from mutual funds of all types yesterday, a spokesman said.
What happens now in emerging markets around the world could depend as much on the reactions of American mutual fund investors as on the plans of central bankers around the globe.
"If people end up withdrawing capital from these emerging markets, they could all be in trouble," Mr. Bhaman said. "People may end up saying that because things are bad in China, they don't want to lend money in Brazil."
So far, however, the problems have been contained in Asia, and nearly all of the withdrawals from emerging market mutual funds in recent weeks have been from funds that specialize in the Asian and Pacific markets, said Robert Adler, president of AMG Data Services, which tracks mutual fund cash flows.
In the week ended Wednesday, Asian funds suffered net outflows of $53 million, while emerging market funds overall took in $149 million, Mr. Adler said.
Funds investing in the Pacific region had already fallen 10 percent to 20 percent this year, before the sharp declines this week. And while most fund managers say they are attracted by the greatly depressed prices in Asian markets, they have been reluctant to plunge in and buy in the middle of the downturn.
"The question is do you want to get in the way of a falling safe, even though you know there's lots of money in it," said Robert Swift, a senior portfolio manager at Putnam Investments. "Right now, people are stepping aside."
And when they do participate, they are as likely to raise cash in order to brace themselves for possible redemptions by shareholders. "Depending on how fast we see stability returning, I think we could see investors make a high level of redemptions in emerging market funds in the next few weeks," said Angeline Ee, co-manager of the Montgomery Emerging Markets fund.
That could spread the weakness in Asia to other regions. The markets outside of Asia that most worry fund managers include Brazil, which suffers from several of the same negative economic factors that have led to currency declines in Asia.
"We have concerns about the real," the Brazilian currency unit, Ms. Ee said. "Brazil has a current account deficit, a fiscal deficit, and the real is currently overvalued. I think that is why it was hit so hard today."
Brazil is also one of the largest, most liquid Latin American markets, which means that it is one of the first emerging markets that mutual fund managers turn to when they need to sell stocks quickly.
Other, smaller South American markets, however, appear to be less vulnerable.
Certainly, Latin American stock funds still have big gains for the year, as do Russian funds. In Eastern Europe yesterday, Russian blue-chip stocks were hit the hardest, but stocks of smaller companies fell much less sharply yesterday.
Christian Strenger, chief executive of Deutsche Bank's mutual fund unit, said he believed that because much of Russia's economic growth is internally generated, rather than dependent on exports, it does not face many of the dangers that have recently afflicted Asian markets.
Whether Asia experiences the V-shaped decline and recovery that investors saw in Mexico two years ago, or a longer, drawn-out recovery like that experienced in Japan in recent years, depends on who steps forward to help the Asian countries and how willing those countries are to make often-painful economic adjustments.
Not all Asian markets fell apart yesterday, and some managers foresee that the long-lasting effect of the currency problems there will be to make products from Asian countries more competitive.
Stock prices rose in Taiwan, for example, and one big industry there -- makers of semiconductor manufacturing equipment -- could find that Asian currency declines have made their products more attractively priced relative to those of American and Japanese rivals.
For investors in emerging market mutual funds, the least effective way to grapple with crisis is likely to be withdrawing money from emerging markets now, only to pour it back in when the stock markets appear on the upswing again is likely to be a fruitless pursuit.
"Emerging markets have gained 15 percent annually over the long term, but that can vary by 40 percent each year," said David Bugen, a financial adviser in Chatham, N.J. "That means you could make 65 percent in two out of three years, but on the other hand it's not unusual to lose 25 percent in a single year."

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE GOVERNOR;
Whitman Plays Down the Polls That Show Her in a Tight Race

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: EDISON, N.J., Oct. 23

 BODY:
Expressing cautious optimism about her re-election bid, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today played down recent polls showing her locked in a close race with her Democratic opponent. But she acknowledged that voters were sending her a strong message to address their concerns over property taxes and auto insurance.
In an interview with reporters and editors at an office in The New York Times's printing plant here, Mrs. Whitman said voters were voicing discontent about those two problems because they did not want her to think "for a minute that you've solved every problem, because you haven't." 
 "They want to keep their politicians honest," she said. "These are the issues we want you to talk about and we're not going to tell you at the end of the day how we're going to vote unless we're satisfied with the way you're going to handle these two issues."
When asked why voters apparently were not giving her much credit for cutting taxes or for helping keep property tax rate increases down, she replied, "Beats me."
But Mrs. Whitman said she thought voters would realize in the final days leading up to the Nov. 4 election that the state's economy was humming and that she had cut taxes, lowered crime, overhauled welfare and created more jobs and new academic standards.
"I think people do appreciate elected officials who keep their promises, and I think that will be reflected on Election Day," she said.
During the one-hour interview, Mrs. Whitman firmly defended her record and summarily dismissed proposals by her challenger, State Senator James E. McGreevey, to reduce property taxes and auto insurance rates. A report on a similar McGreevey interview is to be published next week.
The Whitman interview covered a wide range of topics from the unofficial role that her husband has played in her administration to her plans to spend $215 million on a tunnel in Atlantic City. Excerpts, page B6.
Mrs. Whitman was eager to explain how she would confront the two top problems on voters' minds in a second term. She vowed that she would address them with the same determination that helped her deliver on her 1993 campaign promise to cut state income tax rates during the last four years, a move that won her national notice as a rising Republican star.
"The same focus I put on the issues they were concerned about four years ago, I will put on property taxes and auto insurance," she said, "because those things are too high and we need to get them under control."
Even though the State Legislature had rejected her plan to reduce auto insurance premiums earlier this year, she said she was confident that lawmakers would take it up before the end of the year. She is submitting the same plan to cut rates by allowing consumers the option to limit their ability to file lawsuits after a car accident. Only this time, she said, insurance companies would be required to lower rates for those consumers.
"This has been raised in the course of this campaign to a level that we haven't seen before, and they are hearing this as much as I am hearing it," she said, referring to state lawmakers.
"They know that while it's an issue Nov. 1st, 2d and 3d, it's also going to be an issue the 5th, 6th and 7th. It's not going to go away. They have to take some action or else the public really will be up in arms.
"The Assembly faces an election in two years. People are not going to forget that. And I believe that we have an ability to get it done. Certainly, I have more of an ability to get it done because it's a more comprehensive plan than anything my opponent has put forward. I mean to really provide relief for ratepayers."
Mrs. Whitman attacked Mr. McGreevey's proposal, calling his plan to order a 10 percent mandatory rollback in auto insurance rates unconstitutional.
"Well, first of all, I don't think he has a plan," she said. "He's made statements about what he would do, the first of which is unconstitutional because he's going to roll back, with executive order, a 10 percent rollback." Mrs. Whitman said such an order would be immediately greeted with lawsuits from insurance companies.
"The other part of what he's talking about doing, I can't actually comment on because sometimes he says he'll do it and sometimes he says he won't do it, which is do away with geographic territorial rating," she said, referring to a state law that allows insurance companies to determine rates based on where people live. As a result, New Jersey drivers who live in urban areas pay higher rates than those who live in suburban or rural areas.
On property taxes, Mrs. Whitman also rejected Mr. McGreevey's proposal to create a commission to consider overhauling the state's tax structure, and then to allow voters to choose whether they want higher state taxes or property taxes to cover the cost of public education.
"Send it to the people," she said, her voice indicating sarcasm. "Anything to avoid making a decision. And governors are supposed to be making decisions."
In her second term, Mrs. Whitman said she would continue to give municipalities and school districts the tools to help them keep property tax rates down. She said she was also seeking to change the way that municipal aid is distributed to reward those communities that rein in spending rather than "constantly throwing lots of money."
She firmly rejected any increase in the state income tax or the sales tax to raise revenues. A commission, as suggested by Mr. McGreevey, could recommend increasing both taxes. She said that the tax cut she championed had helped make the state more attractive to businesses and that any increase in the sales taxe would make New Jersey uncompetitive with its neighboring states.
Mrs. Whitman fended off Mr. McGreevey's criticism over her decision to spend $215 million to build a tunnel and roadway in Atlantic City that Donald J. Trump has labeled a "driveway" for his chief casino rival, Steve Wynn.
"The money that the state is spending in Atlantic City is for infrastructure improvement that is critical to Atlantic City," she said. She also said that the project would create 96,000 construction jobs and 16,000 permanent jobs. And she noted that Mr. Wynn was investing $55 million in the project.
Mrs. Whitman was also asked about comments that Ed Rollins, her campaign consultant in 1993, made in Washington at a breakfast on Tuesday. It was at a similar breakfast meeting after Mrs. Whitman's narrow victory in 1993 that Mr. Rollins erroneously asserted that black ministers were paid to keep voter turnout low.
In his most recent remarks, Mr. Rollins suggested that the Governor would not be facing such difficulties in her re-election bid if she had spent less time outside of the state building her image as a national Republican leader.
"Ed Rollins has a penchant for saying things at breakfast that he regrets later on in the day," she said. "That's the best I can say to that."
But when told that Mr. Rollins also said that he thought that she could win, Mrs. Whitman smiled. "Nobody's wrong all the time," she said.
And what about the unofficial role that her husband, John Whitman, an investment banker, has played in her administration?
"Obviously, he is my best friend and my partner, and I talk about things with him," she said. "There's no question about that. And that's normal." She said he has not played any unofficial role, such as meeting with commissioners or aides.
Governor Whitman was also asked what she would do if she lost the race. Without missing a beat, she said she would attend more of her son's lacrosse games at Boston College, where he is now a freshman.
"I did sneak away last weekend," she admitted. "I read that I was supposedly relaxing on Sunday. Well, it was relaxing. It was wonderful. I went up and saw him play lacrosse."
Mrs. Whitman also addressed questions about comments that her husband made about this campaign's being her last campaign ever. "I'm not planning on any other run for anything else," she said. "I'm not looking to this as being a stepping stone to anything else. I just want to be Governor again."

HEADLINE: THE ASIAN CRISIS: THE CURRENCY BATTLE;
Defending Fixed Exchange Rate at Further Cost to Stocks

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Friday, Oct. 24

 BODY:
How much longer can the bloodletting in stock markets go on?
The damage worsened on the Hong Kong stock exchange Thursday, with the benchmark Hang Seng index plunging 1,211 points, or 10.4 percent, after a 6.17 percent fall the day before. It was the steepest one-day drop there since Chinese forces snuffed out pro-democracy demonstrations at Tiananmen Square in Beijing in June 1989. 
 The Government pledged to defend the Hong Kong dollar against currency speculators -- a policy that has accelerated the exodus from stocks. Whether the authorities can do so indefinitely is the $80 billion question everyone is asking, from small investors to monetary authorities in Japan and the United States.
"The key issue is really the currency -- the battle between the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the speculator in the Hong Kong dollar," said John M. Mulcahy, a vice presi dent of W. I. Carr, a brokerage firm in Hong Kong. "And what we have seen in the market today is a very significant increase in money market rates."
Hong Kong authorities said they had not yet touched an $80 billion foreign-exchange war chest to defend their currency. Instead, they jacked up interest rates as high as 300 percent for overnight deposits. But the consequence of preserving the Hong Kong dollar's peg to the American dollar at a rate around 7.75 to 1, most analysts and fund managers agree, will be further losses in stocks.
"If the peg remains, you'll see a sharp deflation in assets, particularly property assets," said Diahann L. Brown, a vice president at Thornton Management Asia Ltd.. "And property makes up a significant component of the market index."
Already with some of the most expensive real estate anywhere -- this summer, an old colonial home tucked onto the top of a wooded ridge on Hong Kong island sold for $100 million -- there has been rumbling about the prospect of Hong Kong's pricing itself out of competition. In the last two months, the number of tourists has plummeted, particularly from Japan, where Hong Kong was long regarded as a shopper's paradise. Now, Japanese tourists say, Hong Kong is simply too expensive.
Moreover, because of its link to United States currency, the Hong Kong dollar has appreciated 20 to 40 percent against free-falling regional currencies like the Thai baht and the Malaysian ringgit. This further erodes Hong Kong's competitive position by making its exports more expensive.
Since Aug. 7, when the Hang Seng stock index hit an all-time high of 16,673.27, nearly 40 percent of its value has been erased. The damage has now spread through Asia and started to take a toll in Europe, driving markets and currencies lower.
For much of this week, Hong Kong has been swept by repeated rumors that its dollar, tightly linked to the American dollar for 14 years, would be devalued. "It seems that people are trying to create a level playing field," said Miron Mushkat, chief Asian economist for Lehman Brothers there. "They've brought down the other markets in Southeast Asia, and now they're focusing on Hong Kong."
On Thursday, that seemed only to harden the authorities' line against speculators. "The first priority is to defend the exchange rate," said Hong Kong's financial secretary, Donald Tsang, at a news conference after the market closed. "We believe it is right to do so."
The Monetary Authority's chairman, Joseph Yam, told the news conference that his agency would charge high penalties to traders who needed to borrow Hong Kong dollars to cover their short positionstoday. It "should be a very interesting day," he added.
Ms. Brown of Thornton Management said the authority was certain to do all it could to squeeze speculators. She predicted that interest rates would remain "very, very high" for the next several days. While ordinary lending rates were nowhere near the triple-digit levels of overnight funds, three big Hong Kong banks on Thursday raised the rates they charge their best customers by three-quarters of a percentage point, to 9.5 percent.
Higher rates are bad for Hong Kong because they deter borrowing, slow the sale of property, a key sector of the economy, and drive money out of stocks and into bonds.
Some analysts saw glimmers of hope. Mr. Mushkat predicted victory for the Government over speculators. And Carlton Poon, a director at Worldsec International Ltd, said many Hong Kong stocks were looking cheap.
"There's a 50 percent sale in Hong Kong -- the Christmas sale has started early," Mr. Poon said. "I see this as a buying opportunity."
Mostly, though, the mood seemed gloomy. Throughout the day, small shareholders huddled around trading screens set up in banks. One investor was shown on Hong Kong television staring helplessly at a monitor. "There's nothing we can do," he said.
The newspaper Sing Pao reported Thursday morning that a senior British executive at a major financial institution had committed suicide over the market's collapse. The executive, who was not named in the report, was found dead in his luxury apartment on the high-rent south side of Hong Kong island.
Throughout the day, there was a mixture of anxiety, nervousness and bravado as people sought to plumb the meaning of the market crash and the prospects in coming days. Yet the prevailing attitude was to flee the market until assaults on the Hong Kong dollar eased and interest rates stabilized.
"People have cut quite a bit of Hong Kong from their portfolios," Ms. Brown said. "I'm holding more cash than I ever held. The next three days to a week will be critical."
The turmoil spilled over into world markets on Thursday, from India and Japan, to the financial capitals of Europe, to Wall Street. And China -- which re-established control of Hong Kong, as a special administrative region, less than four months ago -- was not spared.
The so-called red chips, the stocks of Chinese mainland companies that are traded in Hong Kong, have been hammered all week. Once seen as the go-go stocks of the market, in large part out of a sense they had strong backing from Beijing, they have been swept aside in the rush to sell. The newest and brightest issue, China Telecom, traded at 18 percent below its issue price. On the New York Stock Exchange, the company's American depository receipts declined 37.5 cents on Thursday, to $27.625.
Still, a Chinese spokesman, Shen Guofan, said in Beijing that the Government would not intervene in Hong Kong's financial crisis. "The central Government is responsible only on foreign and defense affairs of Hong Kong," Mr. Shen said. "Hong Kong has the strength to deal with it."

HEADLINE: Overruling Justice Dept., Judge Clears Path for Long Island Hospital Systems' Merger

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Oct. 23

 BODY:
Over the objections of the Justice Department, a Federal judge has cleared the way for the merger of the Long Island Jewish Medical Center and North Shore Health Systems, hospital officials said tonight.
In a lawsuit filed in June, the Justice Department had charged that the merger would violate antitrust laws, lead to higher hospital rates and inhibit the development of competing hospital systems. 
 Lawyers for the two health care providers told hospital officials that Judge Arthur D. Spatt had informed them late this afternoon that he had ruled against the Justice Department.
"We are awaiting the specific details of his decision, which will be made available to us tomorrow morning," said Richard Klarberg, a spokesman for Long Island Jewish Medical Center. "Until then we can't comment on the decision except to say that our lawyers have told us that we have won."
An aide to Judge Spatt said last night that copies of the decision would be available in the clerk's office at the court house in the morning. The aide declined to comment further.
The merger between the two major Long Island hospital systems would create a health care behemoth with 4,000 beds and annual revenues of more than $2 billion.
The hospitals argued during hearings on the Justice Department's suit that without a merger, they faced a bleak financial future in the rapidly changing world of health care. They said the merger would result in major economies and save consumers $100 million or more each year. Justice Department officials sought to block the directors of the hospitals from proceeding with the merger and are expected to appeal Judge Spatt's ruling. In filing the suit, department officials had said they thought the merger would set a negative precedent. They argued that while they did not oppose the mergers of troubled hospitals, both Long Island Jewish and North Shore were thriving.
The merger had the support of the State Attorney General, Dennis C. Vacco, after he received assurances that it would provide lower costs to health care consumers. On the day the Justice Department filed its antitrust suit, Mr. Vacco said he would not stand in the way of the merger.
Mr. Vacco, whose views were made known to Judge Spatt, said the merged entity would create a health care system that would rival some of the biggest and best Manhattan hospitals and would represent a natural outgrowth of the rapid changes in the health care field.
The merger was also backed by officials of two of the region's largest health care insurers -- Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield and the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York -- whose representatives testified during the hearings.
Justice Department officials could not be reached last night for comment on the judge's ruling.
Both hospitals have signed an agreement with Mr. Vacco, agreeing to return a minimum of $50 million total to the community in the form of new outreach programs. Mr. Klarberg said the hospitals had offered to sign similar agreements with the Justice Department, but the Justice Department had declined.

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE CANDIDATES;
Tough Talk About the Mob and Charges About Its Money

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Seeking to promote his image as an arch-foe of organized crime, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani declared yesterday that his drive to oust the mob from the garbage hauling industry and the Fulton Fish Market had saved companies hundreds of millions of dollars. He vowed that in a second term, he would deploy similar tactics in other sectors of New York City's economy, including the air cargo business at Kennedy International Airport.
Mr. Giuliani's Democratic opponent, Ruth W. Messinger, did not dispute the Mayor's record on organized crime. She tried instead to shift the spotlight to his fund-raising, contending that while he was battling the Mafia, his campaign was accepting thousands of dollars in contributions from people and businesses accused of links to the mob. 
 Both candidates spent the day largely eschewing the glad-handing and baby-kissing of their street campaigning earlier in the week, preferring to give speeches and appeal for votes before interest groups. Ms. Messinger met with clergy at a church in lower Manhattan and then talked to professors and students at New York University before holding a fund-raiser with former Mayor David N. Dinkins.
Mr. Giuliani touted the economic benefits of the New York Marathon in the morning, went to a conference for elderly Hispanic people, held a rally with labor leaders and attended a town hall meeting in Queens.
Last night, both candidates attended festive celebrations of Simhath Torah, the Jewish holiday marking the close of the year-long cycle of Bible readings and the start of a new cycle. Ms. Messinger attended services at her own synagogue, the Society for the Advancement of Judaism, on West 86th Street. Later, she and several members of her campaign staff danced to Hebrew folk music on West End Avenue with hundreds of others, many of them members of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun. Mr. Giuliani went to Forest Hills, Queens, to attend a celebration in Gerald McDonald Park.
In a speech in the early afternoon before two business groups in lower Manhattan, Mr. Giuliani portrayed his fight against organized crime as one of the shining accomplishments of his tenure, saying that before he became Mayor, there had essentially been a "mob tax" in the city -- the difference between the fair market rate and the higher price demanded by the violent cartels that controlled the garbage hauling industry and Fulton Fish Market.
Mr. Giuliani said costs had dropped markedly since his administration and law enforcement agencies like the Manhattan District Attorney's office went after organized crime. For example, he said, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center paid $1.2 million annually for garbage hauling in the early 1990's; now it pays $480,000.
"This is a different kind of city than it used to be," Mr. Giuliani said. "This is now a city in which you can come and do business and the city government will help protect you against criminals instead of sit back and say, 'There is nothing we can do about it.' And isn't that really symbolic of so many of the other changes that we have made in the City of New York?"
The Mayor, a former United States Attorney in Manhattan, also said that he had succeeded in banishing organized crime from the Feast of San Gennaro in Little Italy. And he pledged that if he won a second term, he would attack the mob in the construction and garment industries, as well as at Kennedy Airport. He acknowledged that to battle the mob at the airport would require the cooperation of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Mr. Giuliani has long feuded with the authority and unsuccessfully demanded that it relinquish control of Kennedy and La Guardia airports to the city.
Ms. Messinger, who has repeatedly sought to use the Mayor's fund-raising to depict him as unprincipled, returned to that theme yesterday. Before Mr. Giuliani spoke on organized crime, her aides distributed to reporters a list of thousands of dollars in contributions that the Messinger campaign asserted came from companies or people suspected of mob ties.
The list said the Giuliani campaign had collected separate $1,000 donations from two companies -- Expresso Carting Corporation and Dellvena Carting -- that the Giuliani administration had cited for taking part in the crime cartel that controlled the garbage-hauling industry.
The Messinger campaign said Mr. Giuliani's current and 1993 campaigns had accepted a total of $17,900 from Pile Foundation Construction and its workers. In 1985, in a case brought by Mr. Giuliani when he was United States Attorney, the president of Pile testified that he had bribed a mobster to win a contract, the Messinger campaign said.
"Before he worries about getting mob influence out of the economy of this city," Ms. Messinger said, "he should return the campaign contributions that he has received from people who have been convicted as criminals, who are connected to organized crime."
Asked about Ms. Messinger's charges, Mr. Giuliani replied: "We have returned the money that we felt could create the wrong questions. And we didn't return the money in situations where people would be unfairly accused."
He later added: "The way in which people are playing with reputations is kind of like McCarthyite."
Besides lambasting Mr. Giuliani's fund-raising, Ms. Messinger and her aides also criticized a flier that the Giuliani campaign distributed that refers to her as "anti-police -- pro-criminal." The flier accused Ms. Messinger of helping to "incite two days of riots" in Washington Heights in 1992 by joining a march to protest the slaying of a suspect by the police. The Messinger campaign called the flier inflammatory and untrue. The Giuliani campaign stood by it.
Throughout the day, Ms. Messinger discussed the Mayor's budget cuts, comparing him to Ebenezer Scrooge and Marie Antoinette.
"The number of people looking for shelter has grown," she said, "the number of people looking for a meal for themselves and for their children has grown."
The races for the other two citywide offices, public advocate and comptroller, have been quiet in recent weeks, and it appears that they may attract even less attention in the coming days. The Campaign Finance Board had scheduled debates next week in the two contests, but it will now probably cancel at least the one for public advocate because only the Democratic incumbent, Mark Green, has qualified.
To take part, candidates have to reach at least 15 percent in one of two polls. But Mr. Green's Republican-Liberal challenger, Assemblyman Jules Polonetsky, did not hit that threshold, officials said. It is still unclear whether the Republican candidate for comptroller, Annemarie McAvoy, got enough support in the polls to qualify to debate the Democratic incumbent, Alan G. Hevesi.
